title: Ambase Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago quarter and full year results are restated in accordance with SFAS No. 97. Latest quarter and year included benefits of $3 million, or 9 cents a share, and $9 million, or 27 cents a share, respectively, from the ''fresh start'' provision of the Reform Act of 1986. Year-ago quarter and full year results included benefits of $2 million, or 5 cents a share, and $11 million, 31 cents a share, respectively, attributable to ''fresh start''.

title: An Apparent Test for Cancer Relapse
description: A protein secreted by tumor cells can indicate whether women will have a recurrence of breast cancer, researchers report.

title: Currents;   Decorating the Outdoors As If It Were Indoors
description: THE craze for gardening has gone beyond plants and shrubs. Now garden furniture, ornaments and objects are as sought-after as rare hybrid roses, especially in summer communities like the Hamptons.

title: St. Paul Journal;   He Says Populist but Foes Say Pasha
description: While other states grapple with crime or drugs or unemployment, the Minnesota gubernatorial race this year may hinge on one question: Is Gov. Rudy Perpich an arrogant autocrat who lives in a Middle Western Taj Mahal or an offbeat populist who carries his own luggage?

title: Kurt Appelbaum, Pianist, 84
description: Kurt Appelbaum, a pianist and teacher, died of a heart attack on Monday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Chiat/Day Calls It Quits With Reebok
description: CHIAT/DAY/MOJO resigned the $70 million domestic advertising and promotions account of Reebok International yesterday after the nation's second-largest athletic shoe manufacturer decided to place the highly visible account into a competitive review.

title: Home Improvement
description: WHEN a circuit breaker governing a household electrical circuit trips or a fuse blows, power to the circuit is immediately shut off to reduce the chance of fire and injury from electric shock. Restoring power by resetting the breaker or replacing the fuse is usually simple. But care must be taken to proceed safely, and only after the cause of the circuit's malfunction has been corrected.

title: Close to Home
description: A FRIEND and I are sitting together at a wedding reception. The bride and groom - she in lavender, he in navy blue - are on the dance floor, and the band is playing ''The Yellow Rose of Texas.''

title: Soviet Computer People Attend U.S. Convention
description: At a decidedly capitalist gathering at a resort here in the desert, eight people in the personal computer industry in the Soviet Union met informally this week with their American counterparts.

title: Upheaval in the East: U.S. Policy;   BUSH CALLS ON SOVIETS TO JOIN IN DEEP TROOP CUTS FOR EUROPE AS GERMANS SEE PATH TO UNITY
description: In his first State of the Union address, President Bush tonight proposed sharp new reductions in the number of Soviet and United States troops in Europe. He said the cuts had been made feasible by the rapid collapse of the Soviet empire.

title: Reebok International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Taking the Opportunity To Play Hide-and-Seek
description: For the White House, the State of the Union Message was just another golden opportunity to play hide-and-seek.

title: A Computer Model Suggests Gravity Shaped the Universe
description: In the largest computer simulation of the cosmos ever attempted, scientists at Princeton University have addressed the most perplexing question of the moment in cosmology: How did the universe evolve from an initially smooth state to the dense clusters of galaxies that stretch across the heavens today?

title: O'Connor: 'The Real Issue'
description: Following is an excerpt from John Cardinal O'Connor's column in Catholic New York yesterday commenting on Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's stance on abortion:

title: Stakeout for News Gluttons
description: Detectives staked out a newspaper box and arrested three people for taking more copies than they paid for, the authorities said today. The stakeout on Tuesday was requested by The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette because of an increase in complaints of thefts. Each of the three people arrested was offered a choice of being charged with retail theft or enrolling in a $50 course on the evils of shoplifting. All three enrolled.

title: 'Seven Deadly Sins' Postponed in Brooklyn
description: A production of the Kurt Weill and Bertolt Brecht choral ballet ''Seven Deadly Sins,'' featuring the soprano Teresa Stratas, has been postponed from its scheduled April opening at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Cloth Diapers, Brought to Your Door
description: ''THE past year has been a boon for diaper services,'' said John A. Shiffert, the executive director of the National Association of Diaper Services, a trade group based in Philadelphia. Why? ''Because disposable diapers are a symbol of the solid-waste crisis,'' Mr. Shiffert said. ''Cotton diapers are the original curbside recyclables.''

title: Heart Group Begins Food Labeling Amid Outcry
description: A national campaign intended to help consumers make their way through the maze of conflicting nutrition and health claims for food officially opens today. But many health and nutrition experts predict that the American Heart Association's Heartguide program will further confuse consumers.

title: Transcript of Bush's State of the Union Message to the Nation
description: Following is the transcript of President Bush's State of the Union Message to a joint session of Congress last night, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Talks, Seminars, Tours: Gardens to Bookbinding
description: Across Cultures and Time, Cooper-Hewitt Museum, 2 East 91st Street; 212-860-6871.

title: Bass Group Makes an Offer For St. Petersburg Times
description: A group that includes Robert M. Bass, the Texas financier, has offered $270 million to acquire control of The St. Petersburg Times in Florida.

title: Dow Chemical Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $12,000,000.

title: Profits Fall At 2 Steel Companies
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second-largest steel producer, and Armco Inc. the fifth-largest, reported lower earnings yesterday, reflecting softer demand for steel products and higher operating costs, the companies said.

title: U.S. Racketeering Suit To Focus on Dock Union
description: Justice Department lawyers in New York are preparing a civil racketeering suit asserting that some locals of the International Longhoreman's Association are controlled by corrupt leaders, officials said yesterday.

title: Top New Jersey Court Broadens Meaning of 'Family' to Students
description: In the latest in a series of decisions that allows the term ''family'' to be applied to a variety of groups for zoning purposes, the New Jersey Supreme Court has upheld the right of 10 Glassboro State College students to occupy a single-family house over the objections of local officials.

title: Now New York Mass Transit Practices Height Discrimination;   Resist Fare Zones
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Free-Agency Test Awaits Steinberg
description: This time, Dick Steinberg promises, the Jets are prepared for Plan B since the future of the club is not tied to the 37 men the team had on the list of protected players it submitted yesterday to the National Football League.

title: Parent & Child
description: AN 11-year-old girl taunted her 8-year-old sister as they climbed the stairs in a bookstore. ''I hate you!'' she yelled. ''I can't stand being with you! I just hate you!''

title: Ex-Navajo Leader Is Facing 3 Criminal Trials
description: A Navajo tribal judge today ordered Peter MacDonald Sr., the suspended Navajo chairman, to face three criminal trials instead of a single trial on 107 criminal counts.

title: Prices Paid To Farmers Increase 2.7%
description: Prices that farmers get for raw products rose 2.7 percent from December to January, leaving the monthly average 2.7 percent above the level a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Soccer Federation's Goals Are Just That
description: LEAD: Real Madrid never had any trouble scoring goals when the legendary Argentine, Alfredo Di Stefano, led the team to its greatest triumphs in the late 1950's. Usually it was Di Stefano himself who put the ball into the net, but his passion for scoring was infectious, and there always seemed to be goals for his teammates, too.

title: Millard to Play in Bowl
description: Paul Tagliabue, the commissioner of the National Football League, said yesterday that he would permit Keith Millard of the Minnesota Vikings to play on Sunday in the Pro Bowl in Hawaii, but that he would then meet sometime after the game in his league office with the tackle, who was recently selected as the league's defensive player of 1989.

title: Buyout Bid Accepted By Aristech Chemical
description: Directors of the Aristech Chemical Corporation accepted a sweetened offer today of $27 a share, or about $877 million, from a group led by the company's management and financed by the giant Mitsubishi Corporation of Japan.

title: English Ballet Dismisses Its Director
description: Peter Schaufuss, the Danish artistic director of the English National Ballet, was dismissed Tuesday because of ''irreconcilable differences'' between him and the company's board.

title: Atlanta Trial Focusing on Color-Bias Charge
description: A light-skinned black woman who contends she was dismissed as a clerk-typist because of her color said her darker-skinned supervisor told her that her life was too easy, the plaintiff's lawyer said in opening arguments Tuesday in the woman's discrimination suit in Federal District Court.

title: Charges Seen For Developer
description: The General Development Corporation, a real estate developer based in Miami, disclosed today that the company, its mortgage banking subsidiary and members of its senior management are facing possible criminal indictments.

title: Abortion Foes Gain in Wisconsin Assembly Vote
description: One chamber of Wisconsin's Legislature approved a bill early today requiring minors to get parental consent before having abortions and defeated an effort to repeal a law that penalizes doctors who perform abortions.

title: Stop Destroying Files, Poland Says to Police
description: The Government ordered police and security officers today to halt any destruction of files and other official records.

title: Metro Matters;   From Rohatyn, Unlikely Praise For New Mayor
description: David N. Dinkins was Felix G. Rohatyn's second, maybe third, choice last year to be mayor of New York City. Now Mr. Rohatyn pays Mayor Dinkins what appears to be the ultimate compliment.

title: Immigration Policy Sends Blacks Back to South
description: To the Editor:

title: Inco Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included gain of $60.7 million on the sale of a 30 percent equity interest in Shimura Kako Co. for the quarter and year. c-Included gain of $44.2 million from sale of a 20 percent interest in P.T. International Nickel Indonesia. The company said tax loss carryforwards resulted in a special gain of $11.2 million in latest fourth quarter and $56.5 million in latest year. In year-ago periods, there was a special gain of $16.8 million in quarter and $44.6 million for the year. Results are in U.S. dollars.

title: Leading Indicators Climb 0.8%
description: The Government's most widely followed economic forecasting gauge rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in December, the biggest gain since April, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Money-Fund Yields Stable
description: Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were unchanged for the week that ended yesterday.

title: Why Gorbachev Might Quit
description: LEAD: Western journalists in Moscow are reporting rumors that Mikhail Gorbachev may resign as General Secretary of the Communist Party at next week's Central Committee meeting. They add that, while he would leave his post as party leader, he would retain that of chairman of the Supreme Soviet - or President.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Larger Glory of 'Glory';   Soldiers, and Children, Fulfill Expectations
description: Here's some unsolicited advice for New York City's Schools Chancellor, Joseph Fernandez: Make ''Glory,'' the new movie about the first black unit to see combat in the Civil War, required viewing for all students and teachers.

title: Love's Redeeming Value in a Random Universe
description: All is paradox as usual in Iris Murdoch's bewitching new book, ''The Message to the Planet,'' the 24th novel by the Oxford University philosophy teacher whose career as a fiction writer now spans more than 35 years. <TD WIDTH=2

title: Suffragist's Birthplace Is Bought
description: The Alice Paul Centennial Foundation has completed the purchase of Miss Paul's birthplace here, said a spokeswoman for the foundation, Janet Tegley.

title: Liggett Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Seoul Officials See Accord on U.S. Troop Cut
description: Senior Government officials said today that they ''fully expect'' to reach an agreement with the United States this year for the largest withdrawal of American military personnel from South Korea since the end of the Vietnam War.

title: U.S. Spells Out Shifts in Foreign Aid
description: The Bush Administration told Congress today how it will distribute nearly $8 billion in United States foreign aid this year. In an indication of its shifting global priorities, the Administration plans a dramatic increase in aid to Poland and a sharp decrease in assistance to most of Central America, including El Salvador.

title: Grosvenor Dana, Executive, 88
description: Grosvenor Dana, a retired shipping executive, died of injuries sustained last Thursday when he was struck by a hit-and-run driver near his home in Mount Vernon, N.Y. He died on Sunday at Mount Vernon Hospital at the age of 88.

title: Currents;   The Chinese Way to a Healthy Home
description: ''JUST as the 80's were the era of Postmodernism and Deconstructivism, the 90's will deal with humanism, common sense and mysticism,'' said Sarah Rossbach, a writer and expert on feng shui, the ancient Chinese study of form and placement. ''Now more people than ever are interested in learning ways to create a healthy living environment.''

title: Mapco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Upheaval in the East: The Germans;   West Germans Assert Gorbachev Has Cleared Way to Reunification
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's recognition that pressure is growing for German reunification was seized upon in West Germany today as the lifting of the last major obstacle to unity.

title: Trees That Droop, Ever So Sculpturally
description: THE 150-year-old weeping Camperdown elm in Prospect Park in Brooklyn stands a mere 12 feet high, but its intricate pattern of branches etches a 25-foot circle.

title: 2 Ex-Mexican Aides Charged in Slaying Of U.S. Drug Agent
description: The Justice Department announced today that for the first time the United States had charged former high-ranking officials in Mexico with the 1985 kidnapping, torture and killing of a Drug Enforcement Administration agent.

title: Civil Rights Slayings of '64 The Subject of a TV Movie
description: David Wolper, the executive producer of ''Murder in Mississippi,'' a new television movie that NBC will broadcast on Monday at 9 P.M., insists that his film is ''completely different'' from ''Mississippi Burning,'' the 1988 film about the murder of three civil rights workers 26 years ago. '' 'Mississippi Burning' begins where our story ends,'' Mr. Wolper says.

title: A Strategist at American Express
description: Harvey Golub, the chairman and chief executive of IDS Financial Services Inc., the American Express Company's highly successful financial-planning division, will be a key adviser to Howard L. Clark Jr., the newly appointed head of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.

title: Philippines Don't Need Special Powers Chief
description: To the Editor:

title: Xerox Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge of $244 million related to restructuring costs. c-Net loss

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday on a children's opera about crack at the Symphony Space in Manhattan referred incorrectly to Lizandra De La Cruz, the student on whose play the show is based. She attends the PACE Academy for Gifted Students at Junior High School 118 in the East Tremont section of the Bronx.

title: In Oakland, Spaces Tailored To Life and Art
description: WHEN Bruce Beasley moved to Lewis Street here in 1963, there were no sidewalks, no street lights and no trees. But like any resourceful pioneer, he rallied his neighbors and soon persuaded the city to supply those amenities.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Last of the Old Guard Quits as Czech Premier
description: Deputy Prime Minister Frantisek Pitra, the last of the old guard Communist leaders left in power after Czechoslovakia's peaceful revolution, resigned today as leader of the Czech republic, the official press agency said.

title: Events: Modern Ceramics And Ancient Featherwork
description: Double Exposure, Javits Center Gallery, lobby of 26 Federal Plaza, off Worth Street; 212-735-9731.

title: Environmental Groups Told They Are Racists in Hiring
description: Several members of civil rights and minority groups have written to eight major national environmental organizations charging them with racism in their hiring practices.

title: Acted to Protect His Son, 3, Says Man in Subway Killing
description: Surrounded by his lawyers, a plumber accused of fatally beating a homeless man on a subway platform after the man attacked him said yesterday that he regretted the man's death but that he had acted to protect his 3-year-old son, who was with him at the time.

title: Florida Star to Go Pro
description: College football lost another marquee name yesterday when Emmitt Smith of Florida gave up his eligibility for an ''opportunity of a lifetime'' in the N.F.L. The risk of injury as well as the prospect of a wage scale for rookies in 1991 were factors in the all-America tailback's emotional decision to leave a program under investigation by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: Bank in Northeast Sells Leasing Unit
description: The Bank of New England Corporation, scrambling for cash because of large losses from bad real estate loans, announced it had completed the sale of a vehicle-leasing business for $350 million. The bank sold the United States portion of McCullagh Leasing to GE Capital, a unit of the General Electric Company. The business leases car and truck fleets in the United States and Canada, and the banking company said it expected to complete the sale of the Canadian portion next week for around $100 million.

title: Namibian Assembly Sets a Date for Independence
description: Namibia's constituent assembly today formally approved March 21 as the date for the territory's long-awaited independence from South Africa.

title: Upheaval in the East: Soviet Union;   GORBACHEV DENIES PLAN TO QUIT POST
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today denied a report that he was considering resigning as Communist Party leader, saying it was the sort of ''groundless'' invention that typically precedes important party meetings like a critical one scheduled for next week on the party's future.

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL

title: Harlem Troupe's Dancers Being Laid Off Over Deficit
description: Dance Theater of Harlem announced yesterday that it would lay off its dancers, technical staff and some of its administrators as of March 25, the closing date of its winter season at Kennedy Center. The company has canceled a two-week spring season at City Center and will not conduct the annual summer session at its school in Harlem. Arthur Mitchell, artistic director of the company, said Dance Theater expects to resume full operations in the fall, with a New York season in 1991.

title: Words of a Soldier Who Died in Panama
description: Pvt. James Markwell, the 20-year-old Army medic whom President Bush praised in his State of the Union message last night, was among the first of the 23 American servicemen who were killed in the invasion of Panama.

title: F. W. Winterbotham, British Code Expert, 92
description: Group Capt. F. W. Winterbotham, who played a key role in exploiting broken German codes in World War II and wrote the best-selling memoir ''The Ultra Secret,'' died on Sunday, British news reports said today. He was 92 years old.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: The aromas of freshly baked bread, the air after a spring rain or a rose by any other name are lost to millions of Americans who have a muted or absent sense of smell.

title: Puzzle at Running Back for Giants
description: Joe Morris and Ottis Anderson may have played their last games as Giants. So, too, may have Zeke Mowatt, Damian Johnson, Terry Kinard, Johnie Cooks and Raul Allegre.

title: Midway Rebuffs Ampco-Pittsburgh
description: The Ampco-Pittsburgh Corporation, a Pittsburgh-based manufacturer of rolled metal, said Midway Airlines Inc. had rejected its request for a seat on the Chicago-based airline's board. Ampco-Pittsburgh, which holds 9.6 percent of Midway's shares outstanding, reported the rejection in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

title: Southeast Banking Offers Securities
description: The Southeast Banking Corporation of Miami is offering $300 million of asset-backed securities due in 1994 through Southeast Bank Credit Card Trust 1990-A.

title: Irving A. Isaacs, Lawyer, 86
description: Irving A. Isaacs, a lawyer and former bank official, died on Monday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: A Lacquer Finish With Regular Enamel
description: LEAD: Unfinished furniture is hardly new. Much mail-order pine-frame furniture was sold unfinished in the 19th century.

title: E.W. Scripps Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included net gain of $2,300,000, or 3 cents a share, on sale of investment in American City Business Journals. c-Included net loss of $1,800,000 on sale of the Hollywood, Fla., Sun-Tattler for both periods, and the year also included income of $2,600,000, or 3 cents a share, from gain on sale of certain properties then 21-percent owned by American City Business Journals.

title: Bridge
description: One of America's leading players, Nancy Gruver of Ellicott, City, Md., died on Sunday at the age of 78. In a distinguished career, she won 14 national titles and came close to world titles three times.

title: Samuel C. Phillips, Who Directed Apollo Lunar Landing, Dies at 68
description: Samuel Cochran Phillips, an Air Force lieutenant general who directed the Apollo space program through the lunar landing in 1969, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Palos Verdes Estates, Calif. He was 68 years old.

title: CHRONICLE
description: SIR GEORG SOLTI has commissioned four new works for his 22d, and final, season with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, which will also be the orchestra's 100th.

title: Multimedia Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an after-tax gain of about $2 million from the sale of WZTV Channel 17 in Nashville and Multimedia Entertainment of Tennessee.

title: Maxus Energy Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $70 million from the cumulative effect on prior periods of an accounting change.

title: Group Drops Bid For Stride Rite
description: A group of investors scrapped a $900 million takeover bid for the Stride Rite Corporation but refused to rule out another offer for the shoe company. ''We are meeting to discuss all options,'' said Stephen Walsh, managing partner of Walsh, Greenwood & Company, the Greenwich, Conn., investment concern that led the takeover effort.

title: Reagan Depicted by Poindexter as Guiding Contra Aid Efforts
description: John M. Poindexter's effort to force former President Ronald Reagan to relinquish his private diaries underscores how the prosecution of the former national security adviser has challenged the image of Mr. Reagan as a passive figure in the Iran-contra affair.

title: Local School Districts Will Resist Fernandez on Vetoing Job Offers
description: Local school boards in New York City will resist any attempt by Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez to veto candidates for local superintendent, a spokesman for the boards said yesterday, even as the Chancellor issued guidelines for the selection process.

title: Currents;   A Glass Exchange
description: MORE than five years ago, Dwight P. Lanmon, the director of the Corning Museum of Glass in Corning, N.Y., approached the Soviet ministry of culture about organizing an exhibition of Russian glass in the United States.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Moscow McDonald's Opens: Milkshakes and Human Kindness (Reuters)
description: Connoisseurs of fast food and human behavior were doubly satiated today as anxious crowds of Soviet customers engaged in traditional pushing and shoving to place ''Beeg Mek'' orders at the nation's first McDonald's restaurant, only to be calmed by uniformed compatriots dictating that they have a nice day.

title: Knicks' Cold Streak In Boston Continues
description: Larry Bird and Robert Parish would not allow the Knicks' Boston Garden losing streak to end tonight. Bird helped extend the streak to 23 games, 17 in regular-season play, by scoring the final 6 points in the Celtics' 97-91 victory.

title: Thomas Blakeman, 80, Metropolitan Planner
description: Thomas Ledyard Blakeman, one of the early metropolitan regional planners in this country, died of lung cancer on Wednesday at his home in Cataumet, Mass. He was 80 years old.

title: People
description: * Peter Levitan and Joseph McCarthy have been promoted to management directors at Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising, and have been named to the agency's operating committee.

title: Policy Shift On Bailouts Is Explored
description: The chairman of the agency created to manage the bailout of the savings industry said today that the number of ailing institutions had soared to such an extent that the Government should consider keeping some of them open rather than taking them over.

title: Georgia Gulf To Get NL Bid
description: NL Industries, the Houston-based commodity chemical maker that has been seeking to maximize the value of its investment in the Georgia Gulf Corporation, announced today that it intends to make a $45-a-share cash tender offer for the Atlanta-based chemical company by next Wednesday.

title: Wm. Wrigley Jr.  Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $3.2 million, or 8 cents a share, gain from settlement of a U.S. income tax case.

title: Upheaval in the East: Yugoslavia;   3 More Ethnic Albanians Reported Slain in Southern Province
description: Three ethnic Albanians were reported killed today in Kosovo, bringing the total to at least 16 since riots began last week in the poor southern province adjacent to Albania.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Troop Proposal an Effort to Catch Up With Changes in Europe
description: By the Administration's account, President Bush's new proposal for deeper troop cuts in Europe was dictated by the mounting desire of the leaders of Eastern Europe for the withdrawal of Soviet troops.

title: Search Unit Is Sold by Peat
description: KPMG Peat Marwick, the world's largest accounting firm, announced yesterday that it had sold its executive search operation to the unit's management.

title: INSIDE
description: Longest Trial Over, A Retrial Is Scheduled

title: Armco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $45,000,000. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $8,800,000 and $28,800,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, which included a gain a gain on sale of the aerospace segment of $15.2 million in both the fourth quarter and year, and net loss of AFSG Runoff Companies of $24 million in the fourth quarter and $44 million for the year, and the year included an extraordinary credit of $44,100,000, or 50 cents a share, which included gain on early retirement of debt of $6.7 million and a cumulative effect of changes in accounting principles of $37.4 million. The company said unusual items in the latest fourth quarter included a $3.3 million charge for work force reductions at the Kansas City, Mo., plant and a $2.9 million reduction of the previously recorded gain on the sale of 40 percent of the Eastern Steel division. The decrease in sales was primarily attributable to Armco no longer including the operating results of its Eastern Steel division, which became Armco Steel Co. L.P., a joint venture formed earlier this year with Kawasaki Steel Corp. The company also said net income for 1989 included a number of unusual items which increased income by a net of $35.7 million. They were: a gain on the sale of 40 percent of the Eastern Steel division of $109.4 million; a favorable ruling on certain export commitments of $15 million; and provisions of $40.4 million for corporate restructuring, $45 million for the Runoff insurance operations and $3.3 million for work force reductions. Net income for 1988 included a net charge of $26.7 million for unusual items.

title: Lyrics and the Law
description: Tommy Hammond is the proprietor of a record shop called Taking Home the Hits in Alexander City, Ala. Unlike some Americans, he doesn't want to be a censor telling others ''what they can or can't listen to,'' because he believes ''music is up to the person who's listening to it.''

title: Weis Markets reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: Latest quarter represents a 13-week period, compared with 14 weeks in the year-earler period.

title: Alexander Schiff, 90; Was Ringside Doctor
description: Dr. Alexander Schiff, a longtime physician for the New York State Athletic Commission and president of the Actors' Temple, died Monday at the White Plains Hospital. He was 90 years old.

title: Record Industry Bargaining With the Musicians' Union
description: The musicians' union and representatives of the North American record industry are negotiating the contract that will govern payments to the union on commercial recordings. The current contract, which dates from 1986, expired yesterday and covers recording of all kinds, from opera to rock-and-roll.

title: 5 Killed and 105 Wounded In Car-Bomb Blast in Kabul
description: Five people were killed and 105 wounded when a car bomb exploded in the center of Kabul today, a Government spokesman said.

title: Take Some Junk, Let It Rust, Then Bring It Home
description: THE age of the anti-antique is here.

title: No Big Oil Walkout, but Maybe Small Ones
description: Leaders of unionized workers at oil refineries and petrochemical plants decided against a nationwide strike yesterday but threatened to halt work at selected companies as a way to increase pressure on management.

title: Troops to Leave Panama in February
description: President Bush announced tonight that the troops sent to Panama in the invasion last month would be brought back to the United States ''well before the end of February.''

title: Reviews/Television;   How Alzheimer's Affects A Patient's Family, Too
description: Tonight's affecting episode of ''48 Hours'' confirms that the sufferers from Alzheimer's disease include not only those whom it strikes but, very directly, their wives, husbands and children as well. Some four million Americans now have the disease, which, as Dan Rather says, has ''no known cause, no known cure,'' and the number may go up to 14 million in the next 50 years.

title: Hungary Can Take No Pride in Nazi Past
description: To the Editor:

title: Arnaud d'Usseau, 73, Playwright, Screenplay Writer and Instructor
description: Arnaud d'Usseau, a playwright and screenplay writer, died of complications after surgery for stomach cancer on Monday at his Manhattan home. He was 73 years old.

title: Purdue Stuns Michigan On Wolverines' Court
description: With Tony Jones leading the way, Purdue put a vise-like grip on the Big Ten race tonight.

title: General Dynamics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dinkins to Delay Most Police Hiring Till '91, Aides Say
description: Conceding that New York City will not be able to hire enough police officers to reach its goal of having 28,054 officers on the force by June, the Dinkins administration will propose today to postpone that target until June 1991, city officials said yesterday.

title: Tax Changes Are Opposed
description: Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said today that he was not convinced that the Federal tax system is in need of any major change.

title: Man Faces New Trial in Molest Case
description: Two weeks after a jury acquitted him of most charges of child molesting in the longest criminal trial in American history, Raymond Buckey learned today that he had to stand trial again.

title: Neighborhood Effort Planned to Aid Census
description: New York City officials plan to encourage participation in the 1990 census by recruiting neighbors to assist in overcoming language differences, fear of government and other problems that have worked against an accurate count in the past.

title: Hollinger Stake In Paper Chain
description: The chief executive of Hollinger Inc. said Tuesday that the Canadian newspaper chain wanted to continue raising its stake in United Newspapers P.L.C. but was not planning a hostile takeover bid for the giant British publisher.

title: Xerox Has a $212 Million Profit in Period
description: The Xerox Corporation yesterday reported fourth-quarter earnings of $212 million, or $2.01 a share, in contrast to a loss of $77 million in the fourth quarter of 1988. That loss was largely because of a one-time restructuring charge.

title: Shearson's New Era Under a Button-Down Chief
description: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., which was assembled by a succession of brash, savvy leaders into the nation's second-largest brokerage, began a new era yesterday as a top executive from the American Express Company took the corporate reins.

title: Honduran Freighter Is Seized After Load Of Cocaine Is Found
description: The eight-member crew of a Honduran freighter was detained Tuesday after Federal agents seized 1,100 pounds of cocaine found aboard the ship about 400 miles southwest of Miami, officials said.

title: Apple's Chief Details Plans
description: The chairman and chief executive of Apple Computer Inc. said today that the company would develop new products and get them on the market faster in an effort to increase slow sales in the United States.

title: Bush's Plans for Troop Cuts Are Praised on Capitol Hill
description: President Bush's proposal for further troop reductions in Europe won bipartisan praise on Capitol Hill tonight, kindling new hope among even his harshest Democratic critics for deeper cuts in the military budget.

title: Reviews/Television;   '27 Wagons Full of Cotton,' Tennessee Williams Drama
description: The Arts & Entertainment Network seems a bit nervous about ''27 Wagons Full of Cotton,'' the Tennessee Williams play that concludes (tonight at 9) the first batch of monthly one-acters being presented on the new ''American Playwrights Theater.'' Although the first to be produced for the series, this play is the last of four to be shown. Anthony Quinn, the series host, warns that its depiction of a brutal seduction is not family entertainment. But it is Tennessee Williams, and even early, awkward Williams is serious and powerful. If you want soft-core porn, tune into the daytime soaps.

title: Panhandlers Inspire Gifts For Neediest
description: While New Yorkers have become accustomed to beggars, if not accepting of them, visitors to the city may be surprised when panhandlers approach.

title: Mirza Abdul Beg, 55, A Professor of Physics
description: Mirza Abdul Baqi Beg, a professor of physics at Rockefeller University who helped verify that elementary particles like protons and neutrons are made up of smaller entities known as quarks, died of a heart attack on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 55 years old.

title: Excerpts From Foley Address on the Reaction of Democrats
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of a speech by Thomas S. Foley, Speaker of the House, last night on the State of the Union, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: India Says Pakistan Is Stirring Up Kashmir Unrest
description: In its strongest criticism of Pakistan in recent years, India accused Islamabad tonight of ''direct incitement to subversion, violence and terrorism'' in the disputed Jammu and Kashmir state.

title: Ex-Guam Governor Kills Himself On Eve of Jailing for Corruption
description: A former Governor of Guam who was facing the start of a four-year prison term in California in a corruption case shot himself to death today.

title: College Panel at Work
description: With an ambitous agenda aimed at curbing the excesses of prominent college athletic programs, the Knight Foundation Commission on Intercollegiate Athletics held its first meeting here today.

title: Panhandle Eastern Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $11,125,000 and an extraordinary loss of $29,206,000 from early retirement of debt, both are for the quarter and year. c-Net loss and included an extraordinary credit of $14,820,000, or 26 cents a share, for both periods from an accounting change. Both periods' losses from continuing operations included a $51.3 million after-tax reserve for a possible customer refund. The company said operations of Texas Eastern Corp. are included from April 27, 1989, except for capital expenditures which are included from Jan. 1, 1989. Latest fourth-quarter results included Texas Eastern's operating income of $90.4 million. Eight months of Texas Eastern's operating income amounted to $249.1 million in 1989. However, financial results suffered the negative effects of interest expense incurred in the Texas Eastern acquisition. Although not included in company 1988 results, for comparative purposes, Texas Eastern's restated operating income for the fourth quarter of 1988 was $69.3 million.

title: Philip Morris Cos. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included provision for income taxes and 1988 cumulative effect of adopting SFAS 96 of $2,112,000 and $1,390,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively. Share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect the 4-for-1 stock split distributed on Oct. 10, 1989 to stockholders of record on Sept. 15, 1989. Effective Jan. 1, 1988, the company adopted the provisions of SFAS No. 96, accounting for income taxes, and changed its method of computing deferred income taxes from the deferred method used in prior years. SFAS 96 increased 1988 net earnings and share earnings by $213 million and 23 cents, respectively. Kraft Inc. became a wholly-owned subsidiary on Dec. 7, 1988. Accordingly, consolidated results of the company included the operating results of Kraft for the full year 1989 and the 1988 period after acquisition. In 1989 General Foods Corp. was combined with Kraft to form Kraft General Foods Inc. The company charged $179 million against pretax income, which was primarily for costs of this merger. In addition, the company sold its equity investment in Rothmans International Plc for 610 million pounds of 10 1/4-percent notes maturing in 1994, generating a pretax gain of $455 million. These notes were subsequently sold with recourse for approximately $850 million. The net impact of these items was an increase in earnings before income taxes, net earnings and earnings per share of $276 million, $152 million and 16 cents, respectively. During the fourth quarter of 1988, the company provided for restructuring costs at General Foods Corp., which reduced pretax earnings, net earnings and earnings per share by $348 million, $212 million and 23 cents, respectively.

title: School Graft: One Man's Abuse of Power
description: On Nov. 18, 1988, friends of Curtis H. Johnson, then president of Community School Board 9 in the Bronx, gave a fund-raising party for him at the elegant Terrace on the Park in Queens. The theme was a ''Celebration of Educational Excellence.''

title: Juvenile Champions Assigned Topweight
description: The Jockey Club's handicappers today agreed with the recent Eclipse Award balloting for juvenile champions by rating Rhythm the top colt and Go for Wand the top filly on their Experimental Handicap of last year's 2-year-olds.

title: Books of The Times;   Love's Redeeming Value in a Random Universe
description: The Message to the Planet

title: Where Design Meets Ecology
description: If the 90's are partly to be known as a time when people became more conscious of the environment, then there is a magazine for the decade, Design Spirit.

title: M.T.A. Appealing U.S. Judge's Ruling On Subway Begging
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday sought to restore its rule against panhandling in the subways, appealing a Federal Judge's ruling that the ban was unconstitutional.

title: Treasury Prices Move Up Again
description: Prices of Treasury securities moved higher for the second straight session yesterday, as bargain-hunters bought securities that had been battered over the last six weeks. Gains of as much as a full point, or $10 for each $1,000 face amount of securities, were recorded.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PRINCE CHARLES will lead a meeting of international corporate leaders Feb. 20 and 21 in Charleston, S.C. More than 100 chairmen and chief executive officers of companies in the United States, Europe and Japan are expected to attend.

title: Jets Talk to 49er Aide
description: The prolonged search for the Jets' next head coach went through its final step yesterday.

title: Malbin Collection of Modern Art to Be Sold
description: Lydia Winston Malbin's collection of 20th-century art by Fernand Leger, Joan Miro, Constantin Brancusi, Jackson Pollock, Umberto Boccioni, Giacomo Balla and Gino Severini is to be auctioned in May at Sotheby's. The 127 works are valued by the auction house at $65 million to $85 million.

title: Federated Considers Taking Bloomingdale's Off the Block
description: For the first time since it put Bloomingdale's up for sale in September, Federated Stores Inc. said yesterday that it might not sell the 17-store chain.

title: South Africa Appoints Judicial Inquiry in Death of Black Close to Mandelas
description: With millions of South Africans expecting an announcement this week that Nelson R. Mandela is to be freed, the country was shaken today by an official statement saying that a 20-year-old black man who is the father of a Mandela grandchild had died in detention at police headquarters in Johannesburg.

title: Where Money Talks, New Columbia Heads Are Fairly Shouting
description: In their first months as co-chairmen of Columbia Pictures Entertainment, Peter Guber and Jon Peters have raised the ante in one of Hollywood's biggest poker games - the betting of millions of dollars today on scripts that may or may not be tomorrow's hit movies.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sunday about skaters at the Wollman rink in Manhattan misstated the location of the buildings at the rear. They were on Central Park South, not Central Park West.

title: Cardinal Defends a Jailed Bishop Who Warned Cuomo on Abortion
description: John Cardinal O'Connor yesterday strongly defended the Bishop who last week said that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo was ''in serious risk of going to hell'' for his support of abortion rights. The Bishop's views, the Cardinal said, are consistent with church teaching.

title: Mr. Bush's Piggy Bank
description: President Bush's budget dramatizes the sorry rate of savings in America. With admirable candor, he concedes that the Federal deficit is responsible for most of the slack. But he has no real remedy -only another year of nibbling at spending, and a pallid package of tax breaks for savers.

title: Seagate Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Results for the second quarter and first half ended Dec. 31, 1989, included Imprimis Technology from its date of acquisition on Oct. 29, 1989.

title: 'Roger and Me': Documentary? Satire? Or Both?
description: The first among the many questions that could be raised these days about Michael Moore's ''Roger and Me'' is this: Why has this low-budget muckraking documentary, with no box-office stars, no glamour and none of the content that normally draws the moviegoing public, achieved such popularity and profitability?

title: Generic Drugs Recalled After Questions on Data
description: The Bolar Pharmaceutical Company, a generic drug maker, announced today that it was recalling its version of a drug widely used to treat high blood pressure. The company had been resisting the action for months.

title: Commodore International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Settlement in Abbott Case
description: Richard W. Dutrisac, a former director of Pancretec Inc. today settled a Federal civil accusation that he had passed information about merger negotiations between Pancretec and Abbott Laboratories to a close friend in January 1989.

title: Alco Standard Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $57,325,000, or $1.19 a share, because the company sold its ownership in Alco Health Services Corp.

title: Bethlehem Steel reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $15 million in LIFO inventory liquidation credits for both the quarter and year, and the year also included a charge of $105 million for restructuring and downsizing operations at Baltimore Harbor and Bethforge divisions. c-Included an extraordinary credit from early retirement of debt of $11,400,000, or 16 cents a share.

title: Gerald N. Lanier, 52, Entomologist, Is Dead
description: Dr. Gerald N. Lanier, an entomologist who specialized in controlling the bark beetles that cause Dutch elm disease and threaten forests, died of pancreatic cancer on Sunday at Community General Hospital in Syracuse. He was 52 years old and lived in Syracuse.

title: Baker May Meet on Israel-Palestinian Talks
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d is close to opening negotiations with the Foreign Ministers of Egypt and Israel that could pave the way for direct talks between Israel and a Palestinian delegation, Administration officials said today.

title: Upheaval in the East: Poland;   Party's Sticky Past
description: The goal of the 1,633 delegates who attended the congress of the Polish Communist Party last weekend was to dissolve the party, shed its Stalinist skin and emerge as a modern social democratic party.

title: BUSH IS CAUTIOUS ON DOMESTIC GOALS
description: President Bush lent oratorical flourish and the weight of his office to his domestic agenda tonight but added little new substance to policies outlined earlier this week in budget proposals that Democrats have already criticized as inadequate.

title:
Greenspan's Twist;

Fed Chief Surprises Some Colleagues By Citing Lower Odds of a Recession
description: LEAD: Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, threw something of a curve ball in his Congressional testimony on Tuesday when he cited odds that the chances of an imminent recession had declined since last spring.

title: Northrop Sale Of Properties
description: The Northrop Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell two office buildings, one of which houses its corporate headquarters, and another 53-acre site. The price of the sales is more than $250 million.

title: Snap-On Tools Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: The company said earnings and sales in the latest periods were affected by an estimated $18 million in inventory that was consigned rather than sold to new dealers.

title: Baseball Collusion Is Still A Topic
description: Seeking to secure guarantees against collusion in a new labor contract, baseball players yesterday rejected the owners' proposal on collusion and the owners' negotiators withdrew it.

title: A Guard Is Charged With Aiding Suspect Shot in Train Station
description: A state correction officer has been charged with hindering the burglary arrest of a former convict she once guarded in prison and became romantically involved with after his release.

title: KEY RATES
Washington Post Stock
description: The Washington Post Company switched the listing of its class B common stock today from the American Stock Exchange to the New York Stock Exchange. About 7,000 shares of the stock were traded on its first day on the Big Board, and it rose to $270.75 a share, up $2.25 from its close Tuesday on the Amex. The company, which owns The Washington Post and Newsweek, has 10.59 million class B shares outstanding. The company also has nearly 1.9 million shares of class A common stock, which are owned by Katharine Graham, the board chairman, and her family and are not publicly traded. The class A shares have weighted voting power and elect 70 percent of the board.

title: Westerners Quit Sudan Town After Rebel Threats
description: Almost all Western relief workers have been evacuated from the Sudanese town of Juba after warnings from southern rebels that they should leave before an all-out attack on the Government-held town of more than 250,000 people.

title: Senators and Friends And Birthday Wishes
description: While the Senate is often the forum for fiercely partisan debate, there is something about a birthday that makes even political adversaries wax mellow.

title: U.S. Seizes Arizona's Biggest Savings Institution
description: The collapse of the real estate market in Arizona claimed another victim today when Federal regulators seized control of Merabank, the state's largest savings and loan institution, from its parent company, the Pinnacle West Capital Corporation.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: PRO BASKETBALL

title: Yankee Rumor Denied
description: George Steinbrenner yesterday blunted rumors that he was preparing to hire Dick Williams as a special adviser with the Yankees, in part because the team's principal owner does not want to put pressure on his current manager, Bucky Dent.

title: Anti-I.R.A. Drive of 1970's Stirs Furor in Britain
description: The British Government said this week that security forces might have engaged in a campaign to discredit the Irish Republican Army in the 1970's. It said it would reopen the case of a former British Army officer who says he was unfairly dismissed for seeking to end his part in the effort.

title: December New-Home Sales Off 9.6%
description: Sales of new single-family homes fell 9.6 percent in December, ending the worst year for new-home sales since 1984, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Upheaval in the East: Rumania;   Showcase for Bucharest's Dissenters
description: From poet to peasant, Rumanians who want to vent disappointment with the way things are going these days are turning increasingly to Romania Libera, the only major newspaper to take an adversarial role against the ruling Council of National Salvation.

title: Hungary Can Take No Pride in Nazi Past;   Servetus Was Spanish
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Common Stock

title: A Bronx School Superintendent Is Indicted
description: The superintendent of Community School District 12 in the south-central Bronx was indicted yesterday on charges of soliciting a bribe of money and office equipment from the Xerox Corporation.

title: Noranda Forest reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results of Normick Perron Inc. have been consolidated for the last four months of 1989. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Hornets Release Harter as Coach
description: The Charlotte Hornets dismissed Coach Dick Harter yesterday and named the assistant coach, Gene Littles, as interim coach.

title: Northwest Airlines
description: Northwest Airlines, the carrier owned by NWA Inc., said it would invest $422 million in the next five years to upgrade its service. Frederic V. Malek, president of the carrier, which was acquired last year by a group headed by Alfred A. Checchi, said four areas would be worked on: performance, cleanliness, trouble-free customer experience and employee attitude. It is generally accepted that Northwest's service suffered greatly after it merged with Republic Airlines several years ago. The carrier has been working to recover from that image since then.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption in Business Day on Jan. 15 about the involvement of American foundations in economic planning for Eastern Europe misidentified an economist at Indiana University who helped organize a conference. He is Paul Marer.

title: Bulls Lose Protest of 3-Pointer By Tucker but Rule Is Tightened
description: The Knicks' improbable, much-debated victory over the Chicago Bulls on Trent Tucker's 3-point basket with one-tenth of a second left is official. But that sort of victory won't happen again.

title: Dinkins Appoints a Judge To New Deputy Mayor Job
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday appointed a senior appellate judge as deputy mayor for public safety, a newly created position to oversee cooperation among the police, the courts and district attorneys in the face of rising public concern and fear about crime.

title: Talking Deals;   Battle Shapes Up On Centaur Move
description: THE acquisition of a 16.53 percent stake in National Intergroup Inc. by a New York investment partnership has again put pressure on the troubled Pittsburgh-based holding company, which has a pharmaceutical distribution business and owns 50 percent of the National Steel Corporation.

title: The U.N. Has Earned Its Dues
description: President Bush rightly asks Congress to remove an ignominious blot on the good name and credit of the United States. His new budget seeks full payment of U.S. dues to 51 international organizations, including the United Nations. He also seeks approval of a five-year plan to cover back dues to the U.N. of $430 million. That's by far the highest figure on the deadbeat list, the runners-up being South Africa ($37 million) and Iran ($12 million).

title: February Pullout Set For Force in Panama
description: President Bush announced that the troops sent for the invasion of Panama last month would be brought back to the United States ''well before the end of February.''

title: Julia Davis Stuart, Civic Leader, 79
description: Julia Davis Stuart, president of the League of Women Voters of the United States from 1964 to 1968, died Saturday at her home in Spokane. She was 79 years old.

title: 12 Named to Hall
description: Jack Ham, the Penn State linebacker who is already in pro football's Hall of Fame, headed the list of 11 former players and one coach named to college football's Hall of Fame by the National Football Foundation for 1990. Ray Graves, the former Florida coach, and the 11 players will be inducted at a dinner next December.

title: Ogden Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Public Housing With Style
description: ON a quiet hillside in this suburb just south of Seattle, officials say they have created the future of public housing. No apartments. No graffiti-sprayed playgrounds. No duplexes with thin walls.

title: Anti-Abortion Group To Close Headquarters
description: The founder of the militant anti-abortion group Operation Rescue said today that the group would close its headquarters because of debt but that its affiliates nationwide would continue their activities.

title: Threat of 455 Layoffs in Westchester
description: The Westchester County Executive said today that layoff notices would go out to 455 county employees starting on Thursday. But county officials said that it was uncertain how many would eventually be forced from their jobs to balance the county's budget, or which programs and services would be cut.

title: Review/Film;   Legacies of Hiroshima, Faced With Resignation
description: ''Black Rain'' was shown as part of the 1989 New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 26. The film, which is in Japanese with English subtitles, opens today at the Angelika Film Center, Mercer and Houston Streets.

title: Fighting Rages Between Lebanese Christian Forces
description: Fierce street battles raged in most areas of the Christian enclave north of here today as thousands of troops loyal to Gen. Michel Aoun moved to suppress and disarm the Lebanese Forces, a rival Christian militia.

title: Davidoff & Partners And White & Good Join
description: Not only large New York advertising agencies merge; occasionally, small Pennsylvania and Connecticut agencies join forces, as in the case this week of Davidoff, White & Good.

title: Allegheny International Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income There were no share earnings in year-ago first quarter after deducting accretion and dividend requirements for preferred and preference shares. Year-ago quarter ended Jan. 1, 1989.

title: Currents;   Rescuing Architects' Furniture
description: WHEN Kenneth Smith was a student at the Cranbrook Academy of Art in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., he discovered several examples of furniture by the Finnish architect Eliel Saarinen in the school's basement.

title: Asarco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company also said that results for 1989 included previously reported items of a nonrecurring nature which had the net effect of lowering 1989 earnings by $20.3 million. The items comprised a first quarter after-tax charge of $3.1 million to cover remediation costs at a Colorado superfund site, a third quarter after-tax charge of $22.7 million related to the company's decision to get out of asbestos and coal mining, and a credit of $5.5 million as a result of a favorable Canadian tax decision.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Co., New York, the diversified financial services company, named William W. Warrick senior vice president and general auditor.

title: Southwest Airlines Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included non-operating gains totaling $4.2 million taken in the fourth quarter.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-15

title: Kerr-McGee reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $667,000 for the quarter and income of $30,167,000, or 62 cents a share, for the year, both from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $1,136,000 for the quarter and income of $7,525,000, or 16 cents a share, for the year, both from discontinued operations. The latest year net income included $30 million from the completion of the sale of discontinued uranium operations.

title: Stocks End 5-Day Slide; Dow Up 47.30
description: After five losing sessions, stock prices rose yesterday and the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 47.30 points, or 1.9 percent higher, to 2,590.54.

title: Q&A
description: Mildew in the Corners

title: Dow Profits Off in Quarter
description: The Dow Chemical Company said yesterday that profits fell nearly 33 percent in the fourth quarter of 1989 but rose almost 4 percent for the year, a third consecutive record.

title: Defense Seems to Admit Gotti Role as Mob Boss
description: Trying to chip away at vital prosecution evidence, John Gotti's chief counsel appeared yesterday to concede tacitly that Mr. Gotti was heard on tapes directing affairs for the Gambino organization, reputed to be the largest crime family in the nation.

title: Arvin Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,265,000 for the quarter and $1,252,000 for the year. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $7,513,000 and $12,772,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Bush Won. Who Lost?
description: The President won. Oh, yes, the President won - no question at all.

title: Police Officer Is Attacked and Stabbed in Brooklyn
description: A police officer was slashed and stabbed last night as he left the 84th Precinct station house in downtown Brooklyn to get a sandwich for dinner, a police spokesman said.

title: Eastern Airlines To Get $50 Million
description: Burton R. Lifland, the chief judge of the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan, approved a plan to allow Eastern Airlines to spend $50 million from a special fund to help meet its operating expenses.

title: Officer Fatally Shoots Unarmed Teen-Ager
description: A police officer yesterday shot and killed an unarmed Brooklyn teen-ager he wanted to question about the theft of $10 from a man in a park, the police said.

title: 2 Producers' Unusual Deal At Paramount
description: Paramount Pictures said today that it had agreed to a deal with two of Hollywood's most successful producers that sets a benchmark for creative and financial freedom.

title: Ohio Mattress To Leo Burnett
description: The Ohio Mattress Company, the Cleveland-based manufacturer and marketer of Sealy bedding products, gave its $5 million-plus advertising account to Leo Burnett in Chicago.

title: Montana Power Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding are after a 2-for-1 stock split effective Jan. 10.

title: First Aid for a U.S. Agency
description: Every American ought to be outraged about what is happening to one of our great public assets - the National Institutes of Health.

title: Philip Morris's Profit Jumps On Sale of Rothmans Stake
description: The Philip Morris Companies, the world's largest consumer products company, said yesterday that its earnings more than doubled in the fourth quarter, partly because of a large gain from the sale of its stake in a British company.

title: Cuba Accuses U.S. of Firing on Freighter
description: Cuba accused the United States Coast Guard of firing on a Cuban-chartered freighter off the coast of Mexico today while Washington explained that the attack was intended to disable the Panamanian-registered vessel after it refused to stop for a drug search.

title: A Portraitist's Romp Through Art History
description: The woman of a thousand faces was pouring mint tea from a gilded Chinese teapot and talking about invisibility. ''I feel I'm anonymous in my work,'' Cindy Sherman was saying. ''When I look at the pictures, I never see myself; they aren't self-portraits. Sometimes I disappear.'' Ms. Sherman was talking about the photographs in her new show at Metro Pictures, 150 Greene Street in SoHo. These wry visual comments on the history and style of portrait painting depict Ms. Sherman as a radiant Renaissance Madonna, a coy French courtesan, a burgher's prim wife, a bald-pated monk and even a swarthy swashbuckler with the hairiest chest since King Kong.

title: Cosmetics Executive To Run Cartier in U.S.
description: Simon J. Critchell, a cosmetics executive for the last decade, yesterday was named president and chief executive of Cartier Inc., the American subsidiary of the Cartier International Group, the Paris luxury jewelry and cosmetics company.

title: A Deserter, Returning, Is Arrested
description: An American soldier who fled to East Germany in 1959, fearing that an accident in which he was involved would land him in the stockade, saw his family on Tuesday for the first time in three decades and was then taken away as an Army deserter.

title: Wells Fargo Official Is New First Bank Chief
description: After a four-month search, John F. Grundhofer has been named chairman, president and chief executive of the troubled First Bank System Inc. of Minneapolis. Mr. Grundhofer, 51, had been a vice chairman of the Wells Fargo Bank.

title: Upheaval in the East: Bulgaria;   Bulgaria Opposition Rebuffs Communists On Sharing Power
description: Bulgaria's opposition today rejected a Communist offer to share power before the first free elections in more than four decades.

title: Accounts
description: * Glaxo Pharmaceuticals, to Bozell Healthcare, for Zofran, a drug used to control the nausea and vomiting that accompany chemotherapy, with estimated billings of $6 million to $8 million.

title: Booths and Classes Fill the Calendar
description: The second annual Westchester County Sportsmen's Exposition, which opens today at the County Center in White Plains and runs through Sunday, has been expanded by 60 percent to 250 booths on two levels.

title: Currents;   From the Garage to the Living Room
description: ''I'VE always been in love with cars,'' said Marc Miller, a sculptor. ''For a while now I've been hording parts of vintage models.''

title: Sripangapatna Journal;   Sultan Died a Hero. Now Hindus Sully His Name.
description: Tipu Sultan, the swashbuckling 18th-century hero who died here on the ramparts of his fort, trying to stop the British advance across South India, would seem an ideal subject for a television documentary in a land proud of its staunch anticolonialism. But no, not in India in 1990. Tipu Sultan was a Muslim.

title: Dallas Jury Convicts Woman For Counterfeit Coupon Plot
description: A woman with a passion for clipping coupons and proof-of-purchase seals has been convicted of dealing in counterfeit coupons in a $2 million scheme.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Avon Products Inc. said it had begun a joint venture with a Chinese partner, Guangzhou Cosmetics Factory, to make and sell its products in China.

title: Learning To Hang More Than A Diploma
description: There are dos and don'ts in J. Jeffrey Keelan's classroom, and one of the don'ts is never to call wallpaper wallpaper. ''It sounds better if you call it wall covering,'' he said, inspecting a brand-new roll. ''You can charge more money that way, and besides, this is fabric.''

title: Rise in Poverty From '79 to '82 Is Found in U.S.
description: The Census Bureau said today that there had been a rapid increase in poverty from 1979 to 1982, even if the value of food stamps, public housing, Medicare and Medicaid benefits was counted as income

title: Blues' Rookie Goalie Overshadows Nicholls's Garden Debut
description: A night after his success on Long Island in his second start in the National Hockey League, Curtis Joseph, the rookie goaltender of the St. Louis Blues, overshadowed the Madison Square Garden debut for Bernie Nicholls by earning a 2-2 dealock against the Rangers last night.

title: Milton Gordon, 82, An Early Producer Of Television Shows
description: Milton A. Gordon, a financier and early producer of television features and series, died of a heart attack yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Colleges Fearing TV Revenue Loss
description: Colleges across the nation are threatened with the loss of millions of dollars in basketball television revenue because of overexposure of the game this season and the resultant large drop in television ratings, according to some college administrators and television executives. The ratings have declined while the rights fees have more than doubled in the last year or two.

title: Seagate Profit Is Up Sharply
description: Seagate Technology Inc., the leading maker of hard computer-disk drives, today reported sharply improved earnings and revenues for its second quarter ended Dec. 31.

title: Cuomo Vetoes Cable TV Bill
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo yesterday vetoed a bill aimed at forcing cable television companies to compensate subscribers for major changes in programming. The measure was prompted last year when Cablevision, a company based in Woodbury, L.I., failed to provide viewers with sports coverage they had been led to expect. Cablevision agreed to refund subscribers $1.1 million for this failure. Mr. Cuomo said the bill would interfere with the First Amendment rights of the electronic media.

title: RICO Racket in the Senate
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee's vote on a bill masquerading as a ''reform'' of RICO, the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, could provide the year's first indication of Congressional seriousness about ethics and public justice. The bill would remove or weaken the strong civil remedies now available to victims of commercial fraud perpetrated either by mobsters or white-collar professionals who behave like mobsters.

title: Strawberry And Dent's Successors
description: Baseball's bickering club owners and players won't guarantee that spring training will start on schedule. But judging by Darryl Strawberry's domestic dispute and George Steinbrenner's reportedly imminent hiring of Dick Williams as his latest manager-in-waiting, the Mets and the Yankees have rolled out their batting cages.

title: I.M.F. Is Urged to Sell Gold as Hedge Against Bad Loans
description: The United States has proposed that the International Monetary Fund sell about three million ounces of gold, which at current market prices could raise more than $1 billion, to buttress the global lending agency against the growing problem of delinquent payments by its members.

title: Salvadoran Chief Asks U.N. Help To Restart Talks With Guerrillas
description: On the eve of White House talks, President Alfredo Cristiani of El Salvador asked the United Nations today to help restart stalled peace talks with the Salvadoran guerrilla alliance.

title: Market Place;   Can RJR Nabisco Keep Its Promise?
description: WHEN RJR Nabisco Inc. was acquired in the largest leveraged buyout ever, the buyers were betting on more than the health of the food and cigarette businesses. They were betting billions on the continued health of the ''junk bond'' market.

title: International Flavor in Old Ketchup Game
description: To the Editor:

title: School Reform: Business Moves In
description: When it comes to reforming the nation's schools, these days the leading radicals are likely to be wearing pin-striped suits and come from oak-paneled board rooms rather than the ivy-covered walls of academia.

title: Taming Unruly Boys: Old Techniques and New Approaches
description: Boys who are wildly aggressive are the focus of an intensive new effort by psychologists to set them straight while they are still young.

title: Now New York Mass Transit Practices Height Discrimination
description: To the Editor:

title: Chesley Peterson, Fighter Pilot, 69
description: Chesley Peterson, a retired Air Force major general who was the United States Air Force's youngest colonel, died Sunday in Riverside, Calif. He was 69 years old.

title: Auctions
description: Most Expensive Table

title: Mexico's President Urges Latin Investments by West
description: President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico urged the industrialized nations of the West today not to forget Mexico and the rest of Latin America as they move to help the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Economy

title: Shell to Sell Methanol In California Program
description: The Shell Oil Company said today that it would join Exxon, Chevron and ARCO in selling a methanol fuel in California as part of that state's program to test alternative fuels for automobiles.

title: Marriott's Net Off Sharply; Costs of Revamping Cited
description: The Marriott Corporation, one of the nation's leading hotel and restaurant companies, reported yesterday that its net income fell to $1 million, or one cent a share, in the quarter ended Dec. 29, from $65 million, or 56 cents a share, a year ago.

title: Parliament Questions Spain Aide on Scandal
description: Deputy Prime Minister Alfonso Guerra appeared today in an emergency session of Parliament to defend himself against charges that he was implicated in his brother's personal financial activities.

title: SmithKline Price On Drug to Be Cut
description: Under pressure from members of Congress to lower the price of Dyazide, its drug for treating high blood pressure, the SmithKline Beecham Corporation said it was cutting the wholesale price by 11 percent. The new price will be 25.75 cents per capsule, the usual daily dose. The company, based in Philadelphia, said the estimated price to consumers would drop to about 32 cents from 36 cents.

title: DEALS
description: BASKETBALL

title: BUSH SEEKS A RISE IN AID TO SALVADOR
description: President Bush met today with the President of El Salvador, Alfredo Cristiani, and offered him a strong statement of support, hoping it would signal to Congress that the United States should not cut back more on aid to the country.

title: Alaska Journal;   When Moose Find Death on the Rails
description: Staggered by cold so intense that teardrops freeze, the moose have come to the Susitna Valley in search of easy food. Instead, they often find violent death from an iron predator.

title: U.S. Is Seeking Special Counsel In H.U.D. Affair
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said today that he was seeking the appointment of an independent prosecutor to investigate former Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. and other senior housing officials for conspiracy to defraud the Government.

title: Revamping Racketeering Law
description: Brushing aside complaints from consumer groups, the Senate Judiciary Committee approved plans today to cut damages that can be awarded in civil fraud cases under the nation's major anti-racketeering law.

title: Expect the Unexpected When Camacho Talks
description: Protocol goes out the window the instant Hector Camacho enters a room. Any room.

title: Railroadmen's Federal S&L reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
If de Klerk Frees Mandela, Bush Will See Both
description: Hoping to encourage the release of Nelson Mandela from a South African prison, the White House announced today that President Bush will invite Mr. Mandela and President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa to pay separate visits to Washington should the anti-apartheid leader be freed.

title: Grumman Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said included in the 1989 net income was $4.5 million, or 14 cents a share, reported in the second quarter for the expected recovery of product improvement costs on several F-14 contracts. In the third quarter of 1988, Grumman reported a benefit of $11.1 million, or 34 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment for New York state franchise taxes.

title: Knight-Ridder Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $246,000 for the quarter and income of $482,000, or 1 cent a share, for the year, both from discontinued operations, and extraordinary credits of $7,197,000, or 13 cents a share, and $66,884,000, or $1.27 a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After income from discontinued operations of $3,618,000, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter and $9,608,000, or 17 cents a share, for the year. The latest year's income from continuing operations included gain from the sale of the Pasadena Star-News in June 1989.

title: More Filers Settle
description: Larry Andersen and the Houston Astros agreed to a two-year $1.95 million contract yesterday, and six other players who had filed for arbitration settled on one-year contracts.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   New Effort for Barbasol
description: A television commercial for Barbasol breaks today, the Pfizer Inc. product's first new spot in five years. Back then, Ally & Gargano's ads for the inexpensive shaving cream won an Effie. In Ally's new spots, for Barbasol's shaving gel, a wealthy young man sends his butler for shaving gel, and gets Barbasol plus change.

title: SPS Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $234,000, or 5 cents a share, and $1,384,000, or 28 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively, from utilization of non-U.S. tax loss carryforward. The year also included a loss from discontinued operations of $8,389,000 resulting from materials handling segment discontinued in 1988.

title: Cup Winners Ready to Run Again
description: A shift in racing from early retirement to longer careers on the track is becoming clearer than ever this year. For the first time since the inception of the Breeders' Cup in 1984, all seven of the cup race winners are back in training. Most of them, in fact, are just about ready to race.

title: 41 Pathe Theaters Are Sold in Europe
description: The Pathe Communications Corporation said it had sold 41 movie theaters in Britain and the Netherlands for about $233 million. The buyer, Cinema 5 Europe N.V., a company owned by Fininvest International Ltd., will lease the theaters back to Pathe. ''This transaction represents an important step toward implementing our plan to maximize the value of Pathe's assets while continuing to be a leading participant in the entertainment business worldwide,'' said Giancarlo Parretti, Pathe's chairman.

title: Review/Photography;   Photos by Peter Hujar, A Mapplethorpe Precursor
description: Even before his death in 1987, Peter Hujar was known as an overlooked and underappreciated photographer. His mostly underground reputation was based on his portraits of artists and writers and on his frank chronicle of the hip homosexual scene of the 1970's. Because of his subject matter and his preference for square, black-and-white prints, Hujar is viewed by his most ardent admirers as a precursor of Robert Mapplethorpe.

title: Construction Spending Off 0.6%
description: Construction spending advanced last year at its slowest pace since the 1982 recession, the Government said today as it released December data showing that spending declined by six-tenths of a percent that month.

title:
LAW;

Constitution, Anyone? A New Cottage Industry
description: LEAD: A handful of American constitutional law scholars are helping to write or revise constitutions for the new Governments in Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia.

title: Stand on Police Killings Could Shape Lee Brown's Future
description: Less than two weeks after being sworn in as New York City Police Commissioner, Lee P. Brown is facing a test that could shape his relationship for years to come with both officers on the beat and communities alarmed by police brutality.

title: Children of Flight 52: The Wounds Within
description: For the four children still being treated at North Shore University Hospital after surviving the crash of Avianca Flight 52 last week, these are days of confusion and pain, of waiting for broken bones to heal and of trying to understand what happened.

title: Saturn Disq reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Smoke in Subway Overcomes 12 Riders and Delays 60,000
description: Twelve subway riders were treated for smoke inhalation and service on the Lexington Avenue line between Brooklyn and Manhattan was disrupted during the evening rush hour yesterday by smoke from a third rail at the Brooklyn Bridge station, transit officials said.

title: Economic Scene;   Four Pathways Japan Might Take
description: THE traffic jams here beat anything New York has to offer, and so does the concentration of capital. Japan's investors, having bid the prices of buildings, land and stocks to stratospheric levels, are going overseas for cheaper assets, cheaper labor and higher rates of return than they can earn at home.
