Lenin said, ''Imperialism is the final stage of capitalism,'' and the Japanese, bursting forth from their resource-poor islands, seem to be acting out Lenin's script.

title: Jack Gantz Dies at 76; Ran a Brush Company
description: Jack Gantz, a business executive, died of cardiac arrest yesterday at Mercy Hospital in San Diego, Calif. He was 76 years old and lived in Palm Beach, Fla., and Rye, N.Y.

title: 5 Arrests in Ghana Plot
description: Five men, including three military officers, were arrested after trying to destroy evidence linking them to a reported attempt to assassinate Flight Lieut. Jerry Rawlings, the Ghananian leader, the Ministry of Defense said today. The action followed the arrest of seven officers in November on charges of planning to kill Lieutenant Rawlings.

title: Fedders Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $1,516,000, or 8 cents a share, for both the quarter and year. c-Included extraordinary credits of $2,639,000, or 19 cents a share, for the quarter and $7,042,000, or 51 cents a share, for the year.

title: McClatchy Newspapers reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. Charges in Drug Agent's Death: New Friction
description: With the indictment in the United States of two former high-level Mexican law enforcement officials, the five-year mystery surrounding the killing of a United States Drug Enforcement Administration agent in Mexico has once again become an affair of state.

title: Review/Film;   Bette Midler as a Selfless Mother in Tear-Inducing 'Stella'
description: Central Park's Tavern on the Green, where Bette Midler enacts perhaps a three-hanky version of the famous four-hanky ''Stella Dallas'' finale, isn't quite the right setting for this brave mother's ultimate sacrifice. It was in a spirit of joyful self-abnegation that Barbara Stanwyck's Stella, in the most famous scene from King Vidor's 1937 film, stood in the rain outside a grand hotel watching the wedding she could never attend, until a watchful guard shooed her away.

title: Japan Law On Monopoly
description: Japan's Fair Trade Commission said today that its international committee was considering applying anti-monopoly regulations to all foreign companies whose business practices affect Japan.

title: Where to See Pollocks
description: Two new biographies of Jackson Pollock have thrown the American artist's troubled existence into high relief, stirring up lots of talk and setting the movie and probably the mini-series machines in motion.

title: North Carolina Routed By Georgia Tech, 102-75
description: Dennis Scott scored 37 points and Brian Oliver 34 as No. 17 Georgia Tech ended a losing streak at three games tonight with a 102-75 victory over No. 25 North Carolina.

title: Pop/Jazz;   B.B. King: Making the Most of a Lifetime of Experience
description: In 1945, when B. B. King wandered into Memphis and began his career at the age of 20, American music was mutating and proliferating as at no other time since the turn of the century. Radio and records were easily available, and since the big bands were dying out as commercial entities, audiences hungered for the new, as long as it kept the pleasures of the old to remind them how far they'd come. The guitar, electric and loud, was the leader of the shock troops.

title: Beverly Enterprises Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included pretax restructuring charges of about $128,104,000. c-Net loss and included pretax restructuring charges of about $14,550,000. d-Included pretax restructuring charges of $27,039,000.

title: TV Weekend;   American Indian Dancers and Sammy Davis Tribute
description: Except for music-awards shows, performance specials are rare on television these days. But this weekend is featuring two first-rate productions, each very different from the other. Tonight at 9 on Channel 13, ''Great Performances'' is presenting ''American Indian Dance Theater: Finding the Circle.'' And on Sunday, from 8:30 to 11 P.M., ABC has ''Sammy Davis Jr.'s 60th-Anniversary Celebration.'' Each adds up to a splendid show.

title: Ann Straube, Titanic Survivor, 92
description: Ann Straube, who survived the sinking of the Titanic, died Tuesday at the age of 92, relatives said Wednesday. She lived in Chicago.

title: Rudy's Restaurant Group reports earnings for Year to Oct 1
description: b-Included a charge of $64,000 primarily related to the closing of a restaurant in fiscal 1989 for the latest year; the prior year included a charge of $412,000 from disposition of an undeveloped site and the closing of the restaurant in fiscal 1989.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I have proposed a series of actions that will take the hard edge off the tough decisions I have had to make. I will not break our covenant with the most vulnerable of our people.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Sunrise Medical Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: Year-ago periods ended Dec. 30.

title: Sherritt Gordon reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-Included income from discontinued operations of $5,259,000, or 23 cents a share. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Capital Cities' Chief to Step Aside in May
description: Thomas S. Murphy said yesterday that he would step down as chief executive of Capital Cities/ABC Inc. when he turned 65 years old on May 31.

title: Washington Talk;   Fighting Words in a Genteel World
description: With rumors still swirling around Moscow about Mikhail S. Gorbachev's grip on power, debate is kicking up again in Washington about how the United States should deal with the Soviet leader.

title: Rio Restoring Christ Statue
description: Restoration of the Christ the Redeemer statue, cracked and chipped by years of wear on its perch above Rio de Janeiro, began this week, a city spokeswoman said today. Some $2 million will be spent to restore the 125-foot-high monument, which attracts hundreds of visitors every day. The work should be finished by October, in time for the 59th anniversary of the opening of the statue, the spokeswoman, Estela Elliot, said, .

title: Smaller Weapons Industry Proposed
description: For the first time since President Lyndon B. Johnson closed six reactors and six weapons production plants in the 1960's, the White House has proposed steps to make the nuclear weapons industry smaller.

title: SCI Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Eye Care Chief Named U.S. Shoe's President
description: The United States Shoe Corporation thinks Bannus B. Hudson did a terrific job developing its eye care business and has rewarded the effort: It named him president and chief operating officer.

title: Weapon in Drug War: Imagination
description: A police radio crackled, ''Go! Go! Go!'' and two police cars converged on a man in a white hat in one of the city's highest-crime areas. He started to run, saw the other car and froze.

title: Puritan-Bennett Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
French Love For Animals: Too Fervent?
description: There are twice as many of them as there are children in France. They consume more meat than all Spaniards put together. They can be found in 55 percent of France's households: one dog to every three French families and one cat to every four.

title: Hakim on Probation In Iran-Contra Deal But Shares Proceeds
description: Albert A. Hakim, who was Oliver L. North's financial adviser on the arms sales and other secret missions of the Iran-contra affair, was fined $5,000 today and placed on two years' probation for his actions. But he also gained a share of $1.7 million in proceeds from those operations, which are now frozen in Swiss banks.

title: Review/Film;   'Cinema Paradiso,' Memories of Movies in a Movie
description: When the rich, middle-aged Salvatore receives word in Rome of the death of his old friend Alfredo, his mind goes hurtling back over the years to Giancaldo, the parched Sicilian village where he grew up. Possibly because Salvatore is now a successful movie director, he remembers all in neatly chronological order.

title: Hungary Has Another Round Of Steep Increases in Prices
description: Hungarians faced steep price increases for housing, transportion, phones, water and sewage today in the second wave of increases this year aimed at satisfying austerity demands by the International Monetary Fund.

title: CHRONICLE
description: At Lincoln Center, ARLENE SHULER will be dancing behind the scenes as the new vice president for planning and development. Ms. Shuler, 42, has an impressive record of jobs in the arts, including serving as executive director of Volunteer Lawyers for the Arts. And she was a dancer with the Joffrey Ballet for four years.

title: Trial for Disney And MGM/UA
description: The MGM/UA Communications Company and the Walt Disney Company said today that they planned to go to trial to settle a dispute over the use of the MGM name at the Disney-MGM Studios, an Orlando, Fla., amusement attraction.

title: Lilly (Eli) & Co.  (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are fully diluted. The share earnings for all periods was adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split, effected in the form of a stock dividend in March 1989. The 1988 data has been restated to present the company's plant science operating results in other income, net of taxes to conform with the 1989 presentation. Other income in the latest fourth quarter was $22 million, compared with $19.8 million in the year-ago period. In the latest year, other income was $165.1 million, against $129.7 million. In all periods, other income was included in net income results. The company said primary share earnings have not been presented because it does not differ significantly from the reported fully diluted basis.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Sports Pages on Wednesday about the Yale football coach, Carmen L. Cozza, misidentified the college team that has played the most games. The University of Pennsylvania has played the most, 1,105; Yale, with 1,052, is second.

title: Compaq Computer reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Jets Make Ryan a Free Agent
description: Pat Ryan, the Jets' perennial backup quarterback, is going to look for another job.

title: Dining Out Guide: At the Counter
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current.

title: Soviet Aide Welcomes Bush's Troop Proposal
description: A Soviet spokesman today welcomed President Bush's proposals to reduce American and Soviet troop levels in Central Europe and said Moscow was ready to discuss them.

title: The President's Two Worlds
description: George Bush gave two State of the Union addresses Wednesday. The first was a lofty speech about domestic needs, full of oratory and lacking substance. This was the old George Bush, offering bright shining goals - cities without drugs, schools where everyone graduates, a nation bathed in civic virtue - but few new programs, and little new money, for reaching them.

title: Kemper Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $77,820,000, or $1.52 a share, which included gain of $67.2 million on sale of discontinued operations. c-After income from discontinued operations of $5,526,000, or 10 cents a share, for the quarter and $9,955,000, or 17 cents a share, for the year. Both 1988 periods were restated to reflect adoption of FASB No. 97.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: EAST BERLIN CHIEF PRESENTS HIS PLAN TO UNITE GERMANY
description: Prime Minister Hans Modrow today presented for the first time an East German program for the reunification of Germany, which he said should be neutral.

title: In Suspense, East Germans Await Capitalism
description: Some are anxious, some can hardly wait, but it seems that everyone here is waiting for the West Germans.

title: Rumania's Rulers Agree to Share Power
description: Bowing to pressure from opposition forces, the ruling Council of National Salvation agreed today to give up its monopoly on power and join with 29 other political parties in a coalition that is to rule the country until elections in May.

title: Group Giving Swells Fund For Neediest
description: People who work together sometimes give together. Or at least that is the case for many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund campaign.

title: Review/Film;   Tawdriness Is Emphasized in 'Mack the Knife'
description: When the gangster MacHeath (Raul Julia) is saved from hanging by the theatrically happy ending of the Bertolt Brecht-Kurt Weill ''Threepenny Opera,'' the film adaptation ''Mack the Knife'' emphasizes the change of mood by shifting its setting to the Queen Victoria Theater in London. There, a well-dressed, well-heeled audience is seen enjoying this show more wholeheartedly than any prosperous-looking crowd ever should. There are a lot of ways in which this version has altered the letter and spirit of the text, but surely this is the one liable to give Brecht the most vigorous spin.

title: Noverco Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: A Familiar Budget;   Much of Spending Plan From Dinkins Is Reminiscent of the Koch Approach
description: Presenting a preliminary New York City budget that would not have struck Edward I. Koch as unfamiliar, the Budget Director for Mayor David N. Dinkins acknowledged yesterday that ''there aren't a whole lot of brand-new, unthought-of solutions.''

title: Yugoslavia Sends Troops to Province as 6 Are Slain in Strife
description: Yugoslavia deployed troops, tanks and warplanes today in Kosovo province, where six more ethnic Albanians were killed in fierce clashes verging on civil war.

title: Cherishing A Black Past
description: ''IN the past 20 to 25 years, there has been a spectacular growth in the number of institutions that concentrate on one or another aspect of African-American culture,'' said Dr. Mary Schmidt Campbell, New York City's Commissioner of Cultural Affairs and the former director of the Studio Museum in Harlem. ''In the visual arts, there is the Schomburg Center, the Studio Museum, the Jamaica Arts Center, the Bronx Museum and many galleries, and performing-arts groups include Alvin Ailey, Jazzmobile, Dance Theater of Harlem, the Negro Ensemble Company, the Marie Brooks Company and the Boys' Choir of Harlem.

title: Chubb Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax benefits of $4.8 million, or 11 cents a share, from ''fresh start'' adjustment related to the Tax Reform Act of 1986 for the quarter and the full year included $19.2 million, or 44 cents a share. c-Included tax benefits from ''fresh start'' adjustment related to the Tax Reform Act of 1986 of $5.1 million, or 12 cents a share, for the quarter and $20.4 million, or 48 cents a share, for the year. The company said the latest quarter and year results included capital gains of 22 cents a share and 71 cents a share, respectively, and also included in the quarter and year are catastrophe losses of $31.5 million and $89.5 million, respectively. The company also said the year-ago quarter and year results included capital losses of 22 cents a share for the quarter and 30 cents a share for the year, and catastrophe losses of $2.2 million and $16.4 million for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Phelan Plans to Retire As Head of Big Board
description: John J. Phelan Jr., who presided over an extraordinary period of growth, turmoil and change on Wall Street during his six years as the chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday that he planned to retire by the end of the year to pursue other interests.

title: Goodrich (B.F.) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $1,100,000 for the quarter and income of $1,200,000, or 5 cents a share, for the year, both from discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,900,000 and $12,100,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also included a gain of $2,700,000, or 11 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.

title: Apple Discusses Cheaper Machines
description: Apple Computer Inc. said it did not expect to introduce a lower-priced Macintosh in time to benefit from its sales in the 1990 fiscal year, which ends on Sept. 30. The company also said it expected growth in its second quarter, which ends on March 31, to be comparable to its first, in which its revenues grew 6 percent and its earnings declined 11 percent from the previous year.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Crashing and Heaving

title: Changes by USX On Proxy Fights
description: The USX Corporation, strengthening its defenses against the New York financier Carl C. Icahn amended its bylaws to require advance notice of proxy fights. USX's chairman, Charles A. Corry, said he had informed Mr. Icahn, USX's largest shareholder, about the change in a telephone call Wednesday. Mr. Icahn was in meetings today, his secretary said, and did not return a telephone call seeking comment.

title: Money Fund Assets Rise
description: The assets of the nation's 493 money market mutual funds increased by $1.54 billion, to $384.60 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 149 institutional funds decreased by $708.5 million, to $91.71 billion. The assets of the 243 general-purpose funds were up by $1.77 billion, to $129.78 billion. The 101 broker-dealer funds increased by $475.7 million, to $163.11 billion, the institute said.

title: Gritty Eulogies and Anger For Youth Killed by Police
description: For much of yesterday, scores of residents of the Bushwick section of Brooklyn milled about the blood-streaked sidewalk where a 14-year-old robbery suspect was shot on Wednesday by a police officer who mistakenly believed the youth was armed.

title: Molson Cos.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $61,931,000, or $1.88 a share. The latest third quarter's revenue included sales and other revenue from Molson Breweries of Canada for the 4 months ended July 31, 1989, and 50 percent of the sales and other revenue of the Molson Breweries partnership for the 5 months ended Dec. 31, 1989. Results are in Canadian funds. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: Pinnacle West Debt Restructuring
description: One day after Federal regulators seized its savings and loan subsidiary, the Pinnacle West Capital Corporation said today that it had completed a debt restructuring that would allow it to avoid bankruptcy proceedings.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Accounts
description: * Chicago Sun-Times, to Zwiren Collins Karo Trusk & Ayer.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column of Business Day on Wednesday misstated the manner in which the 286 microprocessor handles data. The chip, used in many personal computers, processes data in bundles of 16 characters, or 16 bytes.

title: St. Paul Cos. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain from tax-loss carryforward of $2,643,000, or 6 cents a share.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: URBAN LONELINESS

title: Wynn's International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Latest year results benefited from a gain of $1,375,000, or 36 cents a share, on the sale of joint venture interest during the first quarter. Year-ago fourth quarter results included an after-tax gain of $1,011,000, or 27 cents a share, from a sale of real estate.

title: POWER IS FLEETING, BAKER REFLECTS
description: In an unusual public reflection on religious faith, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that after nine years at the center of power in Washington, he has discovered that ''power doesn't really bring the fulfillment that many think it does.''

title: Nathaniel Rock, Lawyer, 90
description: Nathaniel Rock, a partner in the Manhattan law firm of Rock & Rock, who was active in behalf of American Indian causes, died of pneumonia on Monday at University Hospital. He was 90 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Fast Start Helps Nuggets Outduel the Slumping Nets
description: Alex English, with 26 points, and Fat Lever, with 22, paced the Denver Nuggets to a 123-112 victory over the Nets tonight, the Nets' seventh consecutive loss.

title: Wall St. Praises Helmsman Who Had a Difficult Watch
description: John J. Phelan Jr.'s tenure at the helm of the New York Stock Exchange coincided with one of the most turbulent periods in the history of the United States stock market. Yet as Wall Street executives assessed his six years as chairman, there was almost universal praise for his leadership and the stature he lent an organization that in many ways came of age on his watch.

title: In South Africa, Cricket Tour Stirs More Violence
description: Less than two weeks after arriving in South Africa in defiance of an international ban, a team of English cricketers has been thrown into a mounting cycle of violence that threatens to disrupt steps toward broader racial reforms.

title: Magma Copper Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a pre-tax writedown of assets of $3.5 million for quarter and year.

title: A Chairman Visits His Board Room
description: Few arenas have ever belonged to one runner the way Madison Square Garden belonged to Eamonn Coghlan. He took it over.

title: Isidore Halpern, 88, Brooklyn Lawyer, Dies
description: Isidore Halpern, a Brooklyn lawyer who was known as the ''dean of Court Street,'' died of pneumonia on Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 88 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Nights of Jazz

title: Europe Welcomes Troops Proposal
description: Western European officials said today that President Bush's proposal to cut the number of Soviet and American troops in Europe was a positive move but also inevitable, given the political changes in Eastern Europe.

title: Review/Dance;   The Jose Greco Company Opens a 3-Week Engagement
description: The Jose Greco Company of Spanish Dancers, Singers and Musicians opened a three-week engagement on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street. It will surely be a three-week fiesta.

title: Treasury Prices Narrowly Mixed
description: Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed yesterday in fairly active trading.

title: Marriott Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $35 million for the quarter and $4 million for the year. The losses from discontinued operations for both periods included an after-tax charge of $39 million to reduce Marriott's investment in the family restaurant business to estimated net realizable value. c-After income from discontinued operations of $13 million, or 11 cents a share, for the quarter and $43 million, or 36 cents a share, for the year. Both 1988 periods were restated to reflect restaurant businesses as discontinued operations. The share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.

title: Henry Baker, Viewed as the Dean Of U.S. Realty Brokers, Dies at 99
description: Henry Baker, a New York real-estate broker for more than 75 years and believed to be the oldest active broker in the field in the United States, died of pneumonia yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 99 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: INSIDE
description: Impact of the Budget:

title: L.S. Starrett reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
2 Transcripts Of Tape Differ In Gotti Trial
description: Prosecutors and defense lawyers grappled yesterday at the trial of John Gotti, the reputed Mafia boss, over major differences between two transcripts of the same secretly recorded conversation - one prepared by Federal authorities and one prepared by state authorities.

title: There Is No Military Free Lunch
description: LEAD: Now that the cold war is over and I need worry less about my personal safety and welfare, I find myself contemplating with pleasure all the money I shall save and be able to spend. These savings are of a peculiar kind: they represent expenditures I had thought of making but that no longer seem necessary.

title: Purchasers Index Posts 9th Decrease in a Row
description: The nation's purchasing managers said yesterday that the economy declined sharply in January for the ninth consecutive month, despite strength in orders for exports.

title: Harvard Beats Yale, 1,436-1,070! Touchdowns? No, Pages in the Big-League Law Reviews.
description: If some latter-day Tocqueville wished to illustrate America's obsession with statistics, he would probably turn first to the sports pages. He could also turn to the current issue of The Illinois Institute of Technology-Chicago-Kent Law Review, which includes an article worthy of Bill James's Baseball Abstract or the Elias Sports Bureau.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Budapest and Moscow Discussing Troop Pullout
description: Hungary and the Soviet Union began talks today on a timetable for the withdrawal of all Soviet troops from Hungary.

title: KEY RATES
Massachusetts Drexel Accord
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. agreed to pay Massachusetts $1 million in a settlement announced today, the latest settlement arising from the Wall Street firm's guilty plea to securities fraud charges.

title: With Church's Help, Lebanese Christians Agree to Another Truce
description: After three days of ferocious fighting that left at least 53 people dead and 200 wounded, Lebanon's warring Christian factions said today that they had agreed to a truce in a Christian enclave north of the city.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Balfour Maclaine Corp., New York, a commodities company, appointed John Coffin executive vice president and president of its Balfour Maclaine International Ltd. subsidiary. He replaces Raymond Nessim, who resigned.

title: India Relaxes Kashmir Curbs And Says Situation Is Better
description: The Indian Government further relaxed curfew restrictions in violence-torn Kashmir today and asserted that the situation was improving.

title: Nicholls Shoots but Doesn't Score
description: Bernie Nicholls's debut in Madison Square Garden had all the ingredients for a Hollywood ending except that the Rangers' flamboyant center failed at the fadeout.

title: New Player in Debate Over National Health Insurance: Bush
description: By calling for a review of the nation's health care system, President Bush has brought the White House into the the debate over national health insurance and raised the possibility that he might offer his own proposal, Administration and Congressional officials said today.

title: PanCanadian Petroleum reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: In Africa, Democracy Needs Some Help
description: To the Editor:

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums

title: Herbert Whyman, 76, A Real-Estate Lawyer
description: Herbert Whyman, a Manhattan lawyer for more than half a century, died of bladder cancer on Wednesday at his home in Roslyn Heights, L.I. He was 76 years old.

title: New Name and New Age (Is There a New Party?)
description: A cartoon in The Guardian recently depicted two women reading a sign that said, ''Communist Party of Great Britain - General Secretary Nina Temple.''

title: Britain Will Expel 9 Iranians Because of National Security
description: The British Government today ordered nine Iranians, including the London bureau chief for Iranian Television, to leave the country by Feb. 9 for reasons of national security.

title: Corrections Town and Gown Clash Over Zoning
description: An article on Feb. 2 about a zoning conflict between Princeton, N.J., and Princeton University referred incorrectly to the university's objections to the borough's zoning procedures. The university does not oppose submitting its plans to a public hearing and a vote by the Regional Planning Board of Princeton. It does object to consulting with the board before submitting plans.

title: Helen Jerome Eddy, Actress, 92
description: Helen Jerome Eddy, an actress known for her portrayals of genteel heroines in films like the 1916 version of ''Rebecca of Sunnybrook Farm,'' died of heart failure on Jan. 27 at the Episcopal Home. She was 92 years old.

title: Perkins Family Restaurants L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Affected by charges of $639,000 associated with starting up nine restaurants acquired during the third quarter.

title: Review/Music;   Muti Conducts Busoni Pieces Inspired by 'Turandot' Tale
description: Into every life a little revelation must fall. Ferruccio Busoni, the Italian-born, German-based composer and pianist who lived from 1866 to 1924, has long enjoyed a cult reputation for his scores that has transcended memories of his skills at the keyboard. Despite earnest encounters with most of the major Busoni compositions over the years, I have never quite got it, never felt deep down that here was a composer who was truly significant, who transcended the clever mannerisms and pastiche and occasional striking moments that undoubtedly do occur in his works.

title: North Stars Consider A Change of Scenery
description: On the ice, the Minnesota North Stars' power play ranks seventh in a 21-team league. In the front office, their current power play ranks among the most threatening in professional sports.

title: Christ the King Is Tops on Court
description: Even though the boys' varsity basketball team at Christ the King High School has lost only one of its 15 games, is ranked first in New York State and fourth in the nation by USA Today, the team's coach, Bob Oliva, doesn't get a chance to bask in that glory by himself.

title: Upjohn Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $1,779,000 and $4,954,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a loss on disposal of $130,000,000 for both periods. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $1,789,000 and $5,310,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. d-Net income The company said 1989 fourth-quarter results were reduced by after-tax charges of $206 million associated with a previously announced restructuring. The company said the losses from discontinued operations and disposal of discontinued operations represent its industrial chemical business in North Haven, Conn., which is being phased out. Fourth-quarter 1989 restructuring charges included $130,000,000 from disposal of discontinued operations of its North Haven, Conn., industrial chemical business and $76 million for a special early retirement plan of $23 million, asset write-downs of $35 million and other charges totaling $18 million related to environmental reserves, product liability reserves and corporate contributions. The company said 1988 results were restated to reflect the discontinued operations.

title: Kingdom Hoping to Be 'Sharp' at Garden
description: The indoor track season is half over, and Roger Kingdom has not run a race all winter. Set back by the flu, he has been spending as much time at awards banquets as in training. Tonight, he will make his season debut, in a meet in which he has finished second twice, third and sixth, but never first.

title: Gannett Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Castro Assails the U.S. for Attack on Vessel
description: President Fidel Castro of Cuba told a rally in Havana today that President Bush must have given the order for a Coast Guard cutter to open fire on a Cuban-chartered cargo ship that it suspected of drug-running.

title: NEW TEST DETECTS A GENETIC DEFECT
description: A new test can detect three-quarters of all adults who risk having children with cystic fibrosis, researchers said today, and more accurate versions should soon allow routine screening of every American for this genetic defect.

title: Bush Urged to Void Sale of Airplane-Parts Maker to Chinese
description: A Federal task force has recommended that President Bush nullify a transaction under which a military agency of the Chinese Government purchased an American company that manufactures parts for commercial aircraft, Administration officials said today.

title: 5 Years for Gioiosa
description: A Federal judge in Cincinnati yesterday sentenced Tommy Gioiosa to five years in prison for transporting cocaine and for conspiring to hide Pete Rose's race-track winnings from the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Reporter's Notebook;   Pope's Themes on Africa Trip: 'Drops of Water on a Stone'
description: From start to finish on his latest African pilgrimage, Pope John Paul II has sent up danger flares about otherwise welcome developments in Eastern Europe.

title: Budget for the Space Agency Sets a Broader Course in Exploration
description: The proposed 24 percent increase in the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's budget, which would be the biggest increase for any major agency, represents a critical step in expanding the nation's civilian space program, opening the way finally to building an orbiting space station, initiating two ambitious efforts in Earth and planetary exploration, and setting the agenda for space flight well into the next century.

title: Dennis McIntyre, Dramatist, 47; Wrote of Ills in American Society
description: Dennis McIntyre, a playwright whose work examined the ills of American society, died of stomach cancer yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 47 years old. Mr. McIntyre's latest play, ''Established Price,'' was staged at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven last month by Arvin Brown with a cast that included Jason Robards. Mel Gussow, in his review in The New York Times. said this realistic work about three corporate executives after the takeover of their sporting goods company is ''complete with pertinent commentary about big-business power plays, board room intrigue and the colorful jargon of the trade.'' The review called Mr. McIntyre ''one of our most acute theatrical observers'' of contemporary life.

title: McGraw-Hill Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included after-tax charge of $152 million from writedown of goodwill and other intangible assets of certain acquired units, a provision for the shutdown of certain units, the writedown of other non-performing units and assets, and a reserve for serverance payments associated with staff reductions and other items. c-After income of $8 million, or 16 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting. d-Net income

title: The Bush Style
description: ''Style,'' said the Comte de Leclerc Buffon upon admission to the French Academy in 1753, ''is the man himself.'' He held that style was not an outer garment or mask, but was essence - that the way you organized and expressed your thoughts was the mark of the kind of person you were.

title: Review/Cabaret;   Rosemary Clooney Plus Six
description: The star quality of Rosemary Clooney has rarely been made more evident than in the show in which she opened on Tuesday evening at Rainbow and Stars, on the 65th floor of the RCA Building.

title: Good Gains For Stores Last Month
description: Many of the nation's biggest retailers reported yesterday that their fiscal year ended with generally good sales gains in January.

title: Bush's Quandary on Forces in Europe
description: The Bush Administration insisted today that it will maintain American troop strength in Europe at 225,000, the new level proposed by President Bush in his State of the Union address Wednesday night. But the pace of political change at home and abroad seems likely to make that position untenable in short order.

title: No Place for Sentimental Journalism on AIDS
description: LEAD: The press is always in the cross hairs of somebody's shotgun.

title: 2 Tobacco Dealers Set Merger Accord
description: Two of the nation's largest private tobacco dealers have agreed to merge. The Austin Company, based in Greeneville, and A. C. Monk & Company of Farmville, N.C., said they would form a holding company. No price was disclosed. A name for the new company has not yet been selected, said to Sam J. Calvert Jr., Austin's chairman.

title: Maytag Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $19,481,000, or 26 cents a share, for the quarter and $23,040,000, or 30 cents a share, for the year.

title: William Q. Mooney, Executive, 81
description: William Quirk Mooney, a former vice president of the Shell Chemical Company, a division of the Shell Oil Company, died on Jan. 25 at his home in Kent, Conn. He was 81 years old.

title: Gillette Is Planning to Open A Plant in the Soviet Union
description: In a bid to become the Soviet Union's major Western supplier of razor blades, the Gillette Company said yesterday that it had tentatively agreed to build a $50 million factory capable of making 800 million blades a year, or 80 percent of the total exported annually to the Soviet Union.

title: O'Sullivan Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MacLean Hunter reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credits of $1.9 million, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and year. c-After an extraordinary credit of $1.3 million, or 1 cent a share. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Shifrin and Quartet
description: David Shifrin, the clarinetist, is to play the Mozart Clarinet Quintet (K. 581) with the Fine Arts Quartet at Weill Recital Hall tonight at 8. The quartet - Ralph Evans and Efrim Boico, violinists; Jerry Horner, violist, and Wolfgang Laufer, cellist -will also perform Joaquin Turina's ''Oracion del Torero'' (Op. 35) and the Franck Quartet in D. Tickets are $15. Information: 247-7800.

title: Daniel J. Conroy, 73, An Investment Banker
description: Daniel J. Conroy, retired managing director of William Sword & Company, investment bankers, in Princeton, N.J., died Tuesday at his home in a retirement community in Jamesburg, N.J., after a long illness. He was 73 years old.

title: European Community Remolding Polish Ties
description: The executive body of the European Community said today that it was seeking to bring Eastern European countries into a closer economic and social relationship with the 12-nation Common Market.

title: Creditors' Committees Set
description: Two committees representing the unsecured creditors of Federated Stores Inc. were formed yesterday by Conrad Morgenstern, the United States Trustee overseeing the bankruptcy proceedings.

title: Westmoreland Coal Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $1,640,000, or 20 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change from adoption of SFAS 96.

title: Review/Film;   Liberal Old vs. Conservative Young in 'Flashback'
description: About 30 minutes before it's over, ''Flashback'' begins to go to pieces, like someone who has overdosed on carrot juice and organic marzipan. The movie becomes woozy and sort of distraught. Until then, it's an engaging comedy about the confrontation of a superannuated flower child of the 1960's and a 26-year-old representative of the clean-shaven, cholesterol-conscious, fiercely conservative 1980's.

title: Eli Lilly Earnings Rise; Upjohn Reports a Loss
description: Eli Lilly & Company said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings grew by double digits over the previous year, helped by higher unit sales in United States and foreign markets. The Upjohn Company, meanwhile, said it had a $118 million loss in the quarter, reflecting the costs of a previously announced restructuring.

title: Gold Makes Quick Rebound From Wednesday's Plunge
description: Gold prices roared back today after falling sharply on Wednesday when it was reported that the Treasury had asked the International Monetary Fund to sell at least a million ounces of gold to offset late payments by 11 countries.

title: Imperial Oil Sale
description: Imperial Oil Ltd. has agreed to sell the Atlantic assets of Texaco Inc.'s Canadian division to meet competition concerns raised by an antitrust tribunal last week, an antitrust official said. The quasi-judicial Competition Tribunal ruled last week that Imperial's $5 billion (Canadian) takeover of Texaco Canada Inc. could proceed only if it sold Texaco's Atlantic assets or if it proved that the buyer of a smaller package could compete effectively. ''This should satisfy all the concerns of the Jan. 26 decision,'' the Competition Bureau official said.

title: American Barrick Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company's share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split that took effect in December. Included in the 1989 fourth quarter was a non-recurring charge of $11 million for the investment in Hayes Resources Inc.

title: Ventra Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said year-ago figures were not available. The company last year changed its fiscal year-end to Sept. 30 from Nov. 30. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Panama Crime Wave Shakes Faith in Police
description: A growing crime wave in and around the capital in recent weeks, some of it the work of men carrying assault rifles, has stirred widespread worry about how soon Panama's new police force will be ready to take over law-enforcement duties from American troops.

title: Review/Film;   Of a Platoon Lost in a Vietnamese Jungle
description: ''Dog Tags'' must have been built from a do-it-yourself kit for Vietnam exploitation films. Every cheap cliche is there, tossed on the screen in ramshackle order. There is the platoon stranded in the jungle - a movie location that is clearly the lush, emerald Philippines, without a rice paddy in sight. There are the American P.O.W.'s who escape from a bamboo cage. And don't forget the soldier who goes raving crazy, the child Vietcong (''Me no Charlie!'' he cries) and the soldier whose leg is amputated by his buddies. ''Al, I feel funny,'' he observes, to which Al can only say: ''The leg's gotta come off. Just smoke the dope and go to sleep. When you wake up it'll be over.'' He wakes to find a gorgeous Vietnamese woman making him feel better.

title: N.C.A.A. Clears Ware
description: Andre Ware's weekend trip to the Super Bowl as a guest of the Houston Oiler quarterback Warren Moon did not violate National Collegiate Athletic Association rules, nor did the Heisman Trophy winner's attendance at a party given by Moon's agent, the N.C.A.A. has ruled.

title: Sun Distributors L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Coca-Cola Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a pretax gain of $11 million on the sale of a bottling operation. c-Included a pretax restructuring charge of $27 million and a pretax gain of $103,800,000 on the sale of a bottling operation for both the quarter and year. Share earnings are after preferred stock dividends of $18,217,000 in 1989 and $9,882,000 in 1988.

title: Diplomats Report China's Premier Will Visit Soviet Union in April
description: Prime Minister Li Peng of China is scheduled to visit the Soviet Union in April, in an effort to improve relations between the two nations, foreign diplomats in Beijing say.

title: Market Place;   Ship Companies 'Born to Die'
description: IN the late 1970's, after spending much of his career in real estate, Michael S. Hudner turned his attention to shipping, an industry that had suffered several protracted downturns but that he believed was due for a recovery. In an attempt to persuade skeptical investors, he constructed a new investment vehicle, whose management would not be allowed to invest in new ships or other ventures once it had spent the original amount raised in a public offering.

title: John Hancock Investors Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The net income figures represented net investment income.

title: Every Leveraged Buyout Shakes the Economy;   We're All Losers
description: To the Editor:

title: Is Campeau Himself Bankrupt?
description: Robert Campeau's audacious, but characteristic, move in betting his financial empire on the value of his Campeau Corporation stock now seems to have been his undoing. By most available accounts, his personal fortune of $500 million has all but evaporated before his eyes as the stock, worth $41 a share (Canadian) two and half years ago, is now at $2.40 on the Toronto exchange.

title: Roto-Rooter Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an accounting adjustment gain of $282,000, or 6 cents a share.

title: Strickland Fumes As Knicks Prevail
description: The Knicks played as poorly last night as they did in losing six of their previous seven games. Fortunately for them, the opposition was the Sacramento Kings.

title: Peru Rebels Kill 2 Officials
description: Maoist guerrillas shot to death the deputy mayors of two Andean villages who were members of the Democratic Front, the opposition coalition of presidential candidate Mario Vargas Llosa, the police said. The Shining Path rebels left notes on both bodies that said: ''This is how the new starvers of the people die,'' the police said. They said a group of 15 guerrillas entered the town of San Juan de Iscos, 140 miles east of Lima, before dawn Wednesday, dragged the Deputy Mayor from his home and shot him in the town square. The same guerrillas killed the Deputy Mayor of Ahuac, 130 miles east of Lima, on Monday night, the police said.

title: LEGISLATION EASES LIMITS ON ALIENS
description: In yet another sign of diminishing world tensions, the Senate this week gave final Congressional approval to repealing a provision of a McCarthy-era law that bars foreigners from visiting the United States because of their political beliefs.

title: Congressman in Sex Case Bitterly Attacks Critics
description: In a bitter speech on the House floor, an Illinois Congressman declared today that the House ethics committee had decided not to take any disciplinary action against him after investigating charges of sexual improprieties.

title: Books of The Times;   A Mother's Grip That Reaches Beyond the Grave
description: Passing On

title: De Klerk Weighs Changes in Apartheid
description: President F. .W. de Klerk today put final touches on a major speech to Parliament Friday that could throw light on his plans to release Nelson Mandela, the African National Congress leader, from prison.

title: McCaw Loses $58.4 Million
description: McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. said yesterday that it had lost $58.4 million in the fourth quarter.

title: Judges Can't Agree About Illegal Evidence
description: To the Editor:

title: At the Movies
description: Dennis Hopper's Plans

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Marketing Campaign By Airborne Express
description: Airborne Express, which has refrained from active participation in the advertising wars fought by its rivals the United Parcel Service and the Federal Express Corporation, is joining the fray, with Mandelbaum Mooney Ashley as its new marketing partner. The $15 million San Francisco agency would not disclose billings for the account.

title: 'Tough Call' for Police on When to Fire
description: In the adrenaline-charged moment before a police officer fires at a suspect, the officer must decide, often without solid information, whether the suspect is armed and presents an ''immediate threat'' to others, according to New York City Police Department guidelines and law-enforcement experts.

title: Atlantic Energy Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
S.E.C. Looks At Interstate
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun an ''informal inquiry'' into First Interstate Bancorp's $400 million write-down during the fourth period to cover possible losses at the company's troubled Texas operations.

title: Drop in Compaq Profits Is Less Than Expected
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation, the Houston-based maker of portable business and personal computers, said today that earnings fell 14.1 percent in the fourth quarter, to $79 million, or $1.84 a share. Most Wall Street analysts had anticipated a steeper decline because of statements by Compaq last November that earnings in the period would be below expectations.

title: New Jersey Court Calls Breathalyzer Test Valid
description: Breathalyzer results may continue to be accepted as valid evidence in drunken driving trials in New Jersey, the State Supreme Court has ruled.

title: AZERBAIJAN TALKS STARTING IN LATVIA
description: With an air of low-budget pomp and protocol, political insurgents from four Soviet republics converged on this Baltic capital today to begin peace talks aimed at resolving the Armenian-Azerbaijani civil conflict.

title: Witco Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge of $43,230,000 primarily related to reserves for environmental projects and plant shutdowns. c-Included a charge of $11,440,000 related to the writedown of investments in foreign affiliates, and reserves for environmental projects and plant shutdowns recorded in the first quarter; and also included an accounting adjustment gain of $20,289,000, or 81 cents a share, from the cumulative effect on prior periods of an accounting change. d-Net income

title: Review/Theater;   Accidental Actress: An Encore For Grenfell
description: The spirit of Joyce Grenfell - that of the amateur, the gym teacher, who suddenly finds herself in professional theatrical company - is evoked with congeniality in Maureen Lipman's ''Re:Joyce!,'' now in its United States premiere engagement at the Long Wharf Theater.

title: Hannaford Bros. Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Included $1,874,000 gain on change in accounting method.

title: The Name of the Artist
description: To the Editor:

title: On Stage
description: 3 for Lawrence and Lee

title: Restaurants
description: La Cite

title: Harold E. Fey, 91; A Writer and Editor On Religious Topics
description: The Rev. Harold E. Fey, an author, educator and former editor of religious journals, died of congestive heart failure on Tuesday at Pomona Valley Hospital in California. He was 91 years old and lived in Claremont, Calif.

title: Where Classics Are King And Theaters Their Court
description: MOSS HART once wrote that the best way to get even with a producer is to talk him into doing an Ibsen revival.

title: Budget Proposal Lists Estimates On Productivity
description: The preliminary budget that Mayor David N. Dinkins proposed yesterday is based in part on the city's ability to come up with $172 million in ''productivity'' gains in the next 18 months, including $40 million that still has to be identified.

title: Telxon Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a tax loss of $20,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $72,000 for the year. c-Net income and included tax credits of $160,000, or 1 cent a share, and $434,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Latest quarter results included charges taken as part of the company's continuing efforts to reduce its cost structure. Specifically, the third quarter results reflected the following charges: $1 million for severance and other reorganization costs; $900,000 in adjustments to reflect principally two customer accounts deemed uncollectible; and $900,000 in inventory adjustments.

title: Ottawa Orchestra
description: Gabriel Chumra is to conduct the National Arts Center Orchestra of Ottawa in the New York premiere of Michael Colgrass's ''Schubert Birds,'' Haydn's Symphony No. 85 in B flat (''La Reine''), Schubert's Fifth Symphony and the Nielsen Clarinet Concerto at Carnegie Hall on Sunday at 3 P.M. Richard Stoltzman is to be the soloist in the Nielsen. Tickets are $10 to $40. Information: 247-7800.

title: Engelhard Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a special charge of $237 million relating to exiting of businesses and restructuring of on-going operations for both the quarter and year. c-Net income The company said it took a $160.4 million charge against 1989 fourth quarter results to streamline the company's businesses, reduce its on-going operating costs and improve prospects for increasing shareholder value. The charge consists of $110 million relating to the exiting of businesses and $50.4 million to restructure on- going operations.

title: Rayonier Timberlands L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Net income represents partnership income. Share earnings are in units. The company said its partnership income included reductions for foreign sales commissions to an ITT Rayonier Inc. affiliate that are not allocated to the publicly traded class A units. In addition, class A units share only 95 percent of the primary account income-expenses and 4 percent of the secondary account income-expense. Cash available to the Class A units was $4.01 a unit in 1989 compared to $3.42 a unit in 1988. Rayonier Timberlands said ITT Rayonier, a unit of ITT Corp., owns 74.7 percent of its class A units.

title: Univision Misses Payment
description: Univision Holdings Inc., the New York-based company that operates the country's largest Spanish-language television network and owns nine television stations, said last night that it had failed to make interest payments due yesterday of about $3 million to its bank lenders and about $7 million to holders of subordinated debentures. The company said it had ''insufficient cash flow.''

title: Roaring Back With Microphone in Hand
description: In his 22 years as a professional golfer, Johnny Miller moved from prodigy to pretender, from being the best to burned out to back from the dead. Most memorably, for three years in the mid-1970's, he produced perhaps the most flawless golf ever played.

title: Bulgarian Government Quits In Party Strife Over Change
description: The Communist Government of Bulgaria resigned on Thursday night in a party power struggle over how far the governing Communists will go to revise their party.

title:
LAW;

A California Innovation: Dial-a-Lawyer
description: LEAD: Thanks to the latest innovation in attorney-client relationships, Californians with legal problems or questions can now reach out and touch a lawyer.

title: Foodbusters
description: The American Heart Association is awarding its seal of approval to foods it deems beneficially low in cholesterol, salt and fat. The Food and Drug Administration, stung by the trespass on its turf, has told the association to desist. The unfitting shootout between these two custodians of public fitness at least draws attention to the deepening confusion over food health claims.

title: Weyerhaeuser Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $270,444,000, which included a $298,057,000 charge for restructuring and a $27,613,000 gain on the sale of businesses. c-Included an extraordinary loss of $260,336,000, which included a $320,784,000 charge for restructuring, a $29,584,000 gain on the sale of businesses and a $30,864,000 gain on sale of common stock of a subsidiary. d-Net income Year-ago fourth quarter and full- year results have been restated to reflect implementation of an accounting change. Latest fourth-quarter included 14 weeks while the year-ago quarter included 13 weeks. Latest year included 53 weeks while the year- ago full year included 52 weeks.

title: Review/Opera;   Second Round of 'Traviata'
description: Verdi's ''Traviata'' has been performed 526 times at the Metropolitan Opera. It is unlikely that many of the first 525 were as emotionally and vocally empty as the performance that tumbled through Franco Zeffirelli's overstuffed staging on Monday evening. Even Alfredo Kraus, one of the company's principal assets these days, was powerless to raise the performance to a level of passable mediocrity.

title: Corrections
description: Four recent articles in Business Day about the bankruptcy filing of Federated Stores Inc. - one on Jan. 20, one on Jan. 23 and two on Tuesday - misidentified the United States trustee who is overseeing the proceedings. He is Conrad Morgenstern.

title: Vaclav Havel Discusses New Role With Barbara Walters
description: Tonight, Vaclav Havel achieves celebrity. Known to some as a playwright and to others as the new President of a new Czechoslovakia, he will now be known to millions more as a person worthy of being interviewed by Barbara Walters. The encounter, described by ABC as the first interview Mr. Havel has given on American television since becoming President, takes up about half of a 16-minute segment about Czechoslovakia on tonight's edition of ''20/20,'' between 10 and 11 on ABC.

title: Nipsco Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included estimated costs of about $5.4 million associated with a work force reduction program for both periods, and after an extraordnary loss of $51,661,000 for the quarter and year to cover court-ordered refund to customers, related to amounts collected for a cancelled nuclear plant. c-Net income

title: Our Towns;   When Recycling Means Too Much Of a Good Thing
description: ''You always have some people who don't want to get with the program,'' Bob Sefchek observed with a shake of his head as he nudged his van through the streets of this neat suburban community, behind a work crew putting recycling baskets on the steps and porches of 1,200 homes.

title: Information Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,356,000 for the quarter and $9,144,000 for the year; the year also included a gain of $1.5 million, or 9 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting, and restructuring charges of $5 million. c-Net income and after losses from discontinued operations of $661,000 for the quarter and $1,180,000 for the year.

title: Chrysler Closing Set In St. Louis
description: In a surprise move that will reduce its car-making capacity by about 20 percent, the Chrysler Corporation said today that it would permanently close its suburban St. Louis car assembly plant, laying off about 3,700 workers.

title: H.U.D. Suspends a Top Landlord
description: One of the nation's largest owners of subsidized housing has been suspended from future Government work because of a fraud investigation, the Department of Housing and Urban Development said today.

title: Top U.S. Drug Agent in New York Resigns
description: Robert M. Stutman, the outspoken top Federal drug agent in New York, said yesterday that he would leave office at the end of the month and hinted that when he did he would criticize Federal drug policy.

title: Anxiety Over Anti-Semitism Spurs Soviet Warning on Hate
description: Renewed anxiety that anti-Semitism is surging once more in the Soviet Union has prompted Government officials to start cautioning nationalist and ethnic organizations against provocations toward hatred and pogroms.

title: E-Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $7 million after-tax gain from the proceeds of an insurance policy.

title: Review/Music;   Rockabilly, Dangerously
description: In the mid-1950's, rockabilly must have sounded noisy and frantic and sloppy and dangerous - just the way the Flat Duo Jets sounded Tuesday night when they performed at the Lone Star Roadhouse. In the three-man band from Raleigh, N.C., Dexter Romweber sings old rockabilly sentiments - about girls who drive him insane, about loving them all night long - with the baritone drawl and chesty vibrato of Elvis Presley. He plays all the chords and squiggles and twangs that have been rock guitar essentials for 35 years.

title: Every Leveraged Buyout Shakes the Economy;   Where Was Uncle Sam?
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Moves to Pluralism
description: The Rumanian and Bulgarian rulers agreed to give up one-party control. A 30-party coalition is planned in Bucharest, and the Communists in Sofia said they would seek a broad-based Cabinet. Page A13.

title: Schools Plan: Big Goals, Little Money
description: Meeting the education goals that President Bush outlined Wednesday night would be as hard a task as any the United States has faced, requiring a commitment to new ideas and new money that many educators say the President has so far failed to demonstrate. By the year 2000, Mr. Bush said, the United States should lead other nations in math and science, drastically reduce dropout rates, eliminate illiteracy, insure that every child is ready to enter school and make sure schools are disciplined and drug-free.

title: Moscow's Envoy to Manila Urges U.S.-Soviet Navy Cuts
description: A Soviet diplomat called today for talks on cutting Soviet and American naval forces, particularly in the Asia-Pacific region, and he warned that a continued buildup at sea could cause serious strategic instability.

title: Eugene J. Anspach Jr., Executive, 74
description: Eugene J. Anspach Jr., former president of Anspach Brothers, a chain of opticians with headquarters in East Orange, N.J., died on Jan. 25 at Grossmont Hospital in La Mesa, Calif. He lived in La Jolla, Calif., and was 74 years old.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Yes, One Job Can Bring Prosperity
description: ONE of the most talked-about commercials of recent months is the spot for Honda in which a man visiting an art gallery examines an Accord that is hanging in front of him like a painting - and then, defying gravity, he climbs in and drives the car right off the wall.

title: Stride Rite Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 1
description: b-Included a loss fromdiscontinued operations of $494,000. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $2,827,000 and $4,677,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; the year also included an accounting adjustment gain of $1,723,000, or 6 cents a share.

title: At 15th St. Condo, an English Touch
description: A new 23-story condominium called the Grosvenor House, at 22 West 15th Street between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas, may not have all the English embellishments of the London hotel of the same name. But it apparently has enough to help it sell fairly well in a generally slow market. In nine months, well over 50 percent of the units, 77 of 134, have been sold.

title: Hilton Stock Off on Inaction
description: The shares of the Hilton Hotels Corporation fell $3.25 each today, to $58.50, after the company's directors took no action on several takeover offers.

title: DINKINS PROPOSES 'PAINFUL' BUDGET OF $27.8 BILLION
description: Asserting that New York City faces ''very painful consequences'' and sacrifices that could grow even more severe, Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday presented a $27.8 billion spending plan that calls for tax increases and deep cuts in services to close a budget gap of more than $1 billion.

title: Diphtheria Inoculations Set
description: Health officials are preparing to vaccinate up to 20,000 Dade County preschool children after a 2-year-old boy died of a rare case of highly infectious diphtheria. Diphtheria, which is marked by a serious sore throat, a thick gray-yellow coating at the back of the throat and a low-grade fever, is treated with a strong antibiotic, and a vaccine in use since 1928 is considered highly effective. Starting Monday, the vaccine will be provided free at public clinics. No shortage of either the vaccine or antibiotic is expected.

title: John Hancock Income SecuriFties Tr reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Net income figures represented net investment income.

title: Study Sees Multiple Benefits in Certain Fats
description: Mono-unsaturated fats like olive oil may benefit the heart not only by lowering cholesterol but also by reducing blood pressure and blood sugar, a study in Italy has suggested.

title: Play Set for U.S. Soccer
description: With some hard feelings over contracts still evident, the United States national soccer team returns to competition this weekend after two months off, joining Costa Rica, Colombia and Uruguay in the Marlboro Cup of Miami.

title: Grace (W.R.) & Co.  (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,573,000 and $3,463,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $20,064,000, or 23 cents a share, for the quarter and $36,700,000, or 43 cents a share, for the year, and the year also included income of $4,854,000, or 6 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The company said latest quarter figures included a gain of $2.8 million related to a tax credit. The quarter also included the reversal of previously accrued charges for stock appreciation rights. The company did not disclose a specific figure for the reversal. Latest full-year net from continuing operations included a non-recurring gain of $62 million from the restructuring of its energy-related operations. Year-ago full-year results included a $4.6 million gain related to a tax credit.

title: Review/Film;   Jessica Lange As a Widow Waking Up To Problems
description: There is something so reassuring about the way John Macauley can pound on the back of a noisy refrigerator and somehow make the worrisome racket go away. And only 10 minutes into ''Men Don't Leave,'' that reassurance is gone. John is killed in an accident, leaving his widow, Beth (Jessica Lange), to raise their two sons and to discover just how heavily she always depended on John's support.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Boeing Co., Seattle, received orders totaling $1 billion from Japan Air System, Tokyo, and Qantas Airways, Australia.

title: Mendelssohn Cycle
description: Anthony Newman will play the complete organ works of Felix Mendelssohn at Holy Trinity Episcopal Church, 316 East 88th Street, on Sunday afternoon at 5. Mendelssohn's organ canon includes six sonatas, composed in 1844 and 1845, as well as fantasias, fugues, chorale settings and individual movements. Tickets are $8. Information: 860-2077.

title: Owners Say They're Serious About Possibility of a Lockout
description: In case he had not made himself perfectly clear before, the baseball owners' chief negotiator reiterated yesterday a major element of the owners' bargaining strategy. If the players and owners do not reach some sort of agreement by the scheduled start of spring training, Charles O'Connor said, ''the camps will not open.''

title: O'Connor, Vaughan, Cuomo, Al Smith, J.F.K.
description: As a veteran of the 1960 campaign, I thank heaven that Bishop Austin Vaughan and John Cardinal O'Connor were not sounding off when John F. Kennedy was running for President.

title: Flightsafety International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Every Leveraged Buyout Shakes the Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Ribi Immunochem Research reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Post for Nigel Lawson
description: Nigel Lawson, who resigned abruptly as Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer in October, has been named a director of Barclays Bank P.L.C., the bank said today. Mr. Lawson, 57 years old, will continue as a Conservative Party Member of Parliament and also serve as a part-time adviser to the bank. Barclays declined to disclose how much he would be paid. He said the new position ''fits well with my plans to write a book and remain in politics.''

title: McCaw Cellular CommunicaFtions Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   New Officer at BSB
description: Hoping to add creative flair to an agency that many advertising executives say has grown a bit stale, Backer Spielvogel Bates has apparently lured Peter Murphy from his post as executive creative director of Hal Riney & Partners in San Francisco, advertising executives say. In a novel twist, Mr. Murphy, who left Marschalk/New York in 1986 to take the West Coast creative position, will take the title of executive vice presi-dent/copywriter at BSB.

title: Review/Art;   Bob Thompson's Figures and Abstractions, Religion and Myth
description: The painter Bob Thompson died in 1966 at the age of 28, having spent less than a decade getting all he could out of the New York art scene and the great museums of Italy and France, and putting it to immediate use. It's hard to say if he reached absolute maturity as an artist; the exhibition of his work from the early 1960's at the Vanderwoude Tananbaum Gallery is often uneven. Still, his art brims with talent, fearlessness and the refusal to close off any options.

title: Cuban Heads U.N. Council
description: Cuba's delegate to the United Nations, Ricardo Alarcon de Quesada, took over the presidency of the Security Council today, the first time a Cuban has held the post since 1957. Cuba was elected by the General Assembly late last year to a two-year Council term that began on Jan. 1, the first time it has obtained a seat on the 15-nation body since before Fidel Castro came to power in 1959. The Council's presidency rotates monthly according to the English alphabetical order of its members.

title: Review/Film;   Case of a Haunted Cop With a Second-Hand Heart
description: ''Heart Condition,'' which is supposed to be funny, is a buddy film about a man and a ghost, heart trouble, surgical transplants, greasy food, racial bigotry, a whore with a heart of gold, political scandal, the resiliency of transplanted hearts, cats, and drug pushers. That is, among other things. It is really quite bad. The stars are Bob Hoskins and Denzel Washington. James D. Parriott, whose background is television, wrote and directed the film, his first theatrical feature.

title: For an Ailing Honecker, Two Strange Bedfellows
description: As head of East Germany's Communist Party for nearly 20 years, Erich Honecker had little use for the Lutheran Church, and he presided over a Government that held thousands of political prisoners.

title: Every Leveraged Buyout Shakes the Economy;   The Business of Banks
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Commander in Azerbaijan Sees Troop Pullback Starting Soon
description: The Soviet military commander here expressed hope today that troops could begin returning home by mid-February and that authorities could lift a curfew imposed after violent ethnic clashes in Azerbaijan.

title: Weirton Steel Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $12,595,000 from the extinguishment of debt. c-Net loss

title: Connecticut Agency Budgets Cut
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill today ordered a 2 percent budget cut for most state agencies starting April 1, following a State Comptroller's report putting the state's deficit at $90.1 million, up from $65 million just last month.

title: Caesars Sees A Profit Drop For Quarter
description: After a run of bad luck at the gambling tables, Caesars World Inc. said today that it expected to report drastically reduced earnings for the quarter ended Jan. 31.

title: Court's New Couple: Connors and Evert
description: The chance for a reunion with an old friend and an opportunity to fulfill a longstanding dream have led Jimmy Connors to pass up Wimbledon. Instead of playing in this year's tournament, Connors, who has played in every Wimbledon since his first in 1972, will join Chris Evert for broadcast-booth duty.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The former Surgeon General of the United States, DR. C. EVERETT KOOP, will receive this year's Harry S. Truman Award for Public Service. The award is presented by Independence, Mo., the hometown of the former President, to an American with the qualities personified by Truman.

title: Experimental as Always, P.S. 122 Completes a Decade
description: Performance Space 122 is calling its annual benefit ''Dress Up'' this year. But the audience is not expected to arrive in tuxedos and tails or evening dresses for the four-day festival of new music and dance and performance art, which opened yesterday and runs through Sunday. Instead, audience members are likely to sport anything from the latest in East Village fashions to blue jeans and work shirts. And that is typical of the history and message of P.S. 122, the high-spirited theater complex that is celebrating its 10th anniversary this year.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Ameritech Consolidates
description: Ameritech, the Chicago-based parent company of five Bell telephone companies and of other information technology companies, announced that it was consolidating $30 million to $35 million in spot broadcast media buying with Bayer Bess Vanderwarker in Chicago, which handles Ameritech's corporate advertising. Bayer Bess won the assignment over Ross Roy Advertising, the agency for Michigan Bell; Tatham-Laird & Kudner, the agency for Illinois Bell, and CPM Inc. and Western International, two media buying services.

title: Allen Barke, Ex-Ford Executive, 86
description: Allen Barke, former chief executive of the British subsidiary of Ford, died on Monday. He was 86 years old. The cause of his death was not given. Mr. Barke became director of Ford's product division in 1959 when the company's plants were being increasingly hit by wildcat strikes. In 1965 he contracted hepatitis, and soon after his health forced him to resign.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JOHN C. SAWHILL is the new president of the Nature Conservancy, which protects endangered plants and animals by preserving the places they live in. Mr. Sawhill, 52 years old, was head of the Federal Energy Administration in 1974 and was a Deputy Secretary of Energy from 1979 to 1980. He was president of New York University from 1975 to 1979.

title: Economic Effect of Cutting Troops in Europe Assessed
description: Troop reductions of the type proposed by President Bush would temporarily disrupt the local economy in parts of West Germany, but would have negligible effects on the civilian economy of the United States, experts said today.

title: Fetal Tissue Seems to Aid Parkinson Patient
description: An implant of fetal cells into the brain of a man with Parkinson's disease has alleviated his symptoms, researchers say in a report being published today.

title: Ruling Sought on 'Baskets'
description: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission said today that his agency intends to ask Congress to settle a jurisdictional dispute between Federal regulators of stock and futures trading about a new type of trading instrument.

title: Dow Slips In Slower Trading
description: Stock prices ended narrowly mixed yesterday amid sharply slower trading.

title: Domtar Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $9,000,000, or 10 cents a share, for the quarter and $18,000,000, or 20 cents a share, for the year. c-Net income d-Included income from discontinued operations of $3,000,000, or 3 cents a share, and $8,000,000, or 9 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Diner's Journal
description: His Kind of Food

title: 3 Outsiders Appointed To First Fidelity Posts
description: Anthony P. Terracciano , who was named chairman of the First Fidelity Bancorporation in mid-January, wasted no time in asserting his control. Yesterday, in his first day in office, Mr. Terracciano appointed three outside executives to top positions in the company, the 21st-largest banking company in the country.

title: Guerrilla Jailbreak Tests Chile's President-Elect
description: By staging a jailbreak this week, leftist guerrillas accused of a deadly assault on President Augusto Pinochet's motorcade in 1986 and other acts of violence have thrown a tough challenge to President-elect Patricio Aylwin.

title: Modest Medicine for the City
description: New York's Mayor, David Dinkins, has produced a financial plan that begins to come to grips with the city's troubled finances. But that grip may not be tight enough.

title: It's Time That Winds of Change Reached India;   No Claims by Pakistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Sierra On-Line Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $147,000, or 4 cents a share, and $895,000, or 30 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: New Jersey Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Braintree Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Eaton Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $9,700,000, or 26 cents a share, for the quarter and $15,200,000, or 41 cents a share, for the year. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $800,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $2,300,000, or 6 cents a share, for the year, and the year also included an extraordinary charge of $17,700,000 for provision of $26.9 million, before income tax credits of $9.2 million, for a jury award and accumulated interest, resulting from a lawsuit originally filed in 1976 against a business acquired by the company in 1978. The company said included in both the year-ago quarter and year income from discontinued operations is a provision of $43 million, before income tax credits of $14.6 million, for losses on its naval automated test systems subcontract for the U.S. government as a result of revised estimated costs to complete the contract. Also included is a tax benefit of $31 million, primarily due to the tax on income related to long-term contracts becoming payable in 1988 at a lower tax rate than was used in prior years to provide related deferred taxes.

title: Tool Retesting At McDonnell
description: A subsidiary of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation is retesting 244 master tools it made for use in the assembly of C-17 transport planes, the Air Force said today.

title: Norwich Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included loan loss provisions of $4.8 million for the quarter and $9.2 million for the year. c-Net income

title: Senate and White House Start Clean Air Talks
description: Senior Administration officials have begun discussions with Senate leaders to resolve serious differences between changes proposed for the Clean Air Act by President Bush and legislation that is now before the Senate.

title: Review/Opera;   The Long-Absent 'Faust Returns With Gothic Touches
description: Because Gounod's ''Faust,'' once the most inescapable of operas, dropped out of favor several decades ago, a generation has grown up not knowing it. The Metropolitan Opera's new production will not seriously change that. The premiere on Thursday evening must have left youngsters wondering, not at the work's absence from the repertory, but at its reappearance.

title: Pinochet Gets Role in Inauguration of New Leader
description: After initially seeking ways to avoid taking power directly from Gen. Augusto Pinochet, President-elect Patricio Aylwin has agreed to inaugural plans that include a full ceremonial role for the departing military ruler.

title: Donald Burr, 66, Dies; Led Cosmetics Concern
description: Donald D. Burr, a former cosmetics company executive, died of cancer on Thursday at the H.C.A. Medical Center of Port St. Lucie, Fla. He was 66 years old and lived in Stuart, Fla.

title: Your Money;   Planning Now For '90 Taxes
description: As taxpayers go over their financial records in this tax season, they should see what changes they can make in their personal finances to reduce their tax bill a year from now.
