title: Upheaval in the East: Soviet Union;   Azerbaijanis Begin Talks With Armenians on Peace
description: Representatives of the Armenians and Azerbaijanis opened peace talks today in the capital of Soviet Latvia and immediately found common ground, as both sides criticized the Kremlin for sending troops to their southern region.

title: Beliefs
description: For many Americans, abortion is the most intractable moral issue facing the political system, and the result is that they despair of morality or they despair of politics. Often they end up despairing of both.

title: Upheaval in the East: Bulgaria;   Bulgarian Leader Is Out of Communist Party Job After Stormy Congress
description: Bulgaria's Communist Party chief, Petar Mladenov, was removed from the post today at an emergency party congress that has been struggling to break from the nation's Stalinist past.

title: Gianfranco Contini, Critic, 78
description: Gianfranco Contini, a linguist and literary critic, died on Thursday. He was 78 years old.

title: Flight 52's Crew Spoke in Cockpit Of 'Emergency'
description: Minutes after a missed approach to Kennedy International Airport, the pilot of Avianca Flight 52 asked the co-pilot if he had told air traffic controllers that they had an ''emergency,'' a source told The Associated Press today.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column of Business Day on Wednesday, and a correction in this space yesterday referring to it, misstated the measurement by which the 286 computer chip processes data. It does so in bundles of 16 bits, not bytes or characters. A bit is the smallest unit of information; eight bits equal one byte, the minimum necessary in a computer to define a character (like a letter or a number). The more powerful 386 chip processes data in 32-bit bundles.

title: Lithuanian Breakaway Deserves U.S. Support
description: To the Editor:

title: Indiana Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share earnings and shares outstanding are common and common equivalent shares.

title: Stocks Broadly Higher; Dow Rises 16.44
description: The stock market finished the week on a strong note yesterday on moderately higher volume.

title: Cousins Properties reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included gains on sale of $5,820,000, or 34 cents a share, for the quarter and $6,056,000, or 35 cents a share, for the year. c-Included gains on sale of $65,000, or 1 cent a share, and $321,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said its 1989 results included an after-tax profit of about $5.7 million from a transaction extending a sublease on a parking facility in Atlanta.

title: Lavalin Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian funds.

title: GRC International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $3,500,000 and an extraordinary credit from early extinguishment of debentures of $1,228,300 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income d-After income of $790,000, or 9 cents a share, for the quarter and a loss of $1,287,000 for the 6 months, both from discontinued operations.

title: That Clatterin' Town
description: Peter Cohen, 43, was ''a model of the 1980's breed of bold young leaders of Wall Street,'' according to The New York Times. Tuesday he resigned as boss of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. under pressure from its parent conglomerate, the American Express Company. The Wall Street Journal said his friends had noticed signs of trouble: ''Mr. Cohen was putting on weight and looked as though he was missing sleep.''

title: American Petrofina Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sterling Capital reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: Assets represented net assets and per share figures represented net assets per share. Both results give effect to the company's distributions to shareholders of 57 cents a share paid on Jan. 17 and 9.15 cents a share paid on Sept. 13, 1989.

title: It's Time That Winds of Change Reached India
description: To the Editor:

title: SOUTH AFRICA'S PRESIDENT ENDS 30-YEAR BAN ON MANDELA GROUP; SAYS IT IS TIME FOR NEGOTIATION
description: President F. W. de Klerk today lifted a 30-year ban on the African National Congress, the movement that has been fighting to bring down white minority rule in South Africa, and promised that Nelson Mandela, who has been imprisoned for nearly 28 years, would be freed soon.

title: Orofino Resources reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Included pre-tax writedowns of exploration properties of $11,302,985 for the latest year and $384,886 for 1988. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: ABC and Writers Guild Agree on a Contract
description: Capital Cities/ABC and the Writers Guild of America, East, agreed yesterday on the terms of a three-year contract covering about 150 network and local news writers, editors and other staff members in New York and Washington and graphic artists in Washington. If approved on Monday by the membership, the contract will take effect immediately and run through Feb. 1, 1993.

title: Citytrust Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Koor Debt Accord Reached
description: Foreign and domestic creditor banks of Israel's troubled Koor Industries reached a compromise today to write off nearly $257 million of Koor's debt.

title: Peoples Energy Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included the effect of accounting change of $9.7 million, or 30 cents a share. c-Had the accounting change been made prior to calendar 1988, earnings for the 12-month period would have been $80.7 million, or 48 cents a share. The year-ago results included the effect of a one-time accounting change that increased net income in last year's first quarter by $9.7 million, or 30 cents a share. The Chicago- based holding company adopted the change in fiscal 1989 so that the accounting for monthly revenues would more closely match related costs.

title: Check Technology Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results are restated to reflect adoption of FASB 96.

title: Patents;   Preventing Browning Of Food
description: Researchers at the University of Minnesota obtained a patent this week for a method of preventing the browning of fresh shrimp, and they said it might also work on apples, bananas and potatoes.

title: New Jersey Symphony To Perform in Ireland
description: The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra has been invited to become the resident ensemble of a new two-week music festival this summer in Adare, County Limerick, Ireland. Hugh Wolff, the orchestra's music director, will conduct the festival's opening concerts on July 13 and 14. The program is to include Beethoven's Ninth Symphony and excerpts from his ''Creatures of Prometheus.''

title: Owens-Illinois Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The fourth-quarter sales benefited from the acquisition of the remaining 50 percent interest in United Glass Ltd., the company's affiliate in the United Kingdom, while for the full year this increase was largely offset by the effects of divestitures in the first and second quarters. The net loss for 1989 included an after-tax extraordinary charge of $40.5 million associated with the refinancing of $2.4 billion of bank debt, completed during the second quarter.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Mass Transit, en Masse
description: Transit workers are often lonely. The work of motormen, track walkers, change agents and many managers keeps them apart. That makes all the more valuable the ''transit school'' conducted each year by David Gunn, president of the New York City Transit Authority. He has just done it again, for the last time before leaving office at the end of this month, achieving the usual beneficial boost for managers and riders.

title: Golden Corral Realty Corp.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Strawberrys to Meet With Hearing Officer
description: Darryl and Lisa Strawberry must meet with a hearing officer before the Los Angeles City Attorney's office decides whether to file misdemeanor charges against the Met outfielder for allegedly threatening his wife with a gun last Friday. A spokesman for the City Attorney's office said yesterday that the meeting was scheduled for next Friday.(AP)

title: It's Time That Winds of Change Reached India;   Start With an Election
description: To the Editor:

title: Bank of Boston Revamping
description: The Bank of Boston Corporation, the biggest bank in New England, is streamlining as part of a plan to expand in the region and upgrade its services worldwide, the company's chairman, Ira Stepanian, said today.

title: Cordis Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $661,000 for the quarter and $755,000 for the 6 months.

title: GNI Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included a loss from discontinued operations of $144,160.

title: Lebanese General Seeks to Crush Christian Rival as Talks Collapse
description: Lebanese Army units loyal to Gen. Michel Aoun launched a new offensive today to crush the Lebanese Forces militia after mediation efforts by the Christian rivals failed and a brief truce collapsed.

title: Eastern Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included pretax expenses of $1 million related to environmental clean-up charges, the closing of the company's galvanizing operation and the write-down of idle equipment.

title: Chronicle
description: Declaring it ''one of my best legislative accomplishments,'' an Alaska State Senator, MIKE SZYMANSKI, a Democrat, announced his plans to marry State Senator DRUE PEARCE, a Republican, on Valentine's Day. They plan a private ceremony at the Shrine of St. Therese, a Roman Catholic chapel in Juneau.

title: BUSH APPOINTS 13 TO SCIENCE PANEL
description: President Bush, citing the challenge posed by foreign technological competition, today appointed the 13 scientists and engineers who will make up his long-promised President's Council of Advisers on Science and Technology.

title: A SLOWER O'SULLIVAN WINS WANAMAKER MILE
description: There is something about the mile, especially when Irishmen like Marcus O'Sullivan and Eamonn Coghlan run, that hypnotizes indoor track crowds.

title: NCR and Teradata In Joint Venture
description: The NCR Corporation and the Teradata Corporation said they would form a joint venture to develop parallel processing technology for general purpose business computers. More commonly used in engineering, parallel processing speeds computing by dividing problems between multiple computer processors.

title: Our Financing Impedes Our Technology
description: To the Editor:

title: Novellus Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax loss carryforwards of $551,000 for the quarter and $1,095,000 for the year.

title: Warriors Flash Past Ailing Nets
description: Terry Teagle scored 31 points and Manute Bol blocked a team-record 13 shots tonight as the Golden State Warriors scored a 128-109 victory over the Nets.

title: Ouster of a Whistleblower
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has disclosed that an employee of a long-delayed nuclear power plant southeast of here was dismissed suddenly three months ago after trying to report safety problems to Federal officials. The commission is demanding an explanation.

title: Fight On Cleanup Of Harbor Goes On
description: Long after the last vote was counted in the 1988 Presidential election, Michael S. Dukakis and George Bush remain at odds over one of the issues of the campaign: the cleanup of Boston Harbor.

title: Dawson Geophysical reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
William Muschenheim, An Architect, 87, Dies
description: William Muschenheim, a modernist architect in New York in the 1930's who later taught at the University of Michigan, died of an aneurysm on Thursday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 87 years old and lived in Ann Arbor.

title: Ranger Rookie Wins
description: Mike Richter of the Rangers, who lost only one of seven starts in goal since the start of this year, yesterday was named the National Hockey League rookie of the month for January.

title: Meridian Diagnostics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Flash of Freedom in South Africa
description: South Africa took a giant step yesterday toward joining the community of civilized nations. Offering to replace repression with politics, President F. W. de Klerk announced an astonishing series of moves that could mark the beginning of the end of his country's odious apartheid system and of South Africa's status as an international pariah.

title: Idaho Power Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Concord Computing reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Western Bank-Oregon reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a non-recurring gain of $2,130,000 and an extraordinary credit of $555,000.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The season of violence is over.

title: Chronicle
description: NORMAN MAILER, ALLEN GINSBERG, BARBARA EHRENREICH, LETTY COTTIN POGREBIN and other writers and friends of Abbie Hoffman will celebrate his memory Wednesday at Wetlands, a rock club in downtown Manhattan, with a reading from his works.

title: Battery Park Garden Meets With Less Than Universal Approval
description: To the Editor:

title: Prego's Potential Earnings Put at $30 Million
description: An economist testified yesterday that Dr. Veronica Prego could have earned more than $30 million in a normal career as a doctor if she had not been stricken with AIDS.

title: Noriega May Be Prisoner of War But Can Still Face Trial, U.S. Says
description: The United States Government said in court papers today that although Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega may in fact be a prisoner of war, that would not prevent him from being prosecuted on drug trafficking charges.

title: Utah's Malone Honored
description: Karl Malone of the Utah Jazz, who set a league season high when he scored 61 points Jan. 27 against the Milwaukee Bucks, yesterday was named the Edge National Basketball Association player of the month for January.

description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson repeatedly sought meetings with Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp last year on behalf of an important Jackson fund-raiser and housing financier whose company has become the subject of an investigation by the Department of Housing and Urban Development, agency officials said today.

title: Alex. Brown Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

description: Genentech Inc., the crown jewel of the United States biotechnology industry, said today that it would sell a majority of its shares to a large Swiss health-products company, Roche Holding Ltd.

description: b-Net income Latest quarter and year included loan loss provisions of $18.9 million and $84.4 million, respectively.

title: Car Makers Fight to Reclaim Market in Replacement Parts
description: An embattled automobile industry is mounting a major counteroffensive to reclaim the market for replacement fenders, hoods and other car body parts ruined in accidents.

title: Upheaval in the East: Rumania;   Question in Bucharest: Who's in What Party?
description: To start a political party in Rumania these days, all you need is 251 members, about $1,100 in the bank, an address, a platform and a set of bylaws. Those who met those requirements by Feb. 1 are today part of the interim government that will rule the country until the elections in May.

title: Frontier Adjusters of America reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Linear Technology reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

The company said the latest year's income from continuing operations of $1,721,000, or 54 cents a share reflects a reduction in net income of $1,316,000 relating to the non-recurring charges of the 1989 proxy contest, including the litigation settlement, and a provision for restructuring the company's aviation operations.

title: Bush Would Pay Off U.N. Debt Over 5 Years
description: In his new budget proposals, President Bush has asked Congress to approve a plan for paying off the country's debts to the United Nations and specialized agencies over the next five years, although the United States is likely to remain the largest debtor until the payments are completed.

title: Brazil Fund reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: Assets represented net assets and per share figures---net assets per share .

title: U.S. Stopped by Costa Rica, 2-0
description: The United States national soccer team, which struggled to score goals in qualifying for the 1990 World Cup finals this summer in Italy, struggled again tonight in its first game in more than two months.

title: One on One With Magic And Michael
description: A one-on-one basketball game between Magic Johnson and Michael Jordan, probably the two best and most electric players of the day, would be terrific to see. Mano a mano always is, even if the competitors are refugees from a team sport. But it is Borg versus McEnroe, Ali meeting Frazier, Errol Flynn clanging swords against a sea of pirates.

title: Auto-Trol Technology Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Upheaval in the East;   WORLD VOTE URGED BY SHEVARDNADZE ON GERMAN UNITY
description: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, expressing concern over ''the revival of sinister shadows of the past'' associated with German unification, proposed today that the issue be put to an international referendum.

title: Harmon Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest quarter included a pretax gain of $287,000 from settlement of litigation; latest full-year included a gian of $749,000 from litigation and contract settlements.

title: Chronicle
description: A group of skaters, led by the Olympic champion KEN SHELLEY, have taken over Sky Rink, Manhattan's only full-sized indoor skating rink, and will continue to operate it as a nonprofit training center for figure skaters and hockey players, as well as for recreational use. Sky Rink, which was built in 1967 near Madison Square Garden by the Skating Club of New York, went bankrupt in 1979, and the trustee who has run it has sought a group to operate it. The rink has served as he training ground for Olympic champion figure skaters DOROTHY HAMILL and ELAINE ZAYAK, and BRIAN MULLEN of the New York Rangers.

title: The World Is Moving
description: Questions about South Africa have been like questions about the Soviet Union. Does the leader really mean to change the system? Can he overcome resistance of die-hards? Is the system capable of peaceful fundamental change? Will rulers cede monopoly power? Is it irreversible?

title: Unit of Bond Group Moves Against Parent
description: One of the companies controlled by Alan Bond, the prominent Australian businessman, turned against its parent today, filing court papers that seek to liquidate four Bond group units, including Alan Bond's privately owned Dallhold Investments.

description: b-Included non-recurring merger and restructuring expenses of $1,410,000 related to merger with Digilog Inc. in November. c-Net income

description: Factory orders posted a second consecutive increase in December, rising 1.9 percent because of a surge in orders for civilian aircraft, the Commerce Department said today.

title: In Bogota, Fear, Hope And Finally Only Grief
description: About 10:30 P.M. eight days ago, a friend called the family of Ginneth Tellez to say that the Avianca Airlines plane carrying the young woman to New York had crashed on approach to Kennedy International Airport.

title: Case Against Pregnant Woman Is Dismissed
description: A judge dismissed a felony child abuse complaint against a pregnant woman who drank alcohol, saying the state did not produce probable cause that her fetus had been injured.

title: Six More Reach Accord As Arbitration Starts
description: Salary arbitration hearings began yesterday, with Bo Jackson and the Kansas City Royals arguing almost a million-dollar difference (he wants $1,900,001; the Royals are offering $1 million).

title: Concern on Going Pro
description: Richard Schultz, commissioner of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, met for two and a half hours yesterday with representatives of the National Football League to discuss reports that as many as 40 college football players who are not seniors will turn pro this year.

title: Making Good Time, Deep Thought Loses To Karpov at Chess
description: Anatoly Karpov, the former world chess champion, defeated Deep Thought, the most sophisticated chess program in the world, in just under two hours last night at Harvard University.

Per share results for all periods adjusted for the 3-for-2 stock split paid on Sept. 1, 1989.

India Warns Pakistan on Kashmir But the Unrest Appears to Subside
description: India today resumed its criticism of Pakistan for what it calls interference in the Indian part of the disputed region of Jammu and Kashmir, although the unrest there seems to be subsiding.

title: French Institute to Show Photos of Saint Exupery
description: About 100 photographs of the French aviator and author Antoine de Saint Exupery, taken shortly before his disappearance on a wartime reconnaissance mission in 1944, will be on view from next Friday to March 16 at the French Institute/Alliance Francaise, 22 East 60th Street.

Chronicle
description: Another addition at Harvard Law is $1 million donated by WALTER H. ANNENBERG, the communications magnate and former Ambassador, to supplement salaries of students and recent alumni entering public service. The fellowships are $10,000 each. The endowment was made in honor of JUDGE IRVING R. KAUFMAN of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in Manhattan, who has spent 40 years on the Federal bench. The two men, neither of whom is a Harvard alumnus, were honored at a dinner last week.

title: G.E. Guilty Of Fraud
description: The General Electric Company and two employees were convicted today on several charges of defrauding the Government of $10 million for a battlefield computer system.

title: Protecting Refrigerators From the Cold
description: It sounds illogical, but a cool environment can be harmful to your frost-free refrigerator or freezer.

title: The H.U.D. Investigation So Far
description: April 26, 1989: An internal audit suggests that a number of former H.U.D. officials and prominent Republicans received millions in consulting fees from developers under a program that provided incentives to renovate existing housing for low- and moderate-income families. Following the report Secretary Jack Kemp temporarily suspends the program. Although the audit finds no evidence of criminal wrongdoing, questions arise over procedures for awarding contracts.

title: BUSH WOULD WEIGH EASING SANCTIONS
description: President Bush said today that he would consider a relaxation of American sanctions against South Africa provided that the Pretoria Government follows through on promises to free Nelson Mandela and remove restrictions on the black population.

title: Management Assist. Inc. Liquidating Trust reports earnings for As of Dec 31

title: Justice Dept. Seeks Compromise on Reagan Diaries
description: In a move to avoid a possible constitutional confrontation over executive privilege, the Justice Department today urged a Federal district judge to postpone a Monday deadline ordering former President Ronald Reagan to turn over excerpts from his private diaries to John M. Poindexter, the former national security adviser.

title: PANEL IS CRITICAL OF REPRESENTATIVE
description: The House ethics committee has concluded that Representative Gus Savage, a Chicago Democrat, made ''sexual advances'' toward a female Peace Corps volunteer while he was on an official visit to Africa last March.

title: Hallowell Bowser, Editor, 68
description: Hallowell Bowser, a magazine editor and freelance writer, was found dead, apparently of a heart attack, on Jan. 24 at his home in Manhattan. He was 68 years old.

description: Abigail Cortez, the mother of a 5-year-old girl whose beating death in 1988 drew attention to failures in New York City's child-protection system, pleaded guilty on Thursday to manslaughter in the case, and a judge said she would sentence Mrs. Cortez to 5 to 15 years in prison.

description: Major debuts studded the New York City Ballet's all-Balanchine program Thursday night at the New York State Theater, where several works were new to the repertory season. Rather than spread many ballets out within a week and throughout the season, the company nowadays tends to cluster the same ballets in a short period, picking up with others later.

title: Bridge
description: Perhaps the most confusing auction of the world team championships held in September in Perth, Australia, occurred on the diagramed deal in a match between Colombia and Egypt. East-West bid and raised spades. Then North-South did the same, playing in four spades redoubled.

description: When Benjamin L. Zwirn, the newly elected Town Supervisor of North Hempstead, took office on Jan. 1, part of his office here was missing: a desk, a chair, two computers and a laser printer, to be exact.

title: Review/Pop;   Modern Soukous of Zaire By Three of Four Etoiles
description: Only three of the four Zairian stars who founded Les Quatre Etoiles -the singers Wuta Mayi and Nyboma and the guitarist Syran Mbenza -were on hand when the group performed on Friday night at Kilimanjaro; in the seven-man group, an Angolan bassist, Miguel, deputized for Bopol. There were other letdowns, too, as the first set started typically late and was atypically short, less than an hour. But while the band was onstage, it played expert, enlivening soukous, the Zairian dance music that has conquered West Africa and Paris.

title: Troubled Jet Lands Safely
description: A Northwest Airlines DC-10 bound for Minneapolis with 108 people on board returned safely to Los Angeles International Airport today after the control tower reported flames coming from one of its three engines on takeoff. The crew dumped the plane's fuel. A spokesman for Northwest Airlines said a preliminary examination of the faulty engine indicated that a compressor may have stopped working.

title: Brady Sees Plan Spreading To Other Developing Nations
description: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said today that a debt-reduction package that Mexico is about to sign with its commercial bankers would resolve that country's financial problems for the next three to four years, and predicted that similar agreements would soon be developed for the Philippines and Costa Rica.

title: Costume Jewelry: A Buyer's Guide
description: Costume jewelry, always a popular gift for Valentine's Day, is more popular than ever this year.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost;   A Slice for Each Guest
description: No wedding reception is complete without a cake. Spring and summer weddings are being planned now, and the cake is worth researching. Pastry shops quote prices according to the number of servings and the elaborateness of the decorations. Catering halls and hotels usually charge a flat per-person price for a wedding cake, often including it as part of a package. Some halls and hotels allow cakes to be brought in from the outside, sometimes charging a service fee. Some are willing to order the cake from a specialty baker, who calculates the size of a cake based on a generous slice. Prices range from $2.25 to $3 a person for a ready-made cake to more than $15 a person for an elaborate custom-decorated one. Prices are higher in major cities, especially New York, Washington and Los Angeles. Here is a rough guide: $ Servings Tiers Cost 50 2 $150 to $750 100 2 to 3 $250 to $1,500 150 2 to 4 $375 to $2,500 200 3 to 4 $450 to $3,500

title: Chrysler Workers Skeptical On Detroit Plant's Last Day
description: The Chrysler Corporation shut the doors of its crumbling downtown Jefferson Avenue assembly plant for the last time today, amid an atmosphere of uncertainty among laid-off auto workers. The 3,500 workers are awaiting completion of a factory less than a mile from the old one, and many hope to get jobs there.

No further details were given. Harsco is a diversified industrial company with 13 divisions.

title: Fending Off a New Nightmare in Haiti
description: Ten days of beatings, arrests and expulsions severely compromised Haiti's chances for fair elections this year. But at least Gen. Prosper Avril called off his state of siege 20 days ahead of schedule, following sharp protests from aid-giving nations, including the United States. International protest can be effective.

title: Going on 90, Joseph Fuchs Goes On Making Music
description: ''Look at these hands,'' said the 89-year-old violinist Joseph Fuchs, demonstrating the flexibility of his fingers. ''These are not the hands of an old man. I'd like to go on playing for a while. I don't have any difficulties. When I do, I'll quit, simple as that. It's a matter of pushing against time, and I must say, time has been good to me.''

title: U.S. Seizes Centrust Of Miami
description: Federal regulators today seized Florida's largest savings and loan association, the Centrust Savings Bank in Miami, saying its management was operating irresponsibly and had dissipated assets by buying speculative bonds, art, yachts and Oriental rugs.

title: Hibernia Savings reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Upheaval in the East;   China Bitterly Protests Sanctions by Congress
description: China issued a bitter protest today against a Congressional decision to impose sanctions and said lifting the curbs was a ''necessary condition'' for normalizing relations with the United States.

title: KEY RATES
Art-World Figures Defend Director of Whitney
description: Trustees of the Whitney Museum of American Art have received letters from a number of art-world figures in support of Thomas N. Armstrong 3d, the museum's director, who is under fire from some Whitney trustees. A member of the board and an artist who supports Mr. Armstrong said assertions of anti-Semitism had figured in the discussions - assertions they dismissed.

title: Japan's Trade Surplus Cut
description: Record spending by Japanese abroad, higher oil imports and a strong dollar helped cut Japan's trade surplus in 1989 to its lowest level in four years, but economists here said today that the trend was set to reverse in 1990.

title: Pain Lingers for Poorer Victims of Hurricane Hugo
description: For the poorest and most illiterate victims of Hurricane Hugo in this state, the slap of the storm more than four months ago is turning into a long, dull ache as they struggle to recover.

title: Review/Pop;   Salute to Indian Film Music And a Mix of Styles on Loan
description: Among the world's musical melting pots, the one that bubbles most merrily may be the Indian film industry, which turns out nearly a thousand movies a year, virtually all of them including song-and-dance numbers. Composers of sound-track songs, or filmi, draw on Indian and Western classical music as well as any pop style that strikes their ears. But the singing puts a little curry in the melting pot; the vocal style is distinctively Indian, with the microtonal bends and slides of raga singing, and female voices pitched in a high soprano register. No borrowing is too exotic or far-fetched for the tunes and arrangements.

title: Islanders Hold Fast and Stand Alone in First
description: The Islanders redeemed themselves well for their ineptitude on the power play tonight and defeated the Washington Capitals, 5-3, for their 10th triumph in their last 11 games at Nassau Coliseum.

description: The day after he asked the Knicks to trade him, Rod Strickland was a man of few words.

description: Treasury bond prices tumbled yesterday, while notes and bills posted smaller losses. Dealers said the market was on the defensive from the start of trading, largely because of mixed interpretations of the Government's employment report for January, which was released before trading began.

title: Don't Look To Canada's Health System
description: LEAD: Newspapers, political magazines and network television news programs are obsessed with the supposed inadequacies of the United States' health care system. The solution proposed is a Canadian-style National Health Insurance system, which would be paid for by general revenues and be run either by the individual states or by the Federal

title: A Savings and Loan Is Seized in Florida; 2 Others Progressing
description: The Federal Government seized Florida's largest savings and loan association yesterday and said the institution was the victim of a flamboyant and spendthrift chairman. But in Texas and California, two other big savings institutions made progress toward recovery, thanks to Federal subsidies.

description: Opponents of apartheid reacted enthusiastically today to the relaxation of restrictions announced by President F. W. de Klerk, filling the streets of major cities to raise the symbols of the anti-apartheid groups, which were legalized.

description: The unbanning of the African National Congress yesterday technically restored the organization to the status it had in the 1950's, when it was legal and led by many of the same people who still lead it today.

Eveready said its new alkaline battery has a mercury content less than 0.025 percent by weight.

title: Ford Threatens Cuts in Mexico
description: The Ford Motor Company threatened today to start laying off thousands of workers in reprisal for crippling strikes at two plants in Mexico, About 1,200 workers walked off their jobs at a Ford engine plant in the northern state of Chihuahua at midnight Wednesday, pressing demands for wage increases, said a company spokesman, Carlos Bandala. He said the plant, which ordinarily produces 1,300 engines a day, had been completely shut down by the work stoppage.

title: First Inter-Bancorp Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: First Inter-Bancorp was formed as the holding company for Mid-Hudson Savings Bank on Dec .20. The company said the decline in earnings is principally due to a decrease in the net gain on sale of investments and trading account securities of about $525,000 and a decrease in the gain on sale of loans of about $467,000.

title: Valley Federal Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $106,735, or 10 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months. c-After an extraordinary loss of $1,100 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $46,416, or 4 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: U.S. Reports a Slight Decrease in the Jobless Rate
description: Aided by exceptionally mild weather, job growth quickened in January and the unemployment rate edged down one-tenth of a point to 5.2 percent, the Labor Department reported today.

title: 13-Year-Old Boy Killed by Police As He Chases Another With Gun
description: A 13-year-old boy, who police said was a suspect in an attempted robbery, was shot and killed by the police on a Harlem street last night after he refused to drop a handgun, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on the Law page yesterday about American legal scholars who are consulting on constitutions for foreign governments identified one scholar incompletely. He is Kenneth L. Karst, a professor of constitutional law at the University of California at Los Angeles.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 3, 1990
description: The Savings Industry

title: General Metals & Abrasives Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Upheaval in the East;   Hungary and Soviets See Pact
description: After months of discussions, the Governments of Soviet Union and Hungary said today they had agreed to draft an accord quickly on a full withdrawal of Soviet troops.

title: United Bankshares Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Cincinnati Microwave Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and included income from discontinued operations of $423,000, or 4 cent a share, for the quarter and year.

title: Midwest Energy Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Wellco Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping;   With Tired Bathrooms
description: Your 1950's bathroom is showing its age. It looks gray and dull.

title: Circadian Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
New Head Of Federated And Allied
description: In a change of heart, Allen I. Questrom, the president and chief executive of Neiman Marcus, has decided to give up those posts to become chairman and chief executive of Federated Department Stores Inc. and the Allied Stores Corporation, it was announced yesterday. Only 10 days ago, he had spurned the offer.

title: Some Donors to the Neediest Apologize for Procrastinating
description: Although it is never too late to send a gift to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, as contributions are accepted year-round, most people associate the drive with the Yuletide.

title: Western Co. of North AmerFica reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: As provided in the company's reorganization plan, previously outstanding common stock has been cancelled and about 12.5 million new common shares have been issued and are considered to have been outstanding throughout 1989. Loss per share reported for the three and 12 months ended Dec 31, 1988 was calculated based on 46.5 million shares of previously outstanding common stock. Accordingly, loss per share amounts for the 1988 periods are not comparable to loss per share amounts reported for the 1989 periods and have been omitted from the table.

title: Michigan Star Idled
description: After starting all of Michigan's 19 games this season and averaging 16 points a game, Sean Higgins will be sidelined three to four weeks with a stress fracture in his left foot. The 6-foot-9-inch forward was injured in a 91-73 loss to Purdue Wednesday.

title: Flexsteel Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $551,581 from life insurance proceeds.

title: Senate Panel Puts Off a Decision On a Chief for Nuclear Weapons
description: The Senate Armed Services Committee has indefinitely delayed a vote on whether a former official of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission should be confirmed as Assistant Secretary of Energy for defense programs.

title: MNC Financial reports earnings for Year Dec 31
description: The company said the results reflected its merger with Equitable Bancorp accounted for under the pooling of interest method, including the effects of necessary conformity adjustments to establish uniform methods of accounting as well as merger expenses.

title: About New York;   As Dust Gathers, Oldest Bookstore Reaches the End
description: The other day, somebody stole the big sign. It weighed better than 50 pounds and each morning had to be carted down to the street. It would be placed in front of piles of worthless old books to announce that on the second and third floors of the rickety six-story building at 15 Ann Street existed the Isaac Mendoza Book Company, New York City's oldest bookstore.

title: When the Driver Behind Is Blinding You
description: To the Editor:

title: Ameribanc Investors reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Chicago Board to Aid China
description: The Chicago Board of Trade today agreed to help China establish an agricultural futures market.

title: Tecsyn International reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Latest results reflected the sale of 50 percent of its interest in Polytech Neeting Industries. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: American Water Works Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dynatronics Laser Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $14,934 for the quarter and $29,867 for the 6 months.

title: Universal Security InstruFments Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit from a gain on the sale of real estate of $615,719, or 18 cents a share. c-Net loss

title: Some 911 Calls to Be Shifted So Officers Can Get to Know Areas
description: The New York City Police Commissioner, Lee P. Brown, said yesterday that he planned to change the way the department responds to 911 emergency calls so officers could spend more time learning about their communities.

title: No Chancellor Can Do It Alone
description: At a time of diminished state and city resources, New York City's Schools Chancellor, Joseph Fernandez, sensibly focuses his first budget on a few priorities. He wants to make the school system more accountable, with performance goals, and he wants to make the school environment more inviting, with increased maintenance. For these and other initiatives, Mr. Fernandez seeks a $483 million budget increase for 1991.

title: California Legislator Is Found Guilty of Extortion
description: A State Senator, the first person to stand trial on charges stemming from a Federal investigation of Statehouse corruption, was convicted today of extortion, racketeering and money laundering.

title: Bombs and Schools in the South
description: LEAD: The mail-bomb murders last month of Judge Robert S. Vance of the 11th Circuit Court of Appeals and Savannah City Councilman Robert E. Robinson serve as a jarring and reprehensible reminder that the fight to integrate Southern schools isn't over.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Citizens and Southern Corp., Atlanta and Sovran Financial Corp., Norfolk, Va., both bank holding companies, said their shareholders had approved the combination of the two businesses under a new holding company, Avantor Financial Corp.

title: Eight Decades of Bitterness
description: 1912: The African National Congress is founded to promote the rights of blacks in South Africa.

title: Hunt (J.B.) Transport Services (O) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Inside
description: Change in Police Response

title: O'Rourke Seeks Westchester Budget Change
description: The Westchester County Executive today proposed changes to the current $1.008 billion budget that would prevent the layoff of hundreds of county employees and save the Westchester County Medical Center's Psychiatric Institute, previously threatened with closing.

title: Norex America Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income of $350,078, or 8 cents a share, from the company's previously discontinued cruise business for the quarter and income of $732,012, or 17 cents a share, primarily from charter income on the vessel SS Veracruz, which is pending sale on May 1990, for the year. c-Net loss d-After a loss of $573,307 for the quarter and income of $1,215,386, or 28 cents a share, for the year, both from discontinued operations.

title: Bush, Citing Security Law, Voids Sale of Aviation Concern to China
description: President Bush today nullified the sale of an American company that manufactures airplane parts to a military-related agency of the Chinese Government. In doing so, he resorted for the first time to a law that allows him to bar some foreign investments on national-security grounds.

title: Man Fatally Stabbed In Queens Subway; Assailant Gets Away
description: A Wall Street security guard was stabbed to death yesterday morning, apparently during a robbery at the bottom of a staircase leading into a Queens subway station, the police said.

title: U.S.-Mideast Council To Sponsor a Concert
description: Prokofiev's ''Peter and the Wolf,'' presented with Arabic narration, will be among the works at a concert by the Kennedy Center Opera House Orchestra on Feb. 25 at 7:30 P.M. at the Kennedy Center, 2700 F Street N.W., in Washington.

title: George C. Becket, Lawyer, 88
description: George Campbell Becket, a lawyer in Manhattan and Lakeville, Conn., for more than 60 years, died of a stroke yesterday at Sharon (Conn.) Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived in Lakeville.

title: Joseph P. Farlo, Judge, 64
description: Joseph P. Farlo, a New York State Supreme Court justice in Queens since 1978, died of lung cancer on Thursday at Astoria General Hospital in Queens. He was 64 years old and lived in Astoria.

title: Review/Theater;   The Story of a Pianist, Acted by a Pianist
description: ''Carreno,'' Pamela Ross's tribute to the legendary turn-of-the-century pianist Teresa Carreno, is a typical one-person biographical play except for one crucial element. Besides being an actress, Miss Ross is herself a well-regarded concert pianist. Impersonating the Venezuelan-born virtuoso, who was nicknamed the Empress of the Keyboard, she devotes half the evening to playing romantic war horses by Chopin, Grieg, Liszt, Schumann and others on a grand piano placed center stage at the Intar Theater.

title: Patents;   Wide-Screen TV Uses Conventional Cameras
description: Robert E. Flory, a researcher at the David Sarnoff Research Center in Princeton, N.J., obtained a patent this week for a wide-screen television system that can use conventional cameras and conventional videocassette recorders.

title: A Reward Fit for a King
description: Wayne Gretzky has paid off handsomely for Bruce McNall, and the Los Angeles Kings' owner is going to return the favor to the National Hockey League's career scoring leader.

title: Surprise Witness for Gotti: Victim of the '86 Shooting
description: A former union official who prosecutors say was shot on the orders of John Gotti, the reputed Mafia leader, sat 20 feet from Mr. Gotti yesterday and testified on his behalf as a surprise defense witness.

title: DH Technology Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Canadian Pacific Forest ProdFucts reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said the Canadian dollar averaged about 85 cents a share (U.S.) in 1989, compared with 81 cents a share a year-earlier. The company also said each one cent (U.S.) increase in the value of the Canadian currency reduces the company's net earnings by about $15 million, or 34 cents a share (Canadian). Results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Thorpe's Road Back Paved With Promise
description: Jim Thorpe is celebrating his 41st birthday this week at the A.T. & T. Pebble Beach National Pro-Am, but so far, 1990 has given the veteran touring pro a reason to celebrate a rebirth.

title: Bennett Doubts Value of Drug Education
description: William J. Bennett, the nation's drug policy director, raised questions today about the effectiveness of drug education programs and said children were more likely to respond to aggressive law enforcement and assured punishment.

title: Books of The Times;   After War, Coming Home to an Uneasy Life
description: A Native's Return, 1945-1988

title: Manville Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $24,089,000, or 20 cents a share, on disposal of discontinued operations. c-Net loss and included income from discontinued operations of $1,532,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $6,879,000, or 6 cents a share, for the year, and an extraordinary charge of $1,287,912,000 for the quarter and year; the year also included a loss of $106,937,000 from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Simmons Is Considering Possible Lockheed Bid
description: After being rebuffed by the Lockheed Corporation in a request for seats on its board, the Dallas investor Harold C. Simmons said today that he might try to acquire the military contractor.

title: Bass-Owned California Unit Has Big Profit
description: The once-troubled American Savings Bank today reported a large profit for 1989. The California savings and loan institution was acquired by the Robert M. Bass Group just over a year ago in one of the Government's biggest bailout deals.

title: Chronicle
description: A girl was born to ALAN M. DERSHOWITZ and CAROLYN COHEN last Saturday. Her name is Ella Kaille Cohen Dershowitz. Professor Deshowitz, a Harvard Law School professor, author and former defense lawyer for Claus von Bulow, has two grown children.

title: Logicon Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a provision of $3,350,000 for loss on two fixed price development contracts with the U.S. Navy to provide air traffic controller training systems.

title: Tanglewood Institute Schedules Auditions
description: Auditions for young musicians are to be held by the Boston University Tanglewood Institute from 10 A.M. to 8 P.M. on Feb. 24 and 25 at the Emilia Del Terzo studio at Carnegie Hall. High school- and college-age musicians may audition for summer workshops in voice, instrumental music and composition.

title: Upheaval in the East: The Germanys;   Baker and West German Envoy Discuss Reunification Issues
description: With the momentum seeming to build for unification of the two Germanys, the West German Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, met today with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to coordinate positions on the German question before Mr. Baker meets with Soviet officials next week.

title: Jets' Walker and Giants' Anderson Among Free Agents
description: As anticipated, Pat Ryan and Wesley Walker, a quarterback and a wide receiver with a combined total of 23 years' experience with the Jets, were among 22 players who were left unprotected today by the team and thus became Plan B free agents. But Freeman McNeil, the 30-year-old running back whose salary is $965,000, and Marty Lyons, a 33-year-old defensive lineman, were protected.

title: South Africa's New Era;   Foes of Apartheid Hail De Klerk's 'Positive' Act
description: A senior official of the African National Congress said today that the organization welcomed the ''positive decisions'' announced by President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa but that other demands set by the congress as conditions for talks with the Government had not been met.

title: Japan's Candidates Argue Face to Face
description: Japan held its first election debate in 30 years today, and if there was a clear winner he or she was not among the five party leaders who exchanged barbs on a range of domestic and international issues.

title: Mexico's Recovery: Is It in Peril?
description: On the eve of a landmark loan agreement to ease Mexico's debt burden, economists and business executives here warn that the nation's fragile economic recovery is threatened by Government spending on new social programs and a scarcity of private investment funds needed for sustained growth.

title: Limiting of H.U.D. Inquiry Is Criticized
description: Members of Congress today praised Attorney General Dick Thornburgh for deciding to seek an independent prosecutor to investigate possible criminal wrongdoing by former Housing Secretary Samuel Pierce, but they also faulted the Justice Department for limiting the scope of the inquiry.

title: Chemed Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $1,070,000, or 12 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,335,000, or 14 cents a share, for the year, an extraordinary gain on termination of pension plan of $472,000, or 5 cents a share, for both the quarter and year, and the year also included a gain of $1,664,000, or 18 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.

title: CUNY Panel Says Doctors Fail to Serve As Promised
description: City College opened the Sophie Davis School of Biomedical Education in 1973 to provide reduced-cost medical training to students who would ultimately spend two years as family practitioners, internists or pediatricians in areas where physicians were in short supply.

title: Foremost Corp of America reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and included extraordinary credits which represents gains from change in an accounting principles of $4,290,000, or 35 cents a share, for the quarter and $5,360,000, or 43 cents a share, for the year, and losses from discontinued operations of $383,000 and $1,049,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.
