description: TENNIS

title: Informatrix reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Orthomet Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Defiance Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: James Houghteling, 69, Retired Law Professor
description: James Lawrence Houghteling, a professor of law and former Government lawyer, died after surgery for a ruptured aorta aneurysm Wednesday at Newton-Wellesley Hospital in Newton, Mass. He was 69 years old and lived in Newton.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the Connecticut Film Commission misstated its address. It is at 865 Brook Street, Rocky Hill, Conn. 06067-3405. The telephone number is 258-4301.

title: Nudists' Rights: Image and Reality
description: Your publication of the article about Kevin Kearney [''Lobbying for Nudists' Rights,'' Dec. 24] showed remarkable naivete on a matter that is not without considerable controversy.

title: Pastimes;   Stamps
description: The 13th stamp in the Black Heritage series is a 25-cent issue to honor Ida B. Wells, journalist, suffragette and a founder of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

title: Chinese Know What Human Rights Mean
description: To the Editor:

title: O'Meara Holds A Shaky Lead
description: The A.T.&T. Pebble Beach National Pro-Am reverted today to its usual brutal self, which is just the way Mark O'Meara likes it.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: Question Of the Week;   Should N.F.L. Drug Testing Be Revised?
description: Yes. It should be downgraded to a tropical storm.

title: Pastimes;   Coins
description: To commemorate the birth of the 34th President, the United States Mint has issued a coin celebrating Gen.Dwight David Eisenhower. The coin, called the Eisenhower Centennial Silver Dollar, can now be ordered from the United States Mint.

title: Building a Bathtub Framework
description: ENCLOSING a bathtub to give it the appearance of being set into a raised platform can transform a drab bathroom into a lavish one. The project involves building a framework around the tub by using ordinary 2-by-4 or 2-by-6 lumber, sheathing it with plywood and applying finish material like wood paneling or ceramic tile.

title: Baby Boy Kidnapped at Brooklyn Hospital
description: A two-day-old baby boy was kidnapped yesterday from a Brooklyn Hospital and a young woman who had been chatting with the mother earlier is being sought, the police said.

title: Brenda Stoller Engaged
description: Brenda Lebowitz Stoller, a registered nurse and the clinical educator of orthopedics at Cedars Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, and Dr. Lewis West Marshall Jr., the assistant director of emergency medicine at Jamaica Hospital in Queens, are planning a March wedding. Ms. Stoller, a daughter of the late Dr. and Mrs. Jerome Lebowitz, graduated from Eisenhower College and received a master's degree in nursing from New York University. Dr. Marshall, a son of Dr. Marshall and Sylvia Kinard, both of Washington, graduated from Morehouse College and the Howard University Medical School.

title: GIRLS GROWING UP
description: As the father of a 16-year-old daughter, I read with interest your article on the work being done by Carol Gilligan. Perhaps the confidence of 11-year-olds is the confidence of the blind horse. Most 16-year-old girls have acquired some knowledge of the constraints that all adults must live with. How did Ms. Prose manage to write a lengthy article on the development of adolescent girls without once mentioning puberty, sex or boys?

title: WHEN A PREGNANT WOMAN DRINKS
description: AT THE HUMAN AND BEHAVIOR GENETICS Laboratory at Emory University, in Atlanta, a videotape recording shows a smiling 8-year-old girl peering from behind thick glasses at two clear plastic boxes topped by red bows, each containing a chocolate-chip cookie. The game, a psychologist explains, is to open both boxes and remove the cookies - and no eating until both cookies are out. The girl's 35-year-old mother observes.

title: Review/Music;   Laderman Pieces For Flute
description: The composer Ezra Laderman celebrated his 65th birthday in June, but he is still collecting presents. The latest was a concert of his flute music, presented by the New York Flute Club last Sunday at Cami Hall. Mr. Laderman is an amateur flutist and has written a good deal of solo and chamber music for the instrument.

title: Answering the Mail
description: Q. Our master bedroom has six Thermopane windows. When the temperature outside drops below freezing, condensation forms on the inside of these windows and the water runs onto the sill. This room is the only one exposed to the outside on three sides and the only one with this problem. Our heat is set at 60 degrees during the night. Can you tell us what causes the condensation?

title: All-Star Game Not Real Hockey
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: VANISHING IS A TEACHABLE SKILL
description: STONE JUNCTION

title: A Shortage Of Babies For Adoption
description: LEAD: A SHORTAGE of adoptive babies in Connecticut has become so severe that one adoption agency in the southeastern part of the state has restricted its clientele to childless couples; other agencies have sharply restricted their waiting lists or closed them altogether, and for the 1,000 couples hoping to adopt through the state government, the wait may be seven years.

title:
ABOUT LONG ISLAND;

Of Sticks and Bones: Pro Lacrosse Players Are Enthusiastic, Despite Obscurity
description: LEAD: IN one of the locker rooms in the bowels of the Nassau Coliseum, Darren Muller, a New York Saints forward, was getting his ankle taped before the first lacrosse game of the season.

title: The Executive Computer;   'I'm Sorry; My Machine Doesn't Like Your Work'
description: Managers at most companies are required to give performance evaluations to their workers on a regular basis, usually at least once a year. While some executives say they enjoy the opportunity to provide thoughtful, constructive feedback that will help the worker meet clearly defined performance objectives, others - the majority, perhaps - would rather go to the dentist. Many managers are uncomfortable giving feedback, especially if the review is not a positive one.

title: Pastimes;   Chess
description: There were only three games to go for Jan Timman and, with a two-point lead in his KRO Exhibition Match in Hilversum, the Netherlands, against the British grandmaster Nigel Short, he could not close it out. The Dutch grandmaster lost two of the remaining games and drew the last one to finish in a 3-3 tie.

title: Musicians Who Perform for Giggles and Glee
description: LEAD: FORTY young children fidgeted and hopped on and off their parents' laps while waiting for the show to begin at the South Windsor Public Library. But when the music started and the two women from Woodbury who make up Jam Sandwich began to sing, the children listened attentively.

title: Campus Life: Syracuse;   Students Protest Vote To Raise Their Costs
description: Syracuse University trustees last week approved a cost increase of almost 10 percent for next year despite a weeklong student boycott of the university's student center, bookstores and snack bars.

title: THE STR WARS MESS
description: A SHIELD IN SPACE?

title: Foree P. McCauley to Wed Jack Biddle
description: Mary Caldwell McCauley of Virginia Beach, Va., and Rear Adm. Brian McCauley, U.S.N., retired, of Naples, Fla., have made known the engagement of their daughter Foree Pendleton McCauley to Albert George Wilkinson Biddle 3d, a son of Leah Breen Biddle of Long Beach, Calif., and A. G. W. Biddle of Great Falls, Va. An April wedding is planned.

title: Aid to Damaged Lung Is Implanted in Human
description: A surgeon at a hospital here has implanted in a human an experimental device made of a slender, hollow bundle of fibers that works like a lung in supplying oxygen to the body.

title: Using Proteges as Pawns, China's Aging Masters Vie to Plot Policy
description: China's aging rulers are engaged in intense jockeying over national policy and a possible shuffling of Communist Party and Government posts, Chinese officials say.

title: Prospect of Dull Fight
description: Their bout in Tokyo is less than a week away, and if they don't get sharper in a hurry, it could prove to be a distinctly lackluster affair. That's because the heavyweight champion Mike Tyson and his challenger, James (Buster) Douglas, both appeared sluggish yesterday in abbreviated public sparring sessions.

title: Janis L. Oolie to Marry Peter M. Berk
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sam Oolie of North Caldwell, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Janis Lisbeth Oolie to Peter Marshall Berk, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan S. Berk of Greenwich, Conn., and Stockbridge, Mass. A November wedding is planned.

title: Randi B. Jaffe to Marry Richard Salko
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Jaffe of New York have made known the May wedding plans of their daughter, Randi Babette Jaffe, and Richard Michael Salko, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Salko of Stamford, Conn.

title: Forests of Buildings, Cities of Trees
description: In 1921 the photographer Paul Strand said of John Marin that he was ''one of the few whose work is the supreme proof of the actuality of an American painter, of the possibility of American painting.''

title: Seeking to Bring 'Us' and 'Them' Together
description: ON Jan. 1, four of us stood up in Rye City Hall and took the oath of office as Mayor and members of the City Council. Instantly, two transformations took place. The obvious one was that we had officially taken office. The less-apparent one was that, in the perception of the public, we changed from ''us'' to ''them.''

title: Answering the Mail
description: Q. Our master bedroom has six Thermopane windows. When the temperature outside drops below freezing, condensation forms on the inside of these windows and the water runs onto the sill. This room is the only one exposed to the outside on three sides and the only one with this problem. Our heat is set at 60 degrees during the night. Can you tell us what causes the condensation?

title:
ART;

Spotlight on Women's Views
description: LEAD: TO begin its 25th anniversary season, Gallery North in Setauket is presenting ''A Woman's Point of View,'' an exhibition spotlighting 10 female artists.

title: Coghlan Gets Loudest Cheers
description: Eamonn Coghlan may be 37 years old and he may soon be moving back to his native Ireland and he may be cutting back on a running career that has made him the fastest and perhaps the most popular indoor miler ever.

title: WESTERN CIVILIZATION, 30 SECONDS AT AT TIME
description: Even as the Spenglerian twilight descends on Western civilization, it is good to know that youth is already sharpening its musical sensibilities in preparation for a new dawn. You may think this a suspect statement, but evidence to corroborate it does exist. At hand is an article that recently appeared on the Op-Ed page of The New York Times entitled ''We're Talking the Wrong Language to 'TV Babies.' ''

title: HUGE NEW RESERVE FOR TIBET WILDLIFE
description: Chinese officials and Western conservationists have agreed to create what they say will be the world's largest wildlife reserve, a tract in Tibet the size of Colorado and encompassing the heart of one of the largest and most exotic unspoiled ecosystems on earth.

title: Premiere for 'Emma,' Ragtime Old and New
description: THE artistic directors of Chamber Music Plus, Harry Clark and Sanda Schuldmann, often program contemporary works, but take care to nestle them alongside masterworks of the Baroque, Classical or Romantic eras. On the other hand, when the cellist and pianist joined with the violist Lois Martin to form the Fidelio Trio several years ago, their stated purpose was to perform 20th-century music, most of it recent, much of it commissioned.

title: PERSPECTIVES: The West 30's;   Land Uses Near the Convention Center
description: WHEN fancy took flight after the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center opened in 1986 it was suggested that redevelopment would soon follow in the broad mixed-use area separating its 11th Avenue location in the West 30's from the central business district to the east.

title: New Delhi Moves to Rein In Its Technology Chief
description: The new Indian Government has moved to curb the influence of a former resident of Chicago who returned to India to give a push to the nation's modernization drive and who is now chief of India's telecommunications network.

title: Goldberg, Hoping to End Vietnam War, Was In on Its Escalation
description: To the Editor:

title: TALKING: Landings;   Decorating Shared Areas
description: IN many of New York City's prime residential co-operatives there is a semiprivate elevator landing on each floor - a miniature common area, often no larger than a walk-in closet, shared by only two apartments whose tenant-shareholders are normally given the right to furnish and decorate the landing.

title: Mandela, Inspiration and Legend, Faces Real Politics
description: IN recent weeks, the cry has been raised wherever blacks have gathered to protest apartheid: ''Madiba! Madiba! Madiba!''

title:
THE VIEW FROM: POUND RIDGE;

Ban on Accessory Apartments Is Lifted
description: LEAD: GEORGE ROACH is about to add a stove, sink and refrigerator to the guest cottage on his property on Blue Heron Lake here. Several years ago, paradoxically, he had to remove similar appliances: a guest cottage with a kitchen would have constituted an accessory apartment and, at the time, accessory apartments were illegal in this town.

title: Upheaval in the East: Tito's Jigsaw-Puzzle Land;   Yugoslav Strife Is Called Political, Not Ethnic
description: Ethnic Albanian emigrants from the southern Yugoslav province of Kosovo say that contrary to official reports, the conflict in the area is not religious or ethnic but a struggle for freedom and democracy.

title: Correction
description: An article on Dec. 31 about a proposed landfill in Hunterdon County misidentified the site to which the county ships ash from incinerated trash. The ash is sent to the Grand Central Sanitary Landfill in Plainfield Township, Pa., not to a landfill in Tullytown, Pa.

title: No Time
description: For their roles in the Iran-contra affair, Richard V. Secord was put on probation and Oliver L. North got community service and a fine. So it seemed unlikely that Federal District Judge Gerhard A. Gesell would throw the book at Albert A. Hakim (below), who served as Mr. North's financial adviser. Last week Mr. Hakim was fined $5,000 and put on two years' probation. And, as he is accustomed, he will make a profit on the deal. In return for dropping his claim on $7.3 million in proceeds from the operation, in which Pentagon weapons were sold to Iran at inflated prices to finance the Nicaraguan contras, he will get to split the leftovers, $1.7 million, with two Swiss men who helped set up the secret accounts. By abandoning his claim on the money, Mr. Hakim ''simplifies things considerably,'' said a spokesman for Lawrence E. Walsh, the independent prosecutor in the case. But Mr. Hakim was not feeling appreciative. ''I have been abused by two presidents,'' he said. ''I'm talking about President Reagan and President Walsh. Our judicial system has been used as a tool by the politicians for their own gain.''

title: Dried Porcini Enters Some New Waters
description: WHEN a friend presented me with a giant bag of dried porcini mushrooms he had bought at the Rome airport, duty free, I thought it would be years before I got around to finishing them. But soon I found myself using them more and more often, in a variety of different ways. These powerful mushrooms have a strong meaty flavor that is wonderful in sauces, stews and impromptu pasta dishes. They are so useful that they have now become an item I shall always keep in the cupboard, along with canned tomatoes and tuna and dried pasta.

title: Divergent Goals at River Site Owned by State
description: FOR nearly a quarter of a century, a 17.8-acre slice of wilderness land rising steeply above the Hudson River has remained wild and undeveloped, ignored by the State Department of Transportation, which owns it, and coveted by the village of Ossining, which wants the property on its tax rolls.

title: Cooling Equipment Problem Prompts Nuclear Plant Alert
description: A local emergency agency declared a low-level alert at a nuclear plant in central Pennsylvania today after a problem with cooling equipment developed. Officials said no radiation was released.

title: NEWSDAY WORKER CHARGED IN THEFT
description: A veteran marketing executive at Newsday has been charged with first-degree grand larceny in the theft of circulation lists just before she was to take a senior circulation job at The Daily News, Newsday's arch rival.

title: Base Closings Seen as Opportunity Inside Problem
description: Instead of just single-mindedly fighting the proposed closing of five Bay Area naval bases, local officials here are also considering how to acccomplish the historic task of converting to a peacetime economy with the least immediate pain and the most long-range promise.

title: McEnroe: Victim or Villain?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD:

title: Soviet Jewish Emigres Tell of Fearful Flight
description: The Soviet Jews now flooding into Israel say that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's policy of glasnost gave them new freedom to practice their faith, but that it also gave new voice to anti-Semitic expression in the Soviet Union.

title: Nancy Gorman to Wed
description: Mrs. Paul T. Gorman of New Vernon, N.J., has made known the June wedding plans of her daughter, Nancy Gorman, to James Edward Dougherty 3d, a son of Mrs. Timothy J. Mahoney of Las Vegas, Nev., and the late Mr. Dougherty. Miss Gorman, also the daughter of the late Mr. Gorman, is a candidate for a master's degree in architecture at Columbia University. She is 26 years old and a graduate of the Kent Place School and Barnard College. Mr. Dougherty, 30, is known as Jay. He graduated from Fort Lewis College and is an associate recording engineer in the audio-visual department of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide in New York.

title: For TV Station, a 'Journalistic Coup'
description: WHEN Avianca Flight 52 crashed into a hillside in Cove Neck, most reporters spent hours trekking through dark woods and heavy rain to reach the isolated, barricaded and, by then, traffic-clogged disaster site.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Burlington, Vt.;

Railroad Fights Land Takeover
description: LEAD: THE City of Burlington wants to turn 32 desolate acres on the shore of Lake Champlain into an extension of its downtown with a waterfront park. But first it must wrest the land from Central Vermont Railway, which has held title since the mid-1800's.

title: Sex, Drugs and Rock-and-Roll - Updated
description: Eric Bogosian, the monologuist, writer, actor, is at a crossroads. His new show, ''Sex, Drugs, Rock-and-Roll,'' which opens Off Broadway at the Orpheum Theater Thursday, will, he says, be his last solo performance. For Mr. Bogosian, the show is a culmination, the final synthesis of the characters, attitude and energy he has created that has made him one of the shooting stars of the downtown performance art world. But now it is time, he has decided, to make a break and go head-on with an American dream - Hollywood, writing, directing.

title: Answering the Mail
description: Q. Our master bedroom has six Thermopane windows. When the temperature outside drops below freezing, condensation forms on the inside of these windows and the water runs onto the sill. This room is the only one exposed to the outside on three sides and the only one with this problem. Our heat is set at 60 degrees during the night. Can you tell us what causes the condensation?

title: Many Are Encouraged by Bush's Arts Budget
description: The modest budget increases requested by President Bush for the arts and humanities in fiscal 1991 are regarded by top members of Congress as significant because while they do not keep pace with inflation they reverse a nine-year trend of declining or flat budgets in these areas.

title: Reward Pressed in Hauler Slayings
description: LEAD: BECAUSE she did not want dust to settle on the case of two garbage haulers who were gunned down in their East Northport offices last August, Deborah Lee of Setauket, together with a group of Three Village residents, has established a reward fund for information leading to the arrest of the murderers.

title: An Agency Impoverished By the Poor
description: WHEN Gov. William A. O'Neill steps up to the podium under the Capitol dome on Wednesday to present his 10th budget to the General Assembly, he will speak in numbers. With a shortfall in the current state budget that is estimated at more than $90 million, the Governor is expected to ask for millions of dollars in spending cuts in dozens of state programs and increases for a rare and scattered few.

title: Review/Cabaret;   Marilyn Maye Returns
description: Not every pop-jazz singer matures as gracefully as Marilyn Maye, who is appearing at Michael's Pub (211 East 55th Street) through Feb. 17. It was nearly 30 years ago that Steve Allen discovered the singer in a Kansas City nightclub and made her a regular guest on his television show. She went on to record seven albums for RCA, to have the first successful recording of the title song from ''Cabaret'' and to win the praise of Ella Fitzgerald.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Two years ago Paul Hecht and his wife, Lynn Vogt, built a log cabin in the Muskoka Lake region north of Toronto. Theoretically, that is. Actually, Ms. Vogt built it with the help of her father.

title: Where Neon Art Comes of Age
description: THE smile on the Mona Lisa at 704 Traction Avenue is all lit up. Two delicate bands of neon - a squiggle for the upper lip and a small curve for the lower - are like brush strokes of light. This Mona Lisa, with a dramatic yellow zig-zag above the left eyebrow, a chin outlined in uranium blue and strands of hot pink, yellow and blue hair cascading in a fireworks finish, positively glows.

title: New York Control Towers Said to Gain Amid Flaws
description: Nearly a decade after President Ronald Reagan dismissed 11,400 striking air-traffic controllers across the nation, the New York metropolitan region is still short of fully trained controllers, although the number of flights they have to guide through the crowded skies has soared 58 percent.

title: Drillmasters' Seminar: The Art of War
description: The purveyors of blood and guts are working again - these days in the service of art.

title: Lincoln Tunnel Repaving Poses Test for 'Fragile' Traffic System
description: A TWO-YEAR, $30 million rehabilitation project now under way in the north tube of the Lincoln Tunnel will be the ultimate test of a high-tech communications command center recently installed in the tunnel's administration building here, officials say.

title: Patricia Mahoney Wed in the Village
description: The marriage of Patricia Anne Mahoney, a daughter of James J. Mahoney of Norwich, N.Y., and the late Mary McKenna Mahoney, to Richard Patrick Dempsey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald A. Dempsey of Kennebunk, Me., took place yesterday at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich Village. The Rev. Aldo Tos performed the ceremony.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week;   Who Is The N.B.A.'s Best Player?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: GIRLS GROWING UP
description: The Emma Willard School is a boarding school. As a close-knit community where adolescents away from home must look to community members for support and guidance, the boarding-school environment itself may be responsible, in part, for the morality of care voiced by the girls there.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Outing;   A Seaside Village in the Shadow of Skyscrapers
description: It is possible to spend a pleasant afternoon in a quiet seaside village without leaving New York City.

title: Lisa Kaplan Plans to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Murray Kaplan of Bayside, Queens, have announced April wedding plans for their daughter, Lisa Kaplan, and Cary M. Hirshon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Hirshon of Rego Park, Queens. Ms. Kaplan, 28 years old, graduated from Queens College and received a master's degree in journalism from Columbia University. She is an associate producer at CNBC, the cable network in Fort Lee, N.J. Mr. Hirshon, 28, graduated from the College of Staten Island and the University of Bridgeport Law School.

title: No Job
description: Perhaps the most telling comment on the resignation last week of Peter A. Cohen (above) as chief executive of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. came from the marketplace: Shearson's stock went up. The 43-year-old Mr. Cohen, a Wall Street wunderkind who exemplified the hotshots of the 1980's, rode to glory on a market heated by the takeover boom and was ridden out of Shearson at least in part because a couple of his own takeover moves went sour. Two years ago, Mr. Cohen engineered the company's $1 billion acquisition of E. F. Hutton & Company. But Hutton's retail brokerage business fell off after the stock market crash and Shearson's net worth declined significantly. Then came the $25 billion takeover battle for RJR Nabisco, in which Shearson wound up on the losing side. Last week Mr. Cohen met with James A. Robinson 3d, the head of American Express, Shearson's largest stockholder, and then resigned. Said Mr. Robinson, ''It was time to bring in some additional management.''

title: Freebies for Congress
description: The schedule left plenty of time for golf when the Tobacco Institute, the cigarette lobby, played host recently to about 35 members of Congress and their spouses at a Palm Springs resort. Anyone who thought the newly enacted Congressional ethics package barred lawmakers from accepting such freebies should look again.

title: On Great South Bay, Spring Comes in Its Own Sweet Time
description: IT is a morning deep in February and the village dock on the Great South Bay is deserted except for seagulls. Children are in school; adults are working. The few baymen left are far out on the icy water. They stand in flat wooden boats clawing at the bottom ooze with long, heavy tongs. Silhouetted against the pale gray of sky and bay, their shoulders rock back and forth, back and forth, like men davening at the Western Wall.

title: POSTINGS: Cafe v. Co-op;   Sidewalk Seating
description: When New York's highest court upheld a judgment of $1.57 million in damages to a Manhattan restaurant from the cooperative apartment house that leases it space, and much of the amount was paid, it seemed that the unusual suit had been largely resolved. It hasn't. The eight-year-old case now has spawned at least two more suits.

title:
DINING OUT;

A Long List of Hunan Dishes in Yonkers
description: LEAD: ONE of the first restaurants to bring Chinese regional cuisine to the county, Hunan Village shows no signs of letting up as it celebrates its 18th year in its panda-muraled building on lower Central Avenue. No need to wait for the annual Chinese New Year banquet (this year it was Jan. 28 through Feb.

title: GIRLS GROWING UP
description: As Francine Prose suggested in her article, the key to restoring women's sound psychological development may lie in recovering the physical confidence of an 11-year-old running on the beach, playing tag. If I had my way, I would require girls to complete a carpentry or mechanics course and run a mile in under 10 minutes before they receive their high-school diplomas.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: NEW ORLEANS;

French Quarter Prices Drop
description: LEAD: LAGGING real estate prices in this city's French Quarter are pulling in bargain-hunters from all over the United States and Canada.

title: The Title Glut For Vice Presidents and Up
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Not Market the Silver in Japan?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sudan Seems to Shift Away From Islamic Law
description: The authorities have decided not to cut off the limbs of 12 prisoners condemned to that punishment under Islamic law, and similar cases are under review.

title: NOTABLE CD PLAYERS AND CASSETTE DECKS
description: The Grand Prix given each year to outstanding stereo components may seem like a case of the audio industry vigorously patting itself on the back. While there is some of that - what with the awards being sponsored by Audio/Video International, a prominent trade publication -these accolades also reflect valid judgments. They are based on a poll of audio dealers - and those dealers are tough critics. After all, they have to sell the stuff.

title: Let's Let Business Be Business
description: In a market-based economy that recognizes the rights of private property, the only social responsibility of business is to create shareholder value and to do so legally and with integrity. Yet we do have important unresolved social challenges - from drug abuse to education and the environment - that require collective action. Corporate management however has neither the political legitimacy nor the expertise to decide what is in the social interest. It is our form of government that provides the vehicle for collective choice via elected legislators and the judicial system.

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Soviet Union;   GORBACHEV BACKS MULTIPARTY STATE, SOME IN PARTY SAY
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has endorsed proposals to end the Communist Party's monopoly on power and to accept rival parties and private property, party members familiar with the documents said today.

title: Ill-Timed Suit to Save the Pine Barrens
description: THE old adage ''can't see the forest for the trees'' might never have been more appropriate than on the day the Long Island Pine Barrens Society hurled a massive lawsuit at the people of Long Island.

title: Mutual Funds
description: The flight to safety is on. Investors, worried about skittish stock and ''junk bond'' markets and lured by high interest rates, are shifting their cash to money-market funds. And fund experts say that investor nervousness shows no sign of clearing.

title: HIS SENTIMENTS EXACTLY
description: WHAT I SAW AT THE REVOLUTION

title: Outside Distractions Affect U.S. Performance on Field And Leave Coach Angry
description: Bob Gansler, the coach of the United States national soccer team, made it clear today that he was losing patience with players who have allowed peripheral issues, like contract disputes, to affect their preparation for the World Cup finals four months from now in Italy.

title: Africa's Claim to Egypt's History Grows More Insistent
description: THE poster that hung in a Washington classroom, ''Great Kings and Queens of Africa,'' was a work of pride. All the figures were in heroic poses and all were black. Like Queen Nandi of the Zulus, the Egyptian pharaoh Akhenaton and even Cleopatra had the broad features and dark skin tints indicating origins in Central Africa.

title: Panama Trounced
description: To the Editor:

title: More Abuse in the Child Abuse Case
description: After losing most of the notorious McMartin Preschool child abuse case, the Los Angeles prosecutor Lael Rubin whined that the defendants ''were lucky.'' The jury acquitted Peggy Buckey and her son, Ray, on 52 counts and deadlocked on 13 counts against the son. Ms. Rubin's graceless, unprofessional remark ignored the prosecution's ineptitude, which helped produce an inconclusive 30-month trial after a five-year investigation.

title: Questions Remain On Crowded Skies And Fuel Problems
description: LEAD: AS the shock following the crash of Avianca Flight 52 in Cove Neck began to subside last week, the Federal agency that will investigate the circumstances that led to Long Island's worst air disaster has just begun its work.

title: A June Wedding For Ms. Mahoney
description: Mr. and Mrs. David F. Mahoney of North Hampton, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kathleen Mahoney to E. Osborne Ayscue 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ayscue Jr. of Charlotte, N.C. A June wedding is planned.

title: Kathleen H. KellyTo Wed in April
description: April wedding plans for Kathleen Hull Kelly and Keith Lambert Oberg have been announced by the parents of the prospective bride, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Luther Kelly of Norfolk, Va. Mr. Oberg is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lambert Raymond Oberg of West Hartford, Conn.

title: BEST SELLERS: February 4, 1990
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 7 2 THE BAD PLACE, by Dean R. Koontz. (Putnam, $19.95.) A troubled sleepwalker hires a detective team to discover the causes and consequences of his behavior. 2 6 3 VINELAND, by Thomas Pynchon. (Little, Brown, $19.95.) The passions of the 60's continue to govern the lives of members of a community in California. 3 9 3 A RULING PASSION, by Judith Michael. (Poseidon, $19.95.) A young widow's entry into the world of television brings her adventures fraught with love, intrigue, revenge and murder. 4 1 12 DADDY, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) Unexpected crises wreck the safe, predictable world a man has built for himself and his family. 5 2 12 CARIBBEAN, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $22.95.) The history of the sea islands told in fictional form. 6 11 3 COLD HARBOUR, by Jack Higgins. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The O.S.S. agent Craig Osbourne on a perilous mission during World War II. 7 4 4 HARMFUL INTENT, by Robin Cook. (Putnam, $18.95.) A physician struggles to clear his name in a ''medical malpractice'' death. 8 5 23 CLEAR AND PRESENT DANGER, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $21.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan fights Colombian drug lords. 9 3 14 THE DARK HALF, by Stephen King. (Viking, $21.95.) After a writer of horror tales kills off his pseudonym, the deceased goes on a murderous rampage. 10 12 2 DEVICES AND DESIRES, by P. D. James. (Knopf, $19.95.) Adam Dalgliesh puzzles over a series of killings on the windy Norfolk coast. 11 10 16 TALES FROM MARGARITAVILLE, by Jimmy Buffett. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $16.95.) Short stories set on a mythical Caribbean island. 12 1 COUNTERATTACK, by W. E. B. Griffin. (Putnam, $16.95.) The Marines in action, from Pearl Harbor to Guadalcanal; third volume in ''The Corps'' series. 13 1 WHITE NINJA, by Eric V. Lustbader. (Fawcett, $19.95.) Returning to Tokyo, his spiritual homeland, a Caucasian-Oriental is haunted by an emotional crisis and a cunning madman. 14 * 8 16 FOUCAULT'S PENDULUM, by Umberto Eco. (Wolff/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $22.95.) Ancient documents and arcane codes produce astonishing results when thrown into a computer. 15 13 3 MYSTERY, by Peter Straub. (Dutton, $19.95.) A bright young man and an elderly eccentric join hands to solve a murder that haunts them both. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 5 2 MEGATRENDS 2000, by John Naisbitt and Patricia Aburdene. (Morrow, $21.95.) Prognostications about political, economic and social developments in the next decade. 2 1 13 LIAR'S POKER, by Michael Lewis. (Norton, $19.95.) Wall Street's tumultuous 1980's, as witnessed by a young bond trader. 3 2 20 IT WAS ON FIRE WHEN I LAY DOWN ON IT, by Robert Fulghum. (Villard, $17.95.) A new collection of inspirational essays. 4 8 2 BARBARIANS AT THE GATE, by Bryan Burrough and John Helyar. (Harper & Row, $22.95.) The 1988 battle for control of RJR Nabisco. 5 * 3 66 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Villard, $17.95.) Inspirational essays. 6 4 8 THE TEMPTING OF AMERICA, by Robert H. Bork. (Free Press, $22.50.) A critique of the relationship between politics and the law. 7 6 94 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $18.95.) A scientist reviews efforts to create a unified theory of the universe. 8 1 THE CUCKOO'S EGG, by Clifford Stoll. (Doubleday, $19.95.) An astrophysicist tells how he stalked a computer hacker from California across America to West Germany. 9 7 14 MY TURN, by Nancy Reagan with William Novak. (Random House, $21.95.) The former First Lady's memoir of her White House years. 10 9 23 AMONG SCHOOLCHILDREN, by Tracy Kidder. (Todd/Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) A year in the life of a fifth-grade teacher in Holyoke, Mass. 11 15 13 DRIVE, by Larry Bird with Bob Ryan. (Doubleday, $17.95.) The basketball star's autobiography. 12 10 17 ROSEANNE, by Roseanne Barr. (Harper & Row, $18.95.) The autobiography of the comedian. 13 12 11 ALL MY BEST FRIENDS, by George Burns with David Fisher. (Putnam, $17.95.) Reminiscences about show business acquaintances. 14 * 11 14 EDUCATION OF A WANDERING MAN, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $16.95.) The author recalls the places he visited and the books he read in his youth. 15 * 16 3 WHO NEEDS GOD, by Harold Kushner. (Summit, $18.95.) A rabbi tells how religious commitment can make great differences in our lives. 15 * 18 FROM BEIRUT TO JERUSALEM, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.95.) The Arab-Israeli conflict as observed by a New York Times correspondent over the past decade. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 51 WEALTH WITHOUT RISK, by Charles J. Givens. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) A Florida entrepreneur's advice about how to make a personal fortune. 2 2 8 THE GREAT WALDO SEARCH, by Martin Handford. (Little, Brown, $10.95.) A book of illustrations in which the game is to find a ubiquitous chap named Waldo. 3 24 THE T-FACTOR DIET, by Martin Katahn. (Norton, $18.95.) A new regimen for weight loss. 4 3 30 THE WAY THINGS WORK, by David Macaulay. (Houghton Mifflin, $29.95.) Explanations in pictures and text. 5 5 15 THE FRUGAL GOURMET COOKS THREE ANCIENT CUISINES, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $18.95.) Recipes from China, Greece and Rome.

title: When Murder Is on the Daily Agenda
description: MURDER is a crime and thou shalt not commit it. Everyone knows that. Everyone who reads a newspaper also knows that people murder other people.

title: When It Was Hip to Be Well Read
description: You read your Emily Dickinson

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-26

title: Florio Faces Tough Agenda On Environment
description: LEAD: GOV. JIM FLORIO'S recent appointment of an environmental prosecutor to crack down on polluters fulfilled one of his campaign pledges, and environmental advocates in New Jersey have hailed the move as strong evidence that his administration will usher in an era in which ''the polluter pays.''

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: SALEM, MASS.;

Office Rental Effort Pressed
description: LEAD: AN EFFORT is under way to improve the rental prospects at Endicott Center, a foreclosed $5 million office and retail renovation project that city officials consider vital to reviving the business district of this 360-year-old city. The project is at the intersection of Essex and Washington Streets, across the street from City Hall.

title: Review/Dance;   'Othello' Variation By Elkins
description: Doug Elkins is a product of his time if ever there was one, a choreographer who creates dance bytes and skillfully chains them into a fast-paced flow of visual information that is almost as overwhelming as the aural information offered by his collage-style scores.

title: Ms. Perlmutter and Steven R. Kamen, Law Students at Columbia, to Marry
description: Harriet Perlmutter-Pilchik and Rabbi Ely M. Pilchik of Short Hills, N.J., have made known the engagement of Mrs. Pilchik's daughter, Genesia Perlmutter, to Steven Romain Kamen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Kamen of Huntingdon Valley, Pa. A March wedding is planned.

title: Taking a Cruise At a Discount
description: THERE is no denying that the published prices of most cruises are higher this year than last, but that does not mean that most travelers are paying more. Competition for passengers remains fierce among cruise lines, resulting in widespread discounting.

title: U.S. FIGHTS COLORADO FOR ROCKIES WATER
description: In a trial that could help determine the pace of economic development across the West, the Federal Government is battling the Colorado authorities over control of the water from the Rocky Mountains.

title: At UConn, the Best Grade Now Is a High-Five
description: WHEN Big East basketball returned to the University of Connecticut last Saturday after a four-year absence, it was to a brand-new $28.5 million arena and a raucous sellout crowd of 8,241. Scalpers, who finally had a reason to do business in Storrs, were asking $40 for an $8 ticket. Even the Governor was there.

title: Ashley L. Richards to Marry in June
description: Ashley Louise Richards, an associate in the Washington law firm of Hogan & Hartson, and Jonathan Thomas More Reckford, a senior analyst in the corporate strategy department of the Marriott Corporation in Bethesda, Md., plan a June wedding.

title: A Bid of $23,100 at Sotheby's Wins the Hudson River Quilt
description: THE Hudson River Quilt, created by 30 Westchester-area women two decades ago and known as ''the first group quilt for a cause,'' was sold for $23,100 last weekend by Sotheby's in Manhattan.

title: The Soviet Oil Industry Has Two Decades' Worth Of Progress to Be Made
description: AS the Soviet Union strives to modernize its economy and match the performance of countries with free markets, it begins with an energy industry that missed the important events of the last 20 years. The Soviets are the world's largest producers of oil, but they were never driven to the productivity advances required in the West by years of competition and the price collapse of 1986. And on the demand side, both the industry and consumers missed the conservation lessons of the oil shocks of 1973 and 1979.

title: Fashion: On the Street;   You Can Dress Here For There
description: More and more these winter days, hardy inhabitants of Manhattan's north country - way up there in the East 80's and 90's - are hearing the call of the wild. What else would explain the proliferation of those plaid woodsy wool jackets that immediately conjure up images of a couple of hardy outdoorsmen, say, L. L. Bean and Ralph Lauren, sitting in front of a fire in their rustic cabin, swapping tales of moose-hunting in the boonies?

title: 'Frankie And Johnny' In Fairfield
description: ''I GOT news for you; your Prince Charming has come,'' declares an ardent, insistent short-order cook (Johnny) to a defensive, disbelieving waitress (Frankie).

title:
Pastimes: Gardening;

Plant Wonders Can Be Seen On a Wintertime Walk
description: LEAD: Many think of winter as a harsh, bleak season, a time to stay indoors. Yet the season has much to offer those who enjoy being outside.

title: Toll in Timisoara Disputed
description: A Government report said today that just 71 people died in Timisoara, where the December uprising against President Nicolae Ceausescu began, in contrast to initial estimates that put the number in the thousands. Students at the western city's Polytechnic Institute said they did not believe the official count and would conduct a house-to-house canvass to interview relatives of the victims.

title: THE CHICKEN AND I
description: SWEET TALK

title:
IN SHORT;

NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Lynn Tomfohrde To Marry in May
description: The engagement of Lynn Cazneau Tomfohrde to Richard James Duszynski, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Duszynski of Denver, has been announced by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Heinn Frederic Tomfohrde 3d of Smoke Rise, N.J. A May wedding is planned.

title:
IN SHORT;

NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Long Island Journal
description: The BMX Master

title: Missing Data on Disk Drives
description: To the Editor:

title: Tribes Get Right to 50% of Colombian Amazon
description: Asserting that Indians are the best guardians of the rain forest, Colombia's Government has recognized Indian land rights to half the Colombian Amazon.

title: Distorting the Truth About Cablevision
description: The Jan. 14 reply by David Carey [''Costs of Cable: False Comparisons''] director of public affairs for Cablevision, to the Dec. 17 article [''Cable TV vs. Consumers: Battleground Emerges''] continues to distort the truth about Cablevision. Mr. Carey replies that on a cost-per-channel basis, we are paying less in 1989 than we did in 1986.

title: CRIME
description: Jerry Oster goes too far and pretty much gets away with it in INTERNAL AFFAIRS (Bantam, $16.95), a gritty, if implausible, New York City procedural in which the hero cop, Sgt. Joe Cullen of the internal affairs unit, never seems to visit his precinct house or turn in a work report.

title: All About/Cable Television Programming;   Fighting for Visibility in a Proliferating Industry
description: Only a decade ago, there were so few cable services that marketing merely meant telling the American public that cable existed. Today there are 54 advertiser-supported networks, which get their revenues both from commercials and from fees paid by cable operators. ESPN, the sports network, and CNN, the Cable News Network, are by far the largest, seen in virtually all 55 million cable households. Then there are 11 pay-television stations - Home Box Office, Showtime, the Disney Channel - supported solely by subscriber fees added to basic monthly cable bills.

title: Diana Gail Thall To Wed in March
description: The engagement of Diana Gail Thall to Craig Levin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Levin of Wynnewood, Pa., has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Dr. and Mrs. Richard S. Thall of Locust Valley, L.I. A March wedding is planned.

title: CAMBODIA FACTIONS SAID TO LINK ARMIES
description: A memorandum prepared by the Cambodian Defense Ministry says the two non-Communist factions opposing the Phnom Penh Government are increasingly cooperating on the battlefield with their dominant ally, the Communist Khmer Rouge.

title: Bypass of Voters Sought in Building Schools
description: LEAD: FACED with aging buildings and reluctant taxpayers, New Jersey school boards are seeking legislation that would allow them to bypass voters on bond issues for school construction and renovation.

title: Review/Music;   Taped Lecture by Schoenberg Is Concert Prelude
description: This year's Focus series at the Juilliard School has been exploring the world of Arnold Schoenberg through his own works and works by composers who influenced him or who were influenced by him. In the fifth installment, on Thursday evening at the Juilliard Theater, the student musicians offered a group of harmonically and dramatically edgy works that Schoenberg composed between 1941 and 1950, as well as gentler scores by Luigi Dallapiccola and Earl Kim.

title: Andrew Heath to Wed Amy Greer Birnbaum
description: Mr. and Mrs. Irwin M. Birnbaum of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Charlestown, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Amy Greer Birnbaum to Andrew David Heath, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard G. Heath of Pound Ridge, N.Y., and New York. The wedding is planned for next year.

title: Miss Kane Plans To Marry in April
description: Mrs. James M. Kane Sr. of Longmeadow, Mass., has made known the engagement of her daughter Dianne Kane to William Yukio Yamada, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert K. Yamada of El Cerrito, Calif. An April wedding is planned. Miss Kane, also a daughter of the late Mr. Kane, is a cum laude graduate of the University of Vermont. The prospective bride, a teacher at Public School 3 in Manhattan, is studying for a master's degree in elementary education at Hunter College.

title: Rent Increases Beget Higher Prices
description: Your article ''Isolated Business Districts Facing New Economic Pressures'' [Jan. 21] caused me to write about the abuse of what was once so wonderful.

title: Racial Slur Alleged In Ranger Victory
description: Graeme Townshend, the rookie forward who is only the third black to play for the Boston Bruins, sat at his locker after today's 2-1 loss to the Rangers, dressing quickly, speaking curtly, deflecting as best he could the controversy that had engulfed him in only his second National Hockey League game.

Brown of Herndon, Va., and Enrico Marziali of Washington. An April wedding is planned. Miss Crowther, who is employed by the University of Virginia in Charlottesville, Va., graduated from Fluvanna County High School in Palmyra, Va., and the Woodrow Wilson Center in Fishersville, Va. Mr. Marziali, who is employed by the Veterans Administration in Washington, graduated from Herndon High School and the Woodrow Wilson Center.

title: Dana I. Spector and Scott L. Kimmel, Lawyers, Are Planning a July Wedding
description: Dana Irene Spector and Scott Lauren Kimmel, both lawyers in New York, plan to marry in July. Miss Spector is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph K. Spector of Kings Point, L.I. Mr. Kimmel is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Kimmel of Buffalo.

title: Almost Peace. Why No Dividend?
description: President Bush knows good politics and knows how to be a world leader. He showed that when he abandoned his reluctance to support Mikhail Gorbachev and reached out dramatically to end the cold war. He could now act with equal force at home if only he would seize the opportunity to transform the emerging peace with Moscow into a peace dividend for American society.

title:

Attractive Atmosphere in Bridgewater

title: Campus Life: Berkeley;   'Squat or Rot': Students Fight Eviction Effort

The residence has a history of drug-dealing, poor maintenance and bad community relations, officials say.

description: LIKE all of the land in Westchester, it first belonged to the Indians. Then the pleasant acreage in Purchase was farmed by Quaker families who during the Revolution sheltered wounded from the Battle of White Plains in their nearby meetinghouse.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: CROOKED HEARTS, by Robert Boswell. (Laurel/Dell, $9.95.) For the members of the Warren family of Yuma, Ariz., disappointment is such an expected part of life that they throw parties to celebrate their latest failures. This novel is ''rich and vivid, an intriguingly busy view of the human adventure, the impossible family of man,'' Sharon Sheehe Stark said here in 1987. '' 'Crooked Hearts' is an insightful, nicely turned, amazingly agile piece of work.''

title: Surhoff Gets Contract
description: The Milwaukee Brewers announced yesterday that they had reached a contract agreement with their catcher, B. J. Surhoff, and thereby averted an arbitration hearing scheduled for tomorrow. The contract is for one year, but no other details were announced.

The project is at the intersection of Essex and Washington Streets, across the street from City

description: In the annals of biochemistry it would be hard to find a more enigmatic and intriguing substance than the neurotransmitting chemical called serotonin.

description: Donating money to a charity can be like sending a bottle with a message into the open seas. The ultimate recipient of the gift is unknown to the giver.

title: Mendelssohn's Prophet Triumphs Anew
description: If Handel's ''Messiah'' heralded the dawn of oratorio worship in England, and to a great degree in Victorian America, Felix Mendelssohn's ''Elijah'' struck high noon with its premiere at the Birmingham Festival in 1846. Even in these more secular times, ''Elijah'' appeals, because its beauty and dramatic vitality ring true. With consummate skill Mendelssohn limns the powerful figure of the prophet battling to preserve the faith of Israelites as fickle as a modern political constituency. Baal or Jehovah, Elijah or Jezebel: They follow whoever can give them the best show. But Elijah triumphs, raising the dead, producing rain that ''laveth the thirsty land'' and finally ascending ''by a whirlwind to Heaven.''

Complete Nature Trail In North Haven
description: There was a surprising omission in the lead article on North Haven [''Tiny Oasis Braces for Influx of Wealthy,'' Jan. 14] .

Once Again, It's 'Hello, Columbus'
description: LEAD: Ships, not surprisingly, will play an important part in the 1992 celebration of the quincentennial of Columbus's discovery of the New World.

title: Beating Time (Father, That Is)
description: Alfredo Kraus joined the cast of ''La Traviata'' at the Metropolitan Opera last week as his namesake Alfredo. This might seem like no particularly big deal; Mr. Kraus has sung four romantic tenor leads at the Met in the last two seasons, including Hoffmann this past December.

title: Article 346290 -- No Title
description: A Senate Budget Committee report sent to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney on Friday night asserts that the Pentagon has stockpiled at least $30 billion of spare parts, uniforms and other equipment that it does not need. The report also says the Pentagon still has orders in for $1.8 billion more in supplies that its own auditors say should be canceled.

title: Kristine S. Hatzenbuhler Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Hatzenbuhler of Verona, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kristine Smith Hatzenbuhler, to Michael John O'Connor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William R. O'Connor, also of Verona. A September wedding is planned. Miss Hatzenbuhler, who expects to receive a J.D. from Seton Hall School of Law in June, graduated from Wheaton College. The prospective bride, a member of the Junior League of Montclair-Newark, is a law clerk at the firm of Lum Hoens Conant & Danzis in Roseland, N.J. Her father is a senior vice president of First Fidelity Bank in Newark, and her mother, Marilyn S. Hatzenbuhler, is the executive director of Bradford Bath and Tennis Club in Upper Montclair, N.J.

title: POSTINGS: Park Slope South?;   20-Unit Condo for Brooklyn
description: Even the most conscientious cartographers could not find Park Slope South on any map of Brooklyn. But it exists in the minds of real estate brokers, according to William J. Kane, a Brooklyn developer, and who knows, it may catch on as the new more-marketable name for the area west of Greenwood Cemetery and east of Gowanus Bay that up to now has been called Sunset Park.

title: PARTNERS CHANGE, ALONG WITH ATTITUDES
description: Dance, the most sheerly physical of all the performing arts, has long seemed to offer an inherent though changeable commentary on gender and sexuality. With its wordless metaphoric power, dance is capable of suggesting as much if not more than the relationship of two people sharing a stage in an aria or as characters who talk of their love. Nineteenth-century Romantic ballet sent one message, with its idealization of women. Another message, though not an entirely different one, has come from Martha Graham and the women who act and men who serve as catalysts for action in some of her signature modern dances.

title: Tale of Indomitability In 'The Tears of God'
description: FOR an uncommon example of how a theater can play an essential role in making a play happen, consider ''The Tears of God,'' which is having its world premiere at the three-year-old Playwrights Theater of New Jersey through Saturday.

title: At Yale, the Return of the Carrillon
description: ABOVE High Street on the Yale campus, Harkness Tower soars in neo-Gothic grandeur, as if seeking divine inspiration for a community of scholars. After six months of silence, the tower's bells have rung again with the music of Mozart, Handel and Bach.

title: Gale S. Wechsler Plans a Wedding
description: The engagement of Gale Stacy Wechsler to Jeffrey Lloyd Lewis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Lewis of New York City, has been made known by Miss Wechsler's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Wechsler of New York City. A June wedding is planned.

title: Frankie and Johnny's Uncommon Glow
description: ''I GOT news for you; your Prince Charming has come,'' declares an ardent, insistent short-order cook (Johnny) to a defensive, disbelieving waitress (Frankie).

description: Mr. and Mrs. Everett H. Erlick of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lorre Bert Erlick, to Anthony Pir Brenner, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Brenner of New York. An October wedding is planned.

title: 'The Diary of H. L. Mencken'
description: To the Editor:

title: LEWIS MUMFORD: PREACHER, PROPHET, ROMANTIC
description: ''One of our giant redwoods has fallen, and left a space we cannot fill by any quick plantation of lesser trees,'' Lewis Mumford wrote of Frank Lloyd Wright after Wright's death in 1959, and today we might use these words to speak of Lewis Mumford himself. His death a few days ago at the age of 94 brings to a close a life of extraordinary breadth, sweep, ambition and passion. Our century has had no other figure like Lewis Mumford: essayist, historian of culture and technology, literary critic and surely the greatest architecture critic of our age. His life was committed to the idea that scholarship is not a mere assemblage of facts but a guidepost for civilization. To Lewis Mumford, writing was a means of setting out a moral compass: he had no hesitation about playing a role that was part preacher. He wrote history not to entertain us but to tell us how to live, and nearly everything he produced had a touch of the sermon about it. Perhaps that is why his short critical essays please more than his book-length works, for his temperament was really less that of the historian than that of the critic, searching always for the points at which scholarly insights intersected with contemporary life.

title: A May Wedding For Ms. Lippman
description: May wedding plans for Jacqueline Beth Lippman and Geoffrey Allen Drucker have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lippman of Watchung, N.J. Mr. Drucker is the son of Dr. William D. Drucker of Milwaukee and Mrs. William H. Gindin of Princeton, N.J.

title: One Man's Pork

description: The 145-member Council of National Salvation, Romania's provisional parliament, formally voted to dissolve itself today to open the way for a new multiparty group.

title: The Debate on Self-Service Gas
description: New Jersey should continue to ban self-service at the gasoline stations because in the dozen or more states where I have visited the gasoline price has not gone down. Besides, women in New Jersey do not want to fill their own tanks and smell of gasoline.

title: Down Londons Mean Streets
description: MARTIN AMIS IS probably fiction's angriest writer. In Britain, with its long and decorous literary tradition, his voice stands out discordantly from the rest like a boom box at a harpsichord recital. His urban satires have provoked extreme reactions in Britain, none more so than his latest, most ambitious novel, ''London Fields.'' Although mysteriously absent from this year's nominations for the Booker Prize, England's most prestigious literary award, the book is in the midst of a long run near the top of the best-seller list and has triggered phenomenal media attention. In recent years, Amis has become an outright literary star - an anomaly in Britain. But then, his prose is probably more American than British in its energy and raucousness. For many critics, Amis's comic talent is unrivaled, but for others, mostly older and conservative readers, he is a malevolent harpie, with morbid, vaguely unpatriotic interests. Intriguingly, his father is Kingsley Amis, one of Britain's original Angry Young Men of the 1950's, now a Thatcherite Conservative. Martin sees a fouler England than his father does.

title: POSTINGS: 5th Time on the Block;   School for Sale
description: Next Wednesday, for the fifth time in a decade, New York City will try to sell an old public school at 51st Street and First Avenue that refuses to stay sold. The red-brick, Romanesque building, which opened as Public School 135 in 1892, then became the first home of the United Nations School in the 1940's, is now a shelter for homeless women.

title: Regulation Is Not the Answer To Those High Shuttle Fares
description: To the Editor:

title: GIRLS GROWING UP
description: I was raised in a traditional 1950's home, where I was taught that to be feminine was to be caring . . . as well as to be coy, deferring and, frankly, dishonest. Women had to get by in life by being seductive or subtly manipulative. Too seductive, however, and you were ''loose,'' too manipulative and you were a nag. There wasn't a lot of room for assertiveness, frankness or much integrity.

title: The President Looks On the Bright Side, And It's in Europe
description: IT is hard for most of the world to focus these days on anything other than Europe, as events there tumble forward, pell-mell, and last week President Bush proved to be no exception. Not only did he propose, in his first State of the Union address, radical new cuts in Soviet and American combat forces, but he also gave Mikhail S. Gorbachev another salute, as he described it, for encouraging peaceful change in what used to be called the satellite states.

title: Richard Wilson, 55, Tribal Head In Occupation of Wounded Knee
description: Richard Wilson, the Oglala Sioux tribal president who was a principal target of dissident Indians who occupied Wounded Knee, S.D., for 71 days in 1973, died of complications from an enlarged heart and kidney failure Thursday at a hospital in Rapid City. He was 55 years old. The occupation of Wounded Knee, the historic village within the Pine Ridge Reservation, resulted in gunfights between the dissidents and Federal forces, with dozens of injuries and two Indians' deaths. The dissidents surrendered after the Government had agreed to pull back armored personnel carriers from roadblocks that had been set up in response to the siege.

description: Robert Figlerski's essay (''Encouraging a Healthy Life Style,'' Jan. 14) advocates group calisthenics as a way of lowering medical insturance expenditures.

This week, parents of older students will choose the junior and senior high schools they prefer. On March 12, parents of elementary students begin their selection process.

title: On Two-Wheels in Italian Traffic
description: THE beginning of love stays in memory, a vivid freeze-frame amid the flux of the past. I fell for Italy one mild November morning, my first in Rome, when the street I was walking down opened suddenly upon the Colosseum. Confronted by the huge presence of a long-familiar icon, I gaped like a Visigoth fresh from the boondocks. At the same time, I felt at home, in touch with my roots. Western history no longer seemed dry, abstract, limited to the classroom.

title: Renaissance For a Pioneer Of Black Pride
description: She was tall and tan and stylish, expansive and difficult, playful and brilliant. She began her career as an anthropologist in the late 1920's and made her mark as a novelist during the Depression years. Almost 30 years later she died, nearly forgotten, in a Florida welfare home, and lay buried in an unmarked grave for more than a decade. But Zora Neale Hurston, novelist and folklorist - dubbed the Queen of the Harlem Renaissance, yet mocked by many of her contemporaries as a vehicle for white stereotypes of blacks - is undergoing an intense re-examination by a new generation attracted to her lyrical gifts and strong African-American sensibility.

But perhaps it would stretch interpretation a bit far to attach much extra-musical significance to the Warsaw Philharmonic's choice of music at Carnegie Hall on Friday night.

title: LYNN HILL, CLIFFHANGER
description: I was born in Ellenville, N.Y., in the shadow of the Shawangunk Mountains. This is the first time I've ever heard them referred to as the ''Gunks.'' Yuppies must have coined the phrase without ever having listened to the proper pronunciation, which is SHON-gum, not Sha-wan-GUNK. Don't ask me why, but they're our mountains, and that's what we call 'em.

title: INSIDE
description: Harsh U.S. Report on China

title: In Dubious Battle in Afghanistan
description: America's policy triumph in Afghanistan a year ago has turned sour. Washington expected a swift rebel victory when the Soviet Union ended a decade of occupation last Feb. 15. It didn't happen. Now the onus for fueling a murderous war falls on the U.S. and Pakistan, the main supporters of a quarrelsome rebel coalition. And with the Russians gone, Najibullah, the leader of the Soviet-installed Kabul regime, presents himself as champion of national sovereignty in a country long hostile to foreign meddling.

title: NOW VOYAGERS
description: They're not here. They've already gone to tomorrow. Designers who create the kind of clothes on these and the following pages could never be labeled mainstreamers. Talents like Geoffrey Beene, Issey Miyake, Christian Francis Roth and Norma Kamali are each, in their own way, nudging fashion's frontiers. Their creations are expensive, but very influential. What they show could just presage what's to come. Now, with a new decade at hand - and the last one of the century at that - the visions of these style-seers is all the more interesting.

title:
ART;

Glimpses of the Shaker Way of Life
description: LEAD: WHEN the Shakers came to America in 1774, they were a group of eight. At their height in the 19th century, they numbered about 5,000 in communities in New England and upstate New York. Now, there are said to be eight of them again.

title: At the Crash Scene, Disbelief, Disarray, Then Cooperation
description: EMERGENCY teams in fire departments, hospitals and other agencies spend many hours every year reviewing disaster plans, but when Avianca Flight 52 crashed Jan. 25 in Cove Neck, with 158 passengers and crew members aboard, the same people who had drilled repeatedly and prepared continually for disasters were in disbelief that a catastrophe of that magnitude had actually occurred.

title: Ms. Perry to Wed Joshua Basseches
description: Mr. and Mrs. Roger Perry of Rye, N.Y., have made known the June wedding plans of their daughter Amy Perry and Joshua Thomas Basseches, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Basseches of Washington.

title: In New York, Abortion May Be a Political Test For Republicans
description: LEADERS of the New York Legislature say they expect no major votes on abortion in this year's session. But somewhat paradoxically, the absence of such votes seems to make the issue loom all the larger in this fall's election.

title: Germany: Hidden Words
description: I search through the endless newspaper columns about the German wave rolling toward unification, but I cannot find any of the words I am looking for.

But the Hudson Valley Wind Symphony exists more for the joy of reading through the remarkably rich repertoire for symphonic band than for the occasional local concerts it has presented since it formed in 1988.

title: Answering the Mail
description: Q. Our master bedroom has six Thermopane windows. When the temperature outside drops below freezing, condensation forms on the inside of these windows and the water runs onto the sill. This room is the only one exposed to the outside on three sides and the only one with this problem. Our heat is set at 60 degrees during the night. Can you tell us what causes the condensation?

title: Mr. Bush, You Must Raise Taxes
description: At the end of 1989, as chairman of the Congressional Joint Economic Committee, I issued a report that concluded our top economic policy priority in 1990 should be eliminating the Federal budget deficit. Unfortunately, the budget proposed by President Bush last week breaks no new ground in dealing with the deficit.

title: Campus Life: Vermont;   Attacks Bring End To an Agreement For Study Abroad
description: Four attacks on students in France in the last two and a half years have prompted the University of Vermont to end its 23-year relationship with the University of Nice through the Vermont Overseas Study Program.

They include Memel in Lithuania, Constanta in Rumania and Batum in the Soviet Union.

description: The Superintendent of Schools, Jack Bobroff, has reinstated a teacher and librarian who were suspended after high school students were shown the R-rated film ''Catch-22.''

title: Syphilis Found at 40-Year High as Education Lags
description: Syphilis has risen to its highest rate in 40 years and young people's education about sexually transmitted diseases is lacking, Federal health researchers say.

title: The Extra Dimension of 'Live' Recordings
description: It is always good to be disabused of one's misapprehensions, and that is what has been happening to me with regard to the singing of Elisabeth Schwarzkopf. Ms. Schwarzkopf was the high priestess of the lieder recital from sometime around the early 1950's, when her collaboration with her husband and record producer Walter Legge entered its most fruitful phase, until her gradual retirement in the later 1970's. It was always clear that she had a superior voice (a smooth, glamorous lyric soprano) and superior technical command. Her interpretations were conceived with infinite care (on Legge's part at least as much as on hers) and projected with highly detailed nuancing of enunciation and tone color. Many found her endlessly fascinating; many others found it all too calculated, mannered, emotionally false.

title: Real Soldiers of the Cold War: A 45-Year Assignment
description: AS the end of World War II neared, there was talk among Allied leaders that American soldiers need not remain in Europe for much longer than two years.

title: LOVE COMES TO A MISERABLE COP
description: TRIPHAMMER

title: Marchers Protest Police Killings of 2 Teen-Agers in Bushwick
description: With chants of ''asesino'' and ''murderer'' and banners denouncing police brutality, more than 150 people gathered in front of the 83d Precinct station house in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn yesterday, to protest the killings of two teen-agers by police officers.

title: John B. Griffin, 84, Lawyer in Manhattan

description: Mephistopheles cavorted on stage Thursday night in a new Hal Prince production of Gounod's ''Faust'' at the Metropolitan Opera. One audience member got into the mood by lacquering her hair into a devil's horn. Up in the boxes, an enormous ruby-and-diamond butterfly that could have flown out of Marguerite's garden was perched on Judy Taubman's shoulder. After the performance, Oscar de la Renta, the gala chairman, led 300 guests to the grand tier for a Metropolitan Opera Guild champagne supper.

description: Intense pride radiates from Robert J. Eaton, president of the General Motors Corporation's European car operations. Intense fear, too.

description: Any discussion of how to appreciate a 24-hour race (if the word ''appreciate'' can be applied to something that long) must dwell upon a baser instinct: the ability to enjoy watching someone else's car fall to pieces.

title: Easy Victory for Syracuse
description: Billy Owens scored 25 points, including 12 in a decisive 10-minute stretch in the first half, as Syracuse beat Florida State by 90-69 today.

title: A Salute to the Duck in Various Guises
description: WALL-TO-WALL ducks set the stage at the Duck Pond Inn in Bay Shore. The ducky decor begins outdoors with a family of fowl on the maroon marquee and a handsome carved duck sign marking the restaurant.

description: LEAD: IF there can be said to be a patriarch of the Pepsi generation, he is D. Wayne Calloway. And these days the patriarch worries about two different kinds of nourishment.

description: DAVID N. DINKINS, who once was dismissed by a critic as ''Mr. Smoothie with no position,'' proved last week what dividends such derision can bring. Presenting his first preliminary New York City budget as Mayor, he won praise partly for taking an unpopular stand.

title: O'Rourke Sets New Goal on Housing the Homeless
description: INITIATING what he clearly intended to be a major assualt on Westchester's homeless problem, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke said last week that he was moving from ''the think-tank stage to the let's-do-something stage.''

title: NONFICTION
description: NIGHTMARE IN RED: The McCarthy Era in Perspective. By Richard M. Fried. (Oxford University, $22.95.) ''There was far more to the 'McCarthy era' than Senator Joseph R. McCarthy,'' Richard M. Fried observes. ''Beset by Cold War anxieties, Americans developed an obsession with domestic communism that outran the actual threat and gnawed at the tissue of civil liberties.'' Mr. Fried, who teaches history at the University of Illinois, Chicago, surveys three decades of American anti-Communism, from the Depression years to the New Frontier. On one level, this book is a rogues' gallery of Red-hunters: Congressmen, members of Federal loyalty panels, state legislators, college administrators, book-burning school board members and American Legionnaires. Even gay and anti-nuclear organizations purged their ranks of party members. McCarthy himself, who moves to center stage only in Chapter Five, is almost lost in the swarm of angry patriots. On a different level is Mr. Fried's observation that the anti-Communist crusade was an arena where larger political controversies (the New Deal, World War II, the cold war) played themselves out. If the movement reflected conservatives' ambitions and grievances, it also drew on - perverted, one probably should say - many traditional American values. Mr. Fried writes ably, scrupulously presenting both sides of every issue, covering swiftly a very broad topic; no one will ever do a better six-page precis of the Alger Hiss case. Gone is the tone that has marked cold war polemics: the left's shrill insistence that all accused were innocent, the glee of right-wingers pointing to those Reds who were caught. One misses the passion, but it is all for the best. With the cold war over, both sides may now be able to admit the truth.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: DR. RICHARD I. ALTESMAN;

Helping Parents to Understand Cults
description: LEAD: TWELVE years ago, when more than 900 people living in the jungle in Jonestown, Guyana, committed suicide by drinking Kool-Aid laced with cyanide, the world learned about life and death in a cult.

title: Down to the Sea With Aunt Dorothy

I told her that I was concerned about Borneo as it has more than 150 kinds of snakes and our friend Lucille was chased by a mongoose and grabbed by an orangutan the last time she was in Borneo and Lucille said, don't go. Lucille could not recommend Kuala Lumpur either because she couldn't remember much about it. Of course, out of the 18-day cruise, the ship stops for only one day in each place - how many jungle dangers can a person run into in one day? - but we decided to play safe and not go to Borneo.

Currently, a number of United States sports federations and pro leagues, including the United States Olympic Committee, the National Collegiate Athletic Association, the National Basketball Association and the National Football League, test their athletes for drug use.

title: Currency;   Taking Mr. Greenspan in Stride
description: The yen lost its punch this week, falling back to its level of 145 against the dollar. As for the West German mark, it continued strong, but the dollar only moved down a little against it. Suggestions from Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, that there was less chance of a recession seemed to have little impact. A strengthening in the economy would mean that the Fed is unlikely to ease interest rates, which could push the dollar lower. But the market did not think Mr. Greenspan's remarks hinted at a new bias toward raising interest rates. Indeed, Manuel H. Johnson, the Fed's vice chairman, said late in the week that he does not rule out lower interest rates in the future.

One cross-section of this miscellany might go from the on-the-spot sketches of Robert Henri (lots of them) to the large, squared-up drawing for the mural ''Leisure and Architecture'' by Thomas Hart Benton; another might take in John Marin's impressionistic watercolor of the Seine, Edward Hopper's study of a steamship with sail rigging, a perfect pen and ink that must date from the artist's youth in Nyack; and the anonymous, seemingly late 19th-century portrait of a brown dog asleep on a pink cushion.

title: BOOGIE-WOOGIE, FROM AMMONS TO ZWINGENBERGER
description: A LEFT HAND LIKE GOD: A History of Boogie-Woogie Piano. By Peter J. Silvester. (Da Capo, Paper, $12.95.) Of all the subspecies of jazz, none has caught the public imagination quite so acutely as boogie-woogie, a blues-derived piano style characterized by repeated left-hand figures set against percussive right-hand riffs. What started as a rudimentary form, played mainly by unschooled pianists in rural areas, eventually became a popular craze, orchestrated for the large dance bands of the 1930's and 40's, resulting in such hits as ''The Boogie-Woogie Bugle Boy of Company B.'' Perhaps the most valuable aspect of ''A Left Hand Like God'' is the insight it provides into the style's beginnings in Southern turpentine and logging camps, an obscure world brought to life admirably by Peter J. Silvester, a British civil servant who spent eight years researching this book. Here, too, is biographical material on nearly every boogie pianist, from some of the greats of jazz to contemporary revivalists, from Albert Ammons to Axel Zwingenberger. We get portraits, in varying focus, of such obscure giants as Cow Cow Davenport, Pinetop Smith and Cripple Clarence Lofton, along with rare photographs and reproductions of record labels and other memorabilia. Only the most fanatical boogie-woogie fan will want to read this book from cover to cover, but future scholars will find little to add to what will surely stand as the first and last word, lovingly spoken, on an American cultural phenomenon.

title: For Westbury's Mayor, a Hectic Pace in Parkway Dispute
description: AS a teen-ager, Ernest J. Strada could walk from his home in Westbury to the local high school and never worry about traffic problems. There were pastures nearby and miles of open road. But that was 45 years ago. Mr. Strada, who grew up to become Mayor Strada of the Village of Westbury, recently found himself at the center of a dispute involving the state's $62 million project to rebuild the interchange of the Meadowbrook and Northern State Parkways, a project that Westbury succeeded in halting for more than two months after it won a court fight to force an environmental-impact statement.

title: 15 Million or So More Chinese
description: China's population increased by 15.77 million people last year, bringing the total population to 1.112 billion, according to the State Statistical Bureau. The bureau's figures, reported today by People's Daily, said the natural population increase for the year was 14.33 per 1,000 people, up slightly from 14.2 per 1,000 in 1988. It said there were 20.83 births per 1,000, up from 20.78 in 1988, and 6.5 deaths per 1,000, a slight decline from the previous year.

Mario M. Cuomo rekindles this spirit with an environmental initiative that seeks to protect the natural and cultural beauty of New York.
