A wedding is planned for next year. Miss Morris, who expects to graduate in May from Duke University, graduated from the Moorestown High School. Her father is a vice president of Kidder, Peabody & Company in Philadelphia. Miss Morris is a granddaughter of Mrs. W. Allen Fenimore of Medford, N.J., and the late Mr. Fenimore, and a descendant of James Fenimore Cooper. She is also a granddaughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Morris of Wynnewood, Pa.

title: Katharine Ross To Wed in May
description: The engagement of Katharine Hudson Ross and Charles Lee Johnson has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mrs. Andrew Rockefeller of Greenwich, Conn., and Henry Lawrence Ross of Rancho Mirage, Calif. Mr. Johnson is a son of Robertson Lee Johnson of Portland, Ore., and the late Mrs. Johnson. A May wedding is planned.

title: Scowcroft Asserts 195,000 Is Minimum for U.S. Troops
description: Brent Scowcroft, President Bush's national security adviser, said today that 195,000 is the minimum number of troops that the United States needs to keep in central Europe if a new East-West agreement is reached on cutting conventional forces in Europe.

title: Vincent Van Gogh, Meet Adam Smith
description: No one really knows whether the unexpected return to the market of Vincent van Gogh's ''Irises,'' whose November 1987 auction price of $54 million made it the most expensive painting ever sold, will signal the end of the long bull market in contemporary and Impressionist masterpieces. The value of art, unlike that of stocks or bonds or barrels of crude oil, is determined largely by psychology, and the factors that make one van Gogh worth $54 million rather than, say, $34 million or $74 million are especially elusive.

title: Deadly Force
description: Spend a night cruising the streets of the city in a patrol car, eyeing the crackheads and the hustlers, stopping for domestic disputes and suspicious characters, and by the time the sun comes up, there'll be one clear thought in your head: I'm glad I don't have this job.

title: IT CURES WHAT AILS
description: CHICKEN SOUP SEEMS TO BELONG to New York. It is a curative, a panacea, a culinary medium. Its aroma rushes from the doors of Jewish delis and waves like steamy ribbons behind the bicycles that deliver Chinese food throughout the city. The scent of chicken soup lingers over kitchen stoops in the Italian section of Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, and above the homes of Greek families in Astoria, Queens. An epicurean archeologist could piece together a social history of the city by studying the permutations of its chicken soup.

title: Picture This
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Team Advances
description: The United States clinched a first-round Davis Cup victory over Mexico today as Rick Leach and Jim Pugh made a successful debut in Davis Cup play by beating Jorge Lozano and Leonardo Lavalle in doubles, 6-4, 6-7, 7-5.

title: Christ the King Upset by Tolentine
description: St. Nicholas of Tolentine upset Christ the King by 71-63 tonight in the opening game of the inaugural Metro Classic.

title: Question Of the Week;   Should N.F.L. Drug Testing Be Revised?
description: While I am not familiar with the policies of the N.F.L. on drug testing, I feel that athletes should win or lose based on their ability.

title:
GARDENING;

The Search for Flowering Trees
description: LEAD: THE decline of the native flowering dogwood, Cornus florida, because of fungus diseases has resulted in a dilemma when it comes to selecting a flowering tree for the garden. The flowering crab apple is probably the second most popular tree in the area, but there are many other choices to consider, depending on such requirements as color of flower and time of bloom.

title: 'The Diary of H. L. Mencken'
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;

The Search for Flowering Trees
description: LEAD: THE decline of the native flowering dogwood, Cornus florida, because of fungus diseases has resulted in a dilemma when it comes to selecting a flowering tree for the garden. The flowering crab apple is probably the second most popular tree in the area, but there are many other choices to consider, depending on such requirements as color of flower and time of bloom.

title: Seeking a Suitable Way To Approach the Issue of AIDS
description: ''How do you deal with AIDS in pictures?'' asks Marvin Heiferman. ''Do you show those suffering from the disease, depress everyone, and let the audience gawk at a bunch of sick people? Or do you try to raise issues and hopes, even though that may seem too politically correct?''

title: IN THE EMERGENCY WARD OF THE MIND
description: THE MESSAGE TO THE PLANET

title: Lifestyle;   A Satellite of Mars Mixes Cultures In the Red-Light Zone of Bangkok
description: With the requisite amount of hype and hoopla, the principals of Mars in New York, the club with the ''Bladerunner'' look at Tenth Avenue and 13th Street, have opened a branch along Bangkok's street of shame, Patpong, and it is the most wholesome establishment in the neighborhood.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: February 4, 1990
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 1 WEB OF DREAMS, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $5.50.) The origin of a curse that has haunted a family of orphans in five previous novels. 2 15 THE DRAWING OF THE THREE, by Stephen King. (Signet/NAL, $5.95.) Continuing the horror story begun in ''The Gunslinger.'' 3 2 MUTATION, by Robin Cook. (Berkley, $4.95.) A physician's attempt to create a superior child. 4 12 THE SANDS OF TIME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Warner, $5.95.) A struggle between the Spanish Army and Basque separatists. 5 4 THE LONG DARK TEA-TIME OF THE SOUL, by Douglas Adams. (Pocket, $4.95.) The detective of ''The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy'' pursues the meaning of an explosion at an airport. 6 4 TOO DEEP FOR TEARS, by Kathryn Lynn Davis. (Pocket, $5.50.) The family tragedy that came to light after the 1984 murder of a Toms River, N.J., woman. 9 69 THE POWER OF MYTH, by Joseph Campbell with Bill Moyers. (Doubleday, $19.95.) (Hazelden/Harper & Row, $8.95.) Solving your own problems while caring for other people. 2 9 THE WORLD ALMANAC AND BOOK OF FACTS 1990. (World Almanac, $6.95.) The latest edition. 3 8 RAND McNALLY ROAD ATLAS. (Rand McNally, $6.95.) The 1990 edition. 4 70 DIANETICS, by L. Ron Hubbard. (Bridge Publications, $5.95.) The Scientology handbook. 5 * 1 ERNST & YOUNG'S ARTHUR YOUNG TAX GUIDE 1990, edited by Peter W. Bernstein. (Ballantine, $11.95.) Income tax advice. 6 * 1 HEALING THE SHAME THAT BINDS YOU, by John Bradshaw. (Health Communications, $9.95.) Ways to recover from addictions, compulsions and other self-destructive forces.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: THERE really wasn't a thing Linda could have done to avoid it. One instant, there was an open stretch of roadway. The next moment, there was this deer kissing the right front corner of our van.

title: POSTINGS: Making Way for Metrotech;   Historic Homes on the Move
description: Residents of downtown Brooklyn are being treated this weekend to a phenomenon both rare and dear to the hearts of serious sidewalk superintendents - the inching of three historic houses along the streets to new locations. The 150-year-old structures, which had occupied sites at 106, 108 and 110 Johnson Street, are being towed as a unit eastward on Johnson, then south onto Duffield Street and then to their final site on newly built foundations on Duffield between Myrtle Avenue and Willoughby Street.

title: On the Edge of the Universe With Hard Butter on Cold Toast
description: THERE I was, trying to spread an intractable pat of butter across a rapidly disintegrating slice of toast when my wife suddenly asked across the breakfast table: ''Does the universe go on forever?'' Just like that, no warning, no preparation - metaphysics at 8:15 in the morning, and I hadn't even had my juice yet.

title: Anita B. Elkind To Marry in May
description: Anita Brett Elkind, the general manager of Argus Computerized Exchange, a computer information service in Burlington, Mass., and Dr. Richard M. Pomerantz, a fellow in cardiology at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston, are planning a May wedding. Their engagement has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Marilyn Elkind of Somers, N.Y., and Victor Elkind of La Jolla, Calif.

title: Miss Green Wed To Richard Rule
description: Regina Steuart Green, the daughter of Mrs. Frederick J. Green Jr. of Baltimore and the late Mr. Green, was married yesterday to Richard Paul Rule, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacques F. Rule of Sarasota, Fla. Msgr. E. Melville Taylor performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Shrine of the Sacred Heart in Baltimore.

title: GIRLS GROWING UP
description: Carol Gilligan's ideas are interesting, but it surprises me that they are considered radical or controversial (''Confident at 11, Confused at 16,'' by Francine Prose, Jan. 7). Is there a woman alive who is not aware of exactly when and how she learned that the rules are different for boys and girls? Adolescent boys ''will be boys'' - awkward, dirty, independent, impolite and free. Girls are made to behave like ''little ladies'' when they reach adolescence. I remember coming home from sixth grade and recounting to my mother a conversation I had with a classmate. When I had finished, she sharply informed me that ''you don't say things like that to a boy.''

title: Appraisals
description: To the Editor:

title: In Praise Of Klaus Column
description: Barbara Klaus's ''1990'' column in the Jan. 14 issue was one of the best she has written, and her columns are always intelligent and enjoyable. She is really a prize writer, and my family enjoys her regularly.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;

Preserving Farmland on the East End
description: LEAD: WHEN it came time to sell a 30-acre homestead in Amagansett that she had owned for 22 years, Deborah Ann Light wanted to find some way to make sure that her property, called Quail Hill, would not be further developed. It included a 1960's house, a 160-year-old windmill that had been converted into a second house, and several outbuildings.

title: LYNN HILL, CLIFFHANGER
description: As a writer and an armchair ''climber,'' I enjoyed Trip Gabriel's vivid reporting of the rock climber Lynn Hill, and vicariously enjoyed the thrills of the sport.

title: ROCK'S DEAD-END KIDS TRUST ONLY THEIR OWN SKEPTICISM
description: ''Hey creepos i'm talking to you,'' Siouxsie Sioux sings, buttonholing her listeners in the first moments of the Creatures' album, ''Boomerang'' (Geffen 24275; LP, cassette and CD). ''You've got a problem.'' Actually, it's more than a problem - it's a chronic condition of ''self-hate and loathing,'' of pessimism, cynicism, despair and the willingness to broadcast every grim moment of it. ''How empty and pointless your life must seem,'' Miss Sioux sings, deadpan but not unsympathetic. A few songs later, she echoes Jean-Paul Sartre, declaring, ''Nausea is all I feel today.''

title: FICTION
description: SILVER STALLION. By Ahn Junghyo. (Soho, $19.95.) After almost four decades, the Korean War has become a forgotten war. As the Korean journalist and translator Ahn Junghyo makes clear in his second novel to appear in English, what is even more forgotten, at least for Americans, is the impact that conflict had on the Koreans themselves. Mr. Junghyo's stage is a small South Korean village and its surrounding countryside; his cast is composed of the villagers and some American soldiers, who all become unwitting actors in a tragedy. The central characters are a group of teen-agers, particularly a young villager named Mansik, who change from boys into under-age men as the American invaders involve them and their fellow Koreans in the sordid moral and physical wreckage of the war. After being raped, Mansik's mother joins the ''U.N. ladies'' (also known as ''Yankee wives'') in the occupied area called Texas Town and suffers the social consequences of prostitution. For Mansik and his friends, however, there is retreat into a realm of fantasy. As the war goes on around them, they search, as did their ancestors, for a secret cave, the home of a legendary warrior general who was sent by the gods to free Korea from the Mongols. This search for the general who rode a silver stallion helps to insulate the boys from the miserable reality of war. Mr. Junghyo, whose earlier novel, ''White Badge,'' told the story of Korean participation in the Vietnam War, is a strong writer and graceful translator of his own prose, with a keen sense of his subject - a rural people brought suddenly into a world they never made. As was true of America in Vietnam, in Korea we sat very heavily on a very light country.

title: Denise McBride To Marry in May
description: The engagement of Denise E. McBride to Gregory P. Kelly, a son of Elizabeth Hallinan of Cumberland, Md., and the late William E. Kelly, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Gerald P. McBride of Morristown, N.J. A May wedding is planned.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Hong Kong
description: It is this time of year, as winter slips into spring and residents shed their furs and overcoats, that Hong Kong's eternal bustle accelerates a bit. Instead of hurtling about inside their office towers and shopping arcades, people careen along the sidewalks in their rush to get somewhere. The frenzy moves outdoors, to the markets, to the parks and to the harbor with its European yachts and Chinese junks.

title: Scottish Cheese's Earthy Poetry
description: CHEESEMAKING once knew quite a reputation in Scotland. A painting of Sir Walter Scott by Wilkie shows his wife and daughters outfitted for sheep-milking.

title: A Mobile Police Unit Takes On Drug Trade
description: WHAT is 36 1/2 feet long, 8 feet wide and 12 feet high, weighs 20,000 pounds and moves on wheels? It is ORCA, the latest addition to Hoboken's police force.

title: Bonnie D. Geller Planning to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. A. Neal Geller of Ithaca, N.Y., have made known the September wedding plans of their daughter Bonnie Dara Geller and Laurence Ira Arnold, the son of Alvin L. Arnold of Great Neck, L.I., and the late Nancy Arnold.

title: A Protest Was in Order
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Windstorm in France Kills 18
description: A violent windstorm gusting up to 104 miles an hour battered northern France today, killing at least 18 people and damaging scores of buildings, among them Chartres Cathedral, one of the world's most celebrated Gothic cathedrals.

title: Marcy Weinstein Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stan Weinstein of Hollywood, Fla., have made known the engagement of their daughter Marcy Eden Weinstein to Jeffrey Harris Schneider, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen B. Schneider of Roslyn, L.I. A December wedding is planned. Miss Weinstein and her fiance are 23 years old and are graduates of the University of Pennsylvania. She is a deputy branch office manager at Citibank in New York. The prospective bridegroom is a second-year student at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island;   Recent Sales
description: Bayville $252,000

title:
MUSIC;

Pianist Sets Up a Chamber Series
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH there is no current shortage of chamber music concerts in central and northern New Jersey, the pianist Wu Han believes there is room for one more chamber music series. Ms. Wu has assembled a group of well-known musicians to play four programs in Chatham this year.

title: Jeannine Taylor Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Jeannine Alice Taylor to James Whitney McConnell took place yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Thomas D. Bowers officiated. Ellen W. MacElree was the maid of honor, and Steven W. McConnell was his brother's best man.

title: MARTIN AMIS: DOWN LONDON'S MEAN STREETS
description: MARTIN AMIS IS probably fiction's angriest writer. In Britain, with its long and decorous literary tradition, his voice stands out discordantly from the rest like a boom box at a harpsichord recital. His urban satires have provoked extreme reactions in Britain, none more so than his latest, most ambitious novel, ''London Fields.'' Although mysteriously absent from this year's nominations for the Booker Prize, England's most prestigious literary award, the book is in the midst of a long run near the top of the best-seller list and has triggered phenomenal media attention. In recent years, Amis has become an outright literary star - an anomaly in Britain. But then, his prose is probably more American than British in its energy and raucousness. For many critics, Amis's comic talent is unrivaled, but for others, mostly older and conservative readers, he is a malevolent harpie, with morbid, vaguely unpatriotic interests. Intriguingly, his father is Kingsley Amis, one of Britain's original Angry Young Men of the 1950's, now a Thatcherite Conservative. Martin sees a fouler England than his father does.

title: Review/Theater;   'Philip Glass Buys a Loaf of Bread'
description: A bakery is alive and atonal in David Ives's ''Philip Glass Buys a Loaf of Bread'' as two women, Philip Glass and a baker rap their way through a devastating send-up of this idiosyncratic composer. The play is the first of four in the Manhattan Punch Line's sixth annual festival of one-act comedies.

title: Los Angeles Crowd Hears Islam Leader Ask End to Violence
description: Louis Farrakhan, the leader of the Nation of Islam, on Friday urged a crowd of more than 16,000 to ''stop the killing,'' a reference to both the recent shooting death of a Black Muslim and the continuing violence among street gangs.

title: No Headline
description: BROWSERS' BOUTIQUES

title: Languishing in the Secure, Isolated Comfort of a Nice Cold
description: THEY say colds are all around us. I don't happen to have one at the moment but I must confess that there have been times in my life when I wished I did.

title: U.S. Report Accuses China of Grave Rights Abuses
description: In a sharp departure from the Bush Administration's cautious statements on China, a confidential State Department report says there were pervasive, severe violations of human rights in Beijing, Tibet and other parts of China last year.

title: GIRLS GROWING UP
description: Thank you for the article on Carol Gilligan's work with adolescent girls. I understand that it is a moral study, but I am surprised that there is no mention of the fierce female biological change that takes place at about 12 years of age.

title: Toni Kasander Is Married
description: Toni Kasander, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Kasander of New York, was married last evening to Kermit Prill, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Prill of Lincoln Park, Mich. Rabbi Harold Loss officiated at the Sheraton Oaks Hotel in Novi, Mich. The bride, who will keep her name, graduated summa cum laude from Ohio University and received a master's degree in education from the University of Detroit. She is a special-education supervisor in the Oak Park, Mich., school district. Mr. Prill, a graduate of Wayne State University, is an independent computer analyst.

title: STREETSCAPES: 3 Bronx Railroad Stations Discarded Elegance Near the Point of No Return
description: LIKE a string of discarded jewel boxes, three exquisite but decaying railroad stations of the old Harlem Branch of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad in the Bronx are approaching the point where restoration may not be possible. Built in 1908 and closed in 1937, they are beautiful even in their disintegration.

title: 'The Diary of H. L. Mencken'
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Watch;   New Politics of Social Security May Lead to Sharper Scrutiny
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's proposal to cut the Social Security tax and Richard G. Darman's counterproposal to shield the pensioners' nest egg from the hungry gaze of Congress have so far generated more shock than debate.

title: THE INVISIBLE FAMILY
description: EVERY GOOD-BYE AIN'T GONE

title: WHAT MAKES SAMANTHA RUN?
description: WALL STREET WOMEN

title: Plan B Called Flawed
description: The N.F.L. Players Association is no longer a certified bargaining agent, but its president, Gene Upshaw, said the organization would help any player who wanted to go to court to challenge the National Football League's year-old modified free-agent system.

title: 'We Waste Most of Our Gifted Talent'
description: LEAD: PARENTS waste their gifted children, according to Robert Sternberg, the I.B.M. Professor of Psychology and Education at Yale University and the author of ''Beyond I.Q.: A Triarchic Theory of Human Abilities.''

title: Review/Recital;   English Pianist In Benefit
description: Clive Swansbourne, an English pianist, deftly balanced contemporary British works and staples of the Romantic repertory in his program Tuesday evening at Weill Recital Hall. Only a few dozen people attended - a pity, not only because Mr. Swansbourne's playing is interesting and individualistic, but also because the concert was a benefit for Hale House, the treatment center in Harlem for infants born addicted to drugs or with AIDS.

title: Suzette Brooks To Wed in May
description: Dr. and Mrs. Harold Brooks of New York have made known the May wedding plans of their daughter, Suzette Margaret Brooks, and Seth James Masters, a son of Judith Bush of Sharon, Vt., and Dr. Roger D. Masters of South Woodstock, Vt.

title: Business Diary
description: COMPANIES

title:
GARDENING;

The Search for Flowering Trees
description: LEAD: THE decline of the native flowering dogwood, Cornus florida, because of fungus diseases has resulted in a dilemma when it comes to selecting a flowering tree for the garden. The flowering crab apple is probably the second most popular tree in the area, but there are many other choices to consider, depending on such requirements as color of flower and time of bloom.

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: World Markets
description: While the Frankfurt Bund has been the focus of this year's excitement over investing in the future of Eastern Europe, the Vienna Bourse has quietly crept higher and higher, setting nine new record highs. And this after 1989, a year it outperformed every other major market.

title: Chatham Association's Dues Structure
description: The well-written article on the Chatham Fish and Game Protective Association (''From a Fish and Game Agency to a Friendly Social Center,'' Jan. 7) captured much of the flavor of the club, its past and present. The text must be corrected, however, in regard to the dues structure.

title: FANTASTIC WAYFARERS
description: Tables, chairs and lamps are crafted from branches; others are carved out of tree stumps and stone. Sofas, with deeply curved silhouettes and wild-colored fabrics, are often 20 feet long, and their grand presence almost fills a room. This furniture is not meant to shock. It's functional yet intentionally whimsical. ''Our designs are born out of fantasies,'' says Mattia Bonetti, the Paris-based designer who enchanted the fashion and design worlds three years ago when he and his partner, Elizabeth Garouste, decorated the couturier Christian Lacroix's showroom on the rue du Faubourg St. Honore with real tree branches and raffia-skirted chairs. Dubbed neo-primitive, the pieces at first appear to have been lifted from a Flintstone cartoon, but they have a flair that is arresting. ''All our designs have personality,'' Bonetti says. ''They're expressive, the antithesis of the black furniture that dominated design in the 80's.''

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Miss Schaus Engaged To Christopher Painter
description: Deirdre Olivia Schaus is to be married in July to Christopher Enfield Painter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Whitfield Painter Jr. of Concord, Mass. Their engagement has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Schaus of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Farmington, Conn.

title: Ships of Mauritius: Models of Fine Craft
description: EVEN as travelers streak from place to place in jets, many are drawn back to the days of journeys by sailing ship, of crashing storms and even mutinies. On the island of Mauritius, about 530 miles east of Madagascar in the Indian Ocean, this fascination is created and sated by the island's popular craft of building model ships.

title: Gypsy Life Beguiles a Film Maker
description: May 16, 1989: ''Time of the Gypsies,'' Emir Kusturica's first film since the awardwinning ''When Father Was Away on Business'' (1985) has its premiere at the Cannes Film Festival to cheers that swell into a five-minute standing ovation. The elation of the film's cast can be heard up and down the Croisette till dawn, as gypsy musicians play along the French Riviera.

title: Washington Journal;   Gossip Consumes City That Feeds On It
description: Not since Wilbur Mills took a nocturnal dip in the Tidal Basin back in 1974 has the nation's capital had a story as juicy as the Marion Barry saga.

title: Soviet Emigres to Israel Tell of Hate Back Home
description: Most of the 221 Soviet Jewish immigrants boarding El Al Flight 368 from Budapest to Tel Aviv in the early hours of Wednesday morning said they were fleeing a vicious paradox, the dark side of glasnost.

title:
A SPECIAL GUIDE TO CRUISES WORLDWIDE;

150 Years of Steaming Across the Atlantic
description: LEAD: It has been 150 years since Samuel Cunard formed the British and North American Royal Mail Steam Packet Company, which operated the first regular trans-Atlantic steam service between Liverpool, Halifax and Boston. The company's ship, the paddle steamer Britannia, cut the crossing time from six weeks to two.

title:
Your Own Account;

Savings According to Bush
description: LEAD: No matter how you look at it, the tax-free savings plan proposed by President Bush last Monday beats any type of tax-advantaged account available to Americans today, tax experts say. The plan, designed to bolster the nation's savings rate, would allow most people to escape taxes on the earnings of money that is saved or invested for at least seven years.

title: GETTING THE LEAD IN
description: THE PENCIL

title: DIPLOMACY VS. DEMOCRACY
description: THE ROCKETS' RED GLARE

title: Managing;   When a Handshake Isn't Enough
description: The small high-technology company was ready to go public and needed a chief financial officer. Five or so years ago, any financial type with entrepreneurial flare would have jumped at the chance, particularly since equity was part of the deal.

title: Sailing in the Seas of Knowledge
description: CRUISES are not part of the core curriculum at American colleges and universities; no Caribbean Islands 101 here. But they are part of higher education's agenda for winning friends and influencing alumni.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;

UNDIMMED BY HUMAN TEARS
description: LEAD: Scott Barrow's New York is a city anyone would want to live in. There are no homeless vagrants, no burned-out buildings, no drug dealers, no garbage. Mr. Barrow, a commercial photographer, moved to New York from Virginia more than a decade ago and fell in love with the city. PRIVATE MOMENTS: Impressions of Manhattan (Howell Press, $39.95), a lushly romantic collection of photographs, reflects his uncritical ardor for his new home.

title: Bo Jackson: He Knows Kids and Family and the Art of Hitting
description: Bo Jackson is one player who could have benefited from the threatened lockout if only he had been able to plan for it. No, Bo doesn't need the extra rest between football and baseball seasons. Had he known he might have more time before spring training, he could have planned for more school work.

title: Lawyers' Objection Follows a Pattern
description: I would like to thank the editor who brought us the funny story about the lawyers objecting to mandatory continuing education. These are the same people who object to ''pro bono'' legal assistance in offices or courts. These are the same people who have made it a requirement for other professionals to have continuing education so they can better serve the public.

title: Margaret Price Cancellation
description: The Soprano Margaret Price, who is ill, has cancelled the recital she was to give at Avery Fisher Hall on Feb. 11 It will not be rescheduled. Refunds may be obtained in person or by writing to: Avery Fisher Hall Box Office, Broadwat at 65th Street, New York, N.Y. 10023. Information: 874-2424

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Why the Gray Years Are Called Golden
description: LEAD: MY body, which has achieved its 74th year, submits regularly to an expensive review of its future. This is done, on a trimensal basis, by a Norwalk urologist, a Wilton chiropractor, a Westport dermatologist and a woman who reads Tarot cards in a Bridgeport storefront.

title: Builders Unveil Ski Resort Plan
description: EARLY WINTERS RESORT, a development company based in Bellevue, Wash., has disclosed plans for a $1 billion ski and summer resort five miles northeast of this northeastern Washington village. It would be the largest recreation development in the state.

title: The Rush to One Germany Starts to Blur Europe's Map of Alliances
description: IT had long been the common wisdom that East Germany could have no separate identity if stripped of Communism. What nobody seemed to realize until recently, however, was just how true this was - how rapidly the ''first state of workers and peasants on German soil'' would disintegrate once freed of the Muscovite mold, how swiftly its citizens would reach out to the other Germany.

title: The Methodical Ways of a Collector
description: THE toothpaste tubes should have sent up a signal. When I began dating my husband, his friends chided him about being forthright and honest. I wondered what deep, dark secrets he was hiding. Did he have a criminal record? Was he suffering from some dreaded disease? As it turned out, his affliction was, and is, obsessive collecting.

title: Crying Wolf Over Swans
description: THE caller was somewhat irate. Dismissing me as an uninformed zealot bent on giving hunters a hard time, my critic came to the crux of her argument.

title: Investigating the Darker Corners of The Criminal Mind
description: Educated as well as entertained by those British-made TV adaptations of English crime and mystery fiction that have become a staple feature of public-broadcasting and cable network programming, most American viewers can now distinguish at a glance their favorite detective heroes. This season alone, we have been matching wits with such distinctive sleuths as Agatha Christie's Hercule Poirot, John Mortimer's Rumpole of the Bailey and Dorothy L. Sayers's Lord Peter Wimsey.

title: Editors' Note
description: The Times today adopts the country name Romania, spelled with an o, in place of Rumania. The o form is preferred by many Romanians as a reflection of their Roman origins and has been favored in recent years by most English-language publications.

title: LIFE IS GOOD, BUT DEATH IS STRONG

title: Abigail H. Ross Weds Pierce Sioussat
description: Abigail Hale Ross and Pierce Stewart Sioussat were married yesterday at Brick Presbyterian Church in New York by the Rev. Dr. Herbert B. Anderson. Noel Mason was the maid of honor and Timothy Barnes the best man.

title: In Greenwich, Italian and Informal
description: EVERY town should have a restaurant like Pasta Vera, an informal place that serves freshly made food at reasonable prices.

title: Social Events
description: Bowling with the Stars

title: Other Towns' Projects Unsettling Greenwich
description: LEAD: THE Greenwich First Selectman, John B. Margenot Jr., says that while he does not ''want to have a siege mentality,'' a succession of other governments' public works is making him feel that his town is threatened from without. ''If we don't act to protect ourselves, no one else will,'' he said. At one of the town's borders, Westchester County officials are planning to expand the Westchester County Airport.

title: The Heckelphone: More Musical Than Its Name
description: LEAD: THERE is something about the Heckelphone that satisfies Mark Perchanok artistically. It's not the name. ''That's unfortunate,'' Mr. Perchanok said. ''It makes people laugh.''

title: A June Wedding For Miss Weber
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Dorsey Weber of Guilford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Dorsey Weber, to Karl-Erik Leopoldo Gude, a son of the late Helena Borda de Gude and the late Erik Anker Gude. A June wedding is planned.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL: Locals;   Hofstra Defeats Delaware
description: Frank Walker scored 22 points and Hofstra beat Delaware by 79-64 today in an East Coast Conference game.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Betrayed by Their Minutiae

title: Style Makers;   Jeff Weiss, Advertising Linguist
description: Jef Wis waye kul. Hiz kwan-tro adz, c'est mutch stile.

title: The Rebel's Answer to Pretoria
description: In a speech before the South African Parliament on Friday, President F .W . de Klerk announced measures designed to create a climate conducive to negotiating an end to apartheid. They include the legalization of the African National Congress and the release of its imprisoned leader, Nelson Mandela. Despite Mr. de Klerk's remarks that armed struggle in South Africa is no longer justified, the issue of the cessation of violence by all sides has not lost its importance.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: LIVING WITH A PARENT WHO TAKES DRUGS

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Kew Gardens
description: LEAD: IN the middle of Queens, straddling Long Island Rail Road tracks and hard by an IND express stop, lies Kew Gardens, a quiet suburban neighborhood that has changed little in 50 years.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Florida Imposes Fees for Fishing In Saltwater

title: New Orleans Mayor Is Easy Victor in Bid for a Second Term
description: Mayor Sidney Barthelemy won a second term in a primary today, capturing well over the 50 percent of votes he needed to avoid a runoff against his challenger, Donald Mintz.

title: Review/Dance;   Fagan's 'Easter Freeway'
description: Garth Fagan's ''Easter Freeway Processional'' may well become a modern-dance classic. The dance, created in 1983, offers a clear and vibrant look into Mr. Fagan's unusual choreographic style and uses Philip Glass's music in an equally fresh way. Mysterious emotion bubbles through its fairly formalistic surface. And it is one of those pieces that make the dancers shine, as they did last Sunday in a performance by the Jamison Project at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street).

title:
DANCE;

Reversing a 'One-Way Street' for Ballet
description: LEAD: IN recent years, modern-dance choreographers have frequently traveled into the realm of ballet, creating works in jazz and modern-dance idioms for classically trained dancers. But reciprocal invitations have been conspicuously lacking, some ballet choreographers say. With the advent of an artistic collaboration between Peter Anastos, a ballet choreographer, and modern dancers of the Carolyn Dorfman Dance

title: BURST BY THOMAS SPARKS THE PISTONS
description: Isiah Thomas, playing with five fouls, scored 7 of Detroit's final 9 points today as the Pistons beat the Cleveland Cavaliers, 105-100, for their sixth consecutive victory.

title: Lost in the Mists of Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Sides in Angola Claim Rebel Stronghold
description: The fate of an Angolan rebel stronghold remained unclear today, with both sides in the 15-year civil war claiming that they held the town.

title: Queen Closes the Games
description: Queen Elizabeth II brought the curtain down on the 14th Commonwealth Games today and the 11-day, 57-nation event closed in controversy as one of the world's best-known runners, John Walker, made a sad and angry exit in front of his home public.

title: Lifestyle;   Where a Romance Just Might Bloom
description: The definitions of a romantic dinner vary as much as the people who are asked to define it. To some it may be a snug and serene dining room twinkling with candlelight. To others it might be dressing up in evening clothes and gliding across the dance floor at Maxim's, or maybe living out your Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers fantasy at the Rainbow Room, complete with a chilled bottle of Champagne waiting on the sidelines.

title: Amy J. Schiffman Becomes a Bride
description: Amy Jane Schiffman and Charles Andrew Langer were married last evening at their home in New York by Cantor Ellen Stettner Math.

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: West Germany;   Bonn Balks at Soviet Plea For Vote on German Unity
description: The West German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, today rejected a Soviet proposal for an international referendum on German unity and said his Government expected Moscow to help ease the process of German reunification.

title: THE WOMAN WHO LOVED DR. JEKYLL
description: MARY REILLY

title: The Executive Life
description: LEAD: Heard the one about the $300 orange?

title: Elizabeth Carroll Marries
description: Elizabeth Mary Carroll, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Carroll of River Edge, N.J., was married yesterday at the Clinton Inn in Tenafly, N.J., to Steven Rudinsky, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Rudinsky of New York. Judge John F. Keenan of the United States Federal District Court for the Southern District of New York officiated. Mrs. Rudinsky, 28 years old, is a teacher at P.S. 190 in Manhattan. She is a graduate of Fairfield University and received a master's degree in education from Hunter College. Her husband, 36, is the president of New Vision Management, a recruiting firm in New York. He attended the State University at Oneonta, N.Y.

title: VENTURERS
description: YOUNG MAN started his career as a makeup artist at a cosmetics company. He worked his way up and, with $80,000 from the sale of his house, moved to California to invent his own line. He ordered $500,000 worth of makeup and other products from an Italian concern that supplies the leading cosmetics companies, but when they arrived, the lipstick cases were smashed and the foundation bottles were shattered. The young man melted and reshaped the lipsticks by holding a hair dryer to them; then, one by one, he placed them in new cases. He heated lip gloss on the kitchen stove and piped it through a pastry bag into containers. He carted his products to beauty salons to sell them. At night, he'd return to the stove, churning out a new supply for the next round of sales.

title: At a Defense Plant, No Peace if Jobs Are Lost
description: LAST year, Textron Lycoming in Stratford was predicting a secure future: It had orders to produce 1,000 Army tank engines a year through 1996.

title: AFGHANS: Now They Blame America
description: AT FIRST, IT WAS A JUST A morbid whistling overhead, the sound of an antipersonnel rocket in the dying moments of flight. Then it exploded in a shattering burst of smoke and dust.

title: 777 Madison Ave.
description: To the Editor:

title: The Debate On Self-Service Gas
description: I find it comical, if not ludicrous, to read that safety is one of the factors in prohibiting self-service gas stations in New Jersey (''Debate on Self-Service Gas Lives On,'' Dec. 31).

title: 'Stanley and Iris' Carries a Message Of H-O-P-E
description: ''I have a poster i should show you,'' said Harriet Frank Jr., who, with her husband, Irving Ravetch, co-wrote ''Stanley and Iris,'' which opens Friday. ''It says, 'America: one out of every four people can't read this word.' '' The writer adds: ''It's impactful, it's true and it's a tragedy.''

title: Changing the Culture of Spending at Merrill Lynch
description: On some evenings, William A. Schreyer, chairman and chief executive of Merrill Lynch & Company, takes a helicopter to his home in Princeton, N.J., from Manhattan. This weekend, the brokerage firm, the nation's largest, is hosting an elaborate ''junk bond'' conference, trying to outdo the decadent ball held by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. And on occasion, Merrill hosts exotic trips for its bankers and clients.

title: New Doubt as Jury Takes Up Stuart Case
description: A grand jury investigating what the authorities suspect was Charles Stuart's scheme to kill his pregnant wife heard testimony this week from one of his brothers, his closest friend and several other people who might shed light on the case.

title: In Hot Pursuit
description: On Thursday night, with yesterday's start of the 24 Hours of Daytona sports car endurance race just a couple of days away, it seemed only natural that Al Unser Jr., his cousin, Robby Unser, and Raul Boesel of Brazil, all members of the Dauer racing team, would try to get in a little practice.

title: Maryland Admits Ticket-Scalping
description: University of Maryland athletic officials have acknowledged to the N.C.A.A. that a coach's scheme to scalp tickets for players in 1988 was not an isolated incident, Jeff Adkins, a former Maryland assistant basketball coach, said.

title: Mary Gallatin to Marry Clay Stobaugh
description: Mr. and Mrs. James P. Gallatin of New York and Lloyd Harbor, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Buchanan Gallatin, to Clay Edward Stobaugh, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert B. Stobaugh of Belmont, Mass., and Goudarques, France.

title: Redmen Lose Williams
description: For St. John's, a third consecutive Big East Conference loss was now the least of their problems. A 7-point second-half lead that evaporated more because of their own failures than the success of their opponents had become a footnote.

title: No Stealing
description: There seems a good possibility that for years to come some top officials at the Ford Motor Company will think about Robert W. Kearns (below) every time it rains. In a closely watched patent-infringement suit, a jury in Detroit ruled last week that Mr. Kearns had invented the intermittent windshield wiper used in Ford products and that he was entitled to seek royalties. Mr. Kearns, a former engineering professor who said his invention showed up on Ford vehicles a few years after he showed it to company officials in the early 1960's, is asking $50 for every vehicle sold with his device. Since most cars use the device and since Mr. Kearns has similar suits pending against other auto manufacturers, the 62-year-old inventor could theoretically win as much as $1 billion. Just when he might receive the money is another question. The jury in the case, which has already dragged on for 12 years, will hear arguments on how much Ford should pay Mr. Kearns later this month. Whatever the amount of the award, Ford is almost certain to appeal.

title: Capitalizing on a New Market in Europe
description: AS the Iron Curtain rises, the stage is set for trade, and some of the players are already in place.

title: Q and A
description: Battle of Britain Anniversary

title: Song of Vilnius
description: THE COPPER SCULPTURES IN THE background of the photograph above are among 10 that will be installed at the Opera and Ballet Theater in Vilnius, Lithuania, on Feb. 16. They are the work of artists who belong to Skulpturos Kooperatyvas, an independent enterprise that separated from the state two years ago, among the first steps toward privatization in Lithuania during the Gorbachev era of perestroika. Each nearly 11 feet high and fashioned in welded copper from plaster models, the sculptures represent figures from operas known both locally and internationally, including Mephistopheles from ''Faust'' (far left), Amneris from ''Aida'' (center) and Margiris, a 14th-century warrior hero of Lithuanian legend and central figure of an opera called ''Pilenai.'' (The finished statue is in the rear, second from left; the plaster mold is in the foreground.) Feb. 16 is Lithuanian Independence Day, signifying the occasion in 1918 that Lithuania initiated its short-lived period of self-rule, a tumultuous - but progressive - two decades that came to an end with the republic's incorporation into the Soviet Union in 1940. The fervid emergence of nationalism in recent months makes this year's anniversary loom as especially charged. According to Arunas Degutis, a candidate for the Supreme Soviet backed by Sajudis, the broad-based reform movement in Lithuania, the artists' cooperative is an important symbol. ''Since the order to build the statues was received during the years of stagnation,'' he said, responding, in Lithuanian, to written questions, ''it's hard to say this is part of a cultural renaissance.'' But the dedication day, Feb. 16, he said, is significant. The cooperative, he added, is rebuilding sculptures on the grounds of Vilnius Cathedral, ''which is a result of the changes in Lithuania.''

title: Sports of The Times;   The Land Before Super Bowl Time
description: On the morning after the San Francisco 49ers won their second consecutive Super Bowl game, George Seifert was reminded that nobody has ever won three in a row. True to his personality, the 49er coach responded with a soft smile.

description: STRUGGLES FOR FREEDOM

title: U.S. Aid Just Dribbles In to Nicaragua Opposition, but the Sandinistas Profit
description: A $9 million program to assist the opposition in Nicaragua's presidential election has encountered so many delays and bureaucratic obstacles that a Nicaraguan Government agency has received more money than the coalition of opposition parties supported by the United States, American officials say.

title:
A SPECIAL GUIDE TO CRUISES WORLDWIDE;

Combining Disney Trip And Sailings
description: LEAD: Combining a cruise with a visit to central Florida's prime destination, Walt Disney World, has proved so popular that Premier Cruise Lines, the official cruise line of Disney World, bases three ships in Port Canaveral: the Star/Ship Oceanic, the Star/Ship Atlantic and the Star/Ship Majestic.

title: For New Health Chief, More Problems Ahead
description: NEW YORK CITY'S new health commissioner will not get the usual honeymoon period. Instead, the tenure of Dr. Woodrow A. Myers Jr. is going to be something akin to instant marriage counseling as he seeks reconciliation with the advocates for AIDS services who are bitterly divided over his selection. Important decisions on the city's fight against AIDS hang in the balance.

title: EMERSON ON THE MARCH
description: A CHOICE OF INHERITANCE

title: No Headline
description: Kerry Goldberg Planning to Wed

title: No Blessing
description: The Roman Catholic basilica in the Ivory Coast town of Yamoussoukro was intended to be among the biggest houses of God in the world, but until Pope John Paul II says otherwise, it is little more than the world's largest air-conditioned space. President Felix Houphouet-Boigny had hoped that the Pope would break the schedule of his five-nation African tour last week to bless the enormous cathedral, which is larger than St. Peter's and has an esplanade that can hold 300,000 people. But the basilica, which contains 30 acres of marble and four times the stained glass of the French cathedral in Chartres, cost at least $150 million to build, and the Pope's main theme in Africa was to scold the prosperous for not sharing their wealth. The Vatican has not said that Mr. Houphouet-Boigny should be faulted for spending such a great sum on a church building while his nation is mired in poverty. After all, the great cathedrals of Europe were built when most Europeans lived in similar conditions. But the Pope has shown no inclination to consecrate the Ivory Coast basilica any time soon. A Vatican spokesman hinted at hope: It would be nice, he said, if the building contained more than a church, perhaps an ''institute dedicated to social development.''

title: Shellfire Traps Thousands as Lebanese Truce Fails
description: Rival Christian forces fought with tanks and gunboats for a fifth day today, violating a Vatican-brokered truce after just three hours. Shellfire reportedly killed 25 people and trapped 500,000 in shelters.

title: Troubled Jet Is Brought In
description: An American Airlines 727-200 jetliner with 63 people aboard landed safely at O'Hare International Airport on Friday after the pilot reported steering problems. The flight originated in Omaha. The pilot brought the airliner in with a back-up hydraulic system. No one was hurt.

title: An Epic and Jazz: 2 Views of Black History
description: CONNECTICUT has pulled out more stops than usual for Black History Month; in Hartford alone, half a dozen or more shows are scheduled. Current attractions include a retrospective by the photographer Gordon Parks, at the State Legislative Office Building; a juried show by local black artists, at the Pump House Gallery in Bushnell Park, and ''Free Man,'' a documentary about the successful rebellion of a group of Africans on board the Spanish slave ship Amistad and the American antislavery movement, at the Connecticut Historical Society. Come Thursday, the State Commission on the Arts presents its own selection of black artists, at the Showcase Gallery.

title: Alix Hornblower Becomes a Bride
description: Alexandra Tower Hornblower and Daniel Kempner Thorne were married yesterday at the Knickerbocker Club in New York by Judge Joseph M. McLaughlin of Federal District Court for the Eastern District of New York. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. John Train of Bedford, N.Y., and Whitney Tower of New York and Saratoga Springs, N.Y. Mr. Thorne is the son of the late Oakleigh Lewis Thorne and the late Mary Jean Kempner Pryce-Jones.

title:
GARDENING;

The Search for Flowering Trees
description: LEAD: THE decline of the native flowering dogwood, Cornus florida, because of fungus diseases has resulted in a dilemma when it comes to selecting a flowering tree for the garden. The flowering crab apple is probably the second most popular tree in the area, but there are many other choices to consider, depending on such requirements as color of flower and time of bloom.

title: Why Airline Safety Looks Worse as It Gets Better
description: HOW many passenger jets will crash this year? This is not a popular question with the airlines, which are extraordinarily sensitive to public doubts about safety. But an attempt to answer it illuminates both successes and gaps in aviation's safety record.

title: Style Maker;   Beverly Adler, Jewelry Designer
description: Buttons were not especially voguish five years ago when Beverly Adler, sifting through a jumble of flea market jewelry, came upon a whimsical bracelet of mismatched buttons. She later learned that young Appalachian women crocheted such bracelets during the 1930's, raiding their grandmothers' sewing boxes to create Depression-era jewels. The time was right for a revival of this folk art, as fashion watchers will attest.

title: The Effect of Balloons On the Environment
description: Except for scientific or educational purposes, balloons should be eliminated from use outdoors. Of course there is a sense of excitement (as noted by Erwin Lewis, in his letter to the New Jersey editor on Dec. 17) felt by each of us when they float overhead. However, if only one bird or animal (including human) is injured through strangulation on the things, their use must be stopped. There is another issue involved. In the course of promoting a sports event, students at a neighboring high school, with the approval of the school authorities, launched a thousand balloons. They caused littering in adjoining communities, including mine.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;

Balancing Conservation vs. Development
description: LEAD: THE woods and fields that ring many of New Jersey's reservoirs have long remained undisturbed, forming a distinct natural environment while helping to maintain the quality of the water supply.

description: MONDAY: The Senate Finance Committee holds hearings on Senator Moynihan's proposed Social Security tax cut.

title: CORRECTION
description: A box on Jan. 21 with an article about Harry J. Gray, head of American Medical International Inc., misidentified a business professor at Emory University who has studied older executives. He is Jeffrey Sonnenfeld.

title: NONFICTION
description: WHATCHAGOT STEW: A Memoir of an Idaho Childhood, With Recipes and Commentaries. By Patrick F. McManus and Patricia McManus Gass. Illustrated by Shannon McManus Bayfield. (Holt, $16.95.) ''Whatchagot Stew'' is one long bad joke about how everyone nowadays is writing cookbooks: ''Carl Sagan wrote in Parade magazine that unless a serum was developed soon, within a few years all the land surface on earth would be covered with cookbooks to a depth of twelve feet.'' Since he seems to be unable to handle such an original idea by himself, Patrick F. McManus, author of such previous books as ''The Night the Bear Ate Goombaw,'' teams up here with his sister, Patricia McManus Gass, whom he calls ''The Troll.'' In the memoir of his Idaho childhood Mr. McManus kills off his father in just a few lines so that he can concentrate on details like his mother's favorite culinary tips, one of which was ''just scrape off the burnt part.'' His mother, a teacher, raised the brother and sister alone. Part of the time the family even lived in the back of the schoolhouse where she taught. Mabel McManus probably was an interesting character. Unfortunately, the writing is so ''seasoned with bawdy jokes, loud laughter, bad whiskey, and endless psychological torment'' that truth is completely beside the point. The recipes in the cookbook section are burdened with titles like ''Pat's Perky Popovers.'' One bear recipe - like a great many of the recipes here, Mr. McManus brags, this one was borrowed from another cook - takes over a week to prepare. After all the bad jokes, it's never entirely clear that the reader is supposed to take the recipes seriously. It doesn't matter, since you won't be hungry anyway.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

My Life Revealed in Check Stubs
description: LEAD: I HAVE never kept a diary, but the information contained in old checkbooks seems to have served the same purpose with a lot less wear and tear on the writer. Analyzing the stubs, I am able to piece together what I was doing 5, 10, 20 and more years ago.

title: The Farm Economy Is Fine, And Can Expect More Aid
description: WHEN President Franklin D. Roosevelt signed the first farm subsidy law on May 12, 1933, he promised it was a temporary measure. At a time when people were hungry, he remarked, the Government had no business propping up prices by paying farmers to hold back their harvests. Now, nearly 60 years later, the payments are as much a part of American agriculture as the sun and rain, and tremendously expensive as well.

description: The Communist Party's latest round of humiliation began on New Year's Eve, when a drunken chauffeur in the Ukrainian city of Chernigov swerved his Government car into a lamppost.

IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;

Concordia Is Restoring an 1840 Mansion
description: LEAD: A 150-YEAR-OLD house across Route 22 from the Concordia College campus in Bronxville will echo again with the sound of music once the clamor of its current restoration has subsided.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday on the right to bear arms misstated the annual number of murders in the United States. In recent years there have been just over 20,000.

description: This is the time of year when camera makers proudly trot out their newest models. Why? Because the annual Photo Marketing Association convention is soon to happen in Las Vegas. Every manufacturer wants to have something new to generate foot traffic at its booth.

description: This is in response to a letter to the New Jersey editor in hope that the author, Erwin Lewis, will get his facts straight on the harmful effects of balloon releases.

title: MY JOSEPHINE BAKER
description: There have been more than a dozen books written about Josephine Baker. She herself wrote five autobiographies, a novel and a collection of fairy tales that expressed her vision of universal brotherhood. Since she died in 1975 at the age of 69, at least seven books by other people have been published.

title: Question Of the Week;   Should N.F.L. Drug Testing Be Revised?
description: The drug-testing policy of the N.F.L. should not be under scrutiny here, but rather the journalistic ethics of WJLA radio in its irresponsible attempt for sensationalistic headlines during Super Bowl week. (Is it a coincidence that this radio station cast a shadow over the most prominent player in the Super Bowl, Joe Montana, when it said that three white quarterbacks were ''guilty''?) The N.F.L. is sensible and humane in its drug-testing policy. The first time a player tests positive, no one is told about it, other than the player himself. (For the second offense, players get a 30-day suspension). So how could this radio station have found out that these three quarterbacks tested positive for drug use, if the anonymity of first offenders is protected? WJLA radio could just as easily have said 13 or 30 players were guilty.

description: EVOLUTION OF THE BRAIN

title: Whitaker Retains Titles
description: Pernell (Sweetpea) Whitaker, the International Boxing Federation and World Boxing Council lightweight champion, retained his titles tonight when he won a 12-round unanimous decision over Freddie Pendleton at the Convention Center here.

title: FICTION
description: THREE-LEGGED HORSE. By Ann Hood. (Bantam, Paper, $7.95.) Between the tuna casseroles, the women's magazines of yesteryear served up heart- and hearth-warming fiction. The spirit of that fiction, nicely adapted to the changing social patterns of the 1980's, suffuses ''Three-Legged Horse,'' Ann Hood's third novel, in which Abby Nash comes belatedly of age, shedding her immaturity in the person of her footloose husband, Zach, for whom the summer of 1969 will never end. Licensed as a perpetual adolescent (he's an artist), Zach once seemed irresistibly ''dangerous to love,'' but Abby has finally won through to the home truth that love's not all you need. After a dozen years as a de facto single mother, earning her keep as part of a folk band called Three-Legged Horse, Abby has sung ''Both Sides Now'' in enough tacky lounges to get the message. Ms. Hood purports to tell the family drama from three perspectives. Hannah, the teen-age daughter of Abby and Zach, offers us a mix of Eloise and Holden Caulfield, but Dad gets less than a sixth of the book. Ms. Hood, several steps ahead of her heroine, has apparently written him off. The author's generalizations (''Like most dreams, this one didn't come true'') would equally have served the fictional sorority of the 1950's. But the terms of women's reality have been brought up to date. Not only is Zach impossible, but Doug and Sean (the horse's other legs) also founder. Even Gavin, Abby's unexceptionable suitor, is dismissed with the rest of the shiftless guys: '' 'I can't count on you to make my life wonderful,' Abby said, and her voice was clear and sure. 'I can't count on you or storybook fantasies.' '' What can she count on? Hannah, who's wised up early. The prospect of a female guitar player, Jocelyn, to regenerate ''the new improved Three-Legged Horse.'' Her violin. ''Everything,'' as Hannah puts it, ''that matters.''

title: Keeping the Percys Straight
description: To the Editor:

title: Campus Life: Albany;   Panel Investigates Noise Complaints Against Students
description: The Albany police are used to occasional complaints from residents about noisy parties in the homes of student neighbors. But since September, the police say, those complaints - about revelers urinating on private property, destroying shrubs and arguing loudly in the streets late at night - have gotten out of hand.

title: The Classic Conglomerate Wades Into the 90's
description: It has a reputation for business aplomb, but Textron Inc., the Providence, R.I., conglomerate, is also a company that's found itself on the crest of trends. Back in the early 1950's, when single-mindedness was American corporate gospel, Textron's founder, Royal Little, decided he needed a strategy to protect his cyclical textile business, so he invented the modern conglomerate. In the 1960's, a Textron subsidiary, Bell Helicopter, rode the Huey, the signature aircraft of the war in Vietnam, to record profitability.

title: McEnroe: Victim or Villain?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Pastimes;   Bridge
description: Tournament bridge is in general a democratic game with almost everyone permitted to play subject to occasional restrictions based on gender, age or, more frequently, past performance measured by some standard such as master points.

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: East Germany;   At House of Democracy, Some Pluralism for Berlin
description: A single building, a solid five-story structure from the days of the last Kaiser, houses more political groupings today than this capital has known since Hitler came to power 57 years ago.

title: Wildfowling, Heart and Soul
description: George Reiger's book ''The Wildfowler's Quest'' (Nick Lyons Books, $24.95) is an exuberant, perceptive and sensitive excursion into a venerable tradition that each year moves many hunters to set forth with delight on bitter, stormy days when most men choose to remain beside the hearth.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu;   Salmon Milan-Style: Unlikely Delight
description: Milanese, or Milan-style, means that there will be parmigiano reggiano in the dish along with bread crumbs and eggs. Veal Milanese, rice Milanese and chicken Milanese all sound reasonably familiar. But salmon Milanese?

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Mr. de Klerk, he is trying to start a new South Africa. At least he has got that direction.''

title: MARKET WATCH
description: Investors would have done well to have dabbled in the stock market the first and last trading days of January, but to have taken to the ski slopes in between. The gains of 56.95 and 47.30 points, respectively, on those two days formed handsome bookends around what was otherwise a discouraging trounce.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

Getting Home The Hard Way
description: LEAD: IT'S been a long, tough day at the office in New York. All I want is to get home, have a beer and some dinner and read a good-night story to my son. First, though, I must experience mass transit. PATH dumps me in the bowels of the Hoboken station. Those precious few seconds halted en route make me late for N.

title: Children Learning to Remain Calm
description: LEAD: A DOZEN first graders at Public School 11 in Clifton were gathered around a circle with their teacher, recalling the last time they used a technique to remain calm in a stressful situation.

title: Wall Street
description: The cover of the 1988 annual report of the Rite Aid Corporation, the nation's largest drugstore chain, seems oddly prophetic today. It showed a workman in a hard hat buffing one of the company's giant red-white-and-blue signs. Last April, almost exactly a year after the report was issued, the company's president stood accused of attempting to bribe a member of Ohio's pharmacy board, a giant-sized smudge that is still clouding the market's view of the company.

title: Question Of the Week;   Should N.F.L. Drug Testing Be Revised?
description: In reference to your call for opinions on National Football League drug testing policies: the men playing the games today are big boys. They all know the risks and dangers of using and abusing drugs. I think the league should butt out and leave the individual teams to decide their own policies. Those teams with weak policies will end up out of the game because of weak, debilitated and jailed players.

title: Not All the Drama Is on the Stage
description: BARCELONA is a city of innate theatricality. It is a theatricality that springs, in large part, from the vivid contrasts that make Barcelona so engaging. Laundry hangs from lines draped across apartment houses on some of the most cosmospolitan of streets. A city plaza that bursts with Saturday night street-fair festivities, complete with the skulking ladrones and murmuring gitanos - petty thieves and gypsies - that tourists are warned about, is taken over by elderly men selling stamps and antique postcards on the sunny Sunday morning that follows. A stroll down the Ramblas or a quiet beer at a sidewalk cafe along that bustling pedestrian thoroughfare is likely to yield one human drama after another a few moments. ''More, perhaps, than any city in the world,'' Rose MacCauley wrote of Barcelona, ''it gives an impression of tempestuous, surging, irrepressible life and brio.''

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: MARY LITTLE PARELL;

Regulating Banking in an Era of Growth
description: LEAD: UNTIL last month, Mary Little Parell was the Commissioner of the New Jersey Department of Banking. Her six-year tenure occurred during a period of enormous growth in the state's economy and radical change in the banking industry.

title:
IN SHORT: FICTION;

MONKEY WRENCH ONCE MORE
description: LEAD:

title: Rachel L. Braun To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harvey D. Braun of Livingston, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Rachel Lynn Braun to Zev Stuart Scherl, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Newton Scherl of Englewood Cliffs, N.J. A May wedding is planned. Miss Braun, 24 years old, is a senior account executive at Hill & Knowlton in the public relations firm's New York headquarters. She graduated magna cum laude from Duke University, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. Her father is chairman of the retail services group at Deloitte & Touche in New York. Her mother, Susan Braun, is a psychotherapist in New York.

title: East Harlem Sees Slain Boy As Victim of Drug Epidemic
description: A handmade sign attached to an iron fence at a school in East Harlem said the soup kitchen there would be closed yesterday because of a ''death in our family, Robert Cole, age 13.''

title: For the Sudan, Famine Is Almost As Certain As Civil War
description: POTENTIALLY one of the most prosperous agricultural spots in Africa, the Sudan is facing yet another famine, this time caused not by weather but by war.

title: Review/Dance;   Mark Taylor's 2 Sides: Sanitized and Knotty
description: There were two Mark Taylors on view Thursday at St. Mark's Church, where Mark Taylor and Friends presented a program of four new and recent dances. One Mr. Taylor was a choreographer who creates dances that lope and canter easily through open space, with a sanitized look that is very far from the irony and ambiguity so fashionable now in dance. The other choreographs dark, knotty pieces that look into lives at a particular moment in time. His new ''Union Hall,'' a vibrant little treasure of a dance, belongs in the second category.

title: A PIOUS AND DEPRAVED LIFE
description: PALACE WALK

title: Who's in Charge Here?
description: When Donna Shalala left Hunter College in 1988 to become chancellor at the University of Wisconsin, she received a piece of advice that she has not forgotten.

title: AMERICAN SPIES IN PURSUIT OF THE AMERICAN DREAM
description: For some 18 years, John Walker Jr. sold top military secrets to the Soviet Union, managing in the process to recruit his son, brother and best friend to help him. It's been estimated by some intelligence experts that Mr. Walker provided enough code-data information to alter significantly the balance of power between Russia and the United States. Yet, curiously, the Walker story has not evoked the sustained public attention and outrage once triggered by cases involving Klaus Fuchs or the Rosenbergs. The reason becomes apparent in CBS's five-hour movie ''Family of Spies,'' getting underway tonight at 9, with the conclusion Tuesday at 8.

title: How Shamir at Home Caused Storm Abroad
description: A Soviet official announced in Tunis this weekend that the Soviet Union would not allow direct flights from Moscow to Tel Aviv for Soviet immigrants to Israel, despite a commercial agreement between the two nations to begin the flights in January.

title: Gooden, Hernandez Support Strawberry
description: Darryl Strawberry began 28 days of treatment for alcohol abuse yesterday, and was portrayed as very subdued and scared at the thought that he stood at a crossroads in his personal life and in his career in baseball.

title: Inquiry Gives Race To Dancing Spree
description: The stretch run up the rail that won Dancing Spree the $1 million Breeders' Cup Sprint three months ago didn't quite work in the $50,000 Gulfstream Park Sprint Championship Handicap today, but the stewards made him the winner anyway.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Lessons of Nuclear Winter;   Impassioned Experts Blow Hot and Cold
description: The horrors of nuclear war are hard to exaggerate. That hasn't stopped proponents of the ''nuclear winter'' theory, who announced in 1983 that the soot from a large nuclear war would blot out sunlight and create weeks of icy darkness. The result could be ''global environmental changes sufficient to cause the extinction of a major fraction of the plant and animal species on the Earth,'' wrote a group of eminent biologists in Science magazine. ''In that event, the possibility of the extinction of Homo sapiens cannot be excluded.''

title: Los Angeles Journal;   Bigger. Richer. Taller. It's Trump!
description: There is a Carnegie Deli here. There is a Saks Fifth Avenue. There are enough Mets fans to drown out the locals at Dodger Stadium. There is even going to be a subway. So perhaps it was inevitable that Los Angeles would one day get Donald J. Trump.

title: 3-Pointer Adds Dimension To N.B.A.
description: WHENEVER the shot is made, the referee raises both hands, the crowd buzzes a little louder, and 3 points are added to the scoreboard.

title: Review/Theater;   Harlem Renaissance Figure Relives a Brush With Fame
description: Zora Neale Hurston was, in Alice Walker's words, ''a genius of the South,'' a country woman who reinvented herself as a novelist and folklorist and became a leader of the Harlem Renaissance in the 1920's and 1930's. She is certainly a sizable enough figure to command a stage or a movie screen, but as a subject of theatrical biography, she remains elusive.

title: Higher Rates Are Expected At Bond Auction This Week
description: Even with the sharp increase in interest rates since late December, some credit market analysts say bond yields may need to move higher still in order to attract buyers at the quarterly Treasury auctions that will be held this week.

title: Memorial of Holocaust Is Dedicated in Florida
description: Thousands of Jews, most elderly and some bearing concentration-camp numbers inscribed on their wrists, thronged today to a Holocaust memorial dedicated to what Nobel laureate Elie Wiesel called ''suffering that transcended suffering.''

title: Potential Turns to Problems
description: Ever since he was a senior at Crenshaw High School in Los Angeles in 1983, when he was the No. 1 selection in the nation in the baseball draft, the home-run hitter with the magic bat and magic name, Darryl Strawberry has either awed or exasperated people by the extremes of his performances: on the field, where he has ranged from Olympian power to sullen slumps; off the field, where he has ranged from oracle to rebel.

title: Son of Ex-President of Costa Rica Claims Victory in National Vote
description: The 40-year-old son of a former president claimed victory in presidential elections today in Latin America's oldest democracy.

title: Brooklyn Woman Charged In Kidnapping of an Infant
description: A woman who told the police she had a miscarriage two weeks ago was arrested yesterday as she walked down a Brooklyn street carrying a three-day-old boy whom the police said she kidnapped from a hospital nursery.

title: Sound Becomes the New Frontier for TV Ads
description: A new Coca-Cola commercial probably has some television viewers thinking they are hearing things. At one point during the spot, chirping birds seemingly can be heard flying overhead while the wind whistles through the living room.

title: Yound and Adrift; A special report. 7 case histories: page B8.;   Strife in Families Swells Tide of Homeless Youths
description: Driven by drug abuse, financial pressures and a growing number of single-parent families, hundreds of thousands of adolescents are running away from or being forced out of their homes every year.

title: Comfed Savings Bank Names New President
description: Jack C. Zoeller has moved smartly through many careers, first in the Army, then on Wall Street and now in the banking industry. Mr. Zoeller, 40 years old, has been named president and chief operating officer of the Comfed Savings Bank, based in Lowell, Mass.

title: Reviews/Television;   Words and Tempers Fly As Drug Abuse Is Explored
description: On one point, the participants in ''Teaching, Testing and Treatment'' can agree: drugs are not good either for the individual or for society. But beyond that, this first of four Columbia University seminars on ''Hard Drugs, Hard Choices'' reveals clashes of attitudes, principles and policies that reflect the national confusion on the subject. A mix of officials, former officials, doctors and drug fighters mix it up at 10 tonight on Channel 13.

title: Upheaval in the East: Romania;   A Veteran Leader Resigns in Bucharest
description: Silviu Brucan, a prominent figure of the Romanian revolution who became a chief target of opposition forces, resigned today from the leadership of the Council of National Salvation.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article in some copies on Saturday about the Rev. Jesse Jackson and one of his campaign fund-raisers misstated the history of Mr. Jackson's requests for permission to visit South Africa. The error also appeared in an Associated Press report published on Jan. 9 about a proposed visit by Mr. Jackson. South Africa granted Mr. Jackson a visa for a two-week visit in 1979.

title: Chronicle
description: The likelihood that Mr. Mehta's successor will be LEONARD SLATKIN, music director of the St. Louis Orchestra, has been a topic of intense discussion among highly placed figures in the music industry and orchestral circles.

title: Census Bureau Issues Call for New Workers
description: The Census Bureau is looking for people across the nation to track down hard-to-count Americans in a job that can pay as much as $8 an hour.

title: Upheaval in the East: Czechoslovakia;   RIGHTS MONITORS MEET ON CHANGES
description: Though not quite a celebration, there was a hesitant sense of victory here this weekend as human rights monitors from 16 countries gathered to discuss the changes in Eastern Europe.

title: McMartin Figure Says Trial Failed Children
description: Raymond Buckey, in his first extensive public comment since he was acquitted on dozens of child molestation charges, called the McMartin Preschool trial a miscarriage of justice that destroyed his life and left children in torment.

title: Palestinians Are Ready for Peace if Israel Is;   Political Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: Carroll V. Newsom, 85, President Of N.Y.U. Who First Taught at 14
description: Carroll Vincent Newsom, the president of New York University from 1956 to 1961 and a leader in educational television, died Saturday at his home in Dublin, Ohio. He was 85 years old.

title: South Africa's New Era;   Attention Is Turning to the Obstacles To de Klerk's Plan for Major Change
description: As South Africans began today to absorb the sweeping changes in the political landscape brought about by President F. W. de Klerk's far-reaching relaxation of political restrictions, attention among whites and blacks turned to some of the major obstacles that black groups have said stand in the way of the negotiations for ''a new democratic constitution'' that Mr. de Klerk has proposed.

title: Market Place;   Who's in No Pain When the Flu Hits
description: NOW that the Centers for Disease Control have labeled the flu outbreak a full-fledged epidemic in 35 states, it should come as no great surprise that drugstores almost everywhere are experiencing a rush for dozens of remedies to fight coughs and colds.

title: No Weddings On This Pier, Signs Declare
description: The New York City government, which has signs banning everything from U-turns on streets to smoking in buildings, now has a sign banning weddings.

title: Many Authors Seek to Be Heard as Well as Read
description: Books on audio cassettes are becoming such an important source of income for authors that audio rights are increasingly being treated as valuable literary properties.

title: Camacho Wins Fans, Too
description: At 1 in the morning, in his black robe and buckskin shoes, Hector Camacho headed out of the Convention Center followed by friends, family and, in a strange sight for boxing's leading rogue, a number of well-wishers.

title: Man Killed in Office Accident
description: A worker died today after an accident at Newsday's offices, the police said. Harold Green, 26 years old, of Westbury, was employed by Rutigliano Paper Stock, Inc., which was subcontracted by newsday to load trucks with newspapers for delivery to vendors. A preliminary investigation revealed that at 8:39 A.M., Mr. Green somehow came in contact with a loading chute, which compressed his upper body.

title: Japanese Bid Seen in Brazil
description: A group of Japanese businessmen has offered to buy Brazil's $115 billion in foreign debt in exchange for mining rights for gold deposits in the Amazon, the Brazilian newspaper O Globo said today.

title: Dinkins Urges Law to Bolster a Ban on Bias
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins renewed his call yesterday for a state law specifically banning violence motivated by prejudice. Measures to achieve this died in 1988 and 1989 because of opposition in the State Senate.

title: Accounts
description: * Kwikset Corporation, a manufacturer of locks and keys, to Eisaman, Johns & Laws, Los Angeles.

title: Upheaval in the East: Poland;   New Polish Vanguard: Unemployed Workers
description: As Poland and other Eastern European nations begin transforming their economies from Communism to capitalism, a new workers' vanguard is being formed, and Roman Anucinski is not at all happy to be part of it.

title: Chile Allows Drug Patents To Outsiders
description: In what was probably its last important legislative act, the military Government has adopted a law granting patent protection to foreign pharmaceutical companies whose products are copied and sold in Chile.

title: Melinda Lande and Lief Rosenblatt Wed
description: Melinda Lande and Lief D. Rosenblatt were married yesterday at the Plaza by Rabbi Harlan D. Wechsler.

title: Ms. Kretchmer, Geologist, Weds
description: The Stephen Wise Free Synagogue in New York was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Andrea Gail Kretchmer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Kretchmer of New York, to Dr. Paul Norman Lutvak, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Lutvak of Flushing, Queens. Rabbi Balfour Brickner performed the ceremony, assisted by Cantor Ellen Math.

title: Avianca Flight 52: The Delays That Ended in Disaster
description: Cruising at 37,000 feet near the southern New Jersey coast, neither the crew of Avianca Flight 52 nor its passengers had any apparent reason at 7:40 P.M. on Jan. 25 to worry about reaching their destination safely.

title: Bishop Says He Is Amazed At Furor Over Cuomo Issue
