description: In his first sermon since being released from jail for blocking entry to an abortion clinic, Bishop Austin Vaughan said today that he was amazed at the furor he touched off with his comment that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo was ''in serious risk of going to hell'' because he had not worked to limit abortion rights.

title: Genentech-Roche Deal May Spur Similar Ties
description: The agreement announced Friday in which a large Swiss drug company will buy a majority stake in the biotechnology pioneer Genentech Inc. could be the start of a wave of similar transactions, some industry analysts said this weekend.

title: Palestinians Are Ready for Peace if Israel Is;   Let the Wounds Heal
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Social Events column yesterday gave an incorrect time for a dinner and dance tonight at the Plaza Hotel sponsored by the Children's Hearing Institute of the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital.

title: Cutbacks at Family Media Stir Debate
description: TO some, the magazine publishing company Family Media Inc. is a model of efficiency, able to turn troubled magazines, like The Ladies' Home Journal and Discover, a monthly devoted to science, into profitable operations.

title: Critic's Notebook;   Hollywood Tactics Invade the Sundance Festival
description: Before it won the grand jury prize last week at the Sundance United States Film Festival, ''Chameleon Street'' was an obscure, arty work that had been rejected by many distributors. Now the film's writer, director and star, Wendell B. Harris Jr., is sorting through bids from casting agents interested in his acting, and his sales agency is screening the film for at least three major studios and an independent company, some of which passed on ''Chameleon Street'' the first time around.

title: Jackson a Millionaire Loser
description: Bo Jackson gambled for one of the largest raises ever sought in baseball salary arbitration and lost.

title: Business and the Law;   A Paper Spill Due In the Valdez Case
description: THE Exxon Valdez case is coming - ''one or two million pieces of paper,'' by one lawyer's estimate - and it is already testing the courts' ability to adjudicate for thousands of people at a time.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Feb. 4, 1990:

title: Upheaval in the East;   Democracy Dazes Some Romanians
description: Nikolina Gute, a 40-year-old painter at the giant 23d of August factory outside Bucharest, was one of thousands who put down their tools last Monday and headed for the city to defend the Council of National Salvation.

title: New York Post Hires Kirshenbaum & Bond
description: The New York Post has enlisted Kirshenbaum & Bond to help it fight the New York City tabloid war. The paper's previous agency, Ammirati & Puris, resigned the account in September.

title: Hermes Stake Acquired
description: The Sumitomo conglomerate of Japan entered the Parisian silk scarf business with the purchase of a small stake in Hermes, the family-controlled group said last week. Hermes, the former saddle maker that grew into a global seller of scarves and luxury leather goods, announced that Sumitomo had acquired a 1.2 percent stake in the company. It did not release further details of the purchase. The daily financial newspaper Tribune de l'Expansion said Sumitomo had paid 98 million francs ($18 million) for the small stake. The Hermes family holds 90.3 percent of the company.

title: O'Meara Wins the Pro-Am
description: Mark O'Meara's victory today at the A.T. & T. Pebble Beach National Pro-Am tournament was as devoid of drama as this year's Super Bowl, but like the San Francisco 49ers, he'll be going for three in a row next year.

title: Queens Man, 23, Is Killed On Lexington Ave. Subway
description: A 23-year-old Queens man was fatally wounded by one of three other men who approached him in the IRT-Lexington line station at East 110th Street in Manhattan yesterday evening, the police said.

title: Upheaval in the East: Soviet Union;   100,000 AT RALLY IN MOSCOW URGE DEMOCRATIC CHANGES; CRUCIAL PARTY TALKS TODAY
description: Throngs of Soviet citizens demonstrated their hunger for democracy today by parading 100,000 strong to the Kremlin walls to demand that the Communist Party surrender its monopoly of power over the life of this troubled nation.

title: Appearance Canceled For Ex-H.U.D. Official
description: The chairman of the House panel investigating abuses in the Department of Housing and Urban Development said today that he was canceling an appearance at a hearing Monday by a former top housing official who has been cooperating with investigators.

title: Old Problems Seen Giving Banks Difficulty
description: Although bank profits are expected to improve in 1990 from the depressed level of last year, bankers and analysts see little chance that they will rebound to the record level of 1988.

title: The Co-op Apartment Owner's Guide to the Risks of Default
description: To the Editor:

title: Reporter's Notebook;   For Gotti Jurors, Long Isolation Under Guards' Watchful Eyes
description: Today when summations are completed at John Gotti's trial in Manhattan, everyone will go home except the jury. For three weeks the freedom of 12 jurors and four alternates has been severely restricted as the evidence unfolded against Mr. Gotti.

title: News Summary
description: International A2-13

title: Drug Use in Pregnancy: New Issue for the Courts
description: Kimberly Hardy, a 22-year-old Michigan woman, was ordered Thursday to stand trial on a charge routinely applied to drug dealers: delivering cocaine to a minor. But the minor was her newborn, and she was charged with delivering the drug in the minute or two before the umbilical cord was clamped.

title: Bridge
description: Political figures frequently play social bridge, but few play very well, largely because their schedules are too crowded to develop expertise. One of the few exceptions, and perhaps the best bridge player worldwide among today's politicians, is John Marek, a British Member of Parliament.

title: Crack, Out of the Bottle
description: Two victims of the recent Avianca crash in New York were found to have sealed up quantities of cocaine inside condoms and swallowed them to conceal them from Customs inspectors. How can America ever hope to win a war against drugs when the demand drives people to such degrading, inventive lengths? Why not admit defeat and legalize cocaine and its smokable form, crack?

title: Upheaval in the East;   Gorbachev and the Party: 5 Years of Breathless Change
description: March 1985: Mikhail S. Gorbachev is named to succeed Konstantin U. Chernenko as Soviet leader and outlines an urgent agenda to improve the economy. At 54, he is the youngest man to take charge of the Soviet Union since Stalin, who was 45.

title: South Africa's New Era;   Wife Sees Obstacles to Mandela Release
description: The wife of Nelson Mandela today repeated that obstacles remained to her husband's release, despite President F. W. de Klerk's assertion on Friday that it was imminent. But Mr. Mandela's wife, Winnie, would not say what the obstacles were.

title: Adrift, Angry, Hurt, Alone: Stories of 7 'Throwaway' Youths
description: In midsummer, 21 young people at six youth shelters in five states talked with reporter about how they came to be there. Counselors in the shelters either veirified the accounts or said they were consistent with the lives and personalities of the young people. The stories of seven of the young people from four states are summarized here, and recent checks determined what had happened to them since the interviews.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We need a new socialism with free politics. No one will give this to us. We have to do it ourselves.''

title: South Africa's New Era;   Exiled South African Communist Says Situation Is Now More Volatile
description: The general secretary of the South African Communist Party said today that the changes announced by President F. W. de Klerk had made the political climate in that country more volatile and that the situation could worsen if the Government did not go further in meeting its opponents' demands.

title: Harold G. Warner, Retired G.M. Director, 81
description: Harold G. Warner, who rose from a job installing parts at the General Motors Corporation to become a member of the automaker's board, died of cancer Friday. He was 81 years old.

title: Texas and S.W.C. Feeling New Fire
description: The times have been few and far between when University of Texas fans could complain about a scarcity of tickets to a Longhorn basketball game. For that matter, it has been awhile since the Southwest Conference itself could generate much excitement in the sport.

title: Many Contribute to Neediest As a Tribute to Their Parents
description: To honor one's parents is a biblical commandment, and many people choose to do so by contributing to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Along with their checks, they send touching tributes.

title: After the Boom, Tough Times for Dance
description: Dance Theater of Harlem arrived in San Diego in mid-January to find itself suddenly without work because the local sponsors had run out of money. Last week, the company announced that a five-month layoff would follow its March engagement at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington. ''I don't feel in my heart it's the end of D.T.H.,'' said Arthur Mitchell, the company's artistic director. ''There must be someone out there who will help us.''

title: Books of The Times;   A Child's Revenge on Her Father's Lover
description: Homework

title: Tourist Love For New York Grows Chilly
description: The number of people visiting New York City for business or pleasure declined slightly last year, but what really worries many in the local tourism industry is the prospect that the 1989 statistics may be the first sign of a long slide.

title: Rentals Give Skiers Variety And Room to Maneuver
description: SKIERS are renting equipment in greater numbers than ever before. This increase has been caused partly because rental skis, boots and bindings have been improved in quality and performance, but also because more people are trying the sport for the first time. In addition, many skiers test different ski models before buying; others find it more convenient to rent equipment than to bring their own for ski vacations.

title: In School Bureaucracy, Despair at the System
description: The people who work behind the pebble-glass office doors of the Board of Education's headquarters in Brooklyn and walk its cheerless hallways often complain that the public perceives them as a faceless bureaucracy.

title: Islanders' Healy Stops Sabres, 1-0
description: In the first period of their game against the Sabres tonight, the Islanders gave up 20 shots on goal, which is about twice as many as is appropriate.

title: Strawberry's Demons, and Rum
description: MAYBE it's Demon Rum, and maybe it's not.

title: With Kemp at Helm, H.U.D. Gains New Spirit, but Some Doubts Linger
description: Jack Kemp was impatient. It was 6 P.M. one day last spring, and he wanted to mail a letter directing 3,300 public housing authorities to evict drug dealers. Unfortunately, the agency lawyer who was drafting the document had left for the day.

title: Policy Shift at Engelhard
description: The Engelhard Corporation, a leading metals refiner, said it would sell those businesses to concentrate on chemical production. The Edison, N.J., concern will also cut 500 jobs from its work force of 8,100 and shut a number of plants. Engelhard's stock fell $1.125 on Friday, to $20.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. Because of the restructuring, which was announced Thursday, Engelhard will take a $160 million charge on 1989 earnings, giving it a $77.5 million loss for the year.

title: Global Interests of News Corp. Cause Problems for Stock
description: The programs of Fox Broadcasting may be moving up in the ratings, but the stock of its parent company, the News Corporation, is sagging.

title: Drug Issue Plagues Colombian Soccer
description: The drug problems permeating so much of daily life in Colombia reached a favorite target again today, the national soccer federation.

title: Goal by Turcotte Wins for Rangers
description: The experiment has not been without its exasperation. Darren Turcotte, a center converted to winger, has often found himself baffled on the ice and disappointed afterward.

title: For Families of the Critically Ill, a Dose of T.L.C.
description: When her husband, former Representative Jonathan Bingham, lay dying in an intensive care unit at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center nearly four years ago, June Bingham was at his bedside every day and observed that many other gravely ill patients were all alone - forsaken by loved ones who found the visits frightening and confusing.

title: Rally by Canucks Tops Devils, 4-2
description: Dave Capuano got his first National Hockey League goal as the Canucks scored three straight times in the third period to beat the Devils, 4-2, tonight.

title: Man Held After 4 Year Hunt
description: A New Jersey man who law enforcement officials said had been a fugitive for four years using at least three aliases has been arrested by Federal agents in Connecticut. The man, George Koufas, who most recently worked as a bounty hunter for a Connecticut bail bondsman, had been a fugitive since February 26, 1986, when he escaped a hearing in New York, where he was awaiting removal to New Jersey to face charges of false reporting of firearms and impersonating a Federal agent, said U.S. Attorney Stanley A. Twardy Jr.

title: Costly Pitfalls in Worker Retraining
description: The best way to deal with workers who lose their jobs when industry shrinks, Washington has thought for years, is to teach them to do something else. But retraining is more talked about than done, and in this blue-collar city on the Arkansas-Oklahoma border, it is off to an uncommonly rocky start.

title: Company Rejects Jacobs
description: The CML Group has refused to give a list of its shareholders to Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis corporate raider. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission last week, Mr. Jacobs said he had filed suit in a Delaware state court to compel the Acton, Mass., retail chain to provide the list. A hearing on the suit is scheduled for Feb. 21. Mr. Jacobs wants to ask the shareholders to approve his plans to remove CML's board and sell the company to the highest bidder. CML has rejected Mr. Jacobs's offer of $25 a share, or $167.5 million. CML's stock rose 50 cents today, to $19.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Review/Ballet;   Balanchine's Homage to the French Manner
description: In ''La Source,'' George Balanchine paid overt tribute to France's ballet tradition. Judith Fugate and Ib Andersen of the New York City Ballet suggested in their poetic performance on Saturday afternoon that the choreography needed no outside reference, that it could be sublime on its own terms.

title: 8 Killed and 17 Wounded in Raid On Bus of Israeli Tourists in Egypt
description: Assailants armed with rifles and grenades attacked a tour bus carrying a group of Israeli academics and their wives on a main highway east of Cairo today, killing 8 Israelis and wounding 17 others, Israeli and Egyptian officials said.

title: After Lyrics, What?
description: The Pennsylvania House of Representatives has passed a bill requiring ''parental warning'' labels on certain recordings before they can be sold, or offered for sale. Since the measure requires only the warning, and does not ban sales outright, the House legal counsel insists ''there's no question that our bill is constitutional; there's no censorship in the [label] approach.''

title: Incumbent Easily Wins Second Term as the Mayor of New Orleans
description: Mayor Sidney Barthelemy won re-election to a second four-year term here on Saturday, making a comeback after polls last fall showed that he had lost the confidence of the voters.

title: Carolyn Rand Is Married
description: At the Crest Hollow Country Club in Woodbury, L.I., yesterday, Carolyn Rand was married to Allan J. Berke. Cantor Harold Lerner officiated. Mrs. Berke, 29 years old, is a daughter of Phyllis Rand of De Witt, N.Y., and the late Dr. Milton Rand. A graduate of the State University of New York at Albany, she is an assistant corporate controller at Prime Motor Inns in Fairfield, N.J. Mr. Berke, 31, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Berkowitz of Jericho, L.I., graduated from the University of Rochester and the Boston College Law School. He is an associate at the New York law firm of Tenzer, Greenblatt, Fallon & Kaplan.

title: Reviews/Television;   A New Search for the Truth In 1964 Civil Rights Killings
description: Battered and bruised, the docudrama has a disconcerting habit of bouncing back impressively.

title: Mortgage Rates Rise
description: Fixed-rate home mortgages are averaging 10.17 percent, up from 10.05 percent last week, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.45 percent this week, up from 8.41 percent the week before.

title: A New Look For Softballs
description: Softballs for amateur play will have a new look this spring. Spalding Sports Worldwide, an athletic equipment manufacturer based in Chicopee, Mass., has started to market a fluorescent yellow ball.

title: Headaches in China for Investors
description: When officials of the Shanghai Center told the Chinese customs bureau that the complex planned to import 50 to 60 cars, they received a strange notice: for each model of a Japanese car it imported, it would have to bring in two extra samples. These would be turned over to authorities for ''test driving.''

title: Health Insurers, to Reduce Losses, Blacklist Dozens of Occupations
description: In an effort to avoid losses, many insurance carriers have quietly blacklisted dozens of types of small businesses and professions. A wide variety of occupations, from bartender and gas-station attendant to oil driller and dentist, have been declared ineligible for health insurance.

title: Outdoors: Simmer 6 Days and Enjoy
description: SAVE for a few quarts of tomatoes, rhubarb and green beans, my freezer is nearly filled with venison, ducks and Canada geese, which will be consumed by the end of May to make room for bluefish and striped bass.

title: BAKER TO PROPOSE NEW AFGHAN DEAL DURING SOVIET TRIP
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d is expected to propose to the Soviets this week an approach for ending the Afghan conflict that would allow President Najibullah to remain in power in Kabul for a transitional period before having to step down, Administration officials said today.

title: Reynolds Signs $5 Million Pact
description: Harold Reynolds, the Gold Glove second baseman, reached agreement today with the Seattle Mariners on a three-year, $5 million contract.

title: Treasury Refunding Scheduled This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of issues this week includes today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and a quarterly refunding that begins tomorrow.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Christie, Manson & Woods International Inc., New York, the United States branch of the London auction concern Christie's International P.L.C., named Doris P. Meister executive vice president and chief operating officer.

title: People
description: * Cliff Wilton will retire April 1 as vice chairman and executive creative director of Saatchi & Saatchi DFS/ Pacific, San Francisco. The agency has named Mike Gold president and chief operating officer, Rob Ingalls executive vice president and creative director, Laura Dearborn executive vice president and media director, and Elizabeth Freeman senior vice president and management supervisor.

title: Upheaval in the East: The Europeans;   Fear on Germany Is Focus At East European Meeting
description: Leaders of five Eastern European countries met here today for an extraordinary public debate about the future of Europe, but the meeting was overshadowed by growing anxiety over the prospect of German reunification.

title: Why Send Rumania the Bomb?
description: LEAD: The pending shipment of bomb-grade nuclear fuel for a reactor at a Government research institute near Budapest spotlights the need to correct an overly indulgent U.S. approach to the shipment of such dangerous fuel abroad.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;

A Match Made In Hoop Heaven
description: LEAD: DONNA BRODIS and Derrick Forrest were married last May on Brodis's 20th birthday. The minister who performed the ceremony was her mother. Her father's company catered the reception. And this winter, the Forrests' propensity for keeping things in the family has made them what is believed to be the only wife-husband duo in the nation playing varsity basketball at the same major college.

title: Metro Matters;   Albany Deadlock Blocking U.S. Aid To Poor Families
description: The Federal Family Support Act, approved by Congress 16 months ago, has yet to support a single member of the family of New York.

title: Musicians Reach Contract
description: The American Federation of Musicians, which represents 185,000 musicians in the United States and Canada, reached a tentative agreement on Friday evening with representatives of the North American recording industry on a three-year contract.

title: Sununu Says He Revised Speech on Warming
description: The White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu, acknowledged today that he had edited a forthcoming Presidential speech on global warming and insisted that the changes reflected President Bush's views on the issue.

title: South Africa's New Era;   The Leaders of Black Africa Offer Some Praise, but With a Big 'If'
description: The hostile relationship between South Africa and other nations on the continent could be transformed into mutual co-operation, but only if negotiations for majority rule prevail, officials in black-ruled Africa countries say.

title: Israelis Speculate on Attack's Plotters
description: Israeli military officials speculated this evening that the attackers of an Israeli tourist bus near Cairo were members of a guerrilla organization that sent assassins across the Egyptian border into Israel in December.

title: CHURCH IN CAPITAL SETS ITS OWN RULES
description: The Rev. George A. Stallings Jr., who formed an independent African-American Catholic church last summer, said today that his congregation would encourage the ordination of women and allow birth control and abortion.

title: China Maker Promotes Grandson of Founder
description: Rosenthal A.G., the noted West German maker of fine china, is seeking to expand its presence in the United States and it has put a grandson of the company's founder in charge of its American operations.

title: Kate Simon, Acclaimed Memoirist And Travel Writer, Is Dead at 77
description: Kate Simon, a writer of popular, literate and vivid travel guides and two memoirs that were hailed by reviewers as lucid, lively and humorous, died of cancer yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 77 years old.

title: Boy Dies of Bus Crash Injury
description: A 6-year-old boy who was one of 36 children injured in a school bus accident last week died of severe head injuries today. The boy, Joseph Ribaudo of Monroe, was pronounced brain dead at 2:55 P.M., said Barry Bowman, director of public relations at the Westchester County Medical Center here. Joseph is the only child to die from the accident on Tuesday in the Orange County town of Monroe. The driver and all but two of the 38 children aboard the bus were injured.

title: Wary Knicks Await the Heat
description: In their second season in the National Basketball Association, the Miami Heat have won fewer games than any other team except the Charlotte Hornets. Miami is 19 1/2 games behind the Knicks and may be mathematically eliminated from the Atlantic Division race before the month is over.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Albania Said to Plan Some Modest Changes
description: The Central Committee of the Albanian Communist Party plans to introduce changes as part of a cautious move away from total control of society, the Albanian state press agency reported today.

title: Political Memo;   For Democrats, Something Seems Missing: Fear
description: After a decade of feeling on the wrong side of history, Democrats now sense the unfamiliar stirrings of hope.

title: Burmese Intervention Would Be a Blunder
description: To the Editor:

title: Drexel Lost $40 Million Last Year
description: Closing a chapter of its most tumultuous year, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. reported yesterday that it lost about $40 million in 1989 on gross revenues of about $4.1 billion.

title: Antonetta Ferraro, 84, Mother of Politician
description: Antonetta Ferraro, the mother of Geraldine A. Ferraro, the former Representative and Vice-Presidential candidate, died of emphysema and heart disease on Friday at the home of her daughter in Forest Hills, Queens. She was 84 years old.

title: U.S. Tells Virginia Academy To Accept Women as Cadets
description: In a move that could end a 150-year tradition at one of the nation's oldest military academies, the Justice Department has told the Virginia Military Institute in Lexington to include women in its cadet ranks or face court action.

title: The Year, Perhaps Hour, of the Child
description: This year, the President and Congress have an extraordinary opportunity to speak for the poorest and most helpless of all Americans. Those Americans don't have the vote or any economic clout; they don't know how to read and write; and while they may fight among themselves, they can't possibly fight for themselves. They are, of course, children - ''all special'' as President Bush put it in his State of the Union speech, ''because they are the very future of freedom.''

title: Neely's a Scorer Not a Fighter
description: No sooner does Cam Neely take up his position in the slot than his defenders begin their subtle retreat to positions across what has suddenly become a small, but significant demilitarized zone. The critical ground conceded Neely is done so out of a mixture of respect, fear and a kind of creeping defeatism.

title: Frederick S. Leinbach, A Paper Executive, 79
description: Frederick S. Leinbach, former president of the Riegel Paper Corporation, died of a heart attack on Friday at his home in Ocean City, N.J. He was 79 years old.

title: Palestinians Are Ready for Peace if Israel Is;   U.S. Needs to Do Better
description: To the Editor:

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL

title: Curtiss E. Frank, 85; Was Yonkers Mayor And Company Head
description: Curtiss E. Frank, a lawyer who was a mayor of Yonkers, a publishing executive and the president of Dun & Bradstreet, died of Alzheimer's disease on Saturday at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 85 years old. Mr. Frank was elected to the City Council of Yonkers in 1942, and became mayor in 1944. He resigned in 1949. As mayor, he began investigations of whether public officials had taken payoffs to overlook illegal gambling and from people doing business with the city. Control of the council see-sawed between different political parties during his years in office, and the city went through eight city managers during his tenure.

title: Shanghai Journal;   Lost in Thought in the Land of Thought Control
description: Last fall, when a minor official of the Communist Party wanted to gauge the severity of the campaign against intellectuals, she asked about the writer Bai Hua. ''Is he in jail?'' she wanted to know, and when she heard that he had been left alone, she relaxed and said, ''Things can't be that bad.''

title: Upheaval in the East;   Walesa Doesn't Plan To Keep Solidarity Post
description: Lech Walesa said today he probably would step down in April as leader of Solidarity, the union that he founded as a shipyard electrician and ultimately led into the halls of government.

title: Loyola Runs Up 157-Point Game
description: Bo Kimble, the Division I scoring leader, got 50 points tonight as Loyola Marymount, ranked No. 20, completed a stretch of scoring 448 points in three games over four days.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Complaint Tests Armenia-Azerbaijan Pact
description: A newly signed agreement between popular front leaders from Armenia and Azerbaijan was put to the test today when Armenian negotiators in the capital of Latvia complained of a fresh outbreak of strife and suspended further talks pending an investigation.

title: Cowboy Chief Under Scrutiny
description: Officials in Calfornia are seeking to determine if Jerry Jones, majority owner of the Dallas Cowboys, or a close associate improperly influenced a former executive of a large California public utility to obtain contracts for natural gas supplies, The Dallas Morning News said today.

title: For the Record
description: UNTIL now, the only reference in the Baseball Encyclopedia to outstanding players from the old Negro leagues has been in the list of players elected to the Hall of Fame. And the names of those players have asterisks alongside.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Upheaval in the East;   Gorbachev as Houdini
description: Less than a month ago, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was facing the rebellious Lithuanians, and conspicuously failing to dampen their longing for independence from the Soviet empire.

title: The Subway Isn't a Forum
description: LEAD: Federal judge Leonard B. Sand's decision invalidating the prohibition of begging in the New York City subways makes the disastrous mistake of treating public transportation as a medium for radical social advocacy.

title: Chief to Leave Savings Post
description: Robert Stallings, chief executive of the Western Savings and Loan Association, a Phoenix-based savings and loan seized by the Government, said on Friday that he planned to leave the institution this Friday to work with an investment group that wants to acquire Western.

title: The Old Days
description: IT was the fall of 1892 when the strapping freshman arrived at Cornell the day before registration. As he later recalled, ''With nothing to do after securing a rooming place, I went to Percy Field to watch football practice.''

title: Pact Is Signed to Cut Mexico's Debt
description: The Mexican Government and its foreign bank creditors signed a historic agreement today that will cut Mexico's foreign debt burden by as much as 20 percent. It also guarantees international bankers that the remainder of outstanding loans will be repaid.

title: Review/Music;   Philip Glass Revives a Work Relegated to Cult Status
description: The night of June 1, 1974, was a significant one for Philip Glass - and for American music. It was the date of the first concert by him and his ensemble in a major midtown Manhattan concert hall. While he had played in downtown lofts and in occasional uptown forays at museums like the Whitney and the Guggenheim, this concert in Town Hall was his first venture into the musical mainstream.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Companies Hold Firm On Pretoria
description: Business executives and the anti-apartheid protestors who are pushing them to sever economic ties with Pretoria do not expect the changes announced by President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa to stimulate new foreign investments.

title: Mary Moebus Married To Monte Alan Yedlin
description: Mary Moebus, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Burton Moebus of Garrison, N.Y., was married there yesterday at St. Philip's Church-in-the-Highlands to Monte Alan Yedlin, a son of Mrs. Sidney Yedlin of Van Nuys, Calif., and the late Mr. Yedlin. The Rev. Francis H. Geer, an Episcopal priest, the Rev. Robert Meadows-Rogers, a Methodist minister, and Rabbi Raymond Singer performed the interfaith ceremony.

title: Staying a Superpower
description: Take a long look ahead. Assume the Soviet military threat continues to recede, as grim necessity imposes a policy of contractionism.

title: Major Study of Domestic Violence Fails to Detect a Path to Killings
description: A new study of domestic violence has failed to find any patterns or indicators to help the police anticipate which of thousands of violent incidents reported annually are most likely to result in a killing.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Below are the major economic indicators to be released this week.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;

Tips for a More Comfortable Racquet
description: LEAD: MAYBE it is simply coincidence, but as tennis racquets have become stiffer and lighter, more and more players have begun searching for ways to make their racquets play more comfortably.

title: Thousands of Children Doing Adults' Work
description: With its harsh fluorescent lights and faint odor of caustic chemicals, the cramped belt factory on West 38th Street is an unlikely place to find an 11-year-old girl on a Friday morning. But there among the rows of industrial sewing machines and heaps of remnants, Maria Mendez is hard at work.

title: INSIDE
description: Mexican Debt Pact Signed

title: Andersen Breaks the Auditing Mold
description: From the outside, the Microseal Corporation looks like any other small factory on the fringe of Chicago. But inside, there is an experiment under way that could well change the nature of the accounting profession.

title: Father of Clay Pigeon
description: To the Editor:

title: Editors' Note
description: A report in the Advertising column of Business Day on Friday quoted industry executives who said the agency of Backer Spielvogel Bates had hired a San Franciscan to the new post of executive vice president/ copywriter. The report - appended to the column in New York after its arrival from Los Angeles - included criticism of the agency's recent creativity, attributed only to ''many advertising executives.''

title: Chronicle
description: LEONARD BERNSTEIN has declined a return engagement as music director of the New York Philharmonic Orchestra, which is seeking a successor to ZUBIN MEHTA, who is leaving at the end of next season. But Mr. Bernstein, who is laureate conductor, will increase his time with the orchestra, said ALBERT K. WEBSTER, the managing director.

title: A.T.P. Tour Ready for Debut
description: The North American premiere of the Association of Tennis Professionals Tour will have a West Coast setting, and like any good western, the event will feature a couple of hired guns to round out its cast of 32 players.

title: Nets Smothered By Lakers, 121-105
description: Magic Johnson had 22 points and 13 assists and Byron Scott scored 22 points as the Los Angeles Lakers beat New Jersey, 121-105, tonight and extended the Nets' losing streak to nine.

title: FACTIONS CONTINUE TO FIGHT IN BEIRUT
description: The battle for control of the 300-square-mile Christian enclave in Lebanon went into its sixth day today, as artillery duels between rival Christian forces killed at least 20 more people and wounded scores.

title: Question Box
description: Boggs Bogged Down

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: PRO BOWL

title: Census Bureau Tries New Promotional Tack
description: The Census Bureau's decennial advertising campaign, to be presented today by Secretary of Commerce Robert A. Mosbacher, differs from previous campaigns in its attempt to include more members of minority groups in its count.

title: A Handful of Old Hands Rules Congress
description: To the Editor:

title: Upheaval in the East: Yugoslavia;   Slovenia Breaks From Yugoslav Communists and Calls for Changes
description: The Communist Party in the northern Yugoslav republic of Slovenia broke away from the national Communist Party today and declared that it no longer recognized the national party, which has ruled Yugoslavia since World War II.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Central Committee: The Nerve Center of the Party
description: The Central Committee, the governing body of the Soviet Communist Party, is in principle the font of Communist authority, with the power to appoint and remove members of the ruling Politburo and to set party policy.

title: Palestinians Are Ready for Peace if Israel Is
description: To the Editor:

title: Chronicle
description: DR. THOMAS Q. MORRIS has resigned quietly as president of the Presbyterian Hospital, New York City's largest hospital. The hospital's acting president is HARRY J. BOLWELL, who is 64 years old. A search is under way for a successor to Dr. Morris.

title: New Absolut Drive
description: Turning away from the avant-garde style of past contributors like Andy Warhol and Keith Haring, TBWA's next hook to sell Absolut vodka will be American folk art. Eight original works, all incorporating the Absolut bottle, will be introduced in an insert to the April issue of Country Home magazine, which will be out Feb. 15.

title: Rushdie Appeals For Muslim Tolerance Of 'Satanic Verses'
description: The author Salman Rushdie, in hiding for the past year because of death threats from Islamic leaders offended by his novel ''The Satanic Verses,'' appealed to Muslims today to understand the book not as an attack on their faith but as ''a secular man's reckoning with the religious spirit.''

title: New Friend For CBS: Ted Turner
description: A VERY intriguing meeting took place in Atlanta last week, when two top officers of CBS quietly visited a man whose previous role in the CBS drama was playing the bogyman: Ted Turner.

title: Neo-Nazi Skinheads Mar Leipzig's Rally For German Unity
description: Hundreds of skinheads goose-stepped through Leipzig today, shouting ''Sieg Heil!'' as they smashed windows and disrupted a regular weekly demonstration for German unity.

title: Bush Asks Cautious Response To Threat of Global Warming
description: President Bush called today for a cautious response to the threat of global warming, pleasing those in his Administration who want a deliberate policy but disappointing many environmentalists.

title: Stay Tuned for a Cultural Nightmare, TV Babies;   McLuhan Was Right
description: To the Editor:

title: A Growing Urban Fear: Thieves Who Kill for 'Cool' Clothing
description: A 19-year-old youth who was slain Saturday for his fashionable warm-up jacket is the latest victim of what seems to be an increasingly pervasive kind of urban crime: robberies by young people willing to kill for clothes.

title: Bioengineering Points to Better Rice Plant
description: MOLECULAR biologists around the globe are making rapid strides in efforts to use genetic engineering to increase production of rice, the staple food of most of the third world's expanding populations.

title: L. L. Greneker, 95; Made Mannequins With Movable Parts
description: Lillian Lidman Greneker, a sculptor and inventor who created movable mannequins, died on Jan. 28 at the nursing home of the Actors' Fund in Englewood, N.J. She was 95 years old.

title: Kerr Addison Mines reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said it had a fourth- quarter loss of $4 million which included after-tax charges of $4.9 million from the writeoffs of a mining project and an investment. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Profits Scoreboard
Reviews/Dance;   The Mundial Sisters Portray France and Obsessions
description: The Mundial Sisters, a Parisian performance-art troupe, made a delightful New York City debut on Friday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music with ''Rapsodog.'' That title sounded corny. But the 70-minute production was not in the least so; it was a bittersweet comedy about the joys and sorrows of daily life.

title: Request Is Denied
description: A National Football League request for an injunction prohibiting individual players from filing lawsuits against the league's free-agency restrictions was denied yesterday by United States District Court Judge David S. Doty, sitting in Minneapolis.

title: Review/Opera;   'The Tender Land,' a Rarity by Copland
description: Aaron Copland's second opera, ''The Tender Land'' (1954), has elements that ought to have made it an American classic. Its melodies are charming and folksy, in the tradition of Mr. Copland's most popular works. Its setting is deep in the American heartland, on a farm in the Midwest during the Depression. And its conflict of adolescent rebellion and awakening sexuality remains fully contemporary.

title: New Jersey Steel Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Florio Appoints New Head of State Police
description: Gov. Jim Florio today replaced the Superintendent of State Police, Col. Clinton L. Pagano, a man regarded as a powerful institution in state government.

title: Dinkins Maps Policy of Delay For Raises
description: Facing both a $1 billion budget gap and negotiations with New York City unions that are among Mayor David N. Dinkins's biggest supporters, city officials say they are considering offering contracts with minimal raises this year but the promise of larger payments in the future.

title: Infant Deaths Linked To Mothers' Smoking
description: TWO doctors in Sweden say they have found a strong link between smoking and sudden infant death syndrome. They attributed more than one-fourth of the deaths in a three-year study to smoking by mothers during pregnancy.

title: The Sandinista Machine vs. Avid Opponents
description: Less than three weeks before national elections here, diplomats say the campaign has become a showdown between the organizational skills of the Sandinista Front and the disorganized but energetic rallies of Government opponents.

title: Eastern Plans Fund For Customer Refunds
description: In an attempt to reassure customers, Eastern Airlines said yesterday that it was setting up a fund of $115 million to guarantee that those seeking refunds will be paid.

title: How Schools Can Change Sexual Attitudes
description: To the Editor:

title: Virginia Files Lawsuit on V.M.I. Admissions
description: The Virginia Military Institute and the Virginia Attorney General today challenged a directive by the Federal Justice Department to accept women as cadets or face court action.

title: Notes and Bonds Fall in Light Day
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds fell in very light trading yesterday, as market participants began to position themselves for the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions, which begin this afternoon.

title: Review/Television;   'Elvis,' ABC Series on You-Know-Who
description: Groan, groan, groan. That was more or less how I felt on hearing that ABC had a new series called ''Elvis.'' About the only thing left to explore about Elvis Presley, it would seem, are those bizarre tabloid stories regularly marketed under the heading ''Elvis Lives!'' Spare me, oh ye desperate network programmers.

title: First Brands Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $1,985,000, or 10 cents a share and $5,026,000, or 25 cents a share for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Year-ago sales included sales of $20,520,000 in the quarter and $35,481,000 in the 6 months from the company's European Home Products business which was sold in March 1989.

title: Santa Fe Energy Partners L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included special charges of $900,000 for the planned February 1990 relocation to Houston of the Tulsa, Okla., district office, and $700,000 for voluntary employee separation costs were recorded in the fourth quarter of 1989. c-Included special charges of $14.5 million for expected losses on sales of marginal properties and $1.9 million for the relocation of the Amarillo, Texas, administrative offices to Houston.

title: Vanguard of the Revolution: The Soviet Party
description: 1883: The first Russian Marxist group, ''Emancipation of Labor,'' is founded in Geneva, with G. V. Plekhanov at its head.

title: Poll Detects Erosion of Positive Attitudes Toward Japan Among Americans
description: The percentage of Americans expressing negative views of Japan has increased significantly in recent months, according to the latest Times/CBS News Poll as well as additional interviews with ordinary Americans and leading Japan watchers.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Henry V v. Henry V
description: It's the height of ambition for a 27-year old actor to try remaking a star's masterpiece. But Kenneth Branagh's new film of ''Henry V'' soars with invention, eclipsing even Sir Laurence Olivier's celebrated version. The two films, 44 years apart, attest to Mr. Branagh's skills as actor and director, and the progress in the film maker's art.

title: Utilicorp United reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MDT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-After a charge of $118,000 resulting from early retirement of debt.

title: Cooper Acquires 6.26% of Anacomp
description: The Cooper Companies. a Palo Alto, Calif., contact lens concern, acquired a 6.26 percent stake in Anacomp Inc. and said it would like to discuss a business combination with the management of the Indianapolis-based software and data processing concern. Anacomp reacted strongly against Cooper's suggestion, which was included in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. In a written statement, Louis P. Ferrero, Anacomp's chairman, said, ''The board does not believe this is the time to explore the sale of the company.''

title: Garan Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: The company said the first quarter results included about $3 million in sales that otherwise might have been reflected in the second quarter.

title: Bomber Crashes Off England
description: An American Air Force F-111 bomber with a crew of two crashed into the sea today off east England during a routine training mission. The British Defense Ministry said one body was recovered and a search was under way for the second crew member.

title: New Bucharest Leaders Give Go-Ahead to Free Enterprise
description: The provisional leadership today legalized free enterprise on a much larger scale than existed in 45 years of Communist rule.

title: U.S. Productivity Rises By Only 0.2% in Quarter
description: American workers' productivity rose a barely perceptible two-tenths of a percent in the fourth quarter, while hourly labor costs rose at an annual rate of 6.9 percent, the Government said today.

title: Notebook;   Joyner-Kersee Describes Her Use of Medication
description: Jackie Joyner-Kersee, the Olympic champion in the women's long jump and the heptathlon, disclosed yesterday that she had been taking a sometimes-banned drug during training, to treat her asthma. A prominent physician involved in drug control said use of the drug was allowed sometimes in training, but never in competition.

title: Panama Is Resisting U.S. Pressure To Alter 'Inadequate' Bank Laws
description: Officials of the new Panamanian Government are resisting United States pressure to change the banking laws that historically made the country a haven for enormous illicit drug profits before Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega was removed from power.

title: Cascade Natural Gas reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RCA Is Fined $2.5 Million
description: The General Electric Company's RCA unit pleaded guilty today to obtaining classified Pentagon planning documents illegally, and it agreed to pay $2.5 million to settle charges in an investigation of contractors' trading military secrets.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   A New Look For Politics In Japan
description: THE Japan Socialist Party grabbed unusual public notice last year with a campaign poster showing a large red crayfish above the head of the party's leader, Takako Doi. Meant to symbolize the people's anger over scandals involving the ruling party, the image was a standout in the otherwise drab landscape of Japanese political advertising.

title: Review/Concert;   Haydn to the Present By Ensemble From Ottawa
description: Gabriel Chmura is a Polish-born conductor who held several posts in West Germany in the 1970's, but who is not well known in this country. In 1987 he was appointed music director of the National Arts Center Orchestra of Ottawa, a chamber orchestra of about 50 players that brought a nicely rounded program to Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon.

title: Bentsen Leery on Social Security Tax
description: Senator Lloyd Bentsen, whose support is crucial to adoption of a plan to cut the Social Security tax, declined today to take a stand on the proposal.

title: Helping Eastern Europe Helps the West
description: To the Editor:

title: Lions Hire Leachman
description: Lamar Leachman, the Giants' defensive line coach for the past 10 seasons, was hired yesterday as an assistant coach for the Detroit Lions. Leachman, 55 years old, replaces Dick Modzelewski, who has retired, as defensive line coach.

title: Probert Finishes Term
description: After serving a three-month prison term on a cocaine smuggling charge, Bob Probert of the Detroit Red Wings yesterday was released from a Federal prison hospital in Rochester, Minn. He will spend another three months in a halfway house, according to his lawyer, Harold Fried.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The crux of the party's renewal is the need to get rid of everything that tied it to the authoritarian-bureaucratic system, a system that left its mark not only on methods of work and interrelationships within the party, but also on ideology, ways of thinking and notions of socialism.''

title: Torrejon Journal;   The F-16 Drama (Cont.): Happy Landing in Italy?
description: In the early-morning haze, unperturbed by distant talk of military cuts and disarmament, young American pilots roared pairs of sleek F-16's along the runway of this air base outside Madrid and headed off to train for the eventuality of war.

title: Abraham Schnapf, 68; Led Satellite Projects
description: Abraham Schnapf, a mechanical engineer who was project manager for the Tiros and other weather satellites, died of renal failure Friday at Care Inn of Voorhees in New Jersey. He was 68 years old and lived in Willingboro, N.J.

title: Serbia's President Threatens to Colonize Kosovo
description: The president of the Serbian republic threatened today to send hundreds of thousands of Serbs to take over the province of Kosovo, the scene of a fierce ethnic feud.

title: To Calm German Neighbors' Nerves
description: As the cold war dam bursts, flooding both Germanys with national emotion, stopping unification is like trying to hold back a wall of water. Soviet, European and American leaders have wisely decided to welcome the inevitable. But they have work to do with German leaders if they're going to reassure an uneasy Europe about German unity.

title: Savings Bond Curb Planned
description: The Treasury Department said today that beginning on Oct. 1, it will not issue $50 and $75 Series EE savings bonds through payroll savings plans, making $100 bonds the minimum denomination for plan participants.

title: Scudder New Asia Fund reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: Assets represented net assets and per share figures are net assets per share. The 1989 share earnings are after a capital gains distribution of 94 cents a share in December 1989.

title: CT Financial Services reports earnings for Year Dec 31
description: The company said 1988 earnings included two unusual items that added about $30 million to net earnings, or 25 cents a share, on a fully diluted basis. Results are in Canadian funds. CT is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: Radio Deal in Honolulu
description: The Bedford Broadcasting Company announced Friday that it had agreed to buy the Honolulu radio stations KSSK-AM and KSSK-FM from the Heftel Broadcasting Company of Hawaii. Terms of the sale, which must be approved by the Federal Communications Commission, were not disclosed. Bedford also owns four newspapers in Southern California and a company in San Francisco that publishes books on the arts. Heftel also owns the radio stations KTNO-AM and KLVE-FM in Los Angeles.

title: Hercules Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $323 million pretax charge for bookeeping changes resulting from technical snags and order delays in its Titan IV missile program for both the quarter and year. c-Net income

title: Review/Television;   Soviet Bathing Beauties on Parade
description: It was only a matter of time before the Soviet Union got a nationwide beauty contest. As tonight's ''Miss U.S.S.R.'' reports, the event beat McDonald's to Moscow; the finals of ''the first all-Union beauty contest'' were held last May near Red Square at the big Rossiya Hotel, where men in the audience followed the proceedings with the help of binoculars. This droll account, on Channel 13 at 10 and on Channel 49 at 9, offers a revealing look at women's lives in the Soviet Union as well as at the contestants, several of whom are in swimsuits that cannot have strained even the meager stocks of material in their country of chronic shortages.

title: Ouster of Priest Is Explained
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Washington said today that the Rev. George A. Stallings Jr. had excommunicated himself from the faith by declaring over the weekend that the African-American congregation he organized here last year was ''independent'' of Rome and would permit abortion, birth control, divorce and the ordination of women and married men.

title: Bankeast Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and after a gain of $811,000 from the cumulative effect from the adoption of SFAS No. 96, accounting for income taxes. Bankeast attributed its loss mainly to a fourth-quarter provision of $12.8 million for possible loan losses.

title: Image of Covenant House Is Eroded by Sex Charges
description: Two months after Covenant House was rocked by allegations of sexual misconduct leveled against its founder and guiding spirit, the Rev. Bruce Ritter, the nation's largest shelter program for runaway youngsters is struggling to stem an erosion of support amid widening inquiries by state and church authorities.

title: Outsider Hired to Run Dun & Bradstreet Unit
description: The Dun & Bradsteet Corporation yesterday named Ronald K. Glover, the head of the American Express Company's traveler's check business in the United States, to run the division that produces its well-known corporate credit reports.

title: Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company attributed its 1989 earnings performance primarily to a $132 million increase in net interest margin for the year. Share earnings figures are for voting common stock. Share earnings for non-voting common stock for the year was $426.52, compared with $370.99 for prior year. The company has 100,000 shares of outstanding non-voting common.

title: Multiparty Voting: Back To the Future for Soviets
description: The move for multiparty elections in the Soviet Union, which has been dominated by its Communist Party since 1918, recalls a brief period in early Soviet history when multiparty political activity loomed large - only to be followed by years of monolithic Communist rule.

title: Secor Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary credit of $874,000, or 24 cents a share, from the early extinguishment of convertible subordinated debentures for the quarter and year. c-Net income The 1988 year's income before item included a $6,389,000 tax credit. There were no per share earnings in the latest year after preferred dividends totaling $6,748,000.

title: Henry D. Caruthers, Executive, 65
description: Henry D. Caruthers, president of Caruthers Consulting, a management, marketing and sales development concern, died of complications after surgery yesterday at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L.I. He was 65 years old and lived in Sands Point, L.I.

title: A Role for South Africa
description: It was almost exactly 30 years ago that Prime Minister Harold Macmillan of Britain made his ''wind of change'' speech here. It signaled Britain's sweeping acceptance of decolonization, the dismantling of empires almost everywhere that has so changed the world.

title: Ex-Im Bank Resumes Aid to China
description: The Export-Import Bank, an agency of the Federal Government that provides credit to the customers of American exporters, has made its first loan to China since the military crackdown against pro-democracy demonstrators in June, bank officials said today.

title: Cresmont Federal S&L AsFsociation reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge penalty from the repayment of Federal Home Loan bank advances of $1,504,000 which included the provision of $13,389,000 for increased general reserves, specific loan losses and writedowns of real estate owned, and also included is a pretax loss of $2,020,000 from the sale of mortgage loans, mortgage backed securities and investment securities for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income

title: Saving the Landfills
description: Crab scraps are being converted into high-quality compost in an effort to solve an expensive waste disposal problem. The pilot project in Perry, Fla., uses cypress sawdust, yard waste and bark to convert the smelly crab scraps into marketable compost.

title: Major Harris Eyes Pros
description: Major Harris, the West Virginia quarterback who after his junior year is already the Mountaineers' career leader in total offense with 7,334 yards, is ready to sign with an agent and turn professional, the Thomson Newspapers reported.(AP)

title: Union Carbide Canada reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,853,000 for the quarter and $7,098,000 for the year, and extraordinary losses of $17,790,000 and $15,854,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income and included income from discontinued operations of $58,000 and an extraordinary loss of $10,598,000. d-After a loss of $1,138,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary credit of $6,261,000. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Ex-Paramount Executive In New Job at Time Warner
description: Arthur Barron has been named chairman of a new Time Warner Inc. division that will oversee strategy and venture development - primarily overseas.

title: Home Federal Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said 1988 figures were restated to reflect the merger of Waynesboro Savings Association and two 5 percent stock dividends.

title: Results Plus
description: TENNIS

title: General RE Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an realized capital gains of $4,300,000, or 5 cents a share and $39,800,000, or 44 cents a share for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included income of $3,100,000, or 3 cents a share for the quarter and a loss of $33,400,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations, and realized capital gain of $12,800,000, or 14 cents a share for the quarter and realized capital loss of $5,100,000 for the year.

title: Teradyne Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a net gain of $1,501,000 in the year related to a pattent license fee and pretax restructuring charges of $16,013,000 in the year and the quarter. c-Included pretax gain of $1,121,000 from the sale of an investment. d-Net loss

title: BankAmerica Names Successor to Clausen
description: Richard M. Rosenberg, whose aggressive marketing tactics fueled the BankAmerica Corporation's resurgence in California banking, yesterday was named the next chairman and chief executive of the nation's third-largest banking company.

title: Mayflower Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NBI Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $770,000 for the quarter and $4,031,000 for the 6 months. c-After losses of $1,248,000 and $2,035,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, from discontinued operations.

title: Hospital Didn't Train Prego About Hazards, Witness Says
description: The former director of Kings County Hospital testified yesterday that the hospital trained its interns to handle patients with infectious diseases in 1983, when Dr. Veronica Prego accidentally punctured her finger while working there as an unpaid assistant.

title: Hit-and-Run Victim Is Robbed of a Purse While She Is Dying
description: A woman crossing Times Square was struck by a hit-and-run driver yesterday morning and then robbed of her purse as she lay dying on the pavement, the police said.

title: Horizon Financial Services reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Union Exploration Partners reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Paramount to Ogilvy
description: Graham Phillips called one of his senior executives over the weekend to exult: ''We're back in show business!'' The chief executive of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide was reveling because his Los Angeles office had just won the media planning and buying account of the Paramount Pictures Corporation. The account, which is worth $60 million to $70 million in annual billings, was pulled four weeks ago from D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles's Los Angeles office after less than two years there. Working for a movie studio will not be new to Ogilvy/Los Angeles - it had handled Columbia Pictures in the early 1980's.

title: Friends of Wright Building Seek to Block Jail
description: After 10 years of investigating possible sites for a new jail in this affluent area, the Marin County supervisors thought they had an answer to cries of ''not in my backyard.''

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Premier at Thompson
description: Premier Cruise Lines Ltd., a subsidiary of the Greyhound Corporation that specializes in family vacation-packages to the Bahamas and Disney World, awarded its advertising account yesterday to J. Walter Thompson in Chicago, a unit of the WPP Group. The account, previously at CAK, Miami, has billings of $10 million. The other finalists in the review were Backer Spielvogel Bates and Young & Rubicam.

title: Blockbuster Entertainment reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results are restated for the January 1989 acquisition of Major Video Corp. and the August 1989 acquisition of Video Superstore Master Limited Partnership. These acquisitions were accounted for as pooling of interests.

title: MacDermid Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $350,000, or 10 cents a share, received from a Japanese company for a licensing option.

title: TURKEY SENSITIVE ABOUT ITS IDENTITY
description: Enveloped in smog and, for Turks, in familiarity, too, the slogan that spreads across the highway here on a kind of ceremonial arch proclaims: ''What joy to say I am a Turk.''

title: Pentair Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Westcorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $1.4 million, or 9 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: A Ranger Continues To Deny Racial Slur
description: Kris King, upset by the ugly promise of the next day's headlines, did not sleep very well Saturday night. His Sunday afternoon, the headlines having been read and cringed at, was no better.

title: Liberty Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a net gain of $13.4 million, or $1.57 a share, due to the sale of a television station for both periods; a investment loss of $1.8 million for the quarter and an investment gain of $1.6 million, or 19 cents a share, for the year. c-Net loss and after an investment loss of $4.7 million. d-After an investment gain of $2.4 million, or 27 cents a share.

title: For Moscow, Another Winter Of Revolution?
description: Mikhail Gorbachev's speech to the Central Committee calling for the surrender of the party's monopoly on power signals the onset of a two-month period that promises to be the most significant in Soviet political history since Stalin completed his seizure of power in 1929.

title: Stay Tuned for a Cultural Nightmare, TV Babies;   Making Addiction Easy
description: To the Editor:

title: Is Tyson Sabotaging Himself?
description: rrFor nearly two years, ever since Mike Tyson began creating more headlines outside the ring than in it, the undisputed, undefeated and undignified world heavyweight champion has emerged as his own most dangerous opponent. Considering his competition, the only person who can beat Tyson is Tyson himself. By not training. By not caring. By not surrounding himself with experienced cornermen.

title: Notre Dame Breaks Ranks on TV Football Rights
description: Breaking ranks with other major universities, the University of Notre Dame announced yesterday that it had signed a five-year contract giving NBC the exclusive right to broadcast all its home football games, starting in 1991.

title: Yellow Freight System Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included for the quarter an increase in reserves for workers' compensation and other reserves of $27,707,000, and the year included an accounting adjustment gain of $29,200,000, or $1.01 a share. c-Net income In the fourth quarter of 1989, the company adopted SFAS No. 96, accounting for income taxes, effective as of Jan. 1, 1989, without restatement of prior years.

title: On Horse Racing;   Aiming at Rebuilding A Trainer's Spirit
description: rrShug McGaughey left Gulfstream Park on Nov. 6 with two Breeders' Cup victories and a broken spirit. Two days earlier, the trainer for the Phipps Stable had come within a neck of the greatest afternoon of training in American racing history. After sending out Dancing Spree to win the $1 million Sprint and Rhythm to win the $1 million Juvenile, McGaughey was odds-on to add the $3 million Classic with Easy Goer. Victory would have made him the first trainer ever to win three cup races in a day, and would have made Easy Goer the official Horse of the Year and unofficial horse of the decade.

title: Healthcare International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge due to the writeoff of certain deferred financing costs of $768,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. The company said the net loss for the second quarter included losses from operations of $3.9 million related to Pali Momi Medical Center, which was sold in December 1989. The company realized a loss on the sale of Pali Momi of about $3.4 million in excess of the amount previously reserved for its disposition. The net loss in the prior-year period included a pretax charge from unusual items of $11,004,000.

title: Hunt for Aliens in Space: The Next Generation
description: AFTER decades of dreaming, and sometimes scheming, a small band of earthlings has received Federal money to embark on a $100 million, 10-year project to find aliens in space.

title: Robert Claiborne, 70, Writer and Musician
description: Robert Claiborne, a writer, editor and musician, died of a heart attack on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 70 years old.

title: Noranda Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an after-tax unusual charge of $2 million. The company said the higher value of the Canadian dollar reduced net income by $66 million and higher interest rates reduced net by $32 million. Results are in Canadian funds. The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: Pittston Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $5,282,000 representing the reversal of income tax credits recognized in previous quarters. c-Included extraordinary credits from use of operating loss carryforwards of $3,446,000 and $11,803,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. d-Net income Latest periods' results included special charges of $16.2 million including the following: costs related to a labor settlement and return to normal operations at the company's coal operations; some coal asset writedowns; anticipated losses on some coal sales contracts and a reserve for litigation related to a petroleum distribution business sold in 1983. Figures for 1988 are restated.

title: Capital Cities' Net Up 29.8%
description: Capital Cities/ABC Inc. said yesterday that its net income had risen 29.8 percent in the fourth quarter.

title: Eagle Bancshares Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Woman Held in Killing Of a Colleague's Wife
description: A teacher was held in $250,000 bail today on a charge that she murdered the wife of a man who is reported to have been her lover.

title: Ryland Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for latest year included $14 million, or $1.05 a share, related to an accounting change.

title: Colman Is Honored
description: Dick Colman, the head football coach at Princeton from 1957-68, was among four figures elected to the National Football Foundation's College Football Hall of Fame.

title: Federal Judge on Trial in a Racketeering Case
description: Jury selection began here today in the trial of the first Federal judge charged with violating the Federal racketeering statute through his involvement with two convicted felons.

title: Southern Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sallie Mae Prices $500 Million Issue
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, yesterday priced $500 million in floating-rate notes due Aug. 9 through a group of various securities dealers.

title: Union Electric Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1989 earnings were reduced by 10 cents a share as a result of unusual non-recurring items including the writeoff of the second cancelled unit of the Calloway plant.

title: Putnam Intermed Govt Inome reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: Assets represented net assets and per share figures are net assets per share.

title: Transco Energy Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Results for latest year included gains of $69.4 million, or $2.42 a share, and $13.7 million, or 48 cents a share, from liquidation of a trust and the sale of interests in certain projects. Results for the latest year also included a $25.9 million, or 90 cents a share, charge related to settlements with pipeline customers. Results for prior quarter and year included aftertax charges totaling about $97.2 million. Results for the prior year also included an about $26.9 million, or 94 cents a share, charge related to litigation and restructuring.

title: Four Dead as Violence In Home Turns Deadly
description: A man armed with a gun killed his two adult sons and a girlfriend of one of them and stabbed his wife before taking his own life this morning as the police tried to negotiate with him by telephone, the authorities said.

title: Rush Is On to Capitalize on Testing For Gene Causing Cystic Fibrosis
description: EVEN before researchers have perfected a new test to detect adults who risk having children with cystic fibrosis, commercial laboratories are rushing to create the nation's first large-scale market for genetic screening services.

title: Donations to Neediest Cases Fund Set Record
description: With three weeks left, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund drive has already surpassed the total collection for last year, when the $4 million mark was first broken.

title: Victories for Boston U. and Harvard
description: Mention ''The Beanpot'' to a college hockey player, past or present, in this city and you have his attention. For almost four decades, the midwinter Beanpot Tournament has been special for Boston's four Division I teams - Boston College, Boston University, Harvard and Northeastern - and the Monday night crowds in Boston Garden.

title: First City Bancorp-Tenn.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Pupil Waits 2 Nights in a Bus
description: A kindergarten pupil who fell asleep on a school bus was hospitalized with frostbite after spending nearly two nights in the bus waiting for help, the authorities said. The child, Angela Terrell, boarded the Mayflower school bus on Friday for Ashland Elementary School in midtown Kansas City, the police said. When she did not return Friday afternoon, her mother reported her missing. The police found the girl early Sunday in the bus parking lot. Temperatures fell to 24 degrees on Saturday night.

title: Helen Markel, Writer And Editor, Dies at 71
description: Helen Markel, a magazine writer and editor whose articles appeared in The New York Times Magazine and The Readers Digest, among other publications, died of cancer of the spine on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 71 years old.

title: Review/Architecture;   Frank Lloyd Wright Is Lauded in Phoenix With His Own Work
description: Two things are remarkable about ''Frank Lloyd Wright Drawings: Masterworks From the Frank Lloyd Wright Archives,'' the sweeping exhibition of the master architect's work that has just opened at the Phoenix Art Museum.

title: Capital Cities-ABC Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
East Berlin Cabinet Adding 8 Members of the Opposition
description: The East German Parliament today formalized the power-sharing arrangement reached last week between Prime Minister Hans Modrow and the opposition and voted to add eight new Cabinet ministers from the opposition to the Government.

title: Valhi Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a reversal of tax-loss carryforward of $1.3 million for the quarter and an extraordinary tax benefit from tax-loss carryforwards of $1.1 million, or 1 cent a share, for the year. c-After a reversal of tax-loss carryforward of $3.5 million for the quarter and an extraordinary tax benefit from tax-loss carryforwards of $5.2 million, or 5 cents a share, for the year.

title: Bridge
description: When Horace Walpole coined the word ''serendipity'' from the activities of the Three Princes of Serendip, who regularly made fortunate discoveries by complete accident, he did not have bridge players in mind. But in some remote part of the world it is likely that somebody at a card table benefited from serendipity on the diagramed deal.

title: UDC-Universal Development reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Lexington Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Strawberry's Case Delayed
description: One of Darryl Strawberry's problems was eased yesterday when the city attorney's office in Los Angeles indefinitely delayed a scheduled hearing into the police report on Strawberry's arrest following a fight with his wife on Jan. 26.

title: By Design;   Shorts That Go to the Office
description: One of the first fashions to take off for spring has two legs. Tailored city shorts, cuffed or uncuffed and ending an inch or two above the knees, have caught the fancy of women across the country. An alternate to either a short, slim skirt or regular pants, they are sportier than the skirt and kickier than the pants. These new shorts, as long as they are not too high on the thigh and have a neat, trim line, should be fine for office wear.

title: Chronicle
description: After months of speculation, the plum role of Sherman McCoy in the film version of Tom Wolfe's novel ''Bonfire of the Vanities'' is to go to TOM HANKS after all, according to an executive with Warner Brothers. The studio has not announced the rest of the cast of the film, which will be directed by BRIAN DE PALMA.

title: Greenwich Financial Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MCN Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $3,170,000 on bond redemption for the quarter and year.

title: Oilers Refine Juggling Act On Way to Meeting Devils
description: Since the shoulder injury to Grant Fuhr, Bill Ranford of the Edmonton Oilers has been the most overworked goaltender in the National Hockey League.

title: Nets' Blaylock Sidelined With Broken Finger
description: The Nets not only lost their ninth game in a row Sunday night when they were beaten by the Lakers by 121-105 at the Forum, but they also lost Mookie Blaylock. The point guard fractured the little finger on his left hand in two places in the second quarter when it got caught inside Michael Cooper's jersey while he was fouling the Los Angeles swingman.

title: MEETS HARD-LINE OPPOSITION
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev called on the Communist Party today to forswear its constitutional monopoly on power and to accept the prospect of rival political parties.

title: Books of The Times;   A Poet's Soul and the Demons That Won
description: Dream Song

title: Eliot Frankel, 67, Dies; Producer and Teacher
description: Eliot Frankel, a producer of news and documentary programs for NBC, died of stomach cancer on Sunday at St. Peter's Medical Center in New Brunswick, N.J. He was 67 years old and lived in New Brunswick.

title: Whittaker to Sell Chemicals Group
description: The Whittaker Corporation, based here, agreed to sell its specialty chemicals segment and coatings group to Morton International of Chicago for about $225 million and the assumption of certain liabilities. Whittaker's coatings and adhesives businesses had combined sales of about $180 million in the 1989 fiscal year.

title: Ewing Totally in Charge As Knicks Defeat Heat
description: Patrick Ewing showed many aspects of his game last night, and the Knicks needed all of them before defeating the Miami Heat, 116-107, at Madison Square Garden.

title: Stay Tuned for a Cultural Nightmare, TV Babies;   Attention Lagging?
description: To the Editor:

title: A $15 Million Penalty for Laundering
description: In the first case involving laundering drug money brought by the United States against a large bank, a Federal judge in Tampa today ordered two subsidiaries of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International to forfeit $15 million, the largest penalty ever assessed against a bank.

title: USA Bancorp Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: American Federal Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Per share earnings not shown for latest year and year-ago periods; company went public on Jan. 26, 1989.

title: ECONOMIC ADVISERS ARE FEW IN BEIJING
description: The question being asked these days among Chinese officials and business executives is, ''Who is running the economy?''

title: Exabyte Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $1,250,000, or 7 cents a share. c-Included extraordinary tax credits of $841,000, or 5 cents a share for the quarter and $909,000, or 5 cents a share fot the year.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Darci Kistler, Baby Ballerina, Grown Up and Dancing Hard
description: It was a fairly inconsequential, low-comedy moment in the long and inspirational history of the dance, but it has left its residue. It happened in Los Angeles, on a night in 1969, when the four brawny Kistler brothers - all of whom would go on to win college wrestling scholarships - were dragged by their mother, Alicia, to see Dame Margot Fonteyn and Rudolf Nureyev in ''Sleeping Beauty.''

title: LTV Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and after a loss of $2,263,000,000 from the cumulative effect on prior periods of an accounting change. The loss before items in the 1988 year included a gain of $24.8 million on sale of two vessels and charges of $1,341,000,000 primarily from Chapter 11 claims and writedown of assets and $30 million from the discontinuance of certain businesses.
