title: Drug Study Faults Role Of State Dept.
description: An internal State Department review has concluded that the agency has not taken its role in the drug war seriously because it is hampered by the complexity of its mission, limited resources and a lack of interest among senior agency officials.

title: S.E.C. Said to Review Trading by Simmons
description: Harold C. Simmons, the Texas billionaire, said today that the Securities and Exchange Commission had begun an investigation into his trading in the stocks of the Lockheed Corporation and the Georgia Gulf Corporation.

title: Continental Medical Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting change of $580,000. Year-ago figures are restated to include the results of Rehabworks Inc., which was acquired Sept. 29, and to reflect a change in the method of accounting. The Rehabworks acquisition was accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: New Cruiser to Replace The Iowa at Base on S.I.
description: The nation's newest fighting ship, the guided-missile cruiser Normandy, will replace the Iowa as the flagship of the Navy group to be based at its new base in Stapleton, S.I., the Navy announced yesterday.

title: St. Paul Bancorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $20.6 million addition to reserves for potential loan losses for the quarter and year; the periods also included pre-tax gains on sale of mortgage loans and investments, and mortgage-backed securities of $1,006,000 for the quarter and $1,589,000 for the year. c-Net income and included a pre-tax gain on sale of mortgage loans and investments, and mortgage-backed securities of $3,325,000. d-Included a pre-tax gain on sale of mortgage loans and investments, and mortgage-backed securities of $6,406,000, and a $712,000 after-tax charge related to the early redemption of subordinated capital notes.

title: Daimler Ends Talks on Sale
description: Daimler-Benz A.G. said today that it had broken off talks with a consortium about the sale of its navy and missile technology lines.

title: Reviews/Dance;   A Just-Promoted Swanilda Stars in a New 'Coppelia'
description: Nichol Hlinka's joyful Swanilda in ''Coppelia'' Saturday night at the New York State Theater had something to be happy about. The New York City Ballet promoted Miss Hlinka from soloist to principal dancer over the weekend.

title: A MUTED RESPONSE FROM WASHINGTON
description: The Bush Administration reacted to the rapidly unfolding events in the Soviet Union today with a caution that reflected both uncertainty over the outcome and the Administration's efforts to fight off proposals for more sweeping cuts in the United States military budget.

title: Putnam Master Inter Income reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: Assets represented net assets and per share figures are net assets per share.

title: Calvert Coggeshall, 82, Painter and Designer
description: Calvert Coggeshall, an abstract painter and a designer, died of heart failure on Thursday at his home in Newcastle, Me. He was 82 years old and had maintained a studio in Manhattan until recently.

title: Anthony Derham, 46, Expert on Oriental Art
description: Anthony R. Derham, a former head of the Japan Society Gallery and a former director of oriental art at Christie's, died on Saturday at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan. He was 46 years old.

title: Jean Bissell, 53, Dies; Federal Appeals Judge
description: Jean Galloway Bissell, a judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit, died of cancer Sunday at Sibley Memorial Hospital in Washington. She was 53 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Peace Plan Critic Is Elected President in Costa Rica
description: Rafael Calderon Jr., a critic of the Central American peace efforts of President Oscar Arias Sanchez, was elected Sunday to succeed Mr. Arias, according to nearly complete returns.

title: Ease Comes at Expense of Speed
description: MICROPHONE II version 3.0, an updated communication software package for Apple Macintosh computers, is a lot like the Stealth bomber. It was designed to be extremely powerful and practically invisible. The user can press a single button to put the software on automatic pilot, turning it loose to perform a variety of defined tasks.

title: Compassion And Comfort In Middle Age
description: A FAR more positive image of middle age is emerging from new research that goes beyond the midlife crisis to examine psychological growth during the 40's, 50's and 60's.

title: Heavy Rain? Light Coats Shrug It Off
description: Many women develop the same feeling for their raincoats as they do for their jeans. They do not really love them until they assume the shape of their body, and refuse to discard them until they are so threadbare they no longer hang together.

title: Ford-Mazda Pickup Talks
description: The Ford Motor Company, which has said it will improve its light-truck lineup, said today that it was in talks with the Mazda Motor Corporation about jointly building a new compact pickup truck.

title: A Grieving Israel Pushes Politics Aside
description: Stunned Israelis postponed politics, canceled trips to Egypt and lamented what seemed to be a further blow to regional peace today as the nation recovered its dead and wounded from the terrorist attack on a tour bus near Cairo on Sunday night.

title: Scripps Howard Broadcasting Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Merrimack Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: Peninsular-Laing
description: The Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company offered today to pay $:441 million (about $745 million) for the 78.2 percent of Laing Properties P.L.C. it does not already own. Laing rejected the offer, saying it significantly undervalued Laing's assets and longer-term growth potential. P.&O., which has interests in passenger and cargo shipping, said its offer for Laing, a property investment and development company, amounted to 650 pence, or $10.99, a share. P.&O.'s chairman, Sir Jeffrey Sterling, said the company's board was seeking talks with the board of Laing Properties ''with a view to obtaining their recommendation for the offer.''

title: Federal Signal Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Latest quarter and year results are before a 3-for-2 stock split payable March 1. On a post-split basis, latest and year-ago fourth quarter share earnings are equal to 41 cents and 34 cents, respectively. Latest and prior year post-split share earnings are equal to $1.50 a share and $1.22 a share, respectively.

title: KEY RATES
Talking Business; with Juran of the Juran Institute;   Value of Quality To U.S. Managers
description: Joseph M. Juran has been involved in improving product quality and management techniques since he joined the Western Electric Company as an engineer in 1924. The 85-year-old Mr. Juran is the founder and chairman emeritus of the Juran Institute in Wilton, Conn., a quality consulting firm.

title: Business Digest
description: International

title: Big Christian Battle Taking Shape Along Highway North From Beirut
description: Civilians in Christian East Beirut who spent six days and nights sheltering from fighting between warring Christians took advantage of a lull today to look for food or flee to safer ground.

title: U.S. to Offer Soviets a Compromise for Cutting Aircraft in Europe Under New Treaty
description: To speed the completion of a new treaty cutting conventional forces in Europe, the United States has developed a compromise proposal for reducing NATO and Soviet-bloc aircraft, American and Western European officials said today.

title: West Europeans Vote To Widen Eastern Aid
description: A governing body of the European Community voted today to signal its willingness to extend to East Germany, Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria, Romania and Yugoslavia the aid programs of the major industrialized countries already under way in Poland and Hungary.

title: Study Finds No Benefit in Early Hospitalization of Mothers of Twins
description: THE common practice of hospitalizing women bearing twins to prevent premature labor and other complications late in pregnancy is ineffective, a new study in Australia has found.

title: Panthers Get Virus Similar To AIDS
description: The discovery of an AIDS-like virus in Florida panthers has surprised and worried scientists, but they say there is no indication that the infection is fatal to the endangered cats. An estimated 30 to 50 of the panthers live in South Florida. ''It's just another problem that we need to be aware of,'' said Dr. Melody Roelke, veterinarian for the state panther recovery project.

title: Village Financial Svcs reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Per share earnings not shown; company converted from mutual to stock ownership in December 1989.

title: U.S. Backs I.M.F. Rise
description: The United States is willing to accept an increase of up to 50 percent in assessments for the International Monetary Fund, the Treasury Department said today.

title: Eugenio Henke, Intelligence Expert, 81
description: Adm. Eugenio Henke, who led the Italian secret service in the late 1960's when its agents were linked to right-wing terrorism and coup plots, died of a heart attack on Sunday. He was 81 years old.

title: Plan to Cut Ex-Im Bank Draws Business Protest
description: Budget decisions by the Bush Administration to reduce the operations of the Export-Import Bank have drawn loud protests from business supporters of the Administration, as well as from some lawmakers.

title: Prague Is Showing Off an Empty Secret Police Headquarters
description: The Government showed the Czechoslovak public one of its proudest achievements today. It was a massive building that takes up most of a city block, and it was totally deserted.

title: St. Anthony Wins Metro Classic
description: Since withdrawing from the Hudson County League before the start of last season, St. Anthony of Jersey City now plays for the national spotlight, and tonight the school turned the lights up a little higher by defeating St. Nicholas of Tolentine, 65-63, in the championship of the first Metro Classic.

title: Stay Tuned for a Cultural Nightmare, TV Babies;   Not My Generation
description: To the Editor:

title: EAB reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest fourth quarter included a special provision for loan losses of $23.6 million in recognition of the increased level of non-performing loans, which are principally local real estate loans. The fourth quarter of 1989 and 1988 included approximately $5.1 million and $21.2 million, respectively, of non-recurring income.

title: Clashes in Black Areas Dim South African Joy
description: Angry clashes broke out today between police and demonstrators in a black township near here, and anti-apartheid violence continued in black residential areas elsewhere, underscoring the uncertainty that has overtaken South Africa in the wake of measures announced on Friday by President F.W. de Klerk.

title: South Africa's Infuriated Rightists Vow a Battle to Defend Apartheid
description: The right-wing Conservative Party, furious that President F. W. de Klerk has legalized the African National Congress and promised to free Nelson Mandela, is planning to fight back with a campaign of opposition that it hopes will eventually force Mr. de Klerk out of office.

title: Truck Deaths Linked to Alcohol or Drugs
description: One of every three truck drivers whose bodies were examined after they died in highway accidents had recently used drugs or alcohol, according to a study issued today by the National Transportation Safety Board.

title: Indiana Federal Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
First Woburn Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Careers;   Job Outlook For Middle Managers
description: WHEN middle managers lose their jobs, do they have reason to be optimistic or pessimistic about their chances of finding new positions these days? Even experts on the job market cannot agree.

title: Fugitive in a Slaying in 1982 Is Arriving From Brazil Today
description: A woman on the most-wanted list of the state police for four years is to be returned here from Brazil on Tuesday to face murder charges, the authorities said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   People
description: * Claude Fromm and Stuart Loss have been promoted to executive vice president-media director and executive vice president-chief financial officer, respectively, of TBWA Advertising.

title: Baseball Owners and Players at Impasse Over Almost Everything
description: They met for five hours and could report agreement only on a labor-management committee that will meet three times a year and discuss labor relations issues. That's after they have a new collective-bargaining agreement.

title: Banks of Iowa Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Excel Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Chronicle
description: CHRIS EVERT will get an award on Friday from President Bush, and a covey of United States Representatives - all male - will face off tomorrow against a team of basketball players - all female. The game, and the award, celebrate the National Girls and Women in Sports Day on Thursday.

title: RJR Nabisco Holdings Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss from operations of discontinued businesses, net of taxes, of $6 million and $1 million for the quarter and year, respectively. Operating results for both the quarter and full year treat International Nabisco Brands and Del Monte Foods as discontinued operations. Latest quarter results included approximately $590 million of new non- cash charges. Latest year period represented Feb. 9 through Dec. 31, 1989. Latest period results reflected the cost of going private through a $24.5- billion leveraged buyout by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. RJR Nabisco Holdings Corp. is the indirect parent company of RJR Nabisco Inc. Its major operating subsidiaries are R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co.; R.J. Reynolds Tobacco International, Inc.; Nabisco Brands, Inc.; and Planters Lifesavers Co. For the 3 months ended Dec. 31, RJR Nabisco lost $144 million, compared with a $411 million profit in the 1988 quarter. Sales totaled $3.54 billion, unchanged from a year ago. RJR Nabisco lost $1.5 billion for the entire year and had sales of $12.76 billion, compared with a $1.4 billion profit the previous year on $12.64 billion in sales. RJR Nabisco blamed the negative results on significantly higher net interest expenses, its decision to eliminate excess tobacco trade inventories and costs related to the KKR acquisition which was finalized in early 1989.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allegheny International Inc., Pittsburgh, said it had received approval from the U.S. Bankruptcy Court to submit its latest reorganization plan to creditors and shareholders for a vote.

title: Less Sulfur Found From Marine Organisms
description: SCIENTISTS have found evidence buried within the Greenland ice cap that although human activity is pouring sulfur into the atmosphere at a prodigious rate, sulfur emitted by marine organisms into the air has begun to decline sharply.

title: Stay Tuned for a Cultural Nightmare, TV Babies;   What They Don't Know
description: To the Editor:

title: Vehicle Sales Gained 3.2% In January
description: Helped by fat rebates that enticed buyers back to showrooms they had avoided for several weeks, sales of cars and light trucks rose 3.2 percent in January, despite a relatively poor showing in the last 10 days of the month.

title: Stay Tuned for a Cultural Nightmare, TV Babies;   The Fantasy Box
description: To the Editor:

title: Honda Asked To Sell Jeeps To Japanese
description: The Honda Motor Company said today that the Chrysler Corporation had asked it to sell Jeep recreational vehicles in Japan, and some Honda officials hinted that they were likely to strike an agreement soon.

title: Seoul Is Planning to Convert Its Raucous Politics Into Gray Japanese Model
description: Two years into South Korea's first experiment with a freely elected democracy, the country's strife-weary leaders say they are planning to transform the government into a system that, at least on the surface, will strikingly resemble Japan's: parliamentary-style rule dominated by a single, conservative party powerful enough to drown out opposition voices.

title: 2 Jets Coaching Candidates Cross Paths
description: The two leading candidates for the Jets' head-coaching job couldn't penetrate each other's defenses when they tried to figure out who was ahead.

title: Ramapo Financial Corp.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Donald J. Leahy, Gynecologist, 66
description: Dr. Donald J. Leahy, chief of obstetrics and gynecology at the Flushing Hospital and Medical Center in Queens from 1974 to 1985, died of pneumonia on Friday at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L.I. He was 66 years old and lived in Douglaston, Queens.

title: Westchester Board Approves Plant to Treat Sewage Sludge
description: The Westchester Board of Legislators cleared the way today for construction of an $18.9 million sewage treatment plant in Yonkers. The plant would remove the water from sewage sludge, allowing the county to meet a Federal deadline banning ocean dumping of sludge by the end of next year.

title: U.S. Calls Milk Free of Antibiotics
description: The Food and Drug Administration said today that its most reliable test had found no residues of potentially harmful antibiotics in a nationwide survey of milk, contrary to the findings of earlier tests. But critics immediately challenged the latest results. Concern about the safety of milk was raised in March 1988, when the agency reported that more than half of 70 samples of milk taken in 14 cities were contaminated with antibiotics, which are not permitted in milk.

title: Stay Tuned for a Cultural Nightmare, TV Babies;   Dialogue Takes Two
description: To the Editor:

title: Operating Net Flat At Sears
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer, today reported a sharp increase in fourth-quarter net income. But after adjusting for one-time charges that depressed 1988 results, operating income for the fourth quarter was up only 1.4 percent.

title: 2 Sides at Gotti Trial Slug It Out With Insults in Their Summations
description: Trading insults in unusually rancorous summations, prosecution and defense lawyers yesterday presented vastly different portraits of the evidence in the John Gotti assault trial.

title: Field Biologist With Daunting Mission: Saving a Corner of the World
description: EARLY in the movie ''Gorillas in the Mist,'' Sigourney Weaver, as the naturalist Dian Fossey, flees headlong down a mountain slope, pursued by a roaring male gorilla. ''What does Schaller's book say when a gorilla charges?'' her tracker asks moments later as she recovers in safety.

title: Lockheed Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $4 million from discontinued operations. c-Net income d-After a loss of $3 million for the quarter and income of $166 million, or $2.76 a share, for the year, both from discontinued operations. The loss from continuing operations in the latest fourth quarter included a pre-tax charge of about $300 million for unanticipated costs in development of the Navy's P-7A Maritime Patrol aircraft. The income from continuing operations in the latest year included writeoffs of about $500 million, pre-tax, on fixed-price development contracts.

title: Mandela Set No Conditions For Release, an Aide Insists
description: A senior official of the African National Congress said today that the organization's jailed leader, Nelson Mandela, had set no conditions for his release and that, as far as Mr. Mandela was concerned, ''he should have come out a long time ago.''

title: HomeFed Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
First Black Elected to Head Harvard's Law Review
description: The Harvard Law Review, generally considered the most prestigious in the country, elected the first black president in its 104-year history today. The job is considered the highest student position at Harvard Law School.

title: Baldor Electric Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: Share earnings for all periods are adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split Sept. 20, 1989.

title: Sihanouk Says He'll Go Home
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk said today that he would return to Cambodia by the end of the month to live in a ''liberated zone'' administered by his guerrilla army. Prince Sihanouk, who lives in exile in Beijing, Paris and Pyongyang, North Korea, quit two weeks ago as the leader of a three-party coalition fighting Vietnam's occupation of Cambodia but still claims to be the head of state.

title: Napa Valley Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1988 periods restated to reflect the acquisition of Sulsun Valley Bank on April 17, 1989 on a pooling-of-interests basis.

title: Dow Up 19.82, to 2,622.52, on Lower Volume
description: Stocks registered another strong gain yesterday but on sharply lower volume.

title: Lebanon Faction Claims Attack on Israeli Group
description: An Islamic fundamentalist movement based in Lebanon took responsibility today for the assault on a tour bus carrying Israelis in Egypt, the worst terrorist attack here in years. The group, part of the coalition of extremist factions known as Islamic Holy War, said the killings on Sunday were meant to show opposition to Mideast peace efforts and to the tide of Soviet Jews entering Israel.

title: Big What If: How a Hugo Might Hit L.I.
description: Weather forecasting has never been a sure-bet science, and hurricanes are among nature's most fickle elements.

title: Beneficial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $7,900,000 for both the quarter and year.

title: Putnam Master Income Trust reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: Assets represented net assets and per share figures are net assets per share.

title: New Aggressiveness at Siemens
description: Siemens A.G., Western Europe's largest electronics concern, is at last breaking out of its traditional mold as the prototype of a West German industrial group: conservative, cash-laden and about as exciting as yesterday's sauerkraut.

title: LTV Income Drops 24%
description: The LTV Corporation, the nation's third-largest steel company, said today that its fourth-quarter earnings fell 24 percent from a year earlier, largely because of lower sales to the military industry and lower profits on aircraft operations.

title: Howard Beach Retrial Planned
description: The special prosecutor in the Howard Beach racial attack case said yesterday that he would prosecute three young white men again on riot charges stemming from the 1986 attack.

title: Bkla Bancorp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Indians in Kashmir Shoot Protesters From Pakistan
description: Indian troops opened fire today on a group of civilian demonstrators who crossed from Pakistan into Indian-occupied territory in Kashmir, Government-controlled television said tonight.

title: Britain Set For Linkage
description: The European Community's Competition Commissioner, Sir Leon Brittan, said today that Britain had met the conditions for becoming a full member of the European Monetary System.

title: Central Jersey Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
I Hurled Myself - Literally - Into Danger
description: LEAD: After watching numerous news reports in which a crime is committed with bystanders refusing to help, one often asks a number of questions. Does anyone in New York City give a damn? What would I do in a similar circumstance? Would I be a man or a mouse?

title: First Constitution Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said that the accelerating deterioration of real estate markets in Connecticut after the end of 1989 caused it to add $33.5 million to its provision for loan losses.

title: CHENEY CONCEDES HUGE INVENTORIES
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said today that the Pentagon is still having tremendous difficulties in overseeing its $103 billion inventory of spare parts, uniforms and materiel.

title: Home Buyers Fall Behind
description: Home buyers waited longer to buy in 1989 because prices rose faster than their incomes, an annual study has found. Last year was the 14th straight year that the gap between home prices and income has widened, The Chicago Title and Trust Company said its annual survey of home buyers in 18 urban areas showed that the majority of 1989 home buyers were two-income couples who had saved for an average of 2.9 years -the longest period in the survey's 14-year history - to obtain enough for a down payment.

title: Zapata Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
INSIDE
description: Milk Called Uncontaminated

title: Panel Urges More Pay For Connecticut Posts
description: The commission charged with recommending salaries for elected state officials proposed large pay raises today, including a 35 percent raise for the governor, although one member objected.

title: Archibald Ross Lewis, Historian, Dies at 75
description: Dr. Archibald Ross Lewis, an author, educator and historian, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Tucson, Ariz. He was 75 years old and had homes in Amherst, Mass., and Marblehead, Mass.

title: Ralph Anderson, 67, Architect in Southwest
description: Ralph Alexander Anderson Jr., a leading architect in the Southwest for 40 years, died Saturday at his home in Houston. He was 67 years old.

title: Savings Agency Sets Rules
description: The savings and loan bailout agency approved ethics rules today for deciding which private consultants and managers get a piece of what is being called the biggest real estate sale since the Oklahoma land rush.

title: First Source Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Per share earnings were not available.

title: REAGAN REJECTS POINDEXTER PLEA TO YIELD DIARIES
description: Former President Ronald Reagan refused today to turn over excerpts of his private diaries to John M. Poindexter, heightening the prospect of a constitutional confrontation before the start of the former national security adviser's Iran-contra trial.

title: Blair Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
Up to 60,000 a Year Get Whooping Cough
description: Whooping cough strikes as many as 60,000 Americans a year, Federal researchers say, adding that most victims are preschoolers and too many are unvaccinated.

title: Going to the Hoop To Redirect Lives
description: There are some 110 gangs in this city. They control drug traffic in the public-housing developments and have names like the Vice Lords and the Disciples. The Chicago Housing Authority is trying to convert some members of the gangs into basketball players on teams with names like the Bulls and the Lakers.

title: Stay Tuned for a Cultural Nightmare, TV Babies
description: To the Editor:

title: Blast Reportedly Damages Thermal Plant in Azerbaijan
description: An explosion ripped out the roof of a thermal power plant in Azerbaijan, disrupting electricity in the troubled republic, Tass reported today. The press agency did not say whether the damage was accidental.

title: Grasping Reality
description: The news from South Africa is as breathtaking, in its context, as from Mikhail Gorbachev's Soviet Union. The leader of the party that institutionalized white supremacy, that imprisoned the black majority's spokesmen and outlawed its political movements, has started down the political path toward a new South Africa.

title: International Flavors & Frarances reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Correction
description: An obituary on Thursday about Samuel C. Phillips, a former director of the Apollo space program, misstated his last rank and military assignment. When he retired in 1975, he was a four-star general and commander of the Air Force Systems Command.

title: Market Place;   Hopes Run High For South Africa
description: INTERNATIONAL investors poured cash into South African stocks yesterday, continuing the trend of assuming that signs of political change in the world will work out for the best.

title: An Advance for American Free Speech
description: Amid the anti-Communist hysteria of the McCarthy era, Congress passed the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act, designed to exclude foreign visitors whose politics its proponents didn't like. It was an ill-advised law - passed over President Truman's veto - back in 1952. Now, as Communism relaxes its grip on Eastern Europe and perhaps the Soviet Union, it is even more inappropriate.

title: Sunrise Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $50,000 gain on sale of participating preferred stock in the Federal Home Loan Mortgage for quarter and 6 months. c-Included gains of $95,000 and $170,000 on the sale of stock in second quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: A.T.&T. Urges More Calls Abroad
description: Consumers who make frequent telephone calls to Hong Kong and Taiwan received a curious piece of mail last month: a greeting card from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company commemorating the Chinese New Year, which is being celebrated through this week.

title: Taxes May Increase, Trenton Warns
description: The Florio administration said today that the state faces a $550 million deficit this fiscal year and that the Governor is contemplating tax increases despite his pledge as a candidate last year that none were needed.

title: WLR Foods Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
American Family Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included net realized investment gains of $1,083,000, or 1 cent a share and $4,148,000, or 5 cents a share for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After a net realized investment loss of $3,201,000 for the quarter and a net realized investment gain of $1,000 for the year. The company said the primary causes of its earnings decline were unusual and non-recurring. For the year the company said it had a $34.5 million writedown of the assets of its printing subsidiary, Communicorp Inc., and a higher effective tax rate of 55.5 percent versus 45.3 percent. Total revenues reflect adoption of Financial Accounting Standards Board Statement No. 97, in which realized investment gains before taxes are included.

title: Excerpts From Remarks by Gorbachev Before Central Committee of Party
description: Following are excerpts from remarks by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev yesterday to the Central Committee of the Soviet Communist Party, as provided by the English-language service of the Soviet press agency Tass:

title: RJR Nabisco Had Loss in Quarter, Year
description: RJR Nabisco Inc. yesterday reported a net loss in the fourth quarter of $144 million and a loss for the year of $1.15 billion. But analysts said the results largely reflected an increase in interest expense and other costs from being taken private early last year by the New York investment firm Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Genentech Drops On Deal Analysis
description: Genentech Inc.'s stock fell after analysts concluded that a proposed merger with Roche Holding Ltd. was less favorable to investors than it first seemed. ''If Genentech does well, the stock could rise, but the deal effectively puts a cap on the price.'' said Michael Cohen, an analyst with Hambrecht & Quist. Genentech's stock, which rose $8.125 Friday, fell $1.75 today, to $28.125, on the New York Stock Exchange, where more than 3.8 million shares were traded.

title: EX-H.U.D. OFFICIAL WILL NOT TESTIFY
description: A fifth former official of the Department of Housing and Urban Development today invoked Fifth Amendment protections against compelled self-incrimination and declined to testify before a House subcommittee investigating abuse, favoritism and mismanagement at the agency in the Reagan Adminstration.

title: Chronicle
description: From kissing hands to pounding keys: HENRY A. GRUNWALD has segued from ambassador to author. Mr. Grunwald, the former editor in chief of Time Inc., resigned last month as United States Ambassador to Austria.

title: Baroid Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $339,000, or 1 cent a share and $1,841,000, or 3 cents a share for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included extraordinary tax credits of $419,000, or 1 cent a share for the quarter and $1,284,000, or 2 cents a share for the year.

title: Patterns
description: Splish-Splash

title: Cardinal Financial Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TESTIMONY BEGINS IN OIL SPILL TRIAL
description: Joseph J. Hazelwood was in a bar for seven hours, ordering glasses of vodka, a short time before before his tanker tanker left port on a voyage that would result in the nation's worst oil spill, a prosecutor said today.

title: Charter One Financial Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an after-tax gain from the sale of Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. preferred stock of $4.4 million. c-Included an after-tax gain of $2.3 million on the sale of Federal Home Loan Mortgate preferred stock. d-Included tax loss carryforwards of $1,070,000 and an after-tax gain from the sale of Federal Home preferred stock of $3 million. The 1988 periods were restated to reflect the merger of First Federal Savings of Akron and Western Reserve Savings Bank which took effect Aug. 10, 1989.

title: Our Towns;   Pay or Shiver: Sticker Shock Of Heating Oil
description: rrWinter has not yet run its capricious course, but the near-balmy days of January and early February make the pulse-chilling cold of December seem a bitter memory.

title: Gooden Takes Anti-Drug Message to Brooklyn Pupils
description: Dwight Gooden, the Mets pitcher who underwent treatment for cocaine abuse, told a group of schoolchildren in Brooklyn yesterday that his problems and the recently disclosed alcohol abuse of his teammate Darryl Strawberry should strengthen their resolve to ''say no'' to drugs.

title: Cominco Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $26,800,000, or 34 cents a share for the quarter and $28,500,000, or 36 cents a share for the year. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Poughkeepsie Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the loss in the fourth quarter was due primarily to a special $4 million addition to the loan loss reserves, which was partially offset by a $1 million reduction in income taxes from the realization of losses on loans for which a book provision was previously made. In addition to the loan loss provisions, the year included $8.3 million after-tax for the writeoff of goodwill related to the bank's investment in its branches in North Carolina and South Carolina and a $1 million pretax adjustment of interest income on certain mortgage-backed securities related to prior periods.

title: Showdown for Democracy in the House
description: Imagine an American Presidential election where about half the eligible voters stayed home. That actually happened in 1988. The trend in non-Presidential years is even more lamentable. In 1986, the last midterm election, non-voters outnumbered voters by about 40 million. One fundamental problem is that fully one-third of all eligible voters aren't even registered.

title: Work Stations From I.B.M. To Offer Next Inc. Software
description: In a long-awaited move, the International Business Machines Corporation said today that it would offer easy-to-use software developed by Next Inc. on a forthcoming line of work stations and the PS/2 line of personal computers.

title: Chronicle
description: Two prospective governors declared their candidacies yesterday. If elected, one would be the first woman to serve as Governor of California and the other the first black to be Governor of Georgia.

title: Syracuse Gains 5th Victory In a Row
description: Stephen Thompson knows Syracuse has a reputation as a poor foul shooting team but he says it's folly for opponents to think they can beat the Orangemen by putting them on the free-throw line at the end of the game.

title: Visitors to U.S. Expected To Increase 75% in Decade
description: The number of visitors to the United States will increase more than 75 percent by the end of the decade from last year's 38 million visitors, the Commerce Department said today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-19

title: Seacoast Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Tribune Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1989 fourth quarter and full year included one more week than the comparable 1988 periods. Latest periods are presented less: preferred dividends, net of tax, of $4,640,000 and $12,880,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. Preferred dividends are presented net of related tax benefit. Previously reported primary net income per share for the second and third quarters of 1989 will be increased by 3 cents a 4 cents, respectively, to reflect this tax benefit.

title: Schlumberger Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $21,500,000, or 9 cents a share, representing award from Iran-U.S. claims tribunal. c-Included an extraordinary gain of $22,287,000 for the quarter and year, representing award from Iran-U.S. claims tribunal. Results for the latest year included a $13 million, or 5 cents a share, gain from the sale of the defense systems businesses of Schlumberger Industries. Results for the 1988 year included a $35 million, or 13 cents a share, gain from the sale of the Electricity Control & Transformers division of Schlumberger Industries. The company said decreased interest income of $63 million primarily resulted fromspending $1.2 billion in 1988 to repurchase 34.5 million shares.

title: Chess
description: The former world champion, Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, and the Dutch grandmaster Jan Timman are supposed to be getting set for their final candidates' match in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, starting on March 7, but lately neither has been in good form.

title: Moscow and Pretoria News Lifts Precious Metals Prices
description: Precious metals prices continued to rise yesterday in reaction to developments in South Africa and the Soviet Union. Dealers said a further decline in the dollar against the yen and the West German mark also bolstered the gold market.

title: Pulling Charts Out of a Hat
description: GRAPH-IN-THE-BOX has attracted more than 250,000 users in nine languages since it was introduced in 1986. Now in version 2.2, it produces better charts than ever.

title: Rig Count Drops Again
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States continued to decline last week, dropping by six, to a total of 931, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. But the number was higher than the 780 posted for the corresponding week last year. In the two previous weeks, the count plunged by a total of 82 rigs.

title: Brazil Denies Japan Deal
description: Brazil's President Jose Sarney has denied that Japanese business executives offered to buy Brazil's $115 billion foreign debt in exchange for mining rights over Amazon gold fields.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Council on Competitiveness, Washington, an organization of business, education and labor leaders, named Kent H. Hughes president.

title: Farmer Bros.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sears, Roebuck & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $66,700,000, and the share earnings reflected after-tax charges of $1.17 a share for the restructuring of Sears Merchandise Group and 16 cents a share for a loss on the sale of the Allstate group life- health business. Prior year results reflected after- tax restructuring charges of $457.9 million and income of $544.2 million from a tax accounting change.

title: G.M. Class E Dividend Up
description: The General Motors Corporation today increased its class E stock dividend by 17 percent and split the stock, 2 for 1, because of growth in non-G.M. computer business at the auto maker's Electronic Data Systems Corporation subsidiary.

description: b-Net loss Results for the second quarter and first half ended Dec. 31, 1989, included Imprimis Technology from its date of acquisition on Oct. 29, 1989.

title: Senate Votes Death Penalty Despite Cuomo's Veto Stand
description: In what has become an annual legislative ritual, the State Senate approved the death penalty today, but one Senator's absence left proponents wondering whether they had enough votes to override a gubernatorial veto.

description: Assets represented net assets and per share figures are net assets per share.

description: b-Included writedown of $1,443,000 of the premium of loan sales. c-Included an extraordinary credit of $1,375,000, or $1.00 a share.

title: A Gallimard Sets Deadline
description: The feuding Gallimards, owners of a publishing house whose authors include Marcel Proust and Jean-Paul Sartre, have until mid-February to bid for 12.5 percent of company and end a fight for control.

title: New England Critical Care reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Molestation Case Charges May Be Dropped
description: The Los Angeles District Attorney said today that as many as eight of the 13 child molestation and conspiracy charges remaining against Raymond Buckey might be dropped because at least two potential witnesses, both children, have balked at taking the stand.

title: Nationwide Health Properties reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Insituform Southeast reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
No Need for Dispute Over an Immigration Jail
description: To the Editor:

title: Islanders Survive Lemieux Spree
description: Mario Lemieux of the Pittsburgh Penguins, playing despite pain and acknowledging the possibility of impending back surgery, scored two goals and added three assists tonight to extend his scoring streak to 43 games, 8 short of Wayne Gretzky's National Hockey League record.

title: Edward Massie, 79; Noted Cardiologist Was Author of Text
description: Dr. Edward Massie, a St. Louis cardiologist for 50 years, died Monday at a convalescent hospital in St. Louis County, Mo. He was 79 years old and lived in Clayton, Mo.

title: Bush Calls For Some Regulation
description: In the most thorough presentation of his economic views since he took office, President Bush today embraced the mainstream Republican philosophy of reliance on private initiatives and market forces. But his first Economic Report to Congress did not have the ideological edge of those submitted by Ronald Reagan.

title: Whitestar Head Named Leader of Bell & Howell
description: The Bell & Howell Company yesterday named William J. White chairman, president and chief executive. He replaces Nils Johansson, the company's chief financial officer, who had been acting as interim chief executive since September, when Gerald E. Schultz resigned.

title: McDonald & Co Investments reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $313,000, or 5 cents a share, from retirement of debt for the quarter and 9 months.

title: Uranium Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Moody's Drops Ratings For 3 Japanese Banks
description: Moody's Investors Service Inc. lowered debt ratings of three large Japanese banks yesterday because of problems they face in the Japanese real estate market.

title: Fidelity Fedl Savings Bank (Marion, Ohio) reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Magazine Revenues Increase by 10.9%
description: Advertising revenues in magazines monitored by the Publishers Information Bureau rose to $6.642 billion in 1989, up 10.9 percent from the year before, according to figures released by the bureau. Advertising pages rose 3.5 percent, to 177,000.

title: Kansas City Power & Light reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Johnson & Johnson reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings adjusted to reflect the 2-for-1 stock split in May 1989.

title: Review/Music;   A Tippett Oratorio By Way Of Spirituals
description: Sir Michael Tippett's oratorio ''A Child of Our Time'' is seldom performed in the United States, and it is difficult to fathom why. The subjects, to be sure, are war, persecution and misery, and the mood is predominantly desolate. The ''child of our time,'' it turns out, is ''the scapegoat.'' Yet the work's ultimate message is consolatory, and the composer's incorporation of American spirituals into his highly individual idiom is masterly (far more so than some of his later flirtations with jazz) and touching.

title: Friends Remember Irving Berlin With Stories and His Own Songs
description: The enduring musical legacy of Irving Berlin was honored yesterday at the Music Box Theater in a memorial tribute to the songwriter, who died in September at the age of 101.

title: Harold S. Spielman, Professor, 75
description: Harold S. Spielman, professor emeritus of education at City College, died of complications from Parkinson's disease on Friday at New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Yonkers.

title: Large Losses Are Reported By Texas Air
description: The Texas Air Corporation, citing heavy losses at its Eastern Airlines subsidiary, said yesterday that it lost $362.8 million in the fourth quarter, up from a loss of $224.4 million a year earlier. For the year, the company had a loss of $885.6 million, an industry record, compared with a loss of $718.6 million in 1988.

title: Upheaval in the East: U.S. Policy;   U.S. Backing West German's Unity Idea
description: The United States is backing a proposal by the West German Foreign Minister that a reunified Germany be part of NATO but that no NATO troops be based on the territory of East Germany, a senior Administration official said today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Neither in his real life (author, editor of The Paris Review) nor in his vicarious one (boxer, goalie, pro football player) has GEORGE PLIMPTON considered himself a fashion plate. But he exchanged his baggy tweeds for a dinner jacket last night to pay tribute to one of fashion's icons, the late Diana Vreeland, whose autobiography, ''D.V.,'' he edited.

title: Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit from a litigation settlement of $1,908,000, or 31 cents a share.

title: INSIDE
description: Bush Economic Report:

title: N.H.L. Investigation
description: Brian O'Neill, the National Hockey League's executive vice president, said yesterday that he was directing an N.H.L. investigation of an alleged racial incident involving the Rangers and the Bruins last Saturday at Boston Garden.

title: Central Pacific Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Pers share earnings are fully diluted.

Goal by Sundstrom Earns a Tie for Devils
description: The Devils kept buzzing around Edmonton's goal all game tonight, but converted only 2 of their 32 chances and barely managed a 2-2 tie with the Oilers at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Pacific Telecom reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Market Place;   Brokerage's Fall Has Ripple Effect
description: WHEN a small publicly traded company collapses, the stock market damage is usually limited to its own shares. That is not the case when the failed company is a publicly traded brokerage house like the J. T. Moran Financial Corporation, the once-expanding conglomerate that filed for bankruptcy court protection in New York last week.

title: Kroger Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-After extraordinary losses of $51,252,824 for the quarter and $56,470,769 for the year. The extraordinary items reflected after-tax loss from the writeoff of deferred costs associated with entering into a credit agreement in 1988 and the costs associated with cancelling the related interest rate protection agreement. c-Net income Results included pre-tax restructuring charges of $10,362,028 for the latest quarter and $195 million for year-ago period. The results included pre-tax gain of $28.4 million from the sale of divested unit assets in 1989 and pre-tax costs associated with the restructuring of $10.4 million and $195 million in 1989 and 1988, respectively.

title: Mandela Has Not Set Conditions for Release, a Visitor Says
description: Nelson Mandela is pressing the Government for further concessions before he gains his freedom but he is not staging a prison sit-in, a visitor to his prison bungalow said today.

title: District Offers Tax-Exempts
description: The District of Columbia is tentatively offering $34.8 million in tax-exempt revenue bonds for the Association of American Medical Colleges, through Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: New York Education Chief Seeks New Stress on Nonwhite Cultures
description: The New York State Education Commissioner said today that he would draft broad revisions in the state's public school curriculum to give much greater recognition to the contributions of nonwhite cultures to American society.

title: Emerson Electric Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the primary reason for the 4.3 percent decline in sales was the company's divestitures during the last half of fiscal 1989 of operations with annual sales of approximately $365 million.

title: Broker Gets a 5-Year Term
description: A former stockbroker who bilked his golf buddies and other associates of more than $2 million was sentenced on Monday to five years in prison after pleading guilty to Federal mail fraud and other charges.

title: Will Federated's Chief Have Time?
description: At the helm of Bullock's five years ago, Allen I. Questrom ordered the West Coast department store chain to pull out of a data exchange through which competing chains tracked short-term shifts in market share. He warned his merchandisers and buyers to think of the long term because short-term gains mean little in the life of any business.

title: Rubbermaid Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KCS Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: Cards Hire Redskin Aide
description: Joe Bugel, who has been an assistant coach in the National Football League for 15 years, today was given the job of coaching the Phoenix Cardinals back to respectability.

title: Mel Lewis Memorial
description: A memorial service for the jazz drummer Mel Lewis, who died on Friday, is to be held on Sunday at 7 P.M. at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue at 54th Street.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: No Softening in Tone of the Talks
description: Charles O'Connor, the baseball owners' chief negotiator, continued yesterday to stress the importance of using the current labor negotiations to improve the relationship between owners and players. But the talks were rapidly traveling toward the sort of tone that has sunk efforts to attain labor peace in previous years.

title: Time to Stop Bashing The 'Wealthy' Elderly

description: An article on Dec. 21 about the implications of President Bush's decision to invade Panama included an incorrect quotation from Gen. Colin L. Powell, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. As a recent letter from a reader points out. General Powell said, ''As a practical matter, we have decapitated him from the dictatorship,'' referring to Gen.

title: KEY RATES
Marrying to 'Get There'
description: To The Living Section:

title: American Airlines Sets Dallas Plan
description: American Airlines announced an expansion plan for its hub at the Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport. The $276 million program would allow American to increase its daily flights from Dallas by 25 percent. The airline, which is owned by the AMR Corporation, now schedules more than 400 flights a day out of the airport, the nation's fourth-largest.

title: Grand Central Brought to Halt By Cable Fire
description: A huge machine that levels the tracks leading into Grand Central Terminal snagged a 600-volt electrical cable in a tunnel beneath Park Avenue yesterday, sending up a shower of sparks and flames that injured 11 railroad workers and 2 firefighters. Train service was halted for hours, and thousands of commuters were delayed.

title: Tobacco Company's Gift Is Turned Into a Lesson
description: A Vermont lawmaker plans to teach a few lessons by giving away datebooks sent by the Philip Morris Companies as gifts to legislators. The datebooks will now be used to teach elementary school students about drug and alcohol use.

title: Office Club reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: This Wasn't the Boy East Harlem Knew
description: There are eyes in East Harlem that grow teary with grief at the mention of Robert Cole, the 13-year-old neighborhood boy who was shot to death last week by a police officer after, investigators say, he tried to rob a bodega. And some lips tremble when they speak of ''Robbie'' and the streets that tempt good boys to do bad.

title: Noble Affiliates reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an accounting adjustment gain of $8,825,000, or 20 cents a share.

Chinese Debt Seen Rising
description: China's state-run enterprises plunged further into debt last year as low efficiency and bad planning depressed profits, an official newspaper said today.

Biocraft Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

The company had originally reported net of $4,692,000, or 33 cents a share, in the second quarter, and earnings of $8,252,000, or 59 cents a share, in the 6 months.

description: The company said year-ago full year figures included a gain of $600,000 from disposal of a product line.

title: Joint Venture Planned By G.M. and Chrysler
description: The General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation reached final agreement today on the first manufacturing joint venture among the Big Three auto makers in United States history.

title: Koger Equity reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Revenue for 1988 is included for the period beginning Aug. 25, commencement of operations, and ending Dec. 31.

title: Former Dissident Appointed As Leader of Czech Republic
description: A leader of the Civic Forum opposition group was appointed today as Prime Minister of the Czech republic.

title: Stalin's Legacy of Filth
description: Decades of Communist rule have cast a pall of industrial filth that reaches from the forests of East Germany to the dying shores of the Aral Sea. The rising tide of pollutants has poisoned earth and water throughout the Eastern Bloc, and in many cities threatens human health.

title: Kappa Networks reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $17,655, or 1 cent a share. c-After a loss of $58,179 from discontinued operations.

The year's income from discontinued operations included an after-tax gain of $1.09 million, or 12 cents a share, from the sale of HPI Health Care Services Inc. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $871,000, or 9 cents a share, for the quarter and $2,139,000, or 22 cents a share, for the year; the year also was after income of $330,000, or 3 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Real Estate;   Foreign Cash Fuels Hotels In Manhattan
description: IT might seem odd for new investment to continue to flow into Manhattan hotel projects at a time when the hospitality industry faces a glut in new rooms, a fall in domestic tourism and a decline in business travel because of troubles in the financial district.

title: Appeals Court Nominee Is Questioned on Rights
description: Some members of the Senate Judiciary Committee today closely questioned Clarence Thomas, an outspoken conservative, about his approach to civil rights, but committee aides and others said there seemed to be no significant obstacle raised to his being confirmed to a seat on the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.

title: NL Bid Weighed By Georgia Gulf
description: The Georgia Gulf Corporation, facing a $1.1 billion bid from the Texas investor Harold Simmons, said its board would recommend by the end of the week whether shareholders should accept or reject the proposal. NL Industries Inc., a chemical supply company controlled by Mr. Simmons, began a $45-a-share tender offer today for the 91 percent of Georgia Gulf it does not already own.

title: For Sears's Discover, Next Step Is Harder
description: In the rough-and-tumble world of credit cards, Sears, Roebuck & Company's Discover has been the card with nine lives.

title: Redmen Use Balance To Overtake Rutgers
description: St. John's lost Jayson Williams on Saturday to a fractured right foot. Rutgers lost Earl Duncan on Sunday to a sprained right ankle. It figured that some lost games were certain to follow for both schools as a result. It happened for Rutgers first.

title: Tax Raffles in Argentina
description: Argentina plans to hold weekly and monthly raffles to encourage people to pay the 13 percent value-added tax introduced earlier this month. Numbered sales receipts, distributed by the Federal Tax Bureau, will be used as raffle tickets, the Public Revenues Secretary, Raul Cuello, said Monday night.

title: Northland Cranberries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Laurel Savings Assn reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

description: b-Net loss

Irish Deal Unsettles ABC
description: Stephen J. Solomon, senior vice president of ABC Sports, said yesterday that his network might consider legal action against the College Football Association, the University of Notre Dame and NBC in light of the exclusive five-year contract Notre Dame signed with NBC on Monday to televise football games starting in 1991.

title: Merchants Bancorp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Year-ago per share earnings adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend paid in October 1989.

title: Cuba Said to Cut Rations
description: The Soviet Union has fallen seriously behind on grain shipments to Cuba, forcing the Castro Government to cut the bread ration and increase some food prices, Western diplomats and other experts say. Page A10.

title: Corrections
description: A book review on Saturday about ''Native's Return, 1945-1988,'' by William L. Shirer, misidentified the writer of the film ''The Front.'' He was Walter Bernstein; Woody Allen was the star.

title: ISRAELIS WIDENING ROLE IN ETHIOPIA
description: In an effort to support the last non-Arab presence on the Red Sea, Israel has increased its diplomatic and military links with the embattled Marxist-Leninist Government here, diplomats say.

title: Shelter Components Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $953,000 and $1,365,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss

title: GWC Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Half Measures
description: LEAD: Half measures can kill when on the brink of precipices, chafing in terror at the bit, we strain and sweat and foam because we cannot jump just halfway across.

title: Fine for Agent Firm
description: Secretary of State George Bayoud of Texas said yesterday that Team America, a Nebraska-based sports marketing firm, had admitted wrongdoing and agreed to pay a $10,000 fine for illegally contacting Andre Ware, the University of Houston quarterback, who won the Heisman Trophy last season as a junior.

title: Accounts
description: * Sony Magnetic Products Company, to Burkhardt & Christy Advertising from McCann-Erickson Worldwide, with billings said to be several million dollars.

title: LAC Minerals Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said it has adopted the U.S. dollar as its reporting currency following the acquisition in November of 65 percent of Bond International Gold Inc., which reports in U.S. dollars. Results for 1988 have been converted into U.S. dollars at the exchange rate as of Dec. 31, 1988.

title: F.D.A. Chemist Asserts Agency Is Stalling on Tests for Milk Purity
description: A chemist for the Food and Drug Administration today accused the agency of deliberately stalling the development and use of tests to determine whether milk is contaminated with possibly hazardous antibiotics.

title: Citizens Savings Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $801,000, or 26 cents a share. c-After an extraordinary loss of $920,000. The extraordinary item represented the gain on assumption of certain below market rate Federal Home Loan Bank advances of the Citizens Federal Bank unit by an independent third party during the second quarter of 1989, and the writeoff of the balance of unamortized issuance costs of subordinated debt redeemed during the second and third quarters of 1988.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Indiana Energy Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CHRONICLE
description: YOKO ONO won her day in court. JUDGE CAROL H. ARBER of the New York State Supreme Court in Manhattan granted Ms. Ono's motion to stop MARILYN GOLDBERG, an art dealer, from selling works by John Lennon. The prohibition remains in effect until a trial, expected later this year.

title: Review/Art;   Monet's Complexity and Grandeur in His Series Paintings
description: In Paris in 1890, Impressionism had lost most of its edge and there was little consensus about its leader, Claude Monet. He remained, in the words of the art historian Paul Hayes Tucker, ''on the fringes of acceptability.''

title: Deerfield Federal S&L Assoc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Texas Air orp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Medical Care Intl reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $1,129,000, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter and $3,086,000, or 19 cents a share, for the year, both from tax loss carryforwards. c-After extraordinary credits of $913,000, or 6 cents a share, and $4,462,000, or 31 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively, from tax loss carryforwards.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: AT J. Martinez & Company, John and Melanie Martinez approach coffee with the reverence of wine connoisseurs, the zeal of avant-garde art dealers. Customers buy their coffee by the cup to drink amid the shop's elegant mahogany paneling or by the pound to take home. But unlike most retailers who sell a wide range of exotic-sounding coffees they obtain through brokers, the Martinezes sell only the coffees they import themselves as green beans from seven farms and estates around the world.

title: Early Retirements Taken at U S West
description: U S West Inc., a telecommunications holding company based in Englewood, Colo., said that its early retirement offer had been accepted by some 3,850 managers. The company's president, Richard D. McCormick, said he expected the final tally of participants in the company's cost-cutting program to be 4,000.

title: Contributions to Democrats Lagging
description: The Democratic National Committee, still struggling for financial momentum after the party's bitter defeat in the 1988 Presidential race, collected far less money last year than in the off-election years of 1987 and 1985.

title: From Dinkins's Tax Quest, Warm Words, No Promises
description: With a cordiality rarely seen in Albany, Mayor David N. Dinkins today politely urged state lawmakers to approve almost $300 million in new taxes for New York City. After a full day of meetings with state leaders, he left the Capitol with many compliments, but no commitments.

title: Lincoln Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Upheaval in the East: The Germans;   Exchange Rate Crucial In a Move to One Mark
description: If West Germany and East Germany move rapidly toward a single currency, the crucial decision for both the politicians and the economists will be the rate at which the East German mark is exchanged for the West German mark, several economists said yesterday.

title: Lessons
description: Are the 2.5 million schoolchildren in New York State the victims of a ''Eurocentric'' curriculum that strips minority students of their dignity? Should teachers seek to systematically reduce the ''arrogance'' of white students?

title: Doctor Says Prego Knew of Serious Infection in '85
description: A physician who examined Dr. Veronica Prego in 1985 testified yesterday that he told her she had a serious infection but that he did not know with any certainty at the time that she would get AIDS.

title: Washington Post Co. Profit Rose 38.5% in 4th Quarter
description: The Washington Post Company said today that its fourth-quarter profit climbed 38.5 percent from a year earlier, largely because of charges against earnings taken by Newsweek magazine in the fourth quarter of 1988.

title: Respironics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dresher Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $39,000 for the quarter and $110,000 for the 6 months. The company said included in the year-ago quarter and 6 months losses from continuing operations of $755,000 and $250,000, respectively, both included a $942,000 writedown of investment.

title: Kemp Tightens Control of 3,300 Housing Agencies
description: Responding to findings of financial abuses at a New Jersey public housing authority, Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp has ended a program that gave 600 local housing agencies relative independence in their management practices.

title: Junior Senior Lobbyist Cut His Teeth on Albany
description: There is a polite silence in Albany about John T. Bozzella, the 27-year-old lobbyist who has been handed the daunting portfolio of representing New York City in the State Capitol.

title: National Fuel Gas Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Noranda Forest reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results of Normick Perron Inc. have been consolidated for the last four months of 1989. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Yugoslavs to Study Kosovo Police Controls
description: A commission has been established to investigate complaints against security forces that put down the violent ethnic unrest in Kosovo province, the police chief said today.

title: Reviews/Music;   A Factorylike Emptiness
description: Frank Zappa was perhaps the most intriguing name on Sunday's program by the Aspen Wind Quintet at the 92d Street Y, even if the music he provided was not. In the midst of this all-20th-century afternoon was Mr. Zappa's ''Times Beach,'' at least its new fifth movement. The previous four were first heard in 1985.

title: Burlington to Cut Its Transport Unit
description: Burlington Industries, a maker of fabrics and clothing, said it would restructure its transportation division, cutting nearly 600 jobs, reducing the size of its trucking fleet and assigning some routes to other carriers. The company, a wholly owned subsidiary of Burlington Holdings Inc., said that its facility in North Bergen, N.J., would be closed and that the transportation division's employment would be reduced from about 1,030 to about 580.

title: With Smaller Lineup, Knicks Rally to Win
description: For three quarters, it appeared that the Knicks would have enjoyed visiting Disney World tonight more than visiting Orlando Arena.

title: More Sallie Mae Floating Rates Set
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering its second floating rate issue for the week.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I have no way of proving my innocence. My accusers cannot establish my guilt. I devoutly hope the inquiries under way will bring an end to this incredibly painful chapter in my life.''

title: LaBarge Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax loss carryforwards of $155,700, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $230,100, or 2 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $285,649, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, and after extraordinary tax loss carryforwards of $338,200, or 2 cents a share, and $526,100, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively; the 6 months also included two one-time gains totaling $609,000 from previously divested businesses.

title: Sometimes an Advance Goes Too Far
description: Interactive displays, in which a customer uses a keypad and a graphic screen to ask questions about a product, have become an important feature in modern merchandising. But every once in a while they backfire.

title: Fibreboard Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss of $988,000 for the quarter and income of $1,479,000, or 38 cents a share for the year, both from discontinued operations. c-Included a loss of $6,677,000 and income of $10,843,000, or $2.80 a share for the quarter and year, respectively, both from discontinued operations. Latest quarter included creation of asbestos-related cost reserve of $25 million ($15 million after-tax or $3.87 a share); year-ago quarter included asbestos expense reversal of $4 million ($2.4 million after-tax or 62 cents a share). The fourth quarter of 1989 included a gain on the sale of Timberland of $26.1 million ($13.5 million after-tax or $3.47 a share) while the fourth quarter of 1988 included a special charge of $4.2 million ($2.5 million after tax, or 65 cents a share) for restructuring.

title: Salomon Posts $68 Million Profit in Period
description: Bolstered by sharply higher earnings at its energy subsidiary, Salomon Inc. yesterday reported earnings for the fourth quarter of $68 million, or 42 cents a share, in contrast to a loss of $38 million in the comparable period a year ago.

title: Maxwell Venture Fund
description: The British entrepreneur Robert Maxwell said Monday that he would set up a $1 billion investment fund to finance joint ventures in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. Mr. Maxwell, who heads the Maxwell Communication Corporation, said at the annual World Economic Forum that the fund would be established by his London & Bishopsgate Investment Management P.L.C. Mr. Maxwell said the partnership would invest in East Germany, Hungary, Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria, Romania, Poland and the Soviet Union.

title: Bernard Bernstein, Aide to Eisenhower In 40's, Dies at 81
description: Bernard Bernstein, a lawyer and Treasury Department official who was a financial adviser to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower in World War II, died of cardiac arrest yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: NUI Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income of $1,193,000, or 24 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

description: On a day when he hailed President Mikhail S. Gorbachev for proposing an end to the Communist Party's constitutional monopoly on power in the Soviet Union, President Bush stood on a bleak Mojave Desert ridge today to watch American soldiers fight ''Soviet'' tanks in a mock World War III battle.

title: Bodo L.O. Richter, 74, A Language Professor
description: Bodo Ludwig Otto Richter, a retired professor of romance languages, died on Friday at his home in West Southport, Me., after a long illness. He was 74 years old.

title: Imperial Cleared For Texaco Deal
description: Imperial Oil Ltd., which is controlled by the Exxon Corporation, received final Government approval for its $5 billion (Canadian) takeover of Texaco Canada. Antitrust officials cleared the second-largest takeover in Canadian history, making Imperial the nation's largest oil producer. Imperial, based in Toronto, is 70 percent owned by Exxon.

title: Moses, Morris, Keith
description: To The Living Section:

title: No Quotas On Arrests, Brown Says
description: New York City's Police Commissioner, Lee P. Brown, said yesterday that while his department monitors overtime closely, no officers are barred from making arrests because of excessive costs.

title: Rolling Stone
description: Leslie H. Zeifman, the associate publisher of Rolling Stone, has been promoted to the newly created position of group publisher for Straight Arrow Publishers, which owns the magazine and also US. At Rolling Stone, Dana L. Fields will replace Mr. Zeifman as associate publisher, and Susan Gold will become advertising director.

title: Canfor Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $400,000, or 3 cents a share and $78,400,000, or $3.46 a share for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said sales for the year aren't directly comparable because of changes resulting from the formation of Howe Sound Pulp and Paper Ltd. and Canfor-Weldwood Distribution Ltd. in early 1988 and 1989, respectively, and the acquisition of Balfour Forest Products Inc. in mid-1989. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Washington Talk;   Are Incumbents Playing With a Stacked Deck?
description: By any measure, Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, had a tumultuous year in 1989.

title: Joseph J. Nazzaro, 76, An Air Force General
description: Joseph James Nazzaro, a retired four-star general of the Air Force, died of cancer Monday at the Tucson Medical Center in Arizona. He was 76 years old and lived in Tucson.

title: Corrections
description: An article in SportsMonday this week about Cam Neely and the Boston Bruins referred incompletely to Bruins hockey players who have scored 50 or more goals in a single season. John Bucyk and Ken Hodge -along with Neely and Phil Esposito -have scored 50 or more.

title: November Savings Outflow Is $4.9 Billion, 4-Month Low
description: Savings and loan customers withdrew $4.9 billion more than they deposited in November as the industry continued to shrink in response to tougher financial standards enacted last summer, the Government said today.

title: First Bank Resignations
description: Three senior executives at First Bank System Inc. resigned Monday as the new chairman, John F. Grundhofer, moved swiftly to shore up the troubled Minneapolis bank's lending procedures. The officers who left are Richard W. Schoenke, chief credit and adminstrative officer; Jay B. Walters, president, commercial and investment banking, and Richard L. Shepley, executive vice president, credit policy. Mr. Grundhofer was named First Bank's chairman last week.

title: Plains Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included one-time aftertax gain of $2.4 million, or 25 cents per share, on sale of certain properties in November 1989.

title: Marion K. Morgan, Interior Designer, 84
description: Marion K. Morgan, an interior designer who specialized in the decorative arts of the 18th century, died Jan. 21 at her home in Manhattan after a long illness. She was 84 years old.

title: Upheaval in the East: The Pentagon;   Discount Soviet Peril to Iran, Cheney Tells His Strategists
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has issued a new guide for military planning that instructs the services to drop the mission of defending Iran in the event of a Soviet attack and calls on the United States' Asian allies to take on more of the burden for their own defense, Pentagon officals said today.

title: House Backs Easy Voter Registration
description: Over the objections of President Bush and some other leading Republicans, the House of Representatives today approved legislation that proponents say would dramatically increase the number of Americans who are registered to vote. The vote was 289 to 132. The legislation would establish national voter registration procedures that all states would have to follow, replacing the current patchwork of different procedures from state to state.

title: Jury Starts Deliberations in Gotti Case
description: After being told by a judge to ''apply your common sense'' and not to ''turn the jury room into the twilight zone,'' 12 jurors began deliberating yesterday in the John Gotti assault and conspiracy trial.

description: IT'S not often that you can find a fine restaurant meal plus entertainment for only $15. But at New Delhi, an Indian restaurant that recently opened near Union Square in San Francisco, that's the price for what amounts to an extraordinary culinary and cultural experience every Monday night.

description: The poem was a simple, dramatic dessert to a long dinner around a table laden with delicacies rarely seen during a Soviet winter: plates full of beef and fish and a pyramid of fresh oranges.

title: In a Modeling School, Finish Comes
description: Gladys Davis likes to think her finishing school and model agency is preparing young women - and the occasional man - to face life's challenges head up, back straight, giving the world what Ms. Davis calls ''a chin line.''

description: b-Included a net charge of $17,800,000, consisting of reorganization charges of $12.3 million in international soft drinks and $5.5 million in Taco Bell's domestic operations. After taxes, the net charge amounted to $13.2 million, or 5 cents a share. c-Included a net credit of $4.4 million ($1.8 million after taxes, or 1 cent a share), consisting primarily of a $32.5 million credit resulting from a decision to retain a botling operation in Japan previously held for sale, partially offset by an $8 million reorganization in Kentucky Fried's domestic operations and $17.8 million in reorganization charges. d-Included a total charge of $23.9 million ($16.3 million after taxes, or 5 cents a share) consisting of a $14,500,000 reorganization in domestic soft drinks and a $9.4 million loss on the sale of a winery in Spain. Results for 1988 are restated to report under the equity method of accounting certain previously consolidated foreign joint venture.

title: Barbara Lewis Golub; Fund-Raiser Was 76
description: Barbara Lewis Golub, a fund-raiser for the New York Philharmonic, died of a heart attack on Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 76 years old.

title: Wildfires in Central Florida
description: Drought and a December freeze that dried vegetation have combined to cause central Florida's worst spell of wildfires in five years, officals say. In Polk, Hillsborough and Pinellas counties, which include Tampa and St. Petersburg, 122 brush fires have been reported since Jan. 1, almost triple last year's rate. Statewide, 817 fires have scorched more than 20,000 acres.

title: NWNL Cos. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

Year-ago figures are not directly comparable; the company said it demutualized in January 1989. NWNL's stock department had net income for year-ago periods of $6,946,000, or 64 cents a share, on revenues of $185,604,000, for the quarter and net of $34,627,000, or $3.16 a share, on revenues of $667,523,000, for the year. The stock department for the year- ago periods had realized investment gains of $913,000 for the quarter and realized investment losses of $12.2 million for the year.

title: Northwest Teleproductions reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Investors Rush to Bid For Notes
description: The first leg of the Treasury's $30 billion quarterly refunding auctions received a thunderous welcome from investors yesterday. More than $34 billion worth of bids were placed for the $10 billion worth of three-year notes that were sold.
