title: Metropolitan Diary
description: THE scene was one of the theaters in the Loew's Sixplex on Broadway at West 84th Street. The time, a recent Friday night. Cast of characters: Manette R. Berlinger and the rest of the audience waiting for Woody Allen's ''Crimes and Misdemeanors'' to begin. Instead, the black and white slides of scenes from the 30's and 40's with which the theater prefaces the showing of the feature presentation appeared for the third time. The film-goers sighed loudly. Then the screen went blank as if the feature was about to begin. Instead, recorded tunes from the 30's and 40's began to play.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Baker Offers Prague Economic Aid
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today offered Czechoslovakia a package of economic assistance similar to that provided by Washington to Poland and Hungary to help the new leaders in Prague consolidate their revolution and establish a free-market democracy.

title: Citibank May Have to Alter Insurance Accounting Method
description: Federal banking regulators are considering changes in accounting practices that would require Citibank to recognize more of the risks from its municipal bond insurance subisidiary, and perhaps sharply increase the amount of capital it needs if it continues to hold the insurance unit.

title: Resignation at Ben & Jerry's
description: The president and chief executive of Ben & Jerry's Homemade Inc., Fred (Chico) Lager, will resign at the end of the year, the company said today.

title: Bridge
description: The New York bridge scene loses two of its most popular figures today, when Tom and Sue Snow go Down Under. Tom Snow recently resigned after 10 years as manager of the Cavendish Club, and the couple will live in Sydney. Sue Snow's return to her native Australia, just in time for maternity, will allow her once again to vie for international honors.

title: Upheaval in the East;   A SINGLE CURRENCY FOR TWO GERMANYS IS SOUGHT BY KOHL
description: Seeking to bolster East Germany's collapsing economy, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany today called for immediate talks on creating a single German currency.

title: Blood for Crash Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: As Shipments of Soviet Grain Lag, Cuba Reduces Daily Bread Ration
description: The Soviet Union has fallen seriously behind with its promised grain shipments to Cuba, forcing the Government of President Fidel Castro to cut the bread ration and increase some food prices, Western diplomats and other experts say.

title: Network General reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. View on German Unity
description: The United States backs the West German Foreign Minister's proposal that a reunited Germany be part of NATO, but that no NATO troops be based in East German territory, an American official said. Page A14.

title: Reviews/Music;   Fine Arts Quartet Plus One
description: Since the program presented by the Fine Arts Quartet at Weill Recital Hall on Friday evening included only two substantial works, one expected the players to revel in each to its full extent. But in Mozart's expansive Quintet for Clarinet and Strings in A (K. 581), with the clarinetist David Shifrin taking part, they skipped the opening exposition repeat. This has the unfortunate effect of making the work's sublime first movement seem a bit lightweight in relation to the others.

description: Greece and Bulgaria, both Orthodox Christian nations with significant Turkish Muslim minorities, are developing common strategies toward Turkey that include military cooperation.

title: 5 Said to Pose as Officers to Rob and Rape
description: Five men posing as narcotics detectives terrorized several residents of a Bronx housing project early yesterday, raped a 19-year-old girl on the roof and robbed five tenants at gunpoint while looking for drugs and money, the police said.

title: Aquino's Rule Is Imperiled as Foes Multiply and 'People Power' Grows Frail
description: Two months after turning back a military revolt that almost toppled her Government, President Corazon C. Aquino has seemingly been unable to win back the nation's confidence. Support for her has so eroded that many Filipinos are raising the possibility that her presidency may not survive until the 1992 elections.

title: Corrections
description: A diagram in Science Times yesterday about an effort to find evidence of aliens in space mislabeled the orientation of the microwave frequencies to be monitored on the electromagnetic spectrum. Although stated correctly as 1 to 10 gigahertz, the range should have been reversed, with 10 gigahertz closer than 1 gigahertz to the visible spectrum.

description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, yesterday priced two issues of callable debentures totaling $1.5 billion, through various securities dealers.

description: I HAVE been on a turkey steak kick for some time now, using the inexpensive and healthful cuts from the breast for all sorts of quick recipes. Like chicken, turkey is extremely versatile because of its neutral flavor.

title: A Wise Promise From Lee Brown
description: After only a few weeks in office, New York City's new Police Commissioner, Lee Brown, faces anguished questions about the fatal police shootings of eight criminal suspects since Jan. 1, including three teen-age boys. So far the killings indicate no administrative lapse - but do dramatize the need for new strategies that Mr. Brown is only too willing to pursue.

title: LOS ANGELES NEARS BATTLE ON ETHICS
description: Some called it farsighted and others called it naive when a special Los Angeles commission proposed the ''toughest set of ethics laws in the country'' two and a half months ago.

description: In Lithuania, they say that Algirdas Brazauskas has seen the future of Soviet Communism, and it looks - well, frankly, not very Communist.

Eating to Heal: Mapping Out New Frontiers
description: LIKE so many Alices in Wonderland, grocery shoppers now wander through a maze of products that seem to sing out: ''Eat me. You'll feel better.''

title: Simon to Make $20 Million From Sale of Hawaii Bank
description: William E. Simon, the former Treasury Secretary whose success at leveraged buyouts in the last decade made him an investment legend, proved today that he still has his golden touch.

title: Texas Tells of Bets Inquiry
description: The president of the University of Texas said today that school officials had notified the National Collegiate Athletic Association of an investigation into accusations that as many as 20 Texas football players regularly placed bets with a teammate on college and professional games.

title: First Charter Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $744,423 for the quarter and $1,505,455 for the year. c-After losses of $10,989 for the quarter and $78,547 for the year, both from discontinued operations. The 1988 periods were restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Reviews/Music;   Susan Dunn in Met Debut, With 2 Tenors in 'Trovatore'
description: An opera historian working a century or so from now is likely to develop the theory that through the 1980's, the Metropolitan Opera sought to keep its audiences from meditating on the paucity of great voices by distracting them with grotesquely conceived productions. These will be seen to have been systematically divided between proponents of two schools, the more prevalent being the Garish Decadent school, characterized by overstuffed sets that dwarf the operas for which they were made.

title: Cairo Journal;   Now, a Little Steam. Later, Maybe, a Water War.
description: The river is low these days, beaching half-built barges and faded houseboats on banks of mud as the Nile slides through the city.

title: Review/Theater;   Making the Case That Arms and Legs Are Mere Bagatelles
description: A coupla white chicks, or maybe they're steel magnolias, sit around talkin' in Peter Hedges's ''Imagining Brad,'' a new play presented by the Circle Repertory Company at the Players Theater. The setting is Nashville, and the women's subject is men. Dana Sue Kaye (Sharon Ernster), a bottle blonde with a 90-proof accent, brags about her happy marriage to her high-school sweetie Alex, a devoted breadwinner and ''the best looking man in Tennessee.'' Valerie (Erin Cressida Wilson), a soft-spoken newlywed transplanted from Philadelphia, raves about her own husband, the wealthy, if bedridden, Brad. Though Brad has his drawbacks - he is armless, legless and legally blind, for starters - he has been unfailingly supportive of Valerie's fledgling country-western singing career.

title: Reagan Nears Center Stage of Iran-Contra Affair
description: Slowly but inexorably, Ronald Reagan is being drawn into the Iran-contra affair after years of conflicting statements and an unwillingness to give a public account of his actions.

title: Upheaval in the East: Poland;   World Bank Approves Its First Loans to Warsaw, in Support of Economic Reforms
description: The World Bank today approved its first two loans to Poland, totaling $360 million, part of a package of more than $2.5 billion that it is preparing over the next three years to help break economic bottlenecks and support reforms of the Solidarity-led Government.

title: Genentech Matchmaker Calls Roche Ideal Partner
description: The investment banker behind Genentech Inc.'s plan to sell a 60 percent interest to Roche Holdings Ltd. for $2.1 billion is Frederick Frank, who brought the management of the two companies together and shepherded the deal through.

title: Elmira Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Reviews/Music;   Mateos's Populist Rock, With Lyrics in Spanish
description: Miguel Mateos Zas and his band were the image of late-1980's rock when they performed Sunday night at the Beacon Theater. Mr. Mateos swung his shoulder-length chestnut hair and romped cheerfully across the stage; his band, in a smoke-machine mist, wore pouts or grins, leather pants and mousse-abused hairdos. The music was strictly mainstream rock in a style triangulated by Sting, Bruce Springsteen and Van Halen - close to Bon Jovi's well-groomed populist pomp. The difference was that Mr. Mateos is from Argentina, and the song lyrics were all in Spanish. Mr. Mateos and Duncan Dhu, a band from Spain, are making what is billed as the first United States tour of ''rock en espanol.''

title: Police Kill a Gunman In Brooklyn Drug Raid
description: One man was killed in a shootout with narcotics detectives in a drug raid yesterday in the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn, the police said.

description: Former Gov. Ed Herschler, a Democrat who was elected for a record three terms, died of cancer Monday at Laramie County Memorial Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Cheyenne.

The company said revenue results reflected a change in method of revenue recognition eliminating marketing fees as a source of revenue as of Nov. 1, 1989, thereby substantially increasing product sales.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15

title: Adamant Journal;   Vermont Co-op Store Struggles to Survive
description: The shelves of the Adamant Co-op are tidy and well-stocked, giving the place an aura of modest prosperity, the boxes of prunes arranged neatly next to the canned vegetables, the coolers full of cheese, soda, eggs from local farms and, of course, beer.

title: Johnson Net Rises 10.3%
description: Johnson & Johnson, the world's largest diversified health-care company, yesterday said its profits rose 10.3 percent in the fourth quarter.

title: Delphi Information Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-Net income

title: Ruth Hall Bleecker, Party Planner, 90
description: Ruth Hall Bleecker, a consultant on planning weddings and parties and founder of the Long Island Junior Dances, died of congestive heart failure on Monday at a nursing home in Woodbury, L.I. She was 90 years old and lived in Laurel Hollow, L.I.

title: A.T.&T. Wins a Rate Increase
description: The State Public Service Commission approved an A.T.&T. rate plan today that will increase the cost of evening long-distance calls by an average of 9 percent. The approval lets the company raise its rates this year but prohibits it from filing for another increase for two years.

title: Hughes Aircraft Sued by Ex-U.S. Official
description: A retired Defense Department official has filed suit against the Hughes Aircraft Company, accusing it of overcharging the Government by more than $70 million. He is seeking at least $210 million in damages for the Government.

title: Kingdom Captures Owens Award Trophy
description: Roger Kingdom, the 1984 and 1988 Olympic 110-meter hurdles champion for the United States, who set the world record of 12.92 seconds in the event last year, was chosen yesterday as the winner of the 1990 Jesse Owens International Trophy Award.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: TERRI LIBERMAN looked only slightly guilty as she allowed a friend to buy her ''the only birthday present I wanted'': a pound of truffles from the Green Mountain Chocolate Company.

title: Plight of Women Prompts Gifts to Neediest
description: A group of Manhattan women who meet regularly to discuss feminist issues recently collected $110 to help destitute women through the The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Moog Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: The Pop Life
description: Music Behind the Action

title: Harmonia Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Per share earnings not applicable; company converted to stock ownership form on Nov. 7, 1989.

title: Surveying a New Playing Field to Conquer
description: When Bo Schembechler left the University of Michigan this winter to become president of the Detroit Tigers, the move surprised many, especially those unfamiliar with the web of connections among the powerful people in the sports community of the state.

title: Pitney Bowes Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included for the quarter a one- time, pretax $110 million charge for transition costs related to a previously reported plan to reduce the company's worldwide workforce by about 1,500 positions over three years, among other things; and also included after-tax income from discontinued operations of $4,450,000, or 6 cents a share. b-The year included income from discontinued operations of $6,609,000, or 9 cents a share, which represents income from Wheeler Group, the direct mail marketer of business supplies, which Pitney Bowes has announced it will sell; and an accounting adjustment gain of $66,048,000, or 83 cents a share. c-Included for the quarter after-tax income from discontinued operations of $4,045,000, or 5 cents a share; the year included income from discontinued operations of $12,960,000, or 16 cents a share, which repreents income from Wheeler Group, the direct mail marketer of business supplies, which Pitney Bowes has announced it will sell. Year-ago periods were restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Instrument Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary tax loss carryforwards of $765,000, or 2 cents a share. c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $894,000 and extraordinary tax loss carryforwards of $140,000. There were no share earnings in year-ago first quarter after preferred dividend requirements.

title: University Bank, National Assoc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Motel 6 L.P.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Previn Steps In to Lead The Boston for Ozawa
description: Because of a recurrence of a bronchial infection, Seiji Ozawa has withdrawn as conductor of the Boston Symphony's concerts tonight and tomorrow night at Carnegie Hall. His replacement will be Andre Previn.

title: Olsten Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings adjusted to reflect the 5-for-4 stock split declared Aug. 2, 1989.

title: Maritime Telegraph reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company purchased a controlling interest in Island Telephone Co. during 1989. As a result, Island Tel's financial results are consoldiated in the 1989 statements, making year-to- year comparisons difficult. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Super No More
description: We can now mothball the word ''superpower.'' The Soviet Union, which used to be one, is unraveling, and the United States, which still talks like one, is becoming irrelevant.

title: Kodak Has Loss, Polaroid a Profit
description: The Eastman Kodak Company yesterday reported a larger-than-expected charge in the fourth quarter from selling operations and laying off employees, resulting in a loss of $60 million. In the fourth quarter of 1988, Kodak had profits of $312 million, or 96 cents a share.

title: Reviews/Music;   Pop With a Dose of Dada
description: They Might Be Giants, a duo consisting of John Flansburgh on guitar and John Linnell on accordion, along with backing tapes that reproduce the sound of a band, has come a long way from playing to a handful of people at minuscule Lower East Side clubs. The band, which performed at the Village Gate on Friday night to a sellout audience, has recently released an album, ''Flood,'' on a major label; the pair's videos regularly punctuate MTV's programming.

title: Los Angeles Votes Year-Round School Schedule
description: Faced with overcrowded schools and an enrollment that continues to grow by 15,000 a year, an angrily divided Los Angeles school board voted Monday night to put all its schools on a year-round schedule despite strong opposition from many parents.

title: He's a Lawyer. He's a Writer. But Can He Type?
description: Four years ago, David E. Kelley did not know how to write a television script; he did not even know how to type one.

title: Summit Savings Assoc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Franco's $7.6 Million Pact Is Richest Ever Given to a Met
description: John Franco agreed to a contract with the Mets yesterday that is the richest one the Mets have ever given a player.

title: Ronald Reagan, Still Hiding
description: ''The buck stops here with me,'' John Poindexter told Congress in 1987, protecting his President on the Iran-contra arms deal. That was incredible but also loyal, permitting Ronald Reagan to hide behind a claim of ignorance of what his White House was doing secretly to help the rebels in Nicaragua.

title: Microwave Cooking
description: AN American staying at the Cipriani hotel in Venice was about to order a drink among the pomegranate trees in the waterfront garden. He saw a glass of bright red juice at a nearby table and ordered the same. When he tasted it his face reacted in astonishment: it was not tomato juice, but blood orange juice.

title: Eating Well
description: LOSING weight would be easier, some people believe, if the dieter didn't have to think about it so much and work at it so hard. In fact, two weight-loss programs are making millions of dollars demonstrating that convenience appeals to millions of dieting Americans.

title: Bicycles, Not Cars, Show True Progress
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. TEAM REPORTS ON NICARAGUA VOTE
description: A United Nations observer mission led by Elliot L. Richardson said today that the election campaign in Nicaragua was generally fair, but it found that some opposition candidates had been intimidated by members of the governing Sandinista party.

title: Bay View Capital Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $235,000 for the quarter and $482,000 for the year. c-After extraordinary charges of $201,000 and $1,119,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $2,404,000.

title: Founder of Covenant House Steps Aside in Church Inquiry
description: The Rev. Bruce Ritter, who built Covenant House into the nation's largest shelter for runaway youths and won a devoted personal following as its president, was directed by his Franciscan superiors yesterday to take a leave of absence pending completion of a church inquiry into an allegation against him of sexual misconduct.

title: Oneita Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Cabarrus Savings Bank reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Cabarrus attributed the decline in earnings to a $355,000 addition in the fourth quarter to its loan reserves for a commercial loan secured by properties in the bank's trade area.

title: Book Notes
description: A Mandela Life

title: New Image Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A City in Pain Hopes for Relief Under Florio
description: When people here talk about the future, they do so in a most guarded manner. ''I wouldn't call it anticipation,'' said the Rev. Michael Doyle, the pastor of the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic parish, who has worked among Camden's poor for 21 years. ''But there's a general feeling that things are going to improve. Or at least that they won't get any worse.''

title: Bengals' Coslet Is Named Jets' Head Coach
description: The search for a new Jet head coach that began on the day after Christmas ended today with the arrival of Bruce Coslet, the architect of the Cincinnati Bengals' high-tech, unnerving no-huddle offense.

title: For the Hostages, Link to a Paris Convict
description: A French newspaper reported today that President Bush had informed President Francois Mitterrand that Iran was linking the freedom of eight American hostages in Lebanon to the release of a man serving a long prison term here.

title: TBC Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Utah's Mitchell to Leave
description: Scott Mitchell, who set 10 National Collegiate Athletic Association records in three years as quarterback at the University of Utah, said yesterday he would enter the National Football League draft in April.

title: How U.S. Can Cut Trade Imbalance With Japan
description: To the Editor:

title: O'Brien Energy Sys reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-Included a charge of $1,355,000 for an accounting change.

title: Systems Center Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain from the cumulative effect of change in method of accounting for income taxes of $639,586, or 8 cents a share. c-Included tax credits of $35,616, or 1 cent a share, and $420,072, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Dexter Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $4,393,000.

title: Peerless Manufacturing reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Upheaval in the East: The Soviet Union;   GORBACHEV GAINS SUPPORT IN RAUCOUS DEBATE ON ROLE OF PARTY, DELEGATES REPORT
description: Communist Party leaders went through a raucous day of debate over their future today, with delegates at the closed-door session reporting a strong majority favoring the end of the party's power monopoly and pointing to the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe as the ultimate object lesson.

title: Initiation in the Art of the Egg
description: IT is a humble ingredient, inexpensive and seemingly not complex to prepare.

title: Scherer Selling A Drug Division
description: The R. P. Scherer Corporation, a maker of gelatin capsules, said it had signed a letter of intent to sell its Paco Pharmaceutical Services Inc. division to an investor group led by Paco's president, Russell R. Haines, and Tullis Cook & Company. The price was about $39 million in cash and debt assumption. Specific terms were withheld.

title: Upheaval in the East;   A Leader Ousted in Siberia
description: The Communist Party leader in the Siberian city of Sverdlovsk has resigned in a growing wave of discontent over regional and local party practices, the newspaper Trud reported today. The resignation of the official, Leonid F. Bobykin, was announced on Monday at a regional meeting of party activists, the newspaper said. He was accused of not acting in the spirit of glasnost.

title: Appeals Court Says Mississippi Colleges Remain Segregated
description: A Federal appeals court ruled today that Mississippi's state-supported universities are insufficiently desegregated, saying that racial imbalances have continued since 1962 when the University of Mississippi was ordered to admit its first black student.

title: Pogorelich Postpones
description: The pianist Ivo Pogorelich has postponed his Feb. 21 Carnegie Hall recital and his Feb. 25 Avery Fisher Hall recital because of illness. He is now scheduled to play at Carnegie Hall on May 7 at 8 P.M., and at Fisher Hall on May 13 at 8:30 P.M. Original tickets may be used. Information: Carnegie Hall, 247-7800; Fisher Hall, 874-2424.

title: G.I.'s Who Fought in Panama Are Counseled to Ease Stress
description: The Army, which has long denied that going into combat can cause long-term psychological stress for some soldiers, is providing counseling to try to avert such problems for troops who recently returned from Panama.

title: Rogers Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Canadian Channel Bans Rap Group
description: The rap group Public Enemy has been banned from Canada's music-videos station because the lyrics of its latest record are considered anti-Semitic.

title: Tanker's Captain Seemed Sober, Pilot Tells Court
description: Except for a trace of liquor on his breath, Capt. Joseph J. Hazelwood appeared sober and in control of the Exxon Valdez an hour before the tanker struck a reef in Prince William Sound last March and began spewing almost 11 million gallons of crude oil, a marine pilot testified today.

title: Washington Post reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included one-time charges related to restructuring activities at Newsweek, and non-recurring gains from the sale of the company's interests in certain cellular telephone operations. Without the non-recurring items, net income in the year-ago fourth quarter would have been $49,593,000, or $3.85 a share. c-Included nonrecurring gains of $103.1 million, or $8.01 a share, from the sale of the company's interest in cellular telephone operations, partially osset by restructuring charges at Newsweek. Excluding these nonrecurring items, net income for 1988 would have been $166,059,000, or $12.90. Year-ago fourth-quarter results included charges of $21,144,000 related to the restructuring activities at Newsweek. The company said it repurchased 389,427 shares of its class B common stock during 1989 which had the effect of increasing earnings per share by 2 cents.

title: Patrick Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-Including an accounting change of $126,000.

title: Jones Medical Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Xyvision Inc.(0) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Year-ago quarter and 9-month results included extraordinary gain of $1,083,000 from repurchase of convertible subordinated debentures.

title: Eastman Kodak reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included pre-tax restructuring charges of $525 million and $875 million for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income The company attributed much of the reduction in 1989 earnings to restructuring costs, which amounted to an aftertax charge of $547 million for the year. The company also blamed higher costs, higher interest expense and an unfavorable impact of currency exchange rate changes for the reduced 1989 results.

title: Selma, Ala., Reinstates Black Schools Chief
description: After racial turmoil forced the closing of two public schools, the Selma Board of Education today reinstated the city's first black school superintendent, whom the board dismissed only last week.

title: Food Notes
description: Love Cookies? Take Heart

title: Books of The Times;   The I.R.S. Labyrinth and the Honest Taxpayer
description: A Law Unto Itself

title: A Catalogue Of the Exotic For Kitchen Or Garden
description: WHEN it comes to vegetables, Shepherd Ogden's opinions are as strong as an Ebeneezer onion. Which is exactly the kind of ordinary, garden variety kind of onion that cannot be found in Mr. Ogden's mail-order seed catalogue for the Cook's Garden.

title: CHRONICLE
description: KITTY DUKAKIS returned home last week after spending about a month at an out-of-state clinic.

title: United Telecommunications eiInc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $368,800,000, or $1.81 a share, and $367,100,000, or $1.80 a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. Share earnings reflected 1989 2-for-1 stock split.

title: Fruit of the Loom reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss on refinanced debt of $5,400,000 for both the quarter and year. The company said included in the year-ago continuing operations of $36,600,000, or 60 cents a share for the quarter and $73,000,000, or $1.19 a share for the year both included tax benefit of $23.4 million from sale of the company's investment in tax benefit leases. This benefit is equal to 38 cents a share on a primary basis and 35 cents a share on a fully-diluted basis.

title: British Air Link With Argentina
description: The chairman of British Airways P.L.C., Lord King, said his airline might take a stake in the Argentine flag carrier Aerolineas Argentinas when it is sold to private investors later this year. Speaking to reporters after an interview with President Carlos Saul Menem, Lord King said: ''We are looking at it as we look at any offer - to see if there is anything in it for us.''

title: Bush Offers Farm Plan, but Without Specific Cuts
description: The Bush Administration today sent Congress a package of recommendations for new farm legislation but did not spell out how farm subsidies should be cut to help meet Federal spending cutbacks next year.

title: OPEC Chief Sees Demand Keeping Prices High
description: Fewer oil shipments from the Soviet Union to Eastern Europe have led to higher demand for oil from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. That should keep world prices above $18 a barrel this year, the head of OPEC said today.

title: Addenda
description: * Ross Roy Group has acquired the public relations firm Anthony M. Franco Inc.

title: Walker's Basket Helps Villanova Edge Boston College
description: Chris Walker's 16-foot jumper broke a 63-63 tie with 56 seconds remaining and lifted Villanova to a 66-65 Big East victory over Boston College tonight. Villanova improved to 13-11 over all and 5-6 in conference play. Boston College fell to 7-14 and 1-10. David Hinton, the game's high scorer with 19 points, had hit four consecutive free throws to give Boston College its last lead, 63-61, with 2:13 to go. But Greg Woodard, whose 14 points shared the scoring lead for Villanova with Walker, tied the game with two foul shots with 1:31 to play.

title: United Vermont Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Foam Container Ban Upheld
description: A judge dismissed a legal challenge today by McDonald's restaurants and others to a ban on food containers made of polystyrene foam in Portland. The law, which took effect Jan. 1, prohibits the use of the packaging by restaurants and food vendors. Circuit Judge Douglas R. Spencer ruled today that the city was within its authority in enacting the ban.

title: Lyphomed Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Magazine's Campaign Aims at Ad Executives
description: The Time Inc. Magazine Company is beginning its new magazine Entertainment Weekly with help from a series of trade-as-consumer advertisements that are unusual because they are aimed at young media planners and buyers who are watching their favorite television programs.

title: Household International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $21,100,000, or 60 cents a share. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $16,500,000, or 48 cents a share for the quarter and $63,000,000, or $1.82 a share for the year.

title: Amax Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $42 million charge as a result of the Chevron Corp.'s exercise in August of its one-time right to receive an additional payment on the 15.2 million Amax common shares that Amax purchased from Chevron in 1988. Also included $19.6 million in revenues for amounts previously collected under a coal supply contract and a charge of $22.2 million to reduce the carrying value of an idled coal mine in Utah for both the quarter and year. c-Included nonrecurring pretax gain of $164 million on the sale of 25 percent interest in two primary aluminum plants for the quarter and year, and the year also included $125 million gain from federal income tax settlement.

title: Morgan Products Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge of $3 million for the restructuring of certain manufacturing operations for the quarter and year. c-Net income

Greenery Rehabilitation Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Hospital Staffing Services reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company said shares outstanding reflects, for the first time, the inclusion of common stock equivalents in the calculation of weighted average shares outstanding.

title: Postscript on Swaggart Affair
description: Debra Murphree, the former prostitute whose liaison with the preacher Jimmy Swaggart rocked an evangelical empire, has signed away three-quarters of the $210,000 that Penthouse magazine paid for her story. Ms. Murphree will receive about $54,000 for the article published in July 1988, said Louis H. Schultz, her lawyer. Agents, lawyers and the Internal Revenue Service will get the rest. Mr. Swaggart confessed to ''moral failure'' and was defrocked.

title: First Amfed Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Per share earnings and shares outstanding are not presented for the year-ago period as it is not considered meaningful resulting from the merger on Oct. 27, 1989 of Fayetteville First Federal Savings and Loan Association in Fayetteville, Tenn.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the killings of young people for the clothing they wore misidentified the city where Detective Kenneth White serves. He is a member of the Gang Crimes South Unit in Chicago, not Los Angeles.

title: Progress Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company said year-ago full- year results included $4 million in increased loan loss provisions.

title: Norton Nelson, 80, Doctor Specializing In the Environment
description: Dr. Norton Nelson, a leader in establishing environmental medicine and a former director of the New York University Institute of Environmental Medicine, died of pneumonia on Sunday at Phelps Memorial Hospital in Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 80 years old and lived in North Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: How To Fight Global Warming
description: Environmentalists and politicians can argue the costs and benefits of international action on global warming from now until doomsday, and they probably will. But nothing will get done without an institutional mechanism to develop, institute and enforce regulations across national boundaries.

title: Plymouth Rubber Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 2
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $209,000, or 12 cents a share, resulting from a tax benefit from tax-loss carryforward. c-Net loss

title: Economic Scene;   Social Security: Paying the Piper
description: FOR most of Washington's movers and shakers, the big question about Social Security is whether there will be enough cash to honor the pension promises made to the giant baby boom generation. For Stephen J. Entin, a Reagan Administration Treasury official now at the Institute for Research on the Economics of Taxation, the big question is whether the promises should have been made in the first place. It was foolish, he argues, to commit trillions of scarce tax dollars to a doubling of future benefits.

title: Aoun's Troops Rout Christian Rivals
description: Army troops loyal to Gen. Michel Aoun routed rival militiamen in a strategic coastal town north of here today, as fierce artillery and rocket fighting also raged in Christian East Beirut.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Cyanamid Co., Wayne, N.J., a biotechnology and chemical company, appointed Charles A. Ruibal president of its industrial and performance products division.

title: Louisiana General Services reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $436,000 from discontinued operations. The year-ago first quarter results were restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Microenergy Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Maxim Integrated Products reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Yeghishe Derderian, 80, Armenian Patriarch
description: Yeghishe Derderian, Armenian patriarch of Jerusalem and spiritual leader of the 8,000 Armenians in Israel, the occupied West Bank and Jordan, died of a heart attack on Thursday, church officials said today. He was 80 years old.

title: First State Financial Services Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The net in the year-ago quarter was enchanced by gains on the sales of securities totaling $423,000, or 13 cents a share.

title: Scientific-Atlanta reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: Latest quarter share earnings included a 17-cents-a-share charge taken to improve the company's currency hedge position.

title: Brown Lifts Officer's Suspension in Slaying
description: Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown yesterday lifted the suspension of a police officer who shot an unarmed 17-year-old youth to death in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn on Jan. 27.

title: Reviews/Music;   Haiti's Compas Rhythms From 2 New York Groups
description: Compas, Haiti's pop music, is a mass of rhythmic complication, in which syncopations are accented and pass for downbeats, and rhythms interlock and repeat, all for the benefit of dancers. Two of the best Haitian groups, Skah Shah and Les Superstars, both based in New York, came to S.O.B.'s on Saturday night, and both jammed the dance floor.

title: American Cyanamid Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said in November 1989, it acquired Praxis Biologics Inc. in a transaction accounted for on a pooling of interests basis. The company's 1988 results have been restated, and 1989 results include the accounts and operations of Praxis. The effect of this is to reduce 1988 full-year net earnings by 25 cents a share and 1989 net earnings by 33 cents a share, while 1988 and 1989 fourth quarter net earnings a share were reduced by 6 cents a share and 10 cents, respectively.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Timeout for Webster
description: Coach Tom Webster of the Los Angeles Kings, former coach of the Rangers, has been ordered to take off two weeks because of an inner-ear problem. He will be replaced by two assistants, Cap Raeder and Rick Wilson.

title: Hard Work As Closing Of Classes Approaches
description: Last August, Katherine R. Stearns came to classes at the Mercer University branch here despite casts on both feet. Another student, Geri S. Brown, quit a part-time job to increase her class load from 15 hours a quarter to 25 hours.

title: Connecticut Energy Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said net income for latest and year-earlier periods included a charge of 10 cents a share for after-tax writedowns of the company's oil and gas operations. Share earnings results reflect the 3-for-2 stock split which was effective in October 1989.

title: About New York;   Comedian Tries To End an Image That Isn't Funny
description: Soon, at movie theaters everywhere, ''The Puerto Rican Mambo'' will not be showing. Shot at a cost of $10,000 and now in final editing, it will turn up at cinemas only if its makers are wildly lucky. So what? ''Never before in the history of cinema has the word Puerto Rican appeared on a marquee,'' declared Luis Caballero, the 38-year-old comedian whose life is depicted in the film.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the election of Barack Obama as president of the Harvard Law Review misidentified the United States court on which Patricia M. Wald is Chief Judge. It is the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, not for the Federal Circuit.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Consul Restaurant Corp., Minneapolis, operator of the Chi's Chi's Mexican restaurant chain, said it would purchase three Esteban's Mexican restaurants in the Minneapolis and St. Paul market.

title: Bradley Measure Gains
description: A measure that would require colleges to disclose the graduation rates of athletes made headway in the Senate yesterday when it was accepted as an amendment to an education bill that is expected to pass today.

title: Mercury Air Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-Included charge of $420,000 from litigation settlement for the quarter and 6 months.

title: Upheaval in the East: Hungary;   Hungary to Recognize Vatican
description: Hungary removed 40-year-old restrictions on the Roman Catholic Church today, and the Vatican announced that it was re-establishing diplomatic relations with Budapest.

title: Joel Fluellen, 81, A Longtime Actor In Films and TV
description: Joel Fluellen, a veteran film and television actor who was also noted for his efforts to end stereotyping of blacks in Hollywood films, was found dead at his home in Los Angeles on Friday. He was 81 years old.

title: Anti-Abortionists' Semantic Scam
description: LEAD: In the wake of significant electoral victories by pro-choice candidates, anti-abortion groups have developed a new strategy to criminalize abortions: Go moderate.

title: C.D.'s, Bank Funds Mixed
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were mixed for the week ended yesterday, as banks showed signs of pulling back on yields.

title: William I. Walsh, 67, Ex-Official of A.&P.
description: William I. Walsh, who rose from stock boy to executive vice president of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company before he left the grocery chain in 1980, died of liver cancer on Monday at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 67 years old and lived in River Vale, N.J.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

Kaypro Founder Asks Son Back to Be Chief
description: LEAD: David Kay is returning to the fold as president and chief executive of the Kaypro Corporation, the computer company founded and run by his father, Andrew Kay.

title: Attack on Israelis Upsets Palestinians in Egypt
description: The Egyptian authorities said today that the men they suspected of killing nine Israelis in a rifle and grenade attack on a tour bus near here on Sunday were Palestinians. That has come as no comfort to a dwindling minority of 40,000 Palestinians whose roots here, once firm, have weakened with time.

title: 3 Airlines in Pact On Reservations
description: Delta Air Lines, Northwest Airlines and Trans World Airlines said they had completed their agreement to form a new company that will own and market a computer reservation system. T.W.A. and Northwest will contribute their Pars system to the joint venture, while Delta will contribute its Datas II system. Delta will also pay $48 million to T.W.A. for an interest of 6 2/3 percent.

title: California Backs New Gas Lines
description: California regulators voted unanimously yesterday to allow three competing proposals for pipelines to transport natural gas from Canada and the Rocky Mountains into the state to move ahead.

title: Tempest Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: The Third Russian Revolution;   And the U.S.S.R.'s Union. And Its Economy.
description: It was as though President Bush had proposed in his State of the Union speech to do away with America's two-party system, federalism and private property. Standing there in Moscow, Mikhail Gorbachev confidently proclaimed to the Central Committee of the Communist Party that the party's monopoly of power had to go. Not only that: central control of the Soviet Union from Moscow had to go. And not only that: state ownership of the means of production had to go.

title: Excerpts From Remarks by Soviet Ambassador

title: Covenant House, Beyond Father Ritter
description: The Rev. Bruce Ritter and Covenant House are virtually synonymous. Father Ritter founded this remarkable home for runaway children in 1968. More than 200,000 kids have gone in and out of its doors. What started in two abandoned tenements in New York City's East Village has become a string of houses and shelters across the country. Some of those kids have stayed only a few nights; some have stayed long enough to save their lives.

description: Some people were thunderstruck. Others were numb, unable to absorb one more remarkable blow to Communism. Many were wary, waiting to see if Mikhail S. Gorbachev could ''stay one step ahead of the sheriff,'' as the conservative columnist Robert Novak put it.

description: The World Health Organization said today that an emergency team has been sent to Romania, where 700 children have been found to be infected with the AIDS virus and 50 others have full-fledged AIDS.

title: Profits Scoreboard
McDonnell Layoffs At Helicopter Unit
description: The McDonnell Douglas Helicopter Company will lay off more than 10 percent of its employees by Feb. 23 because of reduced military spending by the Government, the company's president, William P. Brown, announced. The move will involve about 400 workers each at the company's base plant here and at the California Manufacturing Center in Culver City, Calif. The company employs 5,900 in Mesa and 1,650 in Culver City.

title: U.S. Is Given More Time on Noriega Evidence
description: A Federal magistrate today rejected a motion by a lawyer for Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega that would have compelled Government prosecutors to provide ''forthwith,'' instead of in the next week or so, a complete inventory of evidence seized by American troops at homes and offices of the deposed Panamanian military leader.

title: Jimmy Van Heusen Is Dead at 77; Prolific Composer of Pop Songs
description: Jimmy Van Heusen, who composed the music for ''Moonlight Becomes You,'' ''Sunday, Monday or Always,'' ''Call Me Irresponsible'' and ''All the Way,'' among many other popular ballads, died yesterday at his home in Rancho Mirage, Calif., after a long illness. He was 77 years old.

title: Review/Dance;   The Trocks Are Back, Playing With Conventions

If there had been a laugh meter anywhere in the theater, it would have gone into orbit at this opening-night benefit for the Gay Men's Health Crisis.

The plan renews the company's commitment to a small but loyal group of diesel car buyers in this country. The 300D, introduced for sale this week, sells for $39,700, the company said. The 350SDL, which will make its debut in May, has a larger engine and will cost $56,800.

title: Manila Caution to Banks
description: The Philippine Finance Secretary today warned overseas banks that refused to lend more money to the heavily indebted country that their actions could affect future business with Manila. ''The Philippines cannot be taken for granted, and those who are going to support us will be treated very favorably,'' the Finance Secretary, Jesus Estanislao, said. He said that most Japanese banks had been very supportive, adding that certain American banks he did not identify were not ''coming in to support the Philippine package'' seeking to raise $1 billion from commercial banks.

title: At 80, Jessica Tandy May Add an Oscar To Her Three Tonys
description: For the very first time in an acting career that began when she was a teen-ager, there is talk of an Academy Award for Jessica Tandy. ''It's lovely,'' the 80-year-old star of ''Driving Miss Daisy'' said the other day, her attentive, ascetic face suddenly lighting up in a girlish smile. ''This is by far the best movie role I ever had.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''What should I stand here and wait for? You think this pluralism is going to be somehow visible today, or tomorrow, or any time soon? You think this is Eastern Europe? I can tell you, it is not.''

A spokesman for the bureau said it would develop a regional sales development team, modeled on its national sales development team, to try to draw more advertising to broadcast television.

title: Margin Is Deceiving, but Rangers Stay on Roll

title: A Freudian Dream Come True
description: A square in Pribor that once honored Stalin is to be renamed after the Czechoslovak town's most famous son, Sigmund Freud. The state press agency said an opinion poll in the north Moravian town showed most of its inhabitants wanted Stalin Square to be named after the founder of psychoanalysis. Freud, born in Pribor in 1856, moved to Vienna where he pioneered analysis of the subconscious mind. He fled when Hitler annexed Austria in 1938. He died in London in 1939.

description: A 20-member Congressional group named by President Bush to observe the elections in Nicaragua this month was disbanded after members were denied visas by Managua's leftist government, Senator Richard G. Lugar said today.

title: Maintaining Waxed Pine's Healthy Glow
description: LEAD: A quarter of a century has gone by since the start of the waxed-pine furniture invasion from Europe. It is still going on, but the pickings are getting poorer - not necessarily in quality, but in numbers. America has also discovered plenty of its own stripped pine, which may be superior to anything being imported, if not always the particular pieces people prefer: wardrobes, cupboards, dressers and long so-called kitchen tables.

title: Good Design, Good Prices Uptown
description: THEY look like 21 individual brick houses along Manhattan Avenue and 104th and 105th Streets, but they are actually a single building of 74 condominium apartments. The building, Manhattan Valley Townhouses, was finished last year. It was intended for families of moderate income, defined as those with about $30,000 gross income for a family of four.

title: Oregon Governor Won't Run
description: Gov. Neil Goldschmidt announced today that he would not run this year for a second term. The Governor, a 49-year-old Democrat, said that he and his wife of 25 years, Margie, had agreed to separate and that as a result, ''it's certainly no time to be running for governor.'' The Goldschmidts have two children.

title: Baker Cautions Soviets On Bidding Over Troops
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that he would not be surprised if the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, proposed to cut American and Soviet troop levels in Europe to even deeper levels than those suggested last week by President Bush.

title: Edward Ehre, Teacher And Editor, Dies at 84
description: Edward Ehre, a high school English teacher who parlayed his devotion to sports into a separate career as an editor of a popular series of annual anthologies of distinguished sports writing, died on Tuesday at the Beneva Nursing Pavilion in Sarasota, Fla. He was 84 years old and had been suffering from Alzheimer's disease.

title: Review/Pop;   Up From New Orleans, The Reunited Meters
description: The Meters brought the jubilation of countless perfectly placed offbeats to Tramps on Tuesday, when the reunited band opened a three-night stand. Three of the original Meters -Art Neville on keyboards, Leo Nocentelli on guitar and George Porter on bass - are working with a young drummer, Russell Batiste, who carries on the style of Joseph (Zigaboo) Modeliste, the Meters' original drummer, now retired.

The spectacle becomes even sadder when one realizes that all the glitz in the world would still fail to breathe dramatic life into the project. Such a show is ''The Fabulous La Fontaine,'' Owen S. Rackleff's celebration, at the Riverwest Theater, of the life and times of the 17th-century French fabulist Jean de La Fontaine.

title: Costs Can Go Downhill If Skiers Are Flexible

title: Court Upholds 'Pill' But Chides DeSoto
description: A Delaware court on Tuesday upheld DeSoto Inc.'s ''poison pill'' takeover defense but chided the company's directors for failing to seek the best value for shareholders. The court ruled that DeSoto, a paint and chemical maker based in Des Plaines, Ill., had not taken steps necessary to assure maximum shareholder value after rejecting a $50-a-share offer in November, worth $300 million in all, from the Sutton Holding Corporation.

description: Saying the proposed merger between the San Diego Gas and Electric Company and the Southern California Edison Company was not in the public interest, Attorney General John Van de Kamp of California announced that his office would try to block the merger. Mr. Van de Kamp cited five reasons for opposing the merger, including contentions it would violate antitrust laws, thwart public regulation by creating a large and powerful utility and deprive the San Diego region of local control over its energy destiny.

description: The commander of NATO forces in Europe told Congress today that he had recommended against President Bush's proposal to cut American and Soviet troops in central Europe to 195,000, but had been later persuaded that such a cut was acceptable.

title: The Third Russian Revolution;   Transforming the Communist Party.
description: It's hard to overstate the significance of yesterday's epochal votes in Moscow. This is truly a third Russian Revolution. The first overthrew the Czar in February 1917. Nine months later, Lenin's Bolsheviks ousted an interim democratic regime and imposed a dictatorship of the Communist Party. Now, heeding a bold appeal by an embattled Mikhail Gorbachev, the Central Committee of the Soviet Communist Party has voted to do what no one thought it would ever do: abandon its constitutional monopoly on power.

title: Speeding Car Kills Boy Near Brooklyn School
description: A speeding car ran a red light in Brooklyn yesterday, glanced off a city bus and plowed into three pedestrians, killing a boy on his way to school and critically injuring two other people, the police said.

description: Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger asked Congress today to take a more tolerant view of China, saying it was ''less completely evil'' than it seemed in June, when the Chinese Army crushed the democracy movement in Beijing.

Macchiarola, took over as acting president of Covenant House yesterday, at least until investigations of the Rev. Bruce Ritter, founder of the nation's largest shelter for runaway children, are complete.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 12 about the authorship of an article that appeared in the quarterly Daedalus under the pseudonym Z referred incorrectly to Marx's essay ''The 18th Brumaire of Louis Napoleon Bonaparte.'' The title of the essay is the date in the French Revolutionary calendar on which Napoleon seized power in France in 1799, not the date in 1851 when his nephew Louis Napoleon Bonaparte overthrew the Second French Republic. Marx was using the former as a sarcastic allusion to the latter.

title: Turnaround Specialist Sees Test at Shoemaker
description: In business, it is good to have strong financial backing. And that is what John S. Thorbeck has in his unlikely bid to take an old shoe company and put it on a new footing.

Over E.P.A. Protest, White House Alters Wetland Agreement
description: Over the objections of the Bush Administration's chief environmental official, the White House today altered a Federal agreement to protect the nation's wetlands.

description: b-Net loss

Andre Gaillard, 37, Chef at La Reserve For Almost 5 Years
description: Andre Gaillard, a former chef of La Reserve, a French restaurant at 4 West 49th Street, died of a gunshot wound on Tuesday at his home in Creskill, N.J. He was 37 years old.

title: Arthur J. Barry, 80, Chemical Researcher
description: Arthur J. Barry, a chemical researcher who had an important role in the development of silicon products, died of heart disease on Saturday. He was 80 years old and lived in Tucson.

title: Desert Raid: A Rare Effect
description: When gunmen killed nine Israelis on a bus in the desert east of Cairo three days ago, their assault revived one of this region's cruelest realities: In the lexicon of extremism, talk of peace between Arab and Jew translates almost automatically into violence and terror by its adversaries.

title: Illinois Power Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-After a credit of $34,012,000, or 48 cents a share, from the cumulative effect on prior periods of an accounting change. Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the year-ago quarter--therefore no share earnings.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Magazines Placed In Hearst Home Group
description: To make its home-design magazines more attractive to advertisers, Hearst Magazines has pulled them together into the Hearst Home Group. Hearst named David J. Moore director of corporate advertising sales for the group, which comprises House Beautiful and House Beautiful Specials, Country Living, Colonial Homes, Victoria, American Home and Countryside.

title: Chinese Press Is Silent on Gorbachev Plans to End Party Monopoly
description: Chinese readers discovered today that a Soviet organization had awarded a medal to a famous Chinese writer for fostering cultural relations, but they did not learn a word about President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's plan to abolish the Communist Party's monopoly on power in the Soviet Union.

title: New York City Charges Fraud by Exxon in Spill
description: New York City yesterday accused the Exxon Corporation of filing reports for years that falsely indicated that the company's leak-detection system in the Arthur Kill was in good working order.

title: Metro Matters;   An Oasis of Hope Amid Despair Mourns Today
description: ''This,'' Ned O'Gorman said, hugging Kyle Baxter, ''is one of my best friends in the world.''

title: Killer Whale a Write-Down
description: Shamu, the killer whale that appears in advertisments for the Sea World aquarium parks, is only mortal, its new owner has concluded.

title: Diagnostic-Retrieval Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said share earnings results are class A and B common stock.

title: Tellabs Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-Included post-tax investment writeoff of $2,665,000.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Jan. 26 about automobile safety gave an incomplete list of the Japanese cars equipped with air bags as standard equipment. Besides Toyota's Lexus, Nissan's Infiniti and Honda's Acura Legend, the 1990 Toyota Supra and Celica models have air bags as standard equipment.

title: Consolidated HCI reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Polishing Image, Principal Bans Gold Teeth
description: A Brooklyn high school principal has banned decorative gold caps for teeth because he believes they do not convey the serious image his students need to be successful in the business world.

title: Colonial Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago fourth quarter included a pretax charge of $1,800,000 and the 1988 full year results included a pretax charge of $2,550,000.

title: Drug for Babies' Seizures Is Found Ineffective and Perhaps Harmful
description: A drug that is being taken for long periods by tens of thousands of infants and young children to prevent convulsions is ineffective and inhibits intellectual performance, at least temporarily, researchers have found.

title: Swedish Electricity Plan
description: Sweden will have to pay up to $670 million a year in extra costs if it scraps two nuclear power reactors as scheduled in 1995 and 1996, the state electricity board said last week. In addition, companies that consume large amounts of electricity would face higher charges and some might go out of business, the board said in a report. Under a timetable set by Parliament in 1988, Sweden is scheduled to take 2 of its 12 nuclear reactors out of commission in 1995 and 1996.

title: Hewlett-Oki Deal
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company and the Oki Electric Industry Company of Tokyo agreed to build and operate jointly a printed circuit board manufacturing plant in Aguadilla, P.R. The partners will jointly invest $40 million in building the plant, 50 percent of which will be owned by each company. Hewlett-Packard will use its portion of the boards in computer products made in Puerto Rico, while Oki will sell its portion on the open market.

title: Greyhound Canada reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a non-recurring loss of $900,000 from a pending property sale. c-Included special gain of $600,000. The company said 1989 net income was reduced by $233,000 due to the effect of two property sales. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Too Cool on Global Warming
description: Tugged by conflicting views from his advisers, President Bush gave a studiously tepid speech to the meeting in Washington this week on global climate change. The conflict represents a serious debate, within and outside the Administration, about the seriousness of the feared warming of the world's climate by pollutant gases. But Mr. Bush was needlessly vacuous, reflecting his Administration's lack of a greenhouse game plan.

title: Abiomed Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
Valcom Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
Midwinter Songs: Shapely Shrubs, Vivid Hues
description: LAST Friday was Ground Hog Day, and the ''Good Morning, America'' people got a bit confused. On that overcast morning in most of the northeastern United States, I heard with my first cup of coffee that if Punxsutawney Phil saw his shadow we would suffer six more weeks of winter. I was just starting to sip my second when I heard the contradictory intelligence that we were in for more bad weather if this mythical rodent did not see his shadow.

title: SOVIET LEADERS AGREE TO SURRENDER COMMUNIST PARTY MONOPOLY ON POWER
description: The Communist Party leadership agreed today to surrender its historic monopoly of power in the Soviet Union and accept a program that recommends the creation of a Western-style presidency and Cabinet system of government.

title: U.S., Model for Eastern Europe?
description: LEAD: Can Soviet and other Eastern European leaders, both newly institutional and on the cobblestones, learn anything from us as they reform their political systems? Yes, two great lessons, both from our founding period.

title: TOURISM MINISTER IN ROMANIA RESIGNS
description: The Tourism Minister resigned today, accusing the Council of National Salvation of ''dictatorial methods'' reminiscent of the previous Communist Government.

title: American Maize-Products reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $11,980,000 for the quarter and $15,636,000 for the year. The year's loss is related to LLoyd Home & Building Centers Inc., including expected losses through disposition. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,812,000 and $9,333,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said the full year 1989 results included a nonrecurring charge of $3,041,000 related principally to taxes provided on the redemption of the company's 7 1/2 percent exchangeable debentures during the third quarter.

title: Critic's Notebook;   The Writers Who Shook a Government
description: When Vaclav Havel accepted a prize from the German Booksellers Association in October, he spoke of ''the virtually constitutive power of words,'' ''the power of words to change history.''

title: Son Succeeds Father As Comcast President
description: Brian Roberts yesterday was named president of the Comcast Corporation, the nation's fourth-largest cable operator, with 2.5 million subscribers.

title: Georgetown Moves Into First, Defeating Pitt by 97-81
description: Georgetown moved into first place in the Big East Conference tonight with a 97-81 victory over Pittsburgh.

title: The Finish Line Is Finally in Sight
description: Recent efforts to affect the outcome of the final court hearing on who should have the America's Cup have taken on the trappings of a divisive political campaign, embittering sailors who would like to see the matter settled once and for all.

title: Conde Nast Challenges A Vanity Fair Lookalike
description: A sharp dispute has erupted between Conde Nast Publications Inc. and Leonardo Mondadori, the Italian publisher, over the appearance in Italy of a magazine that strongly resembles Vanity Fair, just as Conde Nast is preparing to start an Italian edition of its monthly.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Accounts
description: * Marriott Corp., to Eisner & Associates, Baltimore, for its Fairfield Inn division, with a budget of $4 million.

description: b-Included a charge of approximately $3,600,000 from restructuring. c-Net loss

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Addenda
description: * Porter/Novelli, a member of the Omnicom Group's network of public relations firms, has acquired Events Alive Inc., Chicago, a public relations and special events marketing agency.

title: U.S. Revises Definition Of High-Leverage Loan
description: Federal banking regulators announced new definitions yesterday for bank loans that should be considered as ''highly leveraged transactions'' that must be disclosed in banks' annual reports to shareholders.

title: Natec Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago figures are not comparable; the company was formed in October 1989. All of the company's 1989 revenues were recorded in the fourth quarter; Natec is in a transition from a developmental company to an operating company.

title: Drug Is Said to Cut Risk in Colon Cancer
description: A drug originally developed to eliminate worms in cattle has been found to reduce the risk of death from advanced colon cancer by one-third when used in combination with an established anti-cancer medication, researchers say.

title: Franklin Computer reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: CLOSE TO HOME
description: I HAVE read the warnings and I do what I'm told. My keys are in the pocket of my coat; my wallet is in the pocket of my dress, and only my cosmetics, checkbook, pen, handkerchief and change purse are in my bag. That way, smart money says, I cut my losses. That I will be mugged someday, smart money says, is an inevitability.

title: Hydraulic Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 12
description: Latest fourth quarter's share earnings included gain of 98 cents a share on sale of land and charge of 43 cents a share related primarily to certain non-regulated investments and to legal expenses.

title: Fake Coins Embarrass The Japanese
description: Acutely embarrassed officials at the Bank of Japan and the Ministry of Finance acknowledged today that Japan's vaults hold at least $71 million in gold coins that no one - not even the central bank that minted the originals - had recognized as counterfeit until recently.

title: Reagan Court Filing Clarifies Claim of Executive Privilege
description: Clarifying an earlier court filing, lawyers for Ronald Reagan said today that they were invoking executive privilege in refusing to turn over excerpts from the former President's private diaries to John M. Poindexter, the former national security adviser who faces trial in the Iran-contra affair.

title: Critic's Notebook;   Network News and the Push To Do Less and Do It Worse
description: ''Network News: Getting Better? Getting Worse?'' The question was addressed recently at the annual duPont-Columbia University conference on broadcast journalism. The answer from the panelists, who represented many years of association with the three major commercial networks, was yes and no. But the discussion, carried by C-Span last weekend, did help to explain why some of the deliverers of the news are uneasy.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Jan. 26 about Anna Arnold Hedgeman, a civil rights advocate and former mayoral aide, misidentified the New York City mayoral candidate on whose ticket she ran in 1965. He was Representative William Fitts Ryan.

title: Head of Liberal Party in Canada to Resign
description: The leader of Canada's Liberal Party announced today that he was resigning as head of the official opposition to return to a private law practice.

title: Chronicle
description: The Ford family feud heated up when KATHLEEN DuROSS FORD lost a round in her the fight with between her and her stepchildren over the fortune of her late husband, Henry Ford 2d. In Florida on Tuesday, JUDGE VAUGHN J. RUDNICK of Palm Beach County Circuit Court ruled that SHERWIN P. SIMMONS, a Tampa tax lawyer, should not be removed from his job as counsel to the $350 million trust established in Mr. Ford's will.

title: Teaching Children Self-Protection
description: IT was 4 o'clock on a Friday afternoon, normally a time for doing homework, playing basketball or practicing the piano. But for one group of 8-year-olds in New York City, it was time to learn about kidnappers.

title: Grace Energy Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income of $13,311,000 from cumulative effect of change in accounting for income taxes. The company said the year-ago quarter, latest year and prior year period's share earnings are calculated on a pro forma basis to reflect operating results as if the company's August 1989 initial public offering had been completed on Jan. 1, 1988 and to exclude the cumulative effect of the change in accounting for income taxes for 1988. Pro forma net income for the latest year was $23,617,000 and for the previous year, $19,866,000. The year-ago fourth quarter's pro forma net was $3,764,000.

description: The Ashton-Tate Company reported losses for the quarter and for the year ended Dec. 31, as its revenues declined. The Torrance, Calif., computer software company still lags in shipping the improved versions of its core dBase IV program.

title: Bank Tests Its Formula in Texas
description: When John B. McCoy, chairman of the Banc One Corporation, Columbus, Ohio, talks about himself, he is apt to make self-effacing comments about how he has never (''well, hardly ever'') made a loan and how he was slow to see the opportunities of expanding into Texas.

description: The Convex Computer Corporation, a maker of mini-supercomputers, said yesterday that net income rose 81.8 percent in the fourth quarter, to $4 million, or 21 cents a share, compared with $2.2 million, or 12 cents a share, in the similar period a year ago.

description: b-Included net losses of $8.3 million on asset sales and $13.8 million in lease and well impairments. c-Net income

title: A Vote to Save View of California Landmark
description: Bowing to protests, the county has backed away from a plan to build a box-like jail that would have blocked a view of the only government building erected according to a design by Frank Lloyd Wright.

title: Right-to-Die Group Is Shaken as Leader Leaves His Cancer-Stricken Wife
description: Derek Humphry gained fame when he helped his first wife commit suicide to end her agony from terminal breast cancer at the age of 42.

title: Jury Acquits 3 Accused In Gene Gotti Drug Case
description: A Federal jury in Brooklyn yesterday acquitted three men charged with conspiracy to distribute large amounts of heroin through a drug ring headed by Gene Gotti, who was convicted on related charges last year.

description: The company said results for 1989 reflect reorganization Feb. 2, 1989; results for 1988 were not restated.

description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: South Africa Democrats Seek a New Relevance
description: South Africa's Democratic Party is reappraising its role as the voice of liberal opposition in white politics, given the changes undertaken by President F. W. de Klerk in his speech to Parliament last week.

description: Share earnings are in units.

Where to Find It;   New Twist for Tables: Custom China
description: ''MORE and more people want china that is unusual,'' said Clelia Zacharias, who started her own custom porcelain business a year ago. ''They just don't want the same thing everyone else has.'' An interior designer, Mrs. Zacharias helps to design the plates and then sends sketches to Angelique DeFolin, a Parisian artist who paints the porcelain.

title: Mantels Worthy of a Spot on a Mantel
description: JOHN BRYAN of Pownal, Me., calls himself an artist in wood. For the last four years, the former furniture maker has been designing and carving realistic and intricate motifs out of cherry or pine for fireplace mantels - the kind that used to frame elegant fireplaces in the late 18th and early 19th centuries.

title: Review/Dance;   Paired Stravinskys as a City Ballet Main Course
description: The New York City Ballet's program on Tuesday night was the equivalent of a fine meal. George Balanchine's light ''Donizetti Variations'' was the appetizer while the meaty entree consisted of his paired Stravinsky ballets ''Monumentum pro Gesualdo'' and ''Movements for Piano and Orchestra.''

title: How Steele's Garden Visions Grew
description: For 60 years, Fletcher Steele, one of America's premier landscape architects, created more than 700 gardens. About 100 photographs and drawings of his work continue to be on view through March 30 at the Paine Webber Art Gallery, 1285 Avenue of the Americas, at 51st Street, in Manhattan.

title: Alberta Natural Gas reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary charges which included expenses from the Erythromycin facility in California since its closing in the first quarter and a writedown of the investment in International Permeation Inc. of $3,266,000 for the latest year and $12,514,000 for the year-earlier period. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: John A. Reuling, Church Executive, 83
description: John A. Reuling, a retired missionary and executive with the overseas mission of the United Church of Christ, died of complications from Alzheimer's disease on Monday at a nursing home in Port Huron, Mich. He was 83 years old and had lived in Tenafly, N.J.

title: Some Influential Voices Urge Simpler Tax Code
description: The Bush Administration's top tax officials and the most influential Congressman on tax policy agreed today that aspects of the tax law are too complicated and need to be simplified.

title: Tougher Enforcing of Child Labor Laws Is Vowed
description: In the face of record levels of child labor law violations, Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole today promised ''immediate action to step up enforcement'' of the laws, larger penalties for violations and a review of all regulations governing children who work.

title: Key Production Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: REPAINTING can be a simple way to brighten a room. But to minimize the potential for creating a mess instead, it is important to choose appropriate materials, tools and equipment and to work in an orderly fashion. Latex-based paint is the most popular and the easiest to use. Because the paint is soluble in water, drying takes only about an hour and cleanup can be done with soap and water.

description: The Government of Yugoslavia, which had carefully avoided intervening in the ethnic conflicts in north and south, has moved to involve itself in a crisis that is stirring deep fears about the country's unity.

description: b-Net loss

title: The View From the West
description: In Washington, there was muted wonder at the Soviet Communist Party's actions, and anticipation over President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's next move, while academic experts were divided on the significance of the events in Moscow. Page A11.

title: 12 Die in Raid in Mozambique
description: Rebels attacked a truck belonging to the Government's relief agency, killing the driver and 11 people riding in the back, a Government-run newspaper reported today.

title: Money-Fund Yields Mixed
description: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the week that ended yesterday, as tax-exempt funds increased slightly and taxable ones slipped.

title: Market Place;   Bailout Agency Has Become Big Player in 'Junk Bonds'
description: Wall Street dealers and investors are bracing nervously for the sale by Federal regulators of large amounts of ''junk bonds.'' With the seizure of the Centrust Savings Bank in Miami last week, the Federal agency responsible for selling the assets of ailing savings institutions now controls a portfolio of high-yield, high-risk junk bonds worth almost $2 billion, analysts estimate.

title: Norton Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary tax loss carryforwards of $13.9 million, or 66 cents a share, for the quarter and $19.3 million, or 92 cents a share, for the year. c-After extraordinary tax loss carryforwards of $3.1 million, or 14 cents a share, for the quarter and $12 million, or 57 cents a share, for the year. The latest periods' income before items included income of $800,000 for the quarter and $9.8 million, or 47 cents a share, for the year, from the Eastman Christensen Co., a discontinued operation. Year-ago periods' income before items included income from Eastman Christensen of $1.9 million for the quarter and $8 million, or 38 cents a share, for the year.

title: Badger Meter Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Talks on a Joint Korean Team for Games Fail
description: Talks between North and South Korean sports officials aimed at fielding a joint team for the 1990 Asian Games collapsed today, with South Korea reportedly fearing a trap that would prevent it from using the Beijing Games to improve relations with China.

title: Bonn Panel to Plan for Common Currency With East
description: The West German Government established a ''German unity'' committee today, charged with creating a blueprint for monetary union to rescue East Germany from economic disaster and preparing detailed plans for political reunification of the two German states.

title: Hsi Fan Hsu, 84, Dies; An Expert on Parasites
description: Dr. Hsi Fan Hsu, a parasitologist who was emeritus professor of preventive medicine at the University of Iowa College of Medicine, died of heart disease on Friday. He was 84 years old and lived in Iowa City.
