description: b-Included a $44 million gain on the sale of storage gas inventory; an $8 million gain for a customer settlement; a $13.2 million charge for a reserve for environmental cleanup costs, and a $14.9 million writedown for its Canadian and gas properties.

title: Times Mirror Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge related to a provision on the expected sale of newspaper press equipment of 6 cents a share. The company said that, excluding net gains of 5 cents a share in 1989 and 31 cents a share in 1988, earnings for 1989 would have been $2.25 a share, down 1 percent from $2.27 a share in 1988. The 1989 gains came from the sale of Timberlands, partly offset by a fourth-quarter loss provision on the expected sale of newspaper press equipment. Gains in 1988 resulted from the sale of Timberlands and other assets.

description: Share earnings are restated to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split in December.

title: Lauren's Wink at the Wild Side
description: RALPH LAUREN has never been to Africa. ''Sometimes it's better if you haven't been there,'' he said.

title: Nat Wartels, 88, the Chairman Of the Crown Publishing Empire
description: Nat Wartels, who built the Crown publishing empire and then sold it to Random House in 1988, died of pneumonia yesterday at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: A Victory for a Faction Silenced 70 Years Ago
description: On a visit to the United States in 1959, the Soviet party leader, Nikita S. Khrushchev, was asked about the Mensheviks, the minority faction of Russian revolutionaries who broke with Lenin largely because they thought the new order they were plotting should countenance other parties and some democratic dissent.

Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the downgrading of debt ratings on three Japanese banks misstated their size rankings. The Mitsubishi Trust and Banking Corporation is the world's 19th-largest banking company; the Sumitomo Trust and Banking Company is the 21st-largest, and the Mitsui Trust and Banking Company is the 23d-largest.

description: In a continuation of the management shake-up at Apple Computer Inc., Jean-Louis Gassee, the company's chief of product development, is expected to resign, computer industry officials said today.

description: ONCE denigrated as useful but unglamorous substitutes for natural materials, plastics are now design elements for which in many cases there is no substitute.

O'Neill's Budget Proposes Job Cuts and Borrowing
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill proposed a stringent state budget today that would eliminate 2,000 jobs and borrow against reserve funds, but would not raise taxes.

title: Lebanese Investor Gets Sikes Stake
description: Nicolas T. Gargour, a Lebanese investor with interests in Luxembourg, France and Panama, has acquired the equivalent of a 5.37 percent stake of the Sikes Corporation's class A shares. He said he might seek control of the Lakeland, Fla., ceramic tile concern. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Gargour said that he had signed a confidentiality agreement in order to examine Sikes's financial data.

title: Imasco Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-After an extraordinary loss of $110 million for the quarter and year. The latest periods' revenues excluded the revenues of company- owned Howie's Drug Stores that have been converted to Shoppers Drug Mart and the revenues of 325 drug stores sold. The results are in Canadian funds. The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: Talking Deals;   U.S. Acquisitions Surge in Europe
description: FROM Peter V. Ueberroth, the former baseball commissioner who bought Adidas, to United Parcel Service, which purchased parcel delivery services in seven countries, Americans were buying in Europe last year and buying more than ever.

title: Irish Leader to Visit Bush
description: Irish Prime Minister Charles Haughey, current president of the European Community, will fly to Washington for talks with President Bush on Feb. 27, a Government spokesman said today. Ireland currently holds the rotating presidency of the 12-nation European Community, and Prime Minister Haughey says his country can play an important role in European-American relations.

description: Latest year results included $2.6 million charge for restructuring of U.S. operations, a $448,000 benefit for restructuring a joint venture in Japan, and a $1.1 million expense related to settlement of a proxy contest. description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $129,775. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Tarpley Case Delayed
description: Attorneys for the Dallas Maverick forward Roy Tarpley won another battle yesterday to keep the player out of criminal court and on the basketball court.

title: Soviets Ask Czechs To Extend the Time To Pull Out Troops
description: The Soviet Union told Czechoslovakia today that it needed more time to withdraw the 75,000 Soviet troops in that country, East European diplomats said.

title: Envoy Besieged in Spying Inquiry Is Called Security Risk and Ousted
description: Felix S. Bloch, the American diplomat who came under intense Federal investigation last year when officials said he was photographed with a Soviet spy, was told today that he was being dismissed because he is a national security risk, the State Department said.

title: Notebook;   Balanced Race in Patrick Division
description: As the National Hockey League season finishes its third quarter and approaches the home stretch, its most closely contested pennant race is in the Patrick Division, where the most interesting club in that six-team group is the first-place Islanders.

title: Ohio Edison Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-Reflected a $128 million writeoff related to certain construction costs of nuclear units for the quarter and year.

title: SmithKline Lags On Cosmetics Sale
description: The sale of the cosmetics operations units of the British-American pharmaceutical company SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. ''is not going as well as we wished,'' Robert Bauman, chief executive of the company, said in Tokyo, where it is starting a Japanese unit. There are fewer buyers than expected, partly because of the overall softness of the market, and some of the prices will probably be lower than original estimates, he said.

title: Nekoosa Extension
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation, still battling to acquire the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation, extended its $3.8 billion tender offer another two weeks. The $63-a-share bid for the Norwalk, Conn., paper products company will expire on Feb. 21. The previous extension of the offer, first made Oct. 31, expired Monday. A special meeting of Nekoosa shareholders to consider the buyout offer is scheduled for March 2.

title: Sanyo Plans TV Center
description: The Sanyo Electric Company will set up a high-definition television research and development center at its Spanish subsidiary, Sanyo Espana S.A., by the third quarter of this year, a company spokesman said today. The Barcelona research center will develop a system matched to the European standard for HDTV.

title: Washington at Work;   Amiable Idea Merchant Who Is Viewed as the Most-Feared Japan-Basher
description: Enter Pat Choate's cinnabar-colored Victorian townhouse on Capitol Hill, and you are walking into the Orient. Utamaro woodblocks and a 17th-century painted screen line the gallery of the spare living room. A six-foot-square calligraphy on hammered silver frames the dining room table. A mural of Hokusai's ''Mount Fuji at Dawn'' graces the viewing area of the Japanese rock garden in the backyard.

title: Books of The Times;   Changes in the Stream of Time and Space
description: The Farther Shore

title: Shooting for a Scoring Title
description: Robert Phelps remembers last year's New York State Federation basketball championships very well. He was there to help Nazareth High School of Brooklyn win the Class B title, but he also had another job to do.

title: For Citibank Official, An End and a Beginning
description: For William R. Rhodes of Citibank, yesterday was an end and a beginning. At the Pierre Hotel in Manhattan yesterday, he joined officials from Mexico to sign an agreement to lower Mexico's $48.5 billion in debt with the more than 460 banks involved, winding up almost a year of tough negotiations that he led as co-chairman of the commerical bank advisory committee.

title: Helmerich & Payne reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included gains of $7,904,000, or 32 cents a share, and $155,000, or 1 cent a share, for the latest quarter and year- earlier period, respectively, from the sale or exchange of securities held as investments.

title: Disnat Investment reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Hallmark Aid to Univision
description: Hallmark Cards Inc. began an offer on Tuesday to buy back at a discount some $270 million in debt securities used to finance Univision Holdings Inc., under a plan to ease the debt burden on the unprofitable Spanish-language broadcaster.

title: Baby Costs Plenty
description: To the Editor:

title: American Restaurant Parters reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Officers Shifted At Kinder-Care
description: Kinder-Care Learning Centers Inc., the leading child-care company, announced a change this week in the top officers of the company, with the largest shareholder taking the corporate reins.

title: Skepticism in the Street And No Excited Crowd
description: On the day the Communist Party's leaders voted with near unanimity to forswear the political monopoly their party has held for more than 70 years, Red Square was void of anxious, interested citizens waiting for a sign of democracy to rise from behind the towering brick walls of the Kremlin.

title: Laotian Royal Family Died in Prison Camp
description: To the Editor:

title: Campeau Trustee Forms Creditors' Panels
description: Committees representing bondholders that hold much of the debt of the retailing operations of the Campeau Corporation were appointed yesterday by the United States Trustee overseeing the stores' bankruptcy proceedings.

title: A Gallimard Move Disclosed
description: Christian Gallimard, one-time heir-apparent of a French publishing dynasty, is trying to settle a family feud, his sister said today.

title: Geonex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Giuliani Is Sending Signals He Won't Run for Governor
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani is sending strong signals that he will not be a Republican candidate for governor this year, even though he has started a traditional campaign warm-up: a series of speaking engagements throughout New York State.

title: Reviews/Theater;   A Cool Medea Lashes Back At the Man Who Jilted Her
description: Among the classic Greek tragedies, Euripides' ''Medea'' probably strikes the brightest sparks in contemporary imaginations. Its story of a woman who lashes back at the man who betrayed her after she had saved his life and engineered his ascent to power is one of the most potent revenge fantasies of all time. And in today's fractious marital climate of child custody battles and warring sexual ideologies, it touches several nerves at once.

title: Golden Nugget Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $2,168,000 in the quarter and a loss of $8.5 million in the year, both from litigation judgment. The company said 1989 operating revenue included $65,843,000 from the company's new Mirage Casino-Hotel, opened Nov. 22, 1989. Results for 1989 included about $10 million of costs associated with the Dec. 7, 1989 Leonard-Duran boxing match.

title: School Asks for Penalty
description: The University of Maryland has suggested to the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Infractions Committee that the Terrapins be barred from post-season tournaments this year as punishment for violations that occurred under the three-year term of the former coach, Bob Wade, according to a report in The Washington Post yesterday.

title: Meggett Is Arrested On Solicitation Charge
description: Dave Meggett, the Giants' rookie kick returner and running back, was arrested in Baltimore yesterday on a charge of offering to pay an undercover female police officer for sex. The police said he was charged with lewdness and soliciting a prostitute.

title: Gish Biomedical reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Insituform Mid-America reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Fatal Affair: Love, a Gun And a Puzzle
description: Lieut. C. F. Sullivan of the Greenburgh Town Police Department today compared the yearlong inquiry into the killing of Betty Jeanne Solomon to ''a large puzzle where many pieces fit'' until the image of the ''prime player'' finally appeared.

title: Striking a Defensive Tone, Bush Sees Virtue in Caution
description: Deliberately avoiding any comment on the events in the Soviet Union, President Bush struck a remarkably defensive tone toward his policy on Eastern Europe today, saying ''the world is moving too fast'' for him to know what will happen next and make firm decisions about how to respond.

title: Bass Partnership Files Suit Over St. Petersburg Times
description: A partnership that owns a minority interest in The St. Petersburg Times has filed suit in Federal court against those controlling the Florida newspaper, asserting that the present dividend structure is unfair.

title: 5 to Examine Aristech Assets
description: The Aristech Chemical Corporation said today that five of the nation's leading chemical companies had expressed interest in acquiring assets of the Pittsburgh-based concern.

title: 10-Year U.S. Notes Sell Well
description: A better-than-expected turnout at the Treasury's quarterly auction of 10-year notes spurred a sharp turnaround in the credit markets yesterday, as prices of Treasury securities moved off their lows and closed higher for the day.

title: Monarch Machine Tool reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bridge
description: In a simple bidding style, a player whose partner opens one no-trump tends to settle in three no-trump if he can see values for game and can rule out a major-suit fit. This leads to an occasional disaster when there is extreme weakness in a major suit and the right contract is game in a minor. It is seldom right to play three no-trump when the partnership has a two-two, or worse, fit in a major.

title: The Wheelchair-Friendly Apartment
description: RONNIE EISENBERG, who has multiple sclerosis, lived in an apartment on East 72d Street that was an obstacle course. The arches to the living room and the door to the kitchen were too narrow for her wheelchair. Each time she took a shower, she had to be carried over the lip.

title: Equity Oil reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
When Inspiration Strikes Twice
description: A. The Water Kettle, a 1984 design by the architect Michael Graves, was introduced by the Italian company Alessi in 1985.

title: CPC International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Times Books Appoints An Editorial Director
description: Steve Wasserman, executive editor of Doubleday, was named editorial director of Times Books yesterday, effective on Monday. Mr. Wasserman is to replace Derek Johns, who recently decided to return to Britain. Mr. Wasserman was previously publisher of Hill & Wang and Noonday Press, divisions of Farrar, Straus & Giroux.

title: Poddubny Status Unclear
description: Walt Poddubny's recurring back problems are becoming a mystery to the Devils. Six days ago, they pronounced him fit to play. Today, they say they don't know the extent of Poddubny's injury.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section yesterday about research on the healing potential of foods misidentified the component involved in products developed by Paul Stitt, a biochemist who owns Natural Ovens in Manitowoc, Wis. He uses flaxseed mash and holds the patent for stabilizing the mash, not flaxseed oil.

title: Union Annuities Plan Draws Agents' Fire
description: Objections by player agents have slowed a plan developed by the National Basketball Players Association that the union says would insure the financial security of its members in the years before they are eligible for their pensions.

title: Emons Holdings reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said results for the 1988 period have been restated to reflect the adoption of FASB 96 ''Accounting for Income Taxes'' as of July 1, 1988.

title: Chronicle
description: IRVING P. (SWIFTY) LAZAR, the legendary Hollywood agent, has selected MICHAEL SHNAYERSON to write his as-told-to autobiography. Mr. Lazar has had such clients as Cole Porter, Noel Coward, Irwin Shaw and Richard M. Nixon.

title: Saks and Marshall Field Up for Sale
description: Saks Fifth Avenue and Marshall Field & Company will be put up for sale this week, each hoping to attract a bid of more than $1 billion.

title: Medco Containment Svcs reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss of $27,059,000 from the writedown of the company's investment in the common stock of First Executive Corp. to an amount below the market value of First Executive's common stock on Feb. 6. c-Included a loss of $42,882,000 from the writedown of securities. d-Net income

title: Richard B. Adler, 67, Engineering Educator
description: Dr. Richard Brooks Adler, a professsor who helped to reshape the teaching of electronics, died Tuesday at the University of Massachusetts Medical Center in Worcester, Mass., after being hit by a car while jogging near his home in Concord. He was 67 years old.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Campbell-Mithun Buys Drossman Lehmann
description: Drossman Lehmann Marino, a seven-year-old New York agency known for its application of marketing creativity to packaged goods, has been acquired by Campbell-Mithun-Esty, the Saatchi & Saatchi unit that has been trying to re-establish itself after some executive shuffling and client defections.

title: High Judge Gets Public Scolding In New Jersey
description: Saying the judiciary bears a higher responsibility to conform to the law, the New Jersey Supreme Court yesterday publicly reprimanded one of its own members, Justice Robert L. Clifford, for driving while intoxicated.

title: We're a Yard Behind in a World of Meters
description: To the Editor:

title: CMS Enhancements reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted to reflect the 1-for-4 reverse stock split of Dec. 5, 1989.

Script Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $10,300, or 1 cent a share, and $66,300, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net income

title: Washington Water Power reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago full-year period included the effect of a $4.7 million writeoff. Per-share figures included the effect of payment of preferred stock dividends.

title: Intriguing Reasons Behind Gifts to Neediest
description: Some letters to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund reveal a great deal about their authors, and some raise intriguing questions. For example, one letter this week said, ''Well, I'm unemployed, illegally sub-subletting a dump, and being looked for by the authorities.''

title: 35 Killed as Strike Sets Off Violence in Pakistan
description: At least 35 people were killed and 110 wounded today when Pakistani security forces and anti-Government protesters fought gunbattles in Karachi.

title: Picking On Their Own Size
description: rrSize is everything in college sports. Never was this more apparent than the other day when the biggest of the big-timers made a pre-emptive strike on its colleagues.

title: Negotiations Are to Begin on Ending Restrictions Against Soviet Imports
description: The first round of talks on a trade agreement that could end nearly a half-century of American discrimination against Soviet imports will start on Monday in Washington, the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, announced today.

title: Bangor Hydro-Electric reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge of $476,881 related to investment in Seabrook nuclear power plants.

title: American Fructose reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Perception Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
PARENT & CHILD
description: DURING the first trimester of my wife's pregnancy with our son, her weight stayed the same and I put on 10 pounds. Other fathers have described weeks of morning sickness, food cravings, moodiness or chronic fatigue - symptoms of pregnancy they had expected to see in their wives, not in themselves.

title: First Home Federal S&L reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KEY RATES
Dreyfus Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income of $65,479,000, or $1.61 a share, from the sale of the rights, title and interest in Dreyfus Consumer Bank's mastercard accounts. c-Included a credit of $1,419,000, or 3 cents a share, representing the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Bill Would Overturn Court's Rights Decisions
description: A bipartisan group of legislators introduced a bill today to overturn a series of United States Supreme Court decisions that civil rights leaders said severely weakened job discrimination laws.

title: Badger Paper Mills reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
U.S. Judge Dismisses Lawsuit Against Plan for Coliseum Site
description: A Federal judge has dismissed a lawsuit against the Columbus Center redevelopment plan in a ruling that may help the city move forward with the long-delayed project.

description: Lenin: 10th Party congress, 1921

description: b-Net loss

description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

Kenan Transport reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $1.5 million, or 64 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Goldriver L.P.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Net income The company, the owner of Sam's Town Gold River Hotel & Gambling Hall in Laughlin, Nev., said its results were adversely affected by an expansion project and interest on the issuance of $118,000,000 principal amount of First Mortgage bonds used to finance the construction.

title: Senate Votes Bush Education Bill, With Plan for Teacher Standards
description: The Senate today overwhelmingly approved President Bush's first major initiative in education. But in passing the measure, the lawmakers added a provision that the President opposes: money for an independent board that is working to develop a voluntary national teacher certification system.

title: Thortec International reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $5,600,000 and $10,300,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The year also included an extraordinary credit of $29,100,000, or $3.64 a share, which represented a gain on an exchange of the company's convertible subordinated debentures which was completed in the second quarter of the current fiscal year. c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $1,300,000 and $6,400,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The year also included an extraordinary credit of $1,000,000, or 15 cents a share, the origin of which was not immediately available. Fiscal 1989 fourth-quarter loss included provisions for the write off of plant and equipment totaling $1.2 million and $600,000 of expenses incurred in connection with the company's restructuring efforts. Fiscal 1989 results were adversely affected by losses related to the company's former majority-owned international subsidiary, URS International ($5.3 million), the write-down of certain assets, and significant legal, accounting and consulting expenses.

title: Prime Motor Inns Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Robots Transform Coal Mining
description: The four-inch carbide-steel claws of a screaming yellow robot tore relentlessly at the coal seam 1,000 feet below the surface, digging enough in 30 seconds to meet the electric needs of a typical suburban house for a year.

title: Chronicle
description: GENERAL COLIN L. POWELL, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff; MABEL M. SMYTHE-HAITH, former Ambassador to Cameroon, and VERNON E. JORDAN JR., former president of the National Urban League, were honored as Black History Makers last night, at the Associated Black Charities annual awards benefit at the Waldorf-Astoria.

title: Digital Solutions reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Included a $350,000 writedown.

title: American Pacific Mining reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $381,559. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Harper's Is Proud of Its Circulation THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Campbell-Mithun Buys Drossman Lehmann
description: EVERY month, in a feature entitled ''Annotation,'' Harper's Magazine calls on an expert to decode a document in his or her field, telling readers the real meaning behind the abbreviations and arcana that constitute the expert's written world. A screenwriter might explain a screenplay, or a doctor might interpret a hospital bill.

title: Cleaning Fireplace Utensils
description: It has been a shivery winter, and the fireplace has been burning more than usual. The once-gleaming brass tools that provide rich accents in a room - shovel, tongs, andirons, poker, brass-trimmed screen - are covered with soot and badly stained by smoke, fire gases and resinous secretions. As one fireplace expert put it, ''It's time for open-hearth surgery.''

title: Stewart Information Services reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included for the quarter an aftertax credit of $528,000, or 13 cents a share, for a reversal of a title loss provision made in the second quarter; the provision was reversed because of a change in circumstances related to the claim. The year included aftertax provisions for large title losses of $5,412,000, or $1.33 a share, and the year also included aftertax gain on sale of municipal bonds of $1,139,000, or 28 cents a share. c-Included for the quarter $481,000, or 12 cents a share, gain on the termination of the company's pension plan. The year included aftertax provisions for large title losses of $2,127,000, or 53 cents a share, in 1988, and also included $481,000, or 12 cents a share, for a gain on the termination of the company's pension plan.

title: Ryder System Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary losses, net of tax benefits, of $6,203,000, reflecting the early retirement of debt, for the quarter and year. c-Included extraordinary losses, net of tax benefits, of $18,581,000 from the early retirement of debt and income of $81,096,000, or $1.02 a share, from the cumulative effect on prior years of change in accounting. Earnings for the latest 12 months and 1988 were reduced by $57 million and $52 million, respectively, as a result of several unusual charges. The fourth quarter of 1989 included a gain from the sale of Insurance Management Services which increased net earnings by $9 million, or 11 cents a share. Effective Jan. 1, 1988, the company adopted SFAS No. 96, Accounting for Income Taxes. The cumulative effect reflects primarily the reduction of deferred income taxes as a result of lower tax rates enacted in 1986.

title: Dissension on the Gotti Jury: A Note Complains of 'Bias'
description: A juror in the John Gotti assault trial sent a note to the judge last night indicating that there was dissension among the jurors, suggesting that the panel may be having serious difficulty reaching a verdict.

title: Gulf States Utilities reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $22 million charge from the writeoff of deferrals associated with the River Bend nuclear plant. c-Included a $15 million first quarter charge related to the cancelled River Bend Unit 2. Results also included a third quarter charge of $37 million reflective of writeoffs related to River Bend, and a third quarter charge of $18 million for the writeoff of abandoned lignite leases. d-Net income

title: Rabbi S. R. Weiss, 79-Year-Old Leader Of Orthodox Jewry
description: Rabbi Samson Raphael Weiss, a leader of Orthodox Jewry in the United States and a staunch advocate of Jewish education, died on Tuesday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 79 years old and lived in Jerusalem.

title: Detroit & Canada Tunnel reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
Man Suspected in 4 Slayings Dies in Shootout With Police
description: A man suspected of killing a family of four in their home in December was killed today in a shootout with state troopers. The man's mother was arrested and charged with murder in connection with the slayings.

title: John Merivale, Actor, 72
description: John Merivale, an actor who appeared in such movies as ''A Night to Remember,'' ''King Rat'' and ''Arabesque'' in the 1950's and 60's, died on Tuesday in London. He was 72 years old.

title: Romania's AIDS Babies: A Legacy of Neglect
description: The babies, about 60 of them, are on the third floor of the drab gray hospital, the only AIDS clinic in Romania. In some rooms, there are two babies to a crib. In one small cubicle, four infants, close to death, lie in a row under a single blanket.

title: Fieldcrest Cannon reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
No End to the Threat
description: On the very day when Mikhail Gorbachev was arguing in a stormy Central Committee session for the Soviet Communist Party to begin sharing power with other political groups, what was President Bush's maladroit message to the world?

title: Krug International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-After a loss of $1,501,000 for the quarter and income of $4,388,000, or $1.03 a share, for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations. The year-ago periods' income from continuing operations included after- tax gain of about $300,000 on the sale of property in the U.K. The year-ago 9 months' share earnings of income from continuing operations included an amount received from the U.K. taxing authority related to an intercompany dividend which contributed about 14 cents a share.

title: Liberal Jewish Bimonthly Magazine to Close
description: The American Jewish Committee plans to close its liberal bimonthly magazine, Present Tense, saying the magazine is suffering from financial problems. But some members of the staff said the decision was also politically motivated and related to the magazine's criticism of Israeli policies.

title: Security Tight for Jackson On Arrival in South Africa
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson arrived in South Africa today for his first visit in 11 years and was immediately surrounded by some of the tightest police security ever given to a foreign visitor.

title: Tanker Spills Oil Off California
description: A oil tanker's hull was gashed today and hundreds of thousands of gallons of oil spilled into the water two miles off a popular Southern California beach, officials said.

title: Gundle Environmental SysFtems Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Review/Music;   Cannes Chamber Orchestra In Substitute Program
description: To judge from its concert on Monday night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Chamber Orchestra of Cannes is an excellent ensemble, fully capable of providing satisfying performances in a wide range of repertory. One mentions that because according to Columbia Artists Management, this orchestra, founded in 1976 by its current music director and conductor, Philippe Bender, specializes in contemporary music.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Aldus Corp., Seattle, a provider of computer programming and other software services, said it would acquire Silicon Beach Software, San Diego, a software publisher, through a merger in which shares of Aldus common stock would be exchanged for all of the outstanding shares of Silicon Beach.

title: Obscenities, Hang-Ups and Technology
description: When the telephone rings, some people, curious, still leap to answer. Others don't, wary of an annoying sales pitch or indecent proposition. Now phone companies are able to remove the mystery and perhaps some of the anxiety. With a $50 attachment and for a monthly fee of $6 or $7, a customer can see the caller's number on a screen while the phone is ringing, and decide whether to answer.

title: Gotti Jury Deliberates a Third Day Without a Verdict in Assault Case
description: The jury in the John Gotti assault and conspiracy trial in Manhattan deliberated for a third day yesterday without reaching a verdict.

title: Ford Plant to Build New Vehicle for Mazda
description: In the latest variation of Japanese and American joint automotive ventures, the Mazda Motor Corporation said today that a compact utility vehicle would be built for it by American workers and managers at an existing Ford Motor Company plant in Louisville, Ky., and sold at Mazda's American dealerships.

title: 2 Bands That Choose to Stay Out of the Rock Mainstream
description: Rock-and-roll today is bigger business than ever, but there are still bands that maintain a low-budget, do-it-yourself work ethic. Eleventh Dream Day and the Meat Puppets, two bands that will be performing tomorrow night at the RAPP Arts Center, seem less interested in stadium dates and limousine rides than they are in making personal, challenging music that casually reworks the traditional guitars-bass-drums rock lineup. Both are established club-circuit and college-radio bands that could potentially break through to a mainstream audience, but that would rather make the mainstream bend toward them.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Sports Pages on Tues-day about the trainer Shug McGaughey referred incorrectly to a record he had hoped to attain on Nov. 6. He could not have become the first trainer to win three cup races in a day; D. Wayne Lukas has already done so.

title: Jane Yockel, Arts Administrator, 63
description: Jane Yockel, an arts administrator known for her support of avant-garde dance, theater and music, died of a heart attack on Jan. 31. She was 63 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Investors Savings Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Holiday Inn Deal Completed by Bass
description: Bass P.L.C. completed its acquisition of Holiday Inns Inc. for $2.2 billion and said the motel chain's headquarters would be moved to Atlanta from Memphis. Bryan D. Langton, the chairman of the Bass hotel and restaurant division, will become chairman and chief executive of Holiday Inns and move from Britain to Atlanta.

title: Valley West Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
S.&P. Downgrades Sears On $5.6 Billion of Securities
description: The slower-than-expected recovery in Sears, Roebuck & Company's retailing operations has resulted in the downgrading of about $5.6 billion in the corporation's securities, the Standard & Poor's Corporation announced yesterday.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Julie Wilson's Coleman

title: Maria Gambarelli Fenton, 89, A Metropolitan Opera Ballerina
description: Maria Gambarelli Fenton, who was prima ballerina of the Metropolitan Opera Ballet and headed the bills that opened the Capital and Roxy theaters and Radio City Music Hall, died after a cerebral hemorrhage on Sunday at Huntington Hospital in Huntington, L.I. She was 89 years old.

title: Noise Rules for New Nightclubs Approved
description: The Board of Estimate approved a mixed bag of rules yesterday that it said would strike a balance between New York's often noisy nightclubs and their neighbors who seek peace and quiet.

title: BMR Financial Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A. F. Jacobson Phone Executive, 84
description: A. F. Jacobson, retired president of the Northwestern Bell Telephone Company, died at Clarkson Hospital in Omaha on Wednesday after a brief illness. He was 84 years old.

title: Affiliated Publications Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $341,000 and $27,225,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $43,654,000 for the quarter and $80,882,000 for the year.

title: Apple Suit Delay
description: The closely watched computer copyright lawsuit filed by Apple Computer Inc. against the Microsoft Corporation and the Hewlett-Packard Company may be delayed by the departure of the judge presiding over the case. Federal District Judge William W. Schwarzer in San Francisco said he will take a five-year leave to direct the Federal Judicial Center in Washington. His cases are being transferred to Vaughn R. Walker, who was sworn in as a judge on Monday. While it is unclear how this will affect the timetable of the lawsuit, lawyers said delays are not uncommon when a new judge is brought in.

title: TV Weekend;   Docudrama That's Based On a Drama
description: Not all docudramas are based on best-selling books. Tonight's ''Great Performances'' presentation, on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock, is offering a BBC revival of Terence Rattigan's ''Winslow Boy.'' With names changed, the play is based on a case that riveted England's attention in 1908. The play, produced in London in 1946, was the first major success for Rattigan, who went on to write ''The Browning Version,'' ''The Deep Blue Sea'' and ''Separate Tables.''

title: KEY RATES
BHC Communications Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Latest year reflects net gains of about $774 million on the sale to Time Warner Inc. of 63 percent the company's former interest in Warner Communications Inc.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a new civil rights bill misidentified a Republican backer's home state and rendered her name incorrectly. She is Representative Olympia J. Snowe of Maine.

title: OPPOSITION GAINING A BIT IN NICARAGUA
description: In the heated election battle between the Government and its opponents, it is perhaps no surprise that an opposition rally on Sunday ended in a shoving match. What was notable was that the fight involved only one side: bickering leaders of the main anti-Government coalition.

title: Sullivan May Be Off CBS Morning Show
description: CBS News has told Kathleen Sullivan it plans to replace her as co-anchor of ''CBS This Morning,'' associates of Ms. Sullivan said yesterday.

title: Chris-Craft Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included gains on the sale of 63 percent of Chris-Craft's interest in Warner Communications Inc., which accounted for about $447 million of the year's net income.

title: Upheaval in the East;   NATO Offers East Bloc Concessions on Arms
description: NATO offered the East concessions on arms definitions and troop levels today in an attempt to clear the way for a treaty this year on reducing conventional forces in Europe.

title: Morton Freund, Executive, 91
description: Morton Freund, a New York advertising executive for more than half a century, died of a heart attack on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 91 years old.

title: Nat Rogers, 91, Dies; Chemical Distributor
description: Nat S. Rogers, co-founder of a company that became bi>Univar, one of North America's largest chemical distributors, died Tuesday at a nursing home in Seattle, his home city.He was 91 years old.

title: Appeals Court Rules A.M.A. Acted Against Chiropractors
description: A Federal appeals court has upheld a 1987 ruling that the American Medical Association violated antitrust laws by trying to destroy the chiropractic profession.

title: Felicia Clark, 58, Dies; A Planning Consultant
description: Felicia Clark, an urban-planning consultant, died of complications from a stroke on Tuesday at her home in Boston. She was 58 years old and also had a house on Tuckernuck Island, Mass.

title: Senator Proposes Curbs on Aid to Salvador
description: Senator Christopher S. Dodd of Connecticut introduced a measure today to restrict United States military aid to El Salvador, and the Democratic Senator predicted that Congress would demand new conditions on such aid this year.

title: Sears Roebuck Acceptance Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reflected $11.4 million of additional non-recurring net income resulting from the adoption of the new income tax standard FAS 96. The increase in net income for the quarter was primarily attributable to the company's increased combined investment in Sears notes and receivable balances. For the year, the increased combined investment at higher yields was the primary cause for increased net income. The yields were increased in response to a rise in the average cost of short-term borrowings.

title: Cyclops Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a pretax restructuring charge of $2.7 million and operating gain of $700,000 from liquidation of inventories for the quarter and the year included an operating gain of $8.2 million, or 70 cents a share, resulting from liquidation of inventory. The company said year-ago results are restated to give effect to restoration of continuing operations of two divisions previously accounted for as discontinued.

title: Carlyle Discloses 6.27% Harsco Stake
description: The Carlyle Group L.P., a Washington investment firm, said that it had acquired 6.27 percent of the Harsco Corporation and that it believed the pipe-fitting and metals concern, based in Camp Hill, Pa., was ''a potentially attractive acquisition candidate.''

title: Giddings & Lewis Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a pretax charge of $700,000 for cost overruns. The company said earnings for the 1988 periods and the latest year period are stated on a pro-forma basis, because the company went public on July 27, 1989.

title: Dofasco Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income of $5,200,000, or 8 cents a share, for the quarter and a loss of $41,100,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: James Moody's Jazz

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 495 money market mutual funds increased $2.73 billion, to $387.39 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 150 institutional funds increased by $401.9 million, to $92.11 billion. The assets of the 244 general-purpose funds were up by $1.02 billion, to $130.87 billion. The 101 broker-dealer funds rose $1.31 billion, to $164.42 billion, the institute said.

title: General Says Salvador Can't Defeat Guerrillas
description: The head of the United States Southern Command told Congress today that El Salvador's Government is not able to defeat Marxist-led rebels and that the only way to end the fighting there is through negotiation.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss) *Loss in year-earlier period.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: A Lesson in Love

title: Results Plus
description: N.B.A.

title: The Superczar
description: Just before his fatal heart attack, Andrei Sakharov went before the Soviet Parliament to plead for an end to the monopoly power of the Communist Party; Mikhail Gorbachev shut him up and cut him off.

title: The Army's Silence On Accidental Death
description: LEAD: According to the Defense Department, more than 15,000 active-duty service personnel were killed in peacetime training accidents from 1979-89. On Sept. 26, 1988, our son, Joseph Kutzler, was added to that list.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: City closed.

title: New Head of Danaher From Black & Decker
description: The Danaher Corporation, a Washington-based industrial company built by the Rales brothers, has chosen George M. Sherman, a top executive with the Black & Decker Corporation, to be president and chief executive.

title: Lukewarm Ending for Auctions
description: Investors gave the final portion of the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions a tepid welcome yesterday, but even that was enough to push prices of notes and bonds higher.

title: Oil Tanker in Pacific Spills 300,000 Gallons Off Coast
description: A fully loaded tanker maneuvering toward a pipeline about two miles off this city apparently struck her own anchor on Wednesday and spilled nearly 300,000 gallons of light Alaskan crude oil into the Pacific Ocean.

title: Review/Art;   Good Humor and Doom From Robert Moskowitz
description: The Robert Moskowitz retrospective opening tomorrow at the Museum of Modern Art begins with the collage-paintings of 1961-63 that made Mr. Moskowitz one of the bright young stars of the New York art scene. The painted surfaces are thin. The dominant color is a yellow ocher. There is a nerviness and freedom in the feeling for materials. But in the paper bag suspended from one painting like a hangman's victim, in the window-shade cord ticking within another work like a pendulum, and in the window shade in a third - whose straight bottom edge seems to have the finality of a guillotine - there is a sense that something has been shut forever.

title: The Truth About Pollock's 'Blue Poles'
description: To the Editor:

title: Fairfield County Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: In Reversal, White House Backs Curbs on Health Claims for Food
description: In a reversal of policy, the White House has approved broad and strict regulations intended to halt the proliferation of disease-prevention claims on food packages, Federal officials said today.

title: Padilla Seeks a 3,000-Meter Record
description: Doug Padilla ran five miles Wednesday morning in 48 minutes 9 seconds.

title: Grand Met May Sell Alpo Pet Foods Unit
description: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the British conglomerate, said today that it was exploring the possibility of selling its Alpo Pet Foods Inc. division.

title: Aon Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Books of The Times;   What Did It Feel Like to Be Kafka? Creepy!
description: Kafka

title: China Wins Two Loans Backed by U.S.
description: The World Bank and a United States agency announced loans to China today, reflecting further efforts by the Bush Administration to improve relations despite the American sanctions imposed after the crackdown on the democracy movement in Beijing.

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press in Business Day on Wednesday about the GTE Corporation's earnings report misstated the number of the company's new cellular-mobile telephone customers last year. There were 136,000 new customers in 1989, including 50,000 in the fourth quarter.

title: Judge Refuses to Reinstate Housing Officials
description: A Federal judge refused today to reinstate three officials of the Passaic, N.J., Housing Authority who were suspended by Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp last month after a Federal audit found $1.68 million in excessive salaries and other spending abuses at the office.

title: Review/Film;   Middle-Aged and Not Quite Middle Class
description: Stanley and Iris are not the sorts of characters one often meets in movies these days. They're not exactly high-profile types. There are no extraterrestrials in their lives, no vice cops and not much of anything that could pass for comedy of the thigh-slapping kind.

title: Investors Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The fourth quarter results included a net gain of about $4.6 million on the sale of the majority of the bank's credit card portfolio. The quarter also included expenses of about $694,000 related to severance and other charges related to the downsizing and restructuring plan which management initiated in November 1989. A loss of $984,000 from real estate operations resulted primarily from a charge-off of about $4 million on an equity investment in a hotel property. The 1988 results included a pre-tax gain of $18.2 million on the sale of Investors' mortgage banking operations in March 1988, and a $3 million pre-tax operating loss associated with those operations prior to the sale.

description: Shows, Nature, Museums

NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-12

title: Financial News Network reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $349,895 for the quarter and $943,412 for the 6 months.

title: Stock Prices End Mixed; Dow Up 4.28
description: Stocks turned in a narrowly mixed performance yesterday after a seesaw session in which the Dow Jones industrial average rose 4.28 points, to 2,644.37.

title: First Interstate Corp.  (Wisc.)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included pre-tax charges of $38 million for increasing the allowance for credit losses and for costs related to its pending merger with Norwest Corp., and for securities losses. c-Net income

title: First Harrisburg Bancor reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary credit of $192,400. c-After extraordinary credits of $36,700 for the quarter and $56,500 for the year. Per share earnings reflected 10 percent stock dividend paid in November 1989.

title: Culbro Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Included $800,000 in shutdown and restructuring reserves for the quarter and $4,800,000 in the year. c-Net loss d-Included an extraordinary loss of $1,790,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $1,960,000, or 46 cents a share for the year, both from distributed consumer finance business.

title: Chronicle
description: A new team of defense lawyers for LEONA HELMSLEY said yesterday they had uncovered ''shocking new evidence'' that would prove her innocent of evading about $750,000 in New York State income taxes. Already sentenced to four years in prison for Federal income tax fraud, Mrs. Helmsley, 69, has rejected an offer from state prosecutors to plead guilty.

title: 12 Held in Fake Train Ticket Scheme
description: Instead of buying their monthly railroad commuter tickets the old-fashioned way, at the ticket window in a train station, about two dozen Metro-North commuters gave their money to someone they knew - someone with a photocopying machine, the authorities said yesterday. A very good photocopying machine. Metro-North Commuter Railroad officials say the copier churned out sharp and colorful counterfeit tickets that fooled conductors making the rounds of trains to and from Manhattan. But then one man, Rik Bachman, a lawyer from White Plains, seemed unusually jittery one morning as he flashed his commutation ticket. The conductor became suspicious, and what the authorities say was a well-organized scheme began to unravel.

title: Coastal Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $8,200,000. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,700,000 and $5,300,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. Year-ago results are restated to reflect discontinued operations. The company said year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid in November 1989. Latest quarter's income from continuing operations of $178,300,000, or $1.90 a share, included a $36 million pretax gain realized when the company tendered its shares of Texas Eastern Corp.

title: Threats to Mandela Worry Pretoria
description: The South African Government is concerned about the safety of Nelson Mandela after he is released from prison, its Law and Order Minister, Adriaan Vlok, said today.

title: Bearish Mood Is Overtaking Stock Investors, Study Says
description: Investor sentiment has reached its most pessimistic level since June 1982, just before the start of the 1980's bull market, according to a weekly study that is closely watched by Wall Street.

title: G.E. and 9 Cable Concerns In Satellite Television Deal
description: A division of the General Electric Company and nine large cable television operators said today that they are teaming up in a $100 million venture to deliver programming to homes by satellite.

title: Bishop Repeated Church Teaching to Governor
description: To the Editor:

title: Thomas & Betts Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Upheaval in the East;   Bonn's Politicians Invade East Germany
description: The question here is no longer which power the Communists will surrender next or which hurdle the opposition might clear. The question is which West German party will win the East German election next month.

title: H.H. Robertson Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $1.2 million from sale of certain units and other facilities. c-Net loss and included a restructuring charge of $21,860,000. Results for 1989 included figures from operations of Star Manufacturing Co., which was acquired in August 1988.

title: Restaurants
description: Manhattan still awaits a great Thai restaurant. There are a dozen or so places around town that turn out a striking dish or two - and there are some solid family-run places in Brooklyn and Queens -yet no place has captured in a big way the delicacy and diversity of this underrated cuisine. If pressed to recommend Thai food, I usually mention the Los Angeles import Tommy Tang's on Greenwich Street. Not because it has the most authentic food around - it is really a winsome hybrid that might be called Cali-Thai - but because it is a jaunty place with food that is generally fresh and aggressively seasoned.

title: Major Oil Spills In the Past Year
description: March 24, 1989: Tanker Exxon Valdez ran aground in Prince William Sound, Alaska, spilling 10.92 million gallons of crude oil.

title: Itel Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Itel said the share earnings in 1989 and 1988 included the interest expense associated with the company's minority positions in the Santa Fe Pacific Corp. and American President Companies Ltd. These investments, which were made in connection with the acquisition of assets from the Henley Group Inc., in September 1988, reduced earnings by about $1.40 a share in 1989 and 55 cents a share in 1988. These investments are carried on a cost basis. The 1988 quarter and year results included an $8 million non-recurring bridge financing expense relating to Itel's acquisition of assets from the Henley Group. Share earnings were reflected by preferred dividend requirements.

title: EG&G Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Upheaval in the East;   PARTY MAPS PLAN TO GIVE GORBACHEV BROADER POWERS
description: The Communist Party leadership has mapped out a strategy to endow Mikhail S. Gorbachev with broad new presidential powers, probably without forcing him to undergo a popular election, party officials said today.

title: Of Haydn and Bruckner
description: Erich Leinsdorf is to conduct the New York Philharmonic in Haydn's Symphony No. 90 and Bruckner's Symphony No. 3 tonight at 8 at Avery Fisher Hall. The program is to be repeated tomorrow at 8 P.M. Tickets are $10 to $40. Information: 580-8700.

title: Upheaval in the East: The President;   What Is Bush Up To?
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the leader of the Democratic majority in the House, said today that ''Americans are asking one question: 'Why is President Bush beating plowshares into swords?' ''

title: Dupond Succeeds Nureyev At the Paris Opera Ballet
description: Patrick Dupond, the 30-year-old, internationally known French ballet star, was named today to succeed Rudolf Nureyev as artistic director of the Paris Opera Ballet.

title: 2 Gang Members Slain in Chinatown Restaurant
description: A clash between rival Vietnamese and Chinese gang members in Chinatown early yesterday left two young men dead and three people wounded, the authorities said.

title: Colgate-Palmolive Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain on sale of discontinued operations of $125,000,000, or $1.83 a share, for both the quarter and year, and the year also included income from discontinued operations of $40,134,000, or 59 cents a share. The company said it realized a $54 million reduction in net interest expense for 1989. As previously announced, the company in the fourth quarter of 1989 realized net income of $7 million, or 7 cents a share, from the sale of the initial land parcel for the Colgate Jersey City 34-acre project. In the second quarter of 1989 excess land in England was sold for net of $6.5 million, or 9 cents a share.

title: Home Federal Savings Bank (Ohio) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
To My Social Security Critics . . .
description: Two criticisms of my proposal to reduce Social Security tax rates are in general circulation.

title: For Nebraska Governor, a Hard Path
description: She is ''just plain Kay,'' Nebraska's Governor told students in a rural two-room schoolhouse here, but that is not a view that is very widely held.

title: Bush Inaction Is Seen Weakening Reagan 'Privilege' on His Diaries
description: A Federal district judge said today that Ronald Reagan's claim of executive privilege in refusing to turn over entries from his private diaries to John M. Poindexter had been weakened because President Bush had not invoked the doctrine to protect the same material.

title: John J. Manning, Security Chief, 82
description: John J. Manning, security chief for the 1964-65 New York World's Fair, died of a heart attack on Monday at his home in North Palm Beach, Fla. He was 82 years old.

title: Centerbank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Tuesday about the Soviet Communist Party's plans to abandon its monopoly on power misidentified one of the two Soviet republics that have legalized parties competing with the Communist Party. It is Latvia, not Estonia. (The other is Lithuania.)

title: The New York Times Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income of $198,448,000, or $2.52 a share, from discontinued operations. The income from discontinued operations included a gain of $193,291,000, or $2.46 a share, on the sale of the company's cable television system. c-Net income d-After income from discontinued operations of $1,964,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $6,719,000, or 8 cents a share, for the year. The latest periods also included after-tax equity losses in operations of forest products group of $25,134,000 for the quarter and $15,922,000 for the year. The equity losses in both periods included a charge of $27.2 million for a valuation reserve against the company's investment in its forest products group. The year-ago periods also included after-tax equity earnings in operations of forest products group of $8,111,000 for the quarter and $28,928,000 for the year.

title: Home Owners Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Per share earnings reflected preferred dividend requirements.

title: Fleming Companies Inc. reports earnings for 12wks to Dec 30
description: b-Included a gain equivalent to 46 cents a share from the sale of the White Swan Food-Service unit.

title: Judge Rules Noriega Trial Must Proceed
description: A Federal district judge declared today that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega must stand trial on drug-trafficking charges. In so doing, the judge rejected defense lawyers' arguments that United States courts have no jurisdiction over the fallen Panamanian leader.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We've gotten every conceivable break. The wind, the weather and the location of the accident all work to our advantage. But no one should confuse good luck with good planning.''

title: Chronicle
description: In a letter handwritten from Victor Verster Prison in Paarl, South Africa, NELSON MANDELA writes to DR. STUART JOHN SAUNDERS, the vice chancellor of the University of Cape Town:

title: Bishop Repeated Church Teaching to Governor;   Act on Principle Then
description: To the Editor:

title: A Builder Puts Stress on Open Space
description: LEAD: Kent, a 49-square-mile rural community of 2,900 residents in Connecticut's Litchfield County, is getting its first ''conservation subdivision.'' The town's new rules authorizing such a subdivision permit houses to be built on smaller lots than would ordinarily be allowed to preserve open space and scenic vistas.

title: Upheaval in the East;   100 Leading Estonians Ask Independence
description: Leading Estonians issued a new appeal today for restoration of the Baltic republic's prewar independence.

title: Campeau Units In Creditor Pact
description: Federated Department Stores and the Allied Stores Corporation reached agreements yesterday with a committee of their creditors.

title: Nekoosa Ruling For Georgia-Pacific
description: A Federal judge ruled that a two-thirds vote by the shareholders of the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation would be adequate to oust its directors. Nekoosa's bylaws stipulate that a three-fourths vote is needed, but Federal District Court Judge Gene Carter agreed with the Georgia-Pacific Corporation that the requirement violated Maine's corporate law.

title: Graf Is Injured Skiing
description: Steffi Graf, the 1990 Australian Open champion and the world's top-ranked women's tennis player for the last three years, suffered a thumb injury Wednesday when she fell while cross-country skiing in St. Moritz, Switzerland. She will be sidelined for 10 to 12 weeks.

title: Monetary Union: Would It Help?
description: For East and West Germany, monetary union would be a leap into the unknown, say Western economists who were caught off guard by West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's call to begin negotiations on monetary integration as early as next week. The cushion on landing would depend on the terms of the union, the adaptability of East German enterprises and the confidence of West German investors.

title: U.S. Accuses 2 Nynex Companies Of Overcharging and Fines Them
description: The Government ordered the New York Telephone Company and the New England Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday to pay a total of $1.4 million in fines for what it called an illegal scheme that inflated profits at the expense of customers.

title: Office Depot Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Included a tax credit of $532,000, or 3 cents a share. c-Included tax credits of $102,000, or 1 cent a share, and $648,000, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. Prior year results included $2,000,000, or 18 cents a share, gain from life insurance proceeds.

title: Network Systems Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a pre-tax charge to earnings of about $4.8 million to increase reserves for potential inventory obsolescence.

title: Consumer Debt Grew 6% in 1989
description: Americans took out $4.91 billion more in consumer credit than they retired in December, pushing total consumer debt up 6 percent in 1989, the Federal Reserve said today.

title: Drug Traffickers' Offer to Quit the Business Is Dividing Colombians
description: As President Bush's Latin American drug summit meeting approaches, drug traffickers have released five kidnapping victims - including the son of President Virgilio Barco Vargas's chief of staff - stopped their nightly bombings and surrendered a bus packed with 2,000 pounds of dynamite as part of their offer to quit the cocaine business.

title: People
description: * Bruce Lee Albert has been named a partner and also executive vice president and director of account services at Lord Einstein O'Neill & Partners.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Excerpts From Gorbachev Remarks
description: Following are excerpts from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's concluding remarks Wednesday at the Soviet Communist Party Central Committee meeting, as distributed in translation yesterday by the Soviet press agency Tass:

title: Royal Trustco reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Hearing on Cup Dispute
description: In what is expected to be the final step before a decision establishing who has the right to the America's Cup in yachting, the New York State Court of Appeals yesterday heard 70 minutes of testimony from lawyers representing Michael Fay of New Zealand and his opposition, the San Diego Yacht Club.

title: Ferranti Unit Deal Set With Thomson
description: Thomson S.A. of France said it would pay about $57 million for half of Ferranti P.L.C.'s sonar business in trying to become Europe's leading military electronics contractor through ventures and acquisitions. Under the agreement, Ferranti will transfer its sonar operations to a new company of which Thomson will own 50 percent. For the year that ended last March, the sonar division had sales of $:40 million, about $67.6 million, and operating profit of $:4.7 million, about $7.9 million.

title: Home Port Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1988 year's per share earnings not shown; the company went public in August 1988.

title: Win One, Lose One
description: In other contract dealings yesterday, Wallace Johnson won his salary arbitration case against Montreal and Bobby Bonilla lost his against Pittsburgh, while Jeff Russell became the second-highest-paid player on the Texas Rangers and Danny Tartabull agreed to a one-year deal with Kansas City.

title: Tyson Is No Longer a Novelty
description: As Mike Tyson glowered, hung his head in boredom and bobbed to music only he could hear from the earphones he wore, the subject that had many onlookers abuzz at the heavyweight champion's last news conference before his fight Sunday was whether or not they would meet Donald Trump and Michael Jackson.

title: Preston Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Review/Music;   High-Energy Mendelssohn On the Organ
description: Anthony Newman's immense physical talent for playing keyboard instruments is certainly basic to his prolific ventures in the music business. On Sunday afternoon at Holy Trinity Church, Mr. Newman roared through six Mendelssohn organ sonatas and three Preludes and Fugues as if the effort were barely worth mentioning. It is perhaps this easy fluency and high energy level that allows him to pursue so many things - piano, fortepiano and harpsichord performances, conducting, composing and editing.

title: Nacco Indus reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included gain equaled to 61 cents a share from termination of a pension plan and offset by the writeoff of certain coal leases. c-Included gains of $8.04 million from sale of certain subsidiaries. The latest periods' figures included the results from Hyster Co., acquired in May 1989 for $620 million.

title: Yankees Sign McCullers To One-Year Contract
description: The Yankees averted an arbitration hearing yesterday by reaching agreement on a one-year contract with Lance McCullers, the right-handed relief pitcher who had asked for $725,000 in arbitration. The Yankees had offered $605,000, and the parties agreed on $650,000, a raise of $190,000 for McCullers, who can earn another $30,000 in incentive bonuses.

title: Sweden Gets Inflation Plan
description: Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson said today that Sweden's economy was ''falling apart'' and that his Government would resign unless Parliament banned strikes and put into effect his plan for a two-year freeze on wages and prices.

title: 2 Sentenced in VW Case
description: A West German court today sentenced two men to six years in prison each for forging documents in currency deals involving Volkswagen A.G.

title: Rene P. Dentan, Executive, 77
description: Rene P. Dentan, a former chief executive of Rolex Watch USA, Inc., died of lymphoma on Sunday at his home in Colorado Springs. He was 77 years old.

title: Royal Shakespeare to Shut Down in London for Four Months
description: Calling it a black day for the Royal Shakespeare Company, the company's artistic director and chief executive announced today that because of cash shortages it would have to close its two theaters in London for four months, starting next November.

title: Hecla Mining reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included non-cash writedowns and other non-recurring charges of $14 million for the quarter and $16.7 million for the year. c-Net income

title: Loss of Balloons Hinders Drug Vigil
description: A $7 million radar balloon that was lost after breaking free from its tether and the grounding of two others have left a gap in the efforts to prevent drugs from being flown into this country from Mexico.

title: Danaher Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $14,000,000, or 60 cents a share,, for both the quarter and year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,658,000 for the quarter and $1,030,000 for the year, and the year also included an extraordinary tax credit of $9,000,000 and an extraordinary loss on the early extinguishment of debt of $4,009,000. The latest quarter's income from continuing operations of $12,486,000, or 53 cents a share, results included a $14 million after-tax gain on the sale of its Mohawk Rubber Co. unit and a $3 million gain from the sale of a majority interest in its Allied Steel & Tractor products subsidiary.

title: Hutcheson Likely to Pit Speed Against Class
description: A classic clash between class and speed is the theme of Saturday's Hutcheson Stakes at Gulfstream Park, the first serious stop on the road to the Kentucky Derby.

title: Chronicle
description: The soul singer JAMES BROWN, who has served more than a year of a six-and-a-half-year sentence at the State Park Correctional Center near Columbia, S.C., will finally be eligible to participate in a work-release program in that state. Judge GAYLE HAMRICK of Georgia State Court has altered Mr. Brown's jail sentence, making him immediately eligible for the program. He is serving concurrent South Carolina and Georgia sentences for assault and eluding police officers in a 1988 chase that crossed state lines. Mr. Brown, 56, is known for songs like ''It's a Man's World'' and ''I Feel Good.'' Without the judge's order, issued Wednesday, Mr. Brown would not have been eligible for the work-release program until March 7, since eligibility is based on parole dates in both states.

title: Knicks Hold Off Warriors' Late Rally
description: With Patrick Ewing already saddled with two fouls and the Golden State Warriors ahead of the Knicks, 27-26, with 1 minute 39 seconds left in the opening quarter last night, Coach Stu Jackson of the Knicks decided there was no substitute for good substitutes.

title: Brazil Aspires to Big League in More Than Soccer
description: Touring the United States, Japan, Western Europe and the Soviet Union, Brazil's President-elect has carried to world leaders a determined message: Brazil wants to join the ranks of the first world in the 1990's.

title: Upheaval in the East: Bulgaria;   Communist Cabinet for Bulgaria
description: Bulgaria's Communist Prime Minister formed an all-Communist Cabinet today after failing to persuade his party's old allies and new opposition groups to join a broadly based government.

title: Dennison Manufacturing Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss on early extinguishment of debt of $270,000. c-After a loss from an accounting adjustment of $916,000.

title: Soldier String Quartet
description: The Soldier String Quartet - a string quartet that plays with amplification and a percussionist - is to perform music by Dave Soldier and Elliott Sharp, and transcriptions of songs by the blues singer Muddy Waters and the soul singer James Brown tonight at 7 and 9 at Pyramid, 101 Avenue A, at Sixth Street. Admission is $7, which includes both shows. Information: 475-3538.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Legislators Send Letter to Baker On Kabul Shift
description: Senator Bob Dole, the minority leader, and seven other lawmakers sent a letter to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today expressing concern about a shift in United States policy toward Afghanistan.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Wednesday about Joseph James Nazzaro, a retired Air Force general, referred incorrectly to one of his World War II assignments. He commanded a bombardment group of the Army Air Forces in England.

title: Office Colleagues Join Forces To Assist the Neediest Cases
description: There is something about the camaraderie in an office that seems conducive to fund-raising. In the last few months, joint donations have come to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund from staff members in businesses all over the metropolitan area.

title: Waste Management Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a non-taxable gain of $70,826,000 from the public offering of 5 million Chemical Waste Management Inc. shares, which was largely offset by an unusual net charge of $70,560,000 taken to reflect future impact of federal regulations on solid waste landfills. c-Included net gain of $11,354,000 for waste-to-energy pact with Wheelabrator Technologies Inc. Share date reflected a 2-for-1 stock split paid in December 1989.

title: Upheaval in the East;   A Morning After in Moscow: No Headache at Party School
description: The morning after the Communist leadership renounced its dictatorial role, the sun rose pale and flat as ever over Moscow, and all the studious young Communists still showed up at the Higher Party School, eager as seminarians to catch up with redefined dogma.

title: Durenberger Assails a Report of $1 Million in Loans at Favorable Rates
description: After meeting behind closed doors with the Senate Select Committee on Ethics, Senator Dave Durenberger insisted today that the latest disclosures about his financial dealings were ''a blatant disregard for the facts.''

title: Cayuga Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Experts on Homeless Push for an Old Idea: S.R.O.'s in New York
description: A consensus is emerging among experts on homelessness and housing in New York that if government wants to move tens of thousands of homeless people off the streets and out of shelters, it will have to reinvent an old idea: the single-room-occupancy hotel.

title: Review/Art;   Caravaggio: A Tale of Two Lutes
description: ''A CARAVAGGIO REDISCOVERED: The Lute Player,'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is an exhibition modest only in size. It includes paintings of the first rank, paintings that have not been on view in years and paintings that have been unjustly ignored. It juxtaposes these works with related prints, musical scores and instruments to give a vivid sense of the cultural milieu of the late 16th century, in which Caravaggio was fortunate enough to find himself.

title: The Bush Disaster
description: When has a President responded so feebly to the challenge of historic change? When has the idea of American leadership been so mocked?

title: Arkla Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $21,233,000 for the quarter and $23,321,000 for the year. c-Net income d-After losses from discontinued operations of $7,530,000 and $7,530,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said the latest quarter's income from continuing operations of $68,064,000, or 76 cents a share, included aftertax writedowns associated with a restructuring plan and a $54.7 million book gain from the initial public offering of Arkla Exploration Co. stock. The company also said the latest year's loss from continuing operations of $60,943,000 included aftertax writedowns associated with a restructuring plan but they were not immediately avaiable to specify the amount of the writedowns.

title: On Stage
description: 'Salome' on the Way?

title: Review/Art;   Clothes From the Turn of a Different Century
description: Clothes may make the man or the woman, but they can also make history tantalizingly real, telling tales of the social, economic and political milieus that produced them. At the moment, two exhibitions that focus on French attire of the late 18th and early 19th centuries allow clothes to do just this, although by quite different routes.

title: Review/Dance;   Trocks in Graham Parody and 'Swan' Duet
description: The two best entries on the second program of Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo are ''Anarchic Heart,'' a parody of Martha Graham, and the ''Black Swan'' pas de deux from ''Swan Lake.''

title: Emil Dolensek, 49, Veterinarian For Zoological Society, Is Dead
description: Emil P. Dolensek, chief veterinarian of the New York Zoological Society, died of a melanoma Wednesday at his home on City Island in the Bronx. He was 49 years old.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Romania Is Prohibiting Adoption by Foreigners
description: In response to several thousand inquiries from American families, the Romanian Embassy said today that the Bucharest Government had decided to bar the adoption of Romanian orphans by foreigners.

title: Marsh Supermarkets Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 6
description: Year-ago periods ended Jan. 7.

title: INSIDE
description: Senator Denies Wrongdoing

title: M/A-Com Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $73,890,000. The latest first quarter's loss included estimated restructuring charges and provisions for contract losses of about $43.5 million. c-Net income

title: XL-Datacomp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an aftertax $4.8 million, or 40 cents a share, one-time gain relating to the company's contract settlement with International Business Machines Corp.

title: Auctions
description: The African art collection of Harry A. Franklin, a Los Angeles textile executive who became an art dealer in the 1950's, is to be auctioned on April 21 at Sotheby's in New York. Mr. Franklin continued to buy art with his wife, Ruth, and his daughter, Valerie Franklin-Nordin, until shortly before his death in 1983 at the age of 79.

title: Top Savings Bailout Official Said to Consider Resigning
description: Daniel P. Kearney, the president and chief executive of the Resolution Trust Corporation's Oversight Board, has threatened to resign the position he has held for only a few weeks because of differences with the Treasury Department, Government officials said today.

title: LAWYER CONVICTED IN ABDUCTION PLOT
description: A Federal jury here has found a lawyer from Florida guilty of plotting the vengeful abduction of a Jackson multimillionaire's wife, who has not been seen since she disappeared from her home 19 months ago.

title: Watkins Defends Policy on Warming
description: Energy Secretary James D. Watkins today offered a vigorous defense of the Bush Administration's policy on global warming, asserting that all top policy makers agreed on the President's approach.

title: Review/Film;   International Adaptation Of Novel By Turgenev
description: Can a 19th-century Russian aristocrat played by an American actor find happiness with an Italian woman living in Germany? What will happen after he is seduced by a Russian femme fatale played by a German actress? What language will the children speak, and more to the point, what might a Polish director do with this French-Italian co-production?
