In ''Torrents of Spring,'' Jerzy Skolimowski's adaptation of Turgenev's novel about a passionate triangle, love takes on all the excitement of the most laboriously translated United Nations meeting.

title: Admiral Named for Top Post
description: Presiden tBush will nominate Adm. Frank B. Kelso 2d to be the new Chief of Naval Operations, the White House announced Wednesday in San Francisco, where the President was traveling. Admiral Kelso, now commander in chief of the Navy's Atlantic Command and supreme Allied commander for the Atlantic, would succeed Adm. Carlisle A.H. Trost, whose term expires June 30. Admiral Kelso is 56 years old, a native of Fayetteville, Tenn., and a 1956 graduate of the Naval Academy.

title: Dennis McIntyre Memorial
description: A memorial service for the playwright Dennis McIntyre is to be held at 1 P.M. tomorrow at the Astor Place Theater, 434 Lafayette Street. Arvin Brown, artistic director of the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, Conn., and the actor Jeffrey DeMunn are among those scheduled to take part.

title: Economic Scene;   Catch-Up Game For Gorbachev
description: ''THERE go the people. I must follow them for I am their leader,'' said Alexandre Ledru-Rollin during the 1848 revolution in France.

title: U.S. Fears a Terrorist Attack
description: The United States expressed fears today that a terrorist attack against its interests in Western Europe could take place on or near Sunday, the 11th anniversary of the Iranian revolution.

title: A Soviet Disunion?
description: Fortified by his remarkable triumph over old-line Communists at the Central Committee plenum, Mikhail Gorbachev now faces an equally daunting challenge - holding the Soviet Union together. Having let go the empire in Eastern Europe, he confronts separatist movements that threaten to splinter his own Union into its constituent republics.

title: A New Battleground for I.B.M.
description: The International Business Machines Corporation next week will introduce one of its most significant new product lines ever, a new family of computer work stations.

title: Family Members Leave At Seaman Furniture
description: The Seaman Furniture Company announced yesterday that Morton Seaman, its chief executive, and Jeffrey Seaman, its president, would leave the company founded by their family in the early 1930's. Appointed to lead the company was Matthew D. Serra, who has resigned as president and chief executive of G. Fox, a department store chain based in Hartford.

title: Unum Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Figures for 1988 are restated to reflect adoption of SFAS 97 during the first quarter of 1989.

title: Metrobank reports earnings for 12mo Dec 31
Female Pilots Recall Bullets
description: Two female helicopter pilots rushing United States troops into combat came under heavy gunfire during the Panamanian invasion, the pilots said today in a new indication of the exposure of Army women to combat in Panama.

title: Seau to Enter Draft
description: He became the ninth junior this winter to declare himself eligible for the National Football League draft in April, but the first one named Junior to do so. Junior Seau, Southern California's all-America linebacker, said yesterday he would pass up his final year of college eligibility.(AP)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * BMR Financial Group Inc., Atlanta, and First Chattanooga Financial Corp., Chattanooga, Tenn., said they would merge in a deal worth more than $76 million.

title: World Public Opinion Also a Panamy Casualty;   Latin Anger
description: To the Editor:

title: World Public Opinion Also a Panama Casualty
description: To the Editor:

title: Diner's Journal
description: Paring More Than Potatoes

title: Jailed Players Released
description: Two South Carolina football players arrested on charges of illegally betting on college and professional basketball games and on pro football games, were released yesterday from jail in Columbia, S.C., on $1,000 bond each.

title: Beatrice Witkin, 73; Electronic Composer
description: Beatrice Witkin, a composer of electronic music, died of complications from the flu on Wednesday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital. She was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Summit Health Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Reviews/Film;   On the Road With a Homicidal Whoopi Goldberg
description: Whoopi Goldberg remains one of the great unclassifiable beings on the current movie scene. And ''Homer and Eddie,'' which opens today at the Eastside Cinema, isn't about to make things any better. This time she's a homicidal, recently escaped mental patient who has a brain tumor and only a month to live.

title: Great Southern Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Per share earnings for all periods not available because the company went public on Dec. 21.

title: Westchester Panel Votes to Avoid Layoffs
description: The Westchester Legislature's budget committee agreed today to avoid layoffs of more than 400 county employees by restoring $14.5 million to the 1990 county budget.

title: Home National Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Nature's Forces Unleashed, in Miniature
description: Odd things are happening at the World Financial Center. Tornado clouds are rising, pendulums are wildly twitching, electronic flowers are blooming, and voices and faces are being distorted beyond recognition.

title: Tenneco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $775,000,000, or $5.53 a share, and $823,000,000, or $5.66 a share, for the quarter and year, respectively, from the sale of oil and gas business. Year-ago quarter and full-year loss from continuing operations included after tax special charges of $199 million from the pipeline group, the farm and construction equipment group and chemicals and minerals group.

title: First Federal Bancorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest periods' results included one-time, non-recurring charges of $1.8 million, including a $1.1 million provision for loan losses, a loss on the disposition of assets and expenses related to settlement of an employment contract and retirement benefits for a retired officer.

title: A Gravity Boost to Goal: Jupiter '95
description: Completing the first leg of a long interplanetary journey, the Galileo spacecraftwill swing by Venus early tomorrow in a maneuver using the planet's gravity to get a boost in velocity and a change in trajectory so it can reach its ultimate target, Jupiter, in 1995.

title: Burlington Railroad in Soviet Pact
description: The Burlington Northern Railroad said this week that it had reached an agreement with the Ministry of Railways of the Soviet Union to exchange information that could make both rail systems more efficient.

title: Region Grapples With Sluggish Sales-Tax Revenues
description: Like seers pondering the auguries, economists and government officials in Connecticut, New York and New Jersey are sifting through sales-tax receipts for a vision of the region's future.

title: Adversaries at the Table: The Labor Negotiators
description: Like players, they have distinctive styles. Like owners, they have distinctive interests.

title: Weicker Sees Possible Run For Governor
description: Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s last address to Connecticut, the state he represented in the Senate for 18 years, was a concession speech here in Town Hall on the cold afternoon of Nov. 9, 1988. As his supporters stood stunned and his wife, Claudia, held back tears, Mr. Weicker spoke of ''no excuses, no regrets, no griping, no comebacks.'' His final word was ''goodbye.''

title: Chronicle
description: STANLEY BREZENOFF, the former First Deputy Mayor of New York City, will continue to work on health-care policy when he joins the Commonwealth Fund as a senior program adviser on Feb. 20. Before taking the Deputy Mayor's job, Mr. Brezenoff, 52, served as the president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation from 1981 to 1984.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Flags! Horns! Costa Rica!
description: To people in the U.S., Central America seems a region of unrelieved violence and insecurity, dominated by extremists and peopled by death squads, drug lords, shadowy agents and assorted pistoleros. To the visitor, Costa Rica thus comes as not just a pleasant surprise but a genuine shock. Wedged between Panama and Nicaragua, this little nation, no bigger than Vermont and New Hampshire, seems literally to revel in democracy.

title: Where Love Can Bloom
description: Given the freedom, funds and felicitous companionship, one could get an exhilarating head start on St. Valentine's Day (which is Wednesday) this weekend. One possible scenario could begin late on Friday afternoon.

title: Hasidic Rabbi Shot in Head As Attacker Steals His Car
description: A leading rabbi in a Brooklyn Hasidic sect was shot in the head and critically wounded before dawn yesterday by a man who stole his car, the police said.

title: New England Bank
description: The Bank of New England Corporation said it had revised its agreement to sell its Banc New England Leasing Group unit and $500 million of the unit's lease portfolio to Bank of Tokyo for $92.5 million. The company said $30 million would be paid in a two-year promissory note, with principal payments of $15 million each scheduled for Dec. 31, 1990, and Dec. 31, 1991.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY

title: Bishop Repeated Church Teaching to Governor;   Under Another Rubric
description: To the Editor:

title: Plymouth Five Cents Savings reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included charge of $561,000 from writedown of real estate acquired through foreclosure for quarter and year. c-Net income

title: Reviews/Film;   Hackman and Aykroyd in 'Loose Cannons'
description: In today's cop-buddy movie, Bob Clark's ''Loose Cannons,'' Gene Hackman and Dan Aykroyd play a suitably mismatched pair attached to the Washington police department.

title: You Could Call It Baseball
description: rrWell, it looks as if the dunderheads who run major league baseball will find a way to have their labor dispute even with television spewing out more money than anybody ever imagined.

title: Eldorado Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Monroe Last of '73 Title Knicks To Be Elected to Hall of Fame
description: Earl (the Pearl) Monroe, who worked his magic on the pro basketball courts for 13 seasons, was elected to the Basketball Hall of Fame yesterday along with Elvin Hayes, Dave Bing and the late Neil Johnston.

title: Upheaval in the East: Diplomacy;   Baker Meets in Moscow On Arms and Afghans
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d opened talks today with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, by setting out a variety of arms control initiatives, as well as a new American proposal for solving the Afghan conflict.

title: CBS Gives Rooney a 3-Month Suspension for Remarks
description: CBS News yesterday suspended Andy Rooney, the ''60 Minutes'' commentator, for three months without pay and left his future at the network uncertain in response to complaints that he had made remarks offensive to blacks and homosexuals.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Contel Corp., Atlanta, a telecommunications company, announced the retirement of Don D. Pitts as vice president and treasurer.

title: New York Times Company Reports 4th-Quarter Loss
description: The New York Times Company yesterday reported a loss of $19 million in the fourth quarter, compared with net income of $50.4 million, or 64 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1988.

title: Rescue Was Slowed By Too Much Help, Report on Crash Says
description: An overabundance of volunteer workers, bystanders and firefighters - some responding from fire departments as far away as New Jersey - hampered rescue operations when a Colombian jetliner crashed on Long Island two weeks ago, officials said today.

title: Justin Acquisition Sought by Choctaw
description: Choctaw Securities L.P., an investment partnership based in Kansas City, Mo., said it would ''seek to negotiate a mutually agreeable acquisition'' with the management of Justin Industries. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Choctaw said it had held discussions with financing sources for a possible bid.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Hard Feelings for Communist Faithful
description: Anatoly S. Pankov, a Communist candidate in local legislative elections next month, is not elated about the announcement on Wednesday that his party is willing to give up its 70-year monopoly on power. It is not that he views the decision as a threat to his election. But he says he is afraid that the step comes too late to save the party from further decline, and possibly open division.

title: Israeli in Prague for Talks
description: The Israeli Foreign Minister, Moshe Arens, arrived in Prague today for a three-day visit to discuss the resumption of diplomatic ties with Czechoslovakia. Except for Romania, all Eastern bloc countries followed Moscow in breaking diplomatic relations with Israel in 1967 after the Middle East War. Mr. Arens is expected to sign an agreement on resuming relations with his Czechoslovak counterpart, Jiri Dienstbier.

title: Cubic Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $151,000, or 2 cents a share. The company said its 1988 amounts have been reclassified to reflect the sale of a subsidiary, G.S. Parsons Co., as a discontinued operation.

title: Ford Settles A Mexican Walkout
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it had resolved some of its labor problems in Mexico by reaching a tentative contract agreement with workers at an engine plant in Chihuahua.

title: Bergen County Official Won't Seek Re-election
description: The first Bergen County Executive, William D. McDowell, announced today that he would not seek re-election.

title: Havens for the Heart in a Hard-Boiled City
description: ROMANTIC, in the traditional sense of the word, is not how one expects a casual observer to describe New York City circa 1990. Our steely, impetuous metropolis plays hard to get with new suitors, in contrast to her soft and pretty cousins like Paris, Rome and Barcelona - a saucy Katharine Hepburn to a come-hither Lana Turner. Those who seek amorous milieus during Valentine's week need to pierce the city's tough-cookie exterior, to call its bluff, to grab it by the elbow in that Cary Grant you're-driving-me-to-drink-young-lady fashion.

title: Textron Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $9,500,000 related to arbitration concerning terminated co-production agreement. c-Included extraordinary losses of $8,000,000 and $28,000,000 related to arbitration concerning former line of business for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also included an extraordinary loss of $9,700,000 from early redemption of debt.

title: Dining Out Guide: Informal
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current. Arizona 206 Cafe Diner's Journal (Dec. 26, 1986), 206 East 60th Street (838-0440) - A smart and neighborly annex to the three-star Arizona 206, the cafe features an all-day menu of 12 to 14 specials designed for sharing. The Southwestern-inspired items include yellow-and-blue-corn muffins; a Southern-fried catfish sandwich with fruit mole; lobster-and-crayfish pasta with Creole-cream sauce; chili rellenos with seafood and wild mushrooms, and three-corn fried alligator served with ancho-garlic sauce. Menu from $1.50 to $14. Hours: Noon to midnight Monday to Saturday, 5 to 11 P.M. Sunday. Chantal Cafe

title: Old Republic Intl reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-Included net charge of $39.6 million for increasing title insurance claim reserves for quarter and year.

title: Senate, 92 to 4, Wants U.S. Data On Crimes That Spring From Hate
description: The Senate approved legislation today that would require the Federal Government to collect statistics on crimes motivated by prejudice based on race, ethnicity, religion or sexual orientation.

title: Bush Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included gains of $338,000, or 9 cents a share, from change in method of accounting.

title: Flower, at 120 Million Years, Is Oldest
description: A tiny fossilized plant, barely one inch tall and resembling today's black pepper plant, has been identified by scientists at Yale University as the oldest known flower. It lived 120 million years ago and its flower was probably a drab green or beige - hardly the thing to inspire nosegays for dinosaurs.

title: Tenneco Net Down 65.7%
description: Tenneco Inc., the diversified energy company, said today that its fourth-quarter earnings fell 65.7 percent from the final quarter of 1988, when it had a $775 million one-time gain from the sale of its oil and gas businesses.

title: Texas Coach Enjoys View From Top
description: Jody Conradt stepped around the desk in her new office, simultaneously welcoming a visitor and apologizing for the clutter. After 13 years on the ground floor, Conradt, the 55-year-old women's basketball coach at the University of Texas, was moving into a penthouse office that offered a breathtaking view of the campus and downtown Austin.

title: Islanders Frustrate Flyers
description: When the 5-5 tie between the Islanders and the Philadelphia Flyers was finished in the Spectrum tonight, the New York players and coaches were talking about the goal judge, and the reporters were firing slap-shot-like questions in his direction.

title: End to Bush Observer Team's Role In Nicaraguan Vote Raises Debate
description: A decision to disband an official American delegation that was to observe the Nicaraguan elections has intensified a political battle shaping up over the fairness of the campaign.

title: Chill of Labor Impasse Threatens Baseball's Spring
description: The wintertime hopes of baseball players and fans could be shattered today. The owners of baseball's 26 clubs will meet in Chicago and are expected to carry out their threat to postpone the opening of spring training.

title: Bowie Kuhn Is Said to Be In Hiding
description: Bowie K. Kuhn, the former Commissioner of Baseball, is said to be somewhere in Florida, but not for spring training. In fact, a New York bank and several of his former law partners charged that he was hiding from the bankruptcy of the defunct law firm that bore his name.

title: Genteel Charleston Shakes Off Hugo And Starts Hurrying Toward Spring
description: On a visit to Charleston in 1880, Oscar Wilde and his host strolled through town just after dusk. The Irish author and wit remarked on the beauty of the moon rising over the harbor and the city.

title: Occidental's Notes
description: As part of its continuing debt restructuring, the Occidental Petroleum Corporation this week announced plans to redeem about $550 million of its outstanding 10 percent senior notes due in 1991 at a price of 100. The notes were issued March 1986, and the company said the interest payment due on March 15, 1990, would be paid in the usual manner to registered note holders of record on March 1. Payment of the redemption will made on or after March 15, 1990.

title: Avon Proxy Fight Sought
description: Turning up the pressure on Avon Products Inc., an investment partnership said today that it planned to wage a proxy fight to gain four of the 11 seats on the board of the door-to-door cosmetics company.

title: Bishop Repeated Church Teaching to Governor;   Vote of Confidence
description: To the Editor:

title: Food Lion Inc. reports earnings for 16wks to Dec 31
description: The company said the gains in net in the latest quarter was in part related to the $500,000 decrease in LIFO reserve, compared with a $5.9 million increase in such reserve in the year- ago period.

title: Market Place;   First Interstate Looks for Capital
description: THE old line used to be that a banker would lend any amount of money, so long as the borrower could prove he did not need it. Now it is the bank that needs the money, and the question is whether stock buyers will provide it.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: At the Bar
description: Along Court Street in Brooklyn, in the high-rise rookeries where trial lawyers congregate, there are 65 years' worth of Izzy Halpern stories.

title: Ammirati's President Will Leave
description: ONLY a month after arranging its buyback from the Omnicom Group, Ammirati & Puris, an advertising agency that has been bathed in respect but buffeted by recent turmoil, announced that Edward H. Vick was resigning as its president.

title: Convex Computer Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $297,000, or 2 cents a share, for both the quarter and year. c-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $353,000, or 2 cents a share. The company said that results for the quarter reflect additional sales resulting from the joint sales and marketing relationship with Control Data Corp. The company also said it achieved significant growth in 1989 through an expansion of its business, the success of its product strategy and major market expansion throughout the world.

title: Freeport-McMoran
description: Freeport-McMoran Resource Partners L.P., which is 62 percent owned by Freeport-McMoran Inc., said it had signed an agreement to sell its nitrogen fertilizer assets to the new Agricultural Minerals Corporation for about $230 million in cash and the assumption of liabilities. Freeport-McMoran Resource said it would realize about $275 million from the transaction. Its employees would be retained by Agricultural Minerals.

title: Sequestering a Jury: The Chances a Judge Takes
description: When the judge at the John Gotti assault trial decided to sequester the jurors for the length of the trial, he took a calculated risk.

title: Inquiry Into Mail Bombings Focuses on 1972 Case
description: Opening a new avenue in the investigation of mail bombings in the South, Federal investigators today searched the home of a man convicted on felony bomb possession charges in 1972.

title: Rabid Raccoons Are on Way
description: Raccoons carrying the deadly rabies virus have been found dangerously close to the New York border, prompting state officials to issue a rabies warning. Rabid raccoons are threatening the state's Southern Tier, portions of the mid-Hudson Valley and New York City, the officials said, and raccoon rabies is expected to enter New York State from Pennsylvania this spring. People who work with animals were advised to be vaccinated.

title: Review/Film;   Faithfully Recording The Lives Of Friends
description: In ''New Year's Day,'' Henry Jaglom, who writes, directs and stars in his own films, remains his own tireless Boswell. Undaunted by an often indifferent public, he faithfully records the banalities of his own life and those of his friends, who often play themselves when the movie versions are made.

title: Kansas State Surges to Upset Missouri by 65-58
description: Steve Henson and Jean Derouillere led an 18-2 run late in the second half tonight that carried Kansas State to a 65-58 victory over top-ranked Missouri.

title: Lebanese Weigh Intervention in Christian Enclave
description: President Elias Hrawi conferred with aides on a possible military intervention in the war-torn Christian enclave today as sporadic clashes and sharp political disagreement kept tension high between rival Christian factions.

title: A Row House Is Set Afire; Bias Is Cited
description: A week after it was sold to a black couple, a two-family house in a predominantly white section of Brooklyn was set on fire early yesterday in what Police and Fire Department officials called an apparent case of racially motivated arson.

title: Bolar Suspends Shipment Of All Prescription Drugs
description: The Bolar Pharmaceutical Company, a large generic drug company that last week recalled its best-selling product, has temporarily suspended shipment of all its prescription drugs while it negotiates with the Food and Drug Administration on auditing more of its operations, an agency official said today.

title: Cross (A.T.) Co.  (A) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Drug Lawyers' Quandary: Lure of Money vs. Ethics
description: Lured by huge fees, glamorous clients and the explosion of drug prosecutions, a fraternity of lawyers specializing in drug cases is flourishing, especially in places like South Florida, Texas and Los Angeles.

title: Fair for Teen-Agers
description: Teen-agers who are now thinking about their summer vacations may want to attend the Teen Summer Opportunities Fair, noon to 4 P.M. on Sunday, at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. Among the organizations represented are to be the Usdan Camp for the Performing Arts, the American Youth Hostel and Longacre, a group that specializes in wilderness and community-service programs. Information: 415-5600.

title: Berkeley Journal;   Art Contest Resurrects Memories Of 1964
description: In 1964 at the University of California at Berkeley, a police car was pressed into service as a podium after hundreds of students, blocking the arrest of a civil rights organizer, trapped it on a campus plaza. Leaders of the newly formed Free Speech Movement climbed atop the dented car, demanding the right to set up campaign tables on campus.

title: Playboy Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $207,000, or 2 cents a share, and $1,899,000, or 20 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Included tax credits of $586,000, or 6 cents a share, and $735,000, or 8 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES

title: Mumford Kept His Vision as the American Dream Went Awry
description: To the Editor:

title: Alan J. Perlis, 67; Helped to Develop Computer Science
description: Alan J. Perlis, an educator and a leader in the development of computer science, died of a heart attack Wednesday at Yale-New Haven Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in Woodbridge, Conn.

title: Review/Film;   Coming of Age as a Gypsy With a Turkey for a Friend
description: One of the roles in Emir Kusturica's ''Time of the Gypsies'' is played by a turkey, and the word role is not used lightly. The turkey actually plays a part. For a time, he is the pet and companion of Perhan (Davor Dujmovic), the oafish, naive and highly sensitive gypsy boy who is this coming-of-age film's hero; after that, the turkey winds up in a pot. And after that, the turkey reappears in a magical way, as one of the many omens and miracles that shape Perhan's vision of the world. Not the least of the miracles associated with this film is that it received the best director award at the Cannes Film Festival last year.

title: The Details Come Out In Latest Infiniti Spots
description: The latest television commercials from Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos for Nissan's Infiniti open with - no surprise - scenes of nature. But then come the car and hard statistics - 278 horsepower, a 4.5-liter engine - satisfying dealers who have been screaming for details since the Zen-like campaign made its debut last fall.

title: Review/Theater;   Bogosian Illuminates Life in the City
description: It's not news that Eric Bogosian is a great talent, a chameleon actor and penetrating social observer whose one-man shows have staked out their own mean streets in the crowded 1980's theatrical territory inhabited by Lily Tomlin, Spalding Gray, Whoopi Goldberg and so many others, from stand-up comedians to sit-down performance artists. Nor will it be news that ''Sex, Drugs, Rock & Roll,'' Mr. Bogosian's new show at the Orpheum, follows the format of such preceding recitals as ''Fun House'' and ''Drinking in America.'' Once again the actor appears in black jeans, sneakers and white shirt to take the audience on a nonstop 90-minute tour through the mental states of men who live in these United States.

title: Review/Cabaret;   A Little Porter Amid a Little Bit Of Everything
description: Ann Hampton Callaway is a singer, pianist and songwriter who does everything from impressions of Sarah Vaughan and Billie Holiday to the spontaneous improvisation of original songs based on audience suggestions. She also has the distinction of being the only person to share a songwriting credit with Cole Porter.

title: Community National Bancorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Per share earnings and shares outstanding for 1988 have been readjusted to reflect 1-for-10 stock split on July 29, 1989.

title: Upheaval in the East: Romania;   In Timisoara, Doubts and Vigils Amid Melted Wax
description: All morning and across mid-winter's lengthening afternoon, scores of them come to Opera Square, maybe hundreds. The ritual is always the same.

title: Our Towns;   School Bus Crash Leaves 2 Dead And Questions
description: ''I thought it might be my daughter's bus,'' said Elizabeth Monroe, who stopped by the side of the road with a small bunch of flowers, daisies, she left as a memorial next to the huge tree that still bears a raw white scar where the bus crashed into it.

title: Upheaval in the East: East Germany;   East Germany Agrees to Pay Reparations to the Jewish Victims of the Nazis
description: East Germany, which has long refused to accept responsibility for the crimes of the Nazis against the Jews, has for the first time agreed to pay reparations to Jewish victims, the World Jewish Congress said yesterday.

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: Darman and Moynihan Joust Over Social Security
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Richard G. Darman, the White House budget director, faced off over Social Security today for the first time in a public forum.

title: Chaus (Bernard) Inc.(N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Net income c-Net loss

title: HOLIDAY ON MONDAY
description: Lincoln's Brithday will be celebrated Monday. Here are holiday schedules.

title: GOTTI NOT GUILTY ON ALL 6 CHARGES IN ASSAULT TRIAL
description: John Gotti, who has been described as an icon of the underworld and the nation's top Mafia boss, was pronounced not guilty of assault and conspiracy charges in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday.

title: Sports People: TENNIS;   An Honor for Evert
description: President Bush yesterday awarded the Flo Hyman Award for excellence in sports to Chris Evert, the recently retired tennis pro, calling her ''the role model for our nation's young women.''

title: Upheaval in the East: Hungary;   Hungarians and Vatican Restore Diplomatic Ties
description: After a rupture of four decades, the Vatican formally re-established diplomatic relations with Hungary today, and immediately began talking about doing the same before long with other Eastern-bloc nations.

title: Lydall Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $45,000 for the quarter and $1,083,000 for the year, and income of $40,000, or 1 cent a share, and a loss of $1,464,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, both from divestitures.

title: Review/Music;   Previn Fill In for Ozawa With the Boston
description: The Boston Symphony concerts Wednesday and Thursday nights at Carnegie Hall were originally to have been conducted by Seiji Ozawa, and to have offered a rather more interesting program than usual -Haydn's ''London'' Symphony, Yo-Yo Ma in Shostakovich's Cello Concerto No. 2 and, at the very end, Rossini's ''Semiramide'' Overture.

title: Douglas Long, Newspaper Executive, 65
description: Douglas Long, chairman of The Sunday Correspondent, a British weekly newspaper, and co-founder of the daily Independent, died of liver cancer on Wednesday. He was 65 years old. Mr. Long was deputy managing director of the Mirror Group of newspapers, whose flagship is The Daily Mirror, and in 1980 was made deputy chief executive of the group.

title: Tyson at 220 For Title Fight
description: Mike Tyson weighed in at 220 pounds today for his heavyweight title defense against James (Buster) Douglas, who weighed 231 1/2.

title: Prices of Treasury Securities Soar
description: Treasury securities prices soared yesterday as investors rushed to lock in yields, which have been tumbling since the conclusion of this week's refunding auctions. Dealers said the same high yields that led to the successful sale of $30 billion of Treasury notes and bonds attracted investors to the secondary market in these issues.

title: Canadian Tire reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $1,869,000 for the quarter and $4,928,000 for the year, and an extraordinary credit of $862,000, or 1 cent a share, for both the quarter and year. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Elizabeth Bryan Patten, Civic Leader, 82
description: Elizabeth Bryan Patten, a Chattanooga philanthropist and civic leader, died Thursday at Memorial Hospital in Chattanooga. She was 82 years old.

title: One-Person Protest On City Hall Porch Inspires Top Official
description: A woman, distraught because New York did not reimburse her for expenses in raising her grandson under a foster-care program, left the boy and her own small son on the steps of City Hall yesterday, setting off a flurry that led to a meeting with Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch.

title: Mandela Meets With Anti-Apartheid Coalition
description: Anti-apartheid campaigners spent several hours today meeting with the black nationalist leader Nelson Mandela on developments in the anti-apartheid movement.

title: Callers Besiege CBS Over Rooney
description: CBS was deluged with telephone calls yesterday, some from people supporting Andy Rooney, others praising the network's three-month suspension of the ''60 Minutes'' commentator. Network spokesmen would not say exactly how many calls had been received.

title: The Owners Are Being Ingrates
description: In 1969, baseball was doomed, and I was sent to cover the story. This was my first spring training, and, possibly, my last, and maybe baseball's last, too. The grand old game - 100 years old as a profession then - was on its last legs. To many, the crack of the bat in the batting cage sounded like the pounding of nails in a coffin.

title: Robert W. Kistner, 72, Gynecologist, Is Dead
description: Dr. Robert W. Kistner, a Harvard Medical School professor who specialized in the treatment of endometriosis, a condition of the uterus that can cause infertility in women, was found dead Tuesday at his home at the Palm Beach Polo and Country Club in Wellington, Fla., where he lived in retirement. He was 72 years old.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with the Evening Hours column on Sunday misidentified the man with Julia Serena di Lapigio at a fund-raising party for the Spoleto Festival U.S.A. He was Charles S. Way Jr., chairman of the festival, not Karl Allison.

title: Baltimore Hospital to Start Drug Tests on Its Physicians
description: For the first time, a hospital will conduct random drug and alcohol tests on all doctors who deal directly with patients.

title: GORBACHEV ACCEPTS DEEP CUTS IN EUROPE IF FORCES ARE EQUAL; BAKER HINTS SHIFT ON GERMANY
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is prepared to accept President Bush's proposal for deeper troop cuts in Europe, but only if the plan leaves both countries with equal levels, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said this morning.

title: Hexcel Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $5 million pretax charge from an increase to reserves, related primarily to the planned 1990 reduction of resources dedicated to the military aerospace business for the quarter and year. c-Net income

title: Betsy J. Gootrad Becomes Bride
description: The marriage of Betsy Jane Gootrad to Dr. David Michael Kasper took place yesterday at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York. The Rev. F. Forrester Church performed the ceremony. The bride, 33 years old, is a daughter of Harold Gootrad of Paris and Helen Gootrad of New York. A graduate of Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass., she graduated cum laude from Harvard University and is a managing director of Fomon & Gootrad Holdings, money managers in New York. Her father is chairman of European Homes, a building concern in Paris, and of the Property Planning Group in New York.

title: Waste Law Is Challenged By New York
description: New York State said today that it would sue to overturn a Federal law that requires it to find a place to store low-level nuclear waste, but the move failed to placate angry residents of rural villages who fear their communities may become dump sites.

title: Review/Film;   Out of a Coma, Still Dapper and Disarming
description: In ''Hard to Kill,'' Steven Seagal, the latest and suavest inheritor of the Charles Bronson-Chuck Norris-Bruce Lee action-film mantle, comes out of a seven-year coma looking a lot better than most people would look going in. The tanned, trim, very carefully groomed Mr. Seagal, who sports a sleek ponytail and favors starched white shirts even though they often wind up with bloodstains, is significantly more dapper than the Los Angeles police detective he is supposed to be. But Mr. Seagal has an unforced, highly dangerous street-smart manner to offset any hint of softness. He is also very good at crunching bones.

title: Anchor Shortage
description: Dan Rather and Peter Jennings went to Moscow this week, but Tom Brokaw stayed home.

title: Ancient Roman Silver to Be Sold
description: Fourteen lavishly decorated vessels, said to be from the fourth to the fifth centuries and described as the largest and finest collection of ancient Roman silver ever uncovered, are being sold through Sotheby's. The presale estimate for the collection is $70 million.

title: Foodarama Supermarkets reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: b-Included a provision of 26 cents a share related to the writedown of assets on stores closed for the quarter and year.

title: Happy Occasions Give Rise To Gifts for the Neediest Cases
description: Celebrating an occasion of personal joy seems to bring out the charitable instinct in many people. Births, engagements, weddings, significant birthdays and anniversaries have all been cited with gifts to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Elegantly Triumphant, Gotti Greets Admirers
description: He left the courthouse through the judge's entrance, smiling and dapper like a triumphant politician, and the press and the crowd of admirers were waiting, as always, to pay homage to this man with the aura of invincibility.

title: Patents;   Bill Seeks To Protect Gene Work
description: Imagine that a brewer has developed a low-alcohol beer with all the weight and flavor of a dark German lager. The crucial ingredient is a novel strain of yeast that he has spent years breeding and has patented. But just as sales are picking up, a French company begins importing a perfect imitation.

title: OHM Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Women Know How to Fight
description: LEAD: As Americans, we can count ourselves lucky that in this century the wars we have engaged in have barely touched our soil. But in all wars, there is at least one country that has to endure its ravages, and the women and children of that land face nearly the same hardships as the men who do the actual fighting.

title: Italian Bank for East Bloc
description: The Italian Cabinet approved a plan today to establish a financing company to promote joint ventures in Eastern Europe. The company, Simest S.p.A., will operate like a merchant bank. It will take minority stakes in joint ventures and participate in other industrial and commercial collaborations, mainly with small and medium-sized companies. Simest, which will initially focus on Poland and Hungary, will have starting capital of 98 billion lire, or $78 million, rising to 500 billion lire, or $400 million, within three years.

title: In Today's Housing Market, Is It Better to Buy or Rent?
description: The decision to own or to rent a home has traditionally been based on three elements: cost, personal preference and investment. But the recent decline in house and apartment prices has made a such an investment less of a sure thing and has helped to convert many potential buyers into renters, if only temporarily.

title: Missed Catch Is More Prized and Elusive
description: Lawyers offered varied explanations for John Gotti's most recent acquittal, ranging from the psyches of jurors to the myth-making of the media to the tawdriness of the case against him. Like all instant analyses, they made an outcome jurors wrestled over for four days seem all but inevitable.

title: Ritual of Political Cleansing in Japan
description: Looking gaunt and speaking in a hoarse voice, a politician viewed as among the most likely to become the next Prime Minister of Japan is reminding audiences that newspapers were all but writing his obituary last year.

title: Kodak Recycling
description: The Eastman Kodak Company announced it would begin recycling its Fling, Stretch and Weekend disposable cameras. The company said the program is intended to reduce solid waste. A New York public affairs research organization said last month that the cameras were among the worst examples of overpackaged and nonrecyclable consumer products.

title: RACIAL ARSON PULLS OFFICIALS INTO ALLIANCE
description: In an unusual demonstration of official solidarity, Mayor David N. Dinkins and a half-dozen Brooklyn politicians met at City Hall yesterday to pledge their help to a black man whose newly purchased house in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn was set afire Thursday in what the authorities say was racially motivated arson.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Cars With Blaring Radios Become a New York City Nuisance;   Holmes Had It Right
description: To the Editor:

title: Seized Materials Studied for Mail Bombing Clues
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 9 - Federal investigators today examined several boxes of materials and documents seized Thursday in the investigation of the Southern mail bomb attacks that killed two people in December.

title: Insurgents in Ethiopia Begin Anti-Government Offensive
description: The main rebel group fighting the Ethiopian Government began a long-expected military offensive on Thursday apparently aimed at forcing the Government out of the last piece of Eritrea that it still occupies.

title: Providence Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $187,000.

title: Survey of U.S. Jewish Leaders Finds Overwhelming Support for Israeli-P.L.O. Talks
description: Officials of American Jewish organizations, although highly distrustful of the Palestine Liberation Organization, say that Israel should talk to the P.L.O., a national survey has found.

title: Institution In Iowa Seized
description: Federal regulators took over the nearly $1 billion American Federal Savings and Loan Association of Des Moines today over concern that it could not meet its capital requirements.

title: Icahn on T.W.A. Woe: 'We're at Crossroads'
description: When Carl C. Icahn won control of Trans World Airlines in August 1985 he donned a pilot's uniform jacket in his office and shouted joyfully: ''We've got ourselves an airline! We've got ourselves an airline!'' These days, Mr. Icahn sounds far less jubilant as he tries to determine the course of a carrier whose fortunes have fallen considerably in the last year. T.W.A., which became profitable in 1987 and 1988, is expected to report a loss of about $150 million for 1989 even after counting a $150 million gain from the interest on its large amount of cash. And Mr. Icahn, an oft-distracted investor not known for the commitment of a longtime airline industry figure like Robert L. Crandall of American Airlines, is again asking himself whether T.W.A. can remain viable.

title: Walk-In Doctors' Offices: Care for Those in a Hurry
description: Storefront doctors' offices, where patients can be treated without appointments for all but the most serious medical problems, are thriving in many New York City neighborhoods.

title: Leaving Trenton, Cooperman Still Seeks Answers
description: New Jersey's Education Commissioner, Dr. Saul Cooperman, leaves office at the end of June, content that changes he has engineered have eased the state's teacher shortage, toughened tests for basic skills and allowed the state to take over troubled districts to try to improve education in them.

title: Upheaval in the East: A Troop-Cut Assent;   Gorbachev Accepts Vital Part of Plan By Bush to Reduce Forces in Europe
description: With his troop reduction proposal today, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has in effect accepted a key premise of the Bush Administration's troop reduction plan: that the United States should continue to maintain a large military presence in Europe.

title: New Study Sought on Boston Murder Case
description: Legislators and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis are backing a bill that would create a commission to investigate the way news organizations and the police coped with the events that began with the shooting death of Carol Stuart.

title: Inter-Tel Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
United States Actively Defends Human Rights in El Salvador;   Murder Is the Norm
description: To the Editor:

title: Louther Dance Theater
description: William Louther's Dance Theater Corporation will present ''Murder at the Town Hall'' today at 2 and 7 P.M. at the Kaufman Theater of the American Museum of Natural History. Mr. Louther, a former member of the companies of Martha Graham, Alvin Ailey and Donald McKayle, formed his own troupe in 1974 to enable actors, dancers and musicians to work together on projects. The piece is based on the first act of T. S. Eliot's ''Murder in the Cathedral,'' updated to New Orleans in the 1930's. Tickets are $15 and are available at the door. Reservations: 769-5172.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Lithuanian Parliament Calls Soviet Annexation Unlawful
description: The Lithuanian parliament has approved a resolution declaring Lithuania's 1940 annexation by the Soviet Union ''unlawful and invalid'' and seeking talks with Moscow on independence.

title: Crazy Eddie Arrest Order
description: A Federal district judge yesterday morning ordered the arrest of Eddie Antar, the founder of Crazy Eddie Inc., after Mr. Antar failed to make a court appearance in a civil case and also disregarded an order to return $52 million that the Government contends is illegal profits.

title: British Telecom reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings represented American Depositary Receipts (ADR); each ADR represents 10 shares of British Telecom ordinary stock. Results are in U.S. dollars; results have been expressed at an exchange rate of $1.61 to the pound, the rate prevailing on Dec. 31, 1989, the last date of the reporting period.

title: Upheaval in the East: The Germans;   EAST BERLIN'S RUIN PREDICTED IN BONN
description: A senior adviser to Chancellor Helmut Kohl said today that East Germany might become insolvent in a few days. But spokesmen for the Governments of East and West Germany rejected the statement, as did bankers and diplomats.

title: Why Isn't Nelson Mandela Free?
description: Almost a week after President F. W. de Klerk pledged to release him, Nelson Mandela remains imprisoned in South Africa. A visit by Jesse Jackson, the black American leader, has become the latest excuse for keeping the black South African leader in custody. When Mr. Jackson arrived Wednesday, a Government spokesman said it was unlikely Mr. Mandela would be released during the eight days of the American's visit.

title: Review/Dance;   French Baroque Synthesis Of Dance, Music and Dress
description: Music and dance were allied in France during the 17th and 18th centuries. Theatrical spectacles combined singing, dancing and poetry, and instrumental pieces were often based upon dance forms. People could both listen to minuets in concert halls and dance them in ballrooms. This union of the arts was emphasized in ''French Baroque: Dance and Music for the Dance,'' which the Vineyard Theater presented Tuesday night at the Dimson Theater.

title: The Perfect Rose
description: The traditional Valentine is the red rose. One can say it all, but a dozen are always welcome.

title: CHRONICLE
description: No wonder RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI hasn't declared his intentions about running for Governor of New York. The latest Marist College poll, a highly regarded statewide poll, released yesterday, shows GOV. MARIO M. CUOMO running ahead of Mr. Giuliani by 60 percent to 26 percent. Mr. Cuomo was given a favorable rating by 64 percent of the 639 registered voters in the poll.

title: Reagan to Give Tape Testimony On Iran-Contra
description: Lawyers for former President Ronald Reagan said today that he would provide videotaped testimony about his role in the Iran-contra affair, the first time since the episode became public that Mr. Reagan has agreed to furnish a detailed public explanation of his actions.

title: Three Korean Parties Merge, Setting Off Student Protests
description: The governing party and two opposition groups completed a merger today that gives them a huge majority in Parliament, and students responded with protests, firebombs and rocks.

title: Backloading: Not So Benign
description: Buy now, pay later. That's the premise behind ''backloading,'' the practice that aides to Mayor David Dinkins of New York say they're considering. With the city facing the one-two punch of a $1 billion deficit and expiring labor contracts, City Hall may try to save money up front by delaying wage increases. That sounds practical, and in fact backloading isn't necessarily evil. But it can be dangerous.

title: Voplex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Burmese Troops Said to Win Battle for Rebel Stronghold
description: Government troops have overrun a stronghold of minority rebels along the Thai border after 10 days of fighting in which at least 36 people were killed, a military spokesman said today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BARBARA BUSH is lending her home and her prestige to a cause close to her heart, the eradication of illiteracy in America. Tomorrow night she will be host to the National Literacy Honors, a program that recognizes reading tutors and their successful pupils.

title: Denison Mines reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $99,068,000, which represented a $125 million writedown of oil and gas properties and a $25,932,000 gain on the sale of an interest in Standard Trustco Ltd. Results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Photo: Workers searching the shoreline at Newport Beach, Calif., for splotches of oil that washed ashore from the tanker American Trader. (Associated Press); Map of western California showing location of Newport Beach.;   Hundreds Cleaning Oil-Stained Beaches
description: Hundreds of workers in yellow slickers, carrying oversized paper towels, patrolled the beaches south of here today picking up shiny, coin-size gobs of oil. But the weather continued to hold the bulk of Wednesday's tanker spill a few miles offshore.

title: Bond Fails to Remove Breweries' Receiver
description: Bond Corporation Holdings Ltd., the flagship company of the Australian entrepreneur Alan Bond, failed today to persuade a court to free its Australian breweries from receivership.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In Washington State, SENATOR JIM WEST struck a blow for romance after his proposal to make it illegal for couples under 18 to engage in ''heavy petting'' failed to make it out of committee last week. He succeeded in another proposal: during a State Senate session Mr. West, a Republican from Spokane, sent a note to GINGER MARSHALL, who was watching from the gallery. She nodded yes.

title: Upheaval in the East;   To the West, Parties Applaud, Warily
description: Struggling to adjust to events in Eastern Europe, Western Europe's leading Communist parties have seen themselves forced to applaud the crisis convulsing international Communism to preserve some credibility before their own democratic electorates.

title: Surajkund Journal;   Where India Would Make Fun, It Makes Enemies
description: Not far from here, on more than 28,000 acres of rocks and dust that languished uncoveted for centuries under the Indian sun, the opening shots have been fired in a battle that could determine how the recreational needs of nearby New Delhi will be met in the next century.

title: Smith International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $3.2 million pretax charge related to accounting for inventory under LIFO method and an additional $1.2 million pretax provision for additional contamination cleanup at the company's former Irvine, Calif., manufacturing facility. c-Net income and included positive impact of $666,000, pretax, as a result of adopting the local currency as the functional currency for certain of the company's international operations. d-Included pretax charge of $23.4 million for costs associated with the company's decision to close its Irvine, Calif.-based operations and to consolidate all U.S. manufacturing into Oklahoma and Texas. It also included a pretax gain of $2,208,000, or 8 cents a share, as a result of adopting the local currency as the functional currency in certain of the company's international operations.

title: Moses Training For '92 Games
description: Seventeen months after his last race, Edwin Moses said today that he intended to return to competition this year and continue running through the 1992 Olympics in Barcelona, Spain.

title: Y.&R. Pleads Guilty in Bribe Case
description: Young & Rubicam Inc., one of the world's largest advertising agencies, pleaded guilty yesterday and agreed to pay a $500,000 fine to settle the Federal Government's charge that starting in 1981 it had engaged in a conspiracy to bribe foreign officials to obtain and hold the Jamaican Government's tourism account.

title: Iowa-Illinois Gas & Elec.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Enron Oil & Gas reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Drug-Shooting Casualty Inspires a City to Resist
description: Last weekend, volunteers from a local drug rehabilitation program patched and painted the 35 bullet holes in a pink and white stucco bungalow on Westminister Avenue here, where 60-year-old C. W. Roddy was wounded slightly by gunfire on New Year's Eve.

title: Morrison Knudsen Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $32,650,000 for the quarter and $90,119,000 for the year.

title: Hon Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Included a pretax charge of $19.3 million for costs to restructure and downsize Corryhiebert Corp., a unit, for the quarter and year. c-Net income d-Included income from discontinued operations of $8,433,000, or 45 cents a share and $9,515,000, or 51 cents a share, for the quarter and year. The income from discontinued operations for both periods included gain of $8,269,000 from sale of subsidiary.

title: Sports People: BASEBALL;   Yanks and Guetterman Agree on a Contract
description: For the third straight day, the Yankees and one of their relief pitchers avoided arbitration by settling on a contract. The agreement left the Yankees with no more arbitration cases.

title: Photography Confirms Peary's Pole Claim
description: To the Editor:

title: Disney Bans Commercials At Showings of Its Films
description: The Walt Disney Company is giving theatergoers a bonus - no commercials with its movies. That may please some moviegoers, but cinema advertising executives and theater owners are unhappy.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Colgate-Palmolive Co., the consumer products company, said it would form a joint venture in Portugal with the Unisol division of Quimigal, a state-owned Portuguese company that sells household products. Colgate will own 70 percent of the venture.

title: Florida Airport in Race With Growth
description: The ponds, palm trees and other oasis-like amenities of Orlando International Airport are under siege. Thousands of construction workers, hundreds of trucks with tons of dirt and concrete, and 45,000 passengers pour in and out of the airport every day.

title: News Summary
description: International 3-8

title: Bond Sale Is Postponed By Nabisco
description: In another indication of the weakness in the market for ''junk bonds,'' RJR Nabisco Inc., whose $4 billion in securities dominate the high-yield market, has postponed a $1.25 billion junk bond offering.

title: Big Cocaine Seizure in Mexico
description: The authorities have seized nearly 4,000 pounds of cocaine from a drug ring that was run out of a Mexico City prison with the support of five corrupt police officers, including two members of the country's special anti-narcotics force, the Attorney General's Office said today.

title: John H. Poelker, Ex-St. Louis Mayor, 76
description: John H. Poelker, an accountant who served one term as Mayor after 10 years as comptroller, died today after a long struggle against cancer. He was 76 years old.

title: Atomic Workers' Suit Cleared by U.S. Judge
description: A Federal judge has cleared the way for trial of a decade-old suit by former Nevada Test Site workers and their survivors who contend that the workers contracted cancer and other diseases from nuclear weapons testing.

title: No Camps Without Agreement, Owners Say
description: Negotiators for the owners of the 26 major league baseball clubs studiously avoided the word ''lockout'' today as they reaffirmed that they would not open spring training camps until they had a new labor agreement with the players.

title: Fed Decision Is Disclosed On Easing Interest Rates
description: Federal Reserve policy makers decided at their December meeting on a further easing of their high-interest-rate policies because of the sluggish economy, according to minutes released today.

title: Gibraltar Files Chapter 11
description: The Gibraltar Financial Corporation, the parent of two savings and loan associations seized by the Government last year, said on Thursday that it had sought protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 10, 1990
description: The Economy

title: Motorists Demand A Better Seat Belt
description: While more and more air bags are being installed in new cars to enhance safety and to comply with Federal law, auto makers are scrambling to satisfy rising consumer demand for improved seat-belt design.

title: Review/Television;   A Model Husband's Route to Death Row
description: As a factual portrait of a sociopath, ''Blind Faith'' is not nearly as compelling or incisive as ''Fatal Vision.'' That is true of the best-selling books, both written by Joe McGinniss, and it is true of the subsequent television adaptations, both done as four-hour movies for NBC. ''Blind Faith'' begins tomorrow evening at 9 o'clock and will continue Tuesday at 9.

title: Test of a 'New South Africa': A Bus Ride in Johannesburg
description: When Lloyd George Cloete pulled his double-decker bus out of the depot at 6:15 A.M. today, he had a sense of being on a mission, though in a modest way, for the ''new South Africa,'' whose creation was heralded last week by the country's leader, President F. W. de Klerk.

title: Perrier Recalls Its Water in U.S. After Benzene Is Found in Bottles
description: The company that made bottled mineral water chic is voluntarily recalling its entire inventory of Perrier from store shelves throughout the United States after tests showed the presence of the chemical benzene in a small sample of bottles.

title: Sports People: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;   Coach Overthrown
description: When Drake University plays Wichita State today, Eddie Fields, an assistant coach, will be coaching Drake. That's because Tom Abatemarco was removed as head coach Wednesday after the players said they were upset over his ''inhuman treatment'' and would no longer play or practice for him. Abatemarco was reassigned to unspecified duties in the athletic department. The team has a record of 11-12.

title: Prudential Strategic Income Fund reports earnings for As of Jan 26
description: Assets represented net assets and per share earnings are net asset value per share.

title: KEY RATES
Green Forest Lumber reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Chevron in Sale
description: The Chevron Corporation, the San Francisco-based oil company, said it would sell its operations in Freeport, the Bahamas, to the Venezuelan state-owned oil company for about $100 million. As part of the transaction, Petroleos de Venezuela S.A. will acquire an inactive 500,000-barrel-a-day refinery, which was shut in 1985. The sale also includes storage and shipping operations. The companies said they expected the transaction to close in the second quarter.

title: Apple Names Head of Europe Unit
description: Apple Computer Inc. said today that it had promoted Soren Olsson to president of Apple Computer Europe Inc.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If we can only get close together like this, maybe we can begin to solve our other problems.'' - Charlie Mabutyana, a black passenger on a newly integrated Johannesburg bus. [8:5.]

title: U.S. Jury Clears A Former Mayor In Bribery Case
description: Former Mayor James E. Dyer of Danbury, who had been accused of shaking down developers, was acquitted today of all but one charge in his Federal corruption trial.

title: AMC Entertainment reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Net income The company said latest quarter figures included a pretax gain of $2,052,000 from the disposition of assets; latest 9 months figures included a $12,548,000 pretax gain from disposition of assets. The company said year-ago quarter and 9 months figures both included a pretax gain of $24,615,000 from the sale of United Kingdom operations.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sunday, about a demonstration by East Europeans against a proposed power plant on the Danube River referred incorrectly to the plant site at Gabcikovo. It is in Czechoslovakia, not Hungary.

title: Cars With Blaring Radios Become a New York City Nuisance;   Get All the Noisemakers
description: To the Editor I read ''Ban the Boom,'' your Jan. 31 editorial on banning ''boom'' cars, with interest. I have lived on East 34th Street for the last nine years and am familiar with boom cars, boom fire engines, boom police cars, boom garbage trucks and all the other boomers that are so much a part of life in New York City.

title: Cars With Blaring Radios Become a New York City Nuisance
description: To the Editor:

title: Albany Assumes Final Say Over Whether Staten Island Will Secede
description: Throwing up a new obstacle to the secession of Staten Island, state leaders said today that they had agreed on a bill that would give the Legislature the final say over whether the borough could pull away from the rest of New York City.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: COLLEGE BASKETBALL

title: Westar Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $20.2 million gain on the sale of its interest in Westcoast Energy Inc. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Wanted: Education Chief With Open Ears
description: New Jersey's new Governor, Jim Florio, wants an education commissioner who will involve more voices in policy making, aides say.

title: Sports People: TENNIS;   Graf Outlook Unclear
description: Because heavy swelling prevented doctors from determining the exact extent of damage to a splintered bone in her right thumb, Steffi Graf did not learn yesterday whether she would need surgery. She was injured when she fell on skis in St. Moritz, Switzerland, on Wednesday. She will have another examination Monday.

title: Home Beneficial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Religion Notes
description: Romania and Repentance The head of the World Council of Churches has conceded that the group failed to take a public stand against Nicolae Ceausescu when he was the Romanian dictator.

title: Ametek Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,194,000 and $8,136,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $3,633,000, or 8 cents a share.

title: U.S. and 3 Latin Lands Agree On Plan to Fight Drug Traffic
description: The United States and three South American countries have reached tentative agreement on a plan to cooperate in combating drug traffic throughout the hemisphere, Administration officials said tonight.

title: Grand Canyon Out Of Triple Crown
description: Grand Canyon, the early favorite for the Kentucky Derby on May 5, will be sidelined for four months and miss the Triple Crown races because of a pulled muscle in his left front leg, the trainer D. Wayne Lukas said today in a written statement.

title: Del Shannon, a 60's Songwriter, Dies at Home in Apparent Suicide
description: Del Shannon, who wrote and sang the hit, ''Runaway'' in 1961, was found dead in his home, apparently from a self-inflicted gunshot wound to the head, the authorities said today. He was 50 years old.

title: Shirley Verrett to Open Lincoln Center Series
description: The soprano Shirley Verrett is to be the first guest in the spring series of Lincoln Center Offstage evenings, at 6 P.M. on Thursday at Paul Hall at the Juilliard School, 144 West 66th Street. The program consists of an hourlong discussion between a moderator and the performer. An informal wine-and-cheese reception follows.

title: G-R-I Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss c-After a loss of $6,556,000 from the cumulative effect from change in accounting principle.

title: College Football Contracts For Television Are Reduced
description: The College Football Association said yesterday that it had agreed to smaller television contracts with ABC and ESPN that reflected the University of Notrereame's deciconoto drop out of the agreements.

title: Bridge
description: It is common to end a deal with the sad realization that a very strong hand was not quite strong enough. But the converse is rare. Have you ever had a very weak hand that proves to be not quite weak enough?

title: Producer Prices Post 1.8% Jump
description: Reflecting December's exceptionally harsh weather, producer prices soared 1.8 percent in January, the biggest rise in more than 15 years, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Your Money
description: With promises of a speedier refund, the Internal Revenue Service is encouraging taxpayers to file their returns electronically this year, and it expects two million to do so through 9,000 authorized private firms.

title: United States Actively Defends Human Rights in El Salvador
description: To the Editor:

title: NAMIBIANS ADOPT NEW CONSTITUTION
description: Namibia's Parliament voted for a liberal democratic constitution today and removed the last barrier to independence after 70 years of South African rule.

title: JUDGE OPENS DOOR IN OIL SPILL TRIAL
description: A judge cleared the way today for Joseph J. Hazelwood's lawyers to seek to blame Coast Guard negligence rather than the captain of the Exxon Valdez for the nation's largest oil spill.

title: Tougher Rules Set for Foods' Health Claims
description: The Government today announced plans to toughen its rules on the health claims that are made about food products.

title: Bankruptcy Can Be a Fate Worse Than Liquidation;   Rehabilitation the Goal
description: To the Editor:

title: Midwest Communications Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
About New York;   Frontier of Play: Power Gloves And Stuffed Cars
description: The stories about the dog's arrival vary. Some say it was a stray roaming the subways. Others insist it was lying in the middle of Times Square, a hurting puppy. Lending credence to the latter account is the dog's name. Pancake.

title: Lincoln Savings Testimony
description: At the resumed hearings on Charles H. Keating Jr.'s lawsuit against the Government for the takeover of his failed Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, the last Government witness today gave the clearest testimony to date on the extent of improper accounting practices at the troubled institution.

title: Brown Chooses Top Police Assistant
description: A 48-year-old police commander, whose reputation as a management expert helped propel his rapid rise within the New York City Police Department in the last six years, was appointed as First Deputy Police Commissioner yesterday, the department's second highest post.

title: A WAR OF SNIPING ON LEBANON'S TV
description: The leaders of warring Christian factions have taken to their respective television stations in the last few days, and what they have said about each other has come as a shock to most Lebanese, particularly Christians in the areas devastated by their rivalry.

title: Mary Ground, Indian Elder, 107
description: Mary Ground, an elder of the Blackfeet Indian tribe, died Wednesday. She was 107 years old.

title: Israeli Who Met Arafat Is Freed;He Vows to Press His Peace Effort
description: Unrepentant, the Israeli peace campaigner Abie Nathan was released from prison today. He vowed to continue the activities for which he was jailed four months ago.

title: Milgray Electronics reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Prudential Intermediate InFcome Fund reports earnings for As of Jan 26
description: Assets represented net assets and per share earnings are net assets value per share.

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press yesterday about an antitrust ruling against the American Medical Association for its boycott of chiropractors described the Federal appeals court's opinion incompletely in some copies. The opinion, by the Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, said the A.M.A. had economic motives but was acting mostly out of concern about scientific methods in patient care.

title: National Pizza Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: The latest quarter included revenue of $8,468,000 from Skipper's acquired Nov. 26, 1989.

title: Upheaval in the East: Czechoslovakia;   Czechs Hear Soviets Promise Partial Troop Pullout Soon
description: The Soviet Union will begin withdrawing some troops from Czechoslovakia this month and considers ''realistic'' a Czechoslovak demand that a substantial part of its forces be out by May 30, a Deputy Soviet Foreign Minister told the Czechoslovak press agency today.

title: Lessons From Chinese Students
description: After a furious fight and by a narrow margin, Congress sustained President Bush's veto of a bill giving Chinese students in America a statutory right to stay. Mr. Bush had warned Congress that if it insisted on the bill, Beijing would retaliate by cutting off future student exchanges.

title: Late Goal by Turgeon Frustrates Rangers
description: The seconds couldn't tick off the clock fast enough for Mike Richter, the Rangers' goalie, as he stood in his crease, the game about to expire but the puck again entering his zone.

title: A Sondheim Survivor Rises Again
description: When the Stephen Sondheim-George Furth-Harold Prince musical ''Merrily We Roll Along'' opened on Broadway in November 1981, it was blasted by the critics and closed after 16 performances. But the show has refused to die.

title: Marine Bank Posts $119.9 Million Loss From Bad Loans
description: Marine Midland Banks Inc. yesterday announced a loss of $119.9 million in the fourth quarter because of problems with commercial real estate loans in the United States.

title: Bayou Steel Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said included in first quarter earnings for fiscal year 1990 is a favorable settlement of a lawsuit for a net $900,000.

title: Continental Route
description: An administrative law judge recommended Thursday that Continental Airlines be awarded a daily Houston-to-Tokyo route. The recommendation needs Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner's approval. Continental, based in Houston, has proposed providing daily service between Houston and Tokyo via Honolulu. The other carriers seeking the route are Delta Air Lines, Hawaiian Airlines, American Airlines, Aloha Airlines, and America West Airlines.

title: INSIDE
description: P.L.O.'s Shifting Fortunes

title: Prospect Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $3,347,000 and $5,966,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income and included a loss of $4,026,000 for the quarter and income of $58,108,000, or $2.63 a share, for the year, both from discontinued operations. The company said Illinois Central Corp., acquired in March 1989, is included in 1989 results from April 1. Prospect distributed its common equity interest in Illinois Central in January. The results for 1988 included Murray Bakery Products Inc. as a discontinued operations. Murray was sold in June 1988. National Spirit is presented as a discontinued operation in 1988 and 1989. The company said increases in revenues were attributable principally to the acquisition of Illinois Central. A number of factors influenced the variance in net income, including additional interest expense and one- time transaction fees in 1989, the sale of Murray Bakery Products in 1988, and the sale of the company's stock interests in Best Products Inc. and Facet Enterprises Inc. in 1988.

title: Cassius Marcellus Clay Sr., Former Champion's Father, 77
description: Cassius Marcellus Clay Sr., father of the former heavyweight boxing champion Muhammad Ali, died of a heart attack Thursday night shortly after he collapsed while leaving a department store. He was 77 years old.

title: Iran Reaffirms Rushdie Death Threat
description: Iran's supreme religious leader said today that a decree calling for the death of the British author Salman Rushdie, issued by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini a year ago, remained in force.

title: Toyota's Re-entry Into the Mini-van Market
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation introduced a mini-van here today, the Previa, which features some unusual solutions to technical problems that have vexed such designers for more than a decade.

title: Whirlpool Closing Kentucky Factory
description: The Whirlpool Corporation will close its Mount Sterling, Ky., dishwasher plant by March 1991 and lay off most of the factory's 650 workers. The appliance company said the plant's production would be shifted to its Findlay, Ohio, factory, which already makes dishwashers.

title: Mortgage Rates Rise
description: Fixed-rate home mortgages are averaging 10.21 percent, up from 10.17 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.46 percent this week, up from 8.45 percent the week before.

title: RESIGNATION AT SAVINGS AGENCY
description: The chief executive of the agency that oversees the Government's savings and loan bailout resigned today in what was seen as another sign that the multibillion-dollar White House program to clean up the industry is faltering.

title: Rochester Telephone Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included for the quarter a $2.6 million restructuring charge primarily related to write-off of computer hardware and software; the year included an extraordinary credit of $20,645,000, or 82 cents a share, which reflected the sale of Michigan paging operation and Illinois cellular interests.

title: Review/Dance;   A Richard Tanner Premiere by the City Ballet
description: LEAD: The only premiere of the New York City Ballet's winter season is Richard Tanner's "Prague Symphony" to Mozart, which was presented Thursday night at the New York State Theater.

title: Soviet Consumers Face Cutback In Meat as Feed Grain Runs Out
description: Dispirited Soviet consumers face a cutback in meat production because the country has run out of grain to feed its cattle, the Government's chief food official says in remarks published today.

title: Unisys Aide Is Sentenced
description: A former official of the Unisys Corporation was sentenced today to a year in prison for conspiring to make illegal campaign donations and obstructing the F.B.I.'s investigation of Pentagon procurement fraud.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping;   With Filing Income Tax Returns
description: It's time to prepare income taxes again, and tax reform hasn't really made it easier. It did wipe out some deductions, like sales tax. But it also increased the burden of proof needed to claim allowable deductions. And differing state laws across the country may mean you have to keep the same detailed records as before.

title: P.L.O.'s Fortunes Waning a Bit in Egypt
description: A rift has emerged between the Palestine Liberation Organization and Egypt, one of the P.L.O.'s principal Arab sponsors, diplomats and Egyptian commentators say.

title: Chrysler-Philips Electronics Deal
description: Subsidiaries of the Chrysler Corporation and Philips N.V. of the Netherlands are negotiating a joint venture to make auto electronics products, the companies said. The Philips unit, Philips Car Stereo International G.m.b.H. of West Germany, would hold a majority interest in the venture with Chrysler's parts subsidiary, Acustar Inc.

title: Valley Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $1,500,000. c-Net income Results for 1989 included a charge of $5,905,000 from write-down of assets.

title: Electric Car Draws Interest
description: The General Motors Corporation said its experimental electric car had attracted great interest and that it expects recommendations within three months from a team studying the feasibility of producing the vehicle.

title: David Stivender, 56, Chorus Master of Met Opera
description: David Stivender, the chorus master of the Metropolitan Opera since 1973 and a member of the company's conducting staff since 1978, died of congestive heart failure yesterday at Prresbyterian University Hospital in Pittsburgh. He was 56 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: RF&P Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
James Ryan Dies at 74; Ex-A.T.&T. Executive
description: James Vincent Ryan, a former assistant vice president of public relations for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, died of congestive heart failure on Thursday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 74 years old and lived in Summit.

title: Raid on Chile Police Kills One
description: Unidentified gunmen attacked a police station in a working class district of Santiago with gunfire and a hand grenade late Thursday, killing a policeman and wounding three people, the authorities said.

title: Shared Medical Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
