description: Latest full-year figures included certain one-time expenses and a non- recurring cumulative accounting adjustment which largely offset each other.

title: Sports People: BASEBALL;   Players 3, Owners 3
description: The players tied the owners, 3-3, yesterday when the Pittsburgh Pirate pitcher Bob Kipper won his salary arbitration case, which was heard Thursday in Chicago.

title: Melinte Gains a Mile Record and $100,000
description: The people who staged the Vitalis/Meadowlands Invitational track meet tonight offered a total of $250,000 in bonuses for runners breaking world indoor records in three races.

title: Bankruptcy Can Be a Fate Worse Than Liquidation
description: To the Editor:

title: Cambodia Peace Plan: Better Than Nothing
description: LEAD: The new United Nations peace plan for Cambodia seems to be about the best that the Cambodians can hope for.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost;   Improving Your Skiing
description: Ski resorts these days are offering a variety of classes for skiers of every skill including beginners, as well as instruction in particular techniques. Make arrangements in advance with the resort's ski school to enroll in a class. And, unless you are a beginner, look for a school that arranges for a ''ski down,'' in which an instructor watches you ski before placing you in a class.

title: Slain American Found At Inca Ruins in Peru
description: An American man was found shot to death amid ancient stone ruins in the Andean city of Cuzco, Peru's tourism center and once the capital of the Incas, the police said today.

title: Peter Malatesta, 57, Aide to Spiro Agnew
description: Peter J. Malatesta, a restaurateur and aide to former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew, died of pancreatic cancer on Thursday at his home in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif. He was 57 years old.

title: Thomas Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $5.5 million, or 54 cents a share, from divestiture of tools and fastener division and sale of real estate. c-Included for the quarter a gain of $840,000, or 8 cents a share, from divestments; the year included a gain of $800,000 from change in the method of accounting. Figures for 1989 included results from operations of Day-Brite Lighting, acquired in May 1989.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Poles Ask 17 Countries For Assistance on Debt
description: Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki of Poland has asked 17 nations to let Warsaw suspend its debt repayments this year and freeze its $40 billion debt, the Government said today.

title: Looking at Legends New and Old
description: With the sun shining brightly on a typical Florida day, basketball's top players arrived here today as the National Basketball Association's All-Star weekend began.

title: Georg Borgstrom, 77, Authority on Hunger
description: Georg Arne Borgstrom, a scientist, geographer and ecologist who was an authority on hunger, died Wednesday in Goteborg, Sweden. He was 77 years old and had lived in Goteborg since 1988.

title: Devils, in Fits and Starts, Rally Against Capitals
description: The Devils rallied from a two-goal deficit in the third period tonight and defeated the Capitals, 5-3, here in a game with more stoppages than a busy city street during rush hour.

title: Braniff Will Sell Gates at Orlando
description: Braniff Inc. agreed to sell its three passenger gates at Orlando International Airport to Chicago-based Midway Airlines Inc. for $2.25 million, a Braniff spokeswoman said. Braniff, which is seeking Chapter 11 protection for the second time in a decade, will ask permission to conclude the sale at a hearing on Feb. 22 in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Orlando.

title: DOW ENDS A STRONG WEEK BY GAINING 3.83
description: The stock market ended a strong week on a subdued but positive note yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average edged up by 3.83 points, to 2,648.20, with advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange leading declining ones by 826 to 667.

title: Books of The Times;   Proclamations and Poetry: One President's Literature
description: Abraham Lincoln

title: Review/Music;   Dawn Upshaw as Guest of Richard Goode
description: Operating in a business more ego-ridden than most, Richard Goode's collaboration with Dawn Upshaw on Wednesday night seemed an unusual event. This, after all, was the last of three concerts at the 92d Street Y entitled ''The Richard Goode Series''; yet the pianist seemed happy to share it - indeed, to give most of its time - to a young American soprano increasingly admired for her flexible talents.

title: Review/Pop;   Anything Goes as the B-52's Give a Shindig on Stage
description: Silliness and optimism became amiably subversive when the B-52's performed on Wednesday at Radio City Music Hall in the second of three sold-out concerts. The B-52's turn eccentricities and campy inside jokes into public revelry, sharing the possibility of pleasure in dangerous times. ''Do anything you want,'' Fred Schneider exhorted in ''Dance This Mess Around'' - and the audience wriggled and sometimes shouted along.

title: Fire Halts Thousands on IRT
description: A fire burned track ties on the West Side IRT line and delayed 10,000 people yesterday afternoon. The fire, at 72d Street and Broadway, was reported at 3:50 P.M., after debris on the southbound express track ignited, a spokesman for the Transit Authority, Termaine Garden, said. The No. 1, 3 and 9 lines halted for 35 minutes. ''It produced a small amount of flames, but a lot of smoke,'' he said. No injuries were reported. Nine trains from the No. 2 line were diverted to the Lexington Avenue line, delaying 5,000 riders there.

title: Travelers Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $30,800,000, or 30 cents a share. Results for the 1989 periods included net investment gains of $63,700,000 and $105,500,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; a net gain of $56 million and $65 million for the same periods, respectively, from divestitures; losses of $20 million and $86 million for the same periods, respectively, from catastrophes; and a net charge of $77 million for both periods associated with a plan to streamline certain insurance activities and further strengthen managed health care operations. Results for the year-ago periods included net investment gains of $42,500,000 for the quarter and investment losses of $308,800,000 for the year; a net gain of $107 million from the sale of certain business for both periods, and losses of $7 million and $21 million for the quarter and year, respectively, from catastrophes. Results for 1988 have been restated to reflect adoption of FASB 97.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, a theater review on Sunday about the Manhattan Punch Line's sixth annual festival of one-act comedies appeared with an incomplete paragraph. It should have read: ''Under the clockwork direction and choreography of Jason McConnell Buzas, the cast -Randy Danson, Liz Larsen, Ryan Hilliard and Chris Welles in the title role - turns 'Philip Glass Buys a Loaf of Bread' into a vintage skit worthy of a 'Forbidden Off Broadway.' ''

title: Francis Bowditch, 77, Dean and Headmaster
description: E. Francis Bowditch, dean of students at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology from 1951 to 1956 and later headmaster of the New Lincoln School in Manhattan, died of congestive heart failure Tuesday in Boca Grande, Fla. He was 77 years old and had homes in Boca Grande and Madison, Conn.

title: Omens for South Africa
description: Final touches have been put on the new constitution. South-west Africa will become independent Namibia on March 21, the first day of spring, completing the formal decolonization of Africa.

title: More Wheat for China
description: China has been authorized to buy an additional one million metric tons of United States wheat at subsidized prices, the Agriculture Department announced on Thursday. Under Secretary Richard T. Crowder said the wheat would be available to China under the department's Export Enhancement Program, which allows private exporters to sell American commodities at reduced prices and then collect Government surpluses of grain or other commodities as bonuses. China's purchases of United States wheat for 1989-90 delivery total about 5.7 million tons, much without subsidies.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day yesterday about First Interstate Bancorp misidentified a Texas money manager. He is Shad Rowe.

title: Permian Partners reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Jorgensen (Earle M.) Co.(N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest year included additions to income of $2,724,000, or 43 cents a share, resulting from reduction in LIFO inventory quantities carried at lower costs prevailing in prior years and $4,562,000, or 72 cents a share, gain on the sale of excess land and buildings. Latest quarter included $2,034,000, or 32 cents a share, of the addition to income for the full year resulting from the reduction in LIFO inventory quantities. Prior year included a loss of $1.6 million from discontinued operations.

title: Lord Maclean, 73, Aide to Queen; Organized 1981 Royal Wedding
description: Lord Maclean, the former chief official of Queen Elizabeth II's household and organizer of the 1981 wedding of the Prince of Wales, died on Thursday, his family announced today. He was 73 years old.

title: Quarantine: Sometimes a Duty
description: When to employ a quarantine, the isolation or detention of individuals determined to be an infectious danger to others, is not a new dilemma in public health -especially not in the city of Typhoid Mary. Yet the recent media hullabaloo and protest circus over Mayor David Dinkins's appointment of Woodrow Myers as New York City Health Commissioner badly confused this issue. This is especially true with respect to Dr. Myers's purported support of quarantining HIV-infected individuals who deliberately transmit the fatal virus to others.

title: Police Shoot an Unarmed Robbery Suspect Dead as He Flees
description: A New York City police officer shot and killed an unarmed robbery suspect in a drug-ravaged Brooklyn neighborhood early yesterday morning as the suspect was fleeing, the police said.

title: Washington Talk;   Hearings On the Hill: Inquisition Or Inquiry?
description: Witnesses appearing in the marbled and mahogany hearing rooms on Capitol Hill can be forgiven a bit of confusion over whether they have been invited to an inquiry or to an inquisition.

title: CHRONICLE
description: SUSAN EISENHOWER and ROALD Z. SAGDEYEV cemented one aspect of American-Soviet relations yesterday when they were married in Moscow. The couple made their vows at a Protestant service at the residence of the United States Ambassador, JACK F. MATLOCK.

title: The Smart Way to Close Bases
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's tentative proposal to shut or scale down dozens more military bases caused predictable howls in Congress. Some members warned of economic catastrophe. Others said Mr. Cheney was picking on Democrats. Nonsense, he replied, I'm just saving money. But he may also have been needling members who aim to cut weapons he wants to keep.

title: Other Students, Other Voices
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Television Sets Worth a Hearing
description: Sound has been television's stepchild, and it has been treated badly. It has been battered and bruised in poor equipment and has long suffered neglect at the hands of video manufacturers who regarded sound as secondary.

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Virginia Senators Stall Bill to Curb Abortion
description: An effort to slip past a hostile committee a bill that would have restricted abortions for minors failed in the State Senate on Friday, apparently dooming any chance for such legislation in Virginia this year.

title: Israeli Troops Seal Off Towns in West Bank
description: Israeli troops sealed off major towns in the occupied West Bank today and imposed curfews on parts of Gaza as Arab residents celebrated the eighth anniversary of the outlawed Palestine Communist Party.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: Sunnyside;

Irving's Home Is a Work in Progress
description: LEAD: VISITORS who tour Sunnyside this weekend will find something different from the usual complement of carefully appointed rooms. Upstairs, the house Washington Irving lived in from 1835 to his death in 1859 is in perfect detail of the period. Downstairs, however, the dining room, parlor, study and hallway are virtually empty, the walls devoid of paint or partly covered, the wooden moldings stripped of paint, too.

title: All About/The Tire Industry;   Decreasing Demand and Global Competition Propel Consolidation
description: A decade ago, a dozen major tire manufacturers, half of them American, vied for world leadership. Today, just six giant companies, one in the process of formation, are dominant. The only one based in America is the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company.

title: Luis Menocal 3d And Julia Cahill To Wed in March
description: March wedding plans for Julia Forhan Cahill and Luis Francisco Menocal 3d have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Cahill of Vero Beach, Fla., and Martha's Vineyard, Mass. Mr. Menocal is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Menocal Jr. The ceremony will take place in New York.

title: POSTINGS: New Canon Hq.;   Tennis, Anyone?
description: An unusual amenity, a small sports complex, will be a feature of the $37 million eastern regional headquarters to be built for Canon U.S.A. in South Brunswick, N.J. Construction begins next week, and when the project is completed next year, the subsidiary of the Japanese company will move its regional offices there from Lake Success, L.I., where it will retain its corporate headquarters. The company makes cameras and a wide range of consumer products.

title: R. Leslie Kelley, Car-Pricing Pioneer, 93
description: R. Leslie Kelley, who in 1926 first published the Blue Book to evaluate used-car prices, died Wednesday after a long illness. He was 93 years old.

title: Mary Dombrowski Is Engaged to Joseph B. Rizzo
description: The engagement of Mary Dombrowski to Joseph B. Rizzo, a son of Joan A. Rizzo of New York, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Dombrowski of Westfield, N.J. A September wedding is planned.

title: Review/Theater;   An 'As You Like It' Pastiche
description: In this open season on Shakespeare, theatergoers have already encountered a female ''King Lear'' with a transvestite Fool and a Lady Macbeth committing hara-kiri onstage. It therefore comes as no surprise to see ''As You Like It'' staged in a wrestling ring, with a bell signaling the beginning and ending of scenes. But the first of many questions that arise is why Orlando is the only one in the ring, wrestling himself to the ground instead of vanquishing Charles the wrestler.

title: Dining Out: What About Smoking?
description: I appreciated the Dec. 31 article reviewing New Jersey restaurants (''Critics' Choices: Memorable Meals''), but I feel one important item was entirely skipped - smoking. I don't care how delightful the decor, how friendly the service or how delectable the cuisine, if someone lights up next to me as I am about to savor a glorious evening out, I'd just as soon eat at home.

title: A Feisty Chief Shakes Up the Smithsonian
description: Five years and four months after Robert McCormick Adams succeeded S. Dillon Ripley as secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, the gigantic national storehouse and research and educational center is guided by bold new ideas and unconventional leadership. But, as the institution changes, it is beset with internal discord. Much of the dissension can be laid to the fact that many at the institution, in the view of Mr. Adams's supporters, were living in the past and were ripe for a jolt, but Mr. Adams's aggressive, hardheaded leadership and especially the contrast between him and his predecessor have stirred things up as well. How these conflicts are resolved will help to determine the importance and influence of the Smithsonian in American life well into the next century.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Movie Themes At Disney Park

title:
ART;

Perceptions of the 'Other'
description: LEAD: A PAIR of exhibitions, both based on difficult premises but possessing visual immediacy, are at the Zilkha Gallery Center for the Arts at Wesleyan University in Middletown in observation of Black History Month.

title: Chronicling the Life of Female Pharoah
description: LEAD: SHE took the throne at about age 17, ruled for 21 years and wore men's clothing and a beard for ceremonial occasions. She was Hatshepsut, the only female pharoah of Egypt, and her life is chronicled in ''The Cat Wore Earrings,'' a new book by Regina Maney, who teaches Egyptian studies, environmental issues and English at the Westlake Middle School in Thornwood.

title: A SHARP EYE IN WASHINGTON
description: WITNESS TO THE YOUNG REPUBLIC

title: Heading Home
description: What bothered her more than anything was the pronunciation, Meagher pronounced Mahr not Meager. She had been at the agency seven years and they still refused to pronounce her name correctly. ''Maureen Meager, a Dr. Cutler. It's about your father.'' She had expected the call. He was 70, smoked a pack a day, drank his six-pack, sat in the red vinyl recliner, turned on the TV and fell asleep nearly every night since her mother died.

title: THE SEARCH FOR THE BEGINNING OF TIME
description: ANY SPACECRAFT THAT inspires allusions to Alice of Wonderland cannot be meant for some ordinary excursion through the heavens. The Hubble Space Telescope is, indeed, not just any spacecraft. Scheduled for launching this spring, after five years of delays, the spacecraft and its exquisitely polished 94 1/2-inch-wide telescopic mirror should enable astronomers to see farther and 10 times more clearly than they have before, out tantalizingly close to the edge of the universe and toward the very beginning of time. Excited astronomers can hardly believe their good fortune to be living at a moment so rich in the promise of revolutionary discovery. One of them likens the anticipated adventures in astronomy to Alice stepping into Wonderland.

title: Question Of the Week;   Who Is The N.B.A.'s Best Player?
description: Isiah Thomas

title: MANDELA TO GO FREE TODAY; DE KLERK PROCLAIMS ENDING OF 'CHAPTER' AFTER 27 YEARS
description: President F. W. de Klerk announced today that Nelson Mandela would be released from a prison outside Cape Town on Sunday afternoon, ending 27 and a half years of imprisonment for South Africa's most celebrated black leader.

title: SAY GOODBYE TO THE STUFFED ELEPHANTS
description: William Honan thoughtfully explored the current debate concerning the Field Museum's new exhibit program. However, the reasons we chose to devote significant exhibit space to Micronesia - despite the objections of some anthropologists on the museum staff - were not fully explained. It is true that these islands are home to few of the Pacific's people, but ''Traveling the Pacific'' is about not only human cultures but natural history as well. Many important concepts, such as biological dispersal, adaptation and extinction, are better illustrated on these small islands than on the larger ones where most people dwell. The outrigger canoe, which was a focus of controversy in the article, is an example of cultural adaptation to one Pacific environment and provides a bridge between exhibit sections on natural history and those about human cultures.

title:
WINE;

Bargains and Clunkers Abound After Holidays
description: LEAD: TO stimulate wine sales at this time of year, retail merchants commonly decrease the price of shelved bottles and offer at a discount many cellared cases overlooked during the traditional peak buying period at the end of December. So cost-conscious county consumers can now find a good selection of bargains at most area retail outlets, especially in the less-than-$6-a-bottle category.

title: 40-Year Countdown Is Seen for Environment
description: The world has about 40 years to achieve an environmentally sustainable economy or descend into a long economic and physical decline, according to a report issued today by the Worldwatch Institute.

title:
DINING OUT;

Appealing Italian Fare in West Orange
description: LEAD: IF it weren't for all the cars parked out back, a passer-by would never suspect that hidden behind Tony's, an unpretentious workingman's bar in West Orange, is a lively little trattoria serving some savory Italian dishes.

title: Data Bank/February 11, 1990
Hers;   Being Safe
description: I'LL TEACH YOU HOW to protect yourself,'' Dad said. We were waiting in the 20th Precinct station in Manhattan to report the slashed roof of our green Studebaker convertible. I was 6. ''If a man attacks you, you knee him in the private. Then you take the flat side of your hand and shove the cartilage of his nose into his brain.'' Dad told me this was called a rabbit punch and meant instant death. While we waited for the precinct detective, I shadow-practiced till Dad was satisfied I could kill. That's when I learned protecting myself was up to me. The next year, riding a packed subway with my sister, a man chatted while he tickled us someplace we knew he had no right to.

title:
DANCE;

Giving Form to a Tale of Thwarted Love
description: LEAD: ANTONY TUDOR'S masterpiece, ''Jardin aux Lilas,'' or ''Lilac Garden'' as it is now called, has been described as a tragedy of manners. In this early example of the psychological ballet, which became a Tudor hallmark, the choreography works to reveal the innermost emotions of the characters. The conflict between the psychological forces within the characters and the external forces of a repressive, late Victorian society create a dramatic tension that makes this ballet riveting.

title: August Wedding For Sarah Bloom
description: Sarah Bloom, an associate in New York for the Washington law firm of Arnold & Porter, and Jamin Ben Raskin, the general counsel to the National Rainbow Coalition, a social-political organization in Washington, are planning an August wedding.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Dinner;   Taste of the Mediterranean and Southern Accents
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants by Bryan Miller that have appeared in The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current.

title: Sponsor Woes
description: To the Editor:

title: In 'Stardust,' the Music Of the Years Gone By
description: Sometimes I wonder why

title: To Czechs, Benes Symbolized Resistance
description: To the Editor:

title: Muto Helps Redmen Prevail in Rough Match
description: When the substitution horn sounded, there were 8 minutes 34 seconds left to play in last night's game between St. John's and Villanova at Madison Square Garden, a hard-fought contest that the Redmen would eventually win, 83-69.

title: Ship Safety
description: To the Editor: The Oct. 29 Travel section contained two articles, ''How Safe Are Cruise Ships?'' and ''Under Full Sail From Monte Carlo to Italy's Coast'' on Windstar Sail Cruises' Wind Star. Surprisingly, the two articles could be linked. As a former ship's physician with years of experience on several noteworthy vessels, it became apparent to me that a ship's safety is not only related to the knowledge and experience of the crew in handling the physical hazards that may occur but also to the size and competence of the ship's medical staff. Medical decisions of the utmost gravity, and occasionally with life or death consequences for both passengers and crew, have to be made, usually without benefit of any hospital or technological backup. It is essential that the medical team employed by cruise lines be of sufficient size and experience to handle the emergencies that do happen.

title: Campus Life: American;   Anti-Semitic Slurs Are Painted; Campus Reacts
description: American University students awoke to find anti-Semitic graffiti spray-painted on the main gate and a residence hall last Thursday morning.

title: Campus Life: Case Western;   Students Find Their Refuge From Pressures
description: For nearly a decade, Case Western Reserve University has had a place for students to escape the pressures of classes, roommates, soul mates, parents and illness, but few students knew about it. Now the existence and virtues of the Refuge, as it is known, are being advertised on campus as the program has expanded.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Hot Tears From Icy Sounds

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

Still Waiting to Buy a House
description: LEAD: A FEW years ago, some Morris County real-estate brokers ran a classified ad that said, ''Here's the Young Couple Who Waited to Buy a House.'' The copy ran, in perky type, below a cartoon depicting a doddering couple dressed in ludicrous 1950's collegiate-style dress.

title: Sonic Enters Plea
description: A written plea of not guilty to charges of drunken driving and reckless driving in connection with a car accident Jan. 12 has been entered by Dale Ellis, the Seattle SuperSonics' guard who was injured in the accident.

title: On Language;   Hitting Today's Ceiling
description: THE LEXICON OF fury needs constant updating. In describing a person in a state of extreme rage - your boss, for example, or a red-faced baby in a highchair - you show your age or tolerance for cliches with hit the ceiling, go through the roof, split a gut, blow his stack/cork/gasket, or fly off the handle.

title: Lebanese Tell of Mutiny Against Christian General
description: Large-scale fighting broke out today between rival Christian forces in and around the capital, shattering a three-day truce.

title: Small School Districts Share Culture
description: LEAD: QUAD VILLAGE, a consortium of schools in Hastings-on-Hudson, Dobbs Ferry, Ardsley and Irvington, has scheduled a performance by the Philharmonia Virtuosi, the orchestra based in Dobbs Ferry that plays national engagements. The event, to be held March 16 at Hastings High School, will be the first concert Quad

title: Room Service at Home (and It's Healthy)
description: TWO former General Foods executives and a personal fitness trainer think they know what the future of food technology holds - and they have formed a company based on their belief.

title: SATURDAY NIGHT
description: SATURDAY NIGHT IS different from any other night. On Saturday night, people get together, go dancing, bowling, drinking, out to dinner, get drunk, get killed, kill other people, go out on dates, visit friends, go to parties, listen to music, sleep, gamble, watch television, go cruising, and sometimes fall in love - just as they do every other night of the week. But on Saturday night they do all these things more often and with more passion and intent. Even having nothing to do on Saturday night is different from having nothing to do on, say, Thursday afternoon, and being alone on Saturday night is different from being alone on any other night of the week.

title: Playing Cupid: When Inspiration Strikes
description: LEAD: EVERY now and then there comes along an inspiration of the magnitude recently experienced by Owen Fennessy. Fortuitously, it arrived in time for Valentine's Day. Pausing at the ovens in the window of Nicky's restaurant in White Plains, where he works, Mr. Fennessy said, ''I am going to make my girlfriend a heart-shaped pizza.

title: Likud's Civil War: Insults, Then Apologies
description: Even by the none-too-decorous standards of Israeli political discourse, the mudslinging leading into the Likud party showdown on Monday between Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and three antagonists led by Ariel Sharon seems to be reaching for new lows.

title: COLETTE, MATA HARI AND OTHER HOT TICKETS
description: SERPENT OF THE NILE

title: Chinese See Few Ripples From Soviet Party Move
description: The Soviet Communist Party's decision to repudiate its monopoly on power has aroused interest here, and apparently some anxiety in the leadership, but few people seem to think the Soviet move will have much effect on China.

title: PASTIMES: Chess
description: The early 19th century was the epoch of untrammeled attacking play, the time for slugging it out with an opponent who was just as intent on slugging it out with you. But Wilhelm Steinitz spoiled all that - or almost all that. The man who dominated the chess world from 1866 to 1894 brought a sophisticated grasp to defensive play that had never been seen before.

title: As Gotti Packs, His Pursuers Try to Pick Up the Trail Again
description: As John Gotti prepared to leave for a vacation, prosecutors and investigators in New York were considering new indictments yesterday in a campaign to destroy what they describe as Mr. Gotti's multimillion-dollar Mafia empire.

title: Campus Life: Irvine;   Protests Try To Wrest Control Of Student Center
description: Arguing that they should take control of their school fees, a group of 200 University of California students is trying to replace administrators as managers of several buildings.

title: TROUBLES PLAGUE LIBERIAN HOSPITAL
description: The John F. Kennedy Memorial Hospital, once the finest in West Africa, recently announced on the radio that its morgue could no longer accept ''dead-on-arrival bodies'' until relatives claimed the ones that were already decomposing. The hospital said the morgue's refrigerator was broken. Hardly anyone here was surprised. Twenty years ago the 600-bed hospital, built and equipped with American money, was a technological marvel. Today, even by the relatively modest standards of medical care in sub-Saharan Africa, the Kennedy hospital is regarded by most Liberians as a destination of last resort.

title: Oxford English Dictionary Sets Up Shop in Morristown
description: LEAD: IN a tiny office here, buried under shelves filled with dictionaries, sits Dr. Jeffery Triggs, the director of the first North American Reading Program for the Oxford English Dictionary. Dr. Triggs's job is to find new words and new uses for old words.

IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Question Of the Week;   Who Is The N.B.A.'s Best Player?
description: There are many great players out there, but how many players can fly? Jordan can do it all.

title: Reviews/Concert;   Musical Archeologist Is Still Digging at 75
description: Newell Jenkins was once a musicological pioneer, tilling the fertile but neglected soil of the Italian Baroque during the 1940's and 50's, helping to prepare the way for the Baroque boom of recent decades. Now many of the boomers, after skimming the surface, have hastened on to greener fields, and Mr. Jenkins, doing pretty much what he has always done, finds himself left in the dust. You might think it would make his head spin.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: SPRINGFIELD, MASS.;

Route 5 Lures Developers
description: LEAD: LAST month, F. L. Roberts, a Springfield developer, won approval for a 270,000-square-foot home-design center on 27 acres in West Springfield. The center will be adjacent to Riverdale Shops on Route 5, a $20 million shopping center that Roberts developed in the mid-80's and then sold last April for $28 million to Prudential Realty, the real estate subsidiary of the Prudential Insurance Company.

title: Giants Were Missed
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: ARTFUL LURES TO CATCH COLD FISH
description: Decoys used in ice fishing - color-spattered lures with shimmering metal fins and button eyes - are among the more eagerly sought of the new collectibles. The first major exhibition of such effigies, ''Beneath the Ice: The Art of the Fish Decoy,'' will open Thursday at the Museum of American Folk Art's annex at Lincoln Square, Columbus Avenue at 66th Street, and remain through April 17.

title: Up to $500,000 Stolen From Bloomingdale's
description: Robbers wearing ski masks surprised three security guards at Bloomingdale's on Manhattan's East Side last night and escaped with the day's receipts totalling from $250,000 to $500,000, the police said.

title: In Brazil, Chaos Is Rising With the Inflation Rate
description: Poor people have started looting food stores as Brazil's monthly inflation rate soars.

title: NEW JERSEY Q & A: Michael F. Catania;   Setting Environmental Goals for the 90's
description: MICHAEL F. CATANIA, a former state official, says this decade will be a pivotal one for the environment. Improvements in environmental quality, he says, will have to come as much from individuals as from industry and will require people to make substantial changes in the ways they live.

title: NONFICTION
description: WHITNEY M. YOUNG, JR., AND THE STRUGGLE FOR CIVIL RIGHTS. By Nancy J. Weiss. (Princeton University, $24.95.) Nancy J. Weiss adequately chronicles the life of Whitney M. Young Jr., a consummate inside agitator who simultaneously fought and manipulated the corporate culture to expand opportunities for blacks. As executive director of the National Urban League from 1961 until his death in 1971, Young revitalized an organization that had once been - as the author, a professor of history at Princeton University, describes it - ''the premier national social service agency concerned with the problems of blacks.'' Young put the league in the center of the civil rights movement. But his role as the inside man of the movement, a bridge builder who interpreted the message from black marchers and street demonstrators to white corporate executives and politicians, was often not fully appreciated by either side or by the public at large. Ms. Weiss tells Young's story without much flair or insight. ''Whitney M. Young, Jr., and the Struggle for Civil Rights'' is more useful for its descriptions of Young's background and the inner workings of the league than for its descriptions of the strains within the civil rights movement or the frustrations inherent in persuading whites to accept an aggressive agenda for black advancement. And details of Young's struggle to balance professional demands and family responsibilities show that, like other leaders, he was not flawless. The value of this book is that it reminds us of a talented, dedicated man who waged one of the most important civil rights battles in one of the least visible arenas: the corporate boardroom.

title: Copping a Plea
description: FOR a man who prosecutors say bilked the University of New Mexico out of $25,000, John Koenig, the school's former atlhetic director, is getting off easy, but not necessarily that easy.

title: WHY WASTE THE WINE?
description: RAISED IN COORS COUNTRY, IJU never could develop a taste for beer. Even in my wildest days, at keg parties in college in Tucson, you could always find me over near the Boone's Farm.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article last week about the California clothing company L.A. Gear misstated the length of time the chief financial officer's post had been vacant. It was two months.

title: Margaret Biagini Engaged
description: Margaret Mary Biagini and David Best Matthews, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip S. Matthews of Herndon, Va., plan to marry in August, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Emo Biagini of Santa Clara, Calif., have announced. Ms. Biagini, 24 years old, graduated from Georgetown University, as did her fiance, and is an assistant treasurer in the New York office of the Italian Commercial Bank in Milan. Mr. Matthews, 24, expects to receive a J.D. from Columbia University in May.

description: BUREAUCRACY

title: Dr. Gordon Jones, 74, Music Director, Is Dead
description: Dr. T. Gordon Jones, the organist and director of music at St. Peter's Lutheran Church in Manhattan for over 30 years, died of a heart attack on Wednesday at New York Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Wall Street;   The Camden Zero-Coupon Quandary
description: Underwriters and lawyers agree that the Camden County Municipal Utility Authority bond issue now being marketed to investors across the country is one of the most unusual refinancing deals the tax-exempt market has seen in years.

The center will be adjacent to Riverdale Shops on Route 5, a $20 million shopping center that Roberts developed in the mid-80's and then sold last April for $28 million to Prudential Realty, the real estate subsidiary of the Prudential Insurance

description: LEAD:

title: A Feast of the Sacred and the Profane
description: LEAD: YOU couldn't see past them. There were perhaps 2,000 men standing shoulder to shoulder at an intersection in the center of Salvador, Brazil's fourth most populous city. Dressed in white and startling blue - some topped with terry-cloth turbans and all with blue socks, and blue and white beads draped in great loops across their chests - they moved in slow motion with the stomp, almost a shuffle, that they hold sacred.

title: Gains in Translation By Computer
description: The recent ''New Jersey Q & A'' interview with Dr. Michiko Kosaka (''On the Trail of Automatic Translation'') may have unintentionally given the impression that translation by computer is still only at the stage of a research project.

title: Tree Friend, Tree Foes
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Dance;   Evocations Of Conflict, By Skaggs
description: Sarah Skaggs often depicted choreographic struggles in the program she offered on Thursday night for the Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church. There were also moments of virtuosic skill. But it was the struggles that held the attention.

title: Miss Woods to Wed Michael Leonard
description: June wedding plans for Elisabeth Barrell Woods and Michael George Leonard have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. James Appleton Woods of Lloyd Harbor, L.I. Mr. Leonard is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter A. Leonard of Stuart, Fla.

title: Hodges Goes the Distance
description: With Larry Bird and Michael Jordan competing in the 3-point shooting contest, nobody talked much about Craig Hodges. That was a mistake. Hodges, Jordan's teammate on the Chicago Bulls, captured the 3-point shooting championship tonight by defeating Reggie Miller, 19-18, in the final round.

title: Bush Yields To an Impulse To Stay Cautious About the Soviets
description: PRESIDENT BUSH seemed confident that three days of speechmaking and picture taking at American military bases last week had helped him in his fight with Congress over military spending without damaging foreign policy goals. But the marathon of visits to bases in California and Nebraska left the President with some peculiar new political problems.

title: A Rash of Thoughtful Best Sellers Has Made Publishers Think, Too
description: HARPER & ROW almost seemed to be asking to lose money last year when it published ''The Other Path'' by Hernando de Soto, and it would seem to have been asking to lose even more when it recently reprinted the book in paperback. Written by a Peruvian businessman, the book is a detailed examination of the black market in Lima, with lessons about wealth and poverty in Latin America.

title: PASTIMES: Stamps
description: The world's most prolific stamp designer never sold a design to any government. Rather, he created his own governments, dozens of them, in a wave of artistic wit in the early 1970's. His designs in watercolor have been circulated throughout the world and now hang in museums and galleries.

title: Soviet Faction Sees Split Within Party
description: Leaders of a pro-democracy insurgency within the Communist Party said today that they would wait until a summer congress of the party before deciding whether to break away and form a separate party.

title: FAT CATS IN THE DRIVER'S SEAT
description: EMPEROR OF AMERICA

title: Far From Bangkok, but Taste Is Thai
description: Recently, Thai restaurants have sprung up like mushrooms after a spring rain. Yet, they are still uncommon on Long Island, and the opening of a new Thai outpost is cause for rejoicing among lovers of this intricate and intriguing cuisine.

title: Rights Group Assails Iraq for 'Ruthless' Repression
description: A new human-rights monitoring group, Middle East Watch, assailed the Government of Iraq today for what the group termed ruthless suppression of dissent, apparently seeking to counter Baghdad's assertions that it has entered a period of liberalization in the aftermath of the Iran-Iraq war.

title: Bribery Scandal Spills Over Into Japanese Election Year
description: Once or twice a week, a steady stream of small black limousines pulls up at the Tokyo District Court here and drops off a group of men that Japan's ruling party would just as soon forget, especially this month: the defendants in the Recruit stock and influence-peddling scandal.

title: Renouncing the Revolution's Holy Writ
description: LENINISM, a doctrine with roots in the 19th century that was a scourge of most of the 20th, has finally begun to lose its hold over the Soviet Union on the eve of the 21st.

title: Security Guards: New Position at Camps
description: On page 3 of the memorandum telling the clubs not to open spring training camps until otherwise notified, the heads of the owners' negotiating team wrote: ''Major league training camps shall remain closed during the duration of any labor dispute and the P.R.C. will arrange for a security service to guard all spring training camps 24 hours a day during the labor dispute.''

title: American Visas for Scientists From the East Are Said to Be Lagging
description: Despite the crumbling of cold war barriers, the granting of American visas to Soviet and East European scientists remains mired in red tape, depriving the nation of sorely needed talent, American scientists contend.

title: Health Care: Costs Shifting To Workers
description: LEAD: As the cost of health care soars, more Long Island employers are shifting health-insurance costs to their workers.

title: What Homeless Beggars Must Keep Telling Us;   Early Reagan Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

The Promise and Potholes of Retirement
description: LEAD: OH, it seemed like such a good plan - almost flawless, you might say. First, I took early retirement (collecting a bonus for so doing). Then we sold our house in Croton-on-Hudson and headed for a carefully scouted sunny island where the taxes were low and the living was easy. Hah. The taxes are low, all right, but the living?

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our house is more than 60 years old and has more than one roof on it. The last roof has been on about 20 years, and the last time a contractor checked it he said there were many more years of wear left. I am concerned about the weight of more than one roof on the house because there are some cracks in the foundation, and it appears to me as though the house may be sinking. Could the extra weight of the roof be causing this?

title: What's in a Name? Heritage and a Sense of Self
description: ''KRISH . . . Krishna . . . Kri. . >. . ''Oh, well!'' She threw up her hand, shrugged her shoulders and giggled. ''Wouldn't it be easier to give me your first name?'' She was hoping for a Mary, Jane or Anne, I suppose.

title: Orchestras Offer Popular Preludes: Words Before Music
description: CLASSICAL MUSIC lovers, hoping to be better informed when they take their seats at concerts, are flocking to lectures to gain insights about the music they will hear. Attendance at the lectures has surged, and in some instances, what is packing them in falls just short of theatrics.

title: That Rare Vocal Bird, a True Verdi Mezzo
description: ''I've got this big mama with a big voice'' was how the stage director Lou Galtiero described a student in his class at the Manhattan School of Music to the artist's manager, Elizabeth Crittenden. That was in 1982 and he was referring to Dolora Zajick, a young mezzo-soprano who had just been awarded the bronze medal in the International Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow. (Her name, which is Czechoslovak and pronounced ZAH-chick, was spelled Zajic then; she has since added a ''k'' in a rather dubious attempt to make pronounciation easier.) The mama is not so big anymore, thanks to dieting, but the voice is even bigger. Moreover, it is an instrument that has the same sound throughout its range without any audible shifting of gears as she passes from the lower range to the middle to the top. She is also blessed with an exciting edge to the voice that allows her to cut through an orchestra and ensemble and always be heard.
