title: Corrections
description: A report last Sunday about the engagement of Randi B. Jaffe to Richard M. Salko misidentified the school from which the prospective bride received her J.D. degree, cum laude. It is the Harvard Law School.

title: Adolescent Program Is Gaining In County
description: LEAD: THE Yale Decision Making Program is expanding. Introduced four years ago, the program is designed to help students deal with stress and peer pressure - thus staying away from alcohol and drugs - and to aid parents in coping with raising adolescents.

title: Campus Life: North Carolina;   Residents Oppose Proposal to Build Student Mosque
description: After holding their religious observances in the student union through the 1980's, Muslims at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill can look forward to a distinctive, permanent place of worship in the 90's. The university's Student Muslim Association announced plans, approved by the city's planning board recently, to build a mosque and Islamic center for the 50 Muslim students in this college town of 40,000.

title: Outdoors;   Facing Spawning Challenges
description: The Canadian Department of Fisheries and Oceans faces a double challenge created by dwindling stocks of Atlantic cod and severely depleted spawning runs of Atlantic salmon in many of Newfoundland's rivers.

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Bulgaria;   Baker Asks Bulgaria for Fair Election
description: Hundreds of Bulgarians, chanting ''No money for Commies'' and ''Democracy U.S.A.'' in English, greeted Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d on his arrival today. He stopped for 12 hours to press the new Government to conduct free and fair elections.

title: Ship Safety
description: To the Editor: ''How Safe Are Cruise Ships?'' (Travel, Oct. 29) well illustrated the problems of safety on the seas - laws with no teeth, industry opposition to safety requirements and failures in enforcement.

title: Bush Would Wait For a Weatherman
description: IN predicting the future, much of what is proclaimed as science must ultimately be taken as a matter of faith. A problem that continues to confront the Bush Administration is how fervently it should believe in the dangers of the greenhouse effect - and how high a price the country should pay to forestall them.

title: 2 Young Pianists Return for Concerts
description: TWO young pianists who once lived in the county are returning for concerts this afternoon. Marija Stroke joins the violinist Mark Steinberg for a 2 o'clock program at the Emelin Theater and Susan Merdinger plays a solo recital an hour later at her alma mater, the Westchester Conservatory.

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Soviet Union;   KOHL SAYS MOSCOW AGREES UNITY ISSUE
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany said today that he and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union had agreed that it was ''the right of the German people alone to decide whether to live together in one state.''

title: STREETSCAPES: The 32d Precinct Station House;   Restoration Falters on Amsterdam
description: FOR years the old 32d Precinct station house was a delightful antique on upper Amsterdam Avenue, a proud, slightly sagging police station, but with its delicate roof cresting intact. Over the years the sag increased, especially after a new station house was built and the old one was sealed.

title: No Commentator
description: As things stood last week, the next 780 minutes of ''60 Minutes'' will include no minutes with Andy Rooney. Mr. Rooney, a commentator on the weekly show, was suspended for three months without pay after racist statements were attributed to him in The Advocate, a gay magazine. Mr. Rooney, whose comments have previously incurred the wrath of gay groups, immediately denied the quote and later said it had been made up as part of a campaign by homosexuals to discredit him. The Advocate reporter stood by his story. David W. Burke, the president of CBS News, announced that at the very least Mr. Rooney would be suspended for 13 weeks. The Advocate quoted Mr. Rooney as saying, ''Most people are born with equal intelligence, but blacks have watered down their genes because the less intelligent ones are the ones that have the most chldren.'' In his syndicated column this weekend, Mr. Rooney gave his own verson. He wrote, ''I said, 'The least fit are proliferating,' and I didn't say blacks.'' He added, ''In their campaign against me, gays decided to charge me with racism.''

title: 'Caller ID' Stirs Debate on Phone Privacy
description: A SPECIAL telephone service used by 30,000 customers in New Jersey to view callers' phone numbers without having to pick up the receiver is part of a national debate over privacy.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;

Bidding for Mount Laurel Transfer Funds
description: LEAD: A NEW and controversial wrinkle has developed in the five-year-old law allowing suburban communities to transfer to cities part of their obligation under the state's Mount Laurel rulings to provide low- and moderate-income housing.

title: In the Marketplace of Ideas
description: To the Editor:

title: A HIGHLAND FLING
description: True tartans are the stuff of drama and legend, conjuring up swashbuckling tales of Scots wearing kilts woven in the plaid of their clan. Now, the tartan patterns are used on all sorts of fabrics to make dashing designs for women to wear in all seasons and at any time of day.

title: Perrier Production Halted Worldwide
description: Scrambling to learn how the solvent benzene contaminated bottles of their sparkling mineral water, Perrier officials said today that worldwide production had been halted and that the recall of the famous beverage was being extended to Canada.

title: British Folk-Pop Flourishes, All Souls Bared
description: ''I don't want to hurt you/I just want to join in/ This is a kindly creamer/ A kindly crematorium,'' Tanita Tikaram sings in ''Thursday's Child,'' one of 10 cryptic ballads on her second album, ''The Sweet Keeper'' (Reprise 26091-2; all three formats).

title: SAY GOODBYE TO THE STUFFED ELEPHANTS
description: My wife and I are avid museumgoers and collectors. In fact, we own the Tinkerton Museum here in Sandia Park, N.M. We have some 12,000 items of Americana on display.

title: Argue, Don't Amend
description: I've heard so much about the good old days that I feel as if I've lived through them, even though I never walked five miles through the snow to school. People left their doors unlocked. Everyone said ''good morning'' to everybody else. Women baked. Occasionally a naysayer comes along and suggests that the Depression and segregation had their down side, but folk tales have it that those were the days when the sun shone on the U. S. of A. I got a letter mentioning the good old days not long ago from Alistair Cooke, a handsome man with silver hair and tongue. Mr. Cooke is a spokesman for a group called U.S. English, which is shopping for a constitutional amendment declaring English our official language. It was a form letter, because Mr. Cooke and I don't know each other, although after all those years of hearing him introduce himself before Masterpiece Theater I almost imagined we'd met.

title: Lighthearted Air in Carvings
description: FORGET the cold and dreary days of winter; the Van Fleet Circus has come to Oceanville. Under the big top, clowns cavort, trapeze acrobats hang by their delicate toes and ferocious of the Noyes Museum here. lions glare out from their cages. A calliope and three separate bands seem to be playing a cacophony of oom-pah-pah music.

title: Ex-Informer Is Shot Dead on His Brooklyn Porch
description: A former Federal informer whom the police said ''was hated by everyone'' was gunned down on his front porch in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn Friday night, and detectives said they were investigating whether the killing was linked to organized crime.

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Arms Control;   U.S. and Soviets Appear to Agree On Main Elements of Arms Treaty
description: The United States and the Soviet Union appear to have agreed on virtually all major elements of a strategic-arms treaty that calls for deep reductions in long-range nuclear weapons.

title: Spacecraft Gains a Venus Shove Toward Jupiter
description: The Galileo spacecraft developed camera trouble today after flying around Venus in a maneuver that speeded the craft toward its 1995 encounter with Jupiter.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Parenthood

title: Transcript of de Klerk's News Session on Mandela
description: Following is a transcript of the news conference yesterday by President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa on the release of Nelson Mandela. Part of it was recorded by The New York Times. Other parts were provided to The Associated Press by the South African President's office.

title: Catholics Should Not Be Intimidated
description: LEAD: Several commentators have tried recently to intimidate American Roman Catholics. The occasion was the warning from prison by Bishop Austin Vaughan about the danger to the immortal soul of Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York because of his action (or inaction) on abortion. The Bishop's warning, these commentators ominously hint, gives ammunition to anti-Catholic ''bigots.

title: Woman in Brooklyn, Thrown to Roof, Dies
description: A partially clad woman was thrown from a seven-story Brooklyn housing project early yesterday and was found dying on the roof of a day-care center, the police said.

title: PASTIMES: Camera
description: A friend has been preoccupied of late with copying the pages of old magazines. He is not trying to make reproduction-grade images, just records of what appears on the printed pages. He is also worried that the camera he is using isn't right for the job.

title: Evening Hours;   Lincoln Center Has Zoo Night, Styne a Duet
description: Norton, a 20-pound American alligator; Ramona, a boa constrictor; Bowie, an iguana; and Paki, Holli, Tusa and Oliver, four baby gorillas, were just a few of the animals mingling with 5,600 guests at Lincoln Center Monday night. They were at the 96th annual meeting of the New York Zoological Society, which included cocktails, films and a report by the society's president, Howard Phipps Jr. Then trustees had dinner at Tavern on the Green.

title: Language Study
description: To the Editor: As I was considering a month to study Spanish in Spain, your issue featuring foreign language study abroad (Travel, Sept. 3) appeared.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey;   Recent Sales
description: Bridgewater $250,000

title: Lectures, From Poetry to Black History
description: LEAD: THROUGHOUT the county, opportunities for informal learning through lectures abound in the coming weeks. Scientists, philosophers, art historians and professors are among the many who will share their expertise on a variety of interesting topics and challenging issues.

title: In 'Something to Hide,' Everyone Does
description: The detectives who spend their lives digging out the secrets of the criminal mind come in a variety of types.

title: Still Homesick After All These Years
description: During the turbulent mid-70's, several friends and I just out of high school bought a used van and traveled west.

title: KENYA WILL ALTER PLANNED HIGH-RISE
description: Under pressure from the World Bank and from the United States and Japan, the Kenyan Government has decided to scale back plans for a $200 million 60-story tower that would have been the tallest commercial structure in Africa.

title: Fond Words For Fond Words
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Shed a Tear for Stella, Still Noble but Senseless
description: In both the famous 1937 King Vidor version of ''Stella Dallas'' and the apt-to-be-less-famous (but still surprisingly workable) 1990 remake, Stella receives an unexpected visitor one Christmas Eve. He is Stephen Dallas, the well-born, debonair father of Stella's beloved only child, and Stella hasn't seen him in a long time. She wants to make the right impression. So she hurries to her bedroom and dresses with care, stopping at the last minute to tear off a bit of extra trimming. She knows that her outfit looks a lot more elegant without it.

title: That 'New Breed' Of Volunteers
description: The recent article ''A New Breed of Volunteers Alters Ways of Helping Others'' captured the spirit of the ''new breed,'' people who work from 9 to 5 and still make time in their busy schedules to help others early in the morning, evenings and weekends, or during lunch hours, as well as retirees who are giving their time and expertise. Our fastest-growing group of ''busy people'' volunteers is Volunteer Ventures - mostly single adults who volunteer together on group projects to help communities.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Before anyone else says it:yes, most holidays have been turned into commercial bonanzas; yes, it's the sentiment that counts; yes, gifts given at odd moments during the year, for no reason at all, are the tops. Yes, yes and yes. But it's still nice to get a valentine and if that valentine takes a special form, wouldn't one have to be mad, mad as in crazy, to object?

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: CINCINNATI;

A Mix of Uses On the Ohio
description: LEAD: A NARROW, mile-long tract bordering the Ohio River less than a mile east of downtown is being cleared to make way for Adams Landing, a $200 million, 30-acre condominium and office community that will stretch eastward from the Daniel Carter Beard Bridge.

title: 8 BOMBS EXPLODE IN KASHMIRI TOWN
description: Eight bombs exploded today in this stronghold of Muslim militants seeking independence from India for Jammu and Kashmir state, the police said. No one was wounded.

title: Campus Life: Louisiana State;   Protesters Win: Oaks Still Stand With Magnolias
description: The four 50-year-old oaks and five magnolias alongside the football stadium at Louisiana State University still stand, saved from the saw by student and faculty protests.

title: Why, in the Movies, the South Rises Again
description: Is it a coincidence that the stores these days are full of ''country''-inspired furniture (heavy maple tables, dry sinks and roll-top desks), that menus are heavy on grits and blackened everything, and that all the successful young lawyers seem to be wearing suspenders?

title: Rebels in Ethiopia Claim Capture of Red Sea Port
description: Rebels in Ethiopia's northern province of Eritrea said today that they captured the strategic Red Sea port of Massawa today after opening a major offensive two days ago.

title: The Executive Computer;   Zenith May Have a Breakthrough Machine Zenith May Have a Breakthrough Machine
description: Of the nine computer companies that formed an alliance in 1988 to develop an ''extended industry standard architecture'' (EISA) for personal computers, Zenith Data Systems Inc. of Glenview, Ill., was the last to announce the details of its designs. But late last month Zenith became one of the first to bring such a machine to market. The initial reviews of the Zenith Z-386/33E computer have been enthusiastic. Byte magazine, one of the more technical computer journals, gushed with uncharacteristic praise, even using such nontechnical expressions as ''phenomenal'' and ''amazing.''

title: Lisa Zimmer to Marry Joshua Lisser
description: Mr. and Mrs. David A. Zimmer of Livingston, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lisa Rachel Zimmer to Joshua Bruce Lisser, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley R. Lisser of Great Neck, L.I. A January wedding is planned.

title: Question Of the Week;   Who Is The N.B.A.'s Best Player?
description: The Has-Been: Larry Bird. Now: Michael Jordan. The Future: David Robinson.

title: 'Heidegger for Fun and Profit'
description: To the Editor:

title: THE COURAGE OF THEIR FOOLISHNESS
description: ME AND MY BABY VIEW THE ECLIPSE

title: A New Role for a Theater From the 20's
description: LEAD: WHEN the Lincoln Theater in New Haven was forced to close its doors in September 1982, after screening ''The Last Picture Show,'' supporters of the historic playhouse feared that the wreckers' ball would soon reduce it to rubble.

title: Review/Theater;   Evening B In One-Act Festival
description: A quick, sharp musical curtain-raiser by Peter Tolan begins the second evening in the Manhattan Punch Line festival of one-act comedies. The sketches that follow illustrate the problems and pitfalls of the short-play form.

title:
FOCUS;

Office Resides In a Onetime Industrial Area
description: LEAD: A burst of rehabilitation and new construction over the last few years in this city's North Station area has set the stage for growth in what was once a major industrial and shipping district.

title: Reviews/Theater;   Puerto Rican Anguish In Bilingual 'Ariano'
description: The Puerto Rican on the American mainland. Who is he? What does he want to be? Identity crisis, the perennial puzzlement of the newcomer in the city, is the issue poignantly and melodramatically at hand in Richard V. Irizarry's ''Ariano,'' now playing at the estimable Puerto Rican Traveling Theater.

title: Language Study
description: To the Editor: I had decided on an extended trip to Rome to study Italian, and your article appeared just one week before I left Ohio. Based on your listing, I selected the Torre di Bable Language Center at 74 Via Bixio. After four weeks of intensive Italian classes, I felt almost like a Roman!

title: Volunteers Are Helping Children in Foster Care
description: DONNA HENNINGSEN has not had to move often in her life, relocating only when she came to Westchester with her husband, Peter, and three children in l972. But as a foster mother in Edina, Minn., she sometimes provided a child's sixth or seventh temporary home. ''You can't tell me that's good for any person, much less a child,'' she said.

title: Jill Altheim Marries
description: Jill Altheim and Michael Passeroff were married last evening at the Pierre by Rabbi Mark Goldman. Mrs. Passeroff, 22 years old and the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Altheim of New York, is an assistant manager at the Forest Electric Corporation in New York. Her father is the company's chairman. Mr. Passeroff, 28 and a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Passeroff of New York, graduated from Boston University and is a vice president of the Liz Roberts Apparel Company in New York. His father is the company's president.

title:
PASTIMES: Gardening;

Old-Fashioned Flowers, A Return to Nostalgia
description: LEAD: Their names ring with remembrance: heliotrope, sweet rocket, johnny-jump-up. They stand tall against summer showers. And they are fragrant, some in the cool of fading light, others in the heat of noon. They are the old-fashioned flowers, and, like old garden roses, they are enjoying a renaissance.

title: Schools Coping With Smoking Ban
description: LEAD: THEY sit at school desks with their eyes closed, listening to strange sound effects and the words of the instructor. You are a nonsmoker, he says over and over, because the State Legislature has declared that this group of teachers and members of office and maintenance staffs will be smoke-free, at least while at work.

title: Q and A
description: Rights of Co-op Buyers

title: Kathryn Meisle to Wed M. B. Giamatti
description: [TEXT OMITTED FROM SOURCE] have announced the engagement of their daughter Kathryn Hunt Meisle to Marcus Bartlett Giamatti, a son of Mrs. A. Bartlett Giamatti of Hamden, Conn., and the late Mr. Giamatti. A June wedding is planned.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: On the first page of THE WORLD BEYOND THE HILL: Science Fiction and the Quest for Transcendence (Jeremy P. Tarcher, $29.95), Alexei Panshin and Cory Panshin identify science fiction as ''the myth of the modern Western world.'' This is not offered as a thesis to be defended or a concept to be explored, but as an axiom that the reader must accept in order to make sense of the 685-page history of science fiction that follows.

title: Dangers for Media Do-It-Yourselfers
description: To the Editor:

title: Tess Leopold to Marry Gerald Allen
description: Judge and Mrs. Robert W. Sweet of New York and Pawling, N.Y., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Sweet's daughter Tess Leopold to Gerald Allen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Allen of Great Kills, S.I. A May wedding is planned.

title: What Homeless Beggars Must Keep Telling Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Four Are Killed in Bowling Alley Shooting
description: Robbers forced seven people into a bowling alley office today and shot an employee, his two daughters and another girl to death before setting a fire to try to cover up the crime, the police said.

title: Defrocked
description: The rift between the Rev. George A. Stallings Jr. and the Roman Catholic Church apparently is terminal. The Archdiocese of Washington announced last week that Father Stallings, a priest who founded a separate congregation for black Catholics last summer, had excommunicated himself from the faith through his public statements.

title: With Movies For Sale, What Of Rental?
description: Out there in the video marts these days one sometimes gets the feeling that there are more movies for sale than for rent. Hot new titles - the just-released ''Lethal Weapon 2,'' say - are meant to be bought, or so it seems. Rentals, according to several surveys, appear to be shrinking.

title:
IN SHORT;

NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: The Lure of Fordism, Jazz and 'Americanismus'
description: ''Envisioning America'' at Harvard University's Fogg Art Museum may be the latest foray into the subject of art and American popular culture, but the works of Barbara Kruger, Jeff Koons, Cindy Sherman and Laurie Anderson are nowhere to be found. Andy Warhol's name is never evoked.

title: RESULTS
description: Tennis

title: Schubert's 'Schone Mullerin': Choosing Among New Disks
description: The Schubert song cycles can each be comfortably encompassed on single compact disks - a practical circumstance that must have contributed to the remarkable proliferation of ''Die schone Mullerin'' in the new medium (more than a dozen; the ''Winterreise'' cycle boasts a dozen and half).

title: THE FRENCH CONNECTION
description: As several critics note in PARIS 1889: American Artists at the Universal Exposition (Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts/Abrams, $49.50), the only way to identify the American pavilion there was by the sign over the door. The Americans' French-inspired academic paintings - Impressionism was in the air but not yet on the wall - featured Spanish musicians, Venetian gondoliers and an assortment of European shepherds. This beautifully illustrated volume by Annette Blaugrund, the guest curator and coordinator of the exhibit at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts, re-creates the historical, political and social contexts of the Paris Exposition, as well as providing a critical evaluation of each American painting displayed. The scholar might enjoy pursuing the winding road of influence from the Barbizon painters to William Morris Hunt and from the Spanish realists to Thomas Eakins; the ordinary reader will be fascinated by the arguments over space (the Americans were assigned an out-of-the-way upstairs gallery), politics (Frederick Stuart Church refused to participate, in protest against the 30 percent duty on foreign works of art) and favoritism (American artists living in France provided 80 percent of the paintings). After the French, the largest number of paintings at the fair were by American artists - a show of support for the struggling republican Government unmatched by her wary European neighbors. American paintings received 57 awards and 24 honorable mentions, earning the artists international recognition and giving them the courage to forge their own identity at the World's Columbian Exposition in Chicago in 1893. ''Paris 1889'' captures a fledgling American art on the verge of testing its wings. ROSLYN SIEGEL

title: 2,903 Entered in Westminster
description: The Westminster Kennel Club, which has been staging shows since 1877, opens a two-day run in Madison Square Garden tomorrow with 2,903 dogs representing 141 breeds or varieties.

title: In This Contest Winning Is Only The Beginning
description: While attending the 18th annual Prix de Lausanne ballet competition here recently, I tried to decide exactly how this unusually conceived contest differs from other ballet competitions.

title: Bill Simon's Audacious S. & L. Gamble
description: William E. Simon has a problem, and true to the former Treasury Secretary's reputation, he has a rather audacious solution.

title: India
description: To the Editor: The article ''Treasure House of Gods of India'' by Olivier Bernier (Travel, Jan. 7) brought back memories of several visits to the Madras Government Museum which I made while living in that city.

title: Lifestyle;   Only You? Just Dial For Help
description: Where is Judy Garland buried? What should I wear to a funeral? Is there a holistic veterinarian in Manhattan? Where can I get a haircut after midnight? For the answer to these and other vital questions - if you don't have a concierge at your service - dial 212-925-0900 and speak to Manhattan Intelligence, a subscription telephone guide to New York City.

title: AIDS CASES IN U.S. ROSE 9% IN 1989
description: The number of new AIDS cases in the United States rose 9 percent last year, the smallest increase since the Centers for Disease Control started reporting AIDS cases in 1981. But the number of new cases grew faster among heterosexuals, newborns, women and Southerners, health officials say.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 30 of the Arts and Leisure section today about legislation to require warning labels on certain recordings gives an outdated description in some copies for a bill passed by the Pennsylvania House.

title: On Drugs, Bush Aims for a Meeting of the Minds, at Least
description: IF all goes according to plan, President Bush will fly to Colombia this week and join the leaders of that country, Peru and Bolivia in forming an alliance to wage the war on drugs. But the session is unlikely to resolve deep-seated differences between the United States and the Latin countries.

title: PASTIMES: Coins
description: Later this week, we'll be so smitten with Valentine's Day chocolates, flowers and love that coins won't mean a thing. Years ago in the make-believe kingdom of love, coins were the currency of the realm.

title: The Clock Is Ticking on David's Island Project
description: THE release of a long-awaited Federal review of the proposed $1 billion residential complex on David's Island, a deserted 78-acre site off the coast of New Rochelle, has renewed a bitter public debate and set the stage for a final state study that will determine whether the project can proceed.

title: Belize
description: To the Editor: You might like to tell your readers of some difficulties on an otherwise positive, adventure-filled trip to Belize.

title: DATA UPDATE: February 11, 1990
Social Events
description: Lunch in Albany, etc.

title: The Bobcat, Imperiled Indeed
description: Re: ''Bobcat and Terrapin Are Said to Be Imperiled,'' Dec. 17):

title: Why the 'Prince of Pilots' Turned Producer
description: Right next to the railroad tracks inside an old converted warehouse downtown, the sign tacked up to a rickety elevator says as much about the making of a new TV series as it does about the shaky lift up: ''Ride at Own Risk. If you get stuck - don't panic.''

title: Lifestyle;   A Concierge Means Never Having to Find It Yourself
description: Forget Oscar and Tony; move over Emmy and Grammy; make way for the Silver Plumes. The foot-high, Tiffany-designed award made its debut at the First Annual Concierge Ball when two concierges and a hotel manager were honored for their ''commitment to their professional development of the concierge industry.''

title: Managing;   Pen-and-Pencil Integrity Tests
description: Jerry Pardue, vice president of loss prevention for Super D Drugs Inc., a Southeastern drugstore chain, noticed with horror a few years ago that shrinkage - retailing jargon for stolen goods - was rising dramatically. Mr. Pardue wanted to see if paper-and-pencil honesty tests could screen out thieves among job applicants.

title: 'Heidegger for Fun and Profit'
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about expenditures at Merrill Lynch & Company misstated the location of the company's executive offices. They are in the World Financial Center in lower Manhattan.

title: Response to Jet Crash May Bring Reappraisal
description: LEAD: The massive response by volunteer fire departments, ambulances, government officials and the police to the crash of Avianca's Flight 52 may have hindered more than helped efforts to rescue survivors from the fallen jetliner.

title: Alliances to Discuss Aerial Troop Inspections
description: At 16 minutes past 9 o'clock on the morning of Jan. 6, Maj. John Zandburgen eased a Canadian Air Force jet off the tarmac at Ferihegy Airport in Budapest.

title: Correction
description: An air fare listing in the Travel Watch column on Jan. 28 omitted an airline under the heading ''Discount Fare.'' The airline, B.W.I.A., matches the lowest fare, $249, available on the New York-Barbados route.

title: Line of Credit
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An obituary in some copies on Jan. 27, reprinted in all copies on Jan. 28, about the social critic Lewis Mumford, misidentified a historian who reviewed one of his works. The reviewer was Geoffrey Bruun. It also misidentified Mumford's most important mentor. He was Sir Patrick Geddes, a Scottish sociologist and regional planner.

title: Scarsdale Rethinking Zoning Rules
description: THE town's latest zoning battle - over how big a house can be in relation to its lot - has been put on hold while planners consider the outpouring of homeowner anger their new proposed regulations brought forth.

title: Mutual Funds;   Cool Judgment, Hot Results
description: Ken Oberman, manager of Oppenheimer & Company's Global Fund, keeps several cartoons taped near the computer in his crowded New York City office. One depicts the late Andrei Sakharhov as a diminutive figure on one end of a seesaw upending a massive stone monument of Stalin. Another shows Lech Walesa and asks: How many Poles does it take to change the world? (Answer: One.) But the shifting international scene provides more than just wry humor for the 59-year-old Mr. Oberman. The lessons he draws from it have paid off handsomely over the years.

title: Jolt the Press
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A.M.A. CHIEF QUITS IN A SURPRISE MOVE
description: The top executive of the American Medical Association has resigned unexpectedly, 10 months earlier than scheduled, the Chicago-based organization said in a statement issued yesterday.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Woes of a Semi-Vegetarian
description: LEAD: I CONSIDER myself a vegetarian of the lukewarm, spineless, shilly-shallying, semicommitted type, and I assure you it's not an easy thing to be.

title: Police Fired on Crowd, Jesse Jackson Asserts
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said today that the South African Police had fired on a crowd of blacks gathered to welcome him in a black shantytown outside Cape Town. But a police statement said that the shots had been had fired by a black civilian fighting a rival black group.

title: Support Your Local Police Corps
description: In Charleston, S.C., ''flying squads'' of muscular police officers confront and question drug users on the streets. In Tulsa, Okla., teams of officers work in a drug-infested housing project leading Boy Scout troops, serving as role models for youngsters and enrolling children in a police-run summer camp. In San Diego and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., police team up with firefighters and building inspectors to close down crack houses.

title: Ceausescu Was Not a Fan, Official Says
description: Just as the democratic movements of recent months have rehaped the political landscape of Eastern Europe, the sweeping changes have also had profound impact on the sports organization of each country there.

title: Knicks Will Play In Spain Next Fall
description: The Knicks are going international.

title: Devils Suffer First Shutout
description: Brett Hull of the Blues displayed his scoring brilliance again tonight and showed why he is the league's leader in two important categories.

title: Weather May Bring Oil Spill Ashore in California
description: As the cleanup continued on a 10-mile stretch of Southern California beaches, the authorities voiced concern today that a change in the weather might soon wash ashore much more of the nearly 400,000 gallons of crude oil that spilled from a tanker off Huntington Beach on Wednesday.

title: Reviews/Music;   Cynthia Crane, Cabaret
description: Cynthia Crane is a cabaret singer who develops her programs with unusually industrious and productive research. This research has enabled her to do programs on such relatively commonplace themes as songs of the 1920's, the 30's and the 40's, programs that have been brightened by unfamiliar songs - some funny, some romantic, some that reflect the mores of the times - along with tidbits of background information that add to the interest of what is sung.

title: A Treatise Against Drug Use
description: Any film that features a fictional rap group called ''The Say No Rappers,'' whose antidrug lyrics include the lines ''Big Sister is the white girl/ Her name is cocaine,'' can't begin to reach the teen-age audience it is aimed at. Kids are smarter and savvier than that, and it's hard to imagine they will find much truth in ''The White Girl.'' The film is so sincere, blunt and awkward it resembles a 94-minute-long public service message about the dangers of drugs.

title: No Perrier? A Status Bubble Bursts
description: Page Lee, a 27-year-old aerobics instructor at the Body Bank in Washington, felt this way: ''I am really bummed!''

title: Elizabeth Varley To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Varley of Winnetka, Ill., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Elizabeth Burch Varley and Gregory Talcott Camp, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard T. Camp of New York.

title: Susanne Goetz, Therapist, Weds
description: The marriage of Susanne Goetz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Goetz of Piscataway, N.J., to Stephen William Miller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William D. Miller of Bethesda, Md., and Canberra, Australia, took place yesterday at the Takoma Park (Md.) Presbyterian Church. The Rev. George Taylor performed the ceremony. Mrs. Miller, 29 years old, graduated from American University and received a master's degree in social work from Catholic University. She is a therapist in the independent living program at Youth in Transition, a nonprofit agency in Takoma Park. Her father retired as an administrator at Columbia High School in Maplewood, N.J. Her mother, Carolyn Goetz, retired as a high school guidance counselor in Piscataway.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our house is more than 60 years old and has more than one roof on it. The last roof has been on about 20 years, and the last time a contractor checked it he said there were many more years of wear left. I am concerned about the weight of more than one roof on the house because there are some cracks in the foundation, and it appears to me as though the house may be sinking. Could the extra weight of the roof be causing this?

title: Action on Barry's Case Could Be Taken Soon
description: While Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. has been out of town almost three weeks undergoing treatment behind closed doors in Florida, the grand jury investigating allegations of drug use by him has been working hard behind closed doors here. In fact, it has increased its labors. Federal prosecutors have refused to discuss details of the grand jury's work. But other law-enforcement officials say that the main focus, though not necessarily the only focus, has narrowed to trying to come up with enough evidence to indict the Mayor on charges of perjury, obstruction of justice and conspiracy as a result of alleged drug incidents at two hotels here.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE BRONTES: Charlotte Bronte and Her Family, by Rebecca Fraser. (Fawcett Columbine, $12.95.) This biography, in which the Bronte sisters are cast as 19th-century feminists, benefits especially from its portrait of Charlotte, Virginia Tiger said here last year. ''In its deft drawing of the adamantine circlet Victorian convention ringed round women's sphere, as well as in the elegance of its prose, the book is worthy of its subject.''

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: TEN IN A BED

title: Bellport's Gateway Playhouse Seeks Neighborly Harmony
description: LEAD: For more than 30 years, Gateway Playhouse has operated harmoniously with its residential neighbors in Bellport as a summer-stock theater.

description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 3 THE BAD PLACE by Dean R. Koontz (Putnam, $10.95.) The 1988 battle for control of RJR Nabisco. 3 2 14 LIAR'S POKER, by Michael Lewis (Norton, $18.95.) title: Review/Piano;   A Modernist Goes for the Romantic
description: John Cobb, a pianist whose reputation rests largely on his recordings of contemporary music, devoted his program last Sunday evening at Merkin Concert Hall to works drawn mostly from the Romantic mainstream. The one exception, Clementi's Sonata in F-sharp minor, straddles the line between Classicism and Romanticism. But Mr. Cobb pushed it decisively in the latter direction.

title: LEGISLATING THE IMAGINATION
description: In South Korea and East Germany until recently, the Government had to approve every song, book, film or play. In Singapore, the Undesirable Publications Act forbids song lyrics that make references to drugs or have obscene connotations. And if legislators in about a dozen states have their way, the United States will join such havens of enlightenment in allowing the power of the government to regulate the arts. What they're up to, in effect, is an attempt to regulate the imagination.

title: For Not-Quite-Armchair Astronauts
description: LATER, at the end of my three-day weekend at the Space and Rocket Center in Huntsville, Ala., I would be strapped into a plastic sphere hovering atop a two-story column of air, waiting to experience free fall for an almost imperceptible moment. But the first order of business on Friday morning was group pictures. Twenty at a time we 60 adults were arrayed grinning and slightly dazzled in front of a red white and blue space-shuttle logo and a row of smiling counselors. Just like kids at summer camp.

title: Question Of the Week;   Who Is The N.B.A.'s Best Player?

title: BASEBALL FINANCE SETS A GALL STANDARD

Once upon a time, Babe Ruth signed an $80,000 contract with the Yankees in 1930, right after the Wall Street crash. As the President of the United States that year, Herbert Hoover was being paid $75,000. And when the Babe was asked if he thought he deserved to be making more money than the President, he supposedly replied:

title: Image Problems: A Director's Specialty

Ammong these are playing back home movies recorded by the owner's video camera; presenting images of people acting filmed stories; and capturing real events in surveillance situations. The fine lines among these possibilities have been fascinating the Canadian director Atom Egoyan since be began making movies 10 years ago. And his latest film, ''Speaking Parts'' - opening Friday at the Quad theater - takes an unsettling look at those who produce as well as consume images.

title: CHORUS LINE CONFIDENTIAL
description: ONE SINGULAR SENSATION: The Michael Bennett Story. By Kevin Kelly. (Doubleday, $21.95.) Ever since Michael Bennett died from AIDS in 1987, at the age of 44, he has been the subject of controversy over whether he took credit for collaborators' contributions to such musicals as ''A Chorus Line'' and ''Dreamgirls.'' In ''One Singular Sensation,'' Kevin Kelly, the theater critic of The Boston Globe, accepts residual resentments as a given. Mr. Kelly's gossipy biography of the Wunderkind choreographer and Broadway conceptualizer emphasizes the trashy aspects of Bennett's life: his promiscuous bisexuality, his paranoia and drug addiction, his ''casual brutality'' and ''cruelty [that] was extensive.'' Incorporating an abundance of quotations from interviews with Bennett's family, friends and professional associates, Mr. Kelly's relentlessly vicious account accommodates every point of view except Bennett's own. Bennett is described by his colleagues as ''amoral,'' ''insensitive'' and ''narcissistic''; even his palpable energy is demeaned as ''hostile'' and ''ruthless,'' and his ''sexual charisma'' is reduced to a ''strictly calculated'' ploy. According to Mr. Kelly, for Bennett ''theater always came first. He looked upon outside emotional involvement as a hazard; personal commitments cut into the work.'' ''One Singular Sensation'' lacks the substance and detail that any self-respecting biography would be sure to include, and it displays none of the synthesis or analysis that might have produced a more credible portrait. In his rush to make Bennett appear a victim of his neuroses who in turn victimized everyone who entered his orbit, Mr. Kelly has neglected his achievements as a galvanic force behind the concept musical and as a pioneer of the workshop method, and Bennett's already legendary influence has been denigrated.

title: Clouds Over Covenant House

Last year it spent $87 million on programs for runaways, three times what the Federal Government spent on similar programs. And until last week, the heart of Covenant House was the Rev. Bruce Ritter, who started with two abandoned tenements in the East Village in 1968 and who ran the organization that has served more than 200,000 youths in 17 centers in the United States, Canada and Latin America.

And, too, these pet owners are often their own bosses, who can set their own rules.

title: Seller Beware
description: Celebrities have to be cautious about what they endorse these days: somebody might buy it. Lloyd Bridges, the actor, last week became the latest celebrity endorser to be held personally responsible for the failure of a product he pitched. In an out-of-court settlement, Mr. Bridges paid an undisclosed sum to 11 people who lost hundreds of thousands of dollars they had invested with a Michigan real-estate outfit whose principals wound up in jail for fraud. Mr. Bridges, who used to tout the company in television commercials, was not the first star to find his word taken too seriously. As far back as 1981, Pat Boone found himself agreeing to help pay refunds to dissatisfied purchasers of an acne cream he endorsed. Experts disagreed on what the trend might mean for the future of celebrity endorsements. Some said jittery stars would back away from them. But Al Reis, a Connecticut marketing consultant, said the value of celebrity endorsements would increase. He said consumers might reason that, knowing the risk involved, stars would only endorse things they truly believed in.

title: Playwrights Who Put Words At Center Stage
description: Language is reaffirming itself in the American theater, and the harbingers are Mac Wellman, Eric Overmyer and David Ives. In a reaction against the recent emphasis on performance art, they value words - the polysyllabic as well as colorful vernacular. In common, their dialogue has an imaginative intellectual base. By intention these plays begin with a rational impulse, seem to be written intuitively and generally end at recognizable destinations, but the journey can be outrageous - a trip to a Xanadu of the mind.

So far, the American-born, Australian-bred actor's career has been less like Laurence Olivier's than Errol Flynn's. More than any other actor of his generation, Mr. Gibson has translated the old-fashioned Hollywood image of the heartthrob and swashbuckler into contemporary terms in a series of hugely successful entertainments.

In fact, it seems the monsters have more horns every year.

title: Funds Should Flex Their Muscle
description: Last month, two of the nation's largest pension funds took the unprecedented step of trying to confront the corporate lion in his den. Worried about the long decline in the fortunes of the General Motors Corporation, the heads of the California and New York public employees' pension funds wrote to G.M.'s directors and asked how a successor would be selected when Roger Smith, G.M.'s chairman and chief executive, retires this year. These two pension funds, which have major investments in G.M., urged the directors to mount a broad search and asked to be consulted as goals were formulated for the new chairman and chief executive.

title: After the Run of Rich Deals, Risk in Arbitrage is Back

In fact, they contend that the current bloodbath in takeover stocks should not be cause for concern. Rather, they say, it should be seen as just another business opportunity.

After an intricate, unaccompanied introduction, through which Mr. Weston stuttered and shrunk and stretched out the theme, he drew the band into action with thundering, repeated bass notes.

title:
Your Own Account;

In Hot Pursuit of a Perfect Broker
description: LEAD: When markets are edgy, as they have been lately, the number of investors who complain about their brokers rises dramatically, John Markese, research director for the American Association of Individual Investors, says. But brokers aren't performing any worse, he contends: ''A lot of the complaints I hear are really the fault of the investor, not the broker.

title: Currency;   The Dollar Slips a Little More
description: The dollar lost more ground last week as the West German mark rose because of euphoria over the sudden acceleration of negotiations for a common currency for East and West Germany. The current wor ries about higher interest rates and a slumping bond market in West Germany should only weaken the mark temporarily. The Canadian dollar continued to tumble, finishing the week at 83.2 cents against the American dollar, its lowest level since the summer. The Bank of Canada, which set off the decline by signaling a month ago that it would ease interest rates because inflation had come down, stepped in to give the dollar a boost by lifting its key interest rate to 12.79 percent, the highest level since 1984.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a schedule revision by NASA, a brief report on page 15 of the Travel section today about space shuttle launchings gives incorrect dates in some copies for three missions. The Hubble Space Telescope launching is scheduled for April 18; a Defense Department payload is scheduled for July 9; the Gamma Ray Observatory mission is Nov. 1.

title: A DARK LENS ON AMERICA
description: Richard B. Woodward's article ''A Dark Lens on America'' (Jan. 14), about the film maker David Lynch, was fascinating, but he made a naive mistake about ''Blue Velvet,'' Lynch's erotic detective story. Frank Booth isn't inhaling oxygen from that mask - it's obviously some powerful drug (nitrous oxide? amyl nitrite?). It's a small point, but important to understanding the malevolence of his character.

title: Support Group For Organ Recipients
description: ''A New Life Beckons Organ Recipients'' (Jan. 21) told the stories of four transplant recipients whose lives were turned around because they were able to receive an organ transplant. It was an article full of joy and hope. There are hundreds of others who have been given a second chance at life. The list grows daily.

title: A LITTLE BIT CAN MEAN A LOT
description: It has been conventional wisdom that upping the number of digital bits in the decoder circuits of a CD player improves its sound. While CD players were originally designed for 16 bits, companies like Yamaha and Denon proclaimed the superiority of CD players using 18 or even 20 bits. Those extra bits did indeed offer advantages, even though it was rarely understood that the ebulliently advertised claims in this regard needed careful qualification. As far as the public was concerned, the more bits the better became the uncritically accepted motto of digital progress.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of incorrect information supplied by the broker, Joffee LaSalle, the Residential Resales column on Jan. 28 misstated the closing price on a co-op at 80 Warren Street in Manhattan. It was $560,000, not $460,000.

title: East River Helicopter Crash Injures Five
description: A sightseeing helicopter with five people aboard plunged into the East River shortly after taking off yesterday, trapping a 13-year-old passenger under the cold, murky water for almost 20 minutes.

title: Correction
description: An article in the Sunday Sports section on Jan. 28 about the new National Football League commissioner, Paul Tagliabue, incorrectly reported the status of the basketball jersey number 33 worn by Tagliabue and later Patrick Ewing at Georgetown University. The school has not retired the number.

title: ONE UNIVERSE AT A TIME PLEASE
description: THE GREAT AND SECRET SHOW

title: Catherine Farley and David Elkind Wed
description: Catherine Elizabeth Farley and David S. Elkind were married yesterday at the First Church of Round Hill in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Avery C. Manchester, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony. Margaret Patricia Farley, the bride's sister, was her maid of honor and P. Gregory Schwed was the best man.

title: You Don't Move American Landmarks Like Yankee Stadium;   Bad Idea for the Bronx
description: To the Editor:

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

Postpartum Syndrome: A Patient's View
description: LEAD: CONSIDER this scenario: A farmer takes his unconscious horse to a veterinary hospital. A vet, seeking the cause of the animal's collapse, learns that the horse, normally able to carry no more than 250 pounds of supplies, had been carrying 300, and that it had collapsed after climbing a steep hill.

title: Reviews/Dance;   Male Artists To the Fore
description: The New York City Ballet featured some talented young male dancers in leading roles last Sunday afternoon at the New York State Theater.

title:
FOCUS: Boston;

North Station: Neighborhood in Transition
description: LEAD: A BURST of rehabilitation and new construction over the last few years in this city's North Station area has set the stage for growth in what was once a major industrial and shipping district.

title: South Africa's New Era;   Bush Calls Release a Bold and Significant Step
description: President Bush today welcomed the impending release of Nelson Mandela, the anti-apartheid leader in South Africa, as ''another significant step on the road to the nonracial, democratic South Africa which we all desire.''

title: AIDS Plays the Protagonist In Skits for Young Audiences
description: THE girl is young, the boy insistent. ''Come on, have a drink,'' he urges. Daisy hesitates, then gives in. ''You have the most sexy eyes,'' Mark murmers to her. ''I'd really like to know you much better.

title: Review/Dance;   Character Studies by Balanchine
description: ''The Four Temperaments,'' one of George Balanchine's choreographic masterpieces, looked as marvelous as ever when the New York City Ballet offered it for the first time this season on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater.

title: Help From the Bar
description: One small beleaguered corner of government where public services may actually improve during New York City's looming budget crisis is the Human Rights Commission.

title:
ART;

In the Choices of Albee, Imagination Prevails
description: LEAD: The playwright Edward Albee, who once considered a career in art, has continued to develop his visual sensibilities by studying new work and emerging talent.

title: Pavlovsk
description: To the Editor: In his letter on Pavlovsk (Letters on Travel, Jan. 14), Lester Schulman observes that New York ''is rapidly surpassing Calcutta as a model of urban squalor and decay.''

title: EAST TIMOR BISHOP WRITES OF TORTURE
description: In a letter carried here clandestinely, a Catholic bishop in the former Portuguese colony of East Timor has described the human rights situation there as intolerable and has criticized Portugal and the United Nations for failing to intervene on behalf of the Indonesian-occupied territory.

title: WHATS DOING IN: Montreal
description: While snowflakes whirl in the clear, cold air, Montrealers sweep in and out of tony St.-Denis Street shops and bistros. On nearby St. Laurent Street - where chic meets bargain basement - apple-cheeked youngsters toting hockey sticks and skates brush past shoppers as they scurry home before dark. In Old Montreal, passengers sit under warm fur rugs as their horse-drawn caleche clacks over the cobblestone streets. As dusk falls, skaters waltz to Mozart and Madonna on Parc Lafontaine's illuminated, sheltered outdoor rink. And like a giant blancmange, snowy Mount Royal rises from the middle of the city, its slopes traversed by skis, toboggans and sleds.

title: No Rest for Saban
description: AT the age of 68 and with a resume that includes more than 25 athletic jobs, including coach of three professional and seven college footall teams, just about anybody would agree that Lou Saban could use a rest. Just about anybody, that is, but Lou Saban.

title: A DETOUR THAT LED NOWHERE
description: There can be such a thing as a significant book that almost no one reads - Samuel Rich-ardson's ''Pamela, or Virtue Rewarded,'' springs to mind. Undergraduates, forced to ponder the birth of the English novel, are routinely steered toward it, but my own research indicates that only a handful of Ph.D. candidates actually have read more than a chapter or two. I thought of ''Pamela'' the other evening, perhaps unfairly, as I listened to a performance of Schoenberg's ''Book of the Hanging Gardens,'' a pivotal work in his career and, willy-nilly, in the history of music.

title: Jumping Up To a Calypso Beat
description: ''ARE you feeling the feelings baby, baby?'' sings Shadow, a leading exponent of the soul-calypso hybrid known as soca, in one of the hits of last year's carnival in Trinidad. ''Are you getting the symptoms?''

title: Visions, Naive and Otherwise
description: ''EXTRAORDINARY VISIONS'' is the current show at the Magenta Art Gallery, formerly Art by Design, in Rocky Hill. By the word ''visions'' is meant the paintings and drawings of Justin McCarthy and Jack Blumenthal and, for want of a better term, the assemblages of Liz Whitney Quisgard - artists who have little in common but cohere well enough in the exhibition.

title: Racing Slowly To Find A Niche
description: When Bruno Weil was an exchange student in Fresno, Calif., in the 1960's, he made a three-point field goal that won the state championship for his high school football team. After he set the California field-goal record with a 48-yard soccer-style kick, the little place-kicker from Hahnstatten, West Germany, was offered several football scholarships, and might have ended up on the sports pages instead of the music pages.

title: You Don't Move American Landmarks Like Yankee Stadium
description: To the Editor:

title: Questions Arise as Whales Avoid Baja Waters
description: The thousands of gray whales that are normally drawn to the warm bays of Baja California to give birth have failed to show up so far this season, and the authorities say they do not know why.

title: 'Heidegger for Fun and Profit'
description: To the Editor:

title: Just a Basketball Guy
description: ''YOU KNOW WHAT MY FRUSTRATION IN ALL this is?'' Al Bianchi, general manager of the New York Knicks, was saying. ''That I knew, because I had the experience, what a chance we had to win the championship last year. You understand?''

title: FICTION
description: THE ARROWING OF THE CANE. By John Conyngham. (Fireside/Simon & Schuster, Paper $7.95.) ''Things are so volatile in Africa,'' muses the main character of the South African journalist John Conyngham's first novel, not so much stating the obvious as venting the fears and uncertainties of a man in a precarious position. James Colville, a white sugar-cane grower in South Africa, confronts a host of personal demons - unknown arsonists, problems with alcohol and bad relationships - and the divisions in his life after a series of mysterious fires on his plantation and the discovery of a diary written by one of his ancestors during the Boer War. Throughout ''The Arrowing of the Cane,'' Mr. Conyngham reveals not only an understanding of South Africa's fragile contemporary racial equilibrium but also a love of the natural wonders of his country. This book is as much an elegy for the beauty of South Africa as it is an indictment of the policies that remain that nation's enduring legacy. But the book, the first volume in a projected trilogy, is no fictional travelogue. In it, Mr. Conyngham explores - methodically and at a pace that imparts its own tensions - the pressures on modern South Africans, black and white. He conveys the terrors of apartheid without reporting its every vicious particular. By limning these days in the life of one man, Mr. Conyngham has deftly fashioned a metaphor for a country facing its own 3 o'clock in the morning of the soul.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island;   Recent Sales
description: Massapequa Park $157,500

title: Taxes Give the Democrats One More Identity Problem
description: WHEN Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan proposed cutting the Social Security tax, some party consultants seized on the idea as a brilliant political weapon. Here was a Democratic tax cut for the 1990's that was fairer than the Republican tax cuts of the 1980's. At the same time, the proposal revealed two facts of Republican fiscal policy: that cuts in the progressive income tax had effectively been paid for by increases in the regressive payroll tax, and that the proceeds were being spent like any other revenues rather than being socked away.

title: To Czechs, Benes Symbolized Resistance;   Masaryk's Presentiment
description: To the Editor:

title: 10 Students Reported Killed At a Demonstration in Niger
description: The police shot 10 students to death on Friday and wounded 50 others when they opened fire to disperse a protest against austerity measures and cutbacks, medical workers said today.

title: Holiday Displays On Public Property
description: The holiday season is behind us, but the issue of Christmas and Hanukkah displays on public property persists in public debate in Teaneck. Why? From my vantage point as president of the Jewish Community Council of Teaneck, an umbrella group of all of Teaneck's synagogues and major Jewish organizations, the issue persists because it has special historical significance in Teaneck.

title: Unfair Swipe at Anti-Dumping
description: To the Editor:

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Outing;   Rambling in Westchester County: Antiques, Repasts and Greenery
description: Sometimes Sunday outings need not have a destination, but rather a direction - and let chance be your tour guide. A leisurely drive through parts of Westchester County offers a little of everything to the weekend rambler: history, antiques, scenery, shopping, and even some exceptionally fine dining. A recent exploration of the eastern and northern sections of the county turned up more than a few surprises.

title: Reviews/Concert;   Multi-Media Work by Elliott Sharp
description: ''I'm here to deceive you,'' the composer, guitarist and reed player Elliott Sharp told the audience at the Kitchen on Thursday evening, just before he and his six-piece ensemble blasted into the cacophonous opening section of ''Deception: A Docudrama.''

title: Stalking Nature's Secrets in the Swamp
description: M.J. MORSE stalks stinky lilies. At this time of year, her mission includes trips to a the swamp, to take the temperature of skunk cabbage.

title: Where Sushi Is the Strong Suit
description: ONE of New Haven's many attractions is the ethnic diversity of its restaurant scene. In addition to Chinese, French, Indian, Italian, Mexican, Thai and Vietnamese retaurants, there are now three Japanese restaurants in town. Ashiya, named for a town in Japan, is the latest to appear.

title: Searching for Profits in Space
description: Looking for a hot young business? The Commerce Department projected recently that commercial revenues from ventures in space will jump to $3.3 billion this year, up 27 percent from last year.

title: Owners 5, Players 3
description: THE first week of baseball's arbitration hearings ended yesterday with the scoreboard reading:

title: Dr. Sarah Ellis, Psychologist, Marries Adam Yarmolinsky, College Provost
description: Dr. Sarah Ames Ellis, until recently a clinical psychologist in New York, and Adam Yarmolinsky, provost of the University of Maryland's Baltimore County campus, were married Feb. 3 in New York at the Episcopal Church of St. Luke in the Fields by the Rev. Ledlie Laughlin.

title: Volvo 740 Puts On A New Face in '90
description: A lot of people seem to be saying that cars look alike these days, and that may be true. It may have to do with aerodynamics and the need for a slippery shape. Or it may just be that adults have never been able to tell the difference.

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: The Baltics;   Baltics Say the Kremlin Blocks Economic Shifts
description: One month after a new law took effect promising economic independence to the three Baltic republics, officials in the region say they are encountering bitter resistance from Moscow as they try to introduce experiments in free-market economics.

title: Something Is Waning in Celtic Country
description: It's an uneasy time for New England's old Celtic fans. Larry Bird is back, but it's hard to say that the Celtics are. The question raises itself and will not disappear: are the Celtics the Celtics? Doubt moves over New England like a coastal fog.

title: 'Heidegger for Fun and Profit'
description: To the Editor:

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION: LONG ISLAND SOUND;

Of Slings, Arrows and Cherubs
description: LEAD: In three days we celebrate what we used to call ''Valentime's Day'' in Miss Johnson's second-grade class. (Actually, it could have been fourth or seventh grade. Back then, all teachers were named Miss Johnson. As soon as they became Mrs. Whatever, they had to quit because unbridled passion was too distracting for teaching the volume of a cube.) We spent two weeks making Valentines, which, to Miss Johnson's immense relief, satisfied the art requirement for February.

title: Lendl Going Home
description: It's been six years since he has been on native soil, but now that things have loosened up a bit in his homeland, Ivan Lendl said he would pay a visit to Czechoslovkia early next month.

description: To the Editor:

title: UPSCALE AND WORRIED
description: ALL IT TAKES

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: Lincoln's Birthday. A holiday for New York City offices and some banks, but not for Federal offices or the financial markets. The 10-day American International Toy Fair opens in New York.

title: PASTIMES: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Prune grapevines. Limb up large shade trees to allow more light into the garden. Check rose canes for wind or ice damage. Cut off the faded flowers of amaryllis, but allow the leaves to remain and grow to renew the bulb. Check cactuses for mealybugs; control promptly if these insects are found. If gift plants have yellowing leaves and are losing blossoms, discard them.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

What We Want to Hear About Cancer
description: LEAD: The relatives of the recently diagnosed cancer patient look somber and confused. They want to hear numbers. They are used to hearing numbers. On television and in the movies, the doctors always give you numbers: ''He has a 50-50 chance,'' or ''I'm sorry, she has only six months to live.'' They hope most ardently for ''Ninety percent of the time we can cure this.

title: Strawberry's Wife Meets Prosecutors
description: Lisa Stawberry, wife of the Mets' outfielder, Darryl Strawberry, met with prosecutors Friday to discuss the domestic dispute that led to his arrest for on charges of threatening her with a gun.

title: If the Exxon Valdez Spill Is a Crime, Whose Is It?
description: JURORS in the trial of Joseph J. Hazelwood, the former skipper of the Exxon Valdez, are being asked to think of the oil spill that killed more wildlife than any industrial accident in history as little more than a case of drunken driving.

title: Q and A
description: Cherry Blossom Time

title: Question Of the Week;   Who Is The N.B.A.'s Best Player?
description: The best player is not Magic, Larry, Michael or Patrick. If it were not for him, professional basketball would be filled with strike talks, lockouts, and empty arenas, to be viewed only on some regional cable network. Commissioner David Stern is the best player in the N.B.A.

title: Wine Maker Fails to Thwart Street Alcoholics
description: Cheap, fortified wine, street alcoholics' staple drink, is harder to find in some cities these days because of citizens' groups, government agencies and some companies that make it.

title: Deirdre Lowe and C. C. Burke to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Budd Lowe Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Deirdre Ann Lowe to Christopher Charles Burke, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John James Burke Jr. of Chelmsford, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

title: Racers to Test New Waters at Far-Flung Sites
description: The unlikeliest regions for international yacht racing are showing up on the global map this winter for events in both sailing and powerboating.

title: Jenifer Hendee, Teacher, to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Robert Hendee of Denver have announced the engagement of their daughter Jenifer Lisette Hendee to Jonathan Bruce Behrins, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce G. Behrins of Sunset Hill, S.I. An August wedding is planned. Miss Hendee, 24 years old, received a master's degree in special education from Columbia University and is a special-education teacher at Public School 167 in Brooklyn. She and Mr. Behrins, also 24, graduated from Colorado College in 1988. Her father is a pediatric neurosurgeon in Denver.

title: While Gorbachev Gives In, The World Marvels at His Power
description: THE greatest leaders are often, in reality, skillful followers. They do not control the flow of history, but by having the good sense not to stand in its way, they seem to. So it is with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who time and again dazzles the West by accepting reality.

title: When a Man's Condo Is Not His Castle
description: THERE seems to be one in every suburban condominium development - the buyer who moves in full of promise and joy but who over the months begins to chafe under the restrictions imposed on owners. He may want a 30-foot flagpole on his 20-foot house, or he may assert a Constitutional right to paint his front door puce with polka dots.

title: What's in a Name?
description: For years, I was its only parishioner named James Panos. (Actually, James is not my name, it's Jim. But few people have the guts to use Jim officially. There seems to be that about the familiar form of a name that precludes its use in a formal setting.) A few years ago, I saw the name James Panos listed in the monthly bulletin of my church, as a donor of a contribution I had not made. I let it pass. But in a later edition, there it was: two equal contributions by two parishioners named James Panos. This frustrating confusion persisted for a couple of years. Finally, I asked the church to change my name to Jim on all their files. Having two parishioners with the exact name must have been playing havoc with their mailing lists and bookkeeping because the change was effected pronto and, I suspect, with relief on both sides.

title: Design;   TARTAN TOUCHES
description: Few fabrics carry with them as much folklore as the tartan. Scottish plaids have been used as coats of arms, articles of clothing and patterns that decorate everything from mugs to jewelry boxes.The earliest tartans were thought to have been woven by the Celts before the year 1000. Indeed, these plaids were so much a part of the Scottish culture that between 1746 and 1782, the British Parliament banned their wearing by anyone except the military, in an attempt to break up Scottish clans. King George IV's visit to Scotland in 1822 prompted a tartan revival. Queen Victoria's use of tartans in the interiors of Balmoral Castle turned these plaids into a decorating trend. A similar revival is happening today. ''When Queen Victoria discovered tartan, the Queen invented her own nostalgia about Scottish history,'' says Keith Irvine, a partner in the Manhattan-based decorating company of Irvine & Fleming, who is Scottish. ''Tartans became like the Ralph Lauren decorating style of the 1840's.'' Today decorators are once again using tartan fabrics and objects all over the house. ''The patterns are so recognizable that people feel comfortable living with tartan,'' says Tom Fleming, Irvine's partner. In a living room in Westchester County, for example, Fleming slipcovered much of the upholstery in a tartan wool. ''Tartan is commonly thought of as a winter fabric,'' says Fleming. ''But it's seasonless. There are also wonderful tartan linens that have a crisp look - perfect for summer.''

Why Women Wear What They Wear

description: Magic Johnson of the Lakers has already racked up five National Basketball Association championships. Ewing, Jordan, Barkley, Karl Malone, Akeem Olajuwon and Dominique Wilkins as a group are still searching for their first.

The Executive Life;

Agonizing Over A 'Barbarians' Soiree

Two weeks earlier, the engraved invitations had gone out: ''Norman Pearlstine and The Wall Street Journal invite you to celebrate the publication of 'Barbarians at the Gate' by Bryan Burrough and John Helyar.

description: EAGER to preserve their pristine land in its natural state,a growing number of property owners are exploring a technique known as a ''conservation easement.''

title: Vanessa Kagan Plans to Marry Matthew Diserio

description: LEAD: Owing to increasing revelations of sexual abuse of children, the Lawrence School District has formalized a regulation for its teachers: a touch-at-your-own-risk policy.

description: If the best is a measure of a man's spirit as well as his ability, then the Round Mound wins, hands down. Charles Barkley.

title: Budget Plan Puts Pressure On the Towns
description: WHETHER the $7.2 billion budget that Gov. William A. O'Neill proposed last week is a masterwork of hard-nosed cost-cutting, as many Democrats contend, or a magician's trick full of trap doors, as the Republicans see it, one thing is almost certain as the debate over it goes on: aid to towns and cities, although up from last year, will not be enough. And while the Governor's budget would not raise taxes, municipalities probably will.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 31 of Arts and Leisure about the conductor Bruno Weil misstates the date of one of his appearances at the 92d Street Y. He will conduct on Saturday at 8 P.M., as well as Sunday at 3, and not on Monday.

title: At the Local Post Office, Each Day Is Valentine's Day
