This year, for the first time, the post office is also selling Valentines, from chocolate bars mimicking Love stamps to a heart-shaped plastic music box with a Love stamp pin set in pink tissue paper.

title: CELESTIAL RIFFS, A BLONDE IN A SOMBRERO
description: NO MERCY

title: It's Connecticut's Turn to Find Out About Hard Times
description: THROUGH the roaring 1980's, as Connecticut caught up with and then surpassed Alaska as the richest state in the nation in personal income, it began to seem to many people both inside and outside the state that things here had somehow turned to gold. There was virtually no unemployment, taxes were more likely to go down than up, and growth outstripped the national average for years.

title: Sweet Hearts
description: ''We make them all year round for once a year,'' Walter J. Marshall says. ''That's a Valentine's product, exclusive.'' Marshall, who is the marketing and special-projects manager for the New England Confectionery Company (better known as NECCO), is speaking, of course, about the items known in the candy trade as ''conversation hearts.'' NECCO, a company whose origins date to 1847, originated them, Marshall says, around the turn of the century, though no one knows quite when. They're made by several confectioners now, but it is likely that NECCO remains the leader, churning out, from its Cambridge, Mass., factory, two sizes of tastefully-inscribed, heart-shaped wafers, a total of approximately 1.7 billion pieces every year. ''If you put them back to back, they would go from Boston to San Francisco and back to New York,'' Marshall says. ''We don't quite make it the last 200 miles back to Boston.''

title: SAY GOODBYE TO THE STUFFED ELEPHANTS
description: I finished a tour of Epcot Center a couple of weeks ago feeling angry because the place turned out to be a carnival (''Say Goodbye to the Stuffed Elephants,'' by William H. Honan, Jan. 14). The technology that was used to show the exhibits was more instructive than the exhibits themselves. The ''hands on'' displays for the kids were nothing more than video games.

title: Truth In Packaging
description: To the Editor:

title:
FORUM;

How to Rescue the Peace Dividend
description: LEAD: President Bush, in his first budget submitted to Congress, may think he has set the ground rules for the peace dividend. But he is already losing control of the process.

title: Susan Zilling to Wed R. J. Albright Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. George R. Zilling of Westport, Conn., have announced April wedding plans for their daughter Susan Elizabeth Zilling and Raymond Jacob Albright Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Albright of Chevy Chase, Md.

title:
GARDENING;

Selecting a Spring-Blooming Magnolia
description: LEAD: MAGNOLIAS are among the most popular flowering trees, yet the most commonly planted hybrid has a major flaw: its blossoms are frequently blackened by frost.

title: As Jerusalem Labors to Settle Soviet Jews, Native Israelis Slip Quietly Away
description: At times it seemed a futile exercise. But for weeks on end Mordechai Glick and a few other volunteers showed up outside the United States Embassy each morning at dawn and handed leaflets to Israelis waiting in long lines outside the visa office.

title: Fashion: On the Street;   Objects d'Art Turn Heads This Winter
description: When large overcoats hide fashion, hats become a prime form of expression. This winter, it seems, every other hat wearer is an artist.

title: Unfair Swipe at Anti-Dumping Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: ONE NIGHT IN QUEENS
description: INCIDENT AT HOWARD BEACH

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester;   Recent Sales
description: Danbury, Conn. $178,500

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Diplomacy
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today became the first American Government official to testify before a committee of the Soviet Parliament. He told the legislators that he felt as though he was appearing ''before the Founding Fathers of a new Soviet Union.''

title: Question Of the Week;   Who Is The N.B.A.'s Best Player?
description: Five championship rings. Two-time Most Valuable Player. Ear-to-ear grin. Need I say more?

title: 'I'D RATHER BE A GREAT BAD POET'
description: A review of ''Loving Letters From Ogden Nash'' on Feb. 11 referred erroneously to the poet's widow, Frances Leonard Nash, recipient of many of the letters. She remains alive, in Maryland.

title: Tech Notes;   A Gauntlet Against Contamination
description: Kevlar, a synthetic fiber that is five times as stiff as steel on a same-weight basis, has long been the key ingredient in bulletproof vests. Now it has been incorporated into surgical gloves that E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company hopes will appeal to doctors and nurses concerned about contracting AIDS and other blood-borne diseases from accidental cuts during surgery.

title: Fashion;   'Eco-Jewelry' Shaped by Nature
description: Eco-jewelry - bracelets, earrings and necklaces whose materials, or at least their shapes, spring from nature - is everywhere this season.

title: An Arts Center For Downtown
description: HURT by sliding oil prices and the death of the uranium industry in the 80's and anxious about cuts in spending at nearby defense-related industries, this city is trying to revitalize its downtown, stimulate convention business and attract new industry.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 33 of Arts and Leisure, about television talk shows, misstates the broadcast time for ''A World of Ideas'' on PBS. It is shown on Sundays at 6:30 P.M., not 6.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;

Developers Turn to Financial Incentives
description: LEAD: THE purchase incentive that John Wallice, a Huntington developer, offered buyers at his Indian Trace town-house development in Kings Park last Christmas was a Cutlass Supreme automobile valued at $10,000. There were no takers.

title: A DARK LENS ON AMERICA
description: We all wonder why there is so much violence in our society. The Stuart case here in Boston has refueled these feelings of helplessness. You treat David Lynch as a creative force in the movie industry, but in my view his vision is dark and feeds the ugliest fantasies of his audience. Call his work by its rightful name - pornography.

title: Lisa Shrewsberry Becomes a Bride
description: Lisa Lynn Shrewsberry and Edgar Charles Ivory Greene were married yesterday at Simsbury House in Simsbury, Conn., by Mr. and Mrs. Webster T. Copp, justices of the peace from West Hartford, Conn.

title: Hanoi Remains True to Communism, But Party Is Making More Changes
description: Moscow may have embraced the changes sweeping Eastern Europe, but Vietnam's leaders are mostly sticking to the old-time religion, at least for now.

title: From Turkey and Iran, 'A Singular Vision' in White Plains
description: THE Middle East promises to be a major theme for the next few months, with shows about ancient Egypt at both the Hudson River Museum and Sarah Lawrence College Art Gallery, both in Yonkers. Still, the Museum Gallery at the White Plains Public Library has already started proceedings with ''A Singular Vision,'' a selection of paintings, works on paper and sculptures by artists from Iran and Turkey.

title: Hanging On to Marriage: Tough Task in a Throwaway World
description: DURING a dial-turning session one quiet evening, Paul Newman's face flashed onto my television screen. To my surprise he was talking to Barbara Walters. I'm not a fan of the ubiquitous Ms. Walters but I knew that Newman rarely submits to an interview. I paused to listen.

title: Rogers Is Killingly's 4th Biggest Employer
description: I enjoyed ''The View From Rogers: By Letting There Be Light, a Company Remains a Namesake'' (Jan. 14). However, I would like to point out an inaccuracy in the article. The article referred to Rogers as a village and at another point said that the Rogers Corporation was 'the town's largest and, in fact, only major employer.''

title: OPPOSING ORTEGA
description: BY THE TIME THE CANDIDATE ARRIVES, THE crowd in Granada, Nicaragua, is thousands strong. Ragged street vendors are making a month's pay in hours, and small boys, climbing up for the best view, cling to high shade trees like giant fruit.

title: GIRL FRIDAY TELLS ALL SHE CAN
description: LEAD:

title: PERSPECTIVES: Two-Families in Bushwick;   Widening the Paths to For-Sale Housing
description: IN the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, where other news lately has been grim, something of a home-building resurgence is under way. It has demonstrated that even in one of the poorest sections of the city there are people of moderate means willing and able to invest thousands of their own dollars in a new house.

title: Valentine Poetry Reading
description: Love poems old and new are to be read by a number of writers and others in the arts, including Eric Bogosian, Ann Carlson, Lenny Kaye, Sally Silvers and Ishmael Houston-Jones, on Wednesday at 7:30 P.M. at St. Mark's Church in the Bowery, Second Avenue and 10th Street. Admission is $5. Information: 674-0910.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week;   What Do You Think of The Baseball Impasse?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Ms. Luong Plans To Wed in August
description: Minh-Chau Luong and Willam Maxwell Crouch Jr. plan to marry in August, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Luong-Si Chuong of Cherry Hill, N.J., have announced. Mr. Crouch is a son of Dorothy M. Crouch of Bridgeport, Conn., and the late Mr. Crouch.

title: Long Island Journal
description: Time on Their Hands

title: Shopping for Squid Ink Pasta? Read On.
description: BENEATH the green awning that bears his name, Peter DeRose knelt near a meticulously arranged display of fruits and vegetables as he inspected a shipment of Spanish olive oil. ''Isn't this gorgeous?'' he said, holding up a slender-necked bottle designed to evoke medieval Spain. ''This is when business becomes a work of art.''

title: Robin Fins Is Wed to Lee V. Kaplan
description: Robin Lori Fins, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herman E. Fins of Rockville Centre, L.I., was married there last evening at the Central Synagogue of Nassau County to Lee Victor Kaplan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Kaplan of Massapequa, L.I. Rabbi Jeffrey L. Salkin and Cantor Carla Boscoe-Reynolds officiated.

title:
GARDENING;

Selecting a Spring-Blooming Magnolia
description: LEAD: MAGNOLIAS are among the most popular flowering trees, yet the most commonly planted hybrid has a major flaw: its blossoms are frequently blackened by frost.

title: 25 Years Later, Racial Tensions Revive in Selma
description: A bitter dispute over control of this city's school system has provoked racial animosity just a month before a planned 25th-anniversary commemoration of the ''Bloody Sunday'' protest march that placed Selma indelibly on the map of civil rights battlegrounds.

title: There's Nothing Going for Them But Talk
description: The art of conversation has never been highly developed on television, that famously or infamously visual medium. For the most part, tube talk takes the form of the kissy-kiss gush of show-biz personalities, dim jokes about the weather by local television hosts, early morning burblings about nothing at all. By comparison, the gee-whizzings of sports commentators seem like geopolitical analysis.

title: Deborah Marion Plans a Wedding
description: John L. Marion of New York and Mary Anne Marion of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Deborah Mary Marion to Michael Brearton Murray, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony S. Murray of Darien, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: TYSON LOSES WORLD TITLE IN A STUNNING UPSET
description: James (Buster) Douglas rebounded from a nearly devastating eighth-round knockdown today to pummel Mike Tyson into an overwhelming knockout 1:23 into the 10th round and take the world heavyweight title away from a boxer who had been declared all but unbeatable.

title: Campus Life: Brown;   A 20-Year Experiment Is Praised as a Success
description: Brown's heralded 20-year experiment in student-guided undergraduate education was labeled a ''resounding success'' in an internal review published last week by the university. But its author said the program, free of stated requirements and featuring a pass/fail grade option, has not worked for ''a small minority'' who need a curriculum made of sterner stuff.

title: THE WOUNDS OF CHANGE
description: LEAD:

title: Housebuster Takes Hutcheson as Rhythm Is 7th
description: Housebuster staggered home to a three-length victory over Yonder today in the $94,645 Hutcheson Stakes at Gulfstream Park as Rhythm, last year's 2-year-old champion, finished a dismal seventh in his first start as a 3-year-old.

title: 'Heidegger for Fun and Profit'
description: To the Editor:

title: Board Tries Balancing Act On Yonkers Sludge Plant
description: THE Board of Legislators seemed to solve one problem while compounding another last week when it approved the construction of an $18.9 million sludge-drying plant in the Ludlow Park section of Yonkers. The action came in time for the county to avoid Federal fines for ocean dumping of toxic wastes.

title: Salmon Backer Praises Scots
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Why Not Prudence Plus Leadership?
description: President Bush said last week he'd rather be ''cautious'' than ''reckless'' in how he builds bridges from the old cold war to the new international order and in how he cuts military spending. It's commendable to avoid mistakes, but caution alone can be wrong-minded and even reckless in other ways.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: Dr. Irving Sandler;

Championing Free Artistic Expression
description: LEAD: WHEN the National Endowment for the Arts last November revoked a $10,000 grant to Artists Space, a Manhattan art gallery, for an exhibition about AIDS, the art world very forcefully condemned what it viewed as a censorship attempt. Its collective voice was not unheard; in the same month, the Federal agency reversed itself.

title: Bonus Run Eludes Elliott
description: It was 1:30 this morning, and Peter Elliott was wide awake. His time clock had been askew since he flew from New Zealand to the United States last Sunday after his stunning victory in the Commonwealth Games 1,500-meter final.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our house is more than 60 years old and has more than one roof on it. The last roof has been on about 20 years, and the last time a contractor checked it he said there were many more years of wear left. I am concerned about the weight of more than one roof on the house because there are some cracks in the foundation, and it appears to me as though the house may be sinking. Could the extra weight of the roof be causing this?

title: Campus Life: Dartmouth;   Blacks Create Business to Solve Tonsorial Problem
description: For most of Dartmouth College's 4,000 undergraduates, a trip to the local barbershop or beauty salon is no big deal. But for about 300 black students, until recently, getting a haircut or hairdo to their liking often meant a two-hour trip to Boston.

title: POSTINGS: F.H.A. Loans;   Higher Ceilings
description: The Federal Housing Administration has raised the ceilings on its guaranteed home mortgages in high-cost areas from $101,250 to $124,875 for a one-family home. Administration officials estimated that the change, made last month, would enable 100,000 more moderate- and low-income families to get federally guaranteed private loans.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our house is more than 60 years old and has more than one roof on it. The last roof has been on about 20 years, and the last time a contractor checked it he said there were many more years of wear left. I am concerned about the weight of more than one roof on the house because there are some cracks in the foundation, and it appears to me as though the house may be sinking. Could the extra weight of the roof be causing this?

title: Ewing Demanding Attention
description: When Patrick Ewing walks to midcourt for the tip-off of the All-Star Game today, it will be another symbol of the indelible impression he has left on the National Basketball Association this season.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester;   Waterfront Plunge Is Paying Dividends
description: WHEN Michael DiScala and James Gardella bought the Lock Building near the waterfront of the South Norwalk neighborhood 17 years ago, they knew that the city was at its nadir. The partially rented, 125,000-square-foot factory was losing $60,000 a year and was surrounded by derelict industrial buildings in an area that attracted street people.

title: The Needs Of the Retarded
description: It was gratifying to read Walter H. McCarthy's piece, ''What the Retarded Need: Social Skills'' [Opinion, Jan. 7] . As the parent of a 32-year-old sheltered workshop client, I agree wholeheartedly with his assessment of the current situation.

title: Walking Trips
description: To the Editor: As a veteran of six walking trips with three different organizations, I read Betsy Wade's article on walking vacations (Practical Traveler, Dec. 3) with great interest. In 1980 I went on my first English walking trip, conducted by Douglas Caldow of Country Walking Holidays, a 17-day trip in four different areas.

title: For Valentine's Day, Dinner for Two
description: IT is time to dust off the heart-shaped cookie cutters and cake molds again. Valentine's Day is Wednesday.

title: How Fit Is Fit For the Trip?
description: HOW fit is fit so far as travel is concerned?

title: David Butz Wed To Heidi Cuddihy
description: Harriet DeHaven Cuddihy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Murray Cuddihy of New York, was married yesterday at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York to David Alan Butz, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Robert J. Butz of Columbus, Ohio. The Rev. John G. B. Andrew officiated, assisted by the bridegroom's father, a Presbyterian minister.

title: Meeting on Subway Leads to Gift to Neediest
description: An unexpected conversation on the subway led Martha D. Stevenson of Manhattan to write a check to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and to think about how she chooses to give to charitable causes.

title: Syracuse Pleases Packed House
description: The citizens of central New York, at least the ones who insist they bleed Syracuse Orange, have grown to live for nights like this, when the words ''Sold Out'' are posted on the ticket windows of the Carrier Dome and a record crowd is stacked on three levels, all the way up to a Teflon sky.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: South Street Seaport;   Delays in Redevelopment Imperil Historic Properties
description: COLLAPSE and construction. The signals are as contradictory as any area can send and they are found within a few yards of one another in the South Street Seaport Historic District in lower Manhattan, symbolizing both the tenuous redevelopment and continued abandonment of that 19th-century quarter.

title: Cathleen Kegelman Wed To Douglas A. Reynolds
description: Cathleen Kegelman, an associate buyer for Brooks Brothers, and Douglas Allen Reynolds, an associate at Solomon Brothers, both in New York, were married yesterday at St. Catharine's Church in Spring Lake, N.J. The Rev. Joseph Slinger performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: Campus Life: U.C.L.A.;   Group Disciplined For Harassing Lesbian Sorority
description: A fraternity at the University of California at Los Angeles has been placed on probation after a lesbian sorority said that fraternity members ridiculed and humiliated them at a school football game.

title: Reviews/Music;   Camper Van Beethoven's Mild Rock
description: Camper Van Beethoven played a set like a shaggy-dog story on Tuesday night, opening a three-night engagement at CBGB (315 Bowery, at Bleecker Street). The band's singer, David Lowery, kept asking the audience, ''Are you tired yet?'' The music was unhurried, casual and digressive, with a deadpan ease that carried listeners toward mild punch lines. The songs themselves might be quizzical or death-haunted or optimistic or slyly cutting, but the tone was easygoing, with the half-ironic equanimity that flourishes in northern California.

title: Campus Life: Temple;   Fraternity Redoes Vacant House Of an Old Brother
description: Five years ago, the four-story house of the founder of Temple University was a hazard to the Sigma Pi brothers who lived next door. People repeatedly broke in, old mattresses were strewn about, and vagrants would start fires in the old house, said Donald Cox, alumni president of the fraternity chapter.

title: The Charms of the U.S.A. Are Selling Well
description: THE host of Walt Disney World's Super Star Television attraction recently wandered through the crowd of visitors to the Florida theme park, asking the standard question: ''Where are you from?''

title: JERSEYANA
description: LEAD: THE trolley car traveling north on Clifton Avenue was jammed with teen-agers on their way to high school that cold winter morning. The city was covered in snow, and the students were having fun, chatting and singing to one another. The trolley was packed so tightly that they were standing in the aisles.

title: Southeast Asia Is Now No. 1 Source of U.S. Heroin
description: The Golden Triangle of Southeast Asia, whose flow of drugs the United States has been trying to control for 25 years, is once again the single-largest source of heroin coming into America, with production levels rising sharply.

title: No Joy, but Also No Panic in Florida
description: There is no joy in Port St. Lucie, 109 miles north of here.

title: Oscar Brand Returns to Hyman Kaplan
description: LEAD: Of the thousands of projects in which Oscar Brand has been involved as a folk singer, radio and television host, writer and composer, none has been as important to him as ''The Education of Hyman Kaplan,'' or as enduring.

title: GROWTH HORMONE AND CHILDREN: NEW ERA
description: Going to school, and particularly attending g m classes, used to be torture for Scott F. of Plainview, because classmates teased and mocked him about his height. Only 4 feet 9 inches tall, at age 14, he was so embarrassed about being small he would shy away from his peers.

title: Legacy From Photography's Mount Olympus
description: Of the score or more museum exhibitions organized in ob-servance of 150 years of photography, none has been more eagerly awaited than ''Photography Until Now,'' which opens next Sunday at the Museum of Modern Art. The anticipation is partly a matter of timing, since ''Photography Until Now'' is the last of the sesquicentennial shows to make an appearance. But it is also a reflection of the stature of the show's curator, John Szarkowski.

title: AFTER 60 YEARS, A TRIANGLE IS ROUNDED OFF
description: I am not sure whether the most remarkable thing about the recent competition to find a building to complete the Federal Triangle was the design that won, the design that lost, or the fact that the competition was held at all. For this was like few architectural competitions in our time or any other: all entrants were required to produce a design in the spirit of the neo-classical architecture of the rest of the Federal Triangle, the vast complex of Federal offices between Pennsylvania Avenue, Constitution Avenue and 15th Street that was built in the late 1920's and early 1930's.

title: A LIFETIME OF CONFLICT
description: July 18, 1918 - Mandela is born at Qunu, a small town in the Xhosa-speaking region of Transkei, the son of a Tembu tribal leader. 1938 - Mandela enters Fort Hare College. Two years later, he is expelled for participation in a student strike and moves to Johannesburg. 1941 - Mandela completes work for his bachelors' degree by correspondence and studies law at the University of the Witwatersrand in Johannesburg. 1944 - Mandela, Oliver Tambo and Walter F. Sisulu help form the Youth League of the African National Congress.

title: U.S. JUDGE IS TRIED ON INFLUENCE USE
description: At the opening volleys of his racketeering trial, Federal District Judge Robert P. Aguilar has been portrayed by the Government as an example of the American dream turned nightmare of public disgrace because of power brokering on behalf of a Federal fugitive, a casino owner and two convicted felons.

title: Mood Swings Set the Tone On the Street
description: If psychiatrists, rather than economists, were the specialists that Wall Street relied upon, they might have a simple explanation for the way the stock and bond markets have moved this year. ''Manic-depressive'' would be the diagnosis. One moment all is well; the next brings obvious and overwhelming reasons for fear.

title: FROM SHANGHAI TO PANAMA: A LEGEND REMINISCES
description: It took Patricia Foy five years to persuade Margot Fonteyn to tell the story of her life as a ballerina, as the wife of a Panamanian diplomat-revolutionary and as the emblem of English classical ballet. Miss Foy, one of the first female producer-directors at BBC-TV in London, laughs, remembering their conversations. ''She'd say, 'It's so boring,' '' Miss Foy recalled. '' 'Now I'm living with all these cows in Panama. Who would be interested?' ''

title: Corrections
description: A report last Sunday about the engagement of Suzette M. Brooks and Seth J. Masters described the prospective bride's education incompletely. She graduated cum laude from Harvard Law School.

title: The Right To Complain?
description: To the Editor:

title: Baseless Fears of a Unified Germany
description: LEAD: As Germany's unification unexpectedly draws closer, fear of what it could bring is heard from many quarters, especially from the Soviet Union and other European neighbors. But what exactly are the grounds for such fear, and how valid are they?

title: Iran-Contra: Pressure For a Fuller Accounting
description: FOR a time it seemed that the Iran-contra investigation might lead into the Oval Office and threaten the Presidency of Ronald Reagan. In any case, many hoped, the appointment of Lawrence E. Walsh as special prosecutor in the case would finally help affix responsibility for the secret actions that bedeviled Mr. Reagan's last term.

title:
MUSIC;

New Ventures Ahead For Hoboken Orchestra
description: LEAD: AFTER nine years of struggling to gain identity as a musical force in the state, the Hoboken Chamber Orchestra seems to be on solid ground. ''We are suddenly reaching that point of combustion,'' said Gary M. Schneider, the orchestra's founding music director and conductor.

title: Old Pro, Young Idol Team Up for 'Revenge'
description: On a cool, damp and somewhat misty December afternoon, two men walk across a meadow, rifles in hand and hunting dogs baying as they advance toward a cluster of pine trees in pursuit of their prey. The age difference between them is such that they could be father and son, and the easy familiarity they display toward each other suggests just that. Kevin Costner and Anthony Quinn are busy at work, but as the cameras roll, it is difficult to tell where their roles end and reality begins, so comfortable do they seem in each other's company.

title: How Latin America's Economies Look After a Decade's Decline
description: AFTER a decade in which average incomes fell while foreign debt and inflation soared, Latin America remains in deep economic crisis. The future of its new democracies may well rest on the ability of civilian leaders to improve living standards in the 1990's as they try to modernize their economies in the face of enormous obstacles.

title: Question Of the Week;   Who Is The N.B.A.'s Best Player?
description: Larry Bird neither jumps nor runs nor dunks very well, but he has consistently accomplished all the things that make greatness.

title: Valentine's Day Shopping For Romantics on the Run
description: LEAD: AS holidays go, St. Valentine's Day is a lovely one, filled with hearts, flowers and expressions of sentiment. But when buying those flowers, few people have the time to stand on a long line at the local florist.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Riccardo Muti's Journey To 'the Father of Us All'
description: When Riccardo Muti thinks of Giovanni Battista Pergolesi, whose ''Stabat Mater'' he will conduct tomorrow evening at Carnegie Hall, he thinks of his own youth and of his old age. ''When I was a student at the Naples Conservatory,'' he said the other day after a rehearsal in Philadelphia, ''we were trained to breathe the spirit of the masters of the Neapolitan School. Our daily work was what was required to have a degree, but our ghosts were Jomelli, Durante, Leo, Cimarosa, Pergolesi. Pergolesi in particular; Cimarosa called him 'il padre di tutti noi' '' - the father of us all.

title: A Musical That's Set In a Bronx Cemetery
description: EARLY on in the American Stage Company's new musical, ''A Fine and Private Place,'' a big bologna descends from on high, landing on the stage with a thump. Unless a show aspires to follow in the pratfalls of ''Sugar Babies'' or ''A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum,'' it's not likely to live down a portentous moment like that.

title: HOLIDAY ON MONDAY
description: Lincoln's Brithday will be celebrated Monday. Here are holiday schedules.

title:
DINING OUT;

Light and Healthful Fare in Hastings
description: LEAD: DEVIN ANTHONYS is one of an increasing number of neighborhood restaurants looking hard at what today's diner wants and making an effort to deliver it. To judge from the crowds that line up not only on weekends but also on weeknights, Devin Anthonys has discovered a winning formula: feature pasta and seafood, lighten sauces and be ready to accommodate diners who want none at all, add a fresh salad and a generous variety of carefully cooked vegetables and deliver the tasty goods in unstinting portions and at a moderate if not a bargain price.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: BLUEBIRDS

title: Korean Students and Police Clash
description: Hundreds of students shouting anti-Government and anti-American slogans fought the riot police today with firebombs and rocks to protest the creation of a new conservative governing coalition.

title: Spring Break
description: Some people simply left their overcoats unbuttoned, their scarves dangling and their gloves in their pockets. More fashionable types pulled out whatever it was they'd put away in October and didn't expect to see again for months. For a few days, it has been spring in New York.

title: Why We 'Interfered' With G.M.
description: My decision to ask the board of directors of the General Motors Corporation to describe the process of selecting a new chairman and chief executive was prompted by a number of concerns I have as a major shareholder.

title: Some Americans Abroad, a Playwright at Home
description: In ''Some Americans Abroad,'' which opens tonight at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center, a group of college English professors and their students go on a theater tour of England. The teachers sit at dinner, debating Shaw, capital punishment, the role of politics on the stage and who should pay for the wine. They visit Stratford and peruse the list of souvenirs: T-shirts, shopping bags, the Game of Shakespeare. They walk across Westminster Bridge in London, recite Wordsworth and sing ''God Save the Queen.''

title: Sponsor Woes
description: To the Editor:

title: Objects d'Art
description: To the Editor: The congruence of the situation described by Lynda Morgenroth (''The Lamp That Got Away,'' Travel, Jan. 14) of not buying an objet d'art, a lamp in her case, was remarkably uncanny to my own.

title: PASTIMES: Bridge;   Correction
description: In the dealt hand in last Sunday's bridge column, the clubs were misplaced. They are as follows: North: A J 8 6 2, East 5 4; South 10 3; West K Q 9 7.

title: Munich
description: To the Editor: On a recent visit to Munich, I visited the German Museum of Hunting and Fishing on Neuhauser Strasse. I found the entire museum fascinating, but one exhibit particularly impressed me. On the second floor was a large, low table filled with stuffed animals. In addition to a written identification of these animals, a Braille plate beside each one bore its name. Of course, the blind could touch the animals to understand their shape and the feel of their fur.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International

title: Tough Get Going
description: Sounding as if she had just had a halftime pep talk from a football coach, Leona Helmsley seemed eager to take the offensive last week as she prepared to defend herself against the next round of tax evasion charges. Mrs. Helmsley, who is appealing her Federal conviction, not only said she was innocent of those counts and the state charges she still faces, but also implied that she might be due a tax refund. ''I have never cheated on my taxes,'' she said. ''I've overpaid my taxes.'' Mrs. Helmsley, the wife of Harry Helmsley, the real-estate magnate who was also indicted but found incompetent to stand trial, faces a Federal sentence of four years in prison and a $7 million fine, and a coming state trial on charges that she falsified $3 million in business records. Mrs. Helmsley is out on $25 million bond and has hired Alan Dershowitz, the Harvard Law School professor, to keep her from behind bars. Mr. Dershowitz last week sought a speedy state trial for his client and promised that shocking ''new evidence'' would prove her innocent on all counts.

title: It's All in the Mind
description: MY childhood was marred by what I considered an unforgivable deprivation: 16 years elapsed between my birth and my first flight on an airplane. When my parents finally relented and let me ascend into the heavens - an hourlong shuttle flight from La Guardia to Logan to accompany an older brother on a college interview in Boston - I got airsick. The prospect of all-out nuclear war seemed preferable to my getting on another plane. As if in punishment for my hubris, there was turbulence on the return flight and I came within a hair of disgracing myself. I shook all the way home in the car. So the dreams of youth nosedive into reality.

title: The State That's Wasting Welfare
description: In lawmaking, as in any field, work expands to fill the time available. So it wasn't surprising that, with a deadline of October 1990, the New York Legislature last year failed to pass legislation putting the new Federal welfare reform law into effect. It wasn't surprising - and it wasn't responsible. That failure cost New York money, at least $4.5 million so far, and counting. New Yorkers have a right to wonder what's going on in Albany. More important, they have a right to see welfare reform done right.

title: FICTION
description: THE SINGING SPIRIT: Early Short Stories by North American Indians. Edited by Bernd C. Peyer. (University of Arizona, $24.95.) Louise Erdrich, N. Scott Momaday, Leslie Marmon Silko and James Welch are among the bright stars of contemporary American Indian fiction. Their names are well known, their works widely read. But earlier American Indian fiction writers are not so familiar. In ''The Singing Spirit,'' the Swiss scholar and ethnologist Bernd C. Peyer has collected a treasure trove of stories from the late 19th and early 20th century. Written primarily for a white audience by men and women from numerous tribes, these tales, supported by Mr. Peyer's excellent introduction, enable us to trace the richly diverse origins of the extraordinary output of American Indian fiction that has occurred since the late 1960's. ''The Singing Spirit'' includes hunting adventures, romantic narratives, revenge tales, stories adapted from an oral tradition, satirical sketches and a few stories, masterly in their art, that transcend any easy categorization. ''A Red Girl's Reasoning'' by Pauline Johnson passionately portrays the rage and heartbreak of a young couple when the Anglo husband scorns an Indian tradition sacred to his new bride. Incompatible cultural values are also the subject of ''The Problem of Old Harjo'' by John M. Oskison, but the author treats this theme with a comic touch. Not all the stories in ''The Singing Spirit'' are of equal literary merit, but even the weakest provide fascinating ethnographic data. Reading this collection is like visiting a well-appointed period room in a museum, a welcome and informative experience.

title: New York 'Ground Clutter' Moving Weather Unit to L.I.

description: A group of Bulgarian intellectuals left the ruling Communist Party today and founded the Alternative Socialist Party.

description: After 27 and a half years in prison, Nelson Mandela finally won his freedom today and promptly urged his supporters at home and abroad to increase their pressure against the white minority Goverment that had just released him.

title: Will Panama's Woes Frustrate Democracy?
description: On Central Avenue in downtown Panama City, clothing stores are slowly reopening, selling jeans for $3, cotton shirts for less than $2 and plastic shoes for 99 cents. Shoppers browse under the protection of private security guards carrying shotguns, machine guns and revolvers.

description: With the scheduled opening of spring training only days away, negotiators for baseball's club owners and players are scheduled to resume talks today amid myths and misperceptions about their chances for a quick settlement.

title: National Utility Service Is Acquired by Its Chief
description: When Sarkis Soultanian was 17 he got a job as an office boy at a company called National Utility Service. ''I was fresh out of high school,'' Mr. Soultanian recalled. ''I was the last interview of the day, and I got the job for $45 a week.''

title: It's Westminster Today As the Warmups End

title: Chronicle

The 84-year-old Mr. Fulbright, a widow since 1985, proposed to the 56-year-old Ms. Mayor several weeks ago over the telephone. They will be married in Washington.

title: Bacteria Is Found Not to Be Cause of 22 Hospital Deaths
description: A bacterial outbreak at a hospital here was more widespread than first believed but did not contribute in a significant way to the deaths of 22 people, the state health department says.

description: The Guinness affair, Britain's biggest financial fraud scandal in decades, comes to trial Monday after much legal skirmishing and many delays.

title: Rates Are Tied to Events Overseas
description: The extraordinary developments in the Germanys and political uncertainty in Japan have led to fears of higher inflation abroad. Those concerns will not dissipate quickly, and economists and portfolio managers say interest rate movements in the United States are likely to remain strongly dependent on developments in the overseas bond markets for a while longer.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Moves by Carnation
description: Citing a desire to bring its roster of advertising agencies into line with those of its corporate parent, Nestle S.A., the Carnation Company has taken three accounts, worth $12 million to $15 million in billings, from Ogilvy & Mather in Los Angeles. Advertising for Carnation's Contadina Fresh refrigerated pasta and sauces, and for its infant nutritional products, will go to McCann-Erickson in Los Angeles. A Carnation spokesman said that the third account, Grand Gourmet dog food, would also go to an Interpublic agency.

title: Changes in Crafts
description: ''By Hammer and Hand: New York Trades Transformed, 1788-1842,'' an exhibition on how a growing New York affected the lives and work of craftsmen, will be on view through June 11 at the South Street Seaport Museum, 207 Front Street. Paintings, prints, tools and other items that illustrate changes in woodworking, printing, silversmithing, shoemaking and tailoring are included. Hours: 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily. Admission, $6 ($4 for students; $3 for children under 12). Information: 669-9430.

title: Bridge
description: Alvin Roth has been called ''the greatest theoretician in the history of the game.'' The Roth-Stone system was seminal in the development of bidding theory and introduced the unusual no-trump, the negative double and other significant ideas. At 75 he is as creative as ever; his book on ''Modern Roth'' will be published in the spring.

title: Review/Music;   The Evolution of Bruckner's Third
description: Count on the conductor Erich Leinsdorf to give a program a piquant twist. In the New York Philharmonic's current subscription concerts at Avery Fisher Hall, Mr. Leinsdorf is offering two symphonies, Haydn's No. 90 in C and Bruckner's No. 3 in D minor: on the surface, no surprise. For the Adagio of the Bruckner, however, Mr. Leinsdorf has chosen an ''intermediate 1876 version,'' evidently new to New York.

title:
Market Place;

title: Referee's Count Is What Counts
description: WHATEVER the boxing politicians eventually decree, James (Buster) Douglas is the boxing public's new world heavyweight champion. Yes, he apparently got a wrong count and a long count from the referee during his knockdown by Mike Tyson in the eighth round of their Tokyo title bout. But that was the referee's fault, not his. And in that situation, the fighter is not responsible for the referee's mistake.

title: East Bloc Trip Buoys Baker Yet Alerts Him to the Odds
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d visited Romania today, closing a tour of Eastern Europe that seemed to leave him exhilarated over the hope that the United States apparently has inspired among the new leaders, yet sober about the prospects for easily turning their revolutions into democracies.

title: Review/Television;   Otherworldly Beings Cast Light on Earthly Roles
description: Tonight George and Susan go about producing a new Newcomer. It will not give too much away to report that the process involves a transfer of the ''pod'' from her to him, that both experience contractions and that their teen-aged son, Buck, does too. ''If you women went through anything like us men go through,'' Buck whines, ''there probably wouldn't be any babies at all.''

title: Corrections

description: All over Eastern Europe, the formerly all-powerful ''official press'' is in even bigger trouble than the Communist parties in whose name it has been speaking for 40 years.

description: Ruth Levin Schlein and Sidney Hill were married yesterday in Mr. Hill's apartment in Manhattan by Rabbi James Prosnit. Mrs. Hill is the daughter of the late Dr. and Mrs. Oscar Levin. Mr. Hill, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Lazarus Hill, is a founder of the Berry-Hill Galleries in New York. The bride's first husband died, as did Mr. Hill's first wife.

title: Defense Excels As East Wins

It was defense as much as offense that paved the way for the East's 130-113 victory over the West in the 40th annual National Basketball Association All-Star Game at the Miami Arena.

title: Brother Fires 'Empty' Gun; Sister, 13, Dies

description: Since the beginning of his tenure as New York's Governor, Mario M. The Governor has responded: a tension, perhaps, but not a contradiction.

description: More than 160 writers from around the world appealed for help today to stop death threats against the British author Salman Rushdie.

title: Some View Battle in Snow Country As Turning Point in War Over Fur
description: This wealthy resort town, where mink coats are nearly as common as ski poles, has become the symbolic battleground in a broadening debate over the ethics of wearing fur.

title: Trade Surplus Puts Bonn Ahead of Japan
description: West Germany has announced a record trade surplus for last year, putting Europe's dominant economic power ahead of Japan for the first time since the 1970's.

title: A Chicago Exhibition on Lincoln's America
description: ''A House Divided: America in the Age of Lincoln,'' an exhibition that has just opened at the Chicago Historical Society, is more than a show of bland manuscripts and evenhanded statements about the Civil War. The 600 rare documents and artifacts on view, together with a pointed narrative, have been arranged to make a case for the idea that it was slavery more than secession that led to the conflict.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Executive Changes listing of Business Day on Friday misidentified the company that named Paul B. Goldberg as its president. It is the Summa Medical Corporation of Albuquerque, N.M.

title: Collor Receptive to Criticism Of Brazil's Policy in Amazon
description: Facing foreign criticism of Brazil's treatment of the Amazon region and the Indians living in its rain forest, Brazil's President-elect has been surprisingly conciliatory.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Hal Riney Gets Aide for G.M. Saturn Work
description: Curvin O'Reilly who has held top assignments at BBDO and McCann-Erickson in New York and Ogilvy & Mather in Chicago, has signed on as group creative director at Hal Riney & Partners to help the San Francisco agency advertise the General Motors Corporation's new Saturn automobile.

description: Entertainment Weekly makes its debut today after a promotional blitz that demonstrated the advantage of having a well-placed parent.

title: 6 Convicts, Including 3 Murderers, Escape From a Prison in Illinois
description: Six convicts, including three murderers, escaped from the Joliet Correctional Center early today, apparently by cutting through metal bars, the state police said. One was captured later in the day.

Whose Terms, NATO's or Moscow's, For a Unification That Seems Likely?
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union sowed the wind last October when he signaled that it was time for the old East German leadership under Erich Honecker to go. Now, perhaps long before he expected it, he may reap the whirlwind of German unification.

title: Heritage for the World
description: On the 126th anniversary of the Gettysburg Address last Nov. 19, Governor Cuomo of New York observed in a commemorative speech that ''the sleeping giant of democracy'' was stirring again in Eastern Europe. Standing near where Lincoln had spoken amid the battlefield shambles in 1863, Mr. Cuomo suggested that, as his heirs, ''we must reach out to help.''

title: 6 Said to Die in Salvador Air Force Raid
description: At least six people were killed today, five of them children, when the Salvadoran Air Force bombed a settlement of former Salvadoran refugees, witnesses said.

title: Company News;   Ravitch-United Talks Reported
description: The labor unions of United Airlines have approached Richard Ravitch, the former chairman of the Bowery Savings Bank of New York and former head of the Transit Authority of New York, to become head of the airline if they are able to complete a buyout of the carrier, persons familiar with the effort said yesterday.

title: Harold McCusker; Ulster Politician, 50
description: Harold McCusker, a schoolteacher who became prominent in Northern Ireland politics, died in a hospital Monday after a 16-year battle with cancer, his family announced. He was 50 years old.

Housing Completions Drop
description: Housing completions fell 12.8 percent in December from a month earlier, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.3 million units, the Commerce Department said today. It was the sharpest one-month drop in more than four years.

title: Kuwait Asks End of Quotas
description: Kuwait's oil minister was quoted today as saying that OPEC's oil output quotas should be scrapped as soon as possible.

title: Savings Bond Sales Up
description: Sales of United States savings bonds totaled $826 million in January, up 39 percent from December, the Treasury Department reported last week. January's sales, which were 2 percent higher than those of January 1989, brought the total value of bonds held by the public to a record $118.2 billion. Savings bonds are earning interest at a rate of 6.98 percent when held five years or longer.

title: Time Warner Posts Losses From Merger
description: Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that it had lost $222 million in the fourth quarter, compared with a profit of $56 million, or 97 cents a share, in the corresponding period of 1988.

title: Saztec International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Agency Review At Parker Bros.
description: Parker Brothers, the division of the Tonka Corporation that makes such board games as Monopoly, Sorry and Clue, said yesterday that it had put its $20 million advertising account up for review.

title: More Birds and a Beach Are Casualties of Spill
description: The beachfront at Huntington Beach was closed to the public today for three weeks as a sheen of spilled oil, now about 12 miles long and 4 miles wide, floated just offshore, sending what officials called a two-inch ''mousse'' of oily froth onto the sand.

title: Tyson Failed to Make Adjustments
description: He was widely viewed as an invincible fighter when he stepped into the ring against James (Buster) Douglas Sunday in Tokyo.

title: Savoy Theater in London Is Devastated by a Fire
description: The Savoy Theater, one of London's most famous playhouses, where many Gilbert and Sullivan operettas were first staged, was devastated by fire early today.

title: Our Towns;   Angry Shoppers Protest Cupidity In Valentine Vice
description: Let's take a look in the window of the Penny Lane novelty shop on Main Street here. Valentine's Day cards. Heart-shaped candy. But what's this? ''Sex fantasies'' toilet paper. Let's go inside. Gum and candy rack. Stuffed animals. One carousel after another brimming with birthday cards, valentines, joke greeting cards. Some of them show extremely fat naked women. And look over there, next to the rubber lizards and plastic robot arms: fortune cookies with condoms inside and wind-up toy breasts that jiggle.

title: When Gold Doesn't Glitter
description: To many urban teen-agers, going for the gold means gigantic earrings, multifingered gold rings, even removable gold caps for teeth. Such ostentatious displays may be trendy, but according to Frank Mickens, a Brooklyn high school principal, they don't convey a serious image to potential employers. He's right.

title: 'Apartheid Has No Future'
description: Suddenly what had seemed impossible looked inevitable. To see Nelson Mandela walk free was to foresee the end of white supremacy in South Africa.

title: 42 Poorest Lands, Fearing Loss In Leverage, Plan Drive for Help
description: In an atmosphere of gloom and foreboding, representatives of the world's 42 poorest nations met here this weekend to devise new ways to convince richer countries that nearly half a billion people need help desperately.

Tecogen Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Included a tax credit of $15,000.

title: Fluids Promoted as Way to Stem Infant Deaths
description: IN an effort to reduce a surprising number of deaths from diarrhea among children in the United States, doctors and health-care organizations have opened a two-year campaign to promote the use of what experts say is an inexpensive and effective but often neglected treatment.

title: By Design;   Fringe, the Practical Frippery
description: At first thought, fringe would seem to be a bit of frippery. But it has a flip side. This wispy stuff is actually quite practical, and it certainly packs a fashion punch.

title: U.S. Presents Plan for German Unity
description: The Bush Administration has proposed a process for realizing the speedy reunification of Germany while seeking to satisfy Soviet and European fears, a senior State Department official said today.

title: Linamar Machine reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Sports People: Hockey;   Diduck Hospitalized
description: Gerald Diduck, an Islander defenseman, entered North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L.I., Monday, for treatment of a virus, the club announced. Mark Aldridge, the Islander trainer, said Diduck was being tested for possible blood poisoning. He is not expected to play tonight when the Islanders face the Calgary Flames at Nassau Coliseum. Patrick Flatley, who has a pulled left groin muscle, is doubtful for tonight's game.

title: Crown Jewel of 'Star Wars' Has Lost Its Luster
description: AS the Bush Administration presses for a big increase in financing for the ''Star Wars'' anti-missile program, the visionary weapon that first ignited White House interest in the idea has fallen to its lowest ebb ever, the victim of technical failures and budget cuts.

title: Banks Given Order by U.S.
description: A top Federal regulator ordered commercial bank officers today to correct promptly ''a significant number of fundamental deficiencies'' in their real estate lending operations.

title: Sharon Resigns From Israeli Cabinet
description: Ariel Sharon, the Israeli Trade Minister and leading right-wing rival to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, announced his resignation from the Government today, issuing a challenge to Mr. Shamir's leadership and sending a pivotal Likud party meeting into pandemonium.

title: Patterns
description: 'But Gordon' Henderson Gordon Henderson, who walked away with award from the Council of Fashion Designers of America last week for the young designer of the year, is to introduce a lower-priced clothing line, to be called But Gordon.

title: Pilotless Flights to Explore the Ozone Hole
description: SCIENTISTS at Harvard University are building a pilotless airplane for research flights through the ozone hole in the upper atmosphere over Antarctica. The first flights are expected to begin in the fall of 1991.

title: Sports People: TENNIS;   No Surgery for Graf
description: Steffi Graf will not need surgery to repair her broken thumb, but will be unable to resume swinging a tennis racquet for about six weeks.

title: Safeway Stores reports earnings for 16wks to Dec 30
description: b-Included an aftertax gain of $48 million associated with a divestiture program completed in 1988. The company said it decided to repatriate about $460 million from its canadian subsidiaries, resulting in a $46 million one-time tax expense in the latest fourth quarter, while creating a substantial long-term income tax benefit.

title: Company News;   Grand Met Plans Shift at Retail Unit
description: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the British food and liquor company, said it would reorganize its British retail operations by forming two separate companies to manage its pubs and restaurants. The new pub company will run the Chef and Brewer, Clifton Inns and Berni operations, while the restaurant company will handle Old Orleans, Pastificio, Pizzaland and Perfect Pizza businesses.

title: CAPITAL HOMELESS SUE OVER HOUSING
description: The National Coalition for the Homeless and three homeless families filed a lawsuit yesterday to bar the District of Columbia from placing homeless families in welfare hotels and to insure that District officials provide other housing for them.

title: Synbiotics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Company News;   ARCO Venture
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company signed an agreement with Indalsa, which operates food stores and restaurants in Spain, to open 600 AM-PM Mini Markets in Spain and Portugal. According to the agreement, Atlantic Richfield will own 33 percent of a joint venture with Inalsa that will own, operate and franchise the AM-PM convenience stores, some of which will also sell gasoline. The joint venture is AM-PM's first in Europe. Its owner, the oil company ARCO, has signed a similar licensing venture to open 500 of the convenience stores in Asia. The first three Spanish stores are scheduled to open this year.

title: Session Called on Soviet Chief's Role
description: Leaders of the Soviet legislature voted today to convene an extraordinary session ''in the nearest future'' to expand the powers of the Soviet presidency, a post now held by Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Coalition Government Is Dissolved in Greece
description: Greece's all-party coalition Government was dissolved today and a caretaker Government formed that is to hold general elections in April, the third in nine months.

title: Dow Plunges 29.06 on Slowest Day of Year
description: A late spurt of selling depressed stocks across a broad front yesterday in the slowest trading of the year. The Dow Jones industrial average plunged by 29.06 points, or by 1.1 percent, to 2,619.14.

description: Price and memory advantages offset by weight and shorter battery life.

description: The Nevada bookmakers who take legal bets on sports and racing propositions always win, but last weekend they made their customers look even more foolish than usual.

title: Boston University Wins the Beanpot
description: Boston University humiliated Harvard tonight in the final of the Beanpot Tournament as the Crimson team unraveled before a capacity crowd of 14,448 at the Boston Garden. The final score was 8-2 for the Terriers, who were beaten, 9-6, by the Crimson last year.

title: Moscow's Next Worry: Ethnic Turks
description: LEAD: The shake-up in the Communist countries has ignited ferment among the tens of millions of ethnic Turks living there. Suddenly, Turkish nationalism, a passion thought long dead, has resurfaced in Europe and Asia.

title: Riots Involving Ethnic Rivalries Erupt in Another Soviet Republic
description: A state of emergency was declared in the capital of the Central Asian republic of Tadzhikistan today after a mob of several thousand people set cars, buses and the Communist Party headquarters on fire because of rumors that Armenian refugees were being given scarce housing, official Soviet accounts said.

title: Safeway Stores Plans To Go Public Again
description: Safeway Stores Inc. is going public again.

title: Bush Facing Threats Usually Avoided
description: When President Bush flies to Colombia on Thursday for a conference on drug trafficking, overruling objections from almost all his senior aides, he will face dangers that Presidents normally avoid.

title: Expanding the Presidency
description: Soviet leaders voted to convene the country's Parliament to expand the powers of the presidency, now held by Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Page A12.

title: Art and Realism Collide in the Plans for a Battery Park Garden
description: In 1985, the Battery Park City Authority announced plans for a spectacular project, a 3.5-acre garden that would be a tourist attraction and a haven for residents living in the shadow of office towers.

title: Coin Fraud Case Widens
description: Three Japanese detectives left today for Switzerland to investigate possible Swiss links to a huge counterfeit operation that flooded Tokyo with bogus Emperor Hirohito gold coins, the police said.

title: France Offers Troops to Stop Fighting in Lebanon
description: France has offered to send troops to Lebanon's Christian enclave in an attempt to avert intervention by the Syrian army and stop fighting that has killed 450 people, Arab diplomats said today.

title: Slighting Words, Fighting Words
description: Score 10 on the common sense scale for David Burke, the president of CBS News, for his handling of the newest outbreak of slighting words. America's court of public opinion has performed unevenly on this explosive subject. ''Off with his head,'' it sometimes insists after an egregious public insult. At other times, outrages flare briefly but the public soon forgets. By suspending Andy Rooney, the ''60 Minutes'' commentator, for three months, Mr. Burke distinguishes sensibly between insult and injury.

title: U.S. FORGOES TRIAL OF A PANAMANIAN
description: Federal prosecutors today abandoned their case against a prominent Panamanian businessman whose arrest last year abruptly ended an American covert operation to help the political opponents of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.

title: Judges for Groups Savor the Nuances
description: A Giant Schnauzer, Ch. Skansen's I Have a Dream; a wirefox terrier, Ch. Saphire Star of Silverbush; a bichon frise, Ch. Chaminade Le Blanc Chamour, and a Shetland sheepdog, Ch. Marwal Steppin' Out, became finalists last night in the 114th annual Westminster Kennel Club Show, which opened a two-day run at Madison Square Garden.

title: U.S. Officials Grope for a Logic Beyond Cold War
description: Just at the moment in history when the United States would like to cash in on its victory in the cold war, American officials are discovering that the game of nations is changing and that they may not be able to walk away from the table with all the profits they expected.

title: 2 German Chiefs Prepare to Meet: A Steamroller vs. a Lame Duck?
description: Having returned with what he calls a ''green light'' from Moscow, Chancellor Helmut Kohl stands in a dominant position as he prepares to receive Prime Minister Hans Modrow of East Germany on Tuesday to press a demand for rapid monetary union.

title: Chronicle
description: BOWIE K. KUHN, the former Commissioner of Baseball, surfaced yesterday, sort of. After it was reported that he was hiding in Florida following the bankruptcy of his Manhattan law firm, Myerson & Kuhn, he issued a statement through his lawyer in Manhattan. He is in Florida, he reported, although he didn't say exactly where. He said he has bought a house in Marsh Landing at Ponte Vedra Beach.

description: It is like the first burst of sunlight after a winter storm.

description: A bill to limit smoking in this tobacco state won preliminary approval today in the House of Delegates, over the objections of health lobbyists and legislators who had backed a bill calling for stricter regulation.

title: Judge James Gordon Dies at 71; Imposed a Landmark Busing Plan
description: James Fleming Gordon, a retired Federal judge who 15 years ago imposed the first cross-district integration plan on public schools in a major metropolitan area, died Friday of complications after lung surgery at Sarasota, Fla., Memorial Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Venice, Fla.

title: Trump, the Divorce Case: The Accusations Are Flying

description: Rich Sutter, the Vancouver Canuck right wing, was suspended for five games by the National Hockey League for slashing Glenn Anderson of the Edmonton Oilers last month. In a game Jan. 27, Sutter slashed Anderson across the hands with his stick, resulting in an injury that sidelined the forward.(AP)

Review/Television;   How a Grim Black Area Got That Way
description: The ''Throwaway People'' of tonight's ''Frontline'' live in Shaw, a beat-up, beaten-down district of Washington where the facts of life are grimly familiar: unemployment, single-parent welfare families, school dropouts, drugs and crime. This hour, on Channel 13 at 9 P.M., offers a close-up of sites off the Beltway.

title: Oilfield Opens in Iraq
description: Iraq's Oil Ministry has begun production at its southern Suba oilfield with an initial output of 20,000 barrels a day, the official Iraqi News Agency said today. Developing the Suba oilfield is part of a significant expansion program begun last year to develop Iraq's oil and gas reserves after the August 1988 cease-fire in the eight-year war with Iran. The agency, monitored in Nicosia, reported that production at Suba, 60 miles west of the port of Basra, could be increased to 60,000 barrels a day and that the field could also produce 20 million cubic feet of gas daily.

title: Idyllic Theory Of Goddesses Creates Storm
description: MARIJA Gimbutas is an eminent archeologist who says she believes the world once lived in peace. It was during the Stone Age, she says, when goddesses were worshiped and societies were centered on women.

title: Critic's Notebook;   Why Andy Rooney Had to Go, Guilty or Not
description: The case of Andy Rooney is like a multi-vehicle crash that brings traffic to a stop. Unfettered comment ran smack into minority sensibilities; the public relations needs of a network collided with the prerogatives of one of its most popular performers; a news organization's obligation to openness came up against the medium's role as a binder of society. Add odds and ends of corporate hypocrisy and political opportunism, and you need a fleet of tow trucks to clear the area.

title: A Post-Mod Scheherazade in a Funky, Fearful London
description: At the very beginning of Martin Amis's new novel, his narrator declares, ''this is a true story,'' ''a murder story,'' ''a love story.'' This narrator - Samson Young by name - isn't a terribly reliable (or ethical) fellow, but on this point, at least, he's telling the truth. If one were to characterize ''London Fields'' further, one might add that it's a comic murder mystery, an apocalyptic satire, a scatological meditation on love and death and nuclear winter - ''Bonfire of the Vanities'' crossed with ''Gravity's Rainbow,'' as narrated by Al Goldstein and Jonathan Swift. <TD WIDTH=2

title: Phoenix Re Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said that in the latest year, catastrophic loss activity caused pre-tax losses of $6.6 million.

title: Chronicle
description: In the dubious honors department: HITOSHI MOTOSHIMA, the Mayor of Nagasaki, Japan, who was shot Jan. 18 by a right-wing nationalist, now finds the Japanese edition of ''The Satanic Verses'' by SALMAN RUSHDIE dedicated to him. Without permission. GIANNI PALMA, an Italian businessman, arranged to have the novel published Thursday in Japan by Shinsensha, a leading publisher, and decided to dedicate the edition to Mr. Motoshima. Nagasaki officials said Mr. Motoshima, who has resumed his duties, has asked that the novel not be dedicated to him.

title: Avon Products reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss on sale of discontinued operations of $97,800,000 for the quarter and year. c-Net income d-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $545,600,000, which included a charge of $520 million on sale of discontinued operations. Year-ago income from continuing operations of $141,100,000, or $1.98 a share, for the year included a gain of $20 million, or 32 cents a share, from cumulative effect of a change in accounting.

title: Bush Says He'll Keep Sanctions for Now
description: President Bush said today that he was not willing to lift economic sanctions on South Africa at this time, but that he was prepared to take other steps to show support for President F. W. de Klerk.

title: Progressive Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included net losses on security sales of $600,000 for the quarter and $11.8 million for the year. The company said in the 1989 periods net income was reduced $25.7 million, or 87 cents a share, because it established a reserve for potential premium refunds under rate rollback provisions of California Proposition 103.

title: Adac Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
New Jersey Turnpike Plan Dwindles Despite $2 Billion in Debt
description: Five years ago the New Jersey Turnpike Authority issued $2 billion in bonds to finance the widening of 35 miles of the state's most important road. Today much of the project has been abandoned, none of it is complete, and the authority is seeking large toll increases to pay the cost of the borrowed money it is still deciding how to spend.

title: Clues on Aging
description: Researchers in the United States and Japan say they believe they have found a link between the aging of human cells and a specific chromosome. The findings, which were reported in the Feb. 9 issue of the journal Science, may have relevance not only to the understanding of aging but also to the study of cancer.

title: Controlling The Damage;   Regulators Move Fast To Reassure Markets
description: The speed with which Federal regulators responded to financial problems at Drexel Burnham Lambert's parent illustrates their awareness of how quickly problems at this particular Wall Street firm could spread through the complex structure of today's financial markets.

title: Review/Pop;   Upward Mobility at the Carnaval de Merengue
description: The merengue, the Dominican Republic's most euphoric export, proved its upward mobility when the 12th annual Carnaval de Merengue moved to Madison Square Garden for the first time. After years of sellouts at the smaller Felt Forum, the full house on Friday was an occasion for Dominican pride.

title: Applied Materials reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
Data Switch Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit from repurchase of debentures of $578,000 for the quarter and year. c-Net income

Joule Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: PRESIDENT REBUFFS GORBACHEV'S PLAN ON SIZE OF FORCES
description: President Bush today rebuffed a proposal by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to set equal limits on American and Soviet troops in Europe. He insisted that American soldiers were needed there as ''a stabilizing factor'' even if Moscow withdrew its forces from Eastern Europe.

title: An 'Obsession,' a Tangled Life and a Killing
description: Carolyn Warmus, the 26-year-old woman accused of murdering her former lover's wife, came of age in a wealthy Detroit suburb, earned degrees from well-known universities and went on to teach in Westchester County elementary schools. One neighbor summed up her personality: ''She's the kind of girl you want to bring home to Mom.''

title: INSIDE
description: Bush's Risks in Colombia

title: Pruning Prune Day, and Others
description: Things started out innocently enough back in 1918, when Congress designated Mother's Day. The Congressional penchant for commemoratives has since lurched out of control. National Prune Day, Tap Dance Day and Patient Account Management Day now compete with Dairy Goat Awareness Week for the national spotlight. If that weren't enough, Congress has declared the 1990's to be the Decade of the Brain.

title: MTV Europe Stake Is Sold
description: British Telecommunications P.L.C. said today that it had sold its 24.99 percent stake in the rock music television channel MTV Europe to MTV Networks, a unit of Viacom Inc., the American communications conglomerate.

title: Costar Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 2
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $89,000, or 3 cents a share. The company said it made a decision in January to change its fiscal year to calendar year, with the result that December 1989 became a ''one- month'' year.

title: Credit Markets;   U.S. Notes And Bonds Off Sharply
description: Prices of Treasury securities fell sharply yesterday on what dealers described as profit taking in the wake of the strong rally that followed last week's Treasury refunding auctions.

title: Baseball Factions Quiet After Brief Talk
description: Negotiators for baseball's club owners, facing their own lockout deadline later this week, gave the players' negotiators something to study yesterday, but neither side would acknowledge what it was or that it even existed.

title: Business and Health;   Medical Insurance And Job Mobility
description: AMONG the many horror stories from people who have difficulty obtaining health insurance, that of Paul Tobias is a striking example. Mr. Tobias, an internationally known cellist who has appeared as a guest soloist with the New York Philharmonic, said several major insurers had rejected him and his wife, Elizabeth Moschetti, a concert pianist. One insurer gave as the reason that ''there were too many AIDS cases in the arts community,'' he said. Eventually the couple went to the Empire Blue Cross plan, where they pay $1,520 every 90 days for comprehensive coverage.

title: Violence Is Scarce In Schools, Police Find
description: Five New York City police officers who spent seven months undercover as high school students found little evidence of drug use, weapons, or gang activity in the schools, said officials of the Joint Commission on Integrity in the Public Schools.

title: Mountain Medical Equipment Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Sports People: HOCKEY;   Mogilny Wants to Play
description: The Sabres' general manager says that the Soviet defector Aleksandr Mogilny is prepared to stay with the team despite his fear of flying.

title: Lawsuit Faults Fees and Practices of Dating Service Operator
description: A matchmaker who claims her 22-year career has led to weddings for more than 8,000 couples was sued by the State of New York yesterday, accused of overcharging customers by up to $20,000 and of providing dates with the unexpected, including ex-convicts and married men.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 6 about Panamanian banks and money laundering referred incorrectly to the relationship of the Dadeland Bank of Florida to a senior Panamanian offical and accusations of money laundering. Guillermo (Billy) Ford, Second Vice President of Panama, is not an owner of Dadeland. No Federal or state authorities have accused Dadeland of improper ties to the Medellin drug cartel.

title: Grainger (W.W.) Inc.(N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Shamir-Sharon Showdown
description: LEAD: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's decisive victory over the hardline faction of his Likud Party - and Trade Minister Ariel Sharon's announcement that he was resigning - indicate that the Middle East peace process is on the verge of a potential breakthrough. With Mr. Sharon and other Likud hardliners on the defensive, Mr.

title: Ecogen May Place Itself on the Block
description: Ecogen Inc. said it was considering the sale of all or part of the company because of a shortage of cash for developing and commercializing its biopesticides. To conserve cash in the short term, it said it would temporarily suspend production of one of its biofungicide products, limit field trials and cut certain spending.

title: Canadian Southern Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Endorsement for Douglas
description: A World Boxing Council vice president who supervised the heavyweight title fight between Buster Douglas and Mike Tyson said today that Douglas should be declared the champion because he won the title in the ring.

title: Bridge
description: A team event that is sometimes played in Europe but is very rare on this side of the Atlantic requires each member of a team to play with each of the others in turn. Probably the only American example is the Betty Kaplan Teams, which was played on Saturday at the Roosevelt Hotel in Manhattan.

title: Federated Sued Over New Chief
description: The Neiman Marcus Group Inc. said yesterday that it had filed a $19 million lawsuit against Federated Department Stores Inc., the Allied Stores Corporation and Olympia & York Ltd. accusing them of inducing Allen I. Questrom to resign as head of the Neiman Marcus stores to accept the post of chairman and chief executive of Federated and Allied stores.

title: Critic's Notebook;   Finding the Heart of a Museum In Its Permanent Collection
description: Visitors to the Metropolitan Museum of Art may have noticed a large canvas by Theodore Gericault now hanging just beyond the works by Francisco Goya in the Andre Meyer Galleries. One of only a handful of landscapes painted by the artist, the imaginary mountainous scene of figures bathing downstream from an ancient aqueduct was bought by the museum last year. It was cleaned and recently placed on permanent view entirely without fanfare.

title: Central Reserve Life reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dibrell Brothers Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Washington Talk;   Empathy's Drawback: No Room To Disagree
description: Question: How do you tell the difference between President Bush and the Democrats in Congress? Answer: That is just what the Democrats would like to figure out.

title: It's Wake-Up Time
description: If a modern Rip Van Winkle had been asleep only a few months, he would still wake up astonished. And he would have to whirl his head in all directions because history is playing leapfrog now, as countries jump ahead of each other week by week to escape the long nightmare.

title: Technical Commun reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
Missile and Submarine Finish Navy's Tests
description: The nuclear-powered submarine Tennessee launched two Trident 2 missiles today, bringing to seven straight the string of successes with the missile and allowing both missile and submarine to be certified as ready for active duty.

title: Forecast for Fall: Softer, Calmer, Easier
description: These are the clothes retailers are convinced that women will buy this fall. Called the pre-fall collection, the clothes were presented without fanfare in small New York showrooms to buyers who want them in the stores in June and July.

title: Willem Schilthuis, 95, Grain-Trade Executive
description: Willem C. Schilthuis, a grain industry executive and former president of the New York Produce Exchange, died on Saturday at his home in Westport, Conn. He was 95 years old.

description: To the Editor:
