title: Devils Continue Scoring Slump
description: The Devils are making goaltenders look brilliant these days. They gave another demonstration of their scoring slump tonight by managing only a 1-1 deadlock against the Detroit Red Wings though taking 44 shots.

title: Solzhenitsyn's Conditions
description: Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn has promised to return to the Soviet Union but only when his once-reviled books are freely available, the cellist Mstislav Rostropovich, a close friend of the Nobel-prize winning author, said today.

title: Hollerith in Germany
description: To the Editor:

title: Time Warner Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said that on an historical basis, the acquisition of the initial 59.3 percent common stock interest in Warner Communications Inc. was accounted for as of July 31, 1989 using the purchase method; accordingly, Time Warner's historical operating results for 1989 included the operating results of Warner Communications for the five months ended Dec. 31, 1989, after deducting the Warner Communications minority interests's 40.7 percent share. The amortization of the access of the cost to acquire the 59.3 percent interest in Warner Communications over the book value of the net assets acquired amounted to $161 million in the five months ended Dec. 31, 1989 ($118 million after tax), of which $117 million ($74 million after tax, including an $8 million after-tax adjustment of previously-recorded amortization) was recorded in the fourth quarter. Interest expense for the three months and year ended Dec. 31, 1989 includes $111 million and $327 million, respectively, from the amortization of fees incurred to obtain the short-term financing of the offer. Historical earnings per share are based upon average common shares outstanding during the period after eliminating Time Warner's 59.3 percent interest from July 24, 1989 in the Time Warner exchange shares owned by Warner Communications.

title: Few Chip Gains Seen in '90
description: The worldwide semiconductor market will experience little growth this year, but revenues should begin to rise again next year and will double by 1994, the market research concern Dataquest Inc. predicted today.

title: Perrier Recall: How Damaging Is It?
description: Over more than a decade, Perrier convinced Americans that its French spring water was chic enough to be worth $29 a gallon when consumed in small bottles in restaurants. But over just two days, Perrier has seen its marketing efforts of endangered by a swell of bad publicity.

title: Iowa Southern Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Panel Urges Changes In Campaign Financing
description: Trying to avoid the fate of other state commissions whose recommendations have been filed and forgotten, the ethics commission met with the Governor and legislative leaders today to lobby for changes in campaign financing, the State Board of Elections and municipal government ethics.

title: Georgia-Pacific to sell Safety-Paper Division
description: In a move intended to remove a possible antitrust objection to its $3.8 billion hostile takeover offer for the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation, the Georgia-Pacific Corporation said yesterday that it would sell its safety paper business to the Simpson Paper Company.

title: Maxxam Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-After income from discontinued operations of $7.7 million, or 90 cents a share, for the quarter and $13.8 million, or $1.81 a share, for the year. Maxxam said income from discontinued operations in the 1988 periods represented the disposition of its oil, gas and geothermal operations upon consummation of the merger of MCO Resources Inc. with a subsidiary of United Meridian Corp. Since Oct. 28, 1988, Kaisertech Ltd. has been a wholly owned subsidiary of Maxxam. Maxxam's consolidated statement of income included Kaisertech's consolidated results of operations from Nov. 1, 1988. Commencing with the second quarter of 1988 through Oct. 31, 1988, Kaisertech was accounted for by the equity method of accounting.

description: b-Net loss c-After income of $102.2 million, or $2.69 a share, from discontinued operations. Year-ago figures were restated to reflect an accounting change.

F.A.A. Staggers Under Task Of Monitoring Airline Safety
description: Federal safety inspectors are overwhelmed by the job of monitoring the nation's airplanes, airports, mechanics and pilots. And crash investigators say lapses in these inspections have contributed to several recent fatal accidents.

title: In Slovenia, Link to Rest of Nation Weakens
description: Less than a month ago, the Communists of Slovenia pulled out of a national party congress and became a loose thread that is now unraveling Communist cohesion across the country. A few days ago they shocked their comrades further by announcing they were no longer Communists.

title: Chess
description: A truly brilliant game ought to look berserk at first glance, for what else can you conclude when one of the players throws away his pieces with wild abandon? So when the official bulletins of the Hastings International Tournament in England described Sergey Dolmatov as going ''berserk in the late opening'' in his game against Jonathan Speelman of Britain, a recent world championship candidate, the Soviet grandmaster should have felt complimented.

title: Whooping Cranes Coming Back, But Nearby Barges Pose a Threat
description: THE whooping crane, beneficiary of one of the longest and most intensive efforts to protect an endangered species, may become a victim of its own success.

title: Low-Tech Company In High-Tech Gamble
description: Papken S. DerTorossian, an Armenian who emigrated from Syria, exudes patriotism. At the helm of a $130 million electronics business here, he is among the industry executives most outspoken on the importance of keeping American technology in American hands.

title: Haskell Barst; Lawyer, 82
description: Haskell Barst, a lawyer who specialized in immigration, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Pompano Beach, Fla. He was 82 years old.

title: Poindexter Trial Postponed Anew Over Secrecy Disputes
description: A Federal district judge today postponed by two weeks the trial of John M. Poindexter to provide more time to resolve a number of issues, including a potentially serious snag over 150 classified documents proposed for use as evidence.

title: American Television & Communications Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included one-time pretax charge of $19.9 million for the reorganization and relocation of executive offices. Year-ago results reflect the change in method of accounting for income taxes. The company attributed the latest period's gains to continued strong operating performance, the acquisition of Cable Television Systems from Centel Cable Television Co. and the consolidation of Memphis CATV Inc.

title: Wallace Herndon Smith; Artist, 88
description: Wallace Herndon Smith, an artist who worked mostly in oils and watercolors, died on Saturday at his home in Ladue, Mo. He was 88 years old.

title: BT Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said that net earnings for 1989 were reduced by $352,000 as a result of a Pennsylvania law enacted last July which changes the rate of Pennsylvania shares tax imposed for 1989.

title: Sunrise in South Africa
description: The jail that opened Sunday for Nelson Mandela began to free a nation even as it freed a man. After 27 years, and with the whole world watching, South Africa saw a half-mythical prisoner recalled to political life. Mr. Mandela rose impressively to a remarkable occasion. Calmly and without bitterness, he displayed the measured dignity the old Romans described as gravitas.

title: Market Place;   Shakeout Looms In Office Supplies
description: COMPANIES are rushing to enter the office- supply business and the market has become so crowded that a shakeout is now deemed inevitable.

title: Poor Women at Higher Risk From Anemia in Pregnancy
description: Lower-income mothers do not seem to bounce back from the anemia common in early pregnancy as well as other women, and that increases the risk of premature delivery and fetal death, Federal researchers say in a new report.

description: The company recently reorganized its business focus and said year- earlier figures are not comparable. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Gourdine Shifts to Players' Court
description: Simon Gourdine is returning to pro basketball, but on the other side. Once the deputy commissioner of the National Basketball Association, a position he left in 1981 to become the commissioner of the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs, Gourdine was named general counsel of the National Basketball Players Asssociation on Sunday.

title: Monitor Asserts Valdez Was Off Radar Screen
description: A Coast Guard monitor on duty the night of the oil spill in Prince William Sound testified today that he could not have ordered the tanker Exxon Valdez to change course even if he had seen that the ship was headed for Bligh Reef.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   People
description: * Leonard Short has been named senior vice president and general manager of Ross Roy Direct.

description: The company said the decrease in net income stems from a loss on the sale of marketable securities of $1,674,921, or about 6 cents a share, after taxes.

title: Air France Strike Set
description: Air France's pilots' union today called on its members to strike for 48 hours next weekend to protest deteriorating working conditions and a continuing loss in purchasing power, a union statement said. The statement came as a two-day strike by flight navigators and mechanics at France's three main airlines - Air France, Air Inter and UTA - was drawing to a close. Air France officials said they expect the pilots' strike on Saturday and Sunday to disrupt service on the 300 long- and medium-haul flights the state-owned airline normally operates in that period.

title: CUOMO BUDGET GAP SEEN RISING AGAIN

title: After 3 Decades, Mandela Measures Up to Legend
description: When Nelson Mandela emerged from more than a quarter of a century in jail on Sunday, he told the crowd that gathered to hail him here that he had left behind ''long and lonely years'' of deprivation. He did not mention that he had also left his reading glasses and the text of the speech he had written for the occasion.

title: Reviews/Music;   Prize Winner Offers a Solo In Shared Bill at Carnegie
description: Part of the prize given to winners of the Carnegie Hall International American Music Competition is an appearance at Carnegie Hall as a concerto soloist with the American Symphony Orchestra. Michelle Makarski, the California violinist who won the competition last fall, collected that part of her winnings on Sunday afternoon.

title: Nicholas Ashford, 47, British Foreign Editor
description: Nicholas Ashford, foreign editor of The Independent and a former South Africa and Washington correspondent, died of cancer on Saturday, the newspaper said today. He was 47 years old.

title: China-Soviet Ventures

The newspaper said Soviet technical experts had recently visited some sites. One possible joint project involves a large copper mine in northeastern China.

description: Four days after being shot in the head by an assailant who stole his car and fled, Rabbi Chaskel Werzberger was buried here today in a community he helped found more than a decade ago.

title: Rome Journal;   The Die Is Still Cast, and Italy Is Still Betting on It
description: At the coffee bars where Romans flock to give their hearts and minds the kick-start they sometimes need, the talk this morning was of Mike Tyson and the Naples soccer team. Monday here tends to be a day for losers, and there were more of them today than normal.

title: Will King's Trickeration Backfire?
description: Ever since Don King arrived in boxing, he has wisely projected style instead of substance. Mostly hair style and life style. His coiffure appears to have been designed by a blown fuse. His schedule features tuxedos for breakfast, limos for lunch and unsuspecting negotiators for dinner. Then there's his word style. He hides behind the laughs that his vocabulary creates.

title: The Chorus Master
description: ''Prepare your notes and voices,'' David Stivender would thunder at his choruses. ''The unconsidered sound is not worth making.'' His death of heart failure last week at the age of 56 robs the Metropolitan Opera of a devoted chorus master who never stopped striving for intelligible musical drama.

description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Company News;   Sizeler Property
description: Sizeler Property Investors Inc. said that through last Friday it had been tendered 2.2 million shares of Property Trust of America, or 54.1 percent, in its $11.59-a-share bid. Sizeler said it extended its offer for 2.9 million sahres of Property Trust until March 9. The offer was extended pending an appeals court decision on whether the takeover could be completed between the two real estate investment trusts. Property Trust's shares rose 12.5 cents today, to $9.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Brazil Fire Threatens Refuge Of Monkey
description: A forest fire has burned about 30 percent of a Brazilian reserve that represents the last stand for a monkey species on the verge of extinction, the golden lion tamarin.

description: b-After income of $8,751,000, or 22 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of change in accounting for income taxes. The company's latest quarter figures included a pre-tax charge of $3.1 million related to writedown of plant assets. Year-ago quarter included a pre-tax gain of $81.1 million from settlement of patent litigation. Also in the year-ago quarter the company had a $7.9 million non-recurring pre-tax charge. The 1988 full-year figures also included a non-recurring pre-tax charge of $31.1 million.

title: Black South Africans in New York Area Are Upbeat but Cautious
description: Black South Africans in the New York area said in interviews yesterday that the release of Nelson Mandela improved the prospects for negotiations between the Pretoria Government and South Africans opposing apartheid.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Just when you think things can't possibly get worse in this market, they do.''

title: Deprenyl Research reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $2,789,000, or 63 cents a share, for the latest year and $9,000 for 1988. The latest year's continuing operations of $311,000, or 7 cents a share, included a gain on investments of $828,000, a loss on pharmaceutical operations of $403,000 and investor relations costs of $114,000. The company said the source of the 1989 gain was not immediately available. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Selma Students End Sit-In, but Rift Over School Chief Goes On
description: About 100 black students ended a five-day sit-in at Selma High School today, paving the way for the reopening of the city's 11 schools, which have been closed for a week in a bitter racial dispute.

title: Scott Paper Ltd. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included net gain of $6.5 million, reflecting sale of Sincella Inc., partly offset by non-recurring costs associated with White Swan acquisition. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Company News;   Hilton Shares Up After News Report
description: Shares in the Hilton Hotels Corporation closed $2.875 higher today, at $64.625, with 587,500 shares changing hands after a published report said an investment group including Alfred Checci, the chairman of Northwest Airlines, was contemplating a bid.

title: Green Mountain Power Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Versar Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Personal Diagnostics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Has de Klerk Devised His Own Fall?
description: While millions of people across South Africa today celebrated the release of Nelson Mandela, the question raised insistently by supporters and opponents alike is whether President F. W. de Klerk, in freeing the black leader, has unleashed a chain of events that he will not be able to control.

title: KEY RATES
U.S. and Soviets Confident as Trade Talks Open
description: The United States and the Soviet Union opened talks today on ending nearly a half-century of trade restrictions. Both sides expressed confidence that an accord could be ready for signature when President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev meet in Washington in June.

title: Careers;   Computer Job Demand Up, Interest Off
description: DESPITE the layoffs in the computer industry, there is a growing demand for computer science professionals. At the same time, the number of those majoring in computer science has declined at some universities and barely held steady at others.

title: Taiwan Unit Eases Freeze
description: Taiwan's huge Hung Yuan Group, the island's biggest ''underground'' investment company, resumed paying interest today to some investors, but cash withdrawals remained frozen under an emergency ban.

title: Oregon Steel Mills reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $639,000, or 9 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change, and included a gain of $1.6 million, or 23 cents a share, from the sale of equipment.

title: Robert Half International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SPI Pharmaceuticals reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 31
Egypt Asks Help for New Alexandria Library
description: Short on cash, long on dreams of glories past recalling, Egypt is asking the world to finance the rebirth of antiquity's greatest trove of wisdom: the Library of Alexandria, where scholars once gathered their knowledge of gods and stars and science on scrolls of papyrus.

title: A Generation Writing in English Is Broadening the Fiction of India
description: In a burst of innovation, a new generation of young, iconoclastic and cosmopolitan writers is rapidly expanding India's literary horizons in novels and short stories. Writing in English, these authors are able to present their disarmingly intimate and often unconventional images of India to readers beyond their nation's borders.

title: BRIEFS
description: Andover Bancorp, Andover, Mass., and First Essex Bancorp said they had agreed to a merger in a tax-free stock exchange. Each of the 4.1 million outstanding Andover common shares will remain outstanding and represent one share of the new company. Each of the six million outstanding First Essex shares will be converted into 0.526 share of the combined company.

title: Perrier Asserts Source Of Water Is Unaffected
description: Embarrassed by the discovery of chemical impurities in some of its mineral water sold in the United States, the Source Perrier company rushed to reassure consumers that it had dealt with the problem responsible for the health scare.

title: Reviews/Music;   A Young Violinist's Blend Of Spectacular and Lyrical
description: Still in his early 20's, the American violinist Joshua Bell is already a well-traveled and much-acclaimed performer, and expectations ran high for his solo recital in the Kaufmann Concert Hall at the 92d Street Y on Saturday evening. He met and eventually exceeded them.

title: 'Junk Bond' Prices Fall On Worry Over Drexel
description: The prices of ''junk bonds'' skidded sharply again yesterday as investors reacted nervously to news that Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., long the backbone of those markets, was scrambling to raise much-needed capital from outside sources. Some bonds fell in morning trading by as much as five points, or $50 for every $1,000 face amount, but most ended the day off only one to two points, dealers said.

title: Mandela Sees Negotiations Soon Over Political Rights for Blacks
description: Nelson Mandela predicted today that negotiations on a new constitution extending political rights to blacks could start soon despite his unresolved differences with President F. W. de Klerk.

title: Chronicle
description: The story of JIM JENSEN'S fight against drug addiction begins tonight on WCBS-TV, when the newscaster tells how he freed himself of his cocaine and Valium habits. Segments from ''Jim Jensen: A Profile in Survival'' will be presented on the Channel 2 news broadcasts at 5 P.M. and 11 P.M. Tuesday through Friday. The profile was produced by the Union County (N.J.) Council on Alcoholism and Drug Addictions.

title: Seeing Branches on the Data Tree
description: IN 1985, when the disk management program XTree first appeared, the average user of an I.B.M.-compatible computer probably stored files on floppy disks that held 360,000 characters. If his system included a hard disk drive at all, it was likely to hold 20 million characters.

title:
Business People;

Columbia Hospital Plans To Go Public After Deal
description: LEAD: The Columbia Hospital Corporation, a three-year-old private hospital company, will be taken public this spring after acquiring Smith Laboratories Inc. in San Diego, which makes medical equipment used in orthopedic rehabilitation.

title: Quandary for Patients: Have Surgery, or Await Test for Hepatitis C?
description: SOME blood bank officials are raising a difficult question for those facing elective surgery: Should they consider postponing the operation until a new test for the most common form of hepatitis spread by transfusions can be used to screen all donated blood?

title: Business People;   CS First Boston Hires Chief For Asia/Pacific Subsidiary
description: After a frustrating year-and-a-half search, CS First Boston Inc. said yesterday that it had hired a chief executive for its Asia/Pacific subsidiary, Allen Wheat, who is the chairman of the London-based Bankers Trust International P.L.C., a unit of the Bankers Trust Company.

title: Cuomo Chooses March For Congressional Elections
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today set March 20 as the date for special elections to fill two vacant seats in New York's Congressional delegation.

title: International Container Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Pacific Scientific reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $989,000, or 18 cents a share. c-Net loss and after an extraordinary credit of $576,000, or 11 cents a share, in the year.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   The Strategy For Benson & Hedges
description: DISPUTING the accuracy of recent reports in the advertising trade press, a top Philip Morris marketing executive says the company is not repositioning Benson & Hedges cigarettes as a brand for blue-collar smokers. Instead, the nation's largest tobacco company will try to maintain its edge with the current customers who like the cigarettes' image of style and affluence.

title: Coal Accord in Doubt as Fines Stand
description: A judge in Virginia refused last night to suspend $64 million in strike fines levied against the United Mine Workers of America, raising doubts that the long, costly and sometime violent walkout against the Pittston Coal Company would end soon.

title: Astrex Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits from repurchase of debentures of $1,170,000 for the quarter and $1,652,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss and after an extraordinary credit from repurchase of debentures of $313,000 for the 9 months.

title: Soviets Put Executions By Stalin at 786,000
description: The K.G.B. said in a report today that three-quarters of a million people were shot to death as enemies of the Soviet state from 1930 to 1953.

title: Earl Gagosian Is Dead; Hotel Founder Was 61
description: Earl Gagosian, founder of the Royal Inns of America and the Continental Inns, both hotel chains in the Southwest, died of a heart attack on Friday. He was 61 years old and lived in LaJolla, Calif.

title: The Second Baddest Dude
description: rrIron Mike Tyson, beaten decisively but clinging to a technicality, had claimed that the heavyweight title was still his. Some say, paraphrasing Jimmy Swaggart, that Don King made him do it. Others had spoken about big money from future fights being jeopardized, or that it was simply a refusal to face reality.

title: Rostropovich Is Home at Last With Just a Touch of America
description: Mstislav Rostropovich spoke to his compatriots in his own land and language tonight for the first time in 16 years. What he said to them with the two great Russian symphonies and the encores he conducted was that life is tragic, and the march from tragedy to redemption tortuous.

title: Western Federal Savings reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The 1989 fourth quarter loss included an additional provision for possible loan losses of about $1,771,000.

title: To Help Black South African Students
description: To the Editor:

title: University National Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago quarter and year results restated to reflect the 2-for-1 stock split effective Nov. 14, 1989.

title: Satisfying Menages a Trois: Husbands, Wives Restaurants
description: ''WHEN gourmandism is shared,'' the French gastronome Brillat-Savarin wrote, ''it has the most marked influence on the happiness which can be found in marriage. A married couple who enjoy the pleasures of the table have . . . a subject of conversation which is ever new; they can talk not only of what they are eating, but also of what they have eaten, what they will eat, and what they have noticed at other tables.''

title: Marine Midland Banks Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Marine's results reflected the impact of a provision for loan losses of $263.3 million in the fourth quarter, compared with a provision in the year-ago fourth quarter of $102.6 million, which included $60 million for loans to less developed countries in the process of refinancing their external debt.

title: Framingham Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bush Faces Decision on Arms Talks
description: With conflicting advice from the national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, President Bush faces a decision on whether to wrap up a strategic arms agreement with the Soviet Union or introduce major new proposals that could delay its completion, Administration officials say.

title: Women's Game Draws Rising Crowd Support
description: On Saturday night at Seattle, more than 7,000 spectators watched Washington upset Stanford in women's basketball. On Sunday afternoon at West Lafayette, Ind., more than 13,000 watched Iowa upset Purdue in women's basketball. Both games were televised nationally and not blacked out locally and still drew large crowds.

title: Vienna to Extend Social Benefits To Jewish Victims of the Nazi Era
description: Austria has concluded agreements to pay nearly $200 million in benefits to Jews who suffered there during the Nazi era, officials in New York said yesterday.

title: Retail Sales Gained 1.6% In January
description: Retail sales rose a strong 1.6 percent in January, the sharpest gain in more than a year, the Government said today. Analysts said the broad advance demonstrated enough consumer confidence to hold off a recession.

title: DDI Pharmaceuticals reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: The Collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert;   The Firm Is Not Expected to Survive
description: Although Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. said yesterday that a bankruptcy filing by the firm would be framed under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, a provision intended to give a company time to reorganize, specialists in the field said there was little chance the firm would survive.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Koop's Idea For Alcohol Ban Debated
description: AGREEING with a group of communications professionals that ''advertising works,'' the former Surgeon General, C. Everett Koop, yesterday called for a complete ban on broadcast beer and wine advertising to prevent alcohol abuse and drunken driving, particularly among young people.

title: The Collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert;   For Those Tied to Drexel, Concern but No Panic
description: Those who have a vested interest in the fate of Drexel Burnham Lambert and of the ''junk bond'' market that Drexel created and once dominated are scattered across the business landscape.

title: Three Robbery Suspects Slain
description: Undercover police officers who had been investigating a number of restaurant robberies shot and killed three suspects and wounded a fourth outside a McDonald's restaurant here early Monday. None of the nine police officers were hurt. The suspects had tied up a manager, who was alone, and forced her to give them the combination to the safe. A spokesman for the police said officers opened fire when a suspect pointed a weapon.

title: Perrier Stock Off On Japanese Move
description: The stock of Source Perrier fell sharply for a second straight day today after the Japanese distributor of the French water followed the lead of the United States and withdrew tens of thousands of bottles because of health concerns. Suntory Ltd. said in Tokyo that it had suspended sales temporarily and recalled 10,000 cases of Perrier because of fears the water may contain benzene, a cleaning solvent.

title: Hondo Oil & Gas Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss A gain of $9.7 million on the sale of an oil and gas property was a contributor to improved earnings.

title: KEY RATES
Doleman's Bid Rejected
description: A judge in Minneapolis has rejected a bid by Chris Doleman, a defensive end for the Minnesota Vikings, to become a free agent.

title: Grey Advertising Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Revenue represented gross billings. Commissions and fees for the latest periods totaled $113,170,000 for the quarter and $411,083,000 for the year, compared with $112,886,000 and $373,293,000 for year-ago periods, respectively. The company said in 1988, it sold certain foreign and domestic units, resulting in a gain of $3,730,000, of which $1,780,000 was recognized in the fourth quarter.

title: Julie V. Marsteller, 46, Barnard College Dean
description: Julie V. Marsteller, dean of disabled students at Barnard College, died of complications resulting from muscular dystrophy yesterday at the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. She was 46 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Duriron Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Latest quarter and year results included acquisition of Automax Inc. on Nov. 29, 1989 for 552,000 shares of common stock by pooling-of-interest method.

title: Eddie Antar Surrenders
description: Eddie Antar, the founder of Crazy Eddie Inc. who has been sought since last week in connection with a fraud case, surrendered to the authorities today.

title: Chronicle
description: Although Mayor MAYOR DAVID MN. DINKINS was scheduled to make a public speech at the University Club in Manhattan yesterday, club officials barred reporters from entering the private Fifth Avenue enclave.

title: On Arms: Start, and Start Again
description: The news on Europe continues to astound. Moscow and Washington have now reached agreement on future troop levels in Europe and on a two-stage procedure for German unification. Even as they do so, they're also considering even more far-reaching talks on nuclear and conventional weapons. That sounds premature, but it isn't.

title: Book Notes
description: Record Enrollment?

title: Reuters Holdings Plc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The net income represented profit attributable to shareholders. Share earnings are earnings per American Depositary Share (ADS). Each ADS represented three ordinary shares. The U.S. dollar equivalents have been converted at $1.61 to 1 pound sterling, a rate prevailing on Dec. 31, 1989.

title: Cuomo Asserts Bush Delays 'Peace Dividend'
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo flew here for a visit of a few hours today to accuse President Bush of playing politics with the ''peace dividend'' and to tell reporters, the only people he met with, that he was not thinking, at the moment, about running for President.

title: Poor Reviews for Musical Of 'A Clockwork Orange'
description: ''A Clockwork Orange 2004,'' the Royal Shakespeare Company's much-anticipated stage version of the novel by Anthony Burgess, has opened at the Barbican Theater to mostly negative reviews, with John Peter of The Sunday Times of London calling it ''only an intellectual 'Rocky Horror Show' '' and John Gross of The Sunday Telegraph calling it ''a clockwork lemon.''

title: No. 2 Missouri Tops No. 1 Kansas
description: Since the college basketball season began last November, no less than a dozen different teams have been ranked No. 1 in a fleeting game of musical chairs that followed a familiar, unimpressive pattern: Climb to No. 1 at home, lose it on the road.

title: Preschool Aid for the Poor: How Big a Head Start?
description: Outside Pearl Jones's classroom lie the scars of poverty: vacant lots choked with weeds and trash, smoke-blackened buildings and housing projects where even the balconies have chain-link fences.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: About New York;   Stars Are Born? Booking Cowgirls And Jokeaholics
description: rrSteven Scott Productions, which books acts for everything from Super Bowl parties to cable-television quiz shows to automobile dealerships, advertised in Back Stage that it was again holding auditions for ''unique and unusual acts.'' So what's ''unique and unusual?'' It varies. Past auditioners have included a woman who recites poetry to salt and pepper shakers; a man who jumps into rolls of toilet tissue and then wraps himself like a mummy within 10 seconds, and a pantomimist who imitates a monkey eating a banana.

title: Integrated Resources Files for Chapter 11 Protection
description: After months of trying to reach an out-of-court understanding with its creditors, Integrated Resources Inc. sought voluntary protection yesterday under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $10,983,000 related to retirement of debt for the quarter and year.

title: Westchester Legislators Add To Budget, Averting Layoffs
description: The Westchester County Board of Legislators amended the 1990 budget today, averting the layoffs of some of the more than 400 county workers who were told last week that their jobs were being eliminated.

title: Doubleday Book Shops Sale Is Seen
description: Bertelsmann A.G., the owner of Bantam Doubleday Dell, is believed to be close to reaching a deal to sell its 39 Doubleday Book Shops to Barnes & Noble/B. Dalton.

Vast Security Setup Awaits Bush in Colombia
description: In preparation for President Bush's arrival here for a drug conference on Thursday, Colombia has organized an enormous security operation.

title: Fergus Reid Jr., Stockbroker, 89
description: Fergus Reid Jr., a stockbroker in New York for more than 60 years, died yesterday at York (Me.) Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived in York Harbor, Me.

description: b-After an extraordinary loss from an accounting change for income taxes of $827,000. c-Included an extraordinary credit of $6,315,000, or 40 cents a share, from an accounting change for unbilled natural gas distribution revenues. The company said the latest year's net reflected a $10 million after-tax charge against third quarter figures which resulted from a lawsuit settlement related to Diversified's exploration and production operations. Also included $19.2 million for the settlements of take-or-pay disputes received largely in the first quarter. Results have been restated to reflect accounting change.

title: Smithfield Foods reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
New Faces Revive the 76ers
description: The road was not being kind. The Philadelphia 76ers were little more than a .500 team during a California and Texas trip around the beginning of the new year. John Nash, the team's general manager, was away from the team, scouting college players. This was not a bad time to be watching someone else play.

description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Co-op Manager In Queens Faces City Tax Inquiry
description: Queens authorities are investigating accusations that a once prominent real-estate company has fraudulently failed to pay New York City property taxes and other fees for many of the 80 cooperative apartment buildings it manages in the borough.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Until the unity of Germany is fulfilled, we have a difficult way ahead of us. But we are not heading into uncertainty, because the light at the end of the tunnel is clear even today.''

title: Voters in Ski Resort Reject Ban on Fur Sales
description: Residents of this tiny ski resort town today resoundingly rejected an ordinance that would have banned fur sales.

title: Happy Homecoming for Rangers' Richter
description: Gain the advantage and fail to seize control of the game. Over and over, the Rangers repeated the formula for frustration against the Flyers. A 2-0 lead dissolved. A 3-2 margin vanished.

title: The Collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert;   Key Events for drexel Burnham Lambert
description: 1976: The Drexel Burnham Group Inc., a brokerage firm, agrees to merge with Lambert Brussels Witter, a subsidiary of Groupe Bruxelles Lambert, Belgium's second-largest holding company, creating Drexel Brunham Lambert Group and its brokerage subsidiary. The merger gives Groupe Bruxelles Lambert approximately a 28 percent stake in the new company.

description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $107,000, which reflected change in tax benefit related to early retirement of debt. c-After an extraordinary charge of $406,900 from the early retirement of debt.

In the 1988 fourth quarter the company had after-tax charges of $26.8 million from pension settlement and asset reversion and an employee separation program. c-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $17,400,000, or 30 cents a share. description: Following is the text of a statement today by the Foreign Ministers of West Germany, East Germany, Britain, France, the Soviet Union and the United States:

title: The Collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert;   Drexel Employees Looking; Several Firms Are Hiring
description: Wall Street investment firms said yesterday that they had been flooded with calls from employees of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. looking for jobs. A spot-check of leading firms found several that said they would hire them.

title: General Trustco Canadian reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: The Collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert;   The Fed Nightmare
description: For years, E. Gerald Corrigan, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, has warned anyone who would listen that Wall Street firms have as much potential to disrupt the financial system as commercial banks do - if not more. Thanks to their rapid growth in the 1980's, securities firms today - like banks -have billions of dollars of financial obligations. Yet, unlike banks, securities firms are not answerable to any Government agency with the authority to supervise them in their entirety. Regulators fear that gives them too much leeway to get into risky ventures.

title: Richard Hazen, 78, Consulting Engineer
description: Richard Hazen, retired co-founder and partner in the civil-engineering consulting concern of Hazen & Sawyer in Manhattan, died of pnuemonia on Monday at Community Hospital in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. He was 78 years old and lived in Dobbs Ferry.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Della Femina Gets Ramada
description: Ramada Franchise Systems Inc. yesterday announced the selection of Della Femina, McNamee WCRS as its new advertising agency. The winning of the account enables Della Femina to return to hotel advertising; the agency lost the Sheraton hotel account to Wells, Rich, Greene last March.

title: Bolt Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included net gains from the sale of real estate of $43,000 and $577,000, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: A Big Chicago Realty Firm Stops Paying Some Bills
description: One of the nation's largest real estate firms said today that many of its commercial properties were so troubled financially that it had no choice but to stop paying certain bills.

title: Likud Party's Rift Prompts Jockeying in Israel
description: All the players on Israel's political game board quietly tried to reposition themselves today, every one of them certain that Trade Minister Ariel Sharon's unexpected announcement of his resignation from the Government on Monday could improve their fortunes.

title: Daimler in Berlin
description: Daimler-Benz A.G., West Germany's biggest company, said it would buy a site on the West Berlin side of Potsdamerplatz, one of the main squares. The maker of the luxury Mercedes cars said a new West Berlin-based services subsidiary would eventually move into the office complex it plans to build on the site. It said it would move other important management functions to West Berlin.

title: Velcro Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $250,000 related to discontinuing New Zealand manufacturing operations.

title: Article 050790 -- No Title
description: The Chrysler Corporation today posted a loss of $664 million in the fourth quarter and a 65.8 percent drop in profits for the year.

title: About Education
description: ''Go to the blackboard and write 'today,' '' said Suzy Poon, the teacher. Su, a first-grader born in China, neatly produced the word. ''A little faster,'' said Miss Poon, a 28-year-old Chinese-American. Su complied, then sat down at a work table next to the teacher.

title: Investors Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included net gain of about $4.6 million on sale of the majority of the bank's credit card portfolio; a $694,000 charge for restructuring; a $4 million chargeoff on a hotel property and a $16.6 million provision for possible loan losses for the quarter and year; the year also included $1,541,000 for merger termination expenses. c-Net income and included pre-tax gain of $18.2 million on the sale of mortgage banking operations and a $3 million pre-tax operating loss associated with those operations prior to the sale for both periods.

description: * Bruce Davidson, Jeffrey Frey, Mark Ezratty, Mark McLaughlin and Gail Anne Smith have been promoted to senior vice presidents at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles in New York.

title: Fatal Burglary on Long Island
description: A man was shot to death and his son injured in an apparent burglary, the police said today. A man broke into the rear of the Grauer family house in Hewlett at 9:30 P.M. Monday, the police said. The intruder opened the master bedroom door, apparently thinking no one was home, and was confronted by Stewart and Susan Grauer. The burglar shot Mr. Grauer, 52 years old, in the upper chest, killing him, the police said. Mr. Grauer's 22-year-old son, Brian, was grazed on the left hand by a bullet fired through his door.

title: Colonial Gas Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a credit from cumulative effect of an accounting change of $2,014,000, or 50 cents a share.

title: Shift at Metaphor
description: Metaphor Computer Systems said it would stop selling computer hardware and that it had an agreement with the International Business Machines Corporation to market Metaphor's business analysis software for use on I.B.M. PS/2 computers. David Liddle, Metaphor's president, said the company's manufacturing organization would become a separate company. He said Metaphor would focus on software for computers that run the Unix operating system.

Apogee Robotics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

After 27 Years, Mandela Moves Home to Soweto
description: Nelson Mandela returned home today to a tumultuous welcome from his people after an involuntary absence of more than 27 years.

title: Chronicle
description: STING, DON HENLEY, BRUCE SPRINGSTEEN and PAUL SIMON were among the entertainers at a glittery benefit Monday for the Rainforest Foundation, dedicated to preserving the Amazon forests and their inhabitants.

title: Chrysler Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter and year both included a $577 million one-time restructuring charge. The charge included costs incurred in the idling of the Jefferson Avenue assembly plant in Detroit, the closing of the St. Louis I assembly plant, the discontinuance of certain car lines, pension and layoff costs associated with reductions in the white collar work force and the writeoff of long-term assets, and the year also included a one-time after-tax gain of $309 million on sale of Mitsubishi Motors Corp. stock. Prior year results included a charge of $93 million for plant closings. The company also said its latest year earnings included record results from its Chrysler Financial Corp. subsidiary of $284 million, compared to $259 million in 1988.

title: Life Jackets Result in Search
description: The Coast Guard is searching 2,500 square miles of ocean and questioning the operators of marinas on the United States' Atlantic and Pacific coasts to determine the origin of 13 life jackets that have washed up on a beach at Martha's Vineyard, a spokesman said today. Seven jackets were discovered Sunday and the others Monday.

title: Now, Soviets Studying Capitalism at Harvard
description: The Harvard Business School, whose graduates ritually wave dollar bills over their heads at commencement, has admitted the first four Soviet students to its M.B.A. class of 1992.

title: Audit Says New York Telephone Overpaid
description: A preliminary audit by the New York Public Service Commission found that the New York Telephone Company had overpaid the purchasing division of its parent company, the Nynex Corporation, by as much as $28 million to remove old telephone equipment, according to court documents and people familiar with the audit.

title: WINE TALK
description: IT'S your broker on the phone. Does he have an undervalued takeover prospect? No, he has a trip to Chateau Lafite-Rothschild, in Bordeaux. Included is a private train down from Paris and dinner with Baron Eric de Rothschild, the managing partner.

title: Court Allows Expert Witnesses to Explain Rape Trauma Syndrome
description: In a ruling that could help prosecutors win convictions in rape cases, New York State's highest court today approved the use of expert testimony about the emotional side effects of sexual assault when the intent is to educate jurors about seemingly inexplicable behavior by rape victims.

title: WEST AND SOVIETS AGREE WITH 2 GERMANYS ON RAPID SCHEDULE FOR UNIFICATION TALKS; GORBACHEV ACCEPTS BUSH'S TROOP CEILING
description: The four major World War II Allies and East and West Germany agreed today on a framework for negotiating German reunification after 45 years of division.

title: Review/Dance;   Romance Takes a Beating With the Trocks' 'Giselle'
description: Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo poked fun at choreographic Romanticism, old and new, on Saturday night at the City Center Theater, 131 West 55th Street. This all-male troupe specializes in parodies, and its members have adopted outlandish stage names. The Trocks, as the dancers are familiarly known, took obvious delight in tearing passion to tatters.

title: TRW Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Qintex Entertainment reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income and included a tax credit of $648,000, or 3 cents a share.

title: A.B.A. Group Opposes Curbs on Abortion Rights
description: The policy-making body of the American Bar Association today approved a resolution opposing Government interference with a woman's decision to have an abortion.

title: Microsemi Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and after an extraordinary gain of $570,000, or 7 cents a share, from the repurchase of convertible debentures.

title: Homecoming Is Tragic for Salvador Refugees
description: For eight years Patrocinio Lopez dreamed of little but coming home.

title: 4-Year-Old Is Abducted After Father Is Killed
description: As many as six men posing as narcotics officers burst into a home in Pearl River, N.Y., yesterday, killed a man, tied up his wife and abducted their 4-year-old daughter, the authorities said.

title: Free Choice: When Too Much Is Too Much
description: AMERICANS can choose from more than 25,000 items on their supermarket shelves, tune in as many as 53 television stations, buy any of 11,092 magazines or periodicals, and be solicited by tens of thousands of special-interest and public-interest groups. It's freedom of choice, the American way. But an increasing number of sociologists and other experts are beginning to believe that the marketplace may have outsmarted itself. Americans, they say, are becoming overwhelmed, even paralyzed, by all these choices, and some experts say that the apathy is spilling over into other areas of daily life.

title: How Japan Can Reduce Its Huge Trade Surplus
description: To the Editor:

title: VSB Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Per share earnings not shown for year-ago first quarter; the company went public in October 1988.

title: Pekingese Captures Best At Garden
description: The smallest dog in the ring, a Pekingese, scored the biggest victory of his career last night when he was chosen the best of 2,903 dogs at the 114th annual Westminster Kennel Club show in Madison Square Garden.

title: David McGee, Actor, 43
description: David McGee, a mime and actor who taught movement at the American Academy of Dramatic Arts in New York City, died on Feb. 2. He was 43 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Chronicle
description: NEIL SIMON has given DIANE LANDER SIMON the ultimate Valentine. He married her - again.

title: Profits Up 43.2% at Reuters
description: Reuters Holdings P.L.C., the news and information organization, said today that its profits rose 43.2 percent last year to $:180.6 million ($290.8 million) from $:126.1 million ($203 million) in 1988.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: ELIZABETH SHROCK of White Plains called the Trump shuttle. ''Is this the correct number to call tomorrow morning to see if the 7 A.M. shuttle will be flying to Boston?'' she asked.

title: Mashed Potatoes, A Garlicky Tang
description: EVERYONE likes mashed potatoes; they are ''comfort food,'' pleasing to children and adults alike, haute cuisine buffs as well as fast food addicts. And nothing complements mashed potatoes like gravy -be it the natural juices from a veal roast, thickened pan drippings from a roast turkey, or, as in my menu today, vegetable sauce made for a meat loaf.

title: Goulds Pumps reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $27,393,000 for the quarter and $30,083,000 for the year. c-Net income and after losses from discontinued operations of $695,000 and $1,409,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said that the loss for the year stemmed from a previously reported decision to recognize a $24.8 million writedown of its investment in Raytec Watergroup Co. L.P. The writedown is based on certain assumptions that the company believes are reasonable and will be accounted for as a discontinued operation.

title: Let's Not Get Carried Away With Reality
description: There I was out to dinner with two heavyweight New Yorkers, extremely nice, literate people to whom I was wholeheartedly defending Shirley MacLaine. That's right, Shirley MacLaine. Mind you, I was making no defense of her claim to past lives; that far I can't go. But as to her benign, maybe even salutary emphasis on yoga and meditation, her jam-packed new-age seminars, her books and videos (yes, I've even rented one), in that I could certainly see no evil intent beyond a little spiritual hustling.

title: Support for Airline Deregulation
description: After an extensive study of airline competition, the Transportation Department has found no cause for alarm in the shrinking number of major airlines in the decade since the industry was deregulated.

title: The Collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert;   Prices of 'Junk Bonds' End Higher in a Volatile Session
description: Prices of ''junk bonds'' fell sharply yesterday morning but then recovered on word that Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc., the owner of the firm that has dominated the market in these high-yield, high-risk instruments for the last decade, was considering filing for bankruptcy protection. Trading, however, remained volatile all day.

title: Chicken's Home Not on the Range
description: ONE recent sunny morning Bart Ehman, a chicken rancher, went to visit his ''kids at camp.'' He veered down a muddy back road in Sonoma County, parked his late-model four-wheel-drive Ford and aimed his alligator-tipped cowboy boots toward a row of six low-lying chicken coops. Most days, the chorus of self-contented clucking that greets him pleases Mr. Ehman. Not today.

title: Mountaineer Bankshares reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Radiation Exposure Seen as Posing Risk For Airplane Crews
description: Pilots and flight attendants on many airline routes are exposed to more radiation than most workers in nuclear power plants, new Government studies show. In power plants the Government imposes extensive safety requirements, including education, monitoring and procedures to minimize dose, but no such limits are applied for the flight crews.

title: Brooklyn Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Dinkins to End Needle Plan For Drug Users
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins will scrap New York City's needle exchange program for drug abusers, city officials said yesterday. The decision abandons an AIDS prevention study that provoked bitter debate and did not draw enough participants to test its scientific premise.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   The Death Dilemma
description: Two years ago in Oregon, a boy named Adam Jacoby Howard was dying of leukemia. A bone marrow transplant might have helped but that would have cost $100,000 -money his family, on welfare, didn't have and money the state was not prepared to fork over. Earlier in the year the legislature had voted to stop organ transplants for welfare recipients and devote the funds to prenatal care instead. Adam, his family and friends were within $30,000 of the goal when he died.

Excerpts From the Speech by Mandela in Soweto
description: Following are excerpts from Nelson Mandela's speech here today: His Pride in Soweto . . . As proud as I am to be part of the Soweto community, I have been greatly disturbed by the statistics of crime, what I have read in the newspapers. Although I understand the deprivations our people suffer, I must make it clear that the level of crime in our township is unhealthy and must be eliminated as a matter of urgency. I salute the anti-crime campaigns conducted by our organizations.

title: Texas Journal;   On Geographic Names And Cleaning Them Up
description: The State of Texas is trying to clean up its map, eliminating the racist names of landmarks and neighborhoods, names have brought embarrassment and protest in recent months.

title: Review/Music;   Riccardo Muti Explores 2 Sides of an Italian Coin
description: Monday evening's Philadelphia Orchestra concert at Carnegie Hall was by no means your typical symphonic program, and clearly represented a devotional act by Riccardo Muti, the orchestra's music director. It offered two noble, neatly complementary vocal scores, and the performances had much to recommend them. But in the end the evening spoke more to Mr. Muti's preservation of a perhaps questionably vital performance tradition than to the scores themselves.

description: A Brooklyn grand jury decided yesterday not to indict a New York City police officer who shot and killed an unarmed 17-year-old while arresting him three weeks ago, a spokesman for the Brooklyn District Attorney's office said.

title: Judge Assesses Punitive Damages in Wiretapping
description: A judge has assessed $210,000 in punitive damages against two men who failed to convince a jury that their employer ordered them to perform hundreds of illegal wiretaps.

description: Reverberations from the financial crisis at Drexel Burnham Lambert were felt in the credit markets yesterday as prices of short-term Treasury securities moved higher and bond prices recorded gains of more than half a point.

description: Providence made 12 3-point shots tonight, a season high, and Carlton Screen led the Friars with 29 points as they upset No. 3 Georgetown, 94-90.

description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it had begun pilot production of computer memory chips that store 16 million bits of data, four times the capacity of today's most advanced memory chips.

title: Corrections
description: An explanatory insertion and a headline on Monday with the transcript of an address by Nelson Mandela mistranslated a word of a Xhosa chant used at anti-apartheid gatherings. The word, ''mayibuye,'' is translated ''let it come back'' - a reference to African land and, by implication, political power.

title: Review/Television;   A Folklorist Who Insisted on Black Pride
description: One of the highlights of public television's current Black History Month schedule is tonight's ''American Playhouse'' presentation of ''Zora Is My Name!'' That defiant exclamation point is significant. Zora Neale Hurston, the black writer and folklorist, was a fierce advocate of black pride back in the 1930's and 40's, long before the nation was being pointedly told that black is beautiful. By the time of her death in 1960 in a Florida welfare home, she was sadly neglected. She was left in an unmarked grave for nearly a decade.

description: Law-enforcement officials investigating a series of package bombs mailed in the South last December are intensifying their inquiry into a Georgia man who was convicted in a bomb incident 18 years ago.

Dinkins Present as Labor Talks Start
description: Breaking with tradition, Mayor David N. Dinkins appeared yesterday at the first negotiating session on a new contract with municipal workers and warned that New York City's fiscal problems would require ''tough decisions.''

title: Tyson Concedes; Wants Rematch
description: A rematch between Mike Tyson and James (Buster) Douglas seemed likelier yesterday. The dethroned champion and Don King, his promoter, acknowledged that Douglas had won the heavyweight title in the ring, and the manager of Evander Holyfield, the mandatory challenger, said his fighter was prepared to step aside under the right conditions.

title: Economic Scene;   Global Warming: Look or Leap?
description: FOR George Bush the candidate, global warming was hot stuff - not as critical to the nation's future, perhaps, as ending prison furloughs for murderers, but near the top of the list of issues that mattered to the quiche and Volvo crowd.

title: Hawks' Carr to Kings
description: The Atlanta Hawks traded the forward Antoine Carr and the guard Sedric Toney to the Sacramento Kings today for Kenny Smith, a guard, and Mike Williams, a rookie forward.

title: Ervin Seale, Minister, 80
description: The Rev. Dr. Ervin Seale, a minister of the nondenominational Church of the Truth, who broadcast services each Sunday over WOR Radio in New York, died of pneumonia on Monday at his daughter's home in Asheville, N.C. He was 80 years old and had homes in Manhattan and Asheville.

title: Vons Hires Outsider To Fill a New Position
description: The Vons Companies, one of California's largest supermarket chains, said yesterday that it had hired Dennis K. Eck from the American Stores Company, a retail food and drug chain.

description: The cheering became louder and louder and reached a deafening point when the bench emptied in celebration in a scene reminiscent of the Stanley Cup years for the Islanders.

British Publisher Buys Share of Hungarian Paper
description: Last November, Magyar Hirlap was still the official newspaper of the Hungarian Government. Today, in an indication of how rapidly change is happening here, it was bought by a group of private investors who include the British publisher Robert Maxwell.

title: At The 'Junk Bond' Banquet, The Host Is Suddenly Absent
description: The collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. signals the end of an era in which speculative debt became Wall Street's stock in trade and America's corporate establishment was transformed by financiers buying companies for billions of dollars in i.o.u.'s.

title: Bush May Revive Plan for Warships Off Colombia
description: At his meeting in Colombia on Thursday, President Bush is likely to try to revive a United States proposal to deploy Navy warships off South America to monitor drug-trafficking flights, senior Administration officials said today.

title: The Collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert;   Washington Unshaken by Drexel's Fall
description: The Federal Reserve and the Securities and Exchange Commission worked today to limit damage to the financial markets from the collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., but there was no sense of panic or drama here.

Winds and Swells Push Oil Spill Near Wildlife Refuge and Beaches
description: As winds picked up today sending more deposits of oily sludge near a sensitive wildlife reserve and other beaches south of here, Huntington Beach officials asked the Governor to declare a state of emergency.

title: TOP PRETORIA AIDE SEES END TO RULE BY WHITE PARTY
description: A top aide to President F. W. de Klerk said today that the South African Government expected that the National Party, bastion of white supremacy for 40 years, was ''unlikely'' to remain in control of the Government for much longer than the next five years. He predicted that toward the end of this period, the white House of Assembly would approve a new constitution based on universal suffrage.

title: 'No Longer Working Out'
description: Honey, here's the deal. 1. I swear to cherish you till death do us part. Or at least until the marriage is no longer working out. 2. During the life of this nuptial agreement, I'll brag to the world about your achievements as a world-class skier, your qualities as a mother and your business acumen. And in fact, until the marriage is no longer working out, we will share a lot of business decisions. 3. If, however, for any reason the marriage is no longer working out, I reserve the right to have paid spokesmen disparage your business and other abilities. I might even choose to call you arrogant. 4. And if for any reason the marriage is no longer working out, even after many years and many millions of earnings, we'll stick strictly to this contract. 5. This contract shall constitute the entire agreement between the parties, and no oral understanding not in writing shall be binding. Please sign below. Yours, at least for as long as the marriage is working out, Don

title: Burt Beck, 71, Official And Editor for Unions
description: Burt Beck, a union official and editor of union newspapers, died of cancer on Monday at his home in Suffern, N.Y. He was 71 years old.

title: Presstek Stake Acquired

Chronicle
description: There was another lesson on the environment yesterday. In Washington, DANIEL REICHER, a lawyer for the Natural Resources Defense Council, a leading environmental group, reported to work as a staff member of the White House Council on Environmental Quality, only to be told in the afternoon that he had no job.

title: Law Requires Refunds if Cable TV Reneges

title: Metro Datelines;   Man, 64, Is Accused Of Molesting 3 Girls
description: A 64-year-old Queens man has been charged with molesting three little girls left in the care of his wife at the couple's home, the police said last night.

title: Keating Is Portrayed as a Victim
description: Over the objections of Government attorneys, a Federal judge today allowed lawyers for Charles H. Keating Jr. to portray him as a victim of a vendetta by Federal savings and loan regulators.

title: Party's Agenda: Liberty and Justice
description: The Soviet Communist Party adopted a platform last week endorsing the abolition of the party's constitutional monopoly on political power and other changes. The text of the platform was distributed on Monday night by the official press agency Tass. Here are excerpts from the platform, as translated by Tass.

title: Corporate Error - and Arrogance
description: A company that respects the public's growing concerns for human health and the environment serves society and itself. A company that appears to treat them casually risks a heavy loss in public trust. Perrier seems to have grasped this point; Exxon has not.

title: Cubs Sign Williams To One-Year Contract
description: Mitch Williams, the Chicago left-handed relief ace, signed a one-year contract for $1,125,000 with the Cubs yesterday, thereby avoiding arbitration. Williams had been scheduled for arbitration today.

title: Review/Art;   From Lopsidedness to Limpidity: A Rethought and Renewed Tate
description: Some of the happiest people in London at this moment are the staff members of the Tate Gallery. After yearlong preparation, day-by-day collegial debate and a very short period in which the museum was closed, a renewed, readjusted and rethought Tate Gallery was opened to the public on Jan. 25.

title: Review/Music;   A Bleak Introspection in New Hungarian Music
description: Continuum, the new-music organization that presents retrospective programs devoted to both individual composers and broader compositional schools, has looked to Eastern Europe several times in recent years. Soviet and Ukrainian avant-gardists have been given an evening each, and several Soviet, Ukrainian and Estonian composers have been given retrospectives of their own.

The 1989 income included a second quarter gain of $18 million, or 12 cents a share, on the sale of the company's former European headquarters facility and a loss of $28 million on the writedown of the company's investment in Thomson McKinnon. Income for 1988 was negatively affected by a $41 million charge for discontinued operations recorded in the fourth quarter of that year.

The moves marked the demise of a firm that seemed to symbolize the fast-money era on Wall Street.

The suit contends that Bryant dropped Howard six feet to the ground at a party on July 3, 1988, at Wilkins's home in Atlanta when he tried to throw him into the swimming pool.

In the process, they are running into legal quandaries over how to treat students who have psychological disabilities but whose antisocial acts threaten campus life.

Pan Am said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that the negotiations were completed last month. A spokesman said the airline was seeking additional working capital at a time of year that is traditionally its slowest period.

title: F. R. Collbohm, 83, Ex-Head of Rand, Dies

Collbohm, an aviation engineer who became the founding president of the Rand Corporation, the nonprofit research organization, died Monday at his home here, three weeks after a suffering a stroke. He was 83 years old. Mr. Collbohm, who studied engineering at the University of Wisconsin, worked for the Douglas Aircraft Corporation at Santa Monica, Calif,, on designs for the Douglas DC-1, DC-2 and DC-3 aircraft.
