description: For a company that once spent freely, Integrated Resources Inc. is in the midst of a no-frills bankruptcy under the direction of Stephen D. Weinroth.

title: 'Junk Bonds' Advance; Traders Are Surprised
description: Prices of ''junk bonds'' rose strongly yesterday in moderately active trading, after Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc., which owns the brokerage firm that once dominated the high-yield market, said it had filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection late Tuesday night.

title: 3 Shot in Subway After Man, 65, Opens Fire
description: An 65-year-old man who had been ejected by a Transit police officer from a Queens subway station last night after arguing with a token booth clerk, later returned and opened fire with a .22 caliber handgun, seriously wounding a subway porter, Transit Authority police said.

title: Parent & Child
description: LAURENCE STEINBERG remembers not wanting to go to a neighborhood restaurant with his family when he was 13 years old, fearing that he might run into one of his classmates.

title: HEAD OF SCHOOLS OUSTED IN BOSTON
description: The Boston School Committee has voted to remove the School Superintendent from his job by buying out his contract before its scheduled expiration in June 1991.

title: Lebow Enters Hospital
description: Fred Lebow, president of the New York Road Runners Club, was admitted to Mount Sinai Hospital yesterday after an examination earlier in the day detected a growth in his head.

title: Korean Trade Deficit Seen
description: South Korea will run a trade deficit of $3.3 billion this year, the worst in nine years, the Korea Foreign Trade Association predicted Tuesday.

title: Kinetic Concepts reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Talking Deals;   What NBC Sees In Notre Dame
description: EXCEPT for end-of-the-season bowl games, NBC has been shut out of the college football market since the 1960's. In one bold stroke last week, NBC filled that hole, luring the University of Notre Dame away from the other major football powers that have a deal with ABC, starting with the 1991 season.

title: Firm Has 20.76% Of Gulf Resources
description: D. S. Kennedy & Company, a San Francisco-based brokerage, said it controls a 20.76 percent stake in the Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation and added that it might seek control of the Boston-based coal and petroleum concern ''absent a substantial change in direction by the company.'' In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Kennedy said it had purchased its two-million-plus Gulf Resources shares for an average price of $11.09 a share.

title: Currents;   A Bookshelf for Those Who Don't Like to Read
description: FOR those who want to look as if they collect books, there is trompe l'oeil wallpaper by Richard Neas that looks like a library of leather-bound books.

title: Rangers and Bad Back End Lemieux's Streak
description: The buzzer sounded and Mario Lemieux understood in his heart that more than the second period had ended. He pulled himself one more time to his feet and walked gingerly down the hallway underneath Madison Square Garden, slipping into the locker room and onto a training table.

title: British Air's Profits Up
description: British Airways P.L.C. reported today that its profits jumped 39 percent in its third quarter, partly because of traffic growth, lower pension contributions and aircraft sales. The carrier said earnings for the three months ended Dec. 31 totaled $78 million, compared with $56 million in the corresponding period a year ago.

title: May Stores Appoints Chief of Its G. Fox Chain
description: The May Department Stores Company has filled the top post at its G. Fox department store chain in Hartford with the appointment of Eugene S. Kahn, a young executive from R. H. Macy & Company.

title: Hall (Frank B.) & Co (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $50 million on disposal of discontinued operations. c-After an extraordinary charge of $9,059,000 for the quarter and year.

title: Westbridge Computer reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Latest third-quarter results includes a loss of $921,000 from the operations of Superior Business Machines Ltd. which was sold Jan. 25. Third-quarter results have been reduced by $3.8 million due to an accounting change. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Osmonics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'Miss Daisy' Leads On the Oscars Ballot In a Year of the Small
description: ''Driving Miss Daisy'' came away today with nine Oscar nominations, the largest number for any film this year. The low-budget movie adaptation of Alfred Uhry's Pulitzer Prize-winning stage play about changing social mores in the post-World War II South was made by the Zanuck Company, a fledgling production concern.

title: Dr. Judith Felton Becomes a Bride
description: Dr. Judith R. Felton and Dr. A. Douglas Logue were married yesterday at the Centerton Inn in Bridgeton, N.J. The Rev. Dennis A. Testa, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Merger of Transit and Police Forces Would Hurt Riding Public
description: To the Editor:

title: Reader's Digest Prices Offering
description: Reader's Digest, the publisher of magazines, books and other products marketed worldwide, announced yesterday that its proposed offering of 25 million shares of class A nonvoting common stock would be priced at $20 a share.

title: Top Swedish Party Threatens to End Coalition
description: Sweden's Social Democrats, the country's dominant political force for more than half a century, may quit the Government Thursday if opposition parties carry out their resolve to vote against a proposed wage-and-price freeze.

title: A.T.&T. Is Adding More Translators
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it would greatly expand its translation services to provide businesses and consumers with telephone interpreters who can help with 143 languages and dialects, 24 hours a day.

title: $250 Million Bond Offering Is Placed by New York City
description: The City of New York yesterday completed its first offering of new securities since David N. Dinkins became Mayor on Jan. 1, placing $250 million in tax-exempt general obligation bonds.

title: Canvas for Awnings, Aprons, Covers
description: IF it is canvas you need, Matera Canvas has it: boat covers, tarpaulins, tote bags, awnings, aprons and items some people wouldn't think of making of canvas.

title: Review/Theater;   Seeking Black Roots, in 'White Chocolate'
description: The eight performers who portray several generations of black women in Laurie Carlos's new theater piece, ''White Chocolate for My Father'' at BACA Downtown, move about a stage that is bare except for two symbolic structures. One is the sculptural representation of a waterfall, the other a flight of stairs leading nowhere.

title: Belgians To Write Off Drexel Stake
description: Groupe Bruxelles Lambert, a Belgian holding company that owns 26 percent of Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc., announced today that it would write off its entire investment, which it valued at $92 million.

title: Photo Control Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Curtiss-Wright reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $1,872,000, or 38 cents a share for the quarter and $6,975,000, or $1.40 a share for the year. c-Included extraordinary tax credits of $563,000, or 11 cents a share and $2,023,000, or 41 cents a share for the quarter and year, respectively. The latest year's income from continuing operations of $23,438,000, or $4.69 a share, included cumulative effect on prior years of a change in accounting for income taxes of $1,237,000, or 25 cents a share.

title: Crack Is Genocide, 1990's Style
description: LEAD: Today, as President Bush attends a six-hour drug ''summit'' in Colombia, I wonder why he so often says that drugs are our nation's number one problem, yet he does so little about them. Twenty-five years of working every day in the crucible of urban America have brought me to an extremely disturbing conclusion: The crack epidemic in the United

title: Entergy Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the 1989 year-end loss was primarily due to the third quarter write-off of its Grand Gulf 2 nuclear unit.

title: Yes, Cut Social Security Taxes
description: I became a Republican in large part because the G.O.P. offered a responsible alternative to Big Government. And by standing with the American people - liberating them from high taxes and government encroachment - the G.O.P. won three consecutive national landslides.

title: General Motors Acceptance Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company attributed the decrease in consolidated earnings for the year 1989 to narrower interest margins between the gross earning rates on outstanding finance receivables and the cost of borrowed funds. This was partially offset by the gain on the sale of GMAC's interest in Isuzu Motors Finance Co. in the first quarter of 1989. GMAC is a wholly owned subsidiary of General Motors Corp.

title: $240 Million Publishing Deal Is Set in Italy
description: In an important consolidation of the Italian publishing industry, the publisher of Corriere della Sera, one of Italy's largest newspapers, has agreed to buy a prestigious Turin-based publishing group for $240 million. The group, Fabbri-Bompiani-Sonzogno-Etas, is currently owned by a financial holding company of Giovanni Agnelli, the chairman of Fiat S.p.A., and his family.

title: British Policy Reduced Availability of Heroin;   Only Increases Supply
description: To the Editor:

title: Thermo Electron Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
The Changeless Village
description: To The Home Section:

title: As the Fears of Famine Grow in Ethiopia, War Imperils Relief
description: The intensity of the Ethiopian civil war is seriously threatening efforts to deliver famine relief to peasants afflicted by a drought even more severe in some areas than during the catastrophic famine and mass starvation of 1984-85, Western officials say.

title: Head of Iran's Parliament Says Rushdie Will Be Slain
description: The Speaker of Iran's Parliament said today that Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's death sentence on the author Salman Rushdie will be carried out.

title: JWP Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. Is Decades Behind Europe In Contraceptives, Experts Report
description: A panel of experts convened by the National Academy of Sciences said today that the United States had fallen decades behind Europe in the development of contraceptives and called for Government action to stimulate research on birth control.

title: Brooklyn Man Arrested In Purse-Snatch Killing
description: A Brooklyn man was arrested on Monday and charged yesterday in the killing of a woman who was dragged beneath the wheels of a van last month as her purse was being snatched, the police said.

title: State Turnpike Chief Resigns in New Jersey
description: The chairman of the New Jersey State Turnpike Authority resigned today in the face of rising questions over the management of the independent authority and its requests for a toll increase to pay for $2 billion it borrowed in 1985, most of which it has not spent.

title: Close to Home
description: BY now I will know if this week's mail included two envelopes addressed in rather peculiar scrawls. But, of course, it did. The scrawls were peculiar because the senders tried to disguise their handwriting, and the envelopes opened on valentines. They were either funny or in a foreign language. One of last year's offerings was of a puppy wearing a flowered hat, and read: De muchos besos y abrazos Este Valentin esta lleno Para alguien muy especial Y a quien yo mucho quiero.

title: Masco Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $3.3 million, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $9,990,000, or 12 cents a share, for the year, both related to early extinguishment of debt through the buyback of convertible securities.

title: Philharmonic May Name 3 Conductors to Share Its Directorship
description: The New York Philharmonic, having been rebuffed by several leading conductors in its search for a new music director, appears to be considering an arrangement whereby three conductors - Leonard Bernstein, Sir Colin Davis and Kurt Masur - would share artistic leadership.

title: Sanmark-Stardust Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share net reflected 4-for-3 stock split paid in January. Latest quarter results were adversely affected by the sale of a manufacturing facility at a loss of $138,000. They also included the recognition of an unrealized loss of $420,000 on marketable securities and an unusually high income tax provision due principally to certain capital losses for which no income tax benefit could be provided. In the year-ago quarter, the company sold certain plant and equipment at a gain of $368,000. The quarter included an unusually low income tax provision due to the utilization of prior period tax losses.

title: General Homes Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $166,000 and $259,000 for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively.

title: Undercover Police Inquiry at 9 Schools Is Assailed
description: The head of the New York Civil Liberties Union yesterday criticized a recent undercover police operation in nine city schools that sought to determine the extent of violence, drugs and guns in the schools.

title: Bush's Tax Plan Faulted
description: Congressional economists said today that President Bush's proposed capital-gains tax cut would increase the Federal budget deficit by $11.4 billion in the next five years and would continue to lose revenue far into the future.

title: Two Satellites Lofted in a Laser System Test
description: Two satellites rocketed into space today to test a plan to destroy enemy missiles by bouncing laser beams off orbiting mirrors.

title: Warrantech Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Return for McEnroe
description: John McEnroe, who has been barred from the Queens Club in London since he insulted the chairman's wife in 1984, will end an eight-year absence when he plays in the club's grass-court tournament, scheduled for June 11-17.

title: Q&A
description: A Moldy Walkway

title: 3 More Win and 2 Lose In Arbitration
description: Three players, including two catchers, won their salary arbitration cases yesterday, but two players, both relief pitchers, lost.

title: Leslie Fay Cos. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: The latest fourth quarter results were affected by a pre-tax reserve provision of $1.9 million on account of the $2,157,000 accounts receivable owed to the company by the Allied- Federated Stores at the time of their bankruptcy; by a pre-tax writeoff of $665,000 on account of the closing of the Knitivo division and by greater- than-planned markdowns in certain divisions.

title: Review/Theater;   Anorexic Cookbook Author Invents a Play
description: N. Richard Nash's ''Come as You Are'' is a potluck dramatic stew centering on a cookbook author with an anorexic past. This might be called a case of overcompensation - or artistic bulimia - although, as one later learns, the cook does not eat her own food.

title: No More Fur At Harrods
description: Citing a sharp decline in sales, Harrods is closing its fur salon, which has sold minks to the rich and famous for nearly a century. The renowned department store said today that sales have dropped by 40 percent over the last four years, but said it was not caving in to pressure from animal rights groups.

title: U.S. and Soviet Miners
description: To the Editor:

title: How Covenant House Gave Drifter a False ID
description: A lawyer for Covenant House and a young priest have acknowledged providing false identity papers to a 26-year-old drifter who has emerged as the central figure in accusations against the founder of the organization, the Rev. Bruce Ritter.

title: A Novelist at the Crossroads of Soviet Society
description: As the son of a diplomat, the Soviet writer Victor Erofeyev spent part of his boyhood in Paris. It was there, strolling on the Champs-Elysees, enjoying the sun and the style, that he first felt torn between East and West. ''I felt I had two homes,'' he said, ''Paris and the Soviet Union.''

title: Professional Care reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Senior Tour Rejuvenates Trevino
description: Lee Trevino bounced into the locker room earlier this week at the site of his latest assault on the Senior Tour and asserted himself on the drowsy morning calm as if it were a leader board.

title: Corrections
description: An article in SportsMonday this week about romantic relationships that develop between runners misidentified one runner. He is Pat Petersen.

title: Royal Shakespeare Names Adrian Noble as Its Head
description: Adrian Noble, a 39-year-old director whose credits range from Shakespeare to Cole Porter, today was appointed to succeed Terry Hands as the artistic director of the Royal Shakespeare Company.

title: New Test May Improve Lyme Disease Detection
description: An experimental test for Lyme disease can identify some cases that escape detection by standard methods, scientists from New Jersey and New York have reported.

title: Child Labor and Sweatshops on the Rise
description: To the Editor:

title: Canadian Pacific Ends D.&H. Offer
description: A deal for the Delaware & Hudson Railway, one of the nation's oldest railroads, fell through when Conrail refused to grant traffic rights on a direct route through Pennsylvania to Maryland. Although Canadian Pacific Ltd. then withdrew its offer to buy the D.&H., Government officials and a representative of the bankrupt railroad said they still hope to keep the railroad operating.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE DREXEL COLLAPSE

title: Cash Machines In Post Offices
description: The Postal Service, which ended a half-century of banking in 1966, will soon begin providing automatic teller machines in post office lobbies.

title: An Excerpt From the Bankruptcy Filing
description: An affidavit by Frederick H. Joseph, the president of the Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc., that was filed with Drexel's bankruptcy papers late Tuesday evening in Manhattan provides the most extensive explanation offered by the firm for its collapse. An excerpt from the affidavit follows. The group, referred to as DBL Group, is the parent company for the brokerage house Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., also known as a broker-dealer, and other subsidiaries. DBL Group is a major institutional securities firm that operates through several subsidiaries. DBL Group has trading capabilities in domestic and international securities, income and equity products, and complete investment banking services.

title: Johnson Debt Alleged
description: Jamie Astaphan, the physician at the center of the Ben Johnson steroid case, says that Johnson owes him $30,000 for medical treatment and that he is willing to go to court to collect.

title: Moynihan Quits Lectureship After a Protest
description: Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan relinquished a Vassar College lectureship Wednesday after 100 students took over the college's main administration building to protest what they said was a racist comment he made after a lecture there on Jan. 29.

title: Federal Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extrarordinary charge of $2,400,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Casimir J. F. Patrick, Banker and Lawyer, 83
description: Casimir J. F. Patrick, a retired bank executive and a lawyer in Manhattan for 40 years, died of congestive heart failure on Tuesday at his home in Port Washington, L.I. He was 83 years old.

title: Review/Concert;   Music Is Framed With Talk For Riverside Symphony
description: The concert of the Riverside Symphony in the Miller Theater at Columbia University on Sunday afternoon was a chatty affair. It began with remarks by Peter Smith, the dean of Columbia's School of the Arts, introducing the program, for which printed notes were also provided. After the first work the audience heard a taped interview with the composer of the second, Oliver Knussen, by the orchestra's music director and conductor, George Rothman. And after intermission came a word from the sponsor, Paragon Cable Manhattan.

title: Cable Broker Selling Stake
description: The cable television entrepreneur Bill Daniels plans to sell 49 percent of his cable brokerage firm, Daniels & Associates, to nine of the company's executives. Mr. Daniels, who is 69 years old, will keep 51 percent, the company's senior vice president of marketing, Bob Russo, said on Tuesday.

title: Wolohan Lumber reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $189,000.

title: For Drexel, Creditors Galore
description: The financial crisis at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., which on Tuesday resulted in the largest bankruptcy filing in Wall Street history, has left a disparate collection of groups owed money by the firm, including Japanese banks and insurers and the Federal Government.

title: Official Islam Proving Gentler in Bangladesh
description: When the Government of President H. M. Ershad made Islam the official religion of Bangladesh in June 1988, Hindus, Buddhists and Christians feared for their lives and property.

title: Man Sentenced in Newspaper Hostage Case
description: Eddie Hatcher, one of two militant American Indians who in 1988 held hostages in the offices of The Robesonian, a local newspaper, agreed to plead guilty today in exchange for an 18-year state prison sentence.

title: 2 Die and 2 Are Lost in Alps As Snow Buries French Area
description: Heavy snowfalls in the French Alps caused avalanches today that killed two people, and two other people were missing, the police said.

title: The Healer Who Hits People
description: In the mornings, Dr. Harold Reitman encases his powerful hands in surgical gloves and repairs the damaged limbs of his patients.

title: Review/Dance;   McCusker Expands His Vision
description: Daniel McCusker left New York in 1985 to direct the Ram Island Dance Company in Portland, Me. The company presented a program of his work on Friday night at the Nikolais/ Louis Choreospace that suggested that this creator of luminous microcosms has also become interested in large works that use much larger canvases.

title: Reviews/Dance;   Portraying Women In Turmoil
description: The Claudia Murphey Dance Company, a technically strong and emotionally turbulent all-female troupe from Washington, appeared on Friday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio in four striking works by Ms. Murphey that showed women trying to take desperate measures in desperate straits.

title: Jets Not Wasting Time In Seeking New Talent
description: It took last year's Jet front office virtually all of February to sign the team's first Plan B free agent. And by the end of the season, not one was playing for the club.

title: In Trump v. Trump, the Focus Is on Lots of Fine Print
description: If and when Trump v. Trump goes to court, the main attraction in what already promises to be the most talked about and written about divorce proceeding in years could be four documents of about 35 pages apiece, each filled with paragraph after paragraph of fine print.

title: Currents;   The ABC's Of Interior Design
description: ''THERE'S a clear misperception that the profession of interior design lacks intellectual rigor, and that it's synonymous with home decorating, so we're prepared to address that kind of criticism,'' said Mark Salmon, who will direct the first interior design program offered by the School of Visual Arts in Manhattan. The four-year program, which begins in September, leads to a Bachelor of Fine Arts degree.

title: British Policy Reduced Availability of Heroin;   For Safety's Sake
description: To the Editor:

title: Upheaval in the East;   Angry Politics in the Soviet Heartland
description: There were no vegetables in the stores here. Meat, butter, sugar and sausage were being carefully rationed, and the wait for desperately needed housing was more than 10 years.

title: Arkansas Suffers Another Setback
description: Michael Strickland hit 9 of 12 shots from 3-point range as Texas Christian stunned Arkansas, 81-79, tonight in a Southwest Conference game.

title: For Many Women, One Job Just Isn't Enough
description: Amid the great wave of women sweeping into the American labor force in recent years is a group whose numbers are increasing even faster: women who hold more than one job.

title: Horsham Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $15,735,000, or 19 cents a share, for the quarter and $16,133,000, or 20 cents a share, for the year, both primarily related to Barrick Resources issuing shares at prices in excess of Horsham's carrying value. c-After a loss of $17,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $852,000, or 1 cent a share, for the year, both primarily related to Barrick Resources issuing shares at prices in excess of Horsham's carrying value. The company said earnings results improved primarily because of the acquisition of Clark Oil and Refining Corp. in November 1988. Also contributing was a record year at 22 percent-owned American Barrick Resources Corp.

title: Currents;   Fine Art, Via Polaroid
description: IN 1976, Dr. Edwin Land, chairman of Polaroid Corporation in Cambridge, Mass., had the idea to produce life-size, instant replicas of fine art, using a massive camera. Last November, Polaroid turned his idea into reality, and introduced more than 50 pictures by such artists as Vincent van Gogh, Edward Hopper and Claude Monet, whose ''Grand Canal, Venice'' is shown below.

title: Plan to Free Tropical Trade
description: World trade negotiators agreed today on a plan of action to liberalize trade in the $100 billion tropical products market, ending months of stalemate.

title: Who's Environment Czar, E.P.A.'s Chief or Sununu?
description: As the nation's defense recedes as an overriding issue and the environment becomes a more important one for Republican candidates, the White House chief of staff's role is being watched with alarm by many environmentalists and with concern by some Republican strategists and officials.

title: Sturm, Ruger & Co.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
2 Are Held in Sinking of 2 Lobster Boats
description: The F.B.I. arrested the president of one of the largest offshore lobster businesses in Connecticut and one of its captains today on charges that they scuttled the Sophie G, one of two lobster boats the company has lost at sea in the last 14 months, for $270,000 in insurance.

title: Accused Doctor Contradicts Prego's Testimony
description: A doctor who is a defendant in Dr. Veronica Prego's lawsuit about contracting AIDS began testifying yesterday on the central issue of drawing blood from patients in Brooklyn's Kings County Hospital in 1983.

title: Upheaval in the East;   BILLIONS IN HELP FOR EAST GERMANY APPROVED BY BONN
description: Leaders of both Germanys today welcomed the agreement of the wartime Allies to join in shaping a united Germany. As if to begin the process, Bonn approved a supplementary budget of $4.1 billion, most of it to shore up East Germany until reunification could be achieved.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Deal to Buy Division Of Ohio Mattress Fails
description: A deal to buy the Stearns & Foster Bedding Company from the nation's biggest mattress maker, the Ohio Mattress Company, fell through yesterday.

title: Review/Pop;   The Latest Teen-Agers' Heartthrob
description: From Frankie Avalon to David Cassidy to Donny Osmond, American pop has raised to fame and fortune a long string of insipid, pseudo-adolescent singing idols whose tenure as teen-age heartthrobs rarely lasts more than three years.

title: China Gets Canon Plant
description: The photography giant Canon Inc. said Tuesday that it had set up a subsidiary in China, making it the first leading Japanese company to start a big project there since the military crackdown in June. The new wholly owned subsidiary is in the southern Chinese city of Zhuhai, adjacent to the Portuguese-ruled territory of Macao.

title: Sahara Casino Partners LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are in units.

title: China Shuffles Armed Police Leadership
description: China today announced the replacement of the entire leadership of the People's Armed Police, the 600,000-member national security force that is supposed to be the principal mechanism for maintaining order.

title: ADVERTISING;   Accounts
description: * American Bazaar International, to Ted Chin & Company, for its Evan-Picone line of wool coats, rainwear, leatherwear and weekend wear.

title: Francesco Folonari, Wine Executive, 60
description: Francesco Folonari, the innovative general manager of one of Italy's most prestigious Chianti wineries, died on Monday, the Italian press reported today. He was 60 years old.

title: KEY RATES
British Policy Reduced Availability of Heroin
description: To the Editor:

title: Good Profit Margins Shown At Saks and Marshall Field
description: Prospectuses for Saks Fifth Avenue and Marshall Field show that both companies have produced profit margins about twice the norm for department stores catering to higher-income clientele.

title: New Vintage Publisher
description: Jane Friedman was named to the new position of publisher of Vintage Books yesterday, effective next Tuesday. She will retain her positions as publisher of Random House Audio Books and senior vice president of Alfred A. Knopf. In her new capacity she will report to Sonny Mehta, president of Knopf. Martin Asher, the vice president and editor in chief of Vintage, will become senior vice president. Vintage, the trade paperback unit of Random House Inc., publishes the world's classics, as well as contemporary literature and nonfiction.

title: A How-To For Young Capitalists
description: At age 5, Brandon Bozek began his first business, a lemonade stand in his front yard. He was excited about selling the juice for 25 cents during a marathon race in his Miami neighborhood, until no one stopped to buy.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ROBERT TAFT 2d bowed to the wishes of Republican Party leaders and withdrew yesterday from the governor's race in Ohio. Party leaders want Mr. Taft to run for Secretary of State instead, against Sherrod Brown, the incumbent. Mr. Taft's decision left George V. Voinovich, former Mayor of Cleveland, unopposed for the Republican nomination.

title: Upheaval in the East: Yugoslavia;   Albanian-Serb Tension Touches All in Kosovo
description: The Albanians gather in a haze of cigarette smoke in the university coffee shop, complaining about the ruling Serbs. A few blocks away, in a little restaurant named for the tomb of an epic Slavic poet of resistance to the Ottomans, Serbs grumble about the majority Albanians.

title: Boston Signs Buckner
description: Bill Buckner, the first baseman whose error contributed to Boston's loss of the 1986 World Series to the Mets, has agreed to a minor league contract with the Red Sox. Details were not announced.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Weapons Plant Pressed for Accounting of Toll on Environment and Health
description: The Rocky Flats Plant, the sole supplier of plutonium triggers for thermonuclear weapons, is facing the most intense pressure in its 38-year history for a full public accounting of accidents and operations that have contaminated the Denver area with plutonium.

title: M.I.T. Selects Highly Regarded Biologist on Its Faculty as President
description: The governing board of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology has decided to name a highly regarded biologist from its own faculty, Phillip A. Sharp, as the school's new president, university officials disclosed today.

title: 2 G.M. Units Report Gains For Quarter
description: Two of the principal non-automotive operating subsidiaries of the General Motors Corporation reported sharply higher fourth-quarter profits today, while a third, the finance subsidiary, said its earnings declined 2.4 percent in the period.

title: Muriel Roth, 82, Dies; Pianist and Composer
description: Muriel Parker Roth, a pianist and composer, died of heart failure on Friday. She was 82 years old and lived in Albuquerque, N.M.

title: Community Fights Air France Deal
description: The European Commission decided to oppose Air France's purchase of a controlling interest in Union de Transports Aeriens, a private French airline. The commission found that the acquisition by Air France, which is state owned, violated competition rules of the European Community, a commission spokesman said.

title: Steering the German Steamroller
description: Since the wall came tumbling down in a tide of German emotion, European leaders have been in a panic about reunification, fearing a new and unknown German menace yet also fearing to step in the way of this nationalistic steamroller. But on Tuesday in Ottawa, the foreign ministers of NATO and the Warsaw Pact nations grabbed control of the steamroller and put it on a track that should insure serious deliberations on the toughest issues of European security.

title: 35 Charged in Fraud Case At Child Welfare Agency
description: Thirty-five people, including nine employees of New York City's Human Resources Administration, were charged yesterday with taking part in schemes involving fake and inflated car-service bills that are estimated to have cost the city millions of dollars over four years.

title: Oil Blown Ashore in California, Aiding Cleanup
description: Stormy weather during the night appeared today to have blown ashore most of the oil remaining from last week's tanker accident off Huntington Beach, a development that was seen as a mixed blessing.

title: Merrimac Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
Ropak Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Transamerica Profit Up 31.2%
description: Buoyed by strong results in its consumer lending, commercial lending and leasing operations, the Transamerica Corporation today reported record fourth-quarter earnings. Earnings for the year also exceeded 1988's results.

title: Harvard Appointment
description: Bill Cleary, who is in his 19th season as Harvard's hockey coach, was named yesterday as the school's athletic director. Cleary, 55 years old, will take over his new position April 1, but will remain as hockey coach through the end of this season.

title: Calendar: Ways To Save The Earth
description: From Dwindling Resources, Fashion Institute of Technology, Shirley Goodman Resource Center, Seventh Avenue at 27th Street; 212-760-7670.

title: Active or Passive Iran-Contra Role? Point-Blank Questioning for Reagan
description: When Ronald Reagan appears in a Federal courtroom on Friday, he is likely to be asked point-blank the fundamental questions about his role in the Iran-contra affair, which have gone unanswered for three years.

title: U.S. Supercomputer Makers Challenge Export Proposal
description: United States manufacturers of the most powerful computers are challenging a Commerce Department proposal to relax regulations on exporting the machines. The manufacturers say the proposed change does not go far enough.

title: Questar Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Moscom Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Hynes, Taking Over Brooklyn Job, Takes On Holtzman
description: Charles J. Hynes, the new Brookyln District Attorney, has spent much of his first month in office making charges. But they are not the kind that prosecutors usually make. These are about the record of his predecessor, Elizabeth Holtzman, who was elected New York City Comptroller in November.

title: Royal Winnipeg Ballet Names Artistic Director
description: John Meehan, a former principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, has been appointed artistic director of the Royal Winnipeg Ballet, Canada's oldest ballet company. Mr. Meehan succeeds the late Henny Jurriens as director.

title: Viacom Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included for the quarter a net loss of $776,000 from net effect of immaterial non-operating transactions. The year included pretax gain of $313.1 million, resulting from the sale of cable systems and including the settlement of certain contingencies in the third quarter. The company said proceeds of the sale, valued at about $545 million, were used principally to repay a portion of its bank debt. c-Included for the quarter a loss of $2.4 million reflecting net effect of unreserved pre-acquisition contingencies settled during the quarter. The year included pretax gain of $16.8 million from sale of 812,500 shares of Orion Pictures Corp. and the net effect on unreserved pre-acquisition contingencies settled during the year at a loss of $3.1 million. The company said proceeds of the sale, which were $44.2 million in the aggregate, were applied to retire a portion of bank debt. d-Net loss Share earnings are after exchangeable preferred stock dividend requirements.

title: Decoration Of Old Is Recast For Today
description: From the stables of a Tudor manor house near Bath, Thomas Messel and a team of Gloucestershire artisans produce furniture and decorative accessories that are in the spirit and style of the 18th century, without being retrospective.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I thought it was appropriate. I was upwardly mobile.''

title: Shattered East Beirut Getting Relief Supplies
description: Relief supplies were sent today to East Beirut and tanker trucks began distributing water in the streets of the western part of the capital after two weeks of bitter clashes between Christian factions.

title: A Not-Guilty Plea In Sex Abuse Case
description: A nurse's aide pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges that she had sexually abused a 7-year-old mentally retarded girl at the New York Foundling Hospital in Manhattan.

title: Cheney Begins Asian Trip Seen as a Prelude to Military Cuts
description: Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney arrived in Asia today for 10 days of talks that allies of the United States see as a prelude to a major reduction of American forces in the Philippines and South Korea, and to renewed tensions with Japan over its contribution to the American military's huge presence here.

title: Heritage Media Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Some Find Mandela's Vision Limited
description: Since Nelson Mandela emerged from prison Sunday, his public remarks have generally fallen short of the expectations of many whites and some blacks who had anticipated the kind of inspirational vision that distinguished the late Dr. Martin Luther King in the American civil-rights struggle of the 1960's.

title: INSIDE
description: Drexel's Diverse Creditors

title: Informix Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-After extraordinary credits of $472,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,087,000, or 9 cents a share, for the year.

title: Treasuries Drop in Light Trading
description: Prices of Treasury securities dipped in light trading yesterday, as investor concerns eased about further financial fallout from the demise of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

title: ADVERTISING;   Time Warner Marketing Its Synergy
description: IF there is nervous excitement in the Time & Life Building in Manhattan, there is at least one reason for it. Synergy - the idea of spreading news, entertainment and marketing ideas across the whole range of Time Warner's properties, from magazines to movies to cable television to home video - is about to become a reality.

title: G.M. to Sell Saturn In Canada in 1992
description: The General Motors Corporation's Saturn subsidiary said it plans to begin selling cars in Canada in mid-1992. Saturn cars will be offered in Canada through Passport International Automobiles, the import division of G.M. of Canada. Passport was formed in 1987 as a dealer distribution network aimed at Canadians who favor Japanese and European imported vehicles.

title: U.S. Sues Longshoremen's Locals And 44 People, Citing Ties to Mob
description: The Federal Government yesterday sued six longshoremen's locals and 44 union officials and reputed organized-crime figures, including John Gotti, in an effort to end what the authorities say is Mafia domination of the New York and New Jersey waterfronts.

title: One German Team Seems Likely
description: The rapid political developments bringing East Germany and West Germany closer to unification could mean a single German Olympic team as early as 1992, the next Olympic year.

title: Susceptibility to Tuberculosis Found in Blacks
description: A statistical study indicates blacks may be more susceptible than whites to infection with tuberculosis.

title: Sahara Resorts reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Douglas Is Instant Celebrity
description: James (Buster) Douglas, the only man in history to win the heavyweight boxing championship twice in three days - first when he knocked out Mike Tyson in Tokyo, then when Tyson finally acknowledged that Douglas was really the new champion - inherited his mantle yesterday.

title: Books of The Times;   Farrago of Greed and Deceit In 19th-Century London
description: The Quincunx

title: St. John's Defeats Seton Hall
description: Boo Harvey stepped over the time line tonight and made history, as St. John's defeated Seton hall in overtime, 90-81.

title: Avondale Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,151,000 for the quarter and $4,695,000 for the year.

title: Nekoosa Stock Up After Filing
description: The share price of the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation rose $2 today, to $64, after the company said in a Federal filing that it was already in the ''preliminary stages of negotiations with third parties'' to sell the company for more than $63 a share.

title: Review/Dance;   Stepping Out of the City Ballet Tradition
description: The New York City Ballet, as every child knows, is the home of the neo-classic plotless ballet, and the springboard for that ballet is always the choreographer's choice of music.

title: Micron Products reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Burson-Marsteller Inc., New York, a public affairs and government relations firm, named Nancy Maloley a senior vice president in its Washington office.

title: Quick Pact Less Likely In Baseball Negotiations
description: Chances for a quick settlement that could open spring training camps diminished yesterday when members of the baseball players' negotiating committee dissected the Fay Vincent plan and found it welcome in one sense but too restrictive to accept without serious revisions.

title: Peasant Militia in Peru Kills 8 Leftist Rebels
description: Peasants used machetes, sticks and slingshots to kill eight leftist guerrillas in the latest of a series of clashes betwen ragtag rural militias and rebels in which at least 20 people have died this week, the police said today.

title: Bridge
description: If your partner overbids, landing you in an overly optimistic game contract, you can expect to fail by a trick or two, perhaps doubled. Then, according to your temperament, you can grumble, or glower, or go quietly on to the next hand.

title: New Jersey's Second Crisis In Insurance: Health Costs
description: As New Jersey Blue Cross and Blue Shield sends out new bills this month, the corporation's higher premiums pose for many policyholders an insurance crisis that overshadows the state's long, rancorous auto-insurance problems.

title: St. Lawrence Cement reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Britain Ready to End South Africa Sanctions
description: The British Government said today that it was ready to drop sanctions against new investment in South Africa, unilaterally if necessary.

title: Upheaval in the East: Czechoslovakia;   In Choice of Ambassadors, Prague Leans Toward the Symbolic
description: Rudolf Slansky, a disenchanted former Communist whose father, the General Secretary of the party, was hanged in 1952 after a Stalinist show trial, has been appointed Ambassador to the Soviet Union.

title: Loews Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $18,067,000, or 24 cents a share, which is an after-tax gain on disposition of CBS's Records division. The 1988 year results included a gain on sale of oil tanker of $6.5 million, or 9 cents a share, and a gain on sale of chewing tobacco and little cigar business of $29.7 million, or 39 cents a share. Exclusive of securities transactions, net income for 1989 fourth quarter would have amounted to $202.8 million, or $2.70 a share, compared with $243.4 million, or $3.21 a share, for year-ago period. The latest year's net income included realized investment gains of $96.6 million, or $1.28 a share, compared with same gains of $143.8 million, or $1.89 a share, for 1988. The year-ago quarter and the 1988 year results were restated to give retroactive effect to application of the provisions of FASB Statement No. 97, relating to accounting and reporting for certain long-duration insurance contracts.

title: Airgas Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $31,755,000, or $4.56 a share, gain on the sale of the company's Jackson Products operations, offset by losses from discontinued operations related to the sale of the company's Cryogenics manufacturing operations, of $217,000 and $236,000, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, a $660,000, or 10 cents a share, reduction of the gain estimated on the sale of the company's US Cylinder operations reported in the 1988 quarter for the quarter and year, and the quarter also included a $2,021,000 gain from discontinued operations. c-Included a $3,501,000, or 53 cents a share, gain on the sale of the company's cylinder manufacturing operations for the quarter and 9 months, and gains from discontinued operations of $1,121,000 and $3,311,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said operating results for all periods are restated to reflect Jackson Products Inc., US Cylinders Inc. and US Cryogenics Inc. operations as discontinued operations.

title: F.A.A. Inspector Praises and Also Criticizes USAir
description: A Federal safety inspector yesterday described the training of USAir's pilots as generally good, but stood by a report in which he criticized the airline's deficiencies after one of its jets crashed at La Guardia Airport last year.

title: Mexico and Vatican Move Toward Restoring Ties
description: After more than a century of estrangement, the Mexican Government and the Vatican are suddenly moving toward re-establishing formal diplomatic relations and are also having informal talks on restoring some civil rights to the Roman Catholic Church here.

title: Home Improvement
description: AN easy way to enhance the appearance of a bathroom is to replace a shower curtain with a glass or plastic shower door. Hinged doors are available for virtually all bathtub and shower stall shapes and installations. Sliding doors, described here, are designed to fit rectangular tubs or stalls between two end walls.

title: Faster Chip From Philips
description: Researchers at a unit of Philips N.V., the Dutch electronics company, said today that they had developed a new type of microprocessor that can execute 60 million to 100 million instructions a second, making it far faster than most devices now on the market.

title: A Document From 1824 Backs Up Boscobel's Decor
description: LEAD: When Boscobel was redecorated in the mid-1970's, the staff of the 182-year-old Federal mansion spent years scrutinizing 2,500 bills of sale and other papers to insure historical accuracy. Now the museum has a room-by-room inventory, dated April 27, 1824, that confirms the accuracy of the work, said Frederick W.

title: CHRONICLE
description: With the joint distinction of being the oldest Federal judge and the oldest alumnus of Princeton University, HAROLD R. MEDINA celebrates his 102d birthday tomorrow. The judge retired at age 92 from the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. There will be a quiet celebration at the Valley Nursing Home in Westwood, N.J., where the judge lives. He has two sons, six grandchildren and 10 great-grandchildren.

title: Inventories Fell by 0.2% In December
description: Business inventories fell in December for the first time in more than a year, while sales remained unchanged, the Government said today.

title: Perkin-Elmer reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $3.6 million, or 8 cents a share, for the quarter and $10.2 million, or 23 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: Edward Bursk, 82; Taught at Harvard In Business School
description: Edward C. Bursk, a former editor of the Harvard Business Review and an emeritus professor at the Harvard Business School, died Monday at his home here. He was 82 years old.

title: Upheaval in the East: Western Europe;   On Germany, Not All Is Joy
description: With the reunification of Germany now accepted as inevitable in Western Europe, governments from Brussels to Rome are bracing for the emergence of a single German nation rich and powerful enough to dominate European affairs.

title: New Jersey Troopers Cited for Misconduct
description: A state trooper and a former state trooper, already facing charges of assaulting a motorist on the New Jersey Turnpike, were indicted again on Tuesday by a state grand jury on charges of official misconduct.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Amerifirst Bank, Miami, said it had sued its former managers and auditors, contending that unsafe lending practices, negligent accounting and fraud had hurt the bank. The company is seeking $75 million in damages.

title: Valborg Anderson, Professor, 78
description: Valborg Anderson, professor emeritus of the English department at Brooklyn College, died of Alzheimer's disease yesterday at a nursing home in Colton, Ore. She was 78 years old and moved to Colton from Manhattan two years ago.

title: Metro Matters;   For Legal Beggar In New York City, It's a 9-to-5 Job
description: James Benagh, the first New Yorker to be granted an official permit to beg, is understandably circumspect about precisely where he works. ''Just say Times Square,'' he said yesterday. At 8:37 A.M. on Feb. 5, Mr. Benagh assured himself of a footnote in the annals of panhandling. He filled out Form 3136/7-85, begrudgingly provided by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. The form was an application ''to conduct Free Speech activities'' in the bus terminal on Eighth Avenue in Manhattan. Before the word ''permit,'' the word ''begging'' was written in.

title: Kean 'Circle of Mobility' Called Largely Illusory
description: Eight months after Gov. Thomas H. Kean announced a $2.5 billion ''circle of mobility'' plan to improve roads and mass transit in northern New Jersey, officials, business leaders and regional planners say no real plan exists.

title: Dow Posts 0.22-Point Rise as Volume Dips
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert's woes did not spill over to the stock market yesterday, as the Dow Jones industrial average edged up by 0.22 point, to 2,624.32.

title: Fitch Angry Amid Another Rout
description: The Nets' season continued its downhill plunge tonight, and so did the players' relationship with their coach.

title: Payco American Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income of $772,000, or 15 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of change in accounting.

title: Durham Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income of $1,212,000 for the quarter and a loss of $1,305,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $27,000 and $1,305,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said the latest year's loss from discontinued operations of $3,912,000 are results from the Nov. 30, 1989 completion of the sale of State Capital Insurance Co.

title: Perrier Says Employees Failed to Change Filters
description: The contamination of Perrier sparkling water was caused when company employees failed to replace charcoal filters that screen out benzene, a chemical impurity in the natural gas present in the company's famous spring in southern France, Perrier officials said yesterday.

title: Hollywood Design Myths
description: To The Home Section:

title: Ballard Ruled Unable To Control Own Care
description: A district court judge in Toronto ruled yesterday that Harold Ballard, the hospitalized owner of the Toronto Maple Leafs, was mentally incompetent to make decisions about his health care. But the court battle over control of his medical care and his property is continuing.

title: High-Risk Strategy Taking Toll
description: Few companies were as closely tied to the ''junk bond'' factory at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. as the First Executive Corporation, and today the big Los Angeles insurer is paying the price.

title: Transamerica Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an accounting adjustment loss of $36,869,000. Results for 1989 included about $9 million in combined after-tax losses from Hurricane Hugo in the third quarter and the San Francisco earthquake in the fourth quarter. Year-ago periods are restated in accordance with new requirements for accounting for income taxes, certain life insurance contracts and investment transactions. The effect of these changes was to reduce consolidated net income for the 1988 year by $84,303,000, or $1.12 a share, of which $36,869,000, or 49 cents a share, is for the cumulative effect of the change in accounting for income taxes. For the 1988 fourth quarter, net income was reduced by $19,994,000, or 26 cents a share. Operating income for the years ended Dec. 31, 1989 and 1988 include $40,211,000, or 53 cents a share, and $10,792,000, or 15 cents a share, respectively, of after-tax gains from investment transactions. Operating income for the latest fourth quarter includes no net after-tax gain or loss from investment transactions; the quarter ended Dec. 31, 1988 includes gains of $1,470,000, or 3 cents a share.

title: Enserch Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $3,369,000, or 6 cents a share. c-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $204,181,000 and income from an accounting adjustment of $27,033,000, or 47 cents a share. The company said year-ago fiscal 1988 loss included a $225 million after- tax provision for loss from the discontinuance of oil field services operations and a $50 million benefit from an accounting change. Results for the prior year also included a $29 million after-tax third quarter charge related to the company's engineering and construction operations.

title: Ruble Contest: Prize Is Dollars
description: An official of the Soviet Union today announced a prize of $25,000 to the person who devises the best plan for making the ruble convertible into hard currencies.

title: Review/Cabaret;   Singer, Actor And Pianist Rolled Into One
description: Michael Moriarty is a performer of so many parts that trying to relate them to one another is rather like piecing together an elaborate, oddly cut jigsaw puzzle. In addition to acting, he is a jazz pianist of considerable skill, an oddball singer with more than one vocal personality, and a writer of eccentric, jivey jazz songs. As an arranger and multi-instrumentalist, he also has a fairly well-developed mastery of electronics.

title: What's That Smell? Probably, It's Potpourri
description: IT was not one of those great moments in interior design, like the day Billy Baldwin lacquered Cole Porter's walls brown. Still, the night the decorators ate dried flowers deserves a mention in any account of the evolution of post-modern potpourri.

title: Banner Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $493,000 for both the quarter and 6 months, and the quarter reflected seasonality of earnings from Fairchild Industries Inc., acquired in June 1989. c-Net income and after income from discontinued operations of $14,339,000, or 89 cents a share for the quarter and $14,100,000, or 87 cents a share for the 6 months; the 6 months also included an extraordinary charge of $8,070,000. The company said the year-ago 6-month net income included a one- time first quarter gain from reduction of interest in Rexnord Corp.

title: Athlone Industries Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $262,000, or 4 cents a share and an extraordinary loss of $770,000. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $2,915,000, or 55 cents a share. The company said both years' results have been restated to reflect the reclassification of 1989 earnings of $262,000 and 1988 earnings of $1,330,000 from its sporting goods business as discontinued operations. Sales from the discontinued operations of $14,377,000 in 1989 and $24,457,000 in 1988 have also been excluded from results. In addition, due to the discontinuance of Athlone's women's blouse business in early 1989, a 1988 operating loss of $2,052,000 pertaining to the business was included in discontinued operations. A provision for disposal of $2,100,000 and a writeoff of goodwill of $4,185,000 were also recorded. The company also said extraordinary item is in connection with the early retirement of $25 million of the company's 15 5/8 percent subordinated notes during 1989.

title: Currents;   Ways to Show Off Shoes, And Not on the Foot
description: From Italy'' exhibit at the Italian Trade Commission in Manhattan, Gaetano Pesce, a Venetian architect who now lives in New York City, has displayed shoes in ways seldom seen before.

title: Electronic Data Systems Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Electronic Data is a unit of General Motors Corp.

title: An Eating Club at Princeton Starts Vote to Admit Women
description: Undergraduates at the oldest of the 13 private eating clubs at Princeton University are starting to break a 111-year tradition of all-male membership.

title: Komatsu to Buy 2 Carbide Plants
description: The Union Carbide Corporation said it intends to sell two polysilicon plants to the Komatsu Electronic Metals Company of Tokyo. The plants in Moses Lake and Washougal, Wash., employ a total of 270 people and had 1988 sales of about $35 million. Terms of the impending sale were not disclosed under an agreement between the companies, said Harvey Cobert, a spokesman for Union Carbide, which is based in Danbury, Conn.

title: Moscow Pays the Price
description: For months now, Mikhail S. Gorbachev has been playing a poor hand so deftly that it has often looked like a good one.

title: Merger of Transit and Police Forces Would hurt Riding Public;   Taking a Back Seat
description: To the Editor:

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Junk Bonds, Consenting Adults
description: ''I don't think it's sad for these jerks on Wall Street,'' gloated one critic of ''junk bonds'' after the investment firm Drexel Burnham Lambert declared bankruptcy. So began a wave of pessimistic predictions and moral outrage directed at junk bond dealers.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday headed ''Disparity Between Bonds'' misstated the type of bonds included in the Merrill Lynch high-yield index.

title: Perrier Widens Recall After New Finding
description: Source Perrier announced today that it was withdrawing every bottle of its sparkling mineral water throughout the world after traces of benzene, a toxic chemical, were reported in bottles tested in Denmark and the Netherlands.

title: Mate on Tanker Faults Helmsman in Accident
description: The prosecution's main witness in the trial of Capt. Joseph J. Hazelwood said today that the automatic pilot on the tanker Exxon Valdez had been turned off long before a crucial maneuver and had nothing to do with the ship's grounding.

title: Aetna Life & Casualty reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $28 million, or 25 cents a share and $109 million, or 97 cents a share, of net realized capital gains for the quarter and year, respectively, and extraordinary tax benefits of $22 million, or 20 cents a share for the quarter and $37 million, or 33 cents a share for the year, both from the utilization of net operating loss carryforwards. c-Included $1 million of net realized capital losses for the quarter and $31 million, or 27 cents a share, of net realized capital gains for the year, and an extraordinary tax benefit of $14 million, or 12 cents a share, from the utilization of net operating loss carryforwards for both the quarter and year. The company said catastrophe losses reduced results in the latest year by $170 million, compared with $31 million in 1988. Catastrophe losses, principally from the severe December freeze and the October earthquake in California, reduced fourth quarter 1989 net income by $66 million, compared with $8 million last year. Charges to 1988 results for incurred losses for prior accident years in the commercial property-casualty businesses were substantially higher than in 1989. Results for 1988 also reflected a previously announced $45 million special charge related to Aetna's insurance obligations to A.H. Robins Co. The company said results for 1988 have been restated to include the effect of the first quarter 1989 adoption of statement of Financial Accounting Standards (FAS) No. 97, accounting and reporting by insurance enterprises for certain long-duration contracts and for realized capital gains and losses from the sale of investments.

title: DEMOCRATS PRESS ELECTION CHANGE
description: California, which has the richest block of Presidential delegates, moved closer today to becoming the first large state to vote in the 1992 Presidential primaries, drastically reshaping the way nominees are chosen.

title: I.B.M. Making A 386 Chip
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said today that it was making its own version of the Intel Corporation's 386 microprocessor under a license from Intel and had begun shipping some Model 70 computers containing the chip.

title: Bill to Limit Takeovers
description: A Pennsylvania bill that is considered the nation's toughest antitakeover measure faces a new round of debate Thursday in the State Legislature.

title: CBS Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary losses from extinguishment of debt of $600,000 and $800,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $3 million and $869,600,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and losses from extinguishment of debt of $3 million for the quarter and $3.1 million for the year. The company said the income from discontinued operations is primarily from sale of CBS Records.

title: World Bank's Global Bonds
description: The World Bank said it would price today its second $1.5 billion issue of global bonds. The offering will be made simultaneously in the Euromarkets and in the domestic markets of the United States and Japan.

title: The Score at Ottawa
description: The astonishing Soviet willingness to accede to Western demands, seen once again in the Ottawa agreements on German unification and on conventional forces in Europe, is a mixed but on the whole positive political blessing for President Bush.

title: CBS Earnings Rose 48.4% in Quarter
description: CBS Inc. said yesterday that its earnings rose by 48.4 percent in the fourth quarter of last year.

title: Crash of Indian Airlines Plane Kills 89
description: A new Indian Airlines plane, flying for less than two months in this country, crashed today in the southern city of Bangalore, killing at least 89 people. About 50 survivors were reported taken to hospitals from the fiery crash site.

title: Federal-Mogul reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss on extinguishment of debt of $1,722,000.

title: Mandela's Day: Exercise and Uproar
description: When Nelson Mandela awoke about 5 A.M. today in his matchbox of a home at 8115 Vilakazi Street, he did his exercises as he did every morning in prison.

title: McDermott International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax benefits of $3,257,000, or 9 cents a share, for the quarter and $12,492,000, or 33 cents a share, for the 9 months, and after income from discontinued operations of $79,178,000, or $2.11 a share, for the quarter and $81,215,000, or $2.17 a share, for the 9 months. c-Net loss and included tax benefits of $3,322,000, or 9 cents a share, for the quarter and $3,157,000, or 8 cents a share, for the 9 months, and after income of $4,577,000, or 12 cents a share, for the quarter and a loss of $21,061,000 for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations. Results for the year-ago quarter have been restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Courage in Colombia
description: President Bush journeys today to what may be the most security-conscious ''summit meeting'' in history: a six-hour conference on drug trafficking at a heavily guarded naval base in Colombia. To assure his safety, hundreds of undercover agents worked the streets, bars and beaches of nearby Cartagena, frogmen searched the waters offshore for explosives, and handlers of Presidential aircraft tuned up their defenses against shoulder-fired missiles.

title: Money-Fund Yields Mixed
description: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the week that ended yesterday, as tax-exempt funds dipped slightly and taxables were unchanged.

title: WPL Holdings Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Mrs. Michaelis Wed in Alabama
description: Marianne Michaelis, a former public relations executive in New York City, was married yesterday in Mobile, Ala., to Edwin A. Zelnicker Jr., an insurance executive. Rabbi Donald M. Kunstadt performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's home.

title: Monument to '73 War: An Egyptian Alamo?
description: The man with his wife and two children said he had come to show his family how it had been that day in October 1973 when the Arabs went to war with Israel, and he had been in their ranks.

title: ADVERTISING;   Hal Riney Gets Carvel Account
description: After a run of 35 years, the Carvel Corporation is hanging up Tom Carvel's voice. The ice-cream store chain selected Hal Riney & Partners yesterday to handle its advertising and said future ads would no longer feature the gravelly narration of Mr. Carvel, 84, who founded the company in 1934.

title: Flavian Dougherty, 77, Led Passionist Priests
description: The Rev. Flavian Dougherty, a Roman Catholic priest who formerly headed the Passionist Congregation in the eastern province of the United States, died of cancer on Monday at New York University Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived until recently in Chicago.

title: Texaco Tree Plan
description: Texaco Inc., one of the nation's oil giants, announced a $1 million program to plant trees this spring to start private-sector involvement in President Bush's ''America the Beautiful'' program. James W. Kinnear, Texaco's president, said the money would be shared by Denver, Houston and New Orleans, where the company has extensive operations.

title: Southwestern Energy Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Electric Cars Coming In the Next Few Years
description: To the Editor:

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: Name almost any ailment and you can be sure that some green plant is purported to cure or alleviate the condition.

title: 4th Arrested in Slaying and Girl's Abduction
description: A fourth man was arrested this morning in the killing of a father and the abduction of his daughter in what the authorities described as a drug dispute, Rockland County District Attorney Kenneth Gribetz said.

title: Arthur H. Goldberg, 84, Is Dead; Judge in New York Criminal Court
description: Arthur Henry Goldberg, a retired judge in New York City Criminal Court and an expert on the city's government, died of respiratory failure on Monday at the Pine Rest Nursing Home in Paramus, N.J. He was 84 years old and had lived in Stony Brook, L.I., and Manhattan before moving to the nursing home a year ago.

title: Xylogics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
U.S.-Korea Trade Plan
description: Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher and South Korea's Minister of Trade and Industry, Han Seung Soo, signed an agreement Tuesday to create a joint committee on commercial cooperation intended to expand trade and reduce friction. The committee will develop opportunities for cooperation in trade and investment, and exchange technical information and data on mutually beneficial development projects. ''Our ability to address areas of potential cooperation will lead not only to expanded trade, but reduced friction,'' Mr. Mosbacher said.

title: P.S.C. Releases Phone Audit
description: The New York State Public Service Commission released a staff audit yesterday that found that the New York Telephone Company had paid excessive charges to the purchasing division of its parent company, the Nynex Corporation, for the removal of phone equipment. The audit said the Nynex purchasing division had overcharged New York Telephone by as much as $28 million.

title: Currents;   Now, Hot Coffee in a Warm Cup
description: FOR coffee aficionados, the best if freshly made and piping hot. Le Petit Cafe is a pot and set of cups that sit on the stove top. When the cofee is ready, it pours directly into the cups, which are also warm.

title: Upheaval in the East: Soviet Union;   SOVIET LEGISLATORS LOOK FOR ANSWERS
description: The Soviet Parliament opened its third session today with passionate speeches on the nation's violent ethnic unrest, intensifying separatism and general economic crisis.

title: U.S. Vehicle Sales Up 8.2% in 10-Day Period
description: Sales of American-made cars and light trucks were stronger than expected in early February, leading some automotive analysts to suggest that the industry may be emerging from a four-month sales slump.

title: Washington Talk;   Moynihan Befuddles Democrats With Idea
description: When Democrats don't know what to do, they form a task force. The latest one includes all the top party leaders and committee chairmen from the Senate and the House. It is supposed to decide how the party should respond to Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's plan to lower the Social Security tax.

title: Review/Cabaret;   Portrait Of Composer In Songs From Shows
description: Few pop songs capture more vividly the queasy sense that one never completely recovers from the minor traumas of high school than Craig Carnelia's ''The Kid Inside,'' whose narrator confesses that he still goes around ''righting ancient wrongs and humming old hit songs.''

description: The Voyager 1 spacecraft sent radio signals to Earth today indicating that it had successfully snapped pictures of most of the planets to create the first family portrait of the solar system, the space agency said.

title: Guard to Be Charged in Escape

Two of the inmates from the Joliet Correctional Center were captured, one shortly after the escape and another on Wednesday. Two guards will be suspended, and the department will ask Will County prosecutors to bring charges, yet to be determined, against one of them, officials said.

title: Neiman Marcus

The store will be the Dallas-based retailer's second in the New York area and 24th location in the nation. The first area store opened in White Plains in 1980. A third New York area store is scheduled to open in Paramus, N.J., and sites in Denver, Minneapolis and Cleveland are being pursued, Neiman Marcus said.

title: De Klerk Policy Condemned At White Rally in Pretoria

description: The governing body of the African National Congress is meeting here this week to develop a response to reforms announced by President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa and to determine what role Nelson Mandela will play in the organization.

title: New Champ Still Waits For Respect
description: Inside the Home Box Office studios on East 23d Street, the new world heavyweight champion, James (Buster) Douglas, had been waiting for more than half an hour. Waiting for Mike Tyson and Don King to arrive for yesterday's videotaping of tonight's cable television show dissecting their Tokyo title fight. And now, standing on the sidewalk in the raw, rainy chill outside the front door, the new champion's manager, John Johnson, looked around. ''Did King and Tyson get here yet?'' he asked. ''They didn't come through this door,'' he was told. ''What's holding us up again is Mike Tyson.'' John Johnson was understandably annoyed. He and the world heavyweight champion had been on time. The ex-champion and his promoter would arrive about 45 minutes late after their limo stopped at the wrong HBO building. But despite the transfer of the title, Johnson was standing on the sidewalk in the chill, just as he and Douglas were kept out in the chill before and after the fight. ''They didn't think,'' Johnson was saying now of King and the promoter's people, ''that they had to treat us with respect.''

Results are in U.S. dollars; quarterly translation of income items to dollars is achieved by translating the sterling pound results for the cumulative period of the year at the average rate for that period and deducting therefrom the amount calculated for the previous cumulative peroid. The latest quarter and year results were translated at the exchange rates of $1.59 and $1.64, respectively, and the year-ago quarter and year results were translated at the exchange rate of $1.79 and $1.78, respectively. The results represented replacement cost net income and is calculated after tax and interest expense, and before extraodinary items, but it excluded inventory holding gains and losses. It uses a current cost method of inventory valuation.

Revenue for the period totaled $832 million.

Review/Art;   An 18-Year Journey Through Rauschenberg's Development
description: Robert Rauschenberg's art is so diverse that sometimes it is easy to lose sight of his achievement. He once turned his bed, red quilt and all, into a painting that now hangs in the Museum of Modern Art. He has made ''combines,'' as he calls his painting-sculpture hybrids, using such unlikely items as a stuffed eagle or a stuffed goat with a car tire around its middle. In the early 1950's, he exhibited blank white canvases, and in recent years he has turned to photography.

title: Review/Dance;   Balanchine and Mendelssohn
description: It has been said that George Balanchine was drawn to the creation of ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' by the music of Felix Mendelssohn. Balanchine eventually used the composer's overture and incidental music to the Shakespeare play and other, more obscure Mendelssohn scores for his ballet. Balanchine's first act follows the Shakespeare play with fidelity. But the ballet has never seemed all that heartfelt a response to the score or the story. It is a strange hybrid, really, two ballets in one with a few surprisingly incongruous touches. And the New York City Ballet's performance of the work on Wednesday evening at the New York State Theater was a decently danced but generally dull affair, both onstage and from the orchestra pit, that failed to make up for the ballet's peculiarities.

title: Role in Trump v. Trump is a New One For a Lawyer Steeped in Social and Political Issues

title: Review/Theater;   Tyrannical As Ever, 'Margarida' Returns
description: In the 12 years since Miss Margarida held her first class in New York City, demanding blind obedience to her tyrannical rule, dictators have fallen and a dissident playwright has become president of his country. After cataclysmic historical events, seeing Estelle Parsons in ''Miss Margarida's Way'' in 1990 is like encountering an obstreperous figure from the past, a black sheep returning for a family gathering. As the actress plays the character -should she now be called Ms. Margarida? - it is the comic element of the performance that is principally asserted. The revival of the Roberto Athayde play opened last night at the Helen Hayes Theater.

description: A commuter train bound from New York City to Bay Head, N.J., struck a car at a crossing in Holmdel, N.J., last evening, killing the car's driver, the police said. None of the 475 passengers aboard the N.J. Transit train were injured, but a dozen southbound trains were delayed up to two hours and three northbound trains up to an hour, said Sgt. Alfonse Imperiale of the N.J. Transit Police in Newark.

description: DESPITE the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation's decision to auction itself to the highest bidder, analysts and industry experts predict that the giant paper producer will most likely be acquired by its unwanted suitor, the Georgia-Pacific Corporation.

title: Profits Fall At Ford And G.M.
description: The nation's two biggest auto makers, the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company, posted significant declines in earnings for the fourth quarter and the year, reflecting the softness in auto sales and their costly incentive programs for buyers. Ford's results also reflect the sale of the company's Rouge Steel subsidiary in the fourth quarter.

title: New Hiring Plan Shifts Talk to Race and Images
description: The way Howard Thomas sees it, he is not simply a principal but a black principal. And he thinks that makes a world of difference in how the students at Junior High School 74 in the South Bronx respond to him and perceive themselves.

title: Seoul Agrees on Withdrawal of Some Troops
description: In talks with Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney, the South Korean Defense Minister today accepted in principle the gradual withdrawal of about 5,000 noncombatants from the American force of more than 43,000 soldiers in South Korea.

title: Panama Sets Bank Fines
description: Banks that cooperate in the laundering of drug money will face fines of between $100,000 and $1 million for abusing Panama's banking secrecy laws, Panama's Second Vice President, Guillermo Ford, said today.

title: Nets Lose Track of Players as Skid Hits 12
description: When the second half started tonight, the Nets had only four players on the court. Charles Shackleford, the starting power forward, was in the locker room with an upset stomach, and the Net bench had forgotten to replace him in the lineup.

Most of the writedown, $837,447, occurred in the fourth quarter.
