title: Holyfield Camp Asks First Call if Rematch Stalls
description: If the new heavyweight champion, James (Buster) Douglas, does not really intend to fight again until September, then his mandatory challenger, Evander Holyfield, wants to be the first to fight him, Dan Duva, Holyfield's promoter, said yesterday.

title: Profits Scoreboard
Review/Film;   Following Heidi Through Love and War
description: ''So! Who has a song for us?'' Peter asks Heidi and her schoolgirl chums in a scene from ''Courage Mountain.'' ''We can't have a campfire without a song or a poem!'' Will anyone be surprised to find Charlie Sheen playing cheerleader here in the role of Heidi's stalwart swain? They should be. Both the actor and the film seem to have taken a step backward in time, back to the days when adventure films for young audiences did not involve dance competitions, video games or the kinds of personal triumphs that lead to unanticipated fame.

Review/Pop;   A World Dancing as It Dies
description: In ''Rhythm of Life,'' the most powerful cut on Hugh Harris's recent debut album, ''Words for Our Years,'' the 24-year-old English singer and songwriter accomplishes something that many pop figures have run aground while attempting. Stringing together images of disaster and ecstasy - of houses burning, of making love ''by the light of the bombs'' - he creates a richly charged vision of the world in all its turbulence, dancing and dying at the same time.

title: Review/Music;   Jeffrey Siegel and Ruth Laredo Offer Words With Music
description: Conventional wisdom in the world of classical music is that musicians should play the works on their programs without commenting on them, and that historical, biographical and analytical information should be confined to the program book.

Under the homestead exemption, the first $25,000 of the assessed value of a primary residence is not taxed. There is no additional $5,000 exemption for owners who are 65 or older.

It was a sad time for the oldest existing theatrical house in Times Square, a theater between Seventh and Eighth Avenues that was built by the stage impresario Oscar Hammerstein in 1899.

description: You're unemployed. What kind of help do you want from your Government? How about unemployment insurance that starts high but falls over time? The benefits would remain high if you enrolled in a training program but drop to zero if you refused legitimate job offers.

The 101 broker-dealer funds rose $43.1 million, to $164.46 billion.

title: Review/Art;   Peace, Purity and Energy In Still Lifes by Morandi
description: The exhibition of 16 still lifes by Giorgio Morandi (1890-1964) at the Philippe Daverio Gallery comes at an ideal moment. Against the backdrop of a contemporary art scene in which money, bombast and irony have reigned for a decade, Morandi's example of abstemiousness and monklike dedication to the humblest of tasks is another reminder that art need not be big and brash to make its mark, nor must it be entirely made over from one season to the next, like the latest couture collections.

description: THOSE who had hoped that the observance of photography's first 150 years would occasion a re-evaluation of the medium's place in the world (and in the world of art) can take heart. ''Photography Until Now,'' the Museum of Modern Art's slightly tardy survey of the last century and a half of picture making, is an original, discerning and sometimes surprising show that challenges the public understanding of what the art of photography really is.

title: The Citadel Rejects a Woman
description: The first woman to apply for admission to the corps of cadets at the Citadel has been rejected. The Justice Department recently ordered Virginia Military Institute, the nation's only other state-supported military academy, to admit women or face a lawsuit. Virginia has challenged the order. Since the Citadel was founded 148 years ago, no woman has been admitted to the 2,000-member corps of cadets. The identity of the rejected woman was not disclosed.

Burke said the earliest Lemieux could play would be next Tuesday against Philadelphia.

title: A Law to Light the Darkest Cell
description: No government admits to torture. Indeed, the worst sinners joined in the unanimous General Assembly vote in 1984 that approved a United Nations convention against this ugly practice. Already ratified by 41 countries, the treaty is now before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Should the U.S. join in what may seem a ritual avowal of virtue? Would doing so have practical value? The answer is doubly yes.

description: Does New York State's education curriculum adequately reflect the rich complexity of American society? No, says State Education Commissioner Thomas Sobol. He wants to develop a new multicultural curriculum to increase student awareness of the history and culture of America's ethnic and racial groups and ''other peoples throughout the world.'' Mr. Sobol will seek approval for this thoroughly sensible proposal at a meeting today with the Board of Regents.

title: Mandela Sees Basis for Talks on Power Sharing

description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that the city and state would commit a total of $200 million to develop a park along the Hudson River.

title: Review/Film;   Where Monitors Are Stars, And People Merely Props
description: ''Speaking Parts'' was shown as part of the 1989 New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 29. The film opens today at the Bleecker Street Cinema, at La Guardia Place Video monitors preside eerily over virtually every scene in the Canadian director Atom Egoyan's ''Speaking Parts,'' giving the film its chilly high-tech cachet. In a board room, an absent film executive dominates his employees by means of a giant screen. In her solitary apartment, a spooky, lovelorn woman makes her VCR the centerpiece of a shrine. An ambitious actor says one thing while beside him, on a monitor playing his audition tape, he is seen and heard saying something else. In a very modern mausoleum, a woman mournfully watches the deceased on videotape.

title: The Economic Ripples Of a German Union
description: The prospect of a rapid economic union of West and East Germany is sending jitters through European and other bond markets, pushing interest rates higher.

title: TV Weekend;   A Life of Grace in Motion: Dame Margot Fonteyn Looks Back
description: With unflagging propriety and shrewd selectivity, not to mention perfectly exquisite posture, Dame Margot Fonteyn is providing tonight's presentation of ''Great Performances'' with an enchanting autobiography. ''The Margot Fonteyn Story,'' produced and directed by Patricia Foy for Britain's Channel 4, was filmed last year as part of a 70th-birthday tribute. The 90-minute program will be shown at 9 P.M. on Channel 13.

title: Union Uses Students In Tenure Dispute, Fernandez Contends
description: The New York City Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez, accused the city's principals union today of ''using kids to push their legislative agenda'' of insuring that principals retain tenure in their schools.

title: ADVANCE REPORTED IN LEUKEMIA TESTS
description: Researchers have produced a mouse that suffers from a form of human leukemia, giving scientists a new way to test therapies for treatment of the disease.

title: Near-Misses Again Plague Stadler
description: Craig Stadler has gone without a victory on the PGA Tour since the 1984 Byron Nelson Classic, but none of his near-misses over the last several years were as agonizing to watch as his putting debacle at last week's Hawaiian Open in Honolulu.

title: Public Must Wait to Hear Reagan on Iran-Contra
description: A Federal district judge today barred news organizations and the public from being present Friday when former President Ronald Reagan is questioned under oath for the first time about his role in the Iran-contra affair. But the judge agreed to make public an edited videotape within several days.

title: CHRONICLE
description: High-flying American financiers meet members of a British Parliamentary team next week in a megabridge game in London. The American players include ALAN C. (ACE) GREENBERG and JAMES E. CAYNE, the chairman and the president, respectively, of the Bear Stearns Companies. The two play in a regular big-money game at the Regency Club in New York with MILTON J. PETRIE, the chairman of of Petrie Stores, and LAURENCE A. TISCH, the chairman of CBS, who are also to play against the British.

title: Review/Opera;   Domingo and Verrett in 'Samson et Dalila'
description: No sensible person has ever made great claims for ''Samson et Dalila'' as a great work of art. Its musical and dramatic weaknesses are so obvious that the wonder is how Saint-Saens's once-popular opera could possibly continue to interest a modern audience. Like most inferior operas, it requires the tenderest treatment if it is to succeed. Indeed, despite the puissance suggested by the male hero's name, ''Samson'' is a work of quivering vulnerability, easily crushed by performers who do not understand or cannot convey its period charm. And yet there it stands, still a pillar (if a dangerously thin one) of the opera repertory, thanks to several durable arias.

title: How the First Ladies Dressed for the Ball
description: Edith Wilson's inaugural dress was black velvet and had an eight-foot train studded with sequins. Nancy Reagan's was covered with rhinestones and crystal beads and had one bare shoulder. Grace Coolidge is represented by a short red-velvet ''flapper'' design.

title: Appeals Court Frees Inmate on Hunger Strike
description: A prisoner who had been on a hunger strike for nearly a year to protest his conviction on drug charges has been freed by order of the Michigan Court of Appeals.

title: Coca-Cola to Raise Dividend by 18%
description: The Coca-Cola Company, enjoying a strong global beverage business, raised the quarterly dividend on its common stock by 18 percent and said its board would recommend a 2-for-1 stock split at its annual meeting. Coke's shares rose sharply in on the New York Stock Exchange today, closing at $69.50, up $2.375 each.

description: A 35-hour occupation of Vassar College's main administration offices by students accusing Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of making a racial remark after a lecture on campus ended tonight after the administration agreed to hear student demands.

description: A newspaper article on a potential takeover deal supposedly based on comments made by the president of the First Chicago Corporation was a hoax, the bank said today.

title: Jackson Meets Mandela
description: Nelson Mandela met the Rev. Jackson today on the final day of Mr. Jackson's eight-day visit. ''The misnomer around the world is that Mandela is free,'' Mr. Jackson said. ''That is not true. Mandela is out of jail. He is not free. We must not lower the standards of democracy or expectations for democracy in South Africa.''

title: Fewer Jobless in Britain
description: Unemployment in Britain fell by 23,200 people in January, to a provisional 5.7 percent of the work force, the Government said today. The seasonally adjusted figures showed unemployment at its lowest since October 1980, the year after Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher came to power. The improvement in the unemployment number was tempered, however, by data showing that December's annual rate of increase in average earnings was 9.25 percent, the same as November's. The Conservative Government wants to keep wages down in its battle against inflation, which is now about 7.7 percent.

title: Slain Girl's Parents Shaken as Trial Starts
description: For a year, Richard Tinyes has said, he has not wanted to hear the full story of his daughter's death. But today he and his wife sat in a courtroom and listened as a prosecutor described 13-year-old Kelly Ann Tinyes when investigators found her in a neighbor's house in Valley Stream last March.

The loans were being sold at par value. The loans will be acquired by Canadian Imperial in a three-step financing process. Payments are scheduled to begin next month and are to be completed by April 30.

The food can be as inspiring as the setting.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 17, 1990
description: The Economy

title: Critic's Notebook;   TV's Sizzling News: To Top It All, the Trumps!
description: So now it's the Trumps, the latest sizzler on New York's fast-news griddle. The local news programs have been putting out a juicy menu lately. The trial of Leona Helmsley was followed by the trial of John Gotti and the case of Dr. Veronica Prego, which is being accompanied by the case of Donald and Ivana Trump. Although lacking the bullet holes and bodies that generally enliven the screens between 5 P.M. and 6:30 or 7, and then again at 11, these stories abound in socko elements, tested in tabloids down the years.

title: The Homeless are Dying in the Subway
description: LEAD: The homeless are dying in the New York City subway. Last December alone, 14 died there. For all of 1989, the total was 79; the deaths include 15 people crushed by trains, 11 suicides, 4 at the hands of criminals and 9 through electrocution and other accidents. In recent years, the number who have died in the subway has increased substantially: in 1987, 30; in 1988, 77.

St. Louis-based Ralston said it believes the deal with Agro-Industrial Union of Hajdusag is the first between an American company and an Eastern European farm cooperative. Terms were not disclosed.

Southwestern Bell to End Test of Data 'Gateway' Offer
description: The Southwestern Bell Corporation said yesterday that it plans to end its test offering of a ''public information gateway'' that allows computer users to tap into a variety of data bases by dialing one number from a telephone line.

title: Choreography Winners
description: Four winners have been announced in the Boston International Choreography Competition sponsored by the Boston Ballet. Rick McCullough was awarded the gold medal and a cash prize of $3,000 for ''Others Because . . .,'' set to Prokofiev's first violin concerto. Bonnie Scheibman won the silver medal and $2,000 for ''Moon Roses,'' set to music by Bruce Novack. And William Whitener and Antony Rizzi received bronze medals, with a cash award of $1,000 each. The competition was created in 1978 by E. Virginia Williams, the founder of the company.

title: Upheaval in the East: East Germany;   Small East Berlin Parties Seek to Postpone Unity
description: In what many members view as a rear-guard campaign unlikely to halt rapid reunification of the Germanys, three political movements presented an election program today to preserve the independence of East Germany until it can negotiate unity on more equal terms.

title: Miners Cheered by Contract's Terms
description: About 2,000 miners and their wives gave Richard L. Trumka, president of the United Mine Workers of America, an emotional standing ovation here today, leaving little doubt how they feel about the contract he negotiated and the prospect of going back to work after 10 months of walking picket lines and living on $225-a-week strike pay.

title: Devils' Scoring Slump Continues
description: The play that unfolded with 90 seconds left in the opening period of the game between the Devils and the Rangers tonight exemplified New Jersey's recent scoring woes.

title: Draft Law for Chinese Rule Stirs Protest in Hong Kong
description: A committee in Beijing today ratified its final version of the constitution that will govern Hong Kong after the Chinese takeover in 1997, prompting an outcry from liberal and moderate politicians and angry protests by several thousand college students.

title: KEY RATES
BABY IS CONCEIVED TO SAVE DAUGHTER
description: A middle-aged couple from a Los Angeles suburb have conceived a child solely in hopes that the baby's bone marrow cells will save the life of a teen-age daughter who is dying of cancer.

title: Pentech International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Judge in Jury Trial Orders Northrop to Halt TV Ads
description: A Federal judge presiding over a criminal fraud trial involving the Northrop Corporation has ordered the company temporarily to stop showing television commercials here because they could taint the impartiality of prospective jurors. The Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit in San Francisco later suspended the order, pending further review, a Northrop attorney said.

title: Analog Devices reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: The company said the latest quarter's net income was negatively impacted by a $4.9 million non-operating loss, largely due to an additional reserve taken against the ADE Venture Capital portfolio.

title: Review/Film;   The Bothersome Relatives Who Pay Visits and Stay
description: The fine art of relative-bashing, recently practiced in films like ''The War of the Roses'' and ''National Lampoon's Christmas,'' gets another go-round in ''Madhouse,'' a cheerfully mean-spirited comedy written and directed by Tom Ropelewski. It presents Kirstie Alley and John Larroquette as Jessie and Mark Bannister, yuppie lovebirds who have ''Hers'' and ''Mine'' license plates and have just moved into a quiet new house.

title: EXILED OPPOSITION TO SEND A PANEL TO MEET DE KLERK
description: The governing body of the African National Congress said today that it would send a delegation to South Africa ''as soon as possible'' to meet with President F. W. de Klerk in an attempt to remove obstacles to opening talks with Pretoria.

title: Theodore Karl Himelstein, Surgeon, 83
description: Dr. Theodore Karl Himelstein, an orthopedic surgeon and an educator in Manhattan for 50 years, died of a heart attack on Tuesday at Good Samaritan Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Held in Killing, 43 Unremarkable Years Later
description: When the two Miami police detectives seized Leroy Strachan on a Manhattan street on Thursday, he told them that he had expected it, that it was only a matter of time before they would catch up with him, they said. He was wanted for the murder of a police officer in Miami 43 years ago.

description: The Federal Election Commission said today that it would accept a judge's ruling that it improperly dismissed a complaint against a Republican Party fund-raising group.

title: Prison for Pit Bull's Owner
description: The owner of a pit bull that fatally mauled a 2-year-old child who wandered within reach of the chained dog was sentenced in Santa Clara County Superior Court today to 3 years 8 months in prison. The 39-year-old defendant, Michael Patrick Berry, was convicted in December of involuntary manslaughter and three lesser charges in the death of the child, James Soto. Prosecutors said Mr. Berry had used the dog to protect a crop of marijuana plants in his backyard.

description: With White House backing, the Food and Drug Administration is proposing new rules to halt the proliferation of false or misleading claims on food packages. It's a welcome turnaround. In 1987 the Reagan Administration killed a similar plan, inviting a torrent of deceptive dietary babble.

title: Boeing, McDonnell Seek Chinese Deal
description: The Boeing Company hopes to join China in a project to build 150 airplanes, but a competitor, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, is also in the running, said Dean D. Thornton, the president of Boeing Commercial Airplanes. ''We are in serious talks with China as is McDonnell Douglas,'' he said.

title: Equitable Life Assurance Society of U.S.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The net income figures represented total income. Statutory earnings for 1989 were $126 million, compared with $190 million for 1988. Earnings for 1989 included a $111 million allocation to the Mandatory Securities Valuation Reserve (MSVR) and a $15 million increase in statutory surplus. The MSVR is a reserve required for all life insurance companies to provide for possible future losses on investment securities. Net investment income for the latest year totaled $4,311,600,000, compared with $4,542,700,000 for 1988.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Washington's Birthday will be observed on Monday. Here are holiday schedules.

title: Herald of Trump Trouble Is Sorry for 'Media Circus'
description: Liz Smith, the gossip columnist who broke the story of the breakup of Donald and Ivana Trump's marriage, said yesterday that the story had degenerated into ''a media circus'' and that ''I have been one of its performers.''

title: Masco Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said its l989 and fourth-quarter earnings decline were primarily caused by continued economic softening in a number of its markets, fourth-quarter reserves and charges related to planned sales and restructuring of certain operation, a reduction in equity earnings, as well as costs related to capital improvement program.

title: Mechanical Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Net income and after income from discontinued operations of $259,000, or 7 cents a share. Year-ago period reflected change in method of accounting for income taxes.

title: Masked 'Florists' Take Rugs And Jewelry From a Home
description: Four men wearing ski masks and a woman companion who had pretended to be delivering flowers forced their way into a house in the exclusive Forest Hills Gardens section of Queens yesterday afternoon and stole a safe containing about $1 million worth of jewels, as well as antique rugs valued at $150,000, the police said.

title: Omni Films Intl reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Upheaval in the East;   Romania Defense Chief Resigns After Protests
description: Defense Minister Nicolae Militaru, criticized for trying to disrupt the revolution that ousted Nicolae Ceausescu two months ago, resigned today. He was the third Cabinet officer to resign in three weeks.

title: A Computer Star's New Advance
description: Nine months after the brilliant and reclusive Seymour Cray split from the company he founded and began anew in the hills here, his business has produced a breakthrough in its effort to design the next generation of the world's fastest computers, known as supercomputers.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Shakeup in Poland's Media
description: One-third of the managers and directors of state radio and television have been replaced and the pro-Solidarity broadcast chief plans a full reorganization this spring, the newspaper Gazeta Wyborcza reported today. Most of the new management people are former television journalists and directors ousted when martial law was imposed in December 1981.

title: Would -Be Refugee Describes His Vietnamese Round Trip
description: Le Van Kim, once a fisherman, sat in the house of a charitable friend and bemoaned his fate.

title: Owens & Minor Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
As Election Nears, Japanese Consider a New Notion: Coalition
description: With Japan's scandal-tainted Liberal Democratic Party expected to win a bare parliamentary majority in the elections on Sunday, a new term has started working its way into the political talk here: coalition.

title: Corrections
description: A film review in Weekend yesterday about ''Speaking Parts'' misidentified the theater where it is playing. It is the Quad Cinema, on 13th Street west of Fifth Avenue, not the Bleecker Street Cinema.

title: F.D.I.C. Suit In Suits Unit Failure
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said yesterday that it had sued Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. and two former executives of a Texas savings and loan association, accusing them of fraud in a complex scheme to help finance a corporate takeover.

title: Fiat and Poland In Car Agreement
description: Fiat S.p.A., Italy's auto giant, said it had signed a preliminary agreement to produce a midsize car in Poland. Fiat won the agreement after nearly three years of talks and competition with Japan's Daihatsu Motor Company. The value of the deal was not disclosed.

title: Interhome Energy reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $14.4 million, or 37 cents a share, for the latest year and $16.2 million, or 41 cents a share, for 1988, both from the sale of investment in Sovereign Oil and Gas Plc. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Rail Link to Airport
description: To the Editor:

title: Hewlett-Packard Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
I.R.A. INVESTMENTS
description: Even with changes in the tax laws, Inidividual Retirement Accounts remain one of the best investments for later years. While contributions may not be deductible for some, taxes on all the earnings are deferred until the holder retires. A world of caution comes from bank analysts, who note that a growing number of institutions are adding charges to I.R.A. CD will be more difficult this year. Here are the highest yields available nationwide of Feb. 13 on federally insured certificates of desposits: $ Certificates of Deposit Annual Minimum Yield Deposit One-year CD: 8.88% $500 Bank of New England, Boston 18-month CD: 8.88% 500 Bank of New England Five-year CD: 8.84% 1,500 The Bank Mart, Trumbull, Conn.

title: International American Homes Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income of $800,000, or 11 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting. c-Net income The latest quarter and 9 months included a charge for asset writedowns of after-tax $8.9 million relating principally to land, land deposits and investments in and advances to partnerships. Latest 9 months included $1,350,000, or 19 cents a share, from the sale of investment land, compared with $700,000, or 9 cents a share, in the year-ago period.

title: 76ers Get By With 4 Overtime Points, 100-96
description: Rick Mahorn and Johnny Dawkins had two free throws apiece - the only points in the extra period - as the Philadelphia 76ers won with the lowest-scoring overtime period in National Basketball Association history tonight, 100-96, over the Seattle SuperSonics.

title: Late Program Selling Trims Dow by 13.96
description: A late wave of program selling depressed blue-chip stocks yesterday in slow trading preceding a holiday weekend.

title: All Patent Cases Are Essentially Political
description: To the Editor:

title: Beliefs
description: After three decades of sustained interfaith dialogue among America's Roman Catholics, Protestants and Jews, the borders of most religious groups are largely undefended, and no one is massing troops along them. Compared with the bitter Catholic-Protestant conflicts of, say, the 1950's, today's occasional quarrels look more like customs disputes than full-scale belligerency.

title: Poland's Foreign Lenders Accept Unusual Extension of Payments
description: The United States, West Germany and other major Polish creditors showed support for the Solidarity-led Government today by extending the payment deadlines for $9.4 billion of Poland's hard-currency debt on unusually lenient terms.

title: Georgia Gulf Rejects Offer
description: The Georgia Gulf Corporation rejected a $1.1 billion buyout offer from NL Industries, saying the $45-a-share bid was too low.

title: H.R.A. Dismisses Priest in Inquiry
description: The Rev. John Mario, a priest whose credentials have been questioned in recent weeks, was dismissed yesterday as an official with the New York City Human Resources Administration.

title: Inside
description: Big Trade Improvement

title: Medical Properties reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Action Auto Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Moral Guidance Is a Catholic Prelate's Duty;   Oil on the Flames
description: To the Editor:

title: Moral Guidance Is a Catholic Prelate's Duty;   Kennedy's Own Words
description: To the Editor:

title: Explaining Lights to the Driver Behind
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about a plan for talks on German reunification misstated the origin of the proposal.

title: Texas Utilities reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
New York City Settles a Suit On Stun-Gun Abuse by Police
description: New York City yesterday settled the first of several civil suits brought against it by people who were tortured with an electronic stun gun while prisoners at a police station in Queens.

title: Vincent Ashton, 72, Insurance Executive
description: Vincent J. Ashton, an insurance and advertising executive, died of congestive heart failure on Wednesday at Wyckoff Heights Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 72 years old and lived in Robinwood, L.I.

title: British Airways reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results are in U.S. dollars and had been converted at the exchange rate of a pound sterling equals $1.61 for the latest periods, compared with $1.81 for the year-ago quarter and 9 months. Share earnings represented American Depositary Shares (ADS) and each ADS equals 10 U.K. ordinary shares.

title: Owners Want an Agreement, Fehr Says
description: Negotiators for baseball's club owners and players did not emerge from their four-hour meeting yesterday waving a labor agreement, but the players' chief spokesman brandished what he said was a prerequisite to one: the perception that the owners seriously want a settlement.

title: Patents;   A WAtch to Ease Jet Lag
description: Ross E. Mitchell, an inventor in Newtonville, Mass., obtained a patent this week for a watch to help travelers fight jet lag by making time fly. Mr. Mitchell noted that travelers arriving in a different time zone normally switched to the new time in an abrupt and disorienting way. His new watch is designed to smooth this transition by spreading the adjustment over the flight. A traveler leaving Los Angeles for New York, for example, would program the scheduled flight time and the number of time zones to cross, and the watch would speed up to cover nine hours in a six-hour flight. When the plane lands, the inventor said, the watch returns to its regular speed.

title: Property Capital Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a $13.4 million gain from the sale of investments.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''God has rewarded you for all your suffering'' - The Rev. Jesse Jackson, speaking to Sam Nujoma, Namibia's first President. [7:6.]

title: Fire Kills 2 Who Saved Their Children
description: A mother and father died in a fire early yesterday morning in Brooklyn after the mother desperately squeezed their four children under a window gate that had been illegally wired shut, fire officials said.

title: Baltimore Gas & Electric Co. reports earnings for 12mo to Jan 31
Red Cross Delegates Pay Their First Visit To Noriega in Prison
description: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the deposed Panamanian leader, today received his first prison visit from the Red Cross since the United States Government agreed to treat him as a prisoner of war.

title: Contracts for MCI
description: The MCI Communications Corporation said it had received contracts worth a total of $40 million to provide long-distance telephone services for the Defense Department and E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company. MCI said that it and the Contel Federal Systems Sector would provide a worldwide communications network for the military's medical service information system. The contract is worth $25 million over five years. Under a three-year, $15 million contract with Du Pont, MCI will provide voice and data services.

title: Coast Guard Assailed On Oil Spill Readiness
description: A California Congressman has accused the Coast Guard of overstating its readiness to deal with oil spills like the one that fouled the Pacific Coast south of Los Angeles last week.

title: Review/Film;   Taking Refuge in a Little Town of Horrors
description: If you sell enough horror novels, as Stephen King or Clive Barker do, eventually someone will let you turn them into movies and direct them yourself. This will probably be a mistake; the latest evidence is Mr. Barker's second film, ''Nightbreed.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the bombing of a refugee settlement in El Salvador misidentified the group that confirmed reports of the attack. It was the Salvadoran Red Cross, not the International Committee of the Red Cross.

title: Lamson & Sessions reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
West Virginia Toxic Leak Keeps 15,000 Inside
description: The second toxic chemical leak in two weeks at a plant considered among the most modern in the nation forced the authorities on Thursday to order 15,000 residents here to remain indoors.

title: Carlisle Cos. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a net gain of $5.9 million, or 74 cents a share, on sale of company's interest in Graham Japan Ltd., a joint venture. c-Net loss and included net charges of $7.5 million related to writeoffs of inventories and closing of a business. d-Included a net charge of $6.6 million related to writeoffs of inventories and closing of a business, and a net gain on the sale of International Wire of $900,000, or 11 cents a share.

title: Las Palomas Journal;   Pillow Talk of U.S.-Mexico Towns: What Border?
description: Any time a fire breaks out in this small town on the border with the United States, the fire department in Columbus, N.M., comes roaring across the boundary line to put out the flames.

title: Esselte Business Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income of $905,000, or 4 cents a share, from the cumulative effect on prior periods of an accounting change.

title: British Inflation at 7.7%
description: Britain's inflation rate was unchanged in January at an annual 7.7 percent for the third consecutive month. Financial markets had been expecting a lower figure after economists had predicted that the pace of rises in the retail price index, Britain's main measure of inflation, would fall to 7.5 percent. The latest figures, coming as the Chancellor of the Exchequer, John Major, prepares his 1990-91 budget, due in March, will strengthen Government arguments that high interest rates, although unpopular, must stay.

title: Magellan Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Pacific and Boston stock exchanges.

title: U.S. Seizes Franklin Savings Association
description: Federal regulators today took control of the Franklin Savings Association, a large and unorthodox savings institution based in Ottawa, Kan., with $11.4 billion in assets and close ties to Wall Street. It is now the largest savings unit in Government hands.

title: American National Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Corrections
description: A caption on the Saturday highlights page of the Television section on Sunday misstated the time and cable network for the movie ''Heathers.'' It will be shown tonight at 10 on Cinemax.

title: Will Blue Blood Succeed the Red Flag?
description: LEAD: There may be life in the mothballed monarchs yet.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Soviet Subs in Sweden
description: Every year, Soviet submarines penetrate deep into the territorial waters of neutral Sweden, gathering intelligence and testing Swedish defenses. Sweden keeps hoping that Moscow's leaders, who surely cannot intend these gross violations, will bring their navy under control.

title: Pay-Fone Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-Net income

title: Regents Vote To Revise Teaching Of History
description: Pledging that the state should not rewrite history but should improve the way it is taught, the Board of Regents committed itself today to revamping the state's American history curriculum to better reflect the contributions of nonwhite cultures.

title: Traditional Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an accounting adjustment gain of $1,600,000, or 46 cents a share. Figures for 1988 have been restated to reflect cumulative effect of FASB 96.

title: Herrick B. Young, 86, Ex-College President
description: Herrick B. Young, a former college president who was an authority on international education, died of pneumonia on Thursday at Sibley Hospital in Washington., He was 86 years old and lived in Washington.

title: The Art-Minded Have a Field Day
description: With a wink and a nod at traditional art history, the College Art Association is staging a marathon slide- andtalkfest at the New York Hilton this week. The occasion is the 78th annual convention of the association, whose agenda is heavy with political problems, nonmainstream art and revisionist ideas and ideologies.

title: CHRONICLE
description: GILLIAN MARTIN SORENSEN, New yrok City's Commissioner for the United Nations and Consular Corps for 12 years, is inher last week onthe job. she is not being reappointed by MAYOR DAVID DINKINS, although she wanted to be.

title: Norman Parkinson, Photographer, Adventurer and Royal Gadfly, 76
description: Norman Parkinson, a society photographer who specialized in photographing women and won fame for his pictures of members of the British royal family, died on Thursday in Singapore at the age of 76, his family reported.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Meeting of Industrial Countries Declares Need for More Aid to Poland and Hungary
description: Officials of the major industrial nations meeting here today declared that their seven-month aid program for Poland and Hungary, already surpassing $2 billion in commitments, was well on its way but needed more initiatives for private investment, debt servicing, education exchanges and protection of the environment.

title: School-Based Management Would Give the System a Conscience
description: To the Editor:

title: Seibels Bruce Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included the addition of about $39 million to the company's loss reserves, primarily related to RK&S Co., the company's former West Coast affiliate for the quarter and year; the year results also included $9.8 million pre-tax loss in the third quarter resulting from Hurricane Hugo. c-Net income Results for the prior-year periods have been adjusted to reflect the reclassification of realized gains on investments as required by Statement No. 97 of the Financial Accounting Standards Board.

title: Girl, 2, Is Found As Mother Tells Of Burial Site
description: The disappearance of a 23-month-old girl missing since Feb. 2 was solved on Thursday, after her mother, who had made a plea for her daughter's return, led the police to the child's body.

title: Patents;   Preventing Kidnapping Of Babies in Hospitals
description: Clifford Wheeless Jr., an obstetrician/ gynecologist in Baltimore, has patented a device to prevent the kidnapping of newborn infants. ''There have been a number of babies stolen out of hospitals and nurseries,'' Dr. Wheeless said. The invention is similar to the anti-shoplifting magnetic tags attached to clothing displayed in stores. The tags, which can only be removed by store clerks, set off an alarm if they are carried out the door.

title: United Canadian Shares reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $2,108,000, or $1.49 a share. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Herman Wilson, 54; Led Investment Fund That Aided the Poor
description: Herman Wilson, president of the Cooperative Assistance Fund, died on Thursday at a Washington hospital of complications from a fall at his home in the capital on Nov. 27. He was 54 years old.

title: Hilb, Rogal & Hamilton Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income of $370,000, or 5 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting. Effective Jan. 1, 1989, the company adopted Financial Accounting Standards Board Statement No. 96, Accounting for Income Taxes. All results have been restated to give effect to recent pooling of interests mergers and a 5-for-4 stock split.

title: Vuitton Family Plans To Buy 95% of Lanvin
description: An investment group led by the Vuitton family said today that it planned to buy 95 percent of Lanvin, the 100-year-old Paris fashion house that also makes Arpege and My Sin perfumes.

title: Reagan Testifies in the Poindexter Case
description: More than three years after the Iran-contra affair put his Administration under a cloud, former President Ronald Reagan answered questions under oath today about his role in it, testifying in a locked Federal courtroom for five hours.

title: Cheyenne Software reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CHRONICLE
description: The director of the Yale University Concert Band, THOMAS DUFFY, thinks of the group as a serious orchestra and he normally rejects brassy oom-pah-pah. But it's not every day a band can play the American premiere of a work by John Philip Sousa.

title: Bolar Cited By S.E.C. in Stock Fraud
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed charges of securities fraud yesterday against the Bolar Pharmaceutical Company, the troubled generic-drug manufacturer, and Robert Shulman, Bolar's former president.

title: Spring Exercise for Five Mets
description: On the day they were supposed to report for the start of spring training, five pitchers on the Mets tossed baseballs on a Little League field and played half-court basketball on a playground three miles from their training complex, which was locked and empty.

title: Is Degradability a Throwaway Claim?
description: The use of environmental marketing terms like ''degradable'' and ''recyclable'' is coming under increasing scrutiny from Federal and state officials.

title: Vast New Airport Is Proposed for Chicago
description: Mayor Richard M. Daley has proposed building a new airport on the Southeast Side that would be larger than O'Hare International Airport, one of the busiest in the world.

title: Penn Virginia Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for 1988 are restated to reflect adoption of the equity method of accounting for the investment in Westmoreland Coal Co. The restatement increased net income by $651,000 for the 1988 fourth quarter and by $6,509,000 for the 12 months.

title: Upheaval in the East: Poland;   Poland Demands Guarantees on Borders
description: The Polish Government demanded today that before a reunited Germany emerges, full guarantees must be given in Bonn and East Berlin to Poland's existing borders.

title: Upheaval in the East: Soviet Union;   Riots in Soviet Central Asia Spread to Another Republic
description: Rioting in Soviet Central Asia spread today to the Soviet Republic of Uzbekistan as Muslims clashed with ethnic Armenians in Samarkand, Radio Moscow reported.

title: Warm Bath and Bromide
description: It's a great age for freedom of expression. Everywhere, people imprisoned for speaking their minds are being set free.

title: Faxing as a Way to a Faster Refund
description: Instatax Inc. of San Diego has developed a system that enables taxpayers to fax their prepared tax returns to the company, which then transmits the returns to the Internal Revenue Service. The service costs $29.95 plus faxing and mailing costs. Generally, refunds on returns filed electronically are received within two weeks.

title: Investigator Testifies of Smelling Alcohol on Hazelwood's Breath
description: The first Coast Guard investigator to board the Exxon Valdez after its grounding testified today that Capt. Joseph Hazelwood's breath had ''a very intense and very obvious'' smell of alcohol.

title: News About an Ooze
description: More than half a million gallons of molasses escaped from a ruptured tank here today, oozed more than half a mile, forced the closing of a kindergarten and blocked access to several businesses.

title: Rabbit Software reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the efforts to redirect its focus caused the revenues for 1989 to be significantly lower than for 1988. In addition to reduced revenues, significant one-time charges were incurred to discontinue certain product lines ($1.4 million), European operations ($600,000) and manufacturing operations and facilities ($200,000).

title: Patents;   Honey Is Used to Keep Wine From Spoiling
description: Researchers at Cornell University this week obtained a patent on a method of using honey to prevent wine from spoiling.

title: Keith Haring, Artist, Dies at 31; Career Began in Subway Graffiti
description: Keith Haring, an artist whose graphic talents made him one of the stars of the youthful 1980's art scene and whose images could be found as often on T-shirts as in museums, died of AIDS yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 31 years old.

title: Echo Bay Mines reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $20 million writedown of an investment in Muscocho Explorations Ltd., Flanagan McAdam Resources Inc., and McNellen Resources Inc. for the quarter and year. c-Net income

title: Pressure Building for Mayor Barry to Resign After Indictment
description: The indictment of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. on drug and perjury charges on Thursday has intensified pressure, from friends as well as enemies, for his resignation.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Air Wis Services Inc., Appleton, Wis., said it would buy Aspen Airlines. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Treasury Notes and Bonds Steady
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and other fixed-income securities were mainly unchanged yesterday in a shortened pre-holiday weekend trading session.

title: Realty Refund Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Bush Gets Some Praise For Andean Drug Talks
description: President Bush told his Cabinet today that the regional drug conference in Colombia was an important start in international cooperation in fighting drug trafficking, an assessment shared by Administration critics.

title: Faith McGillicuddy Weds S. J. Benoit
description: Faith Burtis McGillicuddy and Stephen Joseph Benoit were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye, N.Y., by Msgr. Donald J. Pryor.

title: Mack Trucks Has a Record Loss
description: Mack Trucks Inc., the company that once so dominated the heavy truck industry that its name became synonymous with 18-wheelers, announced yesterday that it had record losses in 1989 and had reached two financing agreements to keep from running out of cash.

title: Bush Says Bill Ignores His Powers
description: Signing a bill today to allocate $9.8 billion in funds for the State Department next year, President Bush said he did not consider several of its provisions binding, including language that would require him to inform Congress of any sensitive diplomatic missions.

title: Trade Gap Reaches 5-Year Low
description: The nation's trade deficit narrowed sharply in December to $7.2 billion, the smallest gap in five years, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: News Summary
description: International 3-9

title: Green (A.P.) Industries(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said earnings for the latest fourth quarter and year were adversely impacted by professional fees incurred in the establishment of the company's employee stock ownership trust.

title: If the Sandinistas Win
description: President Bush faces a quandary in Nicaragua. On Feb. 25 the Sandinistas may conduct the most open vote in their country's undemocratic history. That has been the Administration's most insistent condition for disbanding the contra rebels and ending punitive sanctions. If the outcome is an upset victory for the opposition candidate, Violeta Chamorro, the cheering will be led by Mr. Bush.

title: AMCA International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income of $37,799,000, or 28 cents a share, from discontinued operations. c-After income from discontinued operations of $6,532,000, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter and $9,930,000, or 12 cents a share, for the year. The latest year's results also included a gain of $25 million related to the sale of the industrial automation segment. Preferred dividends in the latest periods were $6,025,000 for the quarter and $24,530,000 for the year, compared with $6,161,000 and $24,242,000 for year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Endesa reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Share earnings represented American Depositary Receipts. The company said conversion to dollars is based on an exchange rate of $1.00 equals 109.72 pesestas.

title: Production Dropped 1.2% In January
description: Industrial production took its biggest plunge in nearly four years last month, the Government said today, but analysts cited temporary factors for the 1.2 percent drop and said output should resume growth at a sluggish pace.

title: Bass Bid for St. Petersburg Times Rejected
description: The holders of the controlling stake in The St. Petersburg Times yesterday unanimously rejected a buyout offer from a group that includes Robert M. Bass, the Texas financier.

title: Guggenheim Coup in Minimalism
description: The Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation's acquisition of more than 300 modern American Minimalist paintings and sculptures from Count Giuseppe Panza di Biumo signals a major expansion for its museums in New York and Venice.

title: McEnroe Assails Tour
description: Since his ejection from the Australian Open last month, mum has pretty much been the word on court for John McEnroe, who is in Toronto for the Skydome World Tennis event this week. But upon leaving the court after a victory Thursday night, McEnroe opened up with a stream of invective at Hamilton Jordan, chief executive of the Association of Tennis Professionals Tour.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Chronicle column yesterday about Henry A. Kissinger's resignation from the President's Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board described the board's activities incorrectly. It meets formally about every two months, and consultants and staff members meet at other times. The item also referred incorrectly to John Tower's nomination to the board. He was nominated by President Reagan, not President Bush.

title: Jerelle Kraus Marries Horacio Cardo
description: Jerelle R. Kraus, the art director of The Living Section of The New York Times, and Horacio F. Cardo, a freelance illustrator, were married yesterday in a civil ceremony at City Hall in New York. The bride is a daughter of Joyce Kraus of Berkeley, Calif., and the late Dr. Otto Kraus. Her husband is the son of Mrs. Juan Cardo of Temperley, Argentina, and the late Mr. Cardo.

title: Upheaval in the East;   U.S.-Soviet Pact Clears Way For Flights Over Bering Strait
description: The United States and the Soviet Union agreed yesterday to cooperate in air-traffic control for flights between Alaska and Siberia. The agreement, the first of its kind between the two nations, clears the way for scheduled airline service.

title: Corrections
description: Articles between Jan. 26, 1986, and last Saturday about John Gotti, whom law enforcement officials call the leader of the Gambino crime family, referred incorrectly to the Queens club that is said to be his headquarters. Despite frequent references to the ''Bergen Hunt and Fish Club'' in court papers, a sign recently posted at the club calls it the Bergin Hunt and Fish Social Club.

title: Computer Communications Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Willard Thorp, 90, Princeton Professor; Headed U.S. Studies
description: Dr. Willard Thorp, a literary historian, an editor and a critic who taught at Princeton University for more than 40 years before retiring in 1967, died of cardiac arrest on Thursday at the Merwick Nursing Home in Princeton, N.J. He was 90 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: No. 2 Police Official to Move From L.I. to New York City
description: New York City's new No. 2 police official, First Deputy Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly, who lives in Garden City, L.I., will move into New York to comply with city policy and the philosophy of Mayor David N. Dinkins, city officials said yesterday.

title: Christian General Drives His Rivals From East Beirut
description: Christian army troops loyal to Gen. Michel Aoun scored a clear victory against their Christian militia opponents in East Beirut today, two days after mounting a tank and artillery offensive that left 50 people dead and scores wounded, security officials said.

title: Yes, Virginia, There Will Be Baseball
description: On Thursday, the official day of the opening of the baseball spring-training camps, that traditional post-winter, long-awaited sweet sound of the crack, crack, crack of the bat was replaced with the click, click, click of the lock. No ballplayers allowed. Lockout.

title: Dinkins's $2,000 Lesson: City Officials Fly Coach
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins has learned the hard way that rank has its privileges, but sometimes you have to pay for them. Pay is what he has agreed to do after City Hall aides told him he could not charge New York City for first-class air travel or day rooms in hotels on out-of-town trips.

title: Ford Motor Credit Co. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Ford Credit, a unit of Ford Motor Co., is part of the Ford Financial Services Group.

title: 4-Year Sentence for Ike Turner
description: The soul singer Ike Turner was sentenced today to four years in prison for a variety of cocaine possession offenses. Mr. Turner, 58-year-old former husband and musical partner of the rock star Tina Turner, was convicted in Superior Court here last month. In 1986, he acknowledged that he had been addicted to cocaine for 15 years.

title: Ex-Namibia Rebel Is Named President in Assembly Vote
description: Sam Nujoma, a former guerrilla leader who spent 30 years in exile, was elected Namibia's first President today.

title: Douglas-Holyfield Next?
description: Evander Holyfield's manager said today that he had formally asked boxing officials to clear the way for Holyfield to fight James (Buster) Douglas for the heavyweight championship.

title: Figgie International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $173,000 for the quarter and income of $69,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $1,461,000 for the quarter and income of $1,759,000, or 9 cents a share, for the year, both from discontinued operations.

title: Your Money;   Advice for Elderly On Health Policies
description: Older taxpayers may be taken aback when they start to fill out their 1989 income tax forms. Many thought they had won a major victory in December when Congress repealed the surtax for catastrophic medical care that could have run as high as $800 per person or $1,600 per couple. But there it is on the forms, line 54 of the Form 1040 and line 23 of the 1040A.

title: CHRONICLE
description: THE REV. JESSE JACKSON has never been as popular in Chicago as he has been elsewhare, He's explained this by noting that a prophet is never appreciated in his hometown.

title: Boschman Suspended
description: Laurie Boschman, a forward for the Winnipeg Jets, has been suspended for eight games by the National Hockey League for deliberate high-sticking against Tomas Sandstrom of the Kings on Feb. 8 at the Forum in Los Angeles. The suspension was decided upon at a hearing in Toronto on Thursday and announced yesterday. It will take effect on Feb. 23 unless the Jets waive the period of appeal.(AP)

title: FPL Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago quarter and full year share earnings included 32 cents a share from the sale of Praxis.

Keystone Consolidated reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $802,000, or 22 cents a share, for the quarter and $3,967,000, or $1.08 a share, for the year, both from tax loss carryforwards. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $18,031,000 for the quarter and $18,454,000 for the year. The 1988 periods were reclassified.

title: Duracell Holdings Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Included $10 million for the quarter and $20 million for the 6 months of purchase accounting adjustments, principally amortization of intangibles. c-Included $25 million of purchase accounting adjustments, principally amortization of intangibles, and a $13.1 million charge to the cost of sales for the excess of fair value of beginning inventories over historical cost. d-Net loss and included $74 million of purchase accounting adjustments, principally amortization of intangibles, and a $52.3 million charge to the cost of sales for the excess of fair value of beginning inventories over historical cost. Duracell Holdings acquired Duracell Inc. and its battery-related subsidiaries from Kraft Inc. on June 24, 1988.

title: Kenya Says Minister Was Slain
description: The partly burned body of Kenya's Foreign Minister was found today in a cane field near his home, three days after he disappeared. The Government indicated that the Minister, Robert Ouko, was a slaying victim.

title: Patents;   Disputed Provision in Gene Bill
description: A Congressional proposal aimed at closing a loophole allowing foreign companies to circumvent American biotechnology patents includes a controversial provision that its sponsors initially omitted from discussing.

title: Nature's Sunshine Products reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bridge
description: Few players realize that there are considerable opportunities for effective deceptive plays in the trump suit. There is, for example, a whole family of doubleton tenaces: jack-nine, queen-ten, king-jack and ace-queen. In each case it is sometimes productive to play the higher honor unnecessarily, and lead the declarer down a tempting path.

title: Catalina Lighting reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Revenge Is Seen As the Motive In a Bomb Death
description: Suffolk County investigators are focusing on revenge as the probable motive for the car-bombing death of a highly decorated county narcotics detective outside his home in North Patchogue. L.I., on Thursday.

title: Lockheed Fined $1 Million as Polluter
description: Air quality regulators have fined the Lockheed Corporation $1 million for violating anti-pollution rules in what is the largest penalty ever imposed by a regional pollution control agency here.

title: Ultimate's Board Shuns All Offers
description: The board of the Ultimate Corporation decided not to sell the computer systems company on the recommendation of a special committee of its independent directors.

title: Majestic Contractors reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $1,602,000 and $2,844,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $297,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and a loss of $480,000 from discontinued operations for the year. d-Net income The 1988 results were restated. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Todd Shipyards reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $6,219,000, or $1.48 a share, and $14,099,000, or $3.36 a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; the quarter also included an extraordinary loss of $1,803,000 due to the reversal of a tax credit. uf92c-Included income from discontinued operations of $2,431,000, or 58 cents a share, and $7,954,000, or $1.90 a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Latest quarter and nine-month results included a provision for imapirment of asset values at its Galveston shipyard of $38 million due to the continued underutilized capacity and operating losses. Year-ago quarter and nine-month results for periods ended Jan. 1, 1989 are restated to reflect the reclassification of the assets of Aro Corp. as income from discontinued operations. The company said that a gain from the sale of its Aro Corp. unit to Ingersoll-Rand Co. for $127.5 million will be recorded in the fourth quarter and that net operating loss carryforwards of $44 million and $2 million of tax credit carryforward will be utilized to offset the taxable gain arising from the sale.

title: Capital Holding reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $56,021,000 from an adjustment in accounting. The latest periods included realized investment gains of $20,524,000 for the quarter and $75,557,000 for the year, compared with $14,967,000 and $8,546,000 for same year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Enserch Exploration Partners Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Upheaval in the East;   17 Nations Plan to Relax Rules on Exports to East
description: A watchdog group including Western nations has agreed to begin relaxing controls on the export of advanced technology to Eastern Europe, but the United States has insisted that some of the concessions not yet apply to the Soviet Union, Western officials said today.

description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: A G.M. Pension-Fund Shift Into 'Junk Bonds' Expected
description: Executives at the General Motors Corporation are making plans to shift an undisclosed amount of the company's $35 billion in pension-fund assets into ''junk bonds,'' said people in the market who have been told about the move.

title: Guatemala Bus Crash Kills 12
description: Twelve Guatemalan refugees were killed and five seriously injured when a bus collided head on with a gas tanker near the Mexican town of Chetumal, about 900 miles southeast of Mexico City, the police said today.

title: Micronetics Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Peace Before Power
description: The principle is settled. West Germany will absorb East Germany, probably this year. Bonn's December elections will be for a Reichskanzler, not just leader of the Federal Republic but of all Germany. Whether East Germans participate remains to be decided. But they will have a big influence. The electorate will know it is choosing the government for a united country.

title: New Ford Vehicle
description: After a multimillion-dollar investment and retraining program, the Ford Motor Company has begun full production of its Explorer sports-utilty vehicle. The company's president, Philip E. Benton Jr., said at the assembly plant here that the Explorer, available in two-door and four-door models, would sell at perhaps twice the volume of the Bronco II, which it is replacing. The Louisville plant is expected to produce 85 Explorers an hour, with sales to the public beginning next month.

title: About New York;   Before Perrier, Stronger Drink Made Memories
description: Perrier laced with carcinogens? Obviously not good news. But the idea of New York not awash in bottled water brings back spirited memories for some.

title: Windmere Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Operating results for 1988 included the activities of the Save-Way Beauty Supply store chain, which was sold on Oct. 5, 1988. Sales by this business during 1988 were $26.3 million.

description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $631,000 and $545,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $598,000 and $2,026,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. d-Net loss
