description: b-Net income There were no share earnings after preferred dividend requirements.

title: King Babar and Family Go to Connecticut
description: An exhibition of original illustrations from the children's book series about King Babar the elephant are on view through May 6 at the Barnum Museum, 820 Main Street, Bridgeport, Conn.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ANDREI SERBAN is savoring a sweet moment: the Romanian Government has offered him the directorship of either its National Theater or the Romanian State Opera House in Bucharest.

title: Cutting the Dropout Rate: High Goal but Low Hopes
description: American educators are trying almost anything to keep children in school. They give pizza parties in Chicago, promise after-school and summer jobs in Philadelphia, hold drawings for used cars in Milwaukee and enroll American Indian youths in private schools in Minnesota, at state expense.

title: SBE Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said it recognized $466,000 related to a life insurance policy.

title: Sentencing Criminals: A Formula for Fairness
description: Under a new philosophy of prison sentencing that is spreading across the country, California's judicial system appears to have largely eliminated racial bias in determining which convicts go to prison and for how long, a study by the Rand Corporation has reported.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Private Farmers in Bulgaria Will Get More Land to Till
description: The government has agreed to end restrictions on private farming by lifting curbs on how much land individuals can till, the official press agency reported today.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: Talks on Vestron Reported
description: Live Entertainment Inc., the entertainment company, said today that it was holding talks to buy Vestron Inc., the troubled home video concern.

title: Dahlberg Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
Police Kill 3 in Shootout, but 4th Is Charged
description: A suspect in a holdup of a fast-food restaurant has been charged in the deaths of his three alleged accomplices even though it was police officers who shot and killed them.

title: Daisy Systems Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago quarter's loss included a special charge of $66,827,000 primarily related to the company's acquisition of Cadnetix Corp.

title: Teleflex Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest quarter consisted of 14 weeks and the year, 53 weeks. et1

title: What's Blocking the Thrift Bailout?
description: The meter keeps ticking on the savings-and-loan crisis. Insolvent thrifts are piling up losses at a rate of $6 million a day. Or maybe it's $14 million. Or even $20 million. It's hard to pin down a firm number. It's even harder to pin down who's running the rescue effort.

title: Oce-van der Grinten NV reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company reported in Dutch guilders/florins (NLG). The results have been converted at NLG 2.0084 equaling $1, the noon buying rate of Nov. 30, 1989, compared with NLG 1.9580 equaled $1, for 1988.

title: 2 Public Relations Styles Clash in Battle of Trumps
description: One is a mild-mannered man who once had a client bring a live elephant to the steps of City Hall, but who has since more often relied on his skills as a conciliator to build a large public relations firm and a reputation as a man you need to know in New York City.

title: Gateway Communications Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Many Hospitals Found to Ignore Rights of Patients in AIDS Testing
description: Many hospitals fail to get patients' consent before performing AIDS tests, do not counsel them adequately about the results and lack proper safeguards to insure confidentiality, a national survey has found.

title: Oldsmobile Cuts Price of 2 Models
description: The Oldsmobile division of the General Motors Corporation cut the price on two of its models to spur sales. The price of Oldsmobile's Cutlass Ciera S coupe dropped $200, to $12,195, while the Ciera S sedan's price dropped $500, to $12,495.

title: Myers Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bankers Hesitant on Drexel Sales
description: Senior executives with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the Wall Street firm that collapsed earlier this week, held high-level meetings yesterday with a number of banking officials who have been balking at settling sales of securities by Drexel in the last few days, people who were briefed on the talks said.

title: Coping: With Photographic Red Eye
description: Of all the things that can go wrong in a snapshot, few are more disconcerting than the phenomenon of red eye. It leaves friends and family looking like ghouls, their eyes glowing an unearthly shade of crimson. While over the last 10 years camera manufacturers have eliminated virtually all the other plagues that can ruin photographs, red eye has remained an all-too-common flaw.

title: Marcos Switches to Maverick for Her Defense
description: As if the coming trial of Imelda Marcos needed more personality, there strode Gerry Spence yesterday through the Manhattan drizzle and into the Federal courthouse, with his ill-matching tan slacks and sport jacket and wide-brim cowboy hat, declaring in his Lone Ranger style, ''I'm here because justice demands that I be here.''

title: Emco Ltd. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $1,233,000 and after an extraordinary charge of $3,357,000. c-Net income and included a loss of $5,098,000 from discontinued operations and after an extraordinary charge of $2,750,000. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: APL Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and after income of $708,000, or 19 cents a share, from discontinued operations.

title: Steelers Hire Walton As Offense Coordinator
description: Barely two months after being dismissed by the Jets, Joe Walton was hired by the Pittsburgh Steelers yesterday as their offensive coordinator, the post that once brought him the acclaim he never enjoyed as a head coach.

title: Ernest Williams, 90, Psychiatry Professor
description: Dr. Ernest Y. Williams, a psychiatrist who founded the department of psychiatry and neurology at Howard University Medical School, died of cancer on Monday at Walter Reed Army Hospital. He was 90 years old and lived in Washington.

title:
Style Makers;

Guy Azoulay, Designer and Americaphile
description: LEAD: What's so special about exploiting an American myth in fashion? After all, Ralph Lauren has been doing it for years. But Guy Azoulay had never been to the United States when he decided at the age of 21 to reinvent and sell American classics to the French.

title: Harley A. Farber, Designer, Weds
description: The wedding of Harley Alison Farber, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morton H. Farber of New York, and Robert Martin Raiff, a son of Frederic Raiff of New York and Elizabeth Haron of Greenwich, Conn., took place last evening at the Metropolitan Club in New York. Rabbi Ronald Sobel performed the ceremony.

title: Mindy Gerber and Chip Barber to Wed in June
description: June wedding plans for Mindy Gerber and Comdr. Charles Harry Barber 3d, U.S.N., have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Herman B. Gerber of Charlottesville, Va. Commander Barber is a son of Janet Forester Barber of West Chester, Pa., and the late Mr. Barber Jr. Miss Gerber, who attended Hamilton College, is an independent producer of television commercials, as was her father, who is retired. Her mother, Carol Gerber, retired as a fashion stylist. Commander Barber, known as Chip, is the director of sailing at the United States Naval Academy in Annapolis, Md. He graduated from Franklin and Marshall College and received a master's in administration from George Washington University and a specialist of education degree from the University of Virginia. His father was a real-estate agent in West Chester.

title: Question Of the Week;   What Do You Think of The Baseball Impasse?
description: If the players give in to the owners' demands for salary limitations they risk going right back to the days of servitude.

title: Painless Way to Cut Social Security Deductions
description: To the Editor:

title: Thornburgh Fears Abortion Test for Judges
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh is concerned that the American Bar Association will use a resolution endorsing abortion rights to produce a litmus test for screening judicial nominees.

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Soviet Union;   A Once-Docile Azerbaijani City Bridles Under the Kremlin's Grip
description: Four weeks after troops swarmed into this seaside city to suppress a nationalist uprising, the most popular excursion for classes at local schools is the hilltop park where the city has buried its dead.

title: Tax Credits for Health Insurance Won't Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Currency;   Awaiting the Results in Japan
description: Foreign-exchange traders around the world will be keeping an eye out Sunday for the first results from the Japanese elections for the lower house of Parliament. The Liberal Democratic Party, which has been plagued by scandals and lost the upper house last year, is fighting to keep control of the Government. A loss for the Liberal Democrats could further weaken the yen, at least temporarily. But whichever way the election goes, the Bank of Japan is expected to move to strengthen the yen by raising its key interest rate. Meanwhile, the dollar rallied a little last week against the German mark but lost its gains on Friday, when the Federal Reserve reported that industrial production had declined 1.2 percent in December.

title: Leading Man
description: FROM COOPER TO WAYNE TO Redford to Stallone, the stoic American movie idol has faced criticism for mechanical acting, for being more automaton than man. Now, to use the Hollywood lexicon, the tradition continues.

title: THE KENNEDY CLAN (CONTINUED)
description: May the saints preserve us - not another television drama about the Kennedys! Irish or not, that's the way a good many people may feel about the prospect of devoting six hours to the ABC mini-series ''The Kennedys of Massachusetts'' (two-hour installments begin tonight at 9 and continue tomorrow, with the conclusion on Wednesday). They shouldn't.

title: U.S. VERSUS JAPAN: A PROBLEM OF ATTITUDES
description: THE END OF THE AMERICAN CENTURY

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: Washington's Birthday. Financial markets and Government offices are closed.

title: Dr. Hope Brochin to Wed Next Year
description: Carol G. Brochin of Baltimore has announced the engagement of her daughter, Dr. Hope Ann Brochin, to Joseph A. Horvath, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Horvath of Malvern, Pa. The couple plan to marry next year.

title: Review/Dance;   Another Robbins-Balanchine Pairing
description: Yes, great performances do always touch the heart and move the spirit. Proof, if any is needed, came again when Darci Kistler and Robert La Fosse offered an achingly tender love duet Thursday night in Jerome Robbins's ballet ''In G Major.''

title: HIS BUS CAME IN
description: I realize tiat Danny Aiello's head must be swimming after playing supporting parts in such deathless masterpieces as ''Harlem Nights'' and ''Fort Apache, the Bronx,'' so it's no surprise he failed to mention that he played a leading role in my play ''Gemini.'' It's my recollection that he was with us for nearly three years, Off, and, eventually, on Broadway in the late 1970's. Your reporter seemed to think Mr. Aiello learned everything from Greyhound Bus announcements. I hope it isn't only an author's ego that prompts me to credit ''Gemini'' with Mr. Aiello's developing a persona he has used to some profit in similar material more recently.

title: Both Writers Miss the Point
description: As a veteran teacher and an advisor to a group of teenagers who by all standards can be perceived as ''affluent'' I am compelled to respond to two articles that appeared in the Long Island Weekly on Jan. 21 (''Teachers Have No Chance to Give Their Best'' by Mathias B. Freese and ''Teen-Agers and the Trap of Affluence'' by Roger Keizerstein.) Both Mr. Freese and Mr. Keizerstein miss the point. The magnificent ennui which teachers like Mr. Freese have noted, is there, make no mistake about it. It is apparent when discussions of literature are teacher directed and when selection of reading material is made exclusively by adults for students.

title: Eva Wolf Plans A June Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Ebner of Vienna have announced the engagement of their daughter, Eva Wolf, to Bennett W. Goodspeed Jr., a son of Mary Todd Mann Donley of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Goodspeed. A June wedding is planned.

title: Duke Student Defends Coach
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Culture and Stigma Slow AIDS Reports in Mideast
description: Tradition, culture and religion have contributed to a timid and tardy recognition of the existence of the AIDS virus in much of the Middle East, medical experts said at a conference here this week.

title: Carla Sputz and R. A. Fishbein Wed
description: Carla Ann Sputz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Sputz of Oakland, N.J., was married last evening to Robert Alan Fishbein, a son of Rabbi and Mrs. Irwin H. Fishbein of Westfield, N.J. The bridegroom's father performed the ceremony at the Livingston (N.J.) Country Club.

title: Budget Impasse Comes to an End
description: THE struggle over the county's 1990 budget ended last week as the Board of Legislators averted eliminating more than 400 jobs while indicating that it would take a more assertive role in drawing up future budgets.

title: Washington's Birthday Tomorrow
description: Here are holiday schedules.

title: Marx, Subverted
description: Karl Marx must be cringing in his grave. The draft platform of the Soviet Union's Communist Party that was published last week contains an economic bombshell: approval of private ownership of private capital. This proposed surrender of the party's economic dictatorship is every bit as radical as the document's proposed surrender of the party's 70-year political dictatorship.

title: Pastimes;   Camera
description: Showing your pictures to someone is fraught with perils - especially if it's someone whose opinion you respect. But that doesn't seem to keep anyone's images in the closet.

title: Paying Attention
description: To the Editor:

title: Children's Cancer Tied to British A-Plant Workers
description: Researchers have found a higher risk of leukemia in the offspring of men who worked at a nuclear plant on the northwest coast of England than among the children of men who worked at other jobs in the area.

title: Service for Dr. Yen
description: A service for Dr. Y. C. James Yen, founder of the International Institute of Rural Reconstruction, will be held at 4 P.M. on Wednesday in the chapel of the Interchurch Center at 475 Riverside Drive at 120th Street. Dr. Yen died on Jan. 17 at the age of 96.

title: The Consistency Of a Career Illuminated
description: Witold Lutoslawski's uncanny color sense is usually the first aspect of his music to strike a listener. But the way he precisely and unconventionally manipulates a palate of stunning instrumental timbres into a language of intense expressive gestures is but one of the remarkable aspects of the Polish composer's music. Another is Mr. Lutoslawski's structural inventiveness. With a geometer's sense of proportion, he creates highly exacting musical patterns, the large-scale shapes caging a surprising amount of soulful inner detail.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Inside the garage, my foundation wall has two hairline cracks oozing a steady stream of sand. What can be causing this?

title: Assessing Performance, Not Personality
description: To the Editor:

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

Compassion Fueled by Memories of Poverty
description: LEAD: WE are equity lenders, and so we will grant them a second mortgage to help them out, as the value of their house far exceeds the balance of their mortgage.

title:
DINING OUT;

A Chinese Menu With Unusual Dishes
description: LEAD: GOLDEN KO SHING, which is opposite the Holiday Inn on Route 46 West in Parsippany, is the one of the latest in the wave of Chinese restaurants that have opened in recent months. The Morris County restaurant, in the Arlington Plaza shopping center, is worth a visit because the food is above average.

title: Frances Taylor To Wed in July
description: The engagement of Frances Lynn Taylor to Keith Nicholas Costa has been announced by the prospective bride's mother, Patricia J. Kenney of New York. A July wedding is planned.

title: Washington Official Urges Tax Refusal To Push Statehood
description: Walter E. Fauntroy, the District of Columbia's Delegate to Congress, has urged residents here not to pay their Federal taxes until Congress makes Washington the 51st state.

title: HOW HE BID THE MOB GOODBYE
description: THE PLUMBER

title: New Cigarette Raising Issue of Target Market
description: Four weeks after its debacle with a cigarette aimed primarily toward blacks, the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company may be heading for a new battle over a cigarette reportedly aimed at young, blue-collar white women.

title: Woman of A Certain Age
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about efforts to stop emigration from Israel characterized Mordechai Glick incorrectly. He is a member of the Organization to Stop Emigration From Israel but is not its head. The caption also misidentified the setting. It was Mr. Glick's home, not his office.

title:
ART;

Motifs and Montage In 4-Artist Show
description: LEAD: THE four top prize winners in last year's annual juried exhibition at the Fine Arts Museum of Long Island in Hempstead were Ina Ovruceski, Edith Seltzer, Gerald Shak and Paulette Singer. Their work is now featured in concurrent one-person shows on view through March 11.

title: Dodgers Bring About A Change of Seasons
description: You are looking for baseball - for some kind of sign that spring has arrived and that life goes on - so you come here. And in a time of lockouts and cold-hearted negotiating sessions, you are satisfied.

title: On Language;   If You Will
description: The National - our first all-sports daily newspaper distributed nationwide - was launched last month by the ace sportswriter Frank Deford. It appears to be a literate publication; one headline in its first issue over a story about the New York Knicks basketball center Patrick Ewing was ''The Center Is Holding,'' an allusion to William Butler Yeats's poem ''The Center Cannot Hold.''

title: Quilts Ablaze in Colors and Patterns
description: AFTER seeing a quilt spread over a waterbed in a television commercial, Francis Sheppard was inspired to stitch her own version and call it ''Who'd a Thought It.'' Mrs. Sheppard, who is nearly 100 years old, estimates that she has pieced at least 1,000 quilts since she started playing with small pieces of cloth at the age of 5.

title: Christine Dibble Is Engaged to a Fellow Lawyer
description: Christine Louise Dibble and Cameron Cohick, lawyers in Washington, plan to marry in May. Miss Dibble, 28 years old, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon K. Dibble of Montgomery Village, Md. The prospective bridegroom, 32, is a son of Nancy Cohick of Raleigh, N.C., and Larry Cohick of Beaumont, Tex.

title: CASSETTE TAPES MOVE THE FINISH LINE TO DISTANT LENGTHS
description: In picking a recording tape, audio fans find themselves in the same situation as buyers of soap. Competing brands seem so alike that one is easily swayed by advertising, packaging or other irrelevancies.

title: Another Channel War: Owners vs. Builders
description: Long gone are the days when history, nationalism and mutual suspicion fed doubts that Britain and France would ever be linked by a tunnel under the English Channel. The doubts remain, but today the reason is money.

title: WRIGHT'S HEIRS BUILD SOME BRIDGES TO THE REAL WORLD
description: Olgivanna Lloyd Wright, the widow of Frank Lloyd Wright, died in March 1985, and for more than three years after that, her bedroom in the Wright residence at Taliesin West remained empty. There was no surprise to the fact that the room was left like a shrine: Taliesin, which is owned by the Frank Lloyd Wright Foundation and functions as part tourist attraction, part architecture school, part Wright archive and part ongoing architectural practice, has always had an oddly worshipful, almost cultlike quality to it. The architects work at drafting tables under a huge photograph of Wright; the new buildings they design look like Wright's, and the apprentice architects showing visitors around speak reverently of ''Mr. Wright,'' who died in 1959, as if he were just in the other room.

title: Princess Mora Edges Fieldy
description: Princess Mora stole away to an easy lead on the stretch turn and then just barely held off Fieldy's heroic late charge to win the $64,950 Suwanee River Handicap by a neck today at Gulfstream Park.

title: A Fall Wedding For Laura Kohn
description: Laura Beth Kohn and John Briggs Parkinson Jr. are planning an October wedding, the prospective bride's parents, A. Eugene Kohn and Barbara Kohn, both of New York, have announced. Mr. Parkinson is a son of Mrs. Michael O'Sullivan of Somers, N.Y.

title: Arrest Doubly Embarrassing
description: The president of Clemson University's student body, who recently reviewed and approved the school's toughened alcohol policy, was charged early Friday with driving under the influence of alcohol. William Astor Blackwood 3d, a 21-year-old senior, was arrested by a university police officer. This week, after a committee of students and faculty agreed on changes in the campus alcohol policy, their recommendations were approved by Mr. Blackwood and the dean of students and sent to the university president, Max Lennon.

title: A Bookstore Where Books Are Heard
description: AT the Little Professor Book Center in Niantic, fledgling writers meet to talk about writing, established authors give readings and children attend story hours. The activities represent what a bookstore should offer, said Robert Rue, who, with his wife, Connie, owns the store.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ended Feb. 3

title: Boxing: Same Old Stories, New Twists
description: When Don Skene was a boxing reporter for The New York Herald Tribune, his sense of perspective was so broad he never entered a fight club without saying, ''Things were never like this when we fought on barges.'' Unfortunately, the late Mr. Skene was wrong. Nothing ever changes in boxing. New faces populate the same old stories. But they are the same old stories with new twists. Don King calls it ''trickeration.''

title: A Secluded Indonesian Isle
description: LOMBOK. It sounds like a planet on ''Star Trek.'' The island is not really in outer space, but, as I showed my son on the globe, it was literally on the other side of the world, some 10,000 miles away in Indonesia.

title: Men at Work
description: Overheard in a Manhattan restaurant, one woman to another: ''He's a terrific father, but he's never home.''

title: CAN HE SAVE THE ELEPHANTS?
description: I survived a Kenyan ambush in which a friend sitting beside me was killed and my husband was wounded by gunshot. It was gratifying to read in your article that the Kenyan Government at last is admitting it has serious problems.

title: Mary Jo Sherman To Wed in April
description: Mrs. Edward J. Sherman of Glens Falls, N.Y., and Bradenton, Fla., has announced April wedding plans for her daughter Mary Jo Sherman and Charles E. Stiver Jr., the son of Mr. Stiver of Cape Girardeau, Mo., and Lenore D. Stiver of San Diego. The bride-to-be is also a daughter of the late Mr. Sherman.

title: Racketeering Cases Are Popping Up in Several Varieties
description: JUSTICE DEPARTMENT lawyers in New York City last week filed suit against six locals of a waterfront union that has been tarred with charges of violence and Mafia domination for more than three decades. Not far from the lower Manhattan courthouse where that case was filed, the elegantly suited men who ran the Wall Street house of Drexel Burnham Lambert were announcing the collapse of the firm that was near the center of the financial world for much of the 1980's.

title:
GARDENING;

Fruit Trees Spectacular in Bloom
description: LEAD: AMONG the finest flowering trees for the garden are various species and cultivars of the genus Prunus. It includes cherry as well as ornamental and fruit-bearing forms of apricot, peach and plum. All are early flowering and spectacular trees when in bloom, even those with edible fruit.

title: Gorbachev's Crash Course in Democracy
description: LEAD: After the Central Committee meeting, an associate of Mikhail Gorbachev diagnosed the disintegration of the party and state system.

title: Campus Life: Princeton;   Trying to Erase Their Image As Drinking Clubs
description: Princeton University's 13 private eating clubs provide meals to about 75 percent of the upperclassmen and, until recently, alcohol to hundreds of underclassmen, many of them under age. But if last weekend's club initiation parties are a guide, new rules on alcohol use are turning these campus social centers into bastions of sobriety.

title: H.U.D. FINDS BRIBES AT 3 AUTHORITIES
description: Federal investigators have uncovered bribery schemes at three housing agencies in New Jersey and are investigating four other agencies for possible criminal wrongdoing, the United States Attorney for New Jersey, Samuel A. Alito Jr., said today.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Elkton, Md.;   Maryland Wins A Site Battle
description: MORE than a year of competition between Maryland and Delware has ended with this state's capturing a major research and development center proposed by Himont, an international chemical company based in Wilmington, Del.

title: POSTINGS: West Side Landmark;   Rebuilding a Stable
description: The Claremont Riding Academy, a fixture on the Upper West Side for nearly a century - it stables 100 horses and serves almost 50,000 riders a year - has been rescued from the knacker and will undergo an extensive rehabilitation with the help of the city's Industrial Development Agency.

title:
Pastimes: Gardening;

Grow Your Own Crudites Garden
description: LEAD: In tune with a diet-conscious age, my vegetable garden is being fashioned this year with the accent on raw. Broccoli, kale, beet greens, carrots, dandelions, edible pod peas, peppers, spinach, onions, cress, mustard greens ride high on the nutrition charts. And it is these vegetables that are winning space in my crudites garden.

title: ASPEN: THE CALL OF THE WILD
description: Why did you have to do a cover story about the high-rolling tourists of Aspen? The Italians have an apt expression that fits them: faccia da schiaffi, which roughly translates as ''faces to slap.''

title: More Hype Than HOPE
description: The Bush Administration's new housing initiative, announced with great ballyhoo by the President and Housing Secretary Jack Kemp, certainly has a ring to it. HOPE, it's called, the last word in inspirational acronyms: Homeownership and Opportunity for People Everywhere, a package filled with promising programs.

title: Jean Wallace, 66, Screen Actress Known for 1940's and 50's Roles
description: Jean Wallace, a screen actress who had feature parts in a dozen Hollywood productions and was married to two stars, Franchot Tone and Cornel Wilde, died of a gastrointestinal hemorrhage Wednesday at her home in Beverly Hills, Calif. She was 66 years old.

title: WORKING ON THE MECHANICS
description: How I enjoyed Lesley Hazleton's article about her venture into the world of the internal combustion engine (Hers: ''Working on the Mechanics,'' Jan. 14). It reminded me of my own first, shy requests for initiation into the marvels of 10-wheelers, compaction trucks, backhoes and - my personal favorite - our landfill's 953 ''cat'' bulldozer.

title: Review/Cabaret;   Love Songs and Opera Arias In Angelina Reaux Show
description: The young soprano Angelina Reaux, like her obvious role model Teresa Stratas, is a singer with unusually strong dramatic instincts and the will to transcend the image of opera singer as a delicate hothouse flower.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Fashion page on Jan. 28 about uniforms included an incorrect report from Scafati Inc. in Manhattan about outfits worn by the Rainbow Room staff. They were designed by Carrie Robbins, and they are not sold to the public.

title: Up-to-the-Minute Scores From the Revolution in the East Bloc Election Timetable
description: Except for Poland, which is voting for local and regional governments, all countries are electing new parliaments.

title: Lilli Siegel Plans To Wed in June
description: June wedding plans have been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Burton M. Siegel of Short Hills, N.J., for their daughter Lilli Siegel and Jonathan David Roth, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Roth of Bellerose, L.I.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday about a royal appearance at the House of Lords in London referred incorrectly to the role of Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh, and described the occasion incompletely. The Duke was present only in his role as husband of Queen Elizabeth II; he did not preside. The setting was the annual state opening of Parliament last November.

title: Spring Break: Where to Go
description: A COLLEGE junior from the Northeast asks for suggestions of lively trips to take during spring break other than lie on the beach in Florida or Texas and contemplate beer.

title: Nella Domenici, Executive, to Wed
description: Senator and Mrs. Pete V. Domenici of Washington and Albuquerque, N.M., have made known the engagement of their daughter Nella Louise Domenici to Steven Brian Powell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Carl Powell of Augusta, Ga. An April wedding is planned.

title: English by Force
description: English is America's common tongue, and ought to be. For their own benefit, all who choose to live here need to be fluent. But American freedoms include the freedom not to be.

title: Spartans Stop an Illini Rally to Win
description: Matt Steigenga scored 17 points and low-scoring Mark Montgomery hit 5 quick points today to stop a second-half Illinois run as Michigan State beat the Illini, 70-63.

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Review/Music;   D.R.I. Mix Of Angry Rock Ideas
description: D.R.I., a four-man band from Texas, used to sound like hundreds of other hard-core rock bands, yelling out angry lyrics over fast, choppy, sputtering guitars and drums. Then it got a bright idea: to combine hard core with equally angry heavy metal, thus addressing more camps of listeners. With its album ''Crossover,'' D.R.I. (which stands for Dirty Rotten Imbeciles) introduced songs that ran at three speeds - frenetic hard core; fast speed-metal; slow, grinding heavy metal - simply by switching from one style to another in various verses. At the Lyric Theater on Thursday night, D.R.I. had some fans flopping their long hair, speed-metal style, and others slam-dancing, diving from the stage and shouting lyrics into the singer's microphone like hard-core devotees.

title: Irish Jolt Orangemen on Shot at Buzzer
description: Elmer Bennett hit a 3-pointer at the buzzer and Notre Dame ended Syracuse's home winning streak against nonconference teams at 37 games with a 66-65 victory today.

title: Reagan Is Said to Have Testified He Didn't Authorize Lawbreaking
description: Ronald Reagan said repeatedly during his testimony in a Federal court that he did not authorize John M. Poindexter to violate the law in the Iran-contra affair, a person familiar with the former President's deposition said today.

title: Correction
description: The Fast Forward column last Sunday misidentified the winner of the 1941 Academy Award for best supporting actress. She was Mary Astor.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Dinner;   In Manhattan, American to Afghan
description: This is a summary of reviews of Manhattan restaurants by Bryan Miller that have appeared in The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have ratings. Prices are current.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey;   Recent Sales
description: Howell $168,400

title: In China, Loving Lady Chatterley
description: For the better part of 25 years, I felt discontented with teaching in America. This is not a country that reads much, or believes that the little it is required to read has anything to do with the world of banks, cars and missile silos. We are practical to a fault, clean mental machines, so Thoreau, Whitman and Mark Twain go in one ear and pass out the other, frequently without impediment, loss of speed or any notable effect.

title: THE HOLINESS OPTION
description: THE POLITICAL MEANING OF CHRISTIANITY

title: Waltrip Thriving On a Subtler Style
description: Dominance isn't given up very easily at the Daytona 500. Like a driver in the 10-car conga lines that roll down the backstretch in a bumper-to-bumper draft, if you want to cut in near the front, you could be bucking the turbulence a long time.

title: U.S. to Weigh New Ties If Ortega Wins Election
description: The Bush Administration is considering possible steps to improve relations with Nicaragua if the Sandinistas win free and fair elections on Feb. 25.

title: POSTINGS: Cross & Brown Sells a Division;   Elliman Gets 31 Brokers
description: The Cross & Brown Company, a New York real estate brokerage and property management concern, has agreed to sell its residential division to Douglas Elliman-Gibbons & Ives, a Manhattan residential brokerage. Officials of both companies, who declined to disclose the purchase price, said one effect of the sale would be the transfer of 31 brokers from seller to buyer.

title: Plan to Incinerate Tainted Missouri Soil Is Opposed
description: Times Beach has been a ghost town since dioxin was discovered in the soil seven years ago and the Federal Government bought up all 801 homes and businesses and moved the residents out.

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Corrections
description: In the Caribbean listings of Royal Caribbean Cruise Line, a one-night hotel stay was described incompletely. It applies only to passengers arriving from the West Coast. Fares for seven-night cruises of the Song of Norway were misstated; the range is $1,145 to $2,630.

title: No New Clues Offered in Death of Kenyan Official
description: Government officials offered no further information today on the death of Foreign Minister Robert Ouko, whose partly burned body was found in the western part of the country under mysterious circumstances on Friday.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

I Don't Feel or Look My Age. So What?
description: LEAD: THERE were a series of ads recently that showed people in two photos. The first introduced you to, say, Jim and Sarah. ''This is how they look now'' (at maybe age 60), ''but this'' - and you looked at picture No. 2 - ''is how they feel.''

title: Comissiona to Direct Vancouver Symphony
description: Sergiu Comissiona has taken over conducting chores for the Vancouver Symphony as music director designate until September 1991. He will then become music director through the 1993-94 season.

title: Pastimes;   Bridge
description: The inhabitants of Middle Earth, as described by J.R.Tolkien, are not recorded as having played bridge. But that was simply an oversight on the part of the chronicler, according to a recent report from Under Earth. Richard Hills, writing in the magazine, Australian Bridge, describes bidding in the Mithrandir Memorial Pairs, an imaginary tournament.

title: Dr. Joanne Bader ToWed in April
description: April wedding plans for Dr. Joanne Bader and Jeffrey Mitchell, a son of Judge and Mrs. Jerry W. Mitchell of San Bruno, Calif., have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Frank Bader of Belle Terre, L.I.

title: Fair and Square
description: It is the consensus in the boxing world that shortly after he demonstrated that he was the toughest man on the planet, James (Buster) Douglas was very nearly mugged in broad daylight. Douglas, a 29-year-old journeyman boxer, had in the minds of many fans gone as far as could be expected just by stepping into the same ring with Mike Tyson, the undefeated heavyweight champion. But 10 rounds later, there was Douglas with his hands raised in victory and Tyson on the canvas in search of his senses. Along the way, however, Tyson had knocked Douglas down and the referee had given the challenger a long count. Boxing experts shrugged it off, but Don King, who has made millions of dollars promoting Tyson, persuaded sanctioning groups to suspend the results of the fight pending an investigation - or something. But boxing writers made such a stink about the seeming attempted robbery that Mr. King quickly dropped his objection and he and Tyson proclaimed Douglas the champ.

title: Trudy M. Zohn Is Engaged
description: Trudy Marcia Zohn and David Joel Schwartz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Schwartz of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., are planning a May wedding. Miss Zohn is a daughter of the late Florence and Herman Zohn of New York. She is a fixed-income sales associate at Prescott Ball & Turben, investment bankers in New York. The prospective bridegroom is a counsel to the New York law firm of Debevoise & Plimpton.

title: Engaged in Albany
description: Someday, Andrew Cuomo and Kerry Kennedy just could give new meaning to the term running mates. The son of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the daughter of the late Senator Robert F. Kennedy will be married sometime this spring, Ms. Kennedy's mother, Ethel, announced last week. The prospective union of two clans whose family business is politics immediately gave rise to speculation. Mr. Cuomo, a lawyer who twice served as his father's campaign manager, is known to have political ambitions of his own, though he will doubtless heed his father's wishes and stay off the ballot until Governor Cuomo is out of office. Ms. Kennedy, meanwhile, is herself involved in public affairs as the executive director of the Robert F. Kennedy Center for Human Rights in Boston. But for now Mr. Cuomo and Ms. Kennedy seemed to have more traditional concerns in mind. ''I consider myself a very lucky man,'' said Mr. Cuomo. Said his bride-to-be, ''I think this is the happiest day of my life.''

title: The King of Conflict of Interest
description: For nearly two years now, Don King and Mike Tyson have emerged as the Siamese twins of boxing. Siamese twins joined at the money clip. One is seldom seen in public without the other. And last Tuesday, as King apologized meekly and weakly for having protested that James (Buster) Douglas didn't deserve to be the new heavyweight champion because of a long count, the promoter kept using the word ''we,'' meaning himself and the dethroned champion who was sitting nearby.

title: Conductor to Make Philharmonic Debut
description: LEAD: ''IT'S an enormous blind date, like getting married and never having met the person until the wedding,'' Marin Alsop said.

title:
The Executive Life;

Hollywood Goes Back to the Beach
description: LEAD: ''It's a very organic experience. I don't mean to get real Zen about it but it's just really cool.''

title: Subjugating Hong Kong
description: The most symbolic action of the China-appointed committee deciding Hong Kong's fate was perhaps the choice this week of the flag that will flutter over the territory beginning in 1997: a white bauhinia flower against a revolutionary red background.

title: Review/Music;   Greg Osby's Saxophone Improvisations
description: In the last several years, the young saxophonist Greg Osby has emerged as a distinct, important figure on the alto saxophone, making appearances on his own moody, funk-influenced recordings as well as with the composers Andrew Hill and Steve Coleman and the drummers Cecil Brooks and Jack DeJohnette. Mr. Osby has his eye on all sorts of music, and his show at the Knitting Factory on Wednesday night had him moving from his idiosyncratic and complicated compositions to the sort of simple pop instrumentals that might be heard on what passes for jazz radio nowadays.

title: Europe's Grand Classics of Skiing;   In Austria, The Serious and The Upper Crust
description: PERHAPS the biggest attraction for American skiers in the Alps is that generally the resorts there - unlike the Northeast and the Rockies - were not created for skiing. They are essentially villages that were always there, amid magnificent mountain terrain on which winter sports were easily grafted. Visiting skiers relish the expanse, the wildness, the European atmosphere and, of course, good food and wine. Progress and modernization have taken their toll, but skiers can still satisfy expectations, especially in the grand classics, the old resorts that have made efforts to cling to their charm, and remain playgrounds for the wealthy and fashionable. But even the rich cannot rely on the weather. This winter's early snow melted in a warm spell. Early February was a time of hope.

title: Lifestyle;   Dog Show and a Sideshow: Accessorizing Any Pooch
description: If you heard a woof-woof here and a woof-woof there - here a woof, there a woof, everywhere a woof-woof - chances are you were at Madison Square Garden last week, where the 114th annual Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show was under way.

title: 1st Grade 1925, 1st Grade Today
description: On Wednesday evening my grandson William called to give me an assignment. ''It's the 75th birthday of my school,'' he explained, ''and Mrs. Lyver would like the grandparents to tell what it was like when they were in the first grade. And I have to have it by the first day of next week.''

title: Museums Try to Attract the Family Outing
description: LEAD: AS the county's cultural institutions try to increase their audiences, programs put together with the whole family in mind are becoming more common. ''The trend toward family programming is widespread, although no one is teaching it or advocating it, and there has been no major conference on this,'' said Christopher P.

title:
Style Makers;

Bruce Bradbury, Wallpaper Designer
description: LEAD: It is no surprise that Bruce Bradbury keeps a portrait of Queen Victoria over the fireplace in his studio-showroom. Working as a fine arts and silkscreen printer, he spent years following his fascination with the 19th century by spending all his spare time and money studying architecture, and sketching and tracing original Victorian interiors in England and the United

title: Plastic Packaging: An Unwarranted Bias
description: As executive editor of two food-industry magazines during the last decade, I have had occasion to cover various food-packaging issues, including chlorofluocarbons (CFC's) and the current controversy over banning plastic food packaging. It was therefore distressing to read County Legislator Paul Feiner's Jan. 28 letter, because it contained a major inaccuracy that helps perpetuate an unwarranted bias against plastic packaging.

title: ROMAN SILVER FIT FOR THE BATHS
description: To the ancient Romans, sumptuous silver was a status symbol to be displayed at home and at the public bath. Sotheby's exhibition of 14 magnificent silver vessels - four large plates, five jugs, two buckets, a basin, a vase and a casket for toiletries - may help to explain why. The hefty tablewares, said to be from the fourth to the fifth centuries and described by the auction house as the largest and finest collection of ancient Roman silver ever uncovered, are a tour de force of exuberant decoration.

title: Secretive Nicaraguan Voters Leave Election Hard to Call
description: After a decade of war, economic crisis and political polarization, Nicaraguans will vote in eight days in this country's first free and broadly contested democratic election. But because most voters, wary of such freedom, remain deeply reluctant to discuss their personal views, even the best-informed specialists say they are at a loss to predict who will win.

title: More Rap On Rap
description: To the Editor:

title: Andrea Krahmer Planning to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Johannes Robert Krahmer of Wilmington, Del., have announced the engagement of their daughter Andrea Clemm Krahmer to David McNeill Cross, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Henry Aaron Cross of Chapel Hill, N.C. A June wedding is planned.

title: Painless Way to Cut Social Security Deductions;   Never Was a Trust Fund
description: To the Editor:

title: Tight Budgets Force Towns To Cut Costs
description: ON Lincoln's Birthday last week, for the first time in years, there was no one at the New Haven Public Works Department to answer the phone in an emergency. This weekend, the street-sweeping trucks are not out as usual, as the city cuts overtime hours to save money.

title: Miss Armstrong to Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Maxwell Armstrong Jr. of West Chester, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elisabeth Ely Armstrong to Robert Hattersley Connell, a son of Philip G. Connell Jr. of the Village of Golf, Fla., and the late Nancy Sommerville Connell. A June wedding is planned.

title: Anheuser-Busch's Campaign Against Abusive Drinking
description: To the Editor:

title: Outdoors;   Hookless Lures Still Catch Notice
description: Once recognized only by those who collected, studied or actually made or used them, fish decoys - lures without hooks - are swimming into public view.

title: Ambergris
description: To the editor: My wife and I love snorkeling and skin diving but a series of hip replacement operations has made climbing ladders into dive boats a real struggle for her, especially in choppy water.

title: Question Of the Week;   What Do You Think of The Baseball Impasse?
description: The owners are wallowing in jillions in profits but are unsatisfied and want another jillion or three, and they are unwilling to share even a fraction of a jillion more with the players - when it is to see the players that we pay our contributions to those huge profits.

title: Catholic Schools Close as Costs Outpace Parishes
description: To Charles Trotta, St. Boniface Martyr School in Sea Cliff, L.I., was always more than a place where education mixed with morning prayer and swift discipline. It represented a link to his past and, until this year, his future.

title: Correction
description: A review of ''Silver Stallion'' by the Korean novelist Ahn Junghyo on Feb. 4 rendered the author's family name incorrectly. The review should have referred to him as Mr. Ahn, not Mr. Junghyo.

title: YOU'RE ONLY AS OLD AS WE SAY YOU ARE
description: HOW OLD ARE YOU?

title: Tech Notes;   Knocking Ice Off Airplane Wings
description: A new system for de-icing the the wings of airplanes and the rotors of helicopters has been invented by Leonard Haslim, a program manager at NASA's Ames Research Center in Mountain View, Calif. Accumulations of ice on aircraft surfaces caused 344 aircraft mishaps between 1977 and 1987, according to the National Transportation Safety Board, and resulted in 443 fatalities.

title: Hoyas Prevail to Extend Pirates' Slump
description: In previous seasons, as Seton Hall was blossoming into a Big East power and Georgetown was making its annual push for conference supremacy, a meeting between the schools could always be counted on to tip the conference standing one way or another.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Fort Lee
description: THE name George Washington brings grimaces to the faces of many Fort Lee residents. But it's not the Father of the Country - who laid out a fort on the site in 1776 - they have a grudge against; it's the bridge named for him, the one that was opened in 1931 to connect New Jersey with Manhattan.

title: King: An Artful Dodger Who Lands on His Feet
description: There is a story Don King tells on himself:

title: Senna Apologizes
description: After making the apology demanded by international auto-racing officials, Ayrton Senna of Brazil, a former world driving champion, was granted a license on Friday to drive on the Formula One circuit this year.

title: 'LOUIE LOUIE' AND THE ZEITGEIST
description: ''LOUIE LOUIE'' may not be Beethoven's Fifth Symphony. But the by-now mythic cult adulation accorded this three-chord rock archetype invites a brief comparison to Beethoven. This may seem a tad farfetched, but bear with me.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD:

title: DISPUTE IN SENATE ON FINANCE REFORM
description: Supporters of the Democrats' leading campaign finance proposal say Senator Alan Cranston, the California Democrat whose fund-raising techniques are under the scrutiny of Federal law-enforcement authorities, is quietly maneuvering to dilute the measure.

title: Mark Hirshorn to Wed Miss Hoffman
description: Dr. and Mrs. Marvin J. Hoffman of Rochester have announced the engagement of their daughter Jennifer Yanes Hoffman to Mark Frederic Hirshorn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Hirshorn of Ambler, Pa., and Boca West, Fla. A June wedding is planned.

title: China Gulag Inc.
description: Here is some important legal and business information for Americans importing goods from China or investing in Chinese factories or mines:

title:
Your Own Account;

Beware the Early Payouts
description: LEAD: When the Prudential Insurance Company of America said last month that it would pay death benefits in advance to terminally ill policyholders, it drew attention to a relatively new type of life insurance that offers a so-called accelerated death benefit, or living payout.

title: POSTINGS: Essex House Renovation;   Art Deco Redux
description: The Essex House, at 160 Central Park South between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue, is undergoing a renovation that includes redecorating it to bring it more in line with the Art Deco design it had when it opened in 1931. The $55 million project, scheduled to continue until early next year, will reduce the number of guest rooms from 690 to 580, making some larger and converting others into two-room suites. The size and configurations of 148 other rooms and suites that are privately owned as condominiums will not be changed.

title: Crack Addiction Is Forcing Prostitutes Onto the Streets
description: YOUNG, old, black, white or Hispanic, Long Island's new types of prostitutes share several common bonds. They are almost all addicted to crack; they are for the most part freelance entrepreneurs who work without pimps, and they are part of what is believed to be the greatest number of women ever to ply the sex trade on the Island.

title: Three Aspects of U.S. Glass Explored
description: THREE distinct facets of the world of American glass, past and present, are on exhibit here at the Hudson River Museum. ''Persians,'' a series of sculptural blown-glass assemblages by Dale Chihuly, a leading artist in his field, is the dramatic centerpiece of three shows that will run through March 18.

title: Awesome Power Might Be the Only Predictable Trait Of a Unified Land
description: RIGHT after Chancellor Helmut Kohl returned from Moscow last week, posters appeared on the streets of Bonn showing his picture with Mikhail S. Gorbachev over the legend, ''The way is clear! Now comes unity!''

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Holdouts;   For Durst, It's Now a Tower Instead of Taxpayers
description: SEVENTEEN years after abandoning its vision of a second Rockefeller Center east of Times Square, the Durst Organization has apparently given up trying to assemble one last major parcel on the Avenue of the Americas, and will content itself with building one-story shops.

title: Arabs Divided on Call for Talks on Soviet Jews
description: Arab governments are resisting a call by King Hussein of Jordan for a summit meeting in the next few weeks to discuss the prospect of a huge influx of Soviet Jews to Israel, among other issues.

title: Acquiring Art to Show in Public Spaces
description: TOM MORAN, the visual arts coordinator at the State Council on the Arts, oversees the implementation of the Arts Inclusion Act, which provides for the purchase of art for public spaces in state government buildings. Since joining the council in 1982, he has coordinated more than 50 projects that are enlivening the plazas, lobbies and grounds of new and renovated structures built by the state.

title: Corrections
description: The cruise directory on Feb. 4 omitted the European schedule of the Sun Viking of Royal Caribbean Cruise Line. The ship will begin a series of 12-night Mediterranean cruises from Lisbon on May 4. Also scheduled are a 12-night voyage from Lisbon to London on June 9 and a series of 12-night Baltic cruises from London, concluding on Aug. 20 when the ship returns to Lisbon for Mediterranean departures until Oct. 19. Fares range from $2,495 to $5,995.

title: Microphone for Rose
description: His banishment from baseball doesn't apply to baseball broadcasts, so Pete Rose plans to keep his professional interest in the game alive and perhaps kicking this season as a radio commentator.

title: Painless Way to Cut Social Security Deductions;   Call Him Irresponsible?
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth A. Daly Becomes a Bride
description: Elizabeth Anne Daly and Michael David de Verteuil were married yesterday at St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church in New York. The Rev. Samuel B. Matarazzo performed the ceremony. Candace Daly Scottow, the bride's sister, was her matron of honor, and Carl Frederick de Verteuil, the bridegroom's brother, was the best man.

title: Campus Life: Chatham;   After 121 Years, Don't Admit Men Now, Students Say
description: Students at Chatham College, the oldest women's college in Pennsylvania, say they feel abandoned, betrayed and angry over a proposal to admit men to the 121-year-old school.

title: GOOD TIMES IN THE BAD TIMES
description: By Clifton L. Taulbert.

title: Jan Sigmon Wed to Andrew Dworkin
description: Jan Alison Sigmon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jackson Sigmon of Bethlehem, Pa., was married last evening to Andrew L. Dworkin, a son of Ruth Dworkin of New York and the late Bernard Dworkin. Rabbi Joseph Potasnik officiated at the Peninsula Hotel in New York.

title: Clarence (Hap) Day, Hockey Coach, 88
description: Clarence (Hap) Day, who led the Toronto Maple Leafs to six Stanley Cup championships as a player and a coach in the 1930's and 1940's, died today at his home. He was 88 years old.

title:
FOCUS: SAN DIEGO;

A Post-Modern Complex Raises Hackles
description: LEAD: THE AVENTINE, a 12-acre hotel and office complex designed by Michael Graves, the Princeton, N.J., architect who also designed the controversial and still unbuilt expansion of New York's Whitney Museum of American Art, has set off a hot debate here. Some critics say the Post-Modern complex is out of keeping with the city's character and one described it as an ''architectural historian's nightmare.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: I WAS sitting in a lounge at Denver International Airport waiting for my weather-delayed connector out of Cleveland. Somewhere along the route the jet had slammed into a wall of winter, pinning me down in ski-land. On the television behind the bar, some guy dressed like Fred Astaire was brandishing a sleep-drugged groundhog and predicting an early spring.

title: Which Way for the Whitney?
description: Supporters of the Whitney Museum of American Art can only hope that when the institution's trustees meet early next month to discuss, among other things, the future of Thomas N. Armstrong 3d, the museum's embattled director, they will devote considerable time to a related but larger issue. Missing amid the charges of frivolity and aimlessness against Mr. Armstrong and the counter-assertion that he is pioneering in his support for contemporary art has been a blueprint of what the Whitney should be. The storm over Mr. Armstrong has carried the institution to a crossroads. The trustees now have the responsibility to settle a question at least as pressing as whether Mr. Armstrong should keep his job: What is a museum of American art?

title: A NEW LOOK AT WHAT'S IN A NAME
description: Words like Romanticism, Classicism and Serialism, the common coin of musical commentary, can become so worn from continual handling that they lose all value. They take on a mystical fogginess, emphasized by Germanic capitalization, that makes them impressively abstract but worthless as tools for thought.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

>Strike a Balance, Governor, and Don't Forget to Smile
description: LEAD: MEMO to Gov. Jim Florio:

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted.

title: Seeking Landmarks of a Minority Heritage
description: THE rocks where Indians held council over the centuries and a building where black girls and women attended school in the 1830's are among the Connecticut sites on the National Register of Historic Places. But most places around the state that reflect the history of women and minorities are not recognized, and the Connecticut Historical Commission intends to change that.

title: Japan's Ruling Party Holds a Slight Edge as It Heads Into a Heated Election
description: An unusually hard-fought election campaign ended today with most opinion surveys indicating that the Liberal Democratic Party of Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu would win a slim majority of seats in the lower house of the Japanese Parliament.

title: Boerum Hill
description: To the Editor:

title: Murder in an English Village
description: To the Editor:

title: Renee Reichmann, Real Estate Figure, Dies in Canada at 91
description: Renee Reichmann, the mother of three brothers who quietly built Canada's largest real-estate concern, Olympia & York Developments Ltd., died on Tuesday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Toronto. She was 91 years old and lived in Toronto.

title: The Art of Turning Ethnicity Into Entertainment
description: ''Ethnic Dance'' is the usual label affixed to any troupe that looks foreign and whose offerings are not in the realm of modern dance or ballet. The latest entrants would seem to be the Don Cossacks from the Soviet Union and the Jose Greco Company of Spanish Dancers, Singers and Musicians - two groups that are stirring up enthusiastic audiences this month.

title: CRIME
description: Time stills and then stops altogether for SAND CASTLES (Mysterious Press, $17.95), in which Nicolas Freeling unceremoniously restores to life his well-beloved Dutch detective, Commissaris Piet van der Valk, whom he killed off in ''Aupres de Ma Blonde'' almost two decades ago. Literal-minded readers might find some inconsistencies about this miraculous raising of the dead, but these fade in the considerable pleasure of accompanying the detective and his wife on a holiday tour of the northern Netherlands.

description: CLASSICAL

title: Teachers Know It's an Uphill Struggle
description: After reading Mathias B. Freese's article, ''Teachers Have No Chance to Give Their Best'' (Long Island Opinion, Jan. 21), I feel compelled to respond to the blatant cynicism expressed by the author.

title: Food;   All for One
description: I LIKE BEING A BACHELOR, BUT ALONG WITHJU most of my single friends, I don't always look forward to dinner at home. My refrigerator is a lonely place, occupied by condiments (some dating back to college), fruit, vegetables and mysteries that I call science projects. In the little hanging bin labeled ''Meats,'' I keep film, batteries and medicine for my dog, Ilyia.

title: Pastimes;   Stamps
description: On Feb. 20, 1962, at 3:30 P.M. Eastern Standard Time, John Glenn became the first American to orbit Earth. At the same hour on the same day, the United States released a stamp that had been designed and printed in secret and distributed to 305 post offices.

title: A Death Warrant for Tigers?
description: LEAD: As Billy Arjan Singh, one of India's foremost conservationists and the world's leading expert on solitary big cats, says, ''While the tiger may be behind us in intellect, he's got some qualities we lack.''

description: ADULT ENTERTAINMENT

title: Teachers Know It's an Uphill Struggle
description: ''Teachers Have No Chance To Give Their Best'' is the lament of Mathias B. Freese's article, yet Freese keeps teaching English. A saving remnant, perhaps. I stopped teaching English more than 10 years ago on a beautiful springlike morning.

title: Who Inherits the Future of a Quake Orphan?
description: Jimmy Brown has chubby cheeks and two new teeth, and this week he got his first vaccination. He knows how to shake his head ''no'' and wave goodbye, and he leaves sticky fingerprints on the television screen.

title: Melvyn Hester and Laura Pires Marry
description: The marriage of Laura J. Pires and Melvyn F. Hester took place in New York yesterday at Riverside Church. The Rev. Dr. James A. Forbes Jr., the senior minister at the church, officiated, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Sam G. Hines.

title: >Fund Offers Aid To Children With Severe Illnesses
description: LEAD: FOUR-YEAR-OLD Ryan Damrau was born with a hole in his heart and enough other medical problems to fill a pediatric textbook.

MUSIC;

Italian Soprano to Join State Opera's 'Butterfly'
description: LEAD: THE Italian soprano Adriana Maliponte, who has sung leading roles with major opera companies around the world, will sing ''Madama Butterfly'' for the first time with the New Jersey State Opera.

title: Good or Just Lucky?
description: No doubt about it, it has been a spectacular few months for George Bush.

title: Third Executive Resigns at Corcoran Gallery
description: The Corcoran Gallery of Art has announced the resignation of Bruce H. Yenawine, dean of the Corcoran School of Art. His resignation leaves the gallery with its top three senior positions unfilled.

title: RHAPSODY IN AMERICAN
description: COPLAND

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Inside the garage, my foundation wall has two hairline cracks oozing a steady stream of sand. What can be causing this?

title: S.R.O. in Moscow
description: Mstislav Rostropovich had his audience all but dancing in the aisles last week when he returned to the Soviet Union for the first time in 16 years and gave a concert of other Russians' greatest hits. Mr. Rostropovich, who was forced out of the Soviet Union in 1974 after his career hit a dead end over his support for Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, drew curtain call after curtain call on the conclusion of a program at the Moscow Conservatory that included symphonies by Tchaikovsky and Shostakovich. Mr. Rostropovich and his wife, Galina Vishnevskaya, a soprano, were feted and fawned upon, but the two, whose stripped citizenship was recently restored, did not shirk from pushing the Government toward further change. Speaking of Mr. Solzhenitsyn and other emigres who are still barred from the Soviet Union, Miss Vishnevskaya said, ''These people were stabbed in the back by their own country. Legislation should be passed so as not to allow that ever to happen again.''

title: WITH RETURN OF MANDELA, HIS WIFE IS RESCUED FROM POLITICAL OBLIVION
description: A year ago, Winnie Mandela was held in disgrace by the anti-apartheid movement for condoning what was widely described as bullying and brutality by her young bodyguards.

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Romania;   ROMANIAN LEADERS COURTING MILITARY
description: The provisional Government's abrupt dismissal of Defense Minister Nicolae Militaru on Friday after days of protests by army officers is the latest step in its troubled quest for post-revolutionary credibility.

title: Question Of the Week;   What Do You Think of The Baseball Impasse?
description: Owners collude to hold free-agent costs down, or they engage in cutthroat bidding wars that lead to absurdly inflated contracts for journeymen players. Neither the owners nor the players seem to recognize any common interest with the fans. Get the fans to walk away, and one fine day the whole enterprise will collapse like a house of bubble-gum baseball cards.

title: India Barring Foreign Journalists From Turbulent Kashmir
description: The Indian Government is barring foreign journalists from the Kashmir Valley, where a separatist movement has been growing for more than a year.

title: Europe's Grand Classics of Skiing;   Legends of Style And Diversity In Switzerland
description: PERHAPS the biggest attraction for American skiers in the Alps is that generally the resorts there - unlike the Northeast and the Rockies - were not created for skiing. They are essentially villages that were always there, amid magnificent mountain terrain on which winter sports were easily grafted. Visiting skiers relish the expanse, the wildness, the European atmosphere and, of course, good food and wine. Progress and modernization have taken their toll, but skiers can still satisfy expectations, especially in the grand classics, the old resorts that have made efforts to cling to their charm, and remain playgrounds for the wealthy and fashionable. But even the rich cannot rely on the weather. This winter's early snow melted in a warm spell. Early February was a time of hope.

title: A Condo Plan For Downtown
description: A $16 MILLION, 70-unit condominium project - the first major new condominium proposed since the early 1980's - is being planned for a downtown site by the Hammond-Pacific Development Company.

title: Thai Food Prettily Presented
description: WELCOME news for the jaded palates of restaurant habitues has been the influx of Thai restaurants in Connecticut in recent years. Newest on the scene is Mhai Thai in Greenwich, which earns high marks for its looks as well as its cuisine.

title: When State's Ombudsman Steps In
description: LEAD: ASK anyone who has had to maneuver his way through the maze of bureaucracy and chances are that there will be a tale of woe - often ending with some variation of the plea, ''Isn't there anyone out there who can help?''

title: When Self-Consciousness Became King
description: ''Culture and Commentary, an 80's Perspective,'' at the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden, is that rarity in the world of contemporary art, an ambitious and coherent theme show in which the work of every artist - even those as overexposed as Jenny Schnabel and Cindy Sherman - makes more sense than it did before.

title: Canada

title: Arbitration Record

title: Designer Finds Career In Buttons and Bows

She selected some silver fish and blue stones and strung them together in a combination she called Cousteau, creating a ponytail holder or braclet for her spring collection.

title: Hanging Wall Cabinets
description: HANGING wall cabinets, even an individual cabinet, can be a tricky task for amateurs. But by planning the job beforehand, using the proper tools and fasteners and having at least one helper, a good job can be done without too much trouble.

title: Going to Trial
description: Pressure has been rising on Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. of Washington to resign, but he appears determined to face at least one more set of voters - 12 of them. Mr. Barry, who entered a drug and alcohol clinic in Florida last month after his arrest on cocaine possession charges, was indicted last week on five misdemeanor drug charges and three felony counts of perjury. Mr. Barry, who under law would have to resign if convicted of a felony, said the indictment was ''a continuation of the political lynching'' being conducted by the Justice Department. City officials called on him to step down after the indictment, but Mr. Barry appeared to welcome the prospect of going to trial as Mayor. ''Now that we will be moving into the courtroom - which is where this case should be tried, not in the press - I am relieved,'' he said. Mr. Barry has steadfastly denied drug use, although authoroities say he was videotaped buying and smoking crack in a Federal sting in January.

Mrs. Martin is the daughter of Mrs. John Felice of Rosemont, Pa., and the late Joseph C. Calabro. Her husband is a son of Ruth Martin of North Miami Beach, Fla., and the late Joseph J. Martin.

title: Long Shot Earns Spot On Pro Basketball Team
description: AT first glance, Greg Grant would appear to have no business playing in the National Basketball Association. He is 5 feet 7 inches tall and weighs 145 pounds. Five years ago, he was a college dropout selling fish in his hometown. He then returned to school and became a standout player at Trenton State College, hardly a collegiate basketball power. Last year he was selected late in the professional draft, and like many in that position he was not expected to earn a place on a N.B.A. roster.

The list isn't infinite; still, it's too long.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Whole Cities Have Sailed by This Driver
description: LEAD: I AM one of those unfortunate people born without a sense of direction. When I am in a car on the Merritt Parkway or Interstate 95, and looking for an exit, a sign that directs me north or south leaves me with strictly even-money choice. This is also true of a sign that directs me east or west. They usually spring the signs on me when I am driving blithely along at 55 miles an hour with several acres of impatient traffic close behind me.

title: An Island In Limbo
description: IN THE TOWN OF GUANICA IN SOUTHWESTERN PUERTO Rico, a stone monument commemorates July 25, 1898, the day the village awakened to cannon blasts. That morning, people fled to the cane fields; among the few who remained to watch troops disembarking from the three battleships anchored in Guanica's turquoise bay was Agustin Berrenechea, the town commissioner. Soon, an American general arrived on shore and, through an interpreter, offered Berrenechea the same job under new management and a new flag.

For Mrs. Cuevas and other employees at the hospital and at the adjacent Park Avenue Health Care Center, where Puddle

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;

Turning Around Atlantic City's Inlet Area
description: LEAD: OVER the last three years the focus of revitalization in Atlantic City has been the northeast reaches of the Inlet, a 101-acre oceanfront community shattered by neglect, suburban flight and economic hard times. Where once there was a string of grand old homes there are now cratered, rubble-strewn lots and abandoned buildings.

title: SHARON TAKES AIM AT SHAMIR'S POST
description: Dozens of supporters are planning to lie down across the road here in front of Ariel Sharon's northern Negev ranch early Sunday morning to stop him from driving to Jerusalem for the Cabinet meeting where he plans to resign.

title: Mortimer Edelstein, Lawyer, 85
description: Mortimer Edelstein, a lawyer who was assistant general counsel to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey before he became a partner in the law firm of Paul, Weiss, Wharton & Garrison, died on Thursday at his home in Longboat Key, Fla., where he had retired in 1977. He was 85 years old.

title: Riding the 'Junk' Whirlwind
description: Despite the swift demise last week of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the ''junk bond'' market seems certain to survive, money managers, analysts and traders said. But the form that it will take is not clear, they said, and in the short term, as the Drexel network of lenders is dismantled, some highly leveraged companies will have to scramble to find new sources of financing.

title: Now, to Negotiate The Contours of Apartheid's End
description: THE old man who walked out of the prison farm near Cape Town a week ago was proof even to South Africa's critics that President F. W. de Klerk was serious about changing the universally despised system of apartheid. The unconditional release of Nelson Mandela, now 71 years old, was more than a concession to the world, for it set in motion a process that the Government hopes will produce a new constitution giving the black majority long overdue political rights without jeopardizing the interests of the white minority. ''In this connection, Mr. Nelson Mandela could play an important part,'' Mr. de Klerk told Parliament when he said Mr. Mandela would be freed.

title: Massachusetts Armory Seized By Sheriff With Crowded Jail
description: Over the objections of the state, a sheriff, fed up with months of overcrowding at the county jail here, has commandeered a National Guard armory and says he will temporarily house prisoners there ''to keep the peace.''

title: PERSPECTIVES: Assessments;   The Uneven Impact of the Rise in Values
description: IN a report issued in January by the office of the State Comptroller, New York City's assessors are likened to the mythological King Tantalus, who was condemned to stand chin deep in a pool of water in Hades.

title: THE MAN FROM NARNIA
description: C. S. LEWIS

title: FICTION
description: GREAT BLACK RUSSIAN: A Novel on the Life and Times of Alexander Pushkin. By John Oliver Killens. (Wayne State University, $22.95.) How did it happen that Alexander Pushkin, descendant of an Ethiopian prince known as ''the Negro of Peter the Great,'' came to be the most brilliant poet of the Russian language? A mystery of genius, according to the novelist and scholar John Oliver Killens, in which Pushkin's African heritage was as enigmatic an influence as his mother's withheld love and his lifelong sense of identification with the lowly peasants of the Russian steppes. Killens's novel is admirable for finally giving weight to the 19th-century poet's fascination with his African lineage, an element of his biography largely ignored by Pushkin scholars. And yet, its maladroit title notwithstanding, ''Great Black Russian'' admirably avoids any polemics about race, dealing with the firebrand poet as the complex, puzzling character he was. Here is Pushkin the man, the writer, the African, the Russian, the aristocrat, the revolutionary, the womanizer and the husband. In wildly erratic but somehow mesmerizing prose, Killens (who died in 1987, shortly after completing this novel) takes us from Pushkin's youth, first as an unloved child and then a debauched teen-ager, through his young manhood as a revolutionary poet idolized by the people and exiled by a threatened Czar, to the prime of his productivity, his restricted life at the imperial court, his ill-conceived marriage and his death in a duel in 1837. The book can be maddening, juxtaposing powerful passages like a description of mass baptismal rites on the frozen Neva River with painful, cliche-ridden sex scenes, but it manages nonetheless to capture the essence of Pushkin's greatness - that he was a man who loved his people enough to give them a voice.

title: Up-to-the-Minute Scores From the Revolution in the East Bloc
description: THE SPRING OF 1990 holds the promise of momentous transformations as the nations of Eastern Europe hold elections in their quest for democracy, and as a disengaged Soviet Union strives to forge ahead with change amid an explosion of internal conflicts. Marc D. Charney and Anne Zusy of The Week in Review compiled a country-by-country look at where things stand in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.
