description: People are in lines wrapped around the firehouse in this small borough 35 miles southwest of Philadelphia, but they aren't waiting for barbecued chicken dinners or free rides on the old fire engine.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Gaps Filled In Australia's Airline Strike

title: World Markets;   Volatility in South Africa's Markets
description: Humphrey Borkum, a director of South Africa's largest brokerage house, wasn't surprised by what Nelson Mandela said when he was released last week from prison after more than 27 years. But other players in the South African stock market apparently were.

title: Brazil's President-Elect Is Lifting Some Hopes
description: Optimism, a rare commodity in Brazil until recently, is back in fashion as a wide spectrum of Brazilians are pinning their hopes on the country's young President-elect, a new poll indicates.

title: The Quest for Quiet Takes On An Urgent Note
description: IT would be nice to say I became an anti-noise activist to make Larchmont a quieter place for everyone; but in fact it was to make Larchmont a quieter place for me. I got into the fight for peace and serenity more than nine years ago - and have been raising a ruckus about it ever since.

title: Campus Life: Miami;   Week of Protests Against Increase In Tuition
description: Wearing black armbands ''to mourn the death of affordable tuition at U.M.,'' students at the University of Miami held demonstrations last week to protest higher charges.

title: Q and A
description: Viennese Balls

title: Organizer Bans Liquor At Antidrug Fund Raiser
description: PEOPLE don't need liquor to have a good time. That is the message of an alcohol-free dinner dance scheduled for March 3 in Shelton.

title: Correction
description: An article on Jan. 28 about United States policy toward illegal immigrants from Central America misidentified a former Immigration Commissioner. He is Alan C. Nelson.

title: Commission Gains Support To Propose Tax Changes
description: LEAD: A COMMISSION to propose tax-cutting measures and place them before voters in advisory referendums as soon as next November has gained influential support in Nassau and Suffolk Counties as a promising method for holding down living costs on the Island.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: MAPLE SUGARING TIME

title: Yes, Send Black Schoolchildren to See 'Glory'
description: To the Editor:

title: Selma's Schools Superintendent Sues Board
description: The city's first black Superintendent of Schools has sued the white-majority school board, whose vote not to renew his contract has brought weeks of racial turmoil here.

title: PANAMA: OUR DANGEROUS LIAISON
description: DIVORCING THE DICTATOR

title: 2 Small Bombs Go Off At Markets in Georgia
description: Small bombs exploded in two grocery stores in this Atlanta suburb this afternoon, shortly after the stores were evacuated because of telephoned bomb threats.

title: Vladimir Shcherbitsky, 71, Dies; Former Ukraine Communist Chief
description: Vladimir V. Shcherbitsky, a hard-line former member of the Soviet Communist Party Politburo and chief of the Ukrainian Communist Party for 17 years, died on Friday after a long illness, a day before his 72d birthday, the official press agency Tass reported today.

title: Wall Street;   Rocky Times for Trump's Bonds By DIANA B. HENRIQUES
description: Donald J. Trump's marriage is not the only one of his important relationships that is not working out these days. His rapport with the ''junk bond'' market - whose contribution to his success arguably approaches that of his estranged wife, Ivana - has become equally rocky.

title: Imaginary Shopping Spree Is Draped in Yesterday's Style
description: LEAD: BROWSING is invited at ''Born to Shop,'' an exhibition at the Costume Museum of the New Canaan Historical Society. Vintage clothing is displayed in six simulated stores, each representing one era between 1860 and 1930.

title: An American Sendup Of the British Royals
description: IN ''Rumors in the Palace,'' Enid Rudd's two-character sendup of royal tradition, British style, the oversexed future king (Arthur) and his frigid teen-age princess (Vivian, or Vi) play, teasingly, with plastic water guns. Before long, their fun and games are aimed toward kinky sex. Years later, in a hot tub, where the prince is playing with his little boat, they have a spat over mutual infidelities, and Vi tosses fried chicken nuggets at Artie. By the time they are enthroned, this king and queen of England have been diminished to blathering buffoons.

title: Reviews/Music;   A New Old-Instruments Ensemble
description: The Classical Band, New York's first major attempt to create a period-instruments orchestra, is in the midst of its inaugural season. Wednesday evening's all-Beethoven concert at Carnegie Hall, the ensemble's first under a conductor other than its founder, Trevor Pinnock, had its palpable charms. But it also suggested that the orchestra is still very much feeling its way.

title: Battered Beirut Militia Fights On Against General
description: Lebanon's embattled Christian militia coalition, vowing to fight on despite losing main strongholds in East Beirut, mounted an attack today against an army base north of here where 500 troops loyal to Gen. Michel Aoun have been holding out.

title: POSTINGS: An A.I.A. Guest;   The Prince on Architecture
description: The Prince of Wales, who has been sharply critical of some of the newer examples of modern architecture and urban planning in England, will share his ideas with 600 of this nation's leading architects on Thursday during a visit to Washington.

title: Sulaiman Seen As Ready to Quit
description: Jose Sulaiman, the World Boxing Council president, is reportedly ready to resign because of the controversy surrounding the Mike Tyson-Buster Douglas fight.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Outing;   A Place Where Flowers Come In From the Cold
description: Though spring is officially more than a month away, there is always something blooming at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. Situated on 250 acres of hills, gardens, forest and streams, the garden offers an abundance of green growing things to winter-weary visitors.

title: Group Show at a New Gallery
description: THE Washington Street Gallery, which opened last October, is a center for the arts without the trappings that normally go with such enterprises.

title: Changing Thoughts on Furs
description: TEN years ago, I finally got the full-length mink coat I'd wanted for years. It was then considered the elegant, mature woman's symbol of taste and class and had the unique advantage of ''fitting in'' wherever it was worn, whether over a pair of jeans to the supermarket, to a funeral or covering sequins on their way to a New Year's Eve formal.

title: Megan Tracy Engaged To Mark William Shea
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gerard B. Tracy of New Canaan, Conn., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Megan Anne Tracy and Mark William Shea, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer C. Shea of West Brighton, S.I.

title: Castro's Captive
description: LEAD:

title: Georges Forest; Canadian Language Campaigner, 65
description: Georges Forest, Manitoba's most prominent champion of French-language rights, died on Wednesday night, apparently of a heart attack. He was 65 years old.

title: FICTION COMES TO THE KILLING FIELDS
description: FOR THE SAKE OF ALL LIVING THINGS

title: Heterosexuals and AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;

Dealing With High Hopes at Auctions
description: LEAD: AFTER trying to market a six-bedroom, five-bath restored manor in Old Brookville for more than a year, Robert Praver, a custom-home builder with offices in Lattingtown, decided to put it up for auction with the right to reject too low an offer.

title: Campus Life: UC, Irvine;   Shantytown Sit-In Protests Change In Housing Rule
description: A makeshift shantytown that was raised on Feb. 6 in the shadow of the administration building at the University of California at Irvine is challenging a new policy that bars non-traditional couples, including homosexuals and lesbians, from living together in housing for married students.

title: A Woman's Middle Years
description: To the Editor:

title: Hurting at Illinois
description: ''It hurts,'' said Morton Weir, the University of Illinois chancellor. ''I've been here for 30 years and I feel strongly about this place. It just eats away at me to see the kinds of things being said and written about us. I'm frustrated.''

title: The Sahara
description: To the Editor: I seriously question the propriety of featuring the article by Erik Sandberg-Diment (''Across the Sahara by Car,'' Dec. 31). As adults, the Sandberg-Diments have every right to risk their lives by traveling through that unpredictable and hostile environment. I am appalled, however, that they were accompanied by their children, especially a 7-year-old. It is highly unlikely that children of that age could exercise judgment concerning the dangers that such a journey entails.

title: Fashion;   Spreading Style at Lower Prices
description: Oscar is doing it, and so is Calvin. So, in fact, are Geoffrey and Bill. What Oscar de la Renta, Calvin Klein, Geoffrey Beene and Bill Blass are doing is knocking themselves off in lower-priced lines that have the potential of reaching many more customers and ringing up millions of dollars more in sales.

title: TAKING BACK THE GIFT OF TONGUES
description: LEAD: THREE PATHS TO THE LAKE

title: Style Makers;   Berdie Stein, Frame Designer
description: An almost universal reaction to ''My Frame,'' which was conceived by Berdie Stein, is ''How come no one thought of it before?'' But no one did and that's why children's art was, until last year, usually stuck on refrigerator doors or taped on walls. And that's how the company ''My Art'' was born.

title: Parallel Seen in Mandela Release And Shifts to Black Rule in Africa
description: Black African leaders have greeted the release of Nelson Mandela with caution, emphasizing that it is only a beginning. But they nevertheless see a parallel between the emerging situation in South Africa and the move from white colonial rule to black majority rule in several black African countries, particularly Kenya.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf

title: 'Challenger' Looks At the Human Side Of the Disaster
description: ''Challenger,'' a TV film about the shuttle disaster that will be broadcast next Sunday evening at 8 on ABC, begins with an auspicious claim of factual authenticity. While most other docudramas merely give notice at the end of the credits that they are based on a book or two, this production offers a lengthy message that appears in white letters on a black screen. Read by a disembodied voice, it informs viewers that the dramatization was based on personal interviews, a variety of journalistic accounts and Government investigations, that scenes were filmed at the Johnson Space Center and that ''this picture was researched with the consultation of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.''

title: INSIDE
description: The Freeing of Mandela, At Home and Abroad

title: Drawings From a Distant Era, Photos of More Recent Vintage
description: THOSE who feared the Wadsworth Atheneum was going to wrack and ruin when it showed the photographs of Robert Mapplethorpe may take heart from its eminently respectable ''Mannerism to Modernism.''

title: Data Bank/February 18, 1990
Mystery Master Gives His Town a Gift. It's Murder
description: EVERYBODY had a soft spot for 16-year-old Sally Anders. Friends and family members described her as sweet and responsible, an average teen-ager who looked forward to school dances, sang in the church choir and auditioned for the school play. Why then, asked residents of her quiet Connecticut town, would someone want to murder her? Sally was such a nice, proper girl. Or was she? Through the words and thoughts of detectives and the victim's friends, the mystery writer Hillary Waugh cleverly unravels the answer in ''Death in a Town,'' published by Carroll & Graf, a classic whodunit that follows the investigation after the brutal slaying of a teen-age baby sitter. Set in Guilford (disguised in the novel as Crockford), the book also explores how rumors and accusations can ultimately destroy a community.

title: Review/Music;   Yefim Bronfman and Prokofiev Piano Fireworks
description: In his Carnegie Hall piano recital in December, Yefim Bronfman spent most of his time playing 19th-century Germanic music, with mixed results, but then scored a huge success with Stravinsky's Three Movements from ''Petrushka.''

title: Stephanie Enis to Wed Perry Loesberg in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerome H. Enis of Manalapan, N.J., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter, Stephanie Barri Enis, and Perry Alan Loesberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack P. Loesberg of Potomac, Md.

title: Town and Village at Odds Over a Joint Municipal Center
description: LEAD: A DISPUTE over a new municipal building in Ossining has touched off one of the most bitter political feuds between town and village officials in recent memory.

title: Sandra Pinnavaia Is Engaged To Marry
description: Sandra Marie Pinnavaia, the daughter of Professor and Mrs. Thomas J. Pinnavaia of East Lansing, Mich., and Guy Moszkowski of Buenos Aires and Paris and the late Dr. Erica F. Moszkowski, plan to marry in September.

title: Fight for Leather Coat Is Blamed in Subway Death
description: A 32-year-old security guard was stabbed to death on a subway train in Brooklyn early yesterday, after he refused to give his leather coat to youths who had threatened him moments earlier on a subway platform, the police said.

title: Strategies for the Softer Resale Market
description: JEREMIAH COLE sold his Chelsea co-op in a week by trimming his price and offering brokers 8 percent instead of the normal 6 percent commission.

title: Report of Riots in Soviet Republic Is Denied
description: A regional Communist Party leader today denied reports of rioting in the republic of Uzbekistan, and another top official said the rumors were aimed at inflaming ethnic tensions in the neighboring republic of Tadzhikistan.

title: Europe's Grand Classics of Skiing;   Italian Towns Of Variety
description: PERHAPS the biggest attraction for American skiers in the Alps is that generally the resorts there - unlike the Northeast and the Rockies - were not created for skiing. They are essentially villages that were always there, amid magnificent mountain terrain on which winter sports were easily grafted. Visiting skiers relish the expanse, the wildness, the European atmosphere and, of course, good food and wine. Progress and modernization have taken their toll, but skiers can still satisfy expectations, especially in the grand classics, the old resorts that have made efforts to cling to their charm, and remain playgrounds for the wealthy and fashionable. But even the rich cannot rely on the weather. This winter's early snow melted in a warm spell. Early February was a time of hope.

title:
THEATER;

As One Playwright Strikes Out for the Future . . . Another Tracks His Curiosity Into the Past
description: LEAD: Isadora Duncan is perhaps better known today for the high drama of her life than for her achievements as a pioneering dancer. Her story certainly has the makings of a Greek tragedy. Her two young children drowned when the car in which they were sitting plunged into the Seine; she was later married for a brief, disastrous spell to the mercurial Russian revolutionary poet Sergei Essenin, who hanged himself after they separated, and

title:
GARDENING;

Fruit Trees Spectacular in Bloom
description: LEAD: AMONG the finest flowering trees for the garden are various species and cultivars of the genus Prunus. It includes cherry as well as ornamental and fruit-bearing forms of apricot, peach and plum. All are early flowering and spectacular trees when in bloom, even those with edible fruit.

title: The Earthy Bounty of Umbria
description: UMBRIA, the small, green, hilly, landlocked region of central Italy, is best known in the rest of the world for the Spoleto Festival, the cathedral of Orvieto and St. Francis of Assisi. In Italy it is loved for its natural beauty and quiet civility but most of all for being a good place to eat. Its fruity green olive oil is arguably the finest the country produces. Its woods furnish game birds, and its rivers trout. But what really sets Umbria apart is the pork, the truffles and a rare variety of lentil.

title: Review/Concert;   Speculum Musicae in All-British Bill
description: Speculum Musicae's evening at Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday was called ''Music From the British Isles,'' and three of its four composers seemed to be asking, if not the same question, at least a very similar one: Is it the job of creators to tame chaos or do they find even more profit in exploiting it?

title: Lockout Lessens Clubs' Ability to Rate Players
description: If spring training had started on time the other day, if players were running around fields in bright sunshine in Arizona and Florida, some of them would be finding out just how far they have come back from serious injuries and, in many instances, surgery. More important to their teams, managers would be learning where the players are and how far they had to go before the season starts.

title: Question Of the Week;   What Do You Think of The Baseball Impasse?
description: The whole idea of a lockout is absurd. We faithful fans, numbed by winter, have been looking forward to the new season. And who's responsible for the high salaries, anyway? Certainly not the players. The owners have backed themselves into a corner and are now resorting to very unpleasant methods to get themselves out of it.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu;   Hash Worth the Name But Much Lower in Fat
description: Those familiar with the famous Ritz chicken hash would hardly consider this a reasonable alternative. The original has lots of heavy cream and egg yolks. It is sinfully wonderful, but this chicken hash need make no apology.

title: Fear of Directors
description: To the Editor:

title: SINGING IN TH WOMB
description: COMEDIANS

title: A Festive Bahamas Regatta
description: THE Exumas are like beads off a broken necklace: just when you think you've collected them all, you step on another one. I've been picking them up on and off for almost 20 years, and am still looking. Starting about 35 miles below Nassau, this chain of 365 islands and cays curves southeast for some 150 miles in what many argue is the world's most beautiful water.

title: LIFE IN THE EXECUTIVE SUITE AFTER DREXEL
description: With the demise last week of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., a collective sigh of relief is sweeping the board rooms of corporate America. The collapse of the Wall Street firm, which created the popular ''junk bond,'' is seen as the most convincing evidence yet that the financial fuel for corporate raiders and hostile takeovers is drying up. Now, many executives are looking forward to running their companies without the constant threat of being disrupted by outside intruders.

title: Corrections
description: An answer to a Travel Trivia question in the Travel Watch column on Dec. 31 located the world's second-highest mountain incorrectly. Several readers have written to point out that the mountain, known usually as K2 and also as Godwin Austen, is in the Karakoram range of Pakistan, not in Nepal.

title: A May Wedding For Miss D'Amico
description: Mr. and Mrs. John F. D'Amico of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Suzanne Jean D'Amico to T. Kendrick Sharp Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sharp of Atlanta and Asheville, N.C. A May wedding is planned.

title:
IN SHORT;

NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title:
The View From: Southbury;

Developers Are Waking Up From Their Dream of a Boom
description: LEAD: WHEN Interstate 84 connected Southbury with the rest of the state in 1963, the town's residents braced themselves for a building boom that never came. Southbury remained a quiet residential community known primarily for Heritage Village, a planned retirement community that opened in 1967.

title: $1 a Pound and Nutritious? Squid
description: AT a dollar a pound, which is what it is selling for in Chinatown these days, squid must be the cheapest seafood you can buy. It is also extremely nutritious, being low in fat and calories and high in protein.

title: Cinnie Barnes Plans to Marry
description: Mrs. William Barnes 3d of Decatur, Ill., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Julia Wells Barnes, to Herbert Arthur May 3d, the son of Mrs. May Jr. of Owings Mills, Md., and the late Mr. May. A June wedding is planned. Miss Barnes, 25 years old, graduated from Miss Porter's School and William Smith College. She is a saleswoman at the Brunschwig & Fils furniture and fabric company in New York. Her father was the president, chairman and chief executive officer of the Citizens National Bank in Decatur.

title: Pastimes;   Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Days are getting longer and growth is resuming on house plants. Repot those that need it and take cuttings of any that are overgrown and need trimming. Check plants outdoors for wind and winter injury; prune out any broken or dead limbs, but, in spite of recent mild weather, it is too early to carry out any major garden activities.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

Exercise? Vitamins? Who Needs Health?
description: LEAD: IT'S not enough just to make friends with Exercise, as Cher tells us in those commercials. You have to take Exercise by the throat, throw it against the wall, slap it around and show it who's boss.

title: Jody Guariglia, Executive, Is Married in New Jersey
description: Jody Susan Guariglia, an assistant vice president of the First Chicago Corporation, and Charles Varvaro, a second vice president at Chase Manhattan Bank, both in New York, were married yesterday at the Webb Memorial Chapel in Madison, N.J. The Rev. Dr. William L. Bearden, a Presbyterian minister, and the Rev. Kenneth Grande, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Devils Fight a Losing Battle By ALEX YANNIS
description: The Devils and the Maple Leafs used their heavyweight fighters tonight, perhaps as a result of the proceedings in prior meetings between the teams this season. The game was carefully monitored by the National Hockey League's disciplinarians, and boxing officials would have probably declared the fistfights a draw.

title: Repression Won't Lead To Korean Reunification
description: To the Editor:

title: Friendships Are Spun At Wooly Gatherings
description: LEAD: ON the second Thursday of each month, Jody Hyman of New Milford puts away the toys in her sons' large playroom to make room for her friends, who bring spinning wheels, baskets of sheep fleece and knitting needles when they visit.

title: Q and A
description: Window Guards

title: Managing the Care of Elderly Relatives
description: THERE were 1,500 miles separating Joan K. Pompadur in Hartsdale from her grandmother and aunt in Florida. For years the Florida household had operated fairly smoothly, said Ms. Pompadur, who made periodic trips to Florida to check on her family.

title: China After Tiananmen Square
description: WHO would be the first to mention Tiananmen Square, I wondered as I embarked on a 12-day tour of China in December with 33 other Americans - one of the first large tourist groups back in China since the events of last June 4. The speculation was incredibly naive.

title: WRONGED BY JUSTICE
description: LEAD:

title:
IN SHORT;

NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: No Repertory Rule For Touring Ensembles
description: Happily, among the faults of our beleaguered National Endowment for the Arts is not found a repertory requirement for touring chamber ensembles, as reported in the article about the Da Capo Chamber Players (''Not All Old and Not All New,'' Jan. 7).

title: ASPEN: THE CALL OF THE WILD
description: One of the great privileges of wealth is that it provides the opportunity to travel anywhere, to discover unheard-of places; to meet people of diverse backgrounds; to grow intellectually; to achieve a most important aspect of human existence: new experience.

title: Review/Music;   Misha Dichter Returns to the Schnabel Tradition
description: Misha Dichter's Carnegie Hall recital on Thursday evening, the first of two celebrating the 30th anniversary of his stage debut, was a pleasant surprise. To begin with, the pianist constructed an excellent and demanding program of late Beethoven, late Schubert and late Brahms: repertory, as the advance publicity noted, ''with which he is not usually associated.'' And he played it well enough to make one wonder why on earth not.

title: BEST SELLERS: February 18, 1990
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 5 4 DEVICES AND DESIRES, by P. D. James. (Knopf, $19.95.) Adam Dalgitesh puzzles over a series of killings on the windy Norfolk coast. 2 1 4 THE BAD PLACE by Dean R. Koontz (Putnam, $10.95.) A troubled sleepwalker hires a detective team to discover the causes and consequences of his behavior. 3 3 5 VINELAND, by Thomas Pynchon (Little, Brown ($19.95.) The passions of the 1960's continue to rule the lives of members of a community in Northern California. 4 2 5 A RULING PASSION, by Judith Michael (Poseidon, $19.95.) A young widow's entry into the world of television brings her adventures fraught with love, intrigue, revenge and murder. 5 4 5 COLD HARBOUR, by Jack Higgins (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) Prognostications about political, economic and social developments in the next decade. 2 2 4 BARBARIANS AT THE GATE, by Bryan Burrough and John Helyar (Harper & Row, $22.95.) The 1988 battle for control of RJR Nabisco. 3 3 15 LIAR'S POKER, by Michael Lewis (Norton, $18.95.) Wall Street's tumultuous 1980's, as witnessed by a young bond trader. 4 4 22 IT WAS ON FIRE WHEN I LAY DOWN ON IT, by Robert Fulghum (Villard, $17.95.) A new collection of inspirational essays. 5 6 68 ALL I REALLY NEEDED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, (Villard, $17.95.) A critique of the relationship between politics and the law by Ronald Reagan's Supreme Court nominee. 7 7 4 THE EMPEROR'S NEW MIND, by Roger Penrose (Oxford University, $24.95.) A physicist maintains that computers will never replace human thinking. 8 9 3 THE CUCKOO'S EGG, by Clifford Stoll. (Doubleday, $19.95.) An astrophysicist tells how he stalked a computer hacker from California across America to West Germany. 9* 8 96 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking (Bantam, $18.95.) A rabbi tells how religious commitment can make great differences in our lives. 14 14 20 FROM BEIRUT TO JERUSALEM, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.95.) What a small quarry in the Canadian Rockies has revealed about the past. 16* 4 HEAD FIRST, by Norman Cousins. (Dutton, $19.95.) How the brain affects the body's endocrine and immune systems. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 53 WEALTH WITHOUT RISK, by Charles J. Givens (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) A Florida entrepreneur's advice about how to make a personal fortune. 2 2 10 THE GREAT WALDO SEARCH, by Martin Handford (Little, Brown $10.95.) A book of illustrations in which the game is to find an ubiquitous chap named Waldo. 3 3 26 THE T-FACTOR DIET, by Martin Katahn. (Norton, $18.95.) A new regimen for weight loss. 4 5 176 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $16.95.) A standard reference work, revised and updated. 5 6 17 THE FRUGAL GOURMET COOKS THREE ANCIENT CUISINES, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $18.95.) Recipes from China, Greece and Rome. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States.

title: Fashion;   Latest Name In Designers Discount: Mr. Beene
description: His friends call him Geoffrey, but to his employees he has always been Mr. Beene. And so it is that Mr. Beene, the collection, was named.

title: No Headline
description: For all its glitz, the city of Aspen is pursuing a very unglamorous endeavor in outlawing the sale of fur coats in its local stores. It's a shame this was mentioned only briefly in your article.

title: Campus Life: Arizona State;   Cross Atop Chapel Must Be Removed, A Judge Rules
description: A judge in Phoenix ruled last week that the cross atop Arizona State University's Danforth Chapel must be removed, but allowed Christian groups defending the symbol 30 days to appeal his decision.

title: Japanese Go to Polls Today
description: An unusually hard-fought election campaign ended in Japan, with most opinion surveys indicating that the governing Liberal Democratic Party would win a slim majority in the lower house of Parliament. Page 3.

title: Antiquities Group Delays Land Sale
description: LEAD: COMMUNITY opposition to a preservation society's proposal to sell a parcel of land to developers in Setauket has forced the owners to postpone the action while they look for alternatives. But even as civic groups welcome the reprieve, the owners say that unless the state or county buys the property by

title: Show-'n'-Tell on Safe Driving
description: Hey, I know these guys! There is Sandy Stevens, the driving instructor - I went through a course with him in Rutland, Vt., some years ago. And there is Sam Posey, the racer and television commentator. I followed Posey's pace car, a red Ferrari Boxer, around the track at Lime Rock, Conn., back when I was proving to everybody how truly fumble-thumbed I was at competition.

title: All About/Avionics;   American Electronics Companies Still Rule the Cockpit
description: In 1929, Jimmy Doolittle flew blind - covering the cockpit of his biplane with a hood - to prove that a pilot could rely on flight instruments alone. Since then, cockpit electronics have become sophisticated enough to all but take the place of the pilot.

title: Serena L. Slater Plans to Marry Don A. Wilson
description: May wedding plans for Serena Lyon Slater and Don Andrus Wilson, the son of Mrs. Arthur P. Kaupe of Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Donald A. Wilson, have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Margot M. Slater of Palm Beach and New York and Alexander B. Slater of Locust Valley, L.I., and Aspen, Colo.

title: Elizabeth London To Wed in April
description: Elizabeth Sue London, an administrative aide to Representative Ted Weiss, Democrat of New York, and David Lawrence Piaker, an architect, plan to marry in April.

title: Gotti or No Gotti, The Mafia Looks Infirm These Days
description: FOR John Gotti it was a moment of triumph. Emerging from a Manhattan courthouse where he had just been acquitted on charges of assault and conspiracy, he was enveloped by a wave of cheers from a waiting throng. But that acclaim nine days ago could signal the last hurrah for America's Mafia or La Cosa Nostra.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: A BIT OF HISTORY

title: Police Report a Bank Robber Made His Getaway on a Bus
description: The man who robbed the Westfarms Mall branch of the Farmington Savings Bank on Friday walked out with an estimated $3,900 in mixed bills and then hopped on a bus headed down New Britain Avenue for Hartford, the police said.

title: Warning About Products' Dangers
description: LEAD: FOR the past year, the Connecticut Fund for the Environment has been working to tell parents, teachers and day-care providers about commonly used art supplies, like markers, paint and glue, that could hurt or poison children. Now, a $10,000 grant will allow the fund to focus on toxins in household cleaning supplies and lawn-care products.

title: Rally by Redmen Falls Short
description: Carlton Screen ran the show, the rest of the Providence Friars ran the floor and Lou Carnesecca, the St. John's coach, nearly ran into the stands last night as St. John's lost to Providence, 77-74.

title: Singapore
description: To the Editor: Having just read Steven Erlanger's piece on ''What's Doing in Singapore'' (Travel, Dec. 24), I have two comments. First, the article failed to mention one of the greatest pleasures of travel in Singapore - food.

title: Union Housing Offer Attracts No Takers
description: LEAD: ARTHUR COLOSANTO and the 16 construction unions he represents thought they had an offer no one could refuse. They offered the financing and manpower to build or rehabilitate affordable housing in Westchester and Putnam Counties to match the needs of any community that wanted it. So far, they have found some interest but no takers.

title: New York's Census Is a Campaign: Stand Up and Don't Be Undercounted
description: On a recent Sunday morning, before Mass had ended, the pastor of St. Catherine of Genoa church in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn announced a visitor. Parishioners stirred in their pews as the guest approached the front of the altar, then turned to face the congregation, made up mostly of immigrants from Haiti and other Caribbean lands.

title:
GARDENING;

Fruit Trees Spectacular in Bloom
description: LEAD: AMONG the finest flowering trees for the garden are various species and cultivars of the genus Prunus. It includes cherry as well as ornamental and fruit-bearing forms of apricot, peach and plum. All are early flowering and spectacular trees when in bloom, even those with edible fruit.

title: In Pupil 'Tracks,' Many See a Means Of Resegregation
description: THE battles over voting rights, school integration and public accommodations have long been more or less settled, but some blacks in the South say they now face subtler forms of discrimination. In education, they say, it shows up in public school ''tracking'' systems, and the issue was at the heart of black protests here last week.

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: THE PRICE THEY PAY: OLDER CHILDREN AND DIVORCE
description: THEY WERE MORE SANGUINE ABOUT Laura. She was, after all, in college and on the far side of growing up. They said she had loosened her tether to the family and was no longer hostage to the twists of their fate. They allowed that she would be shaken for a time by their divorce, but insisted that before long she would find her balance and regain her stride. Her younger brothers, on the other hand, were a constant source of nagging concern. At home and in the eye of the storm, they were in closer range and at higher risk. But Laura, they said, was less vulnerable. Not to worry, Laura would be fine.

title: Question Of the Week;   What Do You Think of The Baseball Impasse?
description: It is impossible to feel sorry for either side, impossible to take seriously the question of whose shameless greed is slightly less unjustified. Clearly, there is more than enough money to go around.

title: Social Events
description: Art Over the Centuries

title: About Men;   The Case For Grad School
description: AT LAST IT HAPPENED. Four years of college, one more for good measure - all told a half-decade of great books and gregarious nights and green lawns and girls - and then one day some malignant force somewhere, some vile conspiracy of time and teachers and empty-pocketed parents had the nerve to hand me a diploma. I barely had the chance to read the thing, let alone get it framed, before that very same malignant force picked me up and hurled me, howling, through the air toward life.

title:
THEATER;

As One Playwright Strikes Out for the Future . . .
description: LEAD: A few months ago, as homage to the playwright and hors d'oeuvres to its subscribers, the Second Stage Theater offered a revival of Steve Tesich's ''Baba Goya,'' a fond domestic frolic last seen here in 1973. Occasions of this sort commonly sun a playwright's soul and lubricate his vanity. To his chagrin, this playwright emerged from the experience persuaded that he would never again involve himself in the staging of one of his old works.

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: The Germanys;   The West's Balloons and Slogans Come to the East's Political Arena
description: Eberhard Diepgen, former Mayor of West Berlin and the leader of its Christian Democrats, promised a cheering crowd here today that a vote on March 18 for his party's candidates, combined with hard work and a rejection of all socialist experiments, would bring prosperity under a united Germany.

title: WESTCHESTER Q&A;: JED E. MOWSHOWITZ16-Year-Old Opens a Door on Genetics
description: LEAD: JED E. MOWSHOWITZ of Larchmont is not your typical 16-year-old. For starters, the Mamaroneck High School senior expects to enter college next year as a sophomore, and even then perhaps take graduate-level courses in science. (He has already skipped his junior year in high school.) While some of his fellow students are struggling with Shakespeare, he is fascinated with Nietzsche.

title: Campus Life: Tufts;   Students Protest a Plan to Freeze Financial Aid
description: Students at Tufts University boycotted classes and rallied on Thursday to protest a freeze on financial aid that they say could leave some needy students without assistance.

title: Japanese Composers Delve Into the Past for Their Future
description: Orchestral music in Japan has a history at least as old as jazz in America. Although the musical language of many Japanese composers remains rooted in an internationalist style (especially the ''color-field'' style so prevalent here and in Europe since the 60's, best exemplified by composers such as Witold Lutoslawski or Gyorgy Ligeti), it is being molded with confidence into a more typically ''Japanese'' character. The love of past ideals and the search for a way to infuse them into the present appears to be a major trend.

title: Bogged Down In the Baroque
description: To the Editor:

title:
ART;

3 Artists Pursue Singular Theme in Related Work
description: LEAD: AS its title implies, ''1+1+1,'' the exhibition at the Anthony Giordano Gallery of Dowling College in Oakdale, is the sum of a trio of separate but equal parts.

title: The Anti-Dumping Laws Do Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Donors To Neediest Are Unknown
description: Among the fattest files to accumulate during the 78th annual New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which is nearing its conclusion, is the one containing requests that donors not be identified.

title: Post-Modern Complex Raises Hackles in San Diego
description: LEAD: The Aventine, a 12-acre hotel and office complex designed by Michael Graves, the Princeton, N.J., architect who also designed the controversial and still unbuilt expansion of New York's Whitney Museum of American Art, has set off a hot debate here. Some critics say that the Post-Modern complex is out of keeping with the city's character and one described the project as an ''architectural historian's nightmare.

title: Upheaval in the East: Has Castro Caught the Bug?;   Cubans Outline Plan to 'Perfect' Communist Rule
description: Cuba's Communist Party leadership today announced what it described as plans for deep reforms in the country's political system. But its statement made it clear that Cuba was not abandoning one-party Communist rule.

title: PATRIARCH FOR HIRE
description: LEAD:

title: CORRECTION
description: The Mutual Funds table last Sunday gave incorrect headings for two columns showing percentage change. One column was for January, not December, and the other was for 1990, not 1989.

title: Concertgoing for Those on a Budget
description: IF the high cost of concertgoing is keeping you away from the music you love, consider the performances without admission charge available this week. Today at 3 o'clock, for instance, you can choose between a recital by the pianist Heather Hamilton and friends at the University of Bridgeport (255-0159) and a program of pieces for woodwinds and strings by the William Street Chamber Players at the Yale Center for British Art (432-2850).

title: STREETSCAPES: The Bloomingdale's Block;   Five Little Brownstones and How They Survived
description: AS Bloomingdale's and its parent, Federated Department Stores, seek to reorganize in the wake of bankruptcy proceedings, the store's unusual, low-rise home on a block site - 59th to 60th Streets, Lexington to Third Avenues - also is attracting notice. Any attempts to sell off the store itself would be affected by the split ownership of the property. The land under the store is still owned by the Bloomingdale family and the land lease expires in 16 years (2006), a relatively short time to a potential buyer.

title: Teachers Know It's An Uphill Struggle
description: I hope that Mr. Freese feels better after his whining diatribe on the shortcomings of his students appeared in the Long Island section. Teachers like Mr. Freese indeed ''have no chance to give their best.'' His contempt for his students and their parents is evident.

title: A New Sport For New Yorkers
description: ALL that money! All that sex! All that blond hair! Tout le monde dined out on Donald and Ivana Trump last week after the news broke that the brash billionaire intended to divest himself of Trump, The Mrs. Strangers in barrooms argued over how just much of Mr. Trump's many, many millions Mrs. Trump should get after 13 years and three children. Tabloid newspapers tangled like pit bulls over tidbits such as what, besides tears, was served at Mrs. Trump's midweek birthday party, which fell - puckish fate! - on Valentine's Day. Reporters camped on the doorsteps of everybody who had ever known Marla Maples, the alleged ''other woman,'' a model and actress.

title: MATRONS WITH STICKY FINGERS
description: WHEN LADIES GO A-THIEVING

title: Events for Children on Vacation
description: LEAD: WITH many of the children in the county on midwinter vacation this week, various organizations have scheduled activities to challenge the youngsters' intellect, to introduce them to new areas of interest or simply to entertain them.

title: Experience Is Lacking
description: One of the preliminaries to today's Daytona 500 was a 200-mile race last Sunday sanctioned by the Automobile Racing Club of America as part of its Permatex Super Car series. The series is a training ground for Nascar's Winston Cup tour, the stock car major league.

title: Long Island Journal
description: Love Bytes

title: Corrections
description: The Practical Traveler column on Sept. 10 misstated the policy of Trans World Airlines on bereavement fares. The one-third refund for an airline ticket to a family member's funeral applies only to full fares, not to discounts. The Times queried T.W.A. in October after receiving a reader complaint; T.W.A. replied in early February.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island;   Recent Sales
description: Fort Salonga $230,000

title: Dining: ON THEIR OWN
description: The designer Bill Blass perks up when the subject comes up. A popular man about town wherever he is, Blass dreams of dining alone. ''In New York, it would be in bed; in the country, on a card table set in front of the fire,'' he muses. ''If it's diet, it would be Lean Cuisine. Indulgence?'' - a big smile here - ''Ben & Jerry's ice cream!''

title: Suzanne Marie Desimini Weds Robert Sullivan Jr.
description: Suzanne Marie Desimini, the assistant director of the James Danziger photography gallery in Manhattan, and Robert Edmund Sullivan Jr., a writer at 7 Days magazine in New York, were married yesterday at St. Michael the Archangel Roman Catholic Church in Portland, Ore. The Rev. Edward G. Holterhoff officiated.

title: Little Activity in Plan B Marketplace
description: From Feb. 1 to April 1, under so-called Plan B free agency, 490 National Football League players are free to sign with new teams without having the new teams compensate the old. This opens the door for higher salaries, but with almost a third of the signing period gone, business is slow.

title: Airport Project's Design Unveiled for Legislators
description: A QUONSET hut was transformed into a modern airline terminal, complete with escalators, observation deck and air-conditioning, as county legislators got their first look last week at architectural designs for the long-planned modernization of the County Airport.

title: Question Of the Week;   What Do You Think of The Baseball Impasse?
description: Whether or not I attend any games or watch any on television, I'm going to have to pay for the monetary fiasco, just as I'm going to help pay for the savings and loan scandals. So I say ''a pox on all their houses'': players, owners, television (networks and stations), sponsors and all the rest.

title: DATA UPDATE
description: *4*BUILDING PERMITS ISSUED (Housing units) Dec. 89 Nov. 89 Dec. 88 New York 2,318 2,856 3,341 New Jersey 2,896 2,411 1,135 Connecticut 737 835 1,135 *4*(Source: Census Bureau, U.S. Department of Commerce) *4*MORTGAGE INTEREST RATES (Averages) Last Week Previous Week Year Ago New York Conventional (30-yr) 10.41 10.41 10.94 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 8.64 8.66 8.74 New Jersey Conventional (30-yr) 10.22 10.22 10.67 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 8.34 8.34 8.57 Connecticut Conventional (30-yr) 10.28 10.29 10.82 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 8.53 8.54 8.98 Co-ops (N.Y.) Conventional (30-yr) 10.75 10.68 11.36 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 8.81 8.83 8.79 *4*Indexes for Adjustable-Rate Mortgages* 1-yr. Treasury security 8.13 8.09 9.15 National Mortgage Contract Rate 9.69 9.69 9.31

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Dec. 15 with an article about Puerto Plata in the Dominican Republic misidentified an open corrugated-roofed structure. It was a souvenir stand, as a reader has written to point out; the Amber Museum is nearby. The correction was delayed through an editing error.

title: Kelly Page Basheer to Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. B. William Basheer of McLean, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kelly Page Basheer, to Arthur Sellers Garrett 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Garrett of McLean, Va., and Beach Haven, N.J. An August wedding is planned.

title: Miss Lawrence, Student, Marries
description: Trinity-St. John's Episcopal Church in Hewlett, L.I., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Cynthia Terry Lawrence and Alan Read Ziegler Jr. The Rev. Earle W. Pratt Jr. officiated, assisted by the Rev. Edyth Baker.

title: Conable's World Bank: Finding Fault (and Praise)
description: One of the first things Barber B. Conable Jr. did when he became president of the World Bank nearly four years ago was to adorn his office with non-American objets d'art: a Waterford globe from Ireland, Cantonware serving plates from China, rugs from Mauritania and Morocco.

title: Ilene Goldstein to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Goldstein of Oceanside, L.I., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Dr. Ilene Joy Goldstein and Dr. Robert Scott Nagler, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard W. Nagler of Lloyd Harbor, L.I. Dr. Goldstein is a resident in pediatrics at Schneider Children's Hospital at the Long Island Jewish Medical Center in New Hyde Park, L.I. The prospective bridegroom is an ophthalmologist in Huntington, L.I.

title: Black History: A Bridge Between Two Americas
description: IN the mid-70's, when I was a college freshman and black studies was flourishing on college campuses across America, I took a black history course in which, as expected, there was a roomful of fellow blacks. What was unexpected was one white student among the bunch.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Inside the garage, my foundation wall has two hairline cracks oozing a steady stream of sand. What can be causing this?

title: CAN HE SAVE THE ELEPHANTS?
description: Richard Leakey faces a formidable task: balancing the demands of wildlife, tourists and a growing population. Having returned recently from a tour of Kenyan game reserves, I believe that making tourists more responsible is crucial to the effort. In the Masai Mara, tourists urge drivers to move closer to the animals. Drivers issue gentle reminders that it is better to take the path that disrupts the animals the least. Although cameras have replaced rifles on safari, damaging effects remain.

title: Campus Life: UConn;   Trying to Keep Fans' Fervor Under Control
description: University of Connecticut students are showing rising enthusiasm for their basketball team, which ranks in the nation's top 10 for the first time. But the university has begun to try to calm down some of the fans.

title: Blaine A. Hammer Engaged to Marry
description: A June wedding is planned by Blaine Allyson Hammer and Allen Thomas Levenson, the prospective bride's parents, Martin L. Hammer of New York and Ronnie S. Hammer of Westport, Conn., have announced. Mr. Levenson is a son of Paul Levenson of Framingham, Mass., and the late Rose Levenson.

title: Ms. Mesch Plans An April Wedding
description: Cristine Allen Mesch, the daughter of Mildred A Mesch of New York and Dr. John Mesch of Albany, and Jonathan Simonds Sapers, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Sapers of Brookline, Mass., plan to marry in April, the prospective bride's parents have announced.

title: Sahara
description: To the Editor: As a rule, quite naturally, most Travel section features tend to describe the attractive and inviting. Not so with ''Across the Sahara by Car,'', although it might be strongly appealing to those with a death wish.

title:
DANCE;

Warsaw Ballet to Do 2 'Giselle' Performances
description: LEAD: THE Warsaw Ballet, which packs a distinguished history along with its costumes and pointe shoes, will perform on Wednesday at the State Theater in New Brunswick and on Thursday at Stockton State College's Performing Arts Center in Pomona.

title: ART ENDURES
description: As everyone knows, the winter of 1989-90 has seen the birth in Central and Eastern Europe of a new collective noun - ''a toppling of tyrants.'' In earlier times, tyrants, if toppled at all, were toppled one by one. Others, of whom Stalin was the great and terrible exemplar, lived out long lifetimes as if set in marble. And now, suddenly, all is changed.

title: Elizabeth Dudley To Wed in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Marshall N. Dudley of Guilford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Margaret Dudley, to Anthony P. Coles, a son of Dr. Roberta Goldring Coles of New York and Putnam Valley, N.Y., and the late Dr. Robert S. Coles. An April wedding is planned.

title: Europe's Grand Classics of Skiing;   In a French Vale, A Pair of Towns Keep Traditions
description: PERHAPS the biggest attraction for American skiers in the Alps is that generally the resorts there - unlike the Northeast and the Rockies - were not created for skiing. They are essentially villages that were always there, amid magnificent mountain terrain on which winter sports were easily grafted. Visiting skiers relish the expanse, the wildness, the European atmosphere and, of course, good food and wine. Progress and modernization have taken their toll, but skiers can still satisfy expectations, especially in the grand classics, the old resorts that have made efforts to cling to their charm, and remain playgrounds for the wealthy and fashionable. But even the rich cannot rely on the weather. This winter's early snow melted in a warm spell. Early February was a time of hope.

title: A PASSION FOR POLISHNESS
description: LEAD:

title: WALL STREET'S WONDER BOYS
description: The cynicism of Bruce Wasserstein and those in his profession is no better illustrated than by his remark: ''Robert Campeau failed to do three things. . . . He did not float new junk-bond issues. . . . He did not mortgage his properties. . . . And he did not sell assets.'' (''Wall Street's Wonder Boys: Slightly Tarnished,'' by L. J. Davis, Jan. 28).

title: Witness Protection, Played for Laughs
description: Through the efforts of a team of skilled set designers, a popular Los Angeles dance club called Palette has been made over into a gaudy, neon-lit New York nightspot known as Bruno's Lounge. In her screenplay for the comedy ''My Blue Heaven,'' a new production for Warner Brothers starring Steve Martin and Rick Moranis, Nora Ephron describes Bruno's as ''a typical Queens Boulevard bar with a small combo.''

title: Caring's Dollar Value
description: While the responsibility of management is to increase shareholder value, that does not preclude a corporation from engaging in socially responsible activities. Indeed, such activities may prove to increase shareholder value.

title: Spiciest Fare of the Spice Islands
description: WHEN Neil Armstrong stepped on to the moon, an Indonesian illustrator commemorated the event with a cartoon that still has his countrymen laughing: ''Wonder if he'll find a Padang restaurant?'' one Indonesian was shown saying to another.

title: Corrections
description: The headline on the Commercial Property column on page 13 of the Real Estate section today misstates the decision of the Durst Organization on a midtown project. As the column reports, Durst plans to build one-story retail buildings on the site.

title: New Jersey Justices Ponder the Privacy of Garbage
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court was asked this week to decide whether a person's right of privacy extends to the garbage he places out for collection.

title: Miss Montaigne Wed in Delaware
description: Elizabeth Lippincott Montaigne and Robert Russell Applegate were married yesterday at Old Swedes Episcopal Church in Wilmington, Del. The Rev. Luis Leon performed the ceremony. Katherine Montaigne, the bride's sister, was her matron of honor. Robert Hart Bolling 3d was the best man.

title: Waste Plastic Being Sought For Recycling
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH Long Islanders discard more than 236,000 tons of plastic a year, thousands of tons of waste plastic are being imported from as far away as Louisiana and Nova Scotia by fledgling companies manufacturing plastic lumber and other products.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about consumers' reactions to the recall of Perrier mineral water misstated the position of the restaurant Chez Panisse in Berkeley, Calif. While Panisse is looking forward to eliminating imported bottle water, it has no definite plan to do so.

title: Trial Shows a Strong Valdez Crew With Some Flaws
description: When the Exxon Valdez left the port of Valdez one night last March, her crew included a timid helmsman, a second mate who may have had mental problems and a captain with a history of drinking, according to testimony at the trial here of Capt. Joseph J. Hazelwood.

title: SUNY Fund for Arts Production
description: LEAD: THE State University of New York at Purchase is creating an endowment fund for students in the divisions of dance, music, theater, film and visual arts to help finance productions and shows.

title: Development Brings Calls for Hunting Bans
description: LEAD: CARLOS and Terry Mello woke before dawn last Thanksgiving to a sound like breaking glass. After a quick check around their Weston home showed nothing amiss, they went back to sleep.

title: Our Greatest Asset: Educated Workers
description: WE hear much of the economic decline of Long Island. The key to recovery is the creation of jobs in the service industries and the computer and communications technologies they depend upon.

title:
IN SHORT;

NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: In Mardi Gras Season, The Good Times Roll
description: For those who can't make it to New Orleans for Mardi Gras on Feb. 27, and for those who'll be wanting musical souvenirs, February brings an annual bounty of Louisiana music. From New Orleans proper comes rhythm-and-blues and street-parade music. And from the bayou country up the Gulf Coast comes bouncy, fiddle-topped Cajun music and its bluesier kin, zydeco music, carried by accordion and the clatter of the frottoir or rubboard, a metal washboard played with thimbles or spoons.

title: Mutual Funds;   Digging Out After Drexel
description: When the crisis at Drexel Burnham Lambert hit the news last Monday, Fidelity Investments, the nation's largest mutual fund company, geared up for Tuesday's flood of telephone calls.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE DANISH HOME;

Once Upon a Time, There Was a Little Piece of Denmark
description: LEAD: LONG before one arrives, the signs point the way: quaint-looking white letters on red, reading, ''Danish Home.'' Then, at the end of a twisting country road, the building itself: a stone structure with peaked roofs and dormer windows and a cobblestone courtyard.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week;   Does Tyson Deserve an Immediate Rematch?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: For Young Musicians, Four Chances to Shine
description: YOUNG artists will be in the performing spotlight countywide next weekend, in concerts at four schools.

title: Remembering Earl Monroe
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Don't Forget Baseball's Young Fans
description: Why should I care about Major League baseball? After eight years as a judge in criminal and juvenile court, why would I have special concerns about the 1990 season and the disputes between the players and owners?

title: Italy Sets Hard Line on Kidnappers and on Ransom
description: Long plagued by well-organized gangs of kidnappers, Italy took its first steps this week toward a new hard-line policy against both the abductors and the families who are willing to negotiate with the kidnappers.

title: Marri H. Davis To Wed in June
description: Marvin W. Davis of New York and Southampton, L.I., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Marri H. Davis, to David W. Moffly, a son of William T. Moffly 3d of Fort Washington, Pa., and Louisa Peace Moffly of Oreland, Pa. A June wedding is planned.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE SANDMAN

title: Paper or Foam Cups: A Point of Logic
description: Why would North Salem prefer to have paper cups litter their roads instead of polystyrene? Paper cups are not only more than twice the cost of foam cups, they are less functional, especially in insulation properties.

title: Dr. Michele Hendler Plans April Wedding
description: April wedding plans for Dr. Michele Ann Hendler and Dr. Gregory Allen Beroza, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton P. Beroza of Hempstead, L.I., have been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Stanley B. Hendler of Hollis, Queens.

title: The Quest for Synthetic Blood
description: The long search for synthetic blood for use in transfusions is becoming a neck-and-neck race between companies working on ''white bloods'' and those working on ''reds.'' The goal is to find a substance that is easy to use and free from contaminants like hepatitis or the AIDS virus.

title: Keeping the State's Black History Alive
description: A WEALTH of Connecticut's black history remains locked inside trunks, bureaus and attics in homes across the state, says George Bellinger, president of the Connecticut Afro-American Historical Society in New Haven.

title: Sports of The Times
description: California school officials got it backward a week ago after a coach pulled his team off the court.

title: MAD LADY PEEL
description: BEATRICE LILLIE

title: CAN HE SAVE THE ELEPHANTS?
description: The burning of the elephant tusks taken from poachers was a marvelous symbolic gesture. However, as I recall, the ivory burned was worth approximately $3 million. It seems to me it would have been wiser for the Government to sell the ivory and use the income for elephant-protection services.

title: Pastimes;   Coins
description: The phrase ''Do good, make good'' seems like a good motto to live by, but when found on a curious set of aluminum tokens, it's a reminder of a turbulent period of American prison reform. Prisoners at Auburn and Sing Sing prisons in New York used the tokens when morale and discipline were at an all-time high.

title: RAIDERS OF THE CULTURAL ARK
description: LEAD:

title: 'Incubators' Help High-Tech Companies
description: LEAD: IN twin brownstones on the campus of the Stevens Institute of Technology here, the seeds of invention are germinating.

title: Brian McCarthy Jr. to Wed Lisa Alano
description: Mr. and Mrs. Carlo Alano of Shrewsbury, Mass., have announced April wedding plans for their daughter Lisa Marie Alano and Brian Anthony McCarthy Jr., a son of Arlene McCarthy of Stamford, Conn., and Mr. McCarthy of New Canaan, Conn.

title: Salvadoran Military Accepts Responsibility for Bombing
description: El Salvador's military accepted responsibility today for the bombing of a refugee site last Sunday that killed at least five civilians.

title: SONY'S NORIO OHGA: BUILDING SMALLER, BUYING BIGGER
description: IT IS MIDAFTERNOON IN A SLEEK ANNEX TO the Sony Corporation's headquarters in Tokyo, and Norio Ohga and Michael P. (Mickey) Schulhof are sitting in a plush screening room reserved for the company's top executives. For weeks, Sony's engineers have been trying to get this unlikely team - a former opera singer who is Sony's president and chief executive, and a former physicist who is vice chairman of the Sony Corporation of America - on the same continent at the same time. Down the hall, visitors are wandering through Sony's ''Media World,'' viewing new products such as Sony's tinest video camera, eight months on the market and already the company's biggest runaway success since the Walkman. What they don't see are forthcoming technologies still in the hands of designers - a complete audio-visual entertainment center for an individual airplane seat, for instance; or a palm-sized digital audio tape recorder that packs two hours of sound on a cassette the size of a postage stamp. Or the technology the engineers are preparing to show Ohga and Schulhof - the latest advance in HDTV.

title:
GARDENING;

Fruit Trees Spectacular in Bloom
description: LEAD: AMONG the finest flowering trees for the garden are various species and cultivars of the genus Prunus. It includes cherry as well as ornamental and fruit-bearing forms of apricot, peach and plum. All are early flowering and spectacular trees when in bloom, even those with edible fruit.

title: CAN HE SAVE THE ELEPHANTS?
description: Thank God for a brilliant, violent bruiser like Richard Leakey, who stands squarely on the side of the animals and fairness (''Can He Save the Elephants?'' by Jane Perlez, Jan. 7). I heard him speak at the Explorers Annual Dinner and at the Friends of Conservation fund-raising luncheon last year. His approach is so blunt and unforgiving and determined that he may serve as the catalyst for many who are anguished over the destruction of elephants and rhinos but feel helpless.

title: Nets Losing Streak at 13
description: Early in the second quarter tonight, the Nets were playing cohesively, they were leading by 12 points and the crowd at Byrne Meadowlands Arena was cheering enthusiastically.

title: GOSPEL PRAISES THE LORD AND SINGS THE BLUES
description: There's no sonic boundary between the sacred and the profane. Melodies, rhythms and inflections have no allegiances; they're free agents, at the service of anyone with the technique to perform them. In Europe, popular songs were the foundations for medieval cantus firmus masses; in Latin America, the rhythms of Yoruba rituals are barely altered to drive salsa bands.

title: Chinese Submit to Analysis (the Political Sort)
description: For some Chinese Communist Party members, the next few months will involve a flurry of meetings, self-analysis and the risk of being purged from the party if their outlook and behavior do not live up to the Communist ideal.

title: Catherine Fierro To Wed in Fall
description: Dr. and Mrs. Louis E. Fierro of Chappaqua, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Catherine Ann Fierro to Bryan Keven Hawkins, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Blayne Hawkins of Cashiers, N.C. An October wedding is planned.

title: Gina Bandini and Dan Cooper Marry
description: Gina Pia Bandini, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Bandini of Westport, Conn., was married yesterday to Dan Cooper, a son of Miriam Cooper of Brooklyn and the late Morris S. Cooper, at the New York home of the bridegroom. Justice Budd G. Goodman of the New York State Supreme Court officiated.

title: CRUCIAL RULING DUE IN PARK RAPE CASE
description: A critical ruling in the Central Park rape case is expected this week when the presiding judge is scheduled to decide whether to admit as evidence the incriminating videotaped statements made by five of the six youthful defendants charged in the attack.

title: Harlem Woman, 66, Dies After Robbery
description: A Harlem grandmother who feared staying alone at night suffered a fatal heart attack early yesterday, minutes after she opened the door to two masked gunmen who ransacked the apartment and fled, the police said. Detectives investigating the robbery are treating it as a murder case.

title: Shift in the Western Alliance's Focus: From Moscow to a United Germany?
description: As the Soviet threat to Western Europe diminishes and the Warsaw Pact becomes a hollow alliance, the role of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization is shifting and the alliance is emerging as a potential watchdog over a reunited Germany.

title: Changes in Medicine Bring Pain to Healing Profession
description: Because of an editing error, a capsule listing of issues in medicine last Sunday, with a front-page article about doctors, misstated the percentage of black and Hispanic doctors for 1988. Black doctors made up 3.3 percent of the profession; Hispanic doctors made up 4.7 percent.

title: Barbara Meyer to Wed Thomas Keating in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Meyer 3d of Fair Haven, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Lynn Meyer, to Thomas More Keating, a son of Mrs. Joseph M. White of Rumson, N.J., and James M. Keating Jr. of Shark River Hills, N.J. A November wedding is planned.

title: Leslie Grosvenor Plans Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Grosvenor of New York and Newport, R.I., have made knbow the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Romaine Grosvenor, to R. Marcus Holloway, the son of Lynn K. Holloway of Wilington, Del., and W. Robert Holloway of Glen Cove, L.I. A December wedding is planned.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu;   The Early Fish Cakes
description: Having just read that upscale fish cakes would be popular in the 90's, I thought it seemed like a good idea to get a drop on the competition.

title: Where Schools Err on Athletics
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Nepal Vows to Stop Protests By Advocates of Democracy
description: Nepal has put the police and the military on alert and detained hundreds of people in an effort to crush plans to begin a pro-democracy campaign on Sunday.

title: ASPEN: THE CALL OF THE WILD
description: As regular vistors to Aspen for over 20 years, we know that Jon Bowermaster's description is all too accurate (''Aspen: The Call of the Wild,'' Jan. 21). If your story were only about a small Rocky Mountain town, it would be merely an amusing tale about silly people. It is, unfortunately, a parable about America.

title: The Intricate Patterning of Batik
description: IN a small rice-farming village south of Jogjakarta, Indonesia, a 19-year-old woman crouched in the doorway of her bamboo house, using the last rays of sunlight to see as she applied molten wax to a piece of cotton fabric. The woman, Miss Setyawati, was creating a work of batik, Indonesia's national handcraft. Yet the young artist is an anomaly, for few villagers today know the tools of the ancient craft. Batik, the pride of Indonesia's art for centuries, is dying out. The reason for the decline is simple economics: the labor-intensive craft of hand-printing textiles and coating with wax all parts that are not to be dyed cannot compete with cheap, mass-produced textile prints.

title: TV Awaits Endless Movies
description: The place: Atlanta. The time: another day. With Scarlett and Rhett away on a second honeymoon, Prissy and Aunt Pittypat join forces to launch themselves in business with a home birthing center. Comic complications ensue.

title: Expect Cheers For Strawberry
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: W. Hamilton Hoge, 83, Scientific Entrepreneur
description: William Hamilton Hoge, an early manufacturer of television sets and the first large-screen projection TV sets, died of a heart attack on Friday at his home in Southampton, L.I. He was 83 years old and also had a residence in Manhattan.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-27

title: Blacks in U.S. Gain Inspiration From Mandela
description: From luncheonettes to classrooms to rallies and marches, American blacks are voicing a euphoria and pride in Nelson Mandela of a kind many said has not been seen since the height of the civil rights movement two decades ago.

title: Housing Forum Presses Its Effort at Local Level
description: LEAD: A NONPROFIT agency created last May to encourage affordable housing for the working middle class has begun to gather more grass-roots support for its goal.

title: FICTION
description: THE KNEELING BUS. By Beverly Coyle. (Ticknor & Fields, $18.95.) Reading Beverly Coyle's first novel is like roaming through Disneyland as a child: you wander from image to image, discovery to discovery, and when you're finished you want to do it all over again. Through the perceptions and misperceptions of young Carrie Willis, the daughter of a liberal Methodist minister, Ms. Coyle gives us an intimate view of the small-town Florida of the 1950's, of sleepy towns ''ringing with no sound at all'' in which ''men and women lingered like drugged bees in the intense sun.'' Carrie's world has clear distinctions: ''We Methodists had an oyster shell parking lot behind the new educational plant. But the Baptists just pulled up anywhere.'' And everything, even a dinner-table discussion, takes on a religious hue. ''My mother,'' Carrie says as the family ignores Mrs. Willis's chatter one evening, ''might as well have been speaking in tongues.'' Carrie watches her family absorb the awful news that Grandma has joined a Seventh-day Adventist church. ''They foot-wash,'' Carrie's sister Jeanie says, her voice struck low with shame. Ms. Coyle's last chapter, in which Carrie, all grown up and teaching English in New York City, receives a reluctant visit from her elderly mother, is the most memorable. This may stem from Carrie's painful confrontation with mortality, from the vivid clash of the small town with the big city or from the unresolved mother-daughter battles that are too old to fight. Or maybe what speaks to us is the fond memory of Carrie's memories, which makes us want to go back with her to that childhood world.

title: P.S. 135
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Ehrenfeld To Wed in April
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Roos Ehrenfeld to Kenneth Mendez, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Manuel Mendez of New York and Makati, the Philippines, has been made known by her parents, Mikki Ansin of Cambridge, Mass., and Dr. John Ehrenfeld of Lexington, Mass. An April wedding is planned.

title: Lauren Bartner to Wed Joseph Singer
description: The engagement of Lauren Joy Bartner and Dr. Joseph Ascher Singer has been announced by the prospective bride's mother and stepfather, Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Easton of Alpine, N.J., and Palm Beach, Fla. Dr. Singer is the son of Hannah Singer of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Abraham Singer. An August wedding is planned.

title: Susan Kerr, a TV Executive, Marries
description: Susan Jane Kerr and Allan R. Dragone Jr. were married yesterday at St. James' Church in New York by the Rev. J. Seymour Flinn, an Episcopal priest. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. Julius Hamilton Sedlmayr of New York and Edmund Hugh Kerr of Greenwich, Conn. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dragone of Darien, Conn.; Quissett, Mass., and New York.

title: Maneuvering in Lucia's Footsteps
description: HUNDREDS of tourists who make the somewhat bucolic two-hour rail trip from London to Rye each year have never heard of Lucia, Miss Mapp or E. F. Benson - and more's the pity. It isn't that the East Sussex town, one of the ''Cinque Ports and Two Ancient Towns'' forged as a unit in the 11th century, isn't worthwhile without this esoteric knowledge. It is, certainly to foreign eyes, one of the most picturesque areas in England, from the approach across the sheep-studded Romney Marsh to the town itself, with its cobbled walkways and timbered and brick cottages. Even the place names have an old-fashioned ring - Mermaid and Watchbell Streets, Cobble Cottage, a guesthouse and art gallery called, what else, The Old Vicarage - what else, that is, to anyone who has ever read a British mystery novel.

title: Melissa Weinstein to Wed in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Weinstein of Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Melissa Weinstein to Rabbi Leonid Feldman, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Moisey Feldman of Kishinev, U.S.S.R. An April wedding is planned.

title: Islanders Stumble Again
description: The Islanders still hold first place in the Patrick Division. But their fans had reason for concern as they left Nassau Coliseum today after a 3-1 loss to the Chicago Blackhawks.

title: Vincent Content on His Part In Talks
description: Some people believe that Fay Vincent, the baseball commissioner, risked his standing with his employers, the owners, in a major way when he replaced their revenue-sharing proposal with his own set of ''suggestions'' last week. Vincent is not one of those people.

title: New York City Is Out of the Needle Trade
description: FROM the beginning, it was an idea almost no one liked: give clean needles to drug addicts. As a first step in studying whether that could slow the spread of AIDS, New York City began a program in 1988 to see if addicts would participate.

title: County Couple's Quilts Chosen for Japan Tour
description: LEAD: AMONG the reasons Ardis D. and Bob James give for collecting quilts is their pleasure in sharing their treasures with others. Now this Westchester couple is delighted that 50 quilts from their ever-growing collection, now numbering 591, will be displayed in a traveling exhibition in Japan.

title:
LONG ISLAND INTERVIEW: MARK HAMPTON;

The 'White House Decorator' Sets a Classical Tone
description: LEAD: MARK HAMPTON frequently uses verbs like ''adore'' and adjectives like ''marvelous'' and ''charming.'' He is, after all, a decorator, and at the moment one of New York's and perhaps the nation's most popular since becoming the ''White House decorator.''

title: Turning Left or Right? Please Use the Signal
description: I applaud Irving Kamil's article dealing with drivers who fail to use directional signals (''Turning Without Telling,'' Opinion page, Jan. 7). While our area is so much better than California in this regard, one can't help but be appalled by the lack of courtesy this shows.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the music column of the Connecticut Weekly today omits the time and date of a performance in Newtown by the Lydian String Quartet. It is 3:30 P.M. today.

title: HIS BUS CAME IN
description: I love New York! I love show biz! I love Danny Aiello! I loved Michael Norman's article on Danny (''His Bus Came In,'' Jan. 21)!

title: The Selling of Western Water Rights
description: Last September, the City Council of Aurora, Colo., approved a $1.25 million purchase of agricultural water rights in the South Platte river basin. Eager to secure more water for its rapidly growing population, this municipality east of Denver joined numerous others throughout the West by turning to what it sees as the only vast pool remaining: irrigation water.

title: A MILITARY EDITOR IS SAID TO RESIGN
description: The Air Force officer who is editor of Pacific Stars and Stripes, the United States military's official newspaper in Asia, has resigned in a dispute over charges that the military is censoring the paper.

title: Proper Disposal Of Medical Waste
description: I read with interest Dr. William A. Dwyer's letter to the New Jersey editor entitled ''Fees for Disposing of Medical Waste'' (Jan. 21).

title: Michel Drach Is Dead; French Film Maker, 59
description: Michel Drach, a director who along with Jean-Luc Godard and Francois Truffaut helped create the New Wave style of film making, died on Thursday. He was 59 years old.

title: DEATH BE NO MORBID
description: LEAD:

title: Bullets, Blondes and Booze: Meeting a Hero
description: THE November sky cast a tombstone gray pall over Manhattan. The fictional private eye Mike Hammer always woke to this kind of morning in Mickey Spillane's mysteries, and I smiled at the appropriateness of it. I put on my trenchcoat, turned up the collar and went out to meet Mike's creator.

title: A Loss For the Theater
description: When Dennis McIntyre died on Feb. 1 (of cancer, at the age of 47), obituaries were brief and, for many, his name was unfamiliar. Sadly, his death will not inspire Broadway eulogies, but his life says something revealing about the plight of the playwright. He was a fine playwright with the potential to be a major one, but more than many of his peers he had difficulty getting his work produced.

title: Dentists Donate Care To the Handicapped
description: LEAD: JACK ROEMER, a dentist, liked what he heard at an American Dental Association convention three years ago about a program that provided free services to the handicapped.

title: Painless Way to Cut Social Security Deductions;   Saving the System
description: To the Editor:

title: THE FIGHT FOR THE 20TH CENTURY: RAYMOND ARON VERSUS JEAN-PAUL SARTRE
description: LEAD: The curtains of Communism are drawing to a close, yet a mystery remains: what were the attractions of revolutionary Marxism that drew so many passionate intellectuals to its flag? What was the faith that, like that of the first-century Christian martyrs, summoned many to die for a cause? In one respect, the answer is simple: what once had appealed in the name of God crossed over to the banner of History.

title: Debra Neyman Engaged to Michael C. Silverman
description: Dr. and Mrs. Mark A. Neymanof Andover, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Debra Neyman, to Michael Cary Silverman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley H. Silverman of North Woodmere, L.I. An August wedding is planned.
