KIDS KNOW BEST
description: LEAD:

title: Service for Salo W. Baron
description: A remembrance service for Salo W. Baron, the Jewish historian and Columbia University professor, will be held tomorrow at 4 P.M. at the Altschul Auditorium in the International Affairs Building at Columbia, 420 West 118th Street. Speakers will include Michael I. Sovern, president of Columbia. Professor Baron died Nov. 25 at the age of 94.

title: Design for Westchester Airport Shown
description: A QUONSET hut was transformed into a modern airline terminal, complete with escalators, observation deck and air-conditioning, as county legislators got their first look last week at architectural designs for the long-planned modernization of the County Airport.

title: Competition Needed In Cable TV
description: Re: ''Let's Make the Cable TV Industry Live Up to Its Promises,'' Opinion page, Jan. 7:

title: Diverting Musical Farce
description: THE Forum Theater Group may still be on the lookout for the lesser-known, perhaps esoteric or ''unsung'' musicals that have become the theater's trademark, more or less. For the moment, though, let's say that the theater's artistic credo has been amended by, or converted to, shows on Yiddish themes.

title: Dr. Gayle Milton Engaged
description: Dr. Gayle P.Milton's engagement to Michael Clifford Zeller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Zeller of Great Neck, L.I., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Milton of Newton Centre, Mass. An August wedding is planned. Dr. Milton, 29 years old, is a pediatrician at South Shore Pediatrics in Oceanside, L.I., and Bele Harbor, Queens. She graduated from Wellesley College and received her M.D. from Boston Univeristy. She was previously married and divorced. The prospective bridegroom, 29, is an associate at the New York law firm of Grais & Richards, He graduated from Wesleyan University, where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and received a J.D. from Standard Universtiy.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Manchester, N.H.;

Mill Owners Map Strategy
description: LEAD: OWNERS of the Amoskeag Millyard here are stepping up their effort to ease zoning restrictions so they can seek a wider variety of tenants. Dean Kamen, who owns several mills, will meet next month with the 15 other owners. Collectively, the 19 mills have 3.4 million square feet of space.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Jeans and Generations: A Seat-of-the-Pants Analysis
description: LEAD: LAST night, I mended my jeans. That means I'm older than 35. I mended them on the inside, so the patch wouldn't show. I'm 50, if I'm a day.

title: Mongolia to Remove Its Last Stalin Statue
description: Mongolia's Communist Government has decided to remove the last statue of Stalin from the capital, signaling another concession to democratic demands, an official newspaper said today.

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD:

title:
ART;

Nature Comes Into Its Own in 'Secret Life of Plants' at Lehman
description: LEAD: WHAT'S under your Gro-Light just won't sit still for still life any longer. This is one of the disclosures of ''The Secret Life of Plants'' at the Lehman College Art Gallery here. In fact, as we enter the 1990's, art inspired by nature is the dominant mode.

title: Lifestyle: Evening Hours;   Celebrations of Art And Good Works
description: The Museum of Modern Art celebrated its exhibit ''Photography Until Now'' with a cocktail party, dinner and preview on Wednesday night. The curator of this commemoration of 150 years of photography is John Szarkowski, director of the museum's photography department.

title: Train Derails in Texas, Forcing Evacuation
description: A freight train derailed near this small town early today, sparking a huge fireball and forcing the evacuation of several families, the authorities said.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Orlando
description: If Orlando had not existed before Walt Disney World, those who built the central Florida entertainment empire would probably have had to invent the city. With 32,000 workers and more than 23 million annual visitors, Disney World relies on Orlando and surrounding communities to house its employees and administer the airport that is the gateway to its three theme parks: the Magic Kingdom, Epcot Center and Disney-MGM Studios.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Style Makers column on Feb. 4 about Jeff Weiss misidentified his role in the new advertising campaign for Cointreau. He was not the sole creator; Victor Levin was his collaborator.

title: Lyndhurst Journal;   Township Fights County Over Relocation of Waste Scales
description: OFFICIALS here, frustrated by months of stalled negotiations with the Bergen County Utilities Authority over the amount of money the township is entitled to for participating in the authority's solid-waste disposal operation, have decided to settle the dispute the old-fashioned way.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;

HIGH ART IN THE COMICS
description: LEAD: If comic strips are an art form, as Richard Marschall maintains, consider his book AMERICA'S GREAT COMIC-STRIP ARTISTS (Abbeville, $55) a gallery of old masters: portraits of 16 cartoonists - all members of the Museum of Cartoon Art's Hall of Fame - who were either present at the creation or contributed to the evolution of what is, like jazz, a uniquely American contribution to world culture.

title: 'The Fate of the Forest'
description: To the Editor:

title: Greeks Feel the Pinch as Two U.S. Bases Close
description: A popular Greek cartoon shows American G.I.'s, a look of indifference on their faces, carrying out crates of personal belongings as they abandon their military bases in Greece. Taken away with the belongings is a Greek protester clutching a ''Yankee go home'' sign, a look of bewilderment betraying his confusion at being left without a cause.

title: How 'Magic Circles' Build Self-Esteem
description: LEAD: IN Doris Walker-Smith's class at the Pulaski Road public school in East Northport, phrases like ''mud mind,'' ''clear mind'' and ''sparkler mind'' filter into the third-graders' conversations with the familiarity of Nintendo and L. A. Gear sneakers.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Inside the garage, my foundation wall has two hairline cracks oozing a steady stream of sand. What can be causing this?

title: The Executive Computer;   I.B.M. Jumps Into Work Stations, With Both Feet
description: The announcement last week of a new line of powerful work stations by the International Business Machines Corporation has again focused attention on the microprocessor technology called RISC and the operating system called Unix. While they have been around for years, RISC chips and Unix are widely viewed as the next major steps in the evolution of high-performance business computers. The aggressive re-entry of I.B.M., the world's largest computer maker, into the rapidly growing Unix work station market is certain to create some spirited competition.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE MAN WHO TRIED TO BURN NEW YORK, by Nat Brandt. (Berkley, $3.95.) In one of the more obscure incidents of the Civil War, a band of renegade Confederate soldiers tried to burn New York City in retaliation for what General Sherman did to Atlanta. In 1986 our reviewer, Patrick Clinton, said Nat Brandt's rendition of the trial of one of the conspirators ''is full of surprising perplexities, and the descriptions of his gradual descent into drunkenness and despair and of his death as the last Confederate to be hanged for spying are memorable reading.''

title: Paris Couture: Living Up to the Legend
description: THE PARIS COUTURE IS THE OLYMPIAD of fashion design. In this biannual arena in which a chosen few compete, a couturier has free reign to create whatever vision he has in mind. Money is no object, and the most magnificent materials, accessories and artisans are at his fingertips. The news media of the world are there to cover the results, and, in turn, the publicity helps sell large quantities of more affordable products bearing the couturier's label. Involving massive amounts of money, ego and influence, the couture is heady stuff.

title: NOBODY IS INNOCENT AROUND HERE
description: LEAD:

title: Both Writers Miss the Point
description: Roger Keizerstein's warning that financially advantaged youngsters will have more difficulty establishing independent households because many will not be able to afford comparable lifestyles and will thus choose to remain in the comforts of the parental nest is based on a simplistic formulation of a complex problem.

title: Fashion: On the Street;   Outback Chic Sans Sheep
description: The romance with all things Australian continues. The latest rage from Down Under is the outback coat.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption in this section Feb. 4 accompanying a photograph of a golf tournament at Pebble Beach, Calif., misstated the name of the tournament. It was the A.T.&T. National Pro-Am.

description: COMPANIES

title: S. Dana Snyder To Wed in April
description: The engagement of S. Dana Snyder and James F. Grant, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert M. Grant of Chicago, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William L. Snyder of New York and Hillsdale, N.Y. An April wedding is planned.

title: No Headline
description: THE FULL CATASTROPHE

title: Question Of the Week;   What Do You Think of The Baseball Impasse?
description: I hope I'm not the only one who is rooting for the baseball players and owners to remain at an impasse forever, until the owners file for bankruptcy and the players go on welfare. Let us all hope that some nice protracted intransigence will tear the system down.

title: A Dreary Thriller Spirals Downward
description: IF you accept the idea that a bikini-clad woman who is all alone on her Westchester County estate would not sound the alarm when a weird stranger walks into her garden room and stares at her, then you might consider purchasing a large bridge that spans the East River.

title: I.R.S. INVESTIGATING FOREIGN COMPANIES FOR TAX CHEATING
description: Bolstered by new auditing powers, Federal tax officials are investigating many American subsidiaries of Japanese companies on the suspicion that they have underpaid corporate income taxes by billions of dollars.

title:
DINING OUT;

A New Japanese Menu in White Plains
description: LEAD: NO longer part of the famous Takesushi restaurant chain, the familiar storefront Japanese dining spot on upper Central Avenue has effected a name change and a new management. Now called Ajiyoshi - meaning good taste or taste good - this replacement brings with it a great deal more than the spare menu of sushi and appetizers offered by its predecessor, good as they were.

title: Sky TV Begins to Make Progress
description: Sky Television, Rupert Murdoch's satellite programming service in Britain, had operating losses of about $129 million in its first year. But there are signs that it is making progress.

Of Gender, Sex, Grammar and All That
description: To the Editor:

title: Cope Takes Flag at Daytona
description: Derrike Cope got into stock-car racing when his baseball career ended with what he called a complete blowout of his right knee. Another blowout today, this one in Dale Earnhardt's right rear tire with about a mile to go, gave Cope the victory in the Daytona 500, the sport's biggest race.

title: Charles Simone, Executive, 86
description: Charles Simone, a founder of the Children's Blood Foundation at New York Hospital, died yesterday in Memorial Hospital after a long illness. He was 86 years old and lived in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.

title: LONG-RULING PARTY RETAINS CONTROL IN JAPANESE VOTE
description: Japanese voters, brushing aside appeals to reject the leadership that has governed uninterrupted for 35 years, returned the Liberal Democratic Party of Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu to power in elections for the lower house of Parliament on Sunday.

title: Christiana Cos.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a net gain of about $882,000, or 17 cents a share, on sale of land.

title: Prisoner No. 14279: Forlorn Pawn in Ethiopia's Long and Ruinous Civil War
description: In the tough landscape of rocky canyons and jagged mountains in northwestern Ethiopia, 16-year-old Berhanu Fekanssa has spent the last two years as a prisoner of war.

title: Question Box
description: Homers and Strikeouts

title: Prices Fall in Tea Glut
description: The price of tea has fallen to its lowest level in more than five months because a glut of poor-quality tea has swamped the market, traders said last week. But they said the fall could be short-lived, because better teas are expected soon at London's tea auction and world consumption is expected to remain strong, particularly in India. The weighted average price of tea dropped to a little more than $:1.28 ($2.15) a kilogram (2.2 pounds) at Thursday's London auction, the lowest since Sept. 4, and down from $:1.35 ($2.27) in the previous week.

title: How Johnson Controls Guarded Its Big Secret
description: After a secretive campaign to throw its leading competitor off track, Johnson Controls Inc. has introduced what it maintains is the next generation of computerized systems to control heating, security and other functions in buildings.

title: National Archives Criticizes Records on Weapons Plants
description: The National Archives says it has identified serious weaknesses in the Energy Department's program for managing its vast collection of records on the nuclear weapons industry.

title: Decom Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
Jackson Brings 'Message' From Mandela
description: Fresh from a trip to South Africa, the Rev. Jesse Jackson went to Harlem yesterday and asked black Americans to learn from the life of Nelson Mandela, who was released last week after almost three decades in prison.

title: Bridge
description: One unusual development in national championships in recent years has been the growth of morning knockout team games. Many players, particularly those who have traveled considerable distances to attend, are eager to play serious bridge for 10 hours a day instead of the usual seven. And the morning knockout gives them what they want.

title: Stage Fright Leads to Pension
description: A judge who resigned after developing what he called stage fright has won a lifetime disability pension at the age of 44.

title: Flanigan's Enterprises reports earnings for 13wks to Dec 30
description: b-Included $300,000 in income from the termination of a management agreement.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about the Carmelite convent at the site of the Auschwitz death camp misidentified the news agency providing the report. It was Reuters, not The Associated Press.

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Czechoslovakia;   Havel, U.S. Bound, 'Going to Learn'
description: Twenty-two years lie between Vaclav Havel's American visits, years of struggling for democracy and human rights under a repressive Government, years of persecution and prison.

title: DBA Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the loss in the latest quarter is primarily attributable to the provision for divestiture and losses at DBA Military Products division at Kissimmee, Fla.

title: At Least 4 Are Killed in Maryland Motel Explosion
description: At least four people were killed and some guests were forced to leap from their windows when a natural gas leak apparently set off an explosion and fire in a motel this morning, the authorities said.

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Soviet Union;   Did Moscow Incite Azerbaijanis? Some See a Plot
description: Did Mikhail S. Gorbachev's Kremlin provoke ethnic conflict in this southern republic of Azerbaijan to justify the tightening of its authoritarian control?

title: Reviews/Music;   A Concert of the Sacred From Dave Brubeck
description: For more than 20 years, Dave Brubeck has augmented his jazz career by composing liturgical scores for vocal soloists, chorus, chamber orchestra and jazz ensemble. Friday night in Avery Fisher Hall, Musica Sacra devoted an entire concert to two of them.

title: Business and the Law;   Brokerage Case Goes On and On
description: Three years ago the Supreme Court was swayed by arguments of the securities industry that arbitration is swift, relatively inexpensive and fair. In their ruling in Shearson/American Express Inc. v. McMahon, the Justices locked the doors of Federal courthouses to most customers who contend that they were defrauded by stockbrokers.

description: b-Net income

title: Merger Worries Utilities in New England
description: A likely merger between New England's largest electric utility and the New Hampshire power company that built the Seabrook nuclear plant is troubling the utility industry in the region.

title: Savannah Foods & Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

ABC's 'Home Videos' Pays Off Big
description: Finally this season, network television has a new, undeniable hit: ABC's ''America's Funniest Home Videos.''

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Romania;   Jeering Romanians Seize Offices To Demand Government's Ouster
description: Protesters demanding the ouster of President Ion Iliescu took over the provisional government's headquarters this evening, roughly handling one of the new leaders, tossing red-bound party manuals to the crowd below and shouting for a complete end to Communism.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

Heir Apparent Chosen At Kimberly-Clark
description: LEAD: The race to succeed the chairman and chief executive of the Kimberly-Clark Corporation apparently ended last week when the company's board announced that Wayne R. Sanders would be given significant new duties.

title: New Jersey Police Are Accused of Minority Arrest Campaigns
description: The New Jersey state police, proud of their record of arrests for illegal drug and gun running on the state's highways in recent years, are under pressure to submit to independent oversight of their operations in the wake of complaints that they are aiming at racial minorities and homosexuals.

title: Redlaw Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss of $254,000 from discontinued operations. Year-ago figures reflected the sale of Canadian Foundry operations. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Reviews/Dance;   Energetic Chicago Company Points Way to the Future
description: The Joseph Holmes Chicago Dance Theater, which made an exuberant New York City debut on Saturday night, is very possibly a harbinger of the future.

title: Westbridge Computer reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Latest third-quarter results includes a loss of $921,000 from the operations of Superior Business Machines Ltd. which was sold Jan. 25. Third-quarter results have been reduced by $3.8 million due to an accounting change. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: TERRY A. BENNETT WED TO DOROTHY CHANSKY
description: Dorothy Ann Chansky, a writer, and Terry Andrew Bennett, a set and lighting designer, were married yesterday at the bride's apartment in New York. The Rev. John Backe, a Lutheran minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: C.I.S. Technologies Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Results Plus
description: Golf

title: Wharf Resources reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Washington's Birthday Today
description: Here are holiday schedules.

title: Weinrich Fills Void for Devils
description: The Devils started training camp last fall with a plethora of talented people on defense, and they decided to start the season with nine defensemen rather than seven, as most teams do.

title: Washington Talk;   New Crops For Coca: A Harvest Is Unlikely
description: Before he left Washington earlier this week for his summit conference on drugs with the presidents of Colombia, Peru and Bolivia, President Bush had some blunt words for the farmers who produce coca, the raw material from which cocaine is refined.

title: China Acts to Reduce Economic Discontent
description: Apparently alarmed that economic difficulties might touch off unrest, China's leaders have considerably eased economic controls and returned in part to the economic policies that preceded the violent crackdown last June, Chinese officials and foreign diplomats say.

title: Girl, 14, Is Shot Dead With Gun She Found
description: A 14-year-old Brooklyn girl visiting a friend's home was shot dead yesterday afternoon, and her friend said she was killed when the friend tried to wrest from her a gun she had found, the police said.

title: Xylogics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
Imagine Films Entertainment Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $220,000, or 4 cents a share, from utilization of tax loss carryforward. c-Net loss

title: Argentina to Cut Taxes
description: In an attempt to forestall frantic price markups as Argentina experiences its second bout of hyperinflation in seven months, the Peronist Government announced measures today to curtail state spending and cut taxes on imported food. Among other measures, Economy Minister Antonio Erman Gonzalez said President Carlos Saul Menem's salary would be cut 20 percent and set as the top wage for Federal employees. The Argentine currency, the austral, lost 29 percent of its value against the American dollar last week. Some consumer prices rose by as much as 50 percent.

title: Bank Aid Seen For Eurotunnel
description: The Bank of England has stepped in to rescue the Eurotunnel project to link Britain to the rest of Europe, bankers said today.

title: Force 6 on the Coast
description: The probable shift of the California primary from June to March 3 is about a Force 6 earthquake on the electoral scale - short of what quake watchers call ''the big one'' only because in one major respect it fails to change the political landscape.

title: Coda Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income of $59,260, or 2 cents a share for the quarter and a loss of $1,918,653 for the year, both from discontinued operations. c-Net loss d-Included losses from discontinued operations of $82,695 and $275,897 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: View From the Basement: Ski Races Take a Back Seat
description: LEAD: I knew things were getting serious in the Olympic hockey tournament when Vinnie Eruzione just left school for a while and took off for Lake Placid.

title: Chinese Students Remain a Human Rights Issue;   Protective Directive
description: To the Editor:

title: Circle Fine Art Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''The basic radical evil in this society is unemployment. For the first time, we have young people emerging out of the school system whose fathers never worked and whose grandfathers never worked.''

title: Markets Closed
description: Stock, bond and futures markets will be closed today in observance of Washington's Birthday. Government offices, most banks and many businesses will also be closed.

title: 8 Fraternities and Sororities Announce an End to Hazing
description: Leaders of eight national black fraternities and sororities announced an agreement on Saturday to eliminate hazing by banning the pledging process.

title: Elderly Returning to Campus, This Time for Life as Retirees
description: Waldo Wagner was a big man on the Iowa State University campus back in 1935, the school's first all-America basketball player. And after graduation, he got a job in Washington helping set up the Work Projects Administration, and then went on to a long string of engineering jobs in the Midwest.

title: Roy F. Weston reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included for both periods a loss of $359,000 from discontinued operations, net of an income tax benefit of $248 in 1988; both periods also included an extraordinary loss of $3,258,000, net of an income tax benefit of $2,137 in 1988. c-Net income The company said that in the third quarter of 1989 it established certain reserves to cover the anticipated settlement of the EPA investigation of its Lionville laboratory and costs of organizational restructuring, and also recognized write-offs of uncollectible revenues and equipment and systems development costs. The company said it continued its critical analysis of a number of contracts and acknowledged additional write-downs of about $1 million in uncollectible revenues.

title: India Grounds Airbus Planes After Crash
description: The Indian Government grounded all 14 Airbus A320 aircraft flown by its domestic carrier today after the crash of an Airbus plane last week that killed 97.

title: PAULA DE DFREITAS WED IN SCARSDALE
description: Paula Cristian Correira de Freitas and Douglas Herbert Hoffman were married yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur S. Hoffman, in Scarsdale, N.Y., by Rabbi Emily Korenick. Mrs. Hoffman is the daughter of Isaura de Freitas of Madeira, Portugal, and the late Orlando de Freitas.

title: Small-Town Ad Agency Takes on the Big City
description: When the makers of Very Fine juice went looking for a new advertising agency last fall, the company put together a list of six top Madison Avenue names and one agency that some of the contenders had never heard of: Mullen Advertising.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Egghead Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 6
description: b-Net income and included a loss from the cumulative effect of an accounting change of $617,000. Results are restated to reflect the previously reported change in accounting principle adopted at the end of fiscal 1989 and applied retroactively to the beginning of fiscal 1989.

title: Newborn Baby Girl Is Found In a Welfare Hotel's Garbage
description: A whimpering newborn baby in a plastic bag was found in a garbage can yesterday in a Manhattan welfare hotel, the police said.

title: Shaoshan Journal;   Mao's Halo Is Back and His Hometown Is Happy
description: Pilgrims are streaming once more to this little farming village, the Bethlehem of Maoism, and after a long period of neglect the town seems to be celebrating a resurrection.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Publishing;   Industry Is Troubled, but Booksellers Are Thriving
description: THE American Booksellers Association has been around for 90 years, but it is now friskier than ever and brimming with confidence - almost as if its 7,600 members were unaware of the difficulties in the publishing industry.

title: Mets Seek Workout, Find Frustration
description: The Mets in exile, who were locked out of their training camp Thursday because of the baseball labor dispute, reported for their informal morning workout at a Little League field here today and, to put it bluntly, were locked out.

title: Jury in Guinness Case Is Told About a Scheme
description: The prosecutor in the Guinness P.L.C. case, which finished its first week of trial last week, told the jury the defendants were ''carried away by greed and ambition'' during their 1986 takeover battle for the Distillers Company.

title: Southwest Gas Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Party Is On; Town Isn't Invited
description: A party to celebrate the incorporation of this suburb of about 58,000 between Seattle and Tacoma will be held outside the municipal boundaries, embarrassed organizers have learned. Only after arranging the party for Feb. 28 at a bowling alley did planners learn it was not in the town as approved by voters a year ago.

title: CPT Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Ross Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Davis Distributing reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: MEGUMI KANEKO IS WED IN TOKYO
description: Megumi Kaneko and Jonathan A. Hill were married yesterday in a Shinto ceremony at the Takanawa Prince Hotel in Tokyo. Mrs. Hill is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kiju Kaneko of Yokohama, Japan. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth E. Hill of Rancho Santa Fe, Calif.

title: Mean Streets Force New Yorkers to Just Walk On By
description: Time was, no self-respecting New Yorker would let a car cut him off without kicking its tires, or suffer in silence while some cretin in the next row jabbered his way through the second act. In those days, New Yorkers were New Yorkers, and assertiveness was the proud mark of a native.

title: Maine's Rafters See New White-Water Battle
description: John Abbott used to spend summers leading rafting trips through the white-water rapids of the Kennebec River in Maine. Now he is a lawyer trying to rewrite state law, which he says gives long-established rafting outfitters like his former company an advantage over their fledgling competitors.

title: Lithuanian Aide Sees Secession This Year
description: A member of the Lithuanian Communist Party's ruling politburo predicted today that the republic would pull out of the Soviet Union this year.

title: Wanderkin Wins With Late Charge
description: Wanderkin, the 7-year-old New York-bred gelding who had been looking past his prime lately, scored his first stakes victory in 16 months when he ran down Iron Courage to win the $100,000 Fort Lauderdale Handicap today at Gulfstream Park.

title: Estimate of Cancer Peril In Air Travel Is Raised
description: The risk of fatal cancer from radiation in airliners is 17 times greater than reported last week in a Government study, the Department of Transportation has acknowledged after other scientists found errors.

title: Douglas Shuns Tyson For Holyfield
description: John Johnson, the manager of the heavyweight champion, James (Buster) Douglas, said yesterday that Mike Tyson would have to wait for his rematch with Douglas because his fighter would first meet Evander Holyfield, probably in September.

title: Service Fracturing Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Some Point to Massachusetts as Extreme of Regulation
description: In 49 states, grumbling private doctors are consoled by the fact that the regulation could be worse: they could be practicing in Massachusetts. In the name of controlling costs and improving access to medical care, that state has led the nation in enacting strict laws to govern doctors' practices and limit their fees.

title: ACTOR IN MOVIES, TV AND THEATER WAS 84
description: Erik Rhodes, a stage, screen and television actor best remembered for his characterization of continental gigolos in Fred Astaire-Ginger Rogers musicals of the 1930's, died of complications following pneumonia on Saturday at the Four Seasons Nursing Center in Oklahoma City. He was 84 years old and lived in Oklahoma City.

title: First Boston To Close Unit
description: The First Boston Corporation said on Friday that it planned to close its listed fixed-income futures brokerage business and lay off the operation's 29 employees.

title: WPL Holdings Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Robinson Sought for TV
description: Bill Robinson, who was dropped as a coach by the Mets without explanation in October, disclosed today that the Mets were offering him a kind of olive branch: a chance to substitute for Tim McCarver in the television booth on some Saturdays this season.

title: Immigration Reform Penalizes Employers
description: To the Editor:

title: After a Talk With Senator D'Amato, Rich Contributor Gets Pipeline Moved
description: A major contributor to Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's campaigns had a planned route for a gas pipeline moved off his empty field and into several nearby homeowners' front yards after personally meeting with the Senator and complaining about the pipeline.

title: Triumph Opened Doors
description: THE so-called miracle victory of the 1980 United States Olympic hockey team at Lake Placid wound up being, quite literally, an icebreaker in terms of the sport's visibility at home and the new stature American hockey attained with the National Hockey League. Suddenly hockey gained viability as a career for aspiring athletes who might otherwise have looked to other sports as their launching pads.

title: Options in Cross-Country Gear
description: SIMPLICITY. Cross-country skiing's astonishing growth has sent old-time downhill skiers back into the woods and has introduced the joys of winter to neophytes because it is a simple sport. Devotees have been telling everyone that if you can walk, you can cross-country ski.

title: Colorado Meet Lures Disabled Skiers
description: KIRK PARKHURST sits in a custom-molded plastic seat, with a suspension system of springs and shock absorbers attached to a single ski under him. With his arms, Parkhurst holds short poles with outrigger skis on the ends. He wears a crash helmet to protect his head as he races at speeds up to 60 miles an hour.

title: Mogilny Given Leave of Absence
description: The Buffalo Sabres have given Aleksandr Mogilny, the first top Soviet hockey player to defect to the United States, an indefinite medical leave of absence.

title: VERMONT SUSPENDS SOME JURY TRIALS
description: The Vermont Supreme Court, trying to comply with budget cuts, has suspended civil jury trials for five months.

title: Bidding for the Best and the Poorest
description: Do major colleges and universities conspire to set the price of tuition and financial aid? The Justice Department's antitrust division has been exploring that question for months, looking at the practices of about 60 institutions. The costly legal fees are eating into scholarship money at some colleges. A quick resolution would serve the cause of justice and of higher education.

title: For the Rest Of the Field
description: MOST of the 90,000 or so thoroughbreds who will race in the United States this year will never get within a country furlong of appearing in, much less winning, a classy and lucrative race of the sort that an Easy Goer or a Sunday Silence appears in almost exclusively.

title: Thousand Trails Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $689,000, or 3 cents a share, and $1,858,000, or 8 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Gotti: Dapper Celebrity Or Ruthless Mob Boss?
description: They came every day to see John Gotti and to shake his hand. For three weeks strangers queued up outside a Manhattan courtroom for a glimpse of the man the authorities call the nation's most powerful Mafia figure.

title: Critic's Notebook;   The Season's Hot Playwright: George S. Kaufman in Revival
description: George S. Kaufman began his life in the theater in his early 20's working for a small summer stock company in Troy, N.Y. He quit after one week, sending his father a telegram that said: ''Last Supper and original cast wouldn't draw in this house.''

title: Vero Beach: Dark Clouds Over Paradise
description: This is not a town that stops everything to bow to royalty.

title: Cirrus Logic reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Keeping Specs in Place
description: rrA tennis player who was annoyed that his eyeglasses slipped during play has designed a strapless device to hold eyewear in place.

title: Outdoors: Tackle To Ogle or Acquire
description: MUCH like the hordes of anglers who rush forth on the opening days of the trout or black-bass seasons, collectors of fishing tackle also have their occasions for congregating.

title: CSX Selects President Of Transportation Unit
description: Robert L. Kirk, an aerospace expert, will soon become a railroad man. Mr. Kirk has been named president and chief executive of CSX Transportation, a 19,000-mile rail system operating in 20 states.

title: Reviews/Music;   Up From the Delta, Blues And Its Home-Grown Roots
description: Friday night's Mississippi blues show at the Triplex Theater, presented by the World Music Institute, might as well have been a seminar on how music adapts to the changing world. Otha Turner opened the concert playing a reed fife that probably sounded just fine on the west coast of Africa a few centuries ago; he sang Little Walter's ''My Babe,'' a Chicago blues tune from the mid-1950's, and played a hymn. And Junior Kimbrough, a guitarist from northeast Mississippi, backed by a band playing soul and rhythm-and-blues, closed the show, playing one-chord modal tunes full of clanging and brittle guitar bursts that predated the 12-bar blues form.

title: William C.W. James, Lawyer, 70
description: William C. W. James, a former board chairman of the Salmagundi Club, the oldest professional artists' club in the United States, died Saturday in Fishguard, Wales, where he had retired in 1987 after working in New York. He was 70 years old.

title: Soviet Visitors Tour Space Center As It Readies Spy Satellite Mission
description: Soviet lawmakers toured the Kennedy Space Center today as the space agency readied the shuttle Atlantis for launching with a secret satellite that will reportedly spy on the Soviet Union.

title: Lendl Takes Final, Trouncing Mayotte
description: Ivan Lendl rendered Tim Mayotte just another disposable challenger this afternoon in the finale of the Skydome World Tennis tournament. While Lendl turned the ball into a tiny yellow cannonball, Mayotte threw away shots with the air of a man tossing out the garbage.

title: Warrantech Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Huge Opposition Rally Fills Main Square in Managua
description: A throng of chanting, cheering demonstrators in the blue and white colors of the National Opposition Union surged into Managua's central plaza today in the largest anti-Sandinista rally ever held here.

title: Trevino Notches 2d Seniors Victory
description: Lee Trevino held off a late challenge by Bruce Crampton today to win the Aetna Challenge by one shot, his second PGA Senior Tour victory.

title: U.S. to Buy New Radar After Study Finds Faults
description: The Government has agreed to buy $359 million worth of weather radar equipment despite the conclusion of Air Force testers that an early version of the radar did not do the job it was designed to do.

title: Expansion Hits Halls of Fame
description: WELL slap your forehead and kick yourself for not thinking of it first, but some visionary baseball enthusiasts have beaten you to the brainstorm. They've come up with the idea of starting a baseball hall of fame.

title: Michael Singer, Industrialist, 85
description: Michael Singer, an industrialist and a former chairman of the board of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University, died of cancer on Saturday at his winter home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 85 years old and also lived in Manhattan.

title: Jackpot Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago periods' share earnings and shares outstanding were adjusted to reflect a 5 percent stock dividend in August 1989.

title: New York Lags in Effort to Move Homeless Families From Hotels
description: New York City, which is having trouble moving homeless families out of welfare hotels, may be unable to fulfill a pledge to stop using the hotels by June, municipal officials say.

title: INSIDE
description: Ethiopia's P.O.W.'s

title: Radiant Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $10,200 and $37,100, or 1 cent a share, for the latest and prior quarters, respectively.

title: Londonderry, Burying Strife, Starts to Rebuild
description: Paddy Doherty pointed at a cheerful building that not so long ago was a bombed-out casualty of sectarian strife. ''We brought it back to life,'' he said, with a kind of pride and enthusiasm that make peace and prosperity here seem possible.

title: Wolohan Lumber reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $189,000.

title: West Fraser Timber reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Fourth-quarter sales were not immediately available. The company said lower earnings for the year reflected down-time at its Eurocan linerboard and Kraft paper mill, which underwent an expansion program. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: HOLLYWOOD'S VIETNAM, NOT MINE
description: I grew up in Vietnam during the war and came to the U.S. in 1975 with the first wave of refugees. It is always with mixed emotions that I watch Vietnam war movies like ''The Deer Hunter,'' ''Full Metal Jacket,'' ''Platoon'' and, now, ''Born on the Fourth of July,'' which has received eight Academy Award nominations.

title: Fine-Tuning Panama's Bank Policy
description: As a senior banking executive for the Panamanian branch of the Chase Manhattan Bank many years ago, Ruben D. Carles received an unexpected visitor late one afternoon, the kind of person he says banks here seldom see anymore.

title: Review/Television;   In 'Montana,' Big Sky Upstages Ranchers
description: An old saw about failed Broadway musicals warns that the score is crucial because you can't hum the scenery. Larry McMurtry's ''Montana'' runs into a similar problem. The made-for-cable movie, being shown on Ted Turner's TNT tonight at 8 and 10, was filmed largely in Bozeman, Mont., and is filled with some splendid vistas of Big Sky country. But Mr. McMurtry's curiously meandering script goes off in so many directions at once that it gets lost. Just about all the elements remain promising, and frustrating.

title: The Startling Spring of 1990
description: It has been a long winter indeed since Soviet tanks crushed Prague Spring in 1968. Now, throughout Eastern Europe, from the Urals to the Elbe and from the Black Sea to the Baltic, elections are promised early this year. With independent, democratic and reform parties blossoming, that means an astonishing 144 million people will realize a once-impossible dream. They will, as the following calendar attests, exercise democratic choice.

title: Amid the Impasse, A Look to Future
description: If revenue sharing eventually comes to baseball, the players will have to have a role in management decisions, the owners' chief labor spokesman said today.

title: Many in Medicine See Rules Sapping Profession's Morale
description: Even the most staid audience of doctors applauds with vigor when Dr. Arthur Caplan gets to the part about Gulliver and the Lilliputians.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;

When Layoffs End, The Lessons Begin
description: LEAD: ABOUT this time every February, every golfer strokes a few putts on the living room rug and utters the same words: this is going to be my year.

title: Reviews/Dance;   Warsaw Ballet's 'Giselle' Speaks to Tradition and Today
description: Nineteenth-century ballet classics are sometimes performed almost dutifully these days, with filips of virtuoso dancing sandwiched in for extra interest. But the Warsaw Ballet's presentation of ''Giselle,'' on Saturday night at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College, could have served as a model of a contemporary ''Giselle.'' This is a smallish touring production, but the sets have a fairy-tale magic and the dancing a simplicity and quiet commitment that made for an evening of extraordinarily touching and poetic ballet theater, filled with burnished details of characterization and style.

title: Chronicle
description: CAROL BELLAMY is sending sure signals that she will re-enter politics: she hired a consultant and is taking a poll. She might challenge New York State Comptroller EDWARD V. REGAN this year. Ms. Bellamy, a Morgan Stanley officer and former City Council president who lost a race for mayor in 1985, has hired a campaign consultant, JON LUKOMNIK, who was press secretary for the former City Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin.

title: Impossible Dream Plus One Decade
description: HELMUT BALDERIS, balding but helmeted, is a 37-year-old, part-time player for the Minnesota North Stars of the National Hockey League.

title: Political Memo;   Big State, Big Change, Big Risk for Democrats
description: Once again the Democrats are tinkering with the Presidential nominating process, clearing the way for that behemoth of American politics, California, to move its 1992 primary from the very end of the primary season to nearly the beginning.

title: WTD Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Second Man Is Held In S.I. Bias Slaying Of a Beach Dweller
description: The Florida police yesterday arrested the second suspect in the slaying of a 44-year-old man with emotional problems who was hunted down and stabbed on a remote Staten Island beach last month because his attackers believed he was homosexual.

title: SETH GRIMES WED TO FRANCO BRILLIANT
description: Franco Sophie Brilliant, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Brilliant of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Seth Leizer Grimes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Grimes of Glenside, Pa., and new York. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Brain Walt at the Estherwood mansion in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: Castro's Last Stand
description: ''Socialism or Death'' is now Fidel Castro's slogan, repeated at the opening and close of his speeches. He may be right, but it is not socialism that is ahead for Cuba.

title: Missouri Eyeing No. 1 Again
description: Doug Smith scored 23 points, including the winning 3-point play with 40 seconds left, as Missouri held off Oklahoma, 92-90, today and put itself in position to regain the No. 1 ranking in the Associated Press poll.

title: Robert J. Collishaw, Banker, 55
description: Robert J. Collishaw, Chemical Bank's senior vice president for corporate affairs, died of a heart attack on Saturday at his vacation home in South Orleans, Mass. He was 55 years old and also lived in Mahwah, N.J.

title: Chronicle
description: With no sign of jet lag, MARY McFADDEN was back in her office after her seventh trip to India in three years. She is designing the costumes for ''Zooni,'' an Indian epic that chronicles the fall of Kashmir in the 16th century, to the Mogul Empire.

title: Computer Network Techology Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: REviews/Music;   A Geographical Journey Relayed Through Sound
description: David Behrman, a composer whose metier is the blending of live instrumental timbres and computer-generated sound, presented a concert of his recent works on Thursday evening at Merkin Concert Hall. Called ''A Traveler's Dream Journal,'' the program included three of the works Mr. Behrman composed during sojourns in West Berlin and Tokyo and on a farm in Pennsylvania.

title: Anchors in New Roles Are Gaining Wealth, But Not Much Prestige
description: When Paula Zahn agreed last week to move from ABC to CBS, she became the latest member of the millionaires' subdivision of the already exclusive network news anchors' club. At CBS, Ms. Zahn will replace Kathleen Sullivan as co-anchor of ''CBS This Morning'' and, an industry executive said, will earn $1.15 million a year - more than four times her ABC salary.

title: Epitope Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
In Pretoria: Last Throes of Marxism?
description: The winds of change battering Marxism around the world have hit the South African Communist Party, which has endured by making itself synonymous in many blacks' minds with the struggle of the majority to free itself of domination by the nation's white minority.

title: Reviews/Music;   Quartet Offers an Account Of a Schubert Rarity
description: Prosperity is often the artistic undoing of small chamber ensembles. The ability to fill increasing numbers of seats places them in halls that maximize income while dwarfing the original intentions of chamber music. Music by the few for the many seldom works.

title: New York State's Budget Troubles Are Rising, Approaching a Crisis
description: After two years of bad news about revenues, New York's financial problems appear to be growing increasingly dire. Financial analysts and even politicians are warning that dramatic steps will be needed to arrest the state's slide toward fiscal crisis.

title: General Automation reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $447,000 for the quarter and $680,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss and after extraordinary credits of $222,000 for the quarter and $260,000 for the 6 months.

title: Metro Matters;   A Commissioner For Consumers Has High Hopes
description: Twenty years ago this month, New York City imposed its paradigmatic consumer protection law. Bess Myerson was consumer affairs commissioner then, followed briefly by Betty Furness. Those were the golden days of the consumer movement.

title: O'Sullivan Strives for Form
description: Between 1986 and 1989 Marcus O'Sullivan was the king of the indoor milers.

title: Overnight Mail Service To End in Some Areas
description: Trading off speed for reliability, the Postal Service plans this summer to eliminate overnight delivery of first-class mail for millions of Americans.

title: Sensor Control Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Moscow a Year Later: Rutted Streets and Despair
description: A few impressions of Moscow after an absence of a year:

title: Son Tells of Drugs; Woman Is Arrested
description: A 26-year-old Stratford woman was arrested on drug charges after her 6-year-old son told school authorities, ''My mommy is using drugs,'' the police said.

title: Hytek Microsystems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-After income of $176,000, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter and a loss of $742,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations. c-Net income d-Included losses from discontinued operations of $139,000 and $294,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. Included in the latest year's continuing operations is a loss of $444,000 on the sale of certain assets of Topaz Semiconductor Inc. The company said the decline in the latest quarter and year results reflected the loss of Digital Equipment Corp. as a customer, and general reduction in orders overall.

title: Associated Natural Gas reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect payment of preferred stock dividends.

title: Alan Bond, Besieged Entrepreneur, Struggles to Save Troubled Empire
description: Alan Bond, the entrepreneur and yachtsman, used to boast that his was the most recognized Australian name in the world. But these days, he is becoming better known as the head of an empire in slow-motion collapse -one that might become Australia's largest business failure.

title: PROTESTS IN NEPAL LEAVE FOUR DEAD
description: The police battled with thousands of students and political militants demonstrating for democracy in central Katmandu today, and at least four people were killed in clashes in the Nepalese countryside.

title: George Washington, De-debunked
description: A kind word is in order on President's Day for those white Anglo-Saxon Protestants known as the Founding Fathers. It is tempting, in the free society they helped create, to look back irreverently at these bewigged strangers embalmed in textbooks. Indeed, the word ''debunk'' was first employed by W. E. Woodward in a belittling 1923 biography of George Washington. Yet by the standards of the present no less than his own age, Washington's greatness cannot be debunked.

title: Offense, Offense
description: AFTER holding down ''a million'' jobs, Ernie DiGregorio has returned to the source. The former all-American from Providence College, who was the National Basketball Association rookie of the year in 1973-74, is in his second season as coach of his alma mater, North Providence High School.

title: Islanders Continue To Slide
description: The first-place Islanders have lost three games in a row for the first time since their Great Slump of November.

title: Chinese Students Remain a Human Rights Issue;   Abject Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Open Skies' - Money in the Bank
description: LEAD: An aircraft passes overhead at 33,000 feet. It carries a specially designed camera that is made by a U.S. manufacturer and can be purchased for less than $3 million. Later, a photo interpreter, using pictures taken by the camera from 25 miles away, can read the hands of a church steeple clock.

title: New England Bank Layoffs
description: The Bank of New England Corporation says as many as 2,000 employees will be laid off as part of its attempt to curtail losses.

title: Books of The Times;   Passions for the Ordinary In an Extraordinary Life
description: C. S. Lewis: A Biography

title: Sihanouk to See Cambodian Premier
description: Prime Minister Hun Sen plans to meet this month with Prince Norodom Sihanouk and renew a proposal that the Prince break with the Khmer Rouge guerrillas and return to Cambodia as the country's President and Commander in Chief, Cambodian officials said today.

title: Cuomo Budget Cuts Imperil Dropout Programs
description: To the Editor:

title: Cerner Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Seel Mortgage Invest reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Ernest Cole Dies at 49; Recorder of Apartheid
description: Ernest Cole, a South African photographer who published a pioneering collection of photographs documenting life under apartheid, died of cancer yesterday at New York Hospital in Manhattan. He was 49 years old.

title: SUSAN J. KLEIN IS MARRIED
description: The mariage of Susan Jane Klein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allan Klein of North Bellmore, L.I., to Dr. Kenneth Jay Cohen of Brooklyn, took place yesterday at Temple Hillel in North Woodmere, L.I. Rabbi Morris Friedman and Cantor Chaskele Ritter officiaed. Mrs. cohen, 26 years old, is a candidate for a Ph.D. in clinical psychology at St. John's University. The bridegroom, 27, is a dentist in Woodmere, L.I.

title: A Different Drummer in Japan
description: So often in Japanese business life, success comes to those who avoid risks and follow the well-trodden paths. Then there are people like Kazuo Wada, chairman of the Yaohan Department Store Company, who personifies another Japanese type: the devoted renegade.

title: Azerbaijan and the Kremlin
description: Circumstantial evidence suggests that the explosion of ethnic violence in Azerbaijan was not as spontaneous as it seemed. Page A8.

title: Brock Exploration Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: Barr Laboratories Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Weyenberg Shoe ManufacturFing Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Chronicle
description: A blood feud has split heirs of the Scheuer Family, a wealthy New York philanthropic clan. STEVEN H. and WALTER SCHEUER, two sons of S. H. and Helen R. Sheuer, are suing their brother, Richard; their sister, Amy Scheuer Cohen and her husband Saul, and five non-family directors of the Scheuer Family Foundation.

title: Gibson (C.R.) Co.  (A) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said 1989 figures included the results of Dawn Distributors, the company's new Canadian unit, since the September 1989 acquisition date.

title: The Rap on Frederick Douglass
description: LEAD:

title: KAREN HEISS IS MARRIED
description: Karen Robin Heiss, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris of Brooklyn, and Michael Sturart Eison. the son of Arlene Bluestone of North Long Branch, N.J., and Leonard Eisen of Greenwich, Conn., were married last evening at the Seaview Jewish Center in Brooklyn by Rabbi Alvin Marcus, an uncle of the bridgegroom. Mrs. Eisen, 28 years old, is an assistant district attorney in Manhattan. The bridegroom, 33, is a sportswriter at the Star-Ledger in Newark.

title: Hemacare Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Gradco Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Venereal Disease Is Far More Than a Nuisance
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Overturns Conviction Of Female Marine in Sex Case
description: A military appeals court has overturned the conviction of a former corporal in the Marine Corps who served 226 days in the brig in 1988 on charges of engaging in sex with another woman, a defense lawyer says.

title: Heartland Express Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Seitel Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Chronicle
description: Being a solo musician was growing less satisfying for BOBBY McFERRIN. He took a sabbatical from performing in October, 1988, and has just emerged. During the interlude, he created Voicestra, a music theater group. And he studied conducting.

title: FLORENCE MAMOU MARRIES
description: Florence Mamou, a student at New York University, was married yesterday in Paris to Jean Madar, the founder and president of Jean Philippe Fragrances, a cosmetics and perfume company in New York City. Rabbi Alan Goldman, the Chief Rabbi of Paris, performed the ceremony at Temple Rue de la Victoire. Mrs. Madar, 20 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andre Mamou of Paris. The bridegroom, 29, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raoul Madar of Paris.

title: Crimes of Hate
description: Add Mr. and Mrs. Wilfred Phillip and James Zappalorti to the list of bias-crime victims in New York. The Phillips, a black couple, recently bought a house in a predominantly white Brooklyn neighborhood. A week later, the house burned in what investigators say was a case of racially motivated arson. Mr. Zappalorti, a Staten Island resident, was killed last month, allegedly because he was gay.

title: Couple Is Acquitted in Death Of Son in Religious Healing
description: A Christian Scientist couple who tried to heal their ailing 15-month-old son through prayer instead of medical care, have been acquitted on charges of involuntary manslaughter and child endangerment.

title: Jody Ellant and Howard Reiter Wed
description: Jody Patricia Ellant, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Paul Ellant of Great Neck, L.I., and Boca Raton, Fla., was married last evening to Howard Jay Reiter, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley F. Reiter of New Haven. Rabbis Jerome Davidson and Albert Feldman officiated at Temple Beth-El in Great Neck.

title: Chinese Students Remain a Human Rights Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: Chambers Has 56 as Suns Top Warriors
description: Tom Chambers scored a team-record 56 points today as the Phoenix Suns beat Golden State, 131-113, ending the Warriors' franchise-record home winning streak at 15 games.

title: A Spotlight On Obscure Agency
description: After the upheaval in Eastern Europe and the United States invasion of Panama, the Bush Administration is using a little-known Federal agency as a tool to achieve one of its main international policy goals - market-oriented economic reconstruction.

title: Putting America's Culture on Embassy Walls
description: ''Paintings are like people's children, so I think it is a very big-hearted loan,'' said Lacey Neuhaus Dorn, propping up a luminous Milton Avery that the artist's widow, Sally, lent the State Department 10 years ago for its Art in Embassies program.

title: Sports of The Times;   Lincoln and the N.F.L.
description: PAUL TAGLIABUE, the commissioner of the National Football League, has freed college juniors for eligibility in the league's annual draft, although this doesn't quite make him the Abraham Lincoln for college football underclassmen.

title: Ethnic Groups in Chicago Aid East European Homelands
description: Using a borrowed computer and working out of the study of his house on Chicago's North Side, Gabriel Nicolescou this week finished the second issue of Democratic Romania, a 12-page newsletter that carries translations of American news reports on Romania.

title: New President of Macy Unit
description: Mark S. Sellers, the executive vice president and chief financial officer of the Marshalls Inc. unit of the Melville Corporation, has been named president and chief operating officer of the Macy's South/Bullocks division of R. H. Macy & Company in Atlanta.

title: Datasouth Computer reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: VIRGINIA F. COLEMAN WEDS
description: Virginai F. Coleman, a partner in the law firm of Ropes & Grayin Boston, was married there yesterday to Mervin M. Wilf, who is of counsel to the Boston law firm of Hale & Dorr. Rabbi Beverly Lerner officiated at the Harvard Club, assisted by the Rev. Margaret Gunness, an Episcopal priest. The bride, 45 years old, is keeping her name. She is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Coleman of Bedford Hills, N.Y. Her husband, 63, is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Wilf. Ms. Coleman's previous marriage ended in divorce, as did Mr. Wilf's.

title: Stuart Hall Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Share earnings for all periods are adjusted for the 4-for-3 stock split effective Dec. 18, 1989. The company said that in the last half of 1989, a drop in the price of paper caused a writedown in value of total company inventory by $1,150,000. Most of the writedown, $837,447, occurred in the fourth quarter.

title: Indoor Winner a Man in 1,000
description: A thousand competitors rowed more than 1,500 miles today at the ninth annual world indoor championships and never got out the door of the Rockwell Cage at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, on the banks of the Charles River.

title: Bowl America Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Show by the Platters
description: The Platters vocal group will perform tonight at 8 o'clock at Cafe Feenjon, 40 West Eighth Street (979-8686). Tickets are $15.

title: Knowledge Data Systems Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Suits in Oil Spill Are Settled for $30 Million
description: The 20 lawsuits filed against Ashland Oil Inc. for a 1988 diesel fuel spill that disrupted water service in three states have been settled out of court for $30 million.

title: Fleet Aerospace Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Genrad Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Net income The company said the latest full- year figures included a charge of $3,010,000 for reorganization. Year-ago full-year figures included a charge of $10,000,000 for the restructuring of its service products division in Phoenix, Ariz.

title: Atmos Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Guard Is Arrested In Rape of Student
description: A private security guard at Columbia University was arrested yesterday and charged with the rape of a freshman in her off-campus dormitory room early Saturday, the police said.

title: BARBARA FRISCHER WED TO BARRY ALLEN BROOKS
description: Barbara Jean Frischer, the daughter of Mrs. and Leonard Frischer of Oyster Bay, L.I., was married yesterday in West Hollywood, Calif., to Barry Allen Brooks, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Brooks of Tarzana, Calif. Rabbi Donald Goor performed the ceremony at the Bel Age Hotel.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about Jewish Festival '90 misidentified the company that made the large gefilte fish shown. It was Ungar's Heimishe Gefilte Fish of Spring Valley, N.Y.

title: No-Fuss Clothes, Neat Hair: The Look for Summer
description: Hair styles at the spring and summer haute couture shows in Paris last month were slick and uncomplicated, setting the standard for the warm-weather months.

title: The City's Empty Chairs
description: It's been 15 weeks since David Dinkins knew he'd be Mayor of New York City, and seven weeks since he took the oath of office. Yet critical jobs in his administration remain unfilled. The vacancies are beginning to do damage, and not just in theory.

title: Consultant in Textiles Becomes Manufacturer
description: Roger J. Gilmartin, a European textile consultant, will try his hand at running an American textile company, Opp and Micolas Mills Inc., which has mills in Alabama and offices in New York. One of his strategies will be to expand export markets in Europe.

title: Connecticut Triumphs in Overtime
description: Nadav Henefeld hit a 3-pointer with two seconds left in overtime tonight to give Connecticut a 75-72 Big East Conference victory over Providence.

title: Cuomo Budget, Far From Austere, Exceeds Inflation Increase;   A Gift to the Rich
description: To the Editor:

title: Lasker Foundation Suspends Its Awards
description: IN a surprise move, the Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation has decided not to make its medical and scientific awards this year. The awards of $15,000 each are among the most prestigious American prizes in the field.

title: Party Rivals Rush to Endorse Kaifu
description: Bolstered by a sweeping election victory, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu drew the support of his major Liberal Democratic Party rivals today to remain in office for 18 months more and seek to restore stability to Japan after more than a year of political upheaval.

title: Salary Arbitration a Key Factor As Baseball Talks Are Stalled
description: Salary arbitration, the system that has resulted in an aggregate 98 percent raise for about one-quarter of all major league players, continued to keep baseball's club owners and players sufficiently apart yesterday to jeopardize the start of the exhibition schedule.

title: Lonely Days for Traders at Budapest Exchange
description: With a dozen personal computers placed neatly around a square table in a stuffy, windowless room, Hungary's stock exchange seems more like a student pilot project than a functioning financial market.

title: Allen Rivkin, 86, Dies; Writer of Screenplays
description: Allen Rivkin, a screenwriter and a founder of the Screenwriters Guild, died of kidney failure on Saturday at his home in West Hollywood, Calif. He was 86 years old.

title: On or Off the World?
description: Awareness is spreading among the public that profound changes are racing through the world, and that they will make a big difference to the U.S. role.

title: A Country Is Haunted
description: The flawed political legacy of Nicolae Ceausescu is haunting the efforts of Ion Iliescu, the provisional President, to establish a postrevolutionary government.

title: Chronicle
description: BEATRICE RIVAS SANCHEZ, the Art Institute's president, said the gift will pay for architectural and planning fees, construction costs, a sculpture garden and the base of an endowment to cover museum operations.

title: Jets Add 2 Assistants
description: The Jets have hired two college aides, Greg Robinson of U.C.L.A. and Bob Wylie of Colorado State, as assistant coaches.

title: Jail Term in Pentagon Case
description: A military contracting consultant, Thomas E. Muldoon, has been sentenced to 27 months in prison and fined $10,000 for participating in a six-year scheme to bribe a Pentagon procurement official.

title: Corrections
description: A map accompanying an article yesterday on radiation exposure in airline flights omitted in some copies the number of cancer deaths over the national average that can be expected from flying routes 960 hours a year over 20 years. The national average is 22,000 cancer deaths for each 100,000 people. The following are the additional deaths that a Transportation Department study projected for certain representative routes: New York to Seattle, 1,003; Denver to Minneapolis, 527; Miami to Tampa, 85; Tampa to St. Louis, 357.

title: India Paves Way for Kashmir Elections
description: The Governor of the state of Jammu and Kashmir, which is troubled by anti-India agitation, dissolved the state legislature today, paving the way for possible elections this year.

title: Continually Coming Up Empty;   The Nets Are Losing Games, Fans, Tempers and Respect
description: Welcome to Byrne Meadowlands Arena, home of the Nets. See the empty seats. Endure the comatose atmosphere. Watch the Nets lose. Uninviting as it sounds, that has been the scenario at most Nets home games the last four seasons. Even worse, the perception among many basketball fans is that the Nets have been a losing organization forever.

title: Reviews/Music;   A Lesson in Showmanship From a Master
description: Like most other conductors, the young Austrian Bruno Weil appears to fancy showmanship, and he just received a lesson from a master. Mr. Weil, who has garnered acclaim for his performances in the Schubertiades at the 92d Street Y in the last three seasons, took over the regular concerts of the New York Chamber Symphony in the Kaufmann Concert Hall on Saturday and Sunday. The program was motley, beginning with Arnold Schoenberg's ''Verklarte Nacht'' (Op. 4) and ending with Georges Bizet's Symphony in C, and one was curious to see what Mr. Weil would make of it.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Atmos Energy Corp., Dallas, a distributor of natural gas, named Jerry D. Knierim executive vice president for corporate services.

title: Man Opens Fire in Hospital, Killing 1 at U.C.L.A. Center
description: A gunman opened fire on two employees at the U.C.L.A. Medical Center early today, killing one and seriously injuring the other, the authorities said.

title: Drillers Extract Part of Oldest Ocean Floor
description: AFTER many vain attempts, a sample of what is believed to be the earth's oldest ocean floor has been extracted by drilling into the bottom of the Pacific beneath 18,652 feet of water south of Japan.

title: Dinkins and Florio Striving to Untangle Maze of Problems;   New Jersey's Governor Is Taking a Tighter Grip On Reins of Government
description: In his first month as Governor, Jim Florio has quickly attacked the independent centers of power in state government, drawing into his office more personal control of the sprawling bureaucracy here than any recent governor.

title: INSIDE
description: New Bishop for Brooklyn

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Worst Fears on Acid Rain Unrealized
description: A 10-YEAR, half-billion-dollar federally sponsored investigation is concluding that acid rain causes some significant environmental damage but far less than initially feared.

title: Q&A
description: Sunrise, Sunset

title: Review/Skating;   Pinocchio on Ice at Radio City Music Hall
description: ''Pinocchio,'' a tale that has mesmerized children both as a story written in 1881 by Carlo Collodi and a feature-length animated film by Walt Disney in 1940, is now live on ice at Radio City Music Hall. It is a good skate in every sense of the word and, particularly if one is entertaining smaller fry, will be worth a visit during its stay, which ends on Sunday.

title: Line of Blue, 5,000 Strong, Salutes Slain L.I. Detective
description: Standing seven deep to form a wall of blue that stretched nearly half a mile, more than 5,000 police officers today mourned a Suffolk County narcotics detective who was killed last Thursday in a car bombing outside his home in North Patchogue.

title: BRIEFS
description: Common Stock

title: Plan to Eradicate Coca Would Use Caterpillars
description: The Bush Administration is considering the use of millions of caterpillars that feed on coca plants to destroy cocaine at its source in Peru and Bolivia, an official of the United States Department of Agriculture said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We live in an integrated neighborhood, and 25 years ago whites would have moved out when a black moved in. We fought to overturn the all-white policy at our church. I'm just a different person from the person my mother was back then.''

title: 7 Presumed Dead After Lake Rescue Goes Awry
description: Three young people who fell through thin ice on a mountain lake and four adults who tried to save them were presumed dead today after the water froze over them.

title: MOSCOW REJECTS U.S. PLEA TO ALLOW FLIGHTS TO ISRAEL
description: The Soviet Union, under heavy pressure from Arab countries, has rejected an appeal from the Bush Administration to allow direct flights for Soviet Jews from Moscow to Israel, Administration officials said today.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Review/Theater;   Lead Role for a Theater, With the Audience on Stage
description: ''Crowbar,'' the newest site-specific project of Anne Hamburger's En Garde Arts company, is an act of reclamation and renewal. On Sunday, the Mac Wellman play reopened the Victory Theater on West 42d Street as a home for legitimate theater - unfortunately only through March 11.

title: Chess
description: The 52d running of the Hoogoven International Tournament in Wijk-aan-Zee, the Netherlands, took an unexpected turn before it ended Jan. 28. After 10 of the 13 rounds, Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland had first place all to himself by a half-point and there was no reason to suppose that he would falter.

title: Sweden's Social Model Shows Signs of Cracks
description: As the leaders of Sweden's political parties continue maneuvering to try to form a new government, many people here say they doubt that the Swedish economic and social welfare system, once the envy of the world, can survive in its present form.

title: How to Fight a Tax Bill
description: Challenging tax assessments often requires a lawyer's help. But some homeowners go it alone. The main vehicle is a challenge to the New York City Tax Commission. The forms used are available at the offices of the New York City Real Property Assessment Bureau in each borough. Challenges are considered in tax commission hearings.

title: Putting Disabled In Touch
description: PERSONAL computers can offer independence, employment and information to millions of the estimated 37 million Americans with a physical or mental disability, helping them to lead richer, more fulfilling lives.

title: Congressional Tax Writers Doubt I.R.S. Can Collect New Revenues
description: After taking their first close look at some of the revenue proposals in President Bush's budget, Congressional tax writers say they doubt that $3 billion can be raised next year through management initiatives at the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Dinkins and Florio Striving to Untangle Maze of Problems;   New York Mayor Moves On Some Issues Quickly But Challenges Remain
description: Seven weeks into his term, Mayor David N. Dinkins is facing the difficult challenges of moving an unwieldy city bureaucracy and of persuading supporters that he can make a difference in a city grappling with crime, drugs and poverty.

title: Canada's Trade Surplus Off
description: Canada's merchandise trade surplus fell to its lowest level in a decade in 1989, a federal agency said Friday.

title: Critic's Notebook;   Insidious Elements in Television Cartoons
description: Over the years of confronting television executives and producers, Peggy Charren, president of Action for Children's Television, a national whistle-blower founded in the 1970's by a group of Boston-area parents, has developed a knack for getting directly to the heart of the matter. ''If television were working,'' she says, ''kids would want to go out and clean up the rivers, help the hungry and the homeless, and would know that peace is a good thing and nuclear war is the end of the world.''

title: Rising Hopes for Castro's Fall Have Cubans in Miami Abuzz
description: Across South Florida, bumper stickers proclaim the end of the Castro era: ''Next Christmas in Havana.'' On Spanish-language radio, hour after hour is devoted to fevered speculation about a democratic millennium to come in Cuba. Even the Governor has joined in, convening a commission to imagine a Florida after Fidel.

title: The Voice of Malcolm X Has an Audience Again
description: Twenty-five years after Malcolm X was assassinated, his voice is being heard again, his ideology is being re-examined and his face adorns T-shirts and buttons.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   An Agency That Offers Some Frills
description: MOST small young advertising agencies try to sell themselves to clients by promoting their creative originality. Henszey & Albert is different. It offers prospective clients collateral. And package design and sales promotion and even direct marketing.

title: Co-Founder Leaves Next
description: The vice president of sales at Next Inc. has left the company to become vice president of sales and marketing at the Go Corporation, a start-up computer company that is developing a portable that users can control with handwriting.

title: Malpractice Report Told but a Part of Grim Story;   Combine Plans
description: To the Editor:

title: Melinte Confronts Revenue Sharing
description: Almost everywhere they go these days, athletes from Eastern Europe find themselves answering questions about the changes in their homelands.

title: A Modest Way to Rebuild Airports
description: Since 1973, Federal law has prohibited local airports from imposing head taxes or departure fees on passengers. Now the Bush Administration is asking Congress to lift that ban and to raise the Federal airline passenger tax to 10 percent. Both proposals merit passage.

title: Electronic Forms Fill The Bill In Business
description: EVERY business lives on forms. There are invoices and time sheets, collection notices and purchase orders, requisitions and payment records. FormTool, first marketed in 1985 and now in version 2.01D, lets you design new forms or adapt standard ones on the screen of a personal computer.

title: California Journal;   A Study On Feelings Creates Bad Ones
description: After three years of study that was often derided, the California Task Force to Promote Self-Esteem and Personal and Social Responsibility has issued its final report, promoting Horatio Alger virtures, but clothing them in New Age terms.

title: Chronicle
description: Like many Americans, BARBARA BUSH went sale shopping yesterday. Unlike many Americans, she was surrounded by reporters, a camera crew and tourists in Kennebunkport, Me., near the family's retreat.

title: Drexel Fall May Push Rates Up
description: While the credit markets appear to have weathered the collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. last week, the full fallout from the bankruptcy is likely to include higher interest rates.

title: Chronicle
description: In the shifting sands of California politics, Brown is as close to a dynasty as you can get: for 29 of the last 39 years, a Brown has held a high state office. Now, KATHLEEN BROWN is campaigning for State Treasurer.

title: Japan Business Leaders Ambivalent on Election
description: Japan's worried business community expressed relief but little joy after the election victory Sunday of the pro-business Liberal Democratic Party. Some executives expressed concern over the economic problems that a divided Parliament faces in coming months.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   GGT Acquires Texas Agency
description: The GGT Group of London, a fast-growing, publicly traded group of advertising and marketing service companies, has agreed to acquire GSD&M of Austin, Tex., the two companies said today.

title: William Reed Huntington, 83; Worked for Quakers at the U.N.
description: William Reed Huntington, an architect and a former Quaker representative to the United Nations and director of the Quaker program there, died of lung cancer on Sunday at his home in Norwich, Vt. He was 83 years old.

title: New York Property Tax Bills Soar As City's Real-Estate Boom Ends
description: The owners of cooperatives, condominiums and rental apartments in New York City, who have already seen their property values stung by the stumbling of the local economy, have been getting more bad news in the mail: tax increases now coming due based on the ascent of real-estate values in the mid-1980's.

title: Court to Decide Missouri Prisoner's Right to Father a Child
description: As Sabrena Goodwin sees it, the Federal prison system has a perfect right to keep her husband behind bars, but it should not be able to interfere with their right to have a child.

title: Heavy Activity Despite a Shortened Week
