description: Treasury financings this week include today's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, followed by an auction of two-year notes tomorrow and a five-year note on Thursday.

title: Apple Layoffs Are Expected
description: Apple Computer Inc. is expected to lay off 400 to 500 employees this week as part of an effort to control expenses, industry executives said. Apple's growth has slowed, partly because of an industry slump and partly because its product line lacks competitive inexpensive personal computers.

title: Many With Arthritis Do Not Seek Care
description: Thirty-five million Americans report suffering from arthritis, but 6 million of them say they have not seen a doctor about it, Federal health officials say.

title: Dollar Rises Against the Yen
description: The dollar closed slightly higher today against the yen, which weakened after the Liberal Democratic Party retained power in Japan's general election on Sunday.

title: How Indochina Moved
description: A team of Canadian, Chinese and French geologists has concluded that during the past 50 million years, the collision of India with Asia pushed Indochina more than 300 miles to the southeast and rotated it clockwise. This, they suspect, swung Vietnam more than 400 miles away from China, forming the South China Sea.

title: Movie Cans
description: ''Why don't you bring that stuff?'' she said as they rose from their seats in the shiny new Cineplex Odeon movie theater on Eighth Avenue and 50th. ''What stuff?'' he asked. ''The soda cup, and the empty popcorn bag.'' ''Oh, all right.'' He bent down to retrieve the leavings and noticed what she had already noticed. There was none of the usual sticky spills, no wads of paper; there was no trash at all along the whole row.

title: Review/Theater;   A Comic Portrait of Duncan In Her Gloomy Final Years
description: Isadora Duncan won't dance -don't ask her - in ''When She Danced,'' Martin Sherman's play at Playwrights Horizons. The year is 1923, the place is Paris and the lady is, as she puts it, ''extremely kaput.'' Isadora sees herself as old (45, actually) and fat. Her money and perhaps her inspiration have fled. Her sojourn to Russia has marked her as ''a Bolshevik whore'' back home in America. Her husband, the poet Sergei Yesenin, is a violent, depressive alcoholic nearly two decades her junior. In four years, Isadora will be dead.

title: Steroid Use Reported
description: The University of South Carolina uncovered six instances of possible rule violations and found ''widespread experimentation'' by football players with steroids in 1983-87, says a report by the school to the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: New Bishop Of Brooklyn Is Chosen
description: Bishop Thomas V. Daily of Palm Beach, Fla., will be named the Roman Catholic Bishop of Brooklyn today, succeeding Bishop Francis J. Mugavero, who has led the diocese for 22 years, a Catholic church official said last night.

title: Chronicle
description: From Palm Beach to Palm Springs? MAYOR MARION S. BARRY JR. of Washington will not stay at the Hanley-Hazelden Center in West Palm Beach, Fla., where he completed a 28-day treatment cycle for alcoholism yesterday. He went there following his arrest on Jan. 18 in Washington on a drug charge.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a student protest at Vassar College gave an incorrect account of how it ended.

title: Guard in Columbia Rape Had Arrest Record
description: A 28-year-old Manhattan security guard arrested in the dormitory-room rape of a freshman over the weekend worked for Columbia University for months despite a police record including convictions for gambling and impersonating a police officer, the authorities said yesterday.

title: New Liver for Stormie Jones
description: Stormie Jones, the 12-year-old recipient of the world's first heart-liver transplant, arrived in Pittsburgh today for a second liver transplant because of damage from hepatitis.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a report on sentencing decisions in California's judicial system incorrectly described where the study was published. It was in the Feb. 16 issue of Science, a weekly journal.

title: Molitor's Yearly Pay Hits $3 Million Plateau
description: Paul Molitor joined the $3 million-a-year circle when he and the Milwaukee Brewers agreed on a three-year, $9.1 million contract yesterday, one day before they were scheduled to argue their differences in salary arbitration.

title: Black Studies Meets Classics Department
description: To the Editor:

title: Princeton Eating Club Votes to Admit Women
description: Tiger Inn, one of two all-male eating clubs at Princeton University, voted tonight to take a first step towards admitting women.

title: New Fund to Help Unions Buy Ailing Factories
description: In an effort to prevent plant closings and resulting layoffs, union leaders and a new investment firm said today that they are forming a fund to help workers buy factories.

title: Rights Protesters Attacked in Nepal
description: A Nepalese democracy movement, modeling itself on the campaigns for change that have shaken or toppled governments from Beijing to Bucharest, was born here over the weekend in a hail of broken bricks and stones.

title: Talking Business with Robert A. Stanger;   Real Estate Woe For Syndicators
description: Last week's announcement that VMS Realty Partners, one of the nation's largest sellers of real estate partnerships, was suspending nonessential payments to outsiders provided further evidence of serious problems in the real estate syndication business.

title: William J. McDonald, 62, Dies; Lawyer Who Helped Form Conrail
description: William J. McDonald, a lawyer and former senior vice president of the Union Pacific Corporation who played a major role in the formation of Conrail, died of cancer yesterday at Greenwich, Conn., Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived in Rye.

title: A Survival of the Past, Anti-Semitism Is Back
description: At a time when anti-Semitism has again become a public issue in Hungary, B'nai B'rith International has reopened a chapter here, its first official presence in Eastern Europe after the long hiatus of the Communist era.

title: Airlines' Big Gamble on Expansion
description: The nation's biggest airlines, stung by higher fuel prices and a slowdown in traffic in recent months, are nevertheless gambling on a turnaround and for the most part proceeding with ambitious expansion plans. But with a record number of new planes set for delivery this year, the carriers could find themselves stretched to remain profitable if current conditions continue, analysts say.

title: Cuomo Budget, Far From Austere, Exceeds Inflation Increase
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Taps the East Bloc's Intellectual Reserves
description: Most American companies view the Soviet Union and the newly opening nations in Eastern Europe as potential markets for their products or as sources of low-cost manufacturing labor. And a growing number are expected to tap another resource they describe as plentiful and underused: brainpower.

title: Wendy's Net Drops 16%
description: Wendy's International Inc. today reported a 16 percent decline in profits for the fourth quarter but said earnings for the year increased 6.6 percent. Wendy's, which is based in this suburb of Columbus, cited no specific reason for the drop in its quarterly earnings, except to note that the company ended the year with 55 fewer restaurants, largely because of sales to franchise owners. For the quarter that ended on Dec. 31, profits totaled $5.7 million, or 6 cents a share, compared with earnings of $6.8 million, or 7 cents a share, in the fourth quarter a year ago.

title: Japanese Executives Are Wary
description: Business leaders expressed concern that the Liberal Democrats would not be able to enact legislation addressing domestic economic problems. Business Day, page D2.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a planned reduction in postal service included in some copies an incorrect example of the effects of the cutback. Letters mailed within the same city will still be delivered the next day.

title: Making the New Serve the Old
description: New York City's Landmarks Preservation Commission is scheduled to vote today on a proposed 12-story office building in the South Street Seaport Historic District in lower Manhattan. The vote raises a large issue: whether the Landmarks Commission and the city will embrace a balanced approach to development in historic districts. Such an approach could actually encourage the preservation of older buildings by permitting construction of compatible new buildings.

title: Rangers Win in Overtime
description: The game was over, but the televisions and tape machines in both locker rooms at Madison Square Garden were just beginning to roll. Back and forth the incident was replayed, at regular speed, in slow motion and finally frame by solitary frame.

title: Duva Says King Is a Force In Douglas's Title Defense
description: James (Buster) Douglas and his manager, John Johnson, may want Evander Holyfield, and not Mike Tyson, as the new heavyweight champion's next opponent, but questions remain about whether the bout can be made without a hitch.

title: Accord on Hotel Sales
description: Hotel Investors Trust, a real estate investment trust based here, and the Hotel Investors Corporation, a hotel management company based in San Diego, said last week that they had signed a definitive agreement to sell their interests in 31 hotels to Park Plaza Inc. an affiliate of the EIE International Corporation of Japan, for $185.8 million. The deal is subject to conditions, including approvals from shareholders and regulators.

title: McEnroe Doesn't Go Gently Onto Tour
description: At Philadelphia, where he is attempting to win a record fifth Ebel Pro Indoor title this week, he is billed as the rebel with a cause. More than ever, it seems an appellation that invites no dispute.

title: Billions Elude Dollar Tally; Is Currency in Use Abroad?
description: Call it the mystery of the missing money.

title: VETERANS' LOANS FOCUS OF DEBATE
description: The Bush Administration's proposal to start requiring veterans to make down payments on home loans uses a forecast that a veterans' affairs official says is too pessimistic about foreclosures.

title: 'Magic' Crystals: Key to New Technologies?
description: IT seems more like magic than a laboratory demonstration.

title: Chapman Rose, 83, Lawyer Who Served In 2 Administrations
description: H. Chapman Rose, a Cleveland lawyer who became an Under Secretary of the Treasury in the Eisenhower Administration and later a personal adviser to President Richard M. Nixon in the Watergate crisis, died of emphysema Saturday at Sibley Hospital in Washington. He was 83 years old and lived in Washington.

title: 22-Week Mission Ends for Soviet Astronauts
description: Two astronauts today ended a 22-week mission that included the first American experiment aboard the Soviet space station Mir.

title: Scientists Confront An Alarming Mystery: The Vanishing Frog
description: A panel of experts met here today to assess an alarming number of reports that amphibians are rapidly disappearing from many ponds, rivers, mountains and rain forests around the world.

title: Unit of Bristol-Myers Names New President
description: The Drackett Company, a unit of the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company that makes household products including Windex and Drano, has named Thomas L. Dahl, who made his marketing mark with Huggies diapers, to be its new president.

title: Ann Bissinger and Mark Poor Married
description: Ann Louise Bissinger was married yesterday to Mark Whitney Poor, a son of Comdr. John L. Poor, U.S.N. retired, and Mrs. Poor, of Royalston, Mass. The ceremony was performed at the Nantucket, Mass., home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. H. Gerard Bissinger 2d, who also have a home in New York. The Rev. Theodore Anderson, a Unitarian minister, officiated.

title: Malpractice Report Told but a Part of Grim Story
description: To the Editor:

title: Chronicle
description: R. CROSBY KEMPER has given $6 million to the Kansas City (Mo.) Art Institute to establish a museum of contemporary art. The new Kemper Museum of Contemporary Art and Design will be built on the Art Institute's midtown campus.

title: Our Towns;   Win, Team, Win! That Is to Say, Don't Dare Lose!
description: The Elizabeth High School Minutemen, the top-ranked high school basketball team in New Jersey, won by 30 points Friday night, but Coach Ben Candelino was not happy. Easy shots had strayed from the basket. Passes had slipped through usually unerring hands.

title: But We Close Our Eyes
description: From the Soviet Union to South Africa, societies are confronting their fundamental problems. Immobilism is giving way to change. There has never been a time in the world like this, we say to each other.

title: Fear of Disorder Shadows the Opposition Campaign in Nicaragua
description: In the heated last-minute campaigning for national elections on Sunday, opposition leaders have found themselves confronted by a dark new campaign issue: not whether their fragile coalition would make a good government, but whether it could even survive.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about an art conference at the New York Hilton misidentified one of the artists whose work led to Congressional restrictions on the National Endowment for the Arts. He is Andres Serrano.

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: Vandeweghe Returns For Limited Workout
description: Kiki Vandeweghe participated today in his first practice with the Knicks since last October, but his limited workout did nothing to dispel the uncertainty over when he might play his first game.

title: Books of the Times;   About a Very Old Young Man Married to a Ninny
description: Lewis Percy

title: Japan's Vote And the U.S.
description: As relations between Japan and the United States rapidly deteriorate, officials of both countries today turned to the same question: Will the strong victory posted by Japan's governing party help contain the trade and security disputes tearing at the Pacific alliance?

title: At Duke U., Bogus Baron Fit Right In
description: He called himself Baron Maurice Jeffrey Locke de Rothschild and identified himself as a member of the wealthy Rothschild family of France.

title: Wariness Is Replacing Trust Between Healer and Patient
description: Doctor-patient relationships are becoming a distorted version of the rosy image so many Americans have long held dear.

title: Bronx Game Opens P.S.A.L. Tournament
description: The Public Schools Athletic League tournament will get under way today at 4 P.M. when John F. Kennedy of the Bronx plays Graphic Arts of Manhattan at Lehman High in the Bronx.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-11

title: Anti-U.S. Protesters Fight Manila Police As Cheney Arrives
description: Demonstrators battled with policemen in front of the United States Embassy and at the gate of an American air base today as Defense Secretary Dick Cheney arrived for talks with Philippine officials.

title: In School Conflict, Selma Discovers Old Racial Tensions Are Unresolved
description: In the daily rhythms of life here, whether it is the solemnity of the church or the raucous exuberance of a drag race, blacks and whites touch one another, mingle and even seem to tolerate one another.

title: Daniel Barenboim on Bach, the Bastille and the Baton
description: Over the last dozen years, the Israeli pianist and conductor Daniel Barenboim has turned up in the United States most frequently to wave a baton, either as a guest of American orchestras or with the Orchestre de Paris, the ensemble he directed for 15 years, until last season. He has also made his splashiest recent headlines as a conductor, having been named Sir Georg Solti's successor as music director of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra in January 1989, only two weeks after he had suddenly been dismissed as artistic director of the new Bastille Opera in Paris.

title: By Design;   Forecast for Nighttime
description: There is nothing like a gathering of fashion biggies to give a feeling of what's coming. The recent awards ceremony of the Council of Fashion Designers of America at the Metropolitan Museum of Art was one of those moments. Paloma Picasso, the jewelry and accessories designer, was wearing a brand new Saint Laurent dress of black velvet and satin. It was short and curvy with a sort of sarong-draped skirt. But the plunging, curving neckline was the focal point, fittingly framing her superscale pearl and jewel pendant necklace.

title: Chinese Premier Cautions Ethnic Minorities
description: Prime Minister Li Peng has warned against independence movements among China's ethnic minorities and has urged that separatist efforts be crushed immediately, the official New China News Agency reported tonight.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Study Hints Of Harm In Heart Operations
description: PRELIMINARY results of an international study show that coronary bypass surgery produces subtle, long-lasting impairment of mental performance in nearly one in five people who undergo the operation, researchers say.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Below are the major economic indicators to be released this week.

title: Malpractice Report Told but a Part of Grim Story;   'No Fault' a Misnomer
description: To the Editor:

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Feb. 18, 1990:

title: Survey Finds 2 in 3 Poles Opposed to German Unity
description: Roughly two out of three Poles are opposed to the reunification of Germany, but a majority of Russians and Hungarians feel positively about the idea, according to the results of a poll of political views in eight European countries published here today.

title: Kodo and the Visceral Sound Of One Huge Drum Throbbing
description: ''It has its own personality,'' Yoshiaki Oi was saying about the mighty o-daiko, the 880-pound wood-and-cowhide drum that he played for 10 years. ''Sometimes it wants to be played. Other times, no matter how hard you hit it, it won't make the right sound. You try for the times when both the person and the instrument are playing as one.''

title: Johannesburg Journal;   It's Mandela's Moment but No One Is Untouched
description: On the Johannesburg Stock Exchange, brokers took to calling it the M-Factor - the effect on brokers and investors, mostly whites, of the release of Nelson Mandela, and the way that his merest remark seemed capable of driving down the price of gold shares and of other financial instruments, then pulling them up again, only to push them back down.

title: Racial Dispute Erupts in Boston Over Dismissal of Schools' Chief
description: A group of prominent blacks today accused the Boston School Committee of acting in a racist manner in ousting the city's first black School Superintendent last week and demanded that blacks play a leading role in choosing his successor.

title: China Ends Silence on Deal U.S. Rescinded
description: When President Bush voided the sale of a Seattle aerospace supplier to a Chinese Government agency, the company's executives and employees saw themselves caught in political crosswinds stemming from the killings of demonstrators in Tiananmen Square in June.

title: Anthropology Seen as Father Of Maori Lore
description: IN the traditional tales of the Maori of New Zealand, their ancestors arrived in 1350 in seven magnificent canoes after a heroic migration from the distant islands of Polynesia. They believed in a supreme being known as Io. And so, ever after, the legend of the Great Fleet and the cult of Io have been centerpieces of Maori culture.

title: East German Leader Assails Kohl Over Lack of Quick Financial Aid
description: Prime Minister Hans Modrow bitterly criticized the Government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany today for not providing immediate financial help to the East German economy.

title: Lemieux Out 6 Weeks
description: Mario Lemieux, the National Hockey League's leading scorer, probably will miss the rest of the regular season while he undergoes therapy for a herniated disk in his lower back, his doctor said today.

title: Oil Rig Count Increases
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs increased for the first time this year when it rose by 19 rigs last week to 918, officials of Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. The firm said the number of working rigs was well above the 766 recorded at this time last year. In the previous week, the rig count dropped by 32, to 899, after several weeks of decline. From the beginning of the year until last week, the nation had lost 167 working rigs. The rig count measures exploration activity, not the number of producing wells. The count reflects the number of rotary rigs actively drilling for oil and gas as of Friday.

title: After Lenin, Soviet Anti-Semitism Grew
description: To the Editor:

title: Patterns
description: Like Souvenir Scarves

title: Bridge
description: Britain has won a world open team title only once, and that was in the bygone days when the United States played head to head with the European champions for the crown. But Britain's turn may come again, judging by the fine performance of its young players in winning the 1989 world junior team title in England.

title: A Club for East Europe to Join
description: LEAD: The countries of Eastern Europe are knocking on the doors of Western economic institutions.

title: Police Link Suspect To a Series of Rapes And Other Assaults
description: A man armed with a silver handgun has raped and robbed at least three women and assaulted three other people in their apartments in Brooklyn and Queens over the last month, the police said yesterday.

title: Markets Closed
description: Stock, bond and futures markets in the United States were closed yesterday in observance of Washington's Birthday. Government offices, most banks and many businesses were also closed.

title: Oil Tanker in Spill of Crude Leaves Port for Hull Repair
description: The tanker American Trader left port on Sunday for an expected two-day trip to San Francisco, where she will undergo final repairs to a gashed hull that leaked 400,000 gallons of oil off Southern California.

title: A Mugging? No. More Like A Transaction.
description: LEAD: Just over an hour ago I was mugged my first time. I'm a 27-year-old graduate student and have been living in Manhattan for four years. I figure the numbers finally caught up with me.

title: Getting Along Without 'Sunshine'
description: rrRain and gray clouds swept through South Florida yesterday afternoon, not a welcome omen for the management of Gulfstream Park. Track executives were trying to decide whether to institute a new race whose working title is the Sunshine Stakes.

title: Questions Still Linger for Neighbors of Shoreham
description: The Shoreham Nuclear Power Station is just down the road from Paul Grimes's shop, but he doesn't really care.

title: A.M.A. Is Splintered by Challenges
description: The American Medical Association, the leading voice of American doctors, remains one of the nation's most powerful political lobbies. But in recent years the political influence of organized medicine has been ebbing as it is challenged by consumer groups and fragmented by rivalries between medical specialties.

title: Reviews/Music;   Americans Meet Germans In New and Familiar Works
description: Meet the Moderns at the Cooper Union Thursday night was subtitled ''The New Terrain,'' but that is scarcely what was covered. The Brooklyn Philharmonic with Lukas Foss conducting and Ursula Oppens the piano soloist brought some young Americans and West Germans together, or perhaps more accurately into opposition. From an older generation, there were pieces by Louise Talma and Kurt Weill.

title: Coffee, Chrysanthemums and Cocaine
description: The drug summit meeting in Colombia wasn't just about drugs. Its vital sub-theme was economic survival. What are coca farmers and processors to do for a living if they don't grow coca? Indeed, what will sustain Colombia, Bolivia and Peru?

title: Street-Gang Fury Spoils All the Fun
description: rrWhenever pro basketball players start shoving or swinging, sooner or later somebody's going to get hurt. Rudy Tomjanovich will attest to that. His face was smashed by a punch thrown by Kermit Washington a decade ago. That incident at least occurred out there on the court, part of the risk players take in what is usually a civilized contact sport. But it's a miracle that during a fracas between Bernard King of the Washington Bullets and Chuck Person of the Indiana Pacers on Sunday, a youngster sitting innocently in the first row wasn't trampled.

title: Gasoline Spills in Barge Crash
description: A barge loaded with 30,000 barrels of gasoline caught fire when it collided with another barge in the Intracoastal Waterway, the Coast Guard said today. No one was injured and the fire was extinguished late Sunday night, a Coast Guard spokesman said. The waterway was closed as a precaution because of an undetermined amount of gasoline in the water and the possibility of further fire. Crews were letting the burned barge cool before starting the cleanup.

title: Market Place;   Aerospace Plays Develop in Japan
description: MITSUBISHI HEAVY INDUSTRIES, Kawasaki Heavy Industries and Fuji Heavy Industries, which are among the biggest foreign suppliers of aircraft components to the Boeing Company, ''are going to be the core of the Japanese aerospace industry,'' Dr. Edward Yardeni, economics director for Prudential-Bache Securities, forecast the other day.

title: Careers;   Outplacement Firms Aiding The Spouse
description: OUTPLACEMENT firms, which are hired by companies to help find employment for senior executives who have lost their jobs, have historically offered counseling, resume preparation and use of an office and telephone. Now, outplacement firms are bringing the spouse into the job-search act.

title: Review/Television;   Children of a Previous War
description: ''No Father, No Mother, No Uncle Sam'' describes the children born of black American soldiers and white British mothers during World War II. When the soldiers, who found an unexpectedly warm welcome from British working-class women, were sent back to the United States, they left behind an uncounted number of babies and pregnant lovers.

title: COAL MINERS VOTE ON PROPOSED PACT
description: Coal miners voted today on a contract with the Pittston Coal Group that could end a bitter 10-month strike that drew international support from labor organizations.

title: Missouri Guard Out
description: Lee Coward, starting point guard for the Missouri Tigers, had a cast put on his left wrist and will miss at least two weeks, Coach Norm Stewart said yesterday in Columbia, Mo.

title: Hawaiian Electric Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Donors to Neediest Inspired By a Wide Range of Events
description: Many circumstances lead people to donate to charity, from celebrating a birth to mourning a death, from continuing an old tradition to starting a new one.

title: Rig Count Up in Week
description: The number of United States rigs drilling for oil and gas rose by 19, to 918, for the week ended today, Baker Hughes Inc. said. The Houston oilfield services company said there were 766 operating rigs a year ago. The weekly count reflects the number of rigs exploring for oil and gas.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: IT emerges from the oven with its syrupy batter of cinnamon, sugar and egg white dripping over the side of the plate. It is dense, more like a German coffee cake than a traditional pancake. And it is anything but flat, rising six inches or so above the base of the frying pan in which it is baked.

title: Economic Scene;   Fiercer Rivals, Friendlier Skies
description: ''THE idea,'' suggests one airline executive, ''was to throw eight pounds of paper at the guys who want to re-regulate.''

title: T.C.C. Beverages reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Some year-earlier figures have been restated. Preferred-share dividends were $406,000 in the latest quarter and year and nil in both year-earlier periods. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Bernard C. Kovach, Executive, 55
description: Bernard C. Kovach, president and chief executive officer of Bill Communications, publishers of business magazines, died of a heart attack on Saturday while vacationing with his family in Plymouth, Vt. He was 55 years old and lived in Plandome, L.I.

title: Honda Motor Co.  Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results are in U.S. dollars and have been translated from yen at the rate of 144 yen equaled U.S. $1, the approximate exchange rate prevailing on the Tokyo foreign exchange market on Dec. 29, 1989. The share earnings represented American Shares, which equals two shares of Honda common stock. Earnings per American Share for the corresponding periods a year ago were restated in accordance with the change in the basis of issuance of American Share from 10 common shares to 2 common shares per American Share as a result of a 5-for-1 split of American Shares effected April 3, 1989.

title: Employment Agency Accused of Bias
description: New York State and City officials yesterday accused a major employment agency of discriminating against black applicants and people regarded as too old.

title: People
description: * Patrick Furey has joined W. B. Doner & Co. in Detroit as senior vice president and group management supervisor.

title: Market Place;   Split Opinions On Global Marine
description: TO judge by the stock market, there is life after bankruptcy for Global Marine Inc., the oil driller that came out of Chapter 11 proceedings less than a year ago.

title: Indian and Pakistani Troops Exchange Gunfire in Kashmir
description: Pakistani and Indian troops exchanged fire for several hours today after a Pakistani soldier was wounded on the troubled Kashmir border, officers and a Western observer said.

title: Wendy's International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $138,000 and $1,580,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively, reflecting gain on early extinguishment of debt; the year also included an accounting adjustment gain of $5,191,000, or 5 cents a share.

title: Staten Island in Semifinal
description: Tonight's semifinal round in the City University of New York men's basketball tournament at the College of Staten Island will feature last year's champions and this year's host, the second-seeded Dolphins, who have a 13-13 record.

title: 3 Assembly Victors Favor Death Penalty
description: Three State Assembly seats were filled in special elections yesterday that will have little effect on the makeup of the Assembly but could be pivotal in overriding Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's death penalty veto. All three winners favor the death penalty.

title: Sigma-Aldrich Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Michael Powell Is Dead at 84; Film Career Spanned 50 Years
description: Michael Powell, a British film director, screenwriter and producer whose quirky and often disconcerting movies included ''The Red Shoes,'' ''The Life and Death of Colonel Blimp'' and ''Peeping Tom,'' died of prostate cancer on Monday at his home in Avening, Gloucestershire, England. He was 84 years old.

title: Aristech Offer Is Withdrawn
description: The Huntsman Holdings Corporation, whose unsolicited $813 million bid for the Aristech Chemical Corporation prompted the chemical company to seek a friendly Japanese suitor, said today that it had dropped its offer.

title: Siro Vazquez, 80, Dies; Retired Exxon Official
description: Siro Vazquez, a retired senior vice president and director of the Exxon Corporation, died of congestive heart failure on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 80 years old.

title: Smiley Gets Big Raise
description: The Pittsburgh Pirate left-hander John Smiley won his arbitration case yesterday, giving the players a 4-3 edge over the Pirates in salary hearings. Thomas Roberts, the arbitrator, awarded Smiley a 1990 salary of $840,000, or more than triple his 1989 salary of $230,000. The Pirates had offered $630,000. Smiley was 12-8 with a 2.81 earned run average with eight complete games in 28 starts last season despite pitching for a fifth-place team.(AP)

title: Teams Scramble for Home Ice
description: College hockey's regular-season schedules end this weekend in three of the four Division I leagues, and the teams will be scrambling for final positions that determine playoff sites. Since home teams win two-thirds of the time in playoffs, there is reason to scramble.

title: Reviews/Pop;   Of Broken Hearts and a Broken World
description: Erasure's sold-out show on Friday night at Madison Square Garden was camp with a conscience. The two-man English band - Vince Clarke on synthesizers and guitar, and the singer Andy Bell - has reached the pop audience with catchy, pulsating dance records full of broken hearts and aching romance. But its songs also touch on topics like nuclear apocalypse (''Crown of Thorns'') and the pain of a boy telling parents he's gay (''Hideaway'').

title: General Public Utilities reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Restated.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PAULA ZAHN is being rushed onto the air Monday as a co-anchor of ''CBS This Morning,'' just five days after she is to officially join the network. And just two weeks after her predecessor, KATHLEEN SULLIVAN, was unceremoniously replaced. Ms. Zahn has left her job as a co-anchor of ''World News This Morning'' on ABC-TV, which she joined in May 1988.

title: The West Has a Stake in Perestroika's Success;   Soviet Military Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Communications Satellite Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Industry's Growing Romance With Diamonds
description: Materials scientists are making rapid progress in simplifying the arduous task of manufacturing diamonds. As a result, diamond coatings could become commonplace in the 1990's on everything from industrial drills to scratch-resistant sunglasses and, perhaps as soon as the end of the decade, in a range of high-performance microchips.

title: Review/Opera;   Mirella Freni as Puccini's Manon Lescaut, at Met
description: Puccini's music is not known primarily for inscrutability, but in one respect he is one of opera's paradoxes. Most of the soprano heroines he created are vulnerable little creatures who hold out their hearts to men and ask to have them broken. Yet the voice required of these frail characters must be so robust and throbbingly intense that, used with proper intensity, it can quickly fray and end in tatters.

title: Tosco Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credita of $4,025,000, or 38 cents a share, and $36,994,000, or $3.38 a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. The 1988 year also included a debt retirement charge of $1,806,000. Share data reflected preferred stock dividend requirements and a 1-for-5 reverse stock split effective July 31. The company completed its acquisition of Seminole Fertilizer Corp. for about $133.1 million, including transaction costs on June 30, 1989. Seminole's financial results are included in Tosco's consolidated results beginning July 1, 1989. Fourth quarter 1989 results included a loss of $7.7 million from Seminole, while the six-month period includes a loss of $8.7 million (both losses excluding interest on the acquisition debt). Results of operations for the quarter and year ended Dec. 31, 1989 included a LIFO charge of $1.7 million, compared with a LIFO inventory gain of $1.5 million in the year-ago quarter and charge of $2.3 million for 1988.

title: Gabriel Katzka, 59, Producer in Theater, Films and Television
description: Gabriel Katzka, a theater, film and television producer, died of a heart attack on Monday at his home on the Upper East Side. He was 59 years old.

title: Nash Finch Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
Officials Say Revising U.S. Clean Air Law Would Weaken It
description: The New York City region's air will remain unhealthy if changes in the Clean Air Act under discussion by the White House and the Senate become law, government officials in the Northeast and private environmental groups contend.

title: Food Notes
description: Knowing Nutrition A Gallup survey on diet and health has found that most Americans have a good idea about sensible eating. Ninety-five percent said balance, moderation and variety were the keys to healthy eating, and 77 percent were familiar with the four basic food groups.

title: Tosches Is Honored
description: Coach Steve Tosches of Princeton last night received the Scotty M. Whitelaw Trophy as the Division I-AA coach of the year in the East. Tosches, whose Tigers last season shared the Ivy League championship with Yale, has compiled a 19-10-1 record (14-7 in the Ivy League) over the last three seasons.

title: American Bankers Insurance Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $2,524,000, or 17 cents a share. c-Included an extraordinary gain for utilization of operating loss carryforwards of $14,048,000 for both the quarter and year. Year-ago continuing operations of $2,334,000, or 18 cents a share and $16,788,000, or $1.31 a share for the quarter and year, respectively, included $25,225,000, or $1.94 a share, after-tax gain on sale of a subsidiary and a $12,400,000 after-tax charge for increased credit bond related reserves and the writeoff of certain impaired assets, primarily investments.

title: Sundstrand reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $10.3 million after taxes, or 55 cents a share, for the sale of the company's Trans Com Systems division to Sony USA Inc. c-Net loss and the quarter included a provision of $31 million after taxes related to the resolution of the company's government contract disputes, and the year included a loss of $26,535,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The company said 1989 fourth-quarter results included an interest provision of $5.9 million for potential interest charges related to tax disputes which primarily concerned prices charged by a Singapore subsidiary for products transferred to U.S. operations.

title: Fab Industries Inc. reports earnings for 13wks to Dec 2
Wightman Cup Stopped
description: The Wightman Cup, born in an age when British tennis was the world's best and American women were just learning to play the game, was pushed aside today, the victim of a decade of United States dominance.

title: Pricing Hurts Compaq
description: Price-cutting by the International Business Machines Corporation cut sales of the Compaq Computer Corporation in the last quarter of 1989 and caused Compaq to lose ground in the market for midpriced desktop computers, Compaq said today. I.B.M. set prices for several computers as much as 15 percent below Compaq models.

title: Nicaragua: The Sour-Grapes Brigade
description: Implacable critics of the Sandinista Government are crying foul about next Sunday's elections in Nicaragua. In the face of overwhelming, credible evidence that the campaign has been conducted fairly, their complaints sound suspiciously like efforts to discredit in advance an imminent Sandinista victory at the polls.

title: Georgia Bid Is Accepted By Nekoosa
description: After four months of resisting a takeover by the Georgia-Pacific Corporation, the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation accepted a sweetened offer yesterday of $65.75 a share, or $3.8 billion.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: LEAD: BACK in the dark ages, in the mid-1980's, when Richard and Nancy Ponzi set about building the Bridgeport Brewing Company here, there were no distributors of equipment scaled down for the artisan-brewer. So they made their own brewing tanks and cooling equipment and in 1984 issued Bridgeport Ale, a testament to the skills of the brewmaster, Karl

title: No Sun in Lebanon
description: New thinking opens long-shuttered windows elsewhere. Peace is proclaimed in Europe. Not in cheerless Lebanon. The doleful headlines speak only of continued killing. In East Beirut, two Christian armies have been fighting house to house, room to room, with no quarter given. More than 500 lie dead, 2,000 are wounded, and once-pleasant neighborhoods are in ruins.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Assembly Plans a Powerful Gorbachev Presidency
description: A working group of the Soviet Parliament has drafted a law that would give President Mikhail S. Gorbachev extensive new powers over both the legislative and executive branches of Government, including the authority to disband Parliament.

title: Cryptoclearance Is Retired Because of Injury to a Ligament
description: Cryptoclearance, the popular 6-year-old who has earned more than $3 million, and Summer Squall, one of the early Kentucky Derby favorites, both suffered ailments after recent morning workouts at Gulfstream Park, their trainers said today.

title: U.S. and Japanese Partners In Pact on New Jet Fighter
description: After nine months of bickering that delayed Japan's biggest military aerospace project since World War II, the Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Corporation and the General Dynamics Corporation said today that they had reached agreement on the transfer of critical technology from Japan to the United States for Japan's next-generation fighter aircraft.

title: Upheaval in the East: Soviet Union;   Excerpts From Gorbachev's Remarks on German Unification and Europe
description: Following are excerpts from remarks by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, published today in interview form in Pravda, the Soviet Communist Pa ty newspaper, and distributed in translation by the Soviet press agency Tass:

title: At Super Bowl of Bake-Offs, A Dream Is Worth $40,000
description: The suspense was finally over for 99 tense contestants at 9:29 this morning, when Willard Scott announced that Linda Rahman of Petaluma, Calif., had won the grand prize in the 34th Pillsbury Bake-Off: $40,000 and $0,000 in kitchen appliances.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday headed ''More $100 Bills'' misstated the 1982 figures for the total value of some types of currency in circulation.

title: Nicaraguans Woo Youthful Voters
description: In the middle of an intense campaign for national elections here, the Sandinista National Liberation Front paused recently to celebrate young love.

title: Review/Television;   Prime-Time Cartoon of Unbeautiful People
description: On a Christmas special of ''The Simpsons'' last December, little Bart, the fourth grader, sneered when someone mentioned Santa Claus. ''Oh, please,'' the exasperated brat said. ''There's only one fat guy who brings us presents, and his name isn't Santa.'' All Bart wanted for Christmas was a tattoo. Clearly this show, which was making its debut as a weekly series on Fox Broadcasting a few weeks later - at 8:30 P.M. Sundays on Channel 5 - had a shot at being something refreshingly different, and not just as the only animated cartoon in prime time. The record so far: impressively on target.

title: John M. Henske, 66, A Retired Chairman Of Olin Corporation
description: John McClanahan Henske, former chairman of the Olin Corporation and of the Chemical Manufacturers Association, died on Tuesday at his home in Westport, Conn., after a long illness. He was 66 years old.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES

title: Orion Down on Sale Talk
description: The stock of the Orion Pictures Corporation fell today amid reports that Metromedia Inc. was considering the sale of its 70.4 stake in the movie and television company. The Wall Street Journal reported today that John W. Kluge, the chairman of Metromedia, was discussing the sale of his company's stake. In trading on the New York Stock Exchange, shares of Orion fell 62.5 cents, to $21.875. Last week, after Orion's stock rose $2.875 on Thursday, the company said it knew of no reason for the stock activity. Officials at Metromedia could not be reached for comment today. Telephone calls to the company's office were not answered in the early evening.

title: Upheaval in the East: Jews;   Soviet Rabbi Tells of the New Anti-Semitism
description: An East German newspaper published an unusual interview today with the chief rabbi of Moscow, in which he expressed fears about rising anti-Semitism in the Soviet Union.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Since his presidential campaign sank in scandal in 1987, GARY HART has been quietly practicing law in Denver. Now he is writing a book about the Soviet Union, and he said yesterday he has had access to ''the entire leadership except Mr. Gorbachev.'' He leaves today for Moscow, where he has been traveling nearly every month, 10 days each trip, for a year.

title: Graft Not at All Inherent To Local School Boards
description: To the Editor:

title: Brewers Sign Yount: $9.6 Million for 3 Years
description: Robin Yount, the American League most valuable player last season, has finally agreed to terms with the Milwaukee Brewers on a three-year contract that will pay him $9.6 million. The team announced in December that Yount had agreed to a contract but details were not complete.

title: Court Warns Buyers Of Child Sex Items
description: People who buy child pornography magazines and videotapes in New York State are breaking the law, the state's highest court warned today.

title: News Summary
description: International A2-12

title: C.D. Yields Are Unchanged
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were mostly unchanged for the week ended yesterday.

title: Smoking's Cost to Society Is $52 Billion a Year, Federal Study Says
description: Federal officials estimated today that that cigarette smoking costs the nation $52 billion in health expenses or time lost from work, about $221 per person, each year.

title: BMA Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $303,000 for the quarter and gain of $18,211,000, or $1.88 a share, for the year, both from discontinued operations. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $830,000, or 8 cents a share, for the quarter and $870,000, or 9 cents a share, for the year. Results for 1988 have been restated to reflect the new accounting standards. The company said net earnings in the fourth quarter of 1988 were enhanced by a $2.3 million tax benefit resulting from a favorable Internal Revenue Service audit of prior years' tax returns. Television operations have been reclassified as discontinued operations.

title: C.I.A. CHIEF WARNS OF RESOLUTE K.G.B.
description: The Soviet Union's primary intelligence service, the K.G.B., has not slackened its espionage and other actions against the United States under Mikhail S. Gorbachev, but it has become less ''blatant and flat-footed'' at what it does, the senior American intelligence official said today.

title: Sumitomo Executive Is Recruited by Kidder
description: Kidder, Peabody & Company, the Wall Street securities firm, took a big step toward increasing its investment banking presence in Tokyo yesterday, announcing that it had recruited Ken Saito, a top deal maker at Sumitomo Bank, to head its mergers and acquisitions department in Japan.

title: Limited Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KEY RATES
Recognition Equipment Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a restructuring charge of $1,242,000, primarily related to increased severance expenses. c-Net income The company said that also included in the current first quarter are legal expenses associated with the criminal proceedings in connection with alleged irregularities in the procurement of multi-line mail sorting equipment by the U.S. Postal Service.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Wednesday about New York City's labor negotiations misidentified a segment of the membership of Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. Local 237 negotiates on behalf of horseshoers, not blacksmiths. Blacksmiths are represented by Local 5 of the International Brotherhood of Boilermakers, Iron Ship Builders, Blacksmiths, Forgers and Helpers.

title: Service for Walter Hoving
description: A memorial service for Walter Hoving, former head of Tiffany & Company, will be held on Monday at 11 A.M. at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, 1 West 53d Street. Mr. Hoving died on Nov. 27 at the age of 91.

title: Upheaval in the East: Poland;   Polish Official Vows to Defend Border
description: The leader of the Solidarity bloc in the Polish Parliament said at a conference here today that war would be the only way to change his nation's border with Germany.

title: Groupe Bull Challenges Zenith Price
description: The Zenith Electronics Corporation said today that it was involved in a ''major dispute'' with Groupe Bull of France over the final price for Zenith's computer operations. Groupe Bull described the disagreement as a normal business matter.

title: Gerber Scientific reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Rates Jump At Citicorp Sale
description: Interest rates rose sharply yesterday at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91- and 182-day commercial paper.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Monday on the report of a marriage in Boston referred incorrectly in some editions to the bride of Mervin M. Wilf. She is Virginia F. Coleman.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Coast Savings and Loan Association, Los Angeles, a subsidiary of Coast Savings Financial Inc., appointed Norman H. Raiden executive vice president in charge of its legal and subsidiaries groups.

title: Bank Unit to Martin
description: The Martin Agency, which won the Banc One Corporation account in December, picked up the account of the Columbus, Ohio, holding company's Texas operation, Bank One Texas N.A., on Friday. The account, formerly at the Richards Group, reportedly bills between $10 million and $12 million.

title: Whirlpool Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-After losses from discontinued operations of $52.9 million for the quarter and $67.2 million for the year. Results for 1989 periods included a pretax facility consolidation charge of $9.2 million. Results for 1989 included all of the revenues of Whirlpool International B.V. and 53 percent of the net earnings of the joint venture in line with the corporation's ownership position.

title: Francis Keppel Dies at Age of 73; Was Commissioner of Education
description: Francis Keppel, a former United States Commissioner of Education who was a strong proponent of programs to improve learning opportunities for poor children, died of cancer Monday at Harvard University's Stillman Infirmary in Cambridge, Mass. He was 73 years old and lived in Cambridge.

title: Girl in Landmark Transplant Gets Another
description: ''It went very smoothly.''

title: The Good Principal: A Tradition Breaker
description: Principals who broke traditions and ''refused to let bureaucracy strangle innovation'' were able to build better schools, a nationwide study by a committee of the National Association of Secondary School Principals has found.

title: DREXEL EXECUTIVES RECEIVED BONUSES BEFORE COLLAPSE
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. paid bonuses totaling hundreds of millions of dollars to its executives shortly before its parent decided to file for bankruptcy protection, Wall Street executives said last night.

title: Kisio's Scoring Revival Quietly Sparks the Rangers
description: What the controversy didn't engulf, Brian Mullen's goal overshadowed, thus making it more than likely that the contributions of Kelly Kisio would once again be overlooked.

title: Amid Protests, Dinkins Plans AIDS Shelters
description: The Dinkins administration said yesterday that it that it had decided to place homeless people with AIDS-related illnesses in a newly created medical section of a large shelter.

title: Deere & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Judge Is Asked to Delay Reagan Tape
description: Lawyers for John M. Poindexter today asked a Federal judge to postpone the release of former President Ronald Reagan's videotaped testimony until after a jury is selected for the Iran-contra trial of the former national security adviser.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Calendar listing of the On Your Own page in SportsMonday this week about the Miller Genuine Draft/N.J.L.B.A. Tavern Pool Tournament misstated the information telephone number for the event.

title: Shell From Israeli Zone Kills 2 in Lebanon
description: Two Nepalese soldiers serving with the United Nations peacekeeping force in southern Lebanon have been killed and six wounded by an artillery shell just north of the Israeli-designated security zone in southern Lebanon, officials of the force said today.

title: Haverty Furniture reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest quarter and year results were aided by favorable LIFO adjustment of 16 cents a share.

title: CML Gives Up List
description: The corporate raider Irwin L. Jacobs said that CML Group Inc. had reversed its earlier decision and agreed to give him a list of the company's shareholders. Mr. Jacobs, who is based in Minneapolis, is seeking to remove CML's board and sell the company to the highest bidder. Mr. Jacobs filed suit to force the company to turn ove the list. CML, a retail store chain based in Acton, Mass., has rejected Mr. Jacobs's $25-a-share, or $167.5 million.

title: Japan's Lead in Computer Research Grows
description: In a sprawling laboratory complex here, Japanese researchers are working on an ambitious program that demonstrates how - and how quickly - Japan is widening its lead over the United States in certain crucial fields of electronics technology. It also underlines the contrast in the way the two nations are pursuing a promising but costly frontier of industrial expertise.

title: Rosewood to Sell Its Energy Group
description: The Rosewood Corporation, whose financial group has been fighting for control of troubled First Executive Corporation, has decided to sell its energy exploration and production group, Rosewood Resources. Rosewood, the investment arm of the $1 billion Caroline Rose Hunt estate, said it wished to diversify its assets. The privately held company has sold hotels in Los Angeles and Hawaii and is seeking a partner for its Crescent Court property in Dallas. A company spokesman has said that there is no connection between Rosewood's bid for First Executive and the decision to sell the exploration and production company, which was formed by Ms. Hunt's father, the oil legend H. L. Hunt.

title: Teacher's Aide Hit By Bullet in Class
description: A 54-year-old teacher's aide was struck by a bullet fired into a fourth-floor classroom in a Bronx intermediate school yesterday, and a 16-year-old boy was later arrested for assault, the police said.

title: Expanded Review of Pentagon Cuts Planned
description: The Bush Administration plans to expand a review of possible Pentagon cuts to include up to 12 expensive weapons systems, including two nuclear missiles, because of reduced Soviet-American tensions, a senior Defense Department official said today.

title: Jets Sign Free-Agent Pass Rusher
description: The Jets came to terms yesterday with their first Plan B free agent of the new regime, a pass-rushing defensive tackle whom Dick Steinberg drafted last year for the New England Patriots.

title: Jiffy Lube International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Upheaval in the East;   No Undue Haste to Unity, Irate East German Urges
description: Angered by signs of a growing West German certainty that East German economic and political weakness has made rapid unification on Bonn's terms inevitable, Prime Minister Hans Modrow told the East German Parliament today that this country should not sell itself cheap.

title: Stocks Drop on Rate Fears; Dow Off 38.74
description: Stocks fell across a broad front yesterday as traders worried about rising interest rates here, as well as in West Germany and Japan.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Pioneer Inc., Orlando, Fla., parent company of Pioneer Savings Bank, and HBJ Insurance Cos., said they had ended an agreement for the sale of American Pioneer Life Insurance Co. to HBJ.

title: Capitalism Course May Be Canceled
description: An American graduate degree program that teaches Western-style capitalism to students in China is in peril. But it is unclear whether the threat comes from Federal budget cutters or a White House sensitive to hard-liners in China.

title: Officer Is Questioned as a Suspect In Bombing Death of L.I. Detective
description: A Nassau County police officer was questioned yesterday as a prime suspect in the death of an off-duty Suffolk County narcotics detective who was killed last week in a car bombing outside his home in North Patchogue, L.I., a law-enforcement official said.

title: Miners' Contract Highlights
description: United Mine Workers' summary of the contract they approved. The U.M.W. has been on strike since April 5 in Virginia, West Virginia and Kentucky against the Pittston Coal Group.

title: New Brooklyn Bishop to Bar Cuomo Over Abortion
description: The new head of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, Bishop Thomas V. Daily, said yesterday that he would bar Gov. Mario M. Cuomo from speaking in parishes in the diocese because of the Governor's support for abortion rights.

title: Coal Strike Ends, but Dispute About Eastern Clouds Labor's Mood
description: To the cheers of fellow trade unionists and Labor Secretary Elizabeth H. Dole, the coal miners union announced today that its members had ratified an agreement to end the bitter 10-month strike against the Pittston Coal Group by a nearly two-to-one margin.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We needed to make a practical response to a man, President F. W. de Klerk, who has taken his political life into his hands.''

title: Chip Leads Way to New Video Products
description: The huge amounts of digital computer data necessary to generate video and still images in color have strained the capacity of the fastest personal computers. Now semiconductor designers are fashioning a new generation of chip that can handle the expanding sea of information.

title: The Joy of Daring
description: At first we were going to tough out the Perrier crisis. We figured the odds were pretty good. Benzene was found in only a few bottles.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about AIDS in the Middle East misidentified the head of the World Health Organization's AIDS program. He is Dr. Jonathan Mann.

title: Pettibone Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $56,682,000 and $55,125,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, reflecting a gain which consisted of forgiveness of debt related to the Chapter 11 reorgnization.

title: The West Has a Stake in Perestroika's Success
description: To the Editor:

title: Report Blames Subway Bosses In Track Death
description: A subway track worker was killed last November because his superiors failed to tell him that trains using the track that day would be going in both directions, and because no ''Insufficient Clearance'' signs had been posted, a New York State Labor Department investigator has concluded.

title: INSIDE
description: British Gesture to Pretoria

title: Review/Music;   Chamber Opera Company Offers Revival and Premiere
description: The American Chamber Opera Company's current double bill of one-acts at the Marymount Manhattan Theater sensibly combines a revival with a premiere: ''Dr. Heidegger's Fountain of Youth,'' a 1978 work by Jack Beeson with libretto by Sheldon Harnick, and ''Peronelle,'' a curious new creation by Larry Lipkis with libretto by Barry Spacks, ''based on 'Le Voir Dit' by Guillaume de Machaut.''

title: Management Co. Entertainent Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest third quarter was the period in which a full 3 months of the results of operations of its recently acquired Virgin Vision business has been reflected. The revenue increase resulted principally from the inclusion of $45,599,000 attributable to the Virgin Vision operations, while the loss was primarily attributable to over $4.3 million in interest costs associated with the financing for the acquisition.

title: $250 Million Issue From G.E. Credit
description: The General Electric Credit Corporation is offering $250 million in 8.70 percnt notes due 2003 through Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.

title: Allied Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $546,754, or 8 cents a share, and $2,727,036, or 40 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $822,753, or 12 cents a share, for the quarter and $2,766,997, or 41 cents a share, for the year.

title: Motorola, Toshiba To Help Echelon
description: Echelon, a start-up company with a list of blue-chip executives and investors, said Motorola Inc. and the Toshiba Corporation had agreed to manufacture and market its computer chips, which will be used in automated controls for appliances and other electrical equipment.

title: Henry X. O'Brien, Retired Justice, 86
description: Henry X. O'Brien, former Chief Justice of the Pennsylvania Supreme Court, died of cancer Saturday. He was 86 years old. , Justice O'Brien served on the State Supreme Court for 21 years after 14 years as a trial judge in Allegheny County and five years as an Allegheny County assistant district attorney. He was Chief Justice from 1980 to 1983, after which he served as a consultant for a law firm.

title: Avrett Finds Way to Offer Global Link
description: ''WE'RE more like the old-fashioned agencies that have grown with their clients,'' said Jack Avrett. But even though his agency, Avrett, Free & Ginsberg, has resisted the acquisition offers that flow to small, successful package-goods agencies like congratulatory telegrams to newlyweds, Mr. Avrett and his colleagues have found another way to grow: Concord International.

title: Sugar Policy Is Debated
description: Members of the House Ways and Means Committee called today for revision of the United States sugar program, saying the current system costs taxpayers and sugar-exporting nations billions of dollars each year.

title: Jurors Resume Inquiry on Barry But Can't Get Woman to Testify
description: The Federal grand jury that indicted Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. last week on drug and perjury charges resumed its investigation of him today.

title: Ampco-Pittsburgh Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss of $248,000 for the quarter and income of $1,093,000, or 11 cents a share, for the year, both from discontinued operations and extraordinary gains from tax-loss carryforward of $1,300,000, or 14 cents a share, and $3,900,000, or 41 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $10,760,000 for the quarter and $32,519,000 for the year. Year-ago results are restated.

title: Waltrip Makes History
description: Although he finished only 14th in the Daytona 500, the race at the Daytona International Speedway was an important benchmark for Darrel Waltrip. Waltrip, a 43-year-old native of Franklin, Tenn., who is a three-time Winston Cup champion, earned $49,340 and that total was enough to make him the first man in motor sports history to surpass $10 million in career winnings, with a total of $10,036,481.

title: Toppling of Tyson: More Fallout
description: James (Buster) Douglas's 10th-round knockout of Mike Tyson in Japan shocked the public and caught the boxing establishment off guard. How unprepared for the Douglas era were the major-domos of the sport?

title: Rev. Dr. James Iley McCord, 70, Ex-Chief of Princeton Seminary
description: The Rev. Dr. James Iley McCord, the former president of Princeton Theological Seminary and founder of its Center for Theological Inquiry, died of complications of Parkinson's disease on Monday at the Princeton Medical Center. He was 70 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: Danaher Acquires Easco Hand Tools
description: The Danaher Corporation, an auto parts manufacturer, and Easco Hand Tools Inc. said they had entered into a merger agreement under which Danaher would acquire Easco in a stock-for-stock transaction valued at about $125 million.

title: Scientists Report Producing Genetically Engineered Trees
description: Scientists reported today that they had developed the world's first genetically engineered trees: poplars designed to be grown on large plantations for energy production.

title: No Lone Cause Found to Account For Decline of Frog, Experts Say
description: There is convincing evidence that some species of frogs, toads and salamanders are rapidly declining in many parts of the world, a panel of experts concluded today.

title: 'First Class' Mayor Sought
description: A New York City Councilman, contending that David N. Dinkins is entitled to some privileges as mayor of the nation's largest city, said yesterday that he would introduce legislation to permit the Mayor to fly first class at city expense, which current rules prohibit.

title: Honeywell Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $20.5 million, or 49 cents a share, for the quarter and $53.8 million, or $1.26 a share, for the year. c-Net loss and after income from discontinued operations of $2.7 million, or 5 cents a share, and $46.6 million, or $1.09 a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. The latest periods' results included gains of $331.7 million for the quarter and $340.1 million for the year, from sale of assets, compared with $6.5 million and $33.7 million for like year-ago periods, respectively. The latest periods' results also included provisions for restructuring activities of $74.1 million for the quarter and $81.6 million for the year, compared with $85.5 million and $101.9 million for the like year-ago periods, respectively. The year-ago periods included charges for discontinuuance of product lines of $125.8 million for the quarter and $150.8 million for the year.

title: Vanishing Species: The Local Hangout
description: The Blue Moon Tavern looks like a dump. Its weatherbeaten exterior, dating to the depths of the Great Depression, has been described as ''uniquely ordinary.'' A fern could never grow inside, nor would any of the tavern's regular patrons want it to.

title: The Real Point of Barry's 'Sting'
description: The indictment of the District of Columbia Mayor, Marion Barry, on perjury and drug charges may signal a new and controversial use for the oldest of ''stings.'' Since the lords of the Philistines directed Delilah to entice Samson so that they could ''prevail against him,'' beautiful women have been used to lure vulnerable men into sin, crime and corruption.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Binks Manufacturing Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting change of $375,000, or 13 cents a share.

title: Bureaucrats With Clean Hands
description: Sometimes, bureaucrats offer astounding examples of creativity. Consider a recent memo uncovered by The Daily News that was prepared by some civil servants at New York City's Board of Education, called ''Proper Handwashing.''

title: DNA Test Proves Itself in Solving Crimes
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Legislators Urge A Tight Grip on Rallies
description: The Soviet Parliament urged a crackdown today on illegal demonstrations scheduled for Sunday and said the authorities should tightly control legal rallies, the Tass press agency said.

title: Military Division Chief Promoted at FMC Corp.
description: The FMC Corporation, a chemical producer and maker of military equipment, has named Robert N. Burt as its president.

title: Lawyers for Trumps Stop Discourse, Too
description: And now, the lawyers are not talking to each other either.

title: BMTC Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $3,952,000, or 32 cents a share, and an extraordinary credit of $15,015,000, or $1.18 a share. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $4,628,000, or 37 cents a share. BMTC was formerly known as Cantrex Inc.

title: Blake Is Taking the High Road
description: Arthur Blake had sensed it might be a special occasion, so he wore his special outfit, the gray, double-breasted suit made for him in South Korea during the 1988 Olympics. Sure enough, when he and his coach, Jim Long, arrived at the airport the other day, a limousine was waiting, to take them to a midtown restaurant for the lunch-hour gathering with reporters.

title: Culture Chief Asks Use of Drug Plan Funds
description: New York City's Commissioner of Cultural Affairs proposed yesterday that all government money used for drug education in the city be given to her department for cultural and recreational programs for schoolchildren.

title: Bird Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $866,000, or 24 cents a share, for the quarter and $9,806,000, or $2.46 a share, for the year which consists of loss from operations of discontinued segments of $23,000 and a gain from the sale of discontinued segments of $9,829,000. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $239,000, or 5 cents a share, and $2,027,000, or 48 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. Latest quarter and year's income from continuing operations of $7,098,000, or $1.86 a share, and $9,886,000, or $2.09 a share, included pretax gains related to discontinued business activities of $7,026,000 and $6,478,000, respectively. Year-ago year's income from continuing operations of $3,986,000, or 57 cents a share included charge of $795,000 related to discontinued business activities.

title: Britain, in Split With Europe, Eases Pretoria Ban
description: Britain broke ranks with the other members of the European Community today and ended its ban on new investments in South Africa.

title: Jurors Watch Tape of Tanker Spilling Oil
description: Jurors in the trial of Capt. Joseph J. Hazelwood today saw a videotape of his tanker, the Exxon Valdez, stranded on a reef surrounded by a sea of oil.

title: Refinery Blast Kills Two
description: A truck loading liquefied petroleum gas into a storage tank caught fire and exploded at an Amoco refinery today, killing two people and injuring three others. The accident occurred near the main storage area of the refinery, prompting the evacuation of nearby residents and closing streets in this northwestern Indiana community.

title: Westwood One reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income

title: Stalled Talks Threaten Season
description: The first sign that the owners' lockout of players from spring training camps could endanger the start of the regular season arose in baseball's stagnated labor negotiations yesterday.

title: A Novelist Who Pens Dickensian English And Thinks in Fives
description: Charles Palliser was mildly worried when Ballantine Books bought the American rights to his novel, ''The Quincunx,'' and Penguin Books bought the paperback rights. He started really to worry when the Book-of-the-Month Club and the Literary Guild waged an all-out battle over the book.

title: No Headline
description: LEAD: WHEN Ash Caplan, better known as Cappie, decided to leave South Africa, he did not think his 20 years as a clothing retailer would prove very useful in the United States.

title: Gooden Needs 3 Weeks
description: Dwight Gooden said yesterday that his right shoulder felt ''100 percent better than it did last September,'' but he conceded that his comeback schedule would be disrupted if spring training were further delayed by labor trouble.

title: Drake Coach Resigns
description: Tom Abatemarco resigned as the coach of Drake yesterday and an assistant coach, Tom Butler, was dismissed after an investigation found mistreatment of players and violations of National Collegiate Athletic Association rules. Michael Ferrari, the Drake president, said at a news conference that a university committee concluded that Abatemarco knew nothing of the N.C.A.A. violations but that he used language and engaged in conduct demeaning to players, assistant coaches and trainers. Ferrari said Butler tried to influence a witness in the investigation and refused to cooperate with the committee. (AP)

title: The Pop Life
description: LaVern Baker's Back ''I'm a fighter when it comes to my career,'' the rhythm-and-blues singer LaVern Baker said last week. ''It was my private life that has kept me away.''

title: Bush Meets Prague Leader
description: After meeting with President Vaclav Havel, President Bush waived some restrictions on trade with Prague. Mr. Havel will address Congress today at 11 A.M. Page A10.

title: Illinois Tool Unit In Bid for Binks
description: Illinois Tool Works Inc. said its Ransburg subsidiary had offered to acquire the Binks Manufacturing Company for $45 a share in cash or a combination of cash and Illinois tool stock, in a deal valued at $132.3 milion. Binks shares soared $10.75 today, to $43.75, in trading on the American Stock Exchange. More than three million shares were traded.

title: Bridge
description: Reprinting major works of bridge literature that have long been unavailable is a useful service to the game. Granovetter Books has recently produced a new edition of ''Bridge is a Partnership Game'' by Alvin Roth and Tobias Stone, with a modern supplement. This book, first published in 1958, is the best exposition of the Roth-Stone methods, which contributed much to modern bidding. It is available for $13.95, including postage, from the publishers, 18 Village View Bluff, Ballston Lake, N.Y. 12019.

title: New Consumer Chief Faults R.J. Reynolds On Its 'Camel' Ads
description: An hour after he was sworn in yesterday, New York City's Consumer Affairs Commissioner, Mark Green, took on one of the nation's largest tobacco companies, R. J. Reynolds, saying that it was ''inducing children to smoke.''

title: Real Estate;   Seven-Year Face Lift Is Completed
description: THE enormous building at 120 Broadway that provoked protests 80 years ago and led to enactment of the first zoning laws in New York City - and indeed the nation - has been given a face lift that required seven years of intensive work. Among the tasks in the just-completed renovation were the cleaning of the 50,000-square-foot facade of the 40-story structure and the replacement of many of its eroded terra cotta details.

title: For Jews, Lithuania Is Oasis of Tolerance
description: To the Editor:

title: Cenvill Development reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company said its fourth quarter and fiscal 1988 results included $20,970,000 in revenue and $3,057,000 in net income related to the sale of a shopping center.

title: CHRONICLE
description: VICTORIA PRINCIPAL has struck an unusual deal with ABC: She will star in two series, one right after the other. The first, which begins production next month but doesn't yet have a broadcast date, is in partnership with AARON SPELLING and ALISON CROSS, who won an Emmy award for writing ''Roe vs. Wade.'' It's the story of a former police officer who works in the Los Angeles District Attorney's office and is the divorced mother of an angry teen-age daughter.

title: Volkswagen Campaign
description: Rolling Stone magazine has lent its ''Perception/Reality'' advertising campaign to Volkswagen. In this execution, which appears in the March 8 issue of Rolling Stone, perception is the humble Beetle, and reality is Volkswagen's current line. The One Club recently named the campaign, which was devised by Fallon McElligott, as the third-best campaign of the 1980's.

title: South African Exiles Fear to Return
description: While many South African exiles concede the importance of the changes in their country in recent weeks, few of them are prepared to test the extent and permanence of the new climate by returning home.

title: N.F.L. Must Pay Fees
description: The Supreme Court today refused to free the National Football League from having to pay more than $5.5 million in legal fees to the defunct United States Football League.

title: Inmac Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
24 Toll Takers Fall Ill at Triborough Bridge
description: Twenty-four workers at Triborough Bridge tollbooths became ill over the last four days, and the city is monitoring the air near the booths. No motorists are reported to have been affected.

title: For Philadelphians, New Way to Shop
description: When a fancy new wine store opened here recently, it struck some Pennsylvanians as an event on the magnitude of the dismantling of the Berlin Wall.

title: Lance Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
Feinstein: A Teamster's Hand on the Reins
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the Speaker of the New York State Assembly, Mel Miller, were at a reception last December, doing what politicians usually do at such events -gossiping about other politicians.

title: Painting Hustle Ends in Brush With the Law
description: By the time detectives caught up with him, the police say, he had left dozens of people poorer, but also more than 700 subway pillars in Brooklyn freshly painted in a chain-gang color scheme of black and white stripes.

title: Disciples of the Beatles
description: Near the end of Tears for Fears's concert at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena on Sunday evening, a screen at the rear of the stage lighted up with yellow sunbursts, and the band erupted into ''Sowing the Seeds of Love,'' its exhilarating homage to the 1967 Beatles.

title: Bucks Send Nets to 14th Consecutive Loss
description: Ricky Pierce scored 29 points to offset a career-high 23-point, 26-rebound effort by New Jersey's Charles Shackleford and the Milwaukee Bucks sent the Nets to their 14th consecutive loss tonight, 110-102.

title: Liz Claiborne reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Deductible I.R.A.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: Upheaval in the East: The Germans;   Kohl Stumps as if Germanys Were One
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany, introduced to a cheering throng as the ''Chancellor of our German fatherland,'' today plunged into the intense political campaign for East German elections now less than four weeks away.

title: Leader of Puerto Rico Offers Plan to Sell Utility to Meet Social Needs
description: The Governor of Puerto Rico today announced a plan to sell the Government-owned telephone company and use the proceeds to create two ''perpetual funds'' of $1 billion each, one for secondary education and the other to improve the island's public services like its drinking water and sewage systems.

title: Norstan Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: Year-ago quarter's sales restated to reflect an accounting change for consolidation of majority-owned subsidiaries.

title: New Approach Tried For Monet Jewelers
