description: Departing from the traditional advertising of fashion jewelry, in which the model usually does little more than a mannequin might, Monet Jewelers is about to begin a campaign, created by Margeotes Fertitta & Weiss, that focuses on a woman's life style.

title: Deadline Missed at Eastern
description: Eastern Airlines and its creditors failed yesterday to meet a court deadline for an agreement on how the company could emerge from bankruptcy, an Eastern spokeswoman said last night.

title: Bertelsmann's Trouble in U.S.
description: For decades, Reinhard Mohn, the man who built Bertelsmann A.G. into the West German media giant, has urged company officials to emulate ''the greatest management teachers in the world - the Americans.''

title: CANADA PRESENTS AUSTERITY BUDGET
description: The Government of Prime Minister Brian Mulroney unveiled austerity measures today intended to bring down a budget deficit that is proportionately one of the highest among industrial countries and to ease the financial markets' recent concern about the management of the Canadian economy.

title: Upheaval in the East: Czechoslovakia;   Bush Praises Havel and His 'New Page'
description: President Bush welcomed Czechoslovakia's leader, Vaclav Havel, to the White House today, promising his country new trade benefits and hailing his journey from political prisoner to President as the symbol of Eastern Europe's dramatic transformation in the past year.

title: Brazil's Cooling Alternative To All That Coffee? Fruit Juice
description: Both the tempo and temperature are feverish here with the approach of Carnaval on Feb. 24. Ninety-degree evenings are charged with the beat of dancing feet and drums tapping out this year's samba routines and rhythms. By day, the beaches are flowered with gaily hued umbrellas, towels, surfers, students and tourists. When the sequined dancers and bikinied bathers stop to quench their thirsts, it is Brazil's fruit juice bars that beckon.

title: Sears Certificate Offering Is Aimed at Small Investors
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer, yesterday priced a $250 million issue of pass-through certificates that are being aimed at retail investors rather than the institutional buyers who normally dominate the asset-backed market.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Gov.

title: Common Language, Common Sense
description: LEAD: Paul B. Rosenblatt, a U.S.

title: Kaypro Corp. President Quits
description: David Kay, the son of the founder of the Kaypro Corporation, has resigned as the company's president, less than a month after taking the job.

title: PS Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary losses of $3,000 and $56,000 from the early retirement of debt for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included extraordinary losses from early retirement of debt of $84,000 and $677,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; and losses from discontinued operations of $1,266,000 and $15,939,000 for the same periods, respectively. Results for 1989 periods included pretax charge of $5 million for the writedown of the carrying value of certain high-yield securities held in the company's investment portfolio. Revenue for 1988 year included $105,543,000 gain from termination of retirement plan in the third quarter of 1988, and prior to such termination, the amortization of excess of pension assets over liabilities. Figures for 1988 are restated to conform to 1989 presentation.

title: The Quiet Flame That Lights 3 Stars
description: The name Claude Deligne does not happen to be on the tip of every food fancier's tongue, but many know his work.

title: Drugs Pit Baker vs. Third World at U.N.
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d called on the General Assembly today to adopt a global program against drug traffickers. But third-world speakers demanded that the United States and its industrialized allies curb demand for drugs and help poorer nations cut production.

title: Sony to Share Data at U.S. Plant
description: Advanced Micro Devices Inc., a producer of computer chips, said today that it would sell one of its factories to the Sony Corporation and receive advanced semiconductor manufacturing technology from the Japanese company.

title: The Senate's Idea of Service
description: National service, everybody's cause in Washington last year, finally comes to a vote in the Senate this week. The bill contains something for everybody; unfortunately, it also contains something from almost every senator who had a thought on the issue, and also President Bush's ''thousand points of light.'' The bill reflects little of the clarifying debate that has occurred over the last year. It's almost certain to pass, which means the House will find plenty of room for improvement.

title: Profit Reported By Honeywell
description: Honeywell Inc. reported fourth-quarter net income today of $392 million, or $9.26 a share, on sales of $1.6 billion. That was in contrast to a loss of $483 million in the period a year earlier, when sales totaled $1.58 billion.

title: Hercules In Spring Training
description: Hercules Payne, a 22-year-old rookie pitcher, couldn't wait to get to spring training. He hurriedly packed up his belongings, jumped into his car - a red Javelin, though, as his reputation expanded, camp gossip would turn it into a long white Cadillac - and drove straight from Pine Bluff, Ark., to Fort Myers, Fla., where the Kansas City Royals trained.

title: Timing Coffee Service to Suit the Taste
description: THE fancier the restaurant, the later it serves the coffee, sometimes after the dessert. In diners a mug is filled as soon as you are seated.

title: Zenith Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are given for the company's continuing operations. Net income represented net from continuing operations. Results for the company's discontinued computer business which was sold on Dec. 28, 1989 are not yet available because of a major dispute with the buyer over the final sale price of the business.

title: 'Great to Be a Bishop': Thomas Vose Daily
description: When it came time for Bishop Thomas V. Daily to sum up the spirit he hopes will guide his actions as the newly appointed leader of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, he reached into his pocket and pulled out the familiar prayer attributed to St. Francis of Assisi, ''Lord, make me an instrument of your peace.''

title: Greenspan Sees Modest Growth In the Economy
description: Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and the dominant force in economic policy making, told Congress today that the economy's ''weakest point may have passed'' and that the nation could expect ''moderate economic expansion'' this year.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: BLACK sea bass is one of my favorite local fishes. The plump little fellows with semifirm, mild-flavored white flesh usually range from 1 1/2 to 3 pounds but have been seen as big as 5 pounds. According to historical accounts, sea bass were so prolific around New York Harbor in the first half of the 19th century that commercial fishermen rarely had to venture beyond Sandy Hook, N.J., for their daily catch. Today the black sea bass is caught along the East Coast from Cape Cod to Florida. It has three closely related cousins that, for cooks' purposes, are virtually the same: the southern sea bass, bank sea bass and rock sea bass.

title: Donaldson Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said the year-ago second quarter included expenses related to the closing of the company's Integrated Air Systems operations. The pretax charge of $1.6 million reduced net earnings by $1.1 million, or 11 cents a share.

title: Review/Photography;   A Texas-Sized Show to Boggle the Eye
description: It is a sight to make sore eyes: Houston's George R. Brown Convention Center filled with row upon row of photographs, some 3,500 in all. There are 27 exhibitions in the hall, mounted on temporary Styrofoam walls. Elsewhere, in museums, galleries and other exhibition spaces throughout the city, 60 more shows await photography enthusiasts.

title: Dixie Yarns reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Included gain of $162,000, or 1 cent a share, on fully diluted basis, from the sale of two plants.

title: Blacks 'Brainwashed' On Past, Dinkins Says
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins, reflecting on black pride in a television interview broadcast yesterday to Africa by the United States Government, said American blacks had in the past been slow to appreciate their cultural heritage because they were ''so brainwashed'' by whites.

title: Quarantine Is a Wrong Question on AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan's Status Quo;   Economic Interests Stifle the Outrage In the Electorate Caused by Scandals
description: In the last year, Japan has experienced the downfall of two Prime Ministers, widespread outrage over the official and after-hours behavior of politicians, protests by women and other events suggesting that this most stable of nations was on the verge of great political change.

title: Washington Talk;   President and the Press: A Clash of 2 Obsessions
description: To understand the way the President deals with the press, his charm and his tirades, you must think sports.

title: State Dept. Says Israel Still Violates Arab Rights
description: The United States said today that Israeli soldiers continued to violate the rights of Palestinians in the occupied territories, causing ''avoidable deaths and injuries.'' At the same time, the State Department reported a ''significant increase in violence by Palestinians directed at other Palestinians.''

title: Surgery for Campanella
description: Roy Campanella, the Hall of Fame catcher, who has been hospitalized since Dec. 30 with complications from diabetes, underwent surgery yesterday for the removal of gallstones.

title: Anger Over a Pesticide Is Building in California
description: When the helicopters, flying in military formation, come thudding past her home in the early morning, spraying insecticide over her house, her lawn, her car and her children's yellow plastic slide, Melinda Wills considers what it means to her to be an American.

title: Eating Well
description: ON the way to a slimmer self, most dieters reach a plateau where despite continued effort, extra pounds refuse to budge.

title: Consolidated Natural Gas reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Chevron Cut May Total 1,000 Jobs
description: The Chevron Corporation said today that it would trim up to 1,000 jobs this year, or 12 percent of the payroll of its domestic exploration and production unit. The oil giant also said it would sell more than $700 million worth of its domestic properties in the next two years.

title: Honda Net Off 8% in Quarter
description: Currency losses and higher interest expenses trimmed the Honda Motor Company's group net profits by 8 percent, to $156 million, in the three months ended Dec. 31, 1989, the company said today.

title: TDK Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Periods for 1988 ended Nov. 30. Because of the change in TDK's fiscal year-end from Nov. 30 to March 31 last year, an exact comparison cannot be made with previous semi-annual results. As of July 24, 1989, each American Depositary Share represented one share of common stock. To facilitate comparison, the ADS figure for FY 1988 has been restated to this effect. The amounts shown in U.S. dollars are converted at a rate 143 yen equals U.S. $1, the opening rate on the Tokyo foreign exchange market on Dec. 29, 1989.

title: Fuqua Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $805,000. c-After income from discontinued operations of $5,682,000, or 26 cents a share, for the quarter and $15,970,000, or 74 cents a share, for the year. The company said the combination of Fuqua's photofinishing operation with the domestic photofinishing operations of Eastern Kodak Co. resulted in a 1988 after-tax gain of $68,803,000, or $3.18 a share. Effective May 31, 1989, Fuqua completed the sale of Georgia Federal Bank, FSB, for $234.5 million in cash, plus $7.5 million of dividends paid by Georgia Federal to Fuqua in 1989. Discontinued operations in 1989 represented an adjustment to the reserve, established in December 1988, for the estimated loss on the sale. Discontinued operations in 1988 included the operating results of Georgia Federal Bank and the August 1988 sale and operating results of Ajay Enterprises. The 1988 continuing operations figures included a provision of $9,595,000 after tax (45 cents a share and 41 cents a share fully diluted for the fourth quarter and year, respectively) for the severence benefits and the termination of certain employment agreements.

title: Bad Language, Hurt Feelings and Success
description: Last year Matt Groening, whose bleakly humorous cartoon, ''Life in Hell,'' appears in some 200 newspapers around the country, began creating brief animated features for ''The Tracey Ullman Show'' on Fox Broadcasting. James L. Brooks, an executive producer of the show, saw Mr. Groening's potential audience and invited him to do a full-length special. The result was ''The Simpsons Roasting on an Open Fire,'' which was shown by Fox Television in December.

title: Interpublic Net Increases 17.6%
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies yesterday reported net income for the fourth quarter of 1989 of $27.4 million, or 81 cents a share, up 17.6 percent from $23.3 million, or 70 cents a share, for the fourth quarter of 1988. Revenue rose 2.4 percent, to $380 million from $371.1 million.

title: Chicago Class for the Gifted Requires More Than Brains
description: Inside the peeling walls of Crane High School, surrounded by housing projects and too many gangs to count, the eight members in Joyce Oatman's senior class of gifted students discuss logic and reasoning.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: THe place was the women's locker room at the 92d Street Y where Soozy Goldfarb overheard two women discussing the Pan Am Building. ''Where is it?'' the first woman asked. The second woman gave her the address. ''What does the building look like?'' ''It's mostly glass and metal,'' the second woman replied.

title: Upheaval in the East;   GORBACHEV VOICES NEW RESERVATIONS ON GERMAN UNITY
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev conceded today that the two Germanys had a right to unity but stressed the Soviet Union's own ''inalienable right'' to insure that reunification does not lead to ''moral, political or economic damage'' for the Soviet Union.

title: Ecolab Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included pretax charge from restructuring of $31.5 million for both the quarter and year. c-Net income

title: Shearson's Debt Rating
description: Moody's Investor Services reaffirmed yesterday the A-3 rating it had assigned to Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.'s senior debt.

title: Books of The Times;   Korean's Novel Is Anti-War But Not Anti-American
description: Silver Stallion

title: Lessons
description: From the one-room schoolhouse to the monumental high schools that began to appear at the turn of the century, school architecture has signaled the way Americans think about education.

title: Holyfield Spurns Deal
description: Evander Holyfield yesterday turned down a $40 million, three-fight deal offered by Steve Wynn, owner of the Mirage Hotel in Las Vegas, Nev. James (Buster) Douglas, the heavyweight champion, and Holyfield, the No. 1 contender, have agreed to a title fight this year. The package offered by Wynn included fights with George Foreman and Mike Tyson. (AP)

title: Perkin-Elmer Plan
description: The Perkin-Elmer Corporation said it will conduct a ''Dutch auction'' self-tender offer Wednesday for up to 10 million shares of its common stock, or about 23 percent of the 43.5 million outstanding shares. Under the procedure, the company said, each stockholder will be invited to tender shares at prices of $22 to $26 a share. Perkin-Elmer will select and buy shares up to that price. The offer is scheduled to expire March 23. Perkin-Elmer shares rose $1.25 today, to $24.50, in New York Stock Exchange trading.

title: About New York;   To Stay Young: Walk, Feed Birds, Help Old People
description: Margaret Grossman, more than 87 years into this odd adventure called living, knows many things. ''I will die with a smile on my face,'' is one of them.

title: Doctor Denies She Left Needle for Prego
description: The doctor accused of leaving the needle that punctured Dr. Veronica Prego's finger in 1983 testified yesterday that she had never left a needle on a patient's bed.

title: Wine Talk
description: THE hand-wringing, grumbling and general sense of malaise that has affected a large segment of the wine industry has not yet touched one special group of grape growers and vintners. Perhaps it's because their end product isn't wine. It's Cognac.

title: Supreme Court Roundup;   Justices Limit Parent's Rights in Child Abuse Case
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that a parent who is under a court's supervision for previously abusing a child must obey a court order to produce the child or disclose his whereabouts, even if the disclosure is incriminating.

title: Loblaw Cos. reports earnings for Year to Dec 30
description: b-Included an unusual pre-tax charge of $21.5 million from the costs of downsizing and remerchandising combination stores in eastern Canada and consisted of a $2.1 million gain on the sale of a unit and a $16.7 million provision for a loss on the planned sale of most of the New Orleans division. The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: Corporate Foods Ltd.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary gain from property disposal of $1,500,000, or 8 cents a share. Results are in Canadian dollars. Latest year figures included pro forma results for all of 1989 of Eastern Bakeries Ltd., which merged with Corporate Foods last summer. Eastern Bakeries alone had 1989 earnings of $399,000 on revenues of $54,940,000. The company actually began to amalgamate Eastern Bakeries results on Sept. 11, 1989. Eastern's contribution for the period Sept. 11 to Dec. 31 was not available. Year-earlier figures included, for comparative purposes, pro forma results of Eastern Bakeries, which had 1988 earnings of $2,570,000 on revenues of $54,791,000. The results are for a 53-week peroid.

title: Freshman Steps In and Seton Hall Snaps Losing Streak
description: Marco Lokar of Seton Hall sank more field goals in the game against Pittsburgh tonight than he had made all season. He almost scored more points as well.

title: Ready to Be the Slugger of Old
description: The back is fine. To prove the point, Dave Winfield turns, pulls up his T-shirt and exposes a small scar on his lower back. The scar is the only physical reminder of the surgery he had last March, but not necessarily the only scar Winfield carries from a long and sometimes painful year gone by.

title: Article 897190 -- No Title
description: The owners and managers of an apartment complex here have agreed to pay $450,000 to settle a lawsuit accusing them of discriminating against blacks, their lawyers say.

title: Weary Of J.F.K.? This Field Hopes So
description: Bradley International Airport, New England's perpetual No. 2 airfield after Logan International in Boston, has never escaped the fact that for most travelers Connecticut is a place to be flown over and looked down upon on the way to somewhere else.

title: Democrats Seek Harmony on Campaign Bill
description: Stung by reports of dissention in their ranks, Senate Democrats working to overhaul campaign finance laws sought today to play down their differences as minor disagreements that would not impede action on a reform measure the Senate will take up in late March.

title: Book Notes
description: Weidenfeld Galaxy Losses and disappointing sales led Ann Getty and George Weidenfeld to merge Weidenfeld & Nicolson and Grove Press into a single house last year, and rumors still crop up that the merged house - Grove Weidenfeld - will be shut down. But those rumors now surface much less often, and in the meantime the house has been signing important authors and selling reprint rights for respectable money.

title: WIDOW IN VERMONT WON'T LOSE HOUSE
description: A negligence suit that had threatened an elderly widow with the loss of her home and life savings was settled out of court today, sparing the woman's possessions.

title: G.A.O. Study Of Computers
description: A study by the investigative arm of Congress has concluded that Government regulators need to pay closer attention to the security of computer systems used by the financial markets.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: COLLEGE BASKETBALL

title: Rates Soar To Highest Since May
description: Interest rates soared yesterday as prices of both short- and long-term Treasury securities plunged. Dealers largely blamed concern that rising interest rates overseas would further increase the cost of borrowing in the United States.

title: Teen-Age Couple Shot Dead in Car in Bronx
description: A teen-age couple were shot to death last night while sitting in a car parked on a street in the Bronx, the police said.

title: Interpublic Group of Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Revenue represented gross income.

title: Sheeb Journal;   Africa's 30 Years' War: A Rebel Scouts for Allies
description: Isaias Afwerki, a tall 44-year-old guerrilla dressed in jeans who has long commanded the rebels of Africa's longest war from stone bunkers shrouded in gray thorn trees, has recently emerged into the international world of well-tailored suits and burnished dining rooms.

title: Oil-Dri Corp of America reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
Mississippi Journal;   Hunting Is the Issue Surpassing All Others
description: At a time when single-issue politics has made lawmakers leery of sensitive issues, Mississippi legislators find themselves staring down the barrel of perhaps the most explosive issue of them all.

title: Nominee for M.I.T. Presidency Backs Out of Post
description: A highly regarded biologist nominated last week to be president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology backed out of the job yesterday, saying he could not bear to give up his research.

title: Midway Airlines reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a reversal of tax loss carryforward of $1,174,000. c-Net income and after extraordinary tax loss carryforwards of $174,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $2,599,000, or 24 cents a share, for the year. The company said the 1989 fourth quarter results reflected the cost associated with the establishment of its second Hub at Philadelphia International Airport.

title: First Boston Plans to Sell Loans to Affiliates
description: Burdened with troubled loans and battered ''junk bonds,'' the First Boston Corporation has arranged to get money from several affiliates by selling some of the loans, people at the firm said yesterday.

title: Underdogs, Favorites and California
description: Repeatedly, California's Presidential primary has been secondary. The state contains 1 of every 10 Americans and yet, time after time, the race for one party's nomination or the other has been settled before the first Tuesday in June, when California voters cast their primary ballots.

title: Chrysler, Renault Select Plant Site
description: The Chrysler Corporation and the French auto maker Renault said they had chosen a site in Spain to produce a new four-wheel-drive vehicle. The site, in a plant owned by Renault in Valladolid, about 100 miles north of Madrid, will start making vehicles in 1992. A plant in the United States, probably on a site owned by Chrysler, will be chosen soon.

title: Nowsco Well Service Ltd. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $7,997,000 from discontinued operations. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Correction
description: An Op-Ed article on Tuesday about a young man who was mugged in New York City misidentified the author. He is Robert Learner.

title: Alba-Waldensian reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Role in Housing Inquiry Is Declined
description: A Washington lawyer who was asked to head an independent criminal investigation of former Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. turned down the job this week after warnings of a possible conflict of interest, people close to the search said today.

title: Soviet Inquiry Into a Hate Group Is Reported
description: Prosecutors in Moscow have begun a criminal investigation into the activities of a militant Russian nationalist group that has been repeatedly accused by people around the country of instigating anti-Semitic actions.

title: Robert Lasek, Executive, 71
description: Robert Lasek, founder and president of Decorators Walk, a chain of wholesale showrooms with headquarters in Plainview, L.I., died on Tuesday at his home in Centerport, L.I. He was 71 years old.

title: David Newman, NASA Official, 45
description: David Newman, the internal communications director of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and a former network news producer, died of a heart attack on Monday at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 45 years old.

title: Turkish Killings Echo Across 75 Years to Create a Din in the Senate
description: The Senate spent hours today locked in an unusual debate over honoring the countless Armenians who died early in the century at the hands of the Ottoman Turks, a debate that has pitted some of the Senate's most powerful figures against each other and unleashed a frenzy of lobbying.

title: Havel's 'Paradoxical' Plea: Help Soviets
description: President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia told a joint meeting of Congress today that the best way the United States could aid his country and the rest of Eastern Europe in their quest for freedom was by helping the Soviet Union navigate the ''immensely complicated'' road to democracy.

title: Under Iris Murdoch's Exact, Steady Gaze
description: In the company of this Oxford classmate, long vanished and newly restored to view, Iris Murdoch stood at a window overlooking the Queensboro Bridge and took it all in, piece by piece - the pink walls of the Italian restaurant just below, the pistachio green of a housefront off to the right, the echoes of American Romanesque architecture way off to the south and the late-afternoon traffic swinging round the far corner of East 60th Street and plunging down into Manhattan.

title: Review/Dance;   A New, and Strong, Identity for the Feld Ballets
description: Eliot Feld has just changed the name of his company from the Feld Ballet to Feld Ballets NY. The idea was to give the troupe ''a New York identity,'' the management reports, although the new plural has not been explained.

title: Spiegel Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Certain 1988 amounts have been reclassified to conform to the current year presentation.

title: A Washington-Slept-Here Designation for a West Indies Home
description: ON his 20th birthday, Feb. 22, 1752, George Washington had just returned from Barbados, the only trip he was ever to make abroad. On the voyage to the Caribbean, he had accompanied his half brother and guardian, Lawrence Washington, who had sought a cure for his tuberculosis.

title: Henry Brandon, 77, Stage and Film Actor
description: Henry Brandon, an actor whose ex-perience ranged from Shakespeare in New York theater to westerns in Hollywood, died, apparently of a heart attack, on Feb. 15 in Los Angeles. He was 77 years old.

title: Tyco Toys reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Norcen Energy Res reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: 50 Contenders in Search of a New Political Order
description: With less than five weeks to go before Hungary freely elects a new government, voters and politicians are scrambling to find their places in the political vacuum left by the decline of Communism.

title: Texas Instruments' Chip
description: Texas Instruments Inc. said today that its wafer fabrication plant here had made the company's first computer memory chip capable of storing 16 million bits of information.

title: The Florios' New Home: Italian Marble and Rusty Water
description: Welcome to what the First Lady of the Garden State calls New Jersey's White House.

title: Brad Ragan reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Latest fourth-quarter results included a $1,700,000 unusual yearend inventory costing and other adjustments, and an additional $300,000 reserve for product liability.

title: Observers See Free and Fair Nicaragua Election
description: To the Editor:

title:
CURRENTS;

A Gallery's Inviting Entrance
description: LEAD: THE entrance to A/D, a new gallery at 560 Broadway (Prince Street) in SoHo, was given a slightly different angle by its designers, 1,100 Architects of New York City. The architectural firm installed a door of glass and black steel that adds its own corner to a corner of the irregularly angled sixth-floor corridor outside A/D.

title: Japan to Give Tax Benefits For Charitable Aid in U.S.

description: LEAD: RICH they are not. Fresh out of college, they decorate on a shoestring. But they love their jobs. And now that three private schools in Manhattan have provided buildings for their young teachers to live in, life is much easier for them. They can teach, live where they want to and even have money left over for food.

title: Mandela: Our Cousin, a King
description: My wife and I sat in our robes, with our newspapers and coffee mugs, staring intently at the TV screen. When the motorcade that began inside the prison appeared near the gate, we stiffened. The cars stopped and there was scurrying. Suddenly, I sensed that a man whom I had taken to be a bodyguard and whom I had never seen was the one we were awaiting.

title: Bernice Carey, Mystery Writer, 79

title: Flamingos, Palms and Silence

When the Miami Springs Canal was widened in the early 1900's, the water drained off and there rose, like a tiny Atlantis, a magical place. Two hundred and twenty of its acres were sculpted into Hialeah Park, which opened in 1925 and became known throughout the world as an enchanted kingdom for thoroughbred horses and the people who follow them.

Sheriff Ashe, fed up with overcrowding at the county jail, commandeered the armory and moved 15 minimum-security prisoners there after citing a 17th-century Massachusetts law that he said allowed local authorities to compel National Guard assistance if they perceived a threat to public order. Over the objections of the state, the 15 prisoners remain there.

title: Reviews/Music;   Robert Taub Piano Recital Offers a Babbitt Premiere
description: There are those who lament the supposed rupture of the Western musical performance tradition. In decades past, their argument runs, performers were either naturally interested in the music of their time or composed themselves, thus extending the tradition by recasting the music of the past in the image of the present - the archetype being Wagner and his disciples conducting Beethoven like Wagner. Now, pessimists complain, performers concern themselves only with rote regurgitations of the past, leading to the ossification of the tradition.

title: Market Place;   Can Macy Endure Price-Cutting?
description: MORE than three years after its leveraged buyout, R. H. Macy & Company is encountering doubts about its ability to survive if the current wave of price-cutting by major retailing chains continues. Moody's Investors Service said yesterday that it was considering cutting the rating on Macy's already low-rated ''junk bonds,'' sending the prices of the bonds down further and prompting an angry response from the company.

title: Top Spy Flees to Soviets

title: Brendan Corish, Irish Politician, 71
description: Brendan Corish, former leader of the Irish Labor Party and Deputy Prime Minister from 1973 to 1977, died on Saturday in a nursing home in Wexford, his family said. He was 71 years old. The cause of death was not disclosed. Mr. Corish was a Socialist who first went to Parliament in 1945 and succeeded William Norton as Labor Party leader in 1960.

title: Review/Music;   A Refreshing Side of Mahler, Based in Folk
description: Mahler's songs are, for some, the half-formed embryos from which the later symphonic expanses were to grow. Paradoxically, song forms, and the poetic texts that shape them, also rescued him from excess, imposing boundaries from without and restraining one of the most boundless of Romantic egos. Mahler's songs tend to speak less extravagantly, with less heart-rending passion and at less length than the symphonies, but they may be more coherent in the process.

title: Proxy Fight At Lockheed
description: The Dallas financier Harold C. Simmons said today that he would wage a proxy fight for control of the board of the Lockheed Corporation at the company's annual meeting on March 29.

title: Computer Language Research reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-Net loss

title: Loss at Westwood One
description: Westwood One Inc. reported on Tuesday that it lost more than $4 million in the fourth quarter on sharply higher revenues and operating income. The company, which owns two radio networks and several radio stations, attributed the loss to the heavy cost of recent investments, including the acquisition of a radio station here. For the quarter, the company lost $4.1 million, compared with a $1.3 million loss a year earlier. Revenues in the fourth quarter rose 49 percent, to $38.6 million from $26 million.

title: Brooklyn Bishop Is Facing Diverse Cultures and Tensions
description: When Bishop Thomas V. Daily takes charge of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, he will face racial tensions and ethnic sensitivities as well as difficult choices about maintaining churches and schools in neighborhoods where the numbers of Catholics have declined.

title: Bumbling Rangers Are Tied
description: The Rangers weren't about to add one more mistake to their unsightly collection once the game was over. They were not, for instance, about to mistake their 4-4 draw against the Red Wings for anything other than what it was: a minor miracle and single point achieved with neither grace nor conviction.

title: Outside China's Cities, the Crackdown and the Outrage Are Watered Down
description: Tan Youyun, a 42-year-old private businessman, nibbled a bit of steaming pig intestine and furrowed his brow as he tried to think of some way in which life had changed since the rise of the hard-liners last year.

title: Anthony Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 5 percent stock dividend in December.

title: Iacocca Revival: U.S. Cars Praised
description: For Lee A. Iacocca, a funny thing happened on the way to retirement: The Chrysler Corporation, which seemed to need him less and less during the mid-1980's, is struggling again and is once more turning to his personal brand of salesmanship to revive its fortunes.

title: SPX Gives President Title of Chief Executive
description: The board of the SPX Corporation has elected Dale A. Johnson as the company's president and chief executive. Mr. Johnson, 52, had been president and chief operating officer since 1988.

title: Brady (W.H.) Co.  (O) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit from proceeds from officer's life insurance policies of $4,625,000, or 62 cents a share for both the quarter and 6 months, and the 6 months also included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $1,233,000, or 16 cents a share.

title: Couple Die in Drug Shootout While Parked on Bronx Street
description: A woman on a date in the Bronx with a man she met this month was fatally shot in the crossfire between rival drug dealers Tuesday night, the police said. Her date, one of the suspected dealers, was also killed.

title: As Fighting Escalates, So Do N.B.A. Fines
description: In a continuing effort to discourage fighting and violence, Rod Thorn, the National Basketball Association's vice president for operations, who is known among players as the dean of discipline, fined eight players from four different teams a total of $10,500 yesterday.

title: Authors Guild to Audit Some Royalty Statements
description: Acting after some authors said they did not trust publishers' royalty statements, the Authors Guild announced yesterday that it would pay for an audit of royalty statements of two books a year.

title: Time for a Diet
description: After enjoying a sensational season that won him the National League comeback-player-of-the-year award, Lonnie Smith of the Atlanta Braves went on a calorie-comsuming spree that raised the weight on his 5-foot 7-inch frame from 190 to 225 1/2 pounds. Smith, who hit .315 with 21 home runs, celebrated his success with steak, potatoes, beer and rich chocolate desserts.

title: Canada Malting reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit from the sale of a property of $3,416,000, or 72 cents a share for both the quarter and year. The company said higher sales reflect the contributions of Great Western Malting Co. from March and Hugh Baird & Sons Ltd. in December, as well as growth in its Canadian operations. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Southern Blooms In Northern Climes
description: The first chores of spring begin in late February. Now is the time to have gasoline-powered lawn mowers serviced, to have their blades sharpened or replaced and to check their spark plugs and oil filters. The ornamental grasses and perennials left standing over the winter should be cut back now. Many deciduous shrubs, like the taller kinds of cotoneaster, can be pruned now, when the structure of their branches is plain enough to see.

title: Apple to Cut 400 Workers
description: Apple Computer Inc. said today that it would reduce its work force by 400 people, or about 3 percent, as part of an effort to improve profitability.

title: Fairfax Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Madison Gas & Electric reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CHRONICLE
description: Panama's PRESIDENT GUILLERMO ENDARA is engaged to ANA MAE DIAZ, the 24-year-old aide of RICARDO ARIAS CALDERON, the First Vice President. The Associated Press reported that a senior Government official said the couple plan to marry in June.

title: Merchant Pacific Buys Barry Stake
description: The Merchant Pacific Corporation, a private investment firm in Los Angeles, has acquired 8.4 percent of the R. G. Barry Corporation. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Merchant Pacific said it had bought 313,000 shares on the open market for an average of $9.25 each. Barry's shares rose 12.5 cents each today, to $7.625, in trading on the American Stock Exchange, giving the company a current value of $28.2 million.

title: A List of Those Honored
description: Here is a list of winners at tonight's 32d annual Grammy Awards:

title: National Presto Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Architect's Challenge: Making 60 Rooms Cozy
description: EVEN its architect cannot seem to keep the number of rooms straight. ''I think there are about 60 of them, and 11 or 12 bathrooms,'' Francis C. Klein said of the mammoth private house that he has just completed on a 13-acre property in Fairfield County, Conn.

title: 2,595 New York City Teachers Go Untrained
description: Almost 2,600 untrained New York City teachers hired during the teacher shortage of recent years have not received the training they were promised, school and teachers union officials disclosed yesterday.

title: Royal Dutch/Shell Group of Cos.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings of the Royal Dutch Petroleum Co.'s latest periods were $1.78 for the quarter and $7.58 for the 12 months, compared with $1.56 and $6.27 for the year-ago periods, respectively. The Shell Transport and Trading Co.'s share earnings for the latest periods were $1.08 for the quarter and $4.37 for the 12 months, compared with 83 cents and $3.46 for the year- ago periods, respectively. Sales represented sales proceeds. Royal Dutch and Shell Transport are listed separately on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: United Way to Aid Smaller Agencies
description: Under criticism for supporting only long-established charities, United Way of New York City expects to devote $70 million in the next five years to bolstering scores of small local agencies that help jobless youth, illiterate adults, AIDS patients, victims of domestic violence and the homeless.

title: Kaypro Corp. reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
Evans & Sutherland Computer Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-Included non-recurring pretax cost of $13,200,000 for closing and writing down the assets of the supercomputer operations for the quarter and the year included an extraordinary gain from repurchase of convertible debentures of $1,110,000, or 13 cents a share. c-Net income d-Included an extraordinary gain from repurchase of convertible debentures of $1,100,000, or 13 cents a share. Year-ago income from continuing operations of $790,000, or 9 cents a share, included $4,050,000 pretax inventory writeoff. The company said the latest year's loss from continuing operations of 1 cent a share included $2.20 a share loss from the supercomputer operations offset by a 35 cents a share in balance sheet gains.

title: Northrop Reports Loss
description: The Northrop Corporation said today that it had a loss of $16.6 million in the fourth quarter after setting aside $28 million to cover losses on fixed-price research and development programs. In the comparable period in 1988, the company had a loss of $86.1 million.

title: Review/Theater;   A Sexual Cover-Up in 'New Anatomies'
description: Isabelle Eberhardt drowned in the desert, the victim of a freak flood. This was a bizarre end to a brief, fascinating life. She was a European who transformed herself into an Arab; in the guise of a man, she traveled through the Sahara and lived with with the natives under her adopted name, Si Mahmoud. Dabbling in mysticism, she became an ''oblivion seeker,'' as in the title of one of her short stories.

title: Liver Transplantee Returns To Surgery to Stop Bleeding
description: Doctors for 12-year-old Stormie Jones, the world's first recipient of a heart-and-liver transplant, spent more than nine hours Wednesday trying to stop internal bleeding that began after her second liver transplant.

title: J. P. Industries
description: J. P. Industries said it was investigating alternatives to increase shareholder value that include a strategic alliance or possible change of control. The company, based in Ann Arbor, also said it was in preliminary talks with a ''large manufacturer'' that it did not identify. J. P. Industries, which said the discussions could end at any time, makes transporation products. Its shares rose $1.25 each today, to $14.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. At today's closing price, the company has a value of about $158 million.

title: Lyons Journal;   Interpol Regrets Shady Past, Vows Better Future
description: There were certain untruths about the daring and romantic exploits of its James Bondish agents that Interpol found useful to keep alive behind the aura of mystery that has traditionally surrounded the worldwide police organization.

title: 'A Chorus Line,' the Show That Has Outrun Them All, Is Closing
description: After 15 years as one singular sensation, ''A Chorus Line,'' the longest-running and one of the most influential shows in Broadway history, is closing.

title: Boston Clash on Mandela
description: The acting president of Boston University has criticized the superintendent of the Chelsea public schools, which the university supervises, for using Nelson Mandela as a role model for the Chelsea students.

title: Crystal Brands Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $8,108,000 for the quarter and $8,864,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $624,000 and $1,675,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. As announced previously, Crystal Brands has decided to divest its Ship 'n Shore and William Barry operations. As a result of the Ship 'n Shore divestiture, the company incurred a one-time after-tax charge in 1989 of $8,864,000. The results of operations of Palm Beach and Trifari (both acquired in 1988) were included for the full 12 months of 1989. In the prior year, the results of Trifari were included for eight months but the results of Palm Beach were excluded for the full year, as Palm Beach was acquired at the end of 1988.

title:
CURRENTS;

Ever So Humble: Houses From Tires
description: LEAD: NOW there is something to do with those old car tires: make a building.

title: Nets Shake Off Slide At Sound of Buzzer
description: A few hours after his best friend on the team was traded, Lester Conner found something to smile about tonight.

title: Alliant Computer Systems Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and after extraordinary tax benefits of $350,000, or 3 cents a share for the both the quarter and year, and the year also included a gain on the repurchase of debentures of $2,953,000. Year-ago quarter and year's losses from continuing operations of $27,887,000 and $39,546,000, respectively, both included restructuring charge of $19,937,000.

title: Florida Players Free
description: The four University of Florida players suspended last Oct. 16 after they admitted betting on college and pro games will not be prosecuted and will be eligible to play next year, the university said yesterday.

title: Health Care for the Homeless: Treating the Byproducts of Life on the Street
description: When the 72-year-old retired music teacher visited the Lamb's Clinic near Times Square in New York City, she had a litany of mid-winter medical complaints: flu-like symptoms, feet that retained fluid so they barely fit into tennis shoes and terrible headaches caused by high blood pressure.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 19 about Barbara Piasecka Johnson's proposed purchase of the Lenin Shipyard in Gdansk, Poland, referred imprecisely to her inheritance. Mrs. Johnson inherited $350 million from her husband, J. Seward Johnson; according to a recent calculation by Johnson & Johnson, that was about 11 percent of the total Johnson fortune.

title: Review/Television;   Small-Town Life in 'Grand,' NBC Comedy
description: Somewhere inside the several layers of standard sitcom silliness in ''Grand,'' there is a sharp, bittersweet, often very funny comedy about life and manners in today's small-town America struggling to survive. The new NBC series, Thursdays at 9:30 P.M., is being produced by the Carsey-Werner Company (''The Cosby Show'') in association with Bill Cosby, who is billed as executive consultant. It was created by Michael Leeson (''Taxi''), who is also one of the executive producers.

title: KEY RATES
Gates-FA Distributing reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Dow Finishes 13.29 Lower After a Big Decline Earlier
description: Stock prices fell yesterday, pulled down initially by a report of a 1.1 percent increase in the Consumer Price Index for last month.

title: Metro Matters;   Albany Redux: Faith and Politics Are in Conflict
description: ''I'm a good Catholic,'' the Governor of New York, in the privacy of his Albany office, reminded a ranking Roman Catholic clergyman as they debated a proposed constitutional amendment.

title: Harnischfeger Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After extraordinary tax benefits from tax loss carryforwards of $3,050,000, or 9 cents a share, for the latest first quarter and $3.3 million, or 10 cents a share, for year-ago period.

title: Review/Television;   When the Mystery, Not the Corpse, Is in Pieces
description: If you are looking for a reason to contribute a bit more to public television during its approaching money-raising period, a comparison between tonight's episode of the engaging Hercule Poirot series on Channels 13 (at 8 P.M.) and 21 (at 9 P.M.) and the adaptations of stories by Agatha Christie and others on the Arts & Entertainment cable channel may do the trick. From 9 to 11 on Mondays, under the rubric ''Masters of Mystery,'' A&E is showing British-made one-hour detective tales of the sort that public broadcasting's ''Mystery'' series has long been importing. On A&E they are interrupted by commercials.

title: Frogs as Canaries
description: It would make the beginning of a science fiction story. A world congress of biologists meeting in Canterbury, England, last September found on comparing notes that frogs are disappearing from ponds, swamps, creeks and rain forests all over the world. Are the vanishing amphibians signaling an invisible peril for humans, like canaries in a mine?

title: Decision Due March 1 on Seabrook License
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission announced Tuesday that it would decide on March 1 whether to license the Seabrook nuclear power plant, setting the stage for a legal battle.

title: Dinkins Administration Proposes Another Hurdle to S.I. Secession
description: Proposing yet another hurdle to the secession of Staten Island from New York City, the Dinkins administration is asking the State Legislature to require all voters in the city, not just those on Staten Island, to vote on the issue before it could be approved.

title: Ideas for the House, Ranch to Cape Cod
description: THE far west end of 33d Street is an improbable site to construct a 1,990-square-foot, three-bedroom ranch house. But one was completed there yesterday in the Jacob Javits Convention Center as an exhibit for the Greater New York Home and Apartment Show.

title: Bond Tables Are Incomplete
description: Because of the failure of a computer system at The Associated Press yesterday, the tables listing trading in Government agency bonds could not be processed and do not appear today.

title: Israel Calls U.S. Human Rights Report One-Sided
description: The Israeli Government today criticized a State Department report accusing the military here of abusing Arab human rights, saying that the report failed to make clear that the army's actions were in response to Palestinian violence.

title: Doctor Again Denies Role in Prego Accident
description: Dr. Joyce F. Fogel, who is accused of carelessly causing Dr. Veronica Prego to puncture her finger on a contaminated needle, finished testifying yesterday by saying she was ''totally unassociated'' with the incident.

title: Sanders's Yank Career May Be Coming to Halt
description: The brief but impressive baseball career of Deion Sanders, the Yankees' rookie outfielder, appears to be in jeopardy before it really begins.

title: Moore Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Eurotunnel Dispute on Costs Ended
description: The latest dispute to threaten completion of a tunnel under the English Channel was settled today after the owners and builders of the venture agreed to name an American executive to head the project management team.

title: Culp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: b-Net loss

title: Ex-Officer To Become VMS Chief
description: VMS Realty Partners, the troubled real estate giant, said today that its chief executive of only four months, Jeffrey A. Park, would resign. Joel A. Stone, who had been president before Mr. Park joined the company will succeed Mr. Park, VMS said.

title: U.S. Policy On Deposits Is Criticized
description: L. William Seidman, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said today that regulators were searching for ways to permit very large banks to fail without the Government bailing out all depositors and creditors who might face losses.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: WHEN working with household electrical wiring, it is of utmost importance to make safe, reliable connections. Here are sound methods for joining wires and fastening their ends to things like wall switches and receptacles. Be sure the power is turned off before beginning.

title: Bridge
description: Some tournament deals are good candidates for the old challenge: ''play or defend?'' Looking at all four hands in the diagramed deal, would you choose to play or defend a contract of four hearts? It occurred in the International Fund Game played in all parts of North America last July 28 and was reported by Mike Cafferata of Scarborough, Ontario.

title: CONSUMER PRICES ROSE IN JANUARY BY A SHARP 1.1%
description: Heavily affected by harsh early-winter weather, consumer prices soared 1.1 percent in January, the biggest monthly advance in more than seven years, the Labor Department reported today.

title: United Cities Gas reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After preferred dividend payments of $52,000 in 1989 and $125,000 in 1988. c-After preferred dividend payments of $302,000 in 1989 and $508,000 in 1988. The 1988 year is also after an extraordinary gain of $281,000, or 5 cents a share, on utilization of operating loss carryforward. Year-ago periods restated for Great River Gas Co. pooling of interest.

title: High Court Decides Budget Office Exceeded Power in Blocking Rules
description: Dealing an unexpected setback to the deregulatory efforts of the Reagan and Bush administrations, the Supreme Court ruled today that the White House budget office lacked statutory authority to block certain regulations issued by other Federal agencies.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: ANN P. cringes at the thought of her 10-year-old daughter visiting the home of a particular friend. The problem lies not with the other child but with her parents, who have a strikingly different approach to supervising children.

title: New Financing By Farm Bank
description: The Federal Farm Credit Bank Funding Corporation priced through various securities dealers a three-part bond issue yesterday totaling $2.99 billion.

title: Metzenbaum Weighs In Against Court Nominee
description: Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum joined today with some influential groups representing the elderly in opposing the nomination of Clarence Thomas for the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia. The Senate Judiciary Committee is scheduled to vote on the nomination on Thursday.

title: Sikorsky Plans To Lay Off 300
description: Sikorsky Aircraft said today that it would lay off 300 white-collar workers to streamline the helicopter manufacturer amid declining military spending.

title: Lily M.L. Foregger, 89; Led Medical Company
description: Lily Mae Lassiter Foregger, whose family business, the Foregger Company, manufactured anesthesia equipment and other medical supplies, died of respiratory complications on Feb. 14 at Central Vermont Hospital in Berlin. She was 89 years old and lived in Waterbury Center, Vt.

title: Review/Ballet;   Martins's 'Black and White'
description: Peter Martins's ''Black and White,'' which the New York City Ballet presented for the first time this season on Tuesday night at the New York State Theater, takes its title from the colors of its simple costumes. It is a ballet of mischievous music and sobersided choreography.

title: Bow Valley Industries reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are fully diluted. Shares outstanding are based on weighted average shares and common share equivalents. After preferred dividend requirements, there were no share earnings in 1988. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ''What I Saw at the Revolution,'' PEGGY NOONAN'S book on her days as a speech writer for PRESIDENT RONALD REAGAN, was celebrated at a party last night at the home of JONI EVANS, the publisher at Random House but it had its start in an ''old girl'' network of sorts.

title: CLOSE TO HOME
description: I would like to say that my bag is packed. But it isn't and won't be, not until it's almost time for the goodbye kisses and the rush for the airport.

title: Cuban Begins Hunger Strike
description: A long-term Cuban political prisoner has begun a hunger strike to press for continued scrutiny of Cuba's human rights situation by the United Nations, a leading Cuban dissident said today. Ricardo Bofill, exiled chairman of Cuba's Human Rights Commission, said Ernesto Diaz Rodriguez had begun his fast Feb. 14 at the Combinado del Este prison, near Havana. Cuba is not on the agenda of this year's session of the United Nations Human Rights Commission currently meeting in Geneva.

title: McMartin Case Judge Barred From Presiding Over Retrial
description: A Superior Court judge ruled today that his colleague who presided over the McMartin Preschool molestation trial could not preside at the retrial of one of the defendants, Raymond Buckey.

title: Steel of West Virginia reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BUSH GETS PLEAS OVER ENVIRONMENT
description: Leaders of eight national environmental groups wrote to President Bush today, complaining that his promises to protect the environment are being undercut by his chief of staff, John H. Sununu.

title: Court Forbids Removal of Disputed Silver
description: The Lebanese Government was granted a temporary restraining order on Tuesday by State Supreme Court in Manhattan that bars Sotheby's from removing a collection of 14 pieces of ancient Roman silver from the United States.

title: Norrington To Direct Orchestra Of St. Luke's
description: Roger Norrington, the English conductor who has gained wide popularity through his original-instruments Beethoven recordings, will be named music director of the New York-based Orchestra of St. Luke's, the orchestra's artistic director said yesterday.

title: Voice From Tiananmen Now Heard at Wellesley
description: The Wellesley College basketball coach had nothing but praise for her new point guard.

title: Short-Term Revenue Notes Are Priced by Puerto Rico
description: The Commonwealth of Puerto Rico priced about $550 million in short-term tax- and revenue-anticipation notes yesterday.

title: Digital Planning Cost Cuts That Could Include Layoffs
description: Hurt by a sluggish domestic computer market, the Digital Equipment Corporation might substantially expand its voluntary severance program in an attempt to cut its payroll and slash costs, a Digital official said today.

title: MEI Diversified reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $637,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and year. c-After extraordinary credits of $3,430,000, or 18 cents a share, for the quarter and $3,697,000, or 19 cents a share, for the year. d-Net income

title: Conservative Arabs Still Hostile Toward Iran
description: Nineteen months after the Iran-Iraq war ended, the Teheran Government is still viewed as a clear danger by several conservative Arab oil-producing countries in this region.

title: Knicks Trade Strickland to Spurs for Cheeks
description: Rod Strickland, the unhappy Knick who had asked to be traded, got his wish last night. In an exchange of guards that brought them a more experienced and less controversial player, the Knicks sent the 23-year-old Strickland to the San Antonio Spurs for the 33-year-old Maurice Cheeks.

title: Tankers to Keep Away From Florida Coral
description: The grounding of three cargo ships on the coral reefs off the Florida Keys has led to an agreement by 15 of the nation's largest oil companies to keep their tankers six miles from the fragile reefs.

title: New Delay to Keep A-Plant Closed at Least Until July
description: The idled Rocky Flats weapons plant in Colorado, the sole supplier of plutonium triggers for American nuclear warheads, is unlikely to resume full production until July at the earliest, a senior Energy Department official said today.

title: James River Sale
description: The James River Corporation has agreed to sell its Nonwovens Group to Holzstoff Holding A.G. of Basel, Switzerland, for $175 million. The sale is expected to conclude before the end of March. James River also said it had completed the previously announced deal with Montedison S.p.A. of Italy and the Nokia Group of Finland under which the tissue and disposable hygenics operations of all three companies would be united.

title: Canadian Airline Seeks U.S. Market
description: Canadian Airlines International Ltd., Canada's second-largest airline, is negotiating alliances with two of the eight primary American carriers to gain a foothold in the lucrative passenger market. Trade agreements bar Canadian carriers from expanding south of the border.

title: General Binding Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Campy's Still Smiling
description: The morning after his gallstone surgery, Roy Campanella woke up smiling. ''My operation was a success,'' he told his nurses yesterday, ''and I'm feeling good.''

title: Reviews/Music;   All Flute And All Bach By Rampal
description: Some of Bach's works gain a cumulative impact beyond their individual merits when presented in unified or integral sets. His flute sonatas, however, are not necessarily among them, particularly if performed in a way that irons out their considerable differences. Jean-Pierre Rampal, who played the set complete at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday afternoon with the harpsichordist John Steele Ritter and, showing a kind of hubris seemingly intrinsic in today's superstar events, overlooked an obvious expedient: enlisting a third performer.

title: Binks to Consider Offer by Ransburg
description: The Binks Manufacturing Company said its board would study a $45-a-share offer from the Ransburg Corporation, a unit of Illinois Tool Works Inc. ''Historically, Binks has been committed to remaining independent and has a bright future,'' Burke B. Roche, the company's president, said, ''and personally, I am skeptical about a number of aspects of the Ransburg offer.''

title: Sandinistas Mount Mammoth Rally
description: Hundreds of thousands of Sandinista supporters, many of them singing and chanting, gathered here today for a rally that may be the largest in the history of the country.

title: Growers Reach for the Ballot in California Duel Over Pesticides
description: In a duel over pesticides that could have important implications for the rest of American agriculture, California growers today began collecting signatures for a ballot measure that they said would reform programs to protect food, water and farm workers from toxic chemicals.

title: American Travellers Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $333,000, or 9 cents a share for both the quarter and year, from a cummulative effect of prior years of adopting SFAS No. 96.

title: Oshkosh B'Gosh Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Books of The Times;   Deception and Journalism: How Far to Go for the Story
description: THE JOURNALIST AND THE MURDERER

title: Transmedia Network Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Norbert Schimmel, Collector, Dies; Specialist in Antiquities Was 85
description: Norbert Schimmel, a collector of antiquities who gave an important group of ancient Egyptian reliefs to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in 1985, died of pneumonia on Friday at his home in Longboat Key, Fla. He was 85 years old, and had lived for many years in Great Neck, L.I.

title: Money-Fund Yields Mixed
description: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the week ended yesterday, as tax-exempt funds dipped slightly and taxable funds were virtually unchanged.

title: Erly Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinue operations of $960,000 for the quarter and $1,407,000 for the 9 months. Year-ago shares outstanding are adjusted to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend in November 1989. Year-ago results are restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Public Service New Mexico reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and for the year included one-time charges totaling $87.7 million.

title: Q&A
description: Sewer Drain Water

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Company Briefs listing of Business Day yesterday described the E M C Corporation incorrectly. It makes computer storage products and is based in Hopkinton, Mass.

title: $1 Billion Venture Set To Provide Satellite TV
description: NBC, Rupert Murdoch and one of the nation's largest cable companies have agreed to become partners with Hughes Communications Inc. in a satellite service that will beam television programs directly to homes.

title: UNC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $8,909,000, or 53 cents a share, and $12,221,000, or 73 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively; the year also included an accounting adjustment income of $3,915,000, or 23 cents a share. c-Net income

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station referred incorrectly in some copies to the operator of a custom window-treatment business down the road from the plant. He is Eugene Grimes.

title: Lesotho Strips King of Power
description: Lesotho's military ruler said today he had stripped King Moshoeshoe II of all powers after the King refused to approve his choices to replace top military officials who were accused of plotting against the Government and arrested Monday. Maj. Gen. Justin Lekhanya's action deepened the political crisis in the southern African nation after the arrest of four officials suspected of plotting against the Government.

title: H. C. Pollack Jr., 48; Led Brokerage Houses
description: H. Clinton Pollack Jr., a stockbroker and an advertising executive, died on Sunday at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 48 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Rose Emerges in a Federal Inquiry on Unreported Income
description: A Federal grand jury is investigating whether Pete Rose may owe taxes on income from cash earned at baseball card and memorabilia shows, a spokeswoman for Rose confirmed today.

title: Michael Scherker, 32, Dance Archivist, Dies
description: Michael Scherker, the archivist of Dance Theater of Harlem and a founder of Preserve, the Coalition for Performing Arts Archives, died on Monday at Coney Island Hospital. He was 32 years old.

title: Bishop Mugavero Sees Liberal Legacy
description: The day after Pope John Paul II appointed a new, self-proclaimed conservative bishop to head the Diocese of Brooklyn, the departing bishop said that he was confident that his liberal legacy would continue in the diocese.

title: Reviews/Music;   Californians Lead a Retreat Into the Past
description: Europe - particularly Great Britain, West Germany and Austria -has enjoyed a considerable headstart on early-music players on the United States. The question is not knowledge so much as skill. Eighteenth-century oboes, flutes and strings are played similarly to the instruments taught currently in music conservatories, but their purity of sound comes at a price: mechanisms that are often less sophisticated, more awkward and consequently treacherous to manage. The relearning process can last a generation.

title: Exxon to Renew Alaska Cleanup; Accord Ends Standoff With State
description: The Exxon Corporation has agreed to return to the beaches fouled by the Exxon Valdez oil spill no later than May 1 and resume cleanup operations in Prince William Sound and the Gulf of Alaska.

title: Father Charged In Fatal Scuffle Offers to Testify
description: A construction worker accused of killing a homeless man on a Manhattan subway platform said yesterday that he would appear voluntarily before a grand jury in the belief that the jury would accept his explanation of self-defense and clear him of any charges.

title: Honolulu Offers Tax-Exempt Issue
description: The city and county of Honolulu is offering $60 million in tax-exempt general obligation bonds through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Abitibi Is Set to Raise Newsprint Price by $35
description: North America's largest producer of newsprint, Abitibi-Price Inc., has said it wants to increase the price for the low-grade paper by $35 a metric ton, to $685. But analysts said yesterday that soft demand and ample supply would allow newspaper publishers to shift to other suppliers, making it unlikely that Abitibi would succeed.

title: Hearns vs. Tyson?
description: Thomas Hearns, who has won championships in five weight classes, including the World Boxing Organization's supermiddleweight title, which he will defend against Michael Olajide on April 28 in Atlantic City, is dreaming of fighting as a heavyweight, against Mike Tyson.

title: Personal Health
description: Eating disorders, which afflict millions, threatening their health and sometimes their lives, are most successfully treated when detected in their early stages. Yet, experts say, neither families nor physicians are sufficiently alert to the early signs of serious eating problems.

title: Interim Systems Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Worthy Setting for the Javits Center
description: New York City's Board of Estimate has a chance to make a good thing better today by approving a plan to rejuvenate the area around the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. Four years after it opened, the Convention Center still sits in isolated splendor on Manhattan's West Side, surrounded by an uninviting mix of warehouses, parking lots, vacant land and commercial businesses, and a generous complement of prostitutes.

title: 49% Stake to Cost Fiat $104.8 Million
description: Fiat S.p.A., the Italian automobile giant, will pay $104.8 million for 49 percent of a new unit that will make and distribute Maserati cars, De Tomaso Industries said. Under the deal, Fiat will also assume $23.1 million in deferred severance pay obligations. The deal was announced in December, but no price had been set.

Airlines Ask U.S. to Require Buckling Up Babies in Flight
description: Seizing the initiative in a long debate over the safety of children on airplanes, the nation's airlines today asked for Federal regulations requiring that infants and toddlers be strapped into protective seats when they fly.

title: Heart-Valve Suits Hurt Pfizer Stock
description: Pfizer Inc.'s share price fell $4.50 yesterday, to $59.25, amid growing concern about the giant drug company's potential liability for deaths and injuries attributed to fractures in artificial heart valves marketed by its Shiley Inc. subsidiary.

title: Bush and Baker Press the Israelis To End Deadlock on Peace Plan
description: President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d suggested today that it was time for the Israeli Government to stop hesitating about putting its own peace plan into effect, and to make the necessary compromises to open negotiations with the Egyptians and Palestinians.

title: Harold Leland Goodwin, Author, 75

description: Teresa Bednar remembered people screaming, fire alarms clanging and flames flicking from the ceiling. She also recalled customers who looked as if they would rather have fried than flee.

Net income in 1988 included a recapitalization charge of $16.3 million.

title: Dispute in California May Derail Early Primary
description: The California Senate today approved a plan to make the state's Democratic Presidential primary one of the nation's earliest, but legislative leaders said concerns about how an earlier primary could affect state legislative races might ultimately kill the measure.

title: Channel 5 Phone Ads
description: WNYW, Channel 5 in New York, said yesterday that it would restrict commercials for 900-number telephone services, which offer callers either recorded messages or live conversation. The station said it will run the commercials only between midnight and 6 A.M. and will not run any spots with sexual themes. Representatives of other local television stations said they had restrictions on 900-number commercials. WABC, Channel 7, said it refused to run any.

description: b-After income of $491,000, or 32 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting.

title: Margaret Craske Is Dead at 97; Directed Met Opera Ballet School
description: Margaret Craske, a leading ballet teacher in England and the United States, died on Sunday at Grand Strand General Hospital in Myrtle Beach, S.C. She was 97 years old. A pupil of Enrico Cecchetti, the great Italian ballet pedagogue, Miss Craske danced for a short time with the Diaghilev Ballets Russes and toured with Ninette de Valois, founder of the Royal Ballet, in a small group that performed in English variety theaters during the 1920's. She had her own studio in London, where she was ballet mistress for the Sadler's Wells (now Royal) Ballet and conducted examinations for the Imperial Society of Teachers of Dancing. She left for New York when, at the suggestion of the choreographer Antony Tudor, American Ballet Theater invited her to become the company's ballet mistress and teacher in 1946.

title: CNBC to Chiat/Day
description: The Consumer News and Business Channel, or CNBC, has switched its advertising account from Lord Einstein O'Neill & Partners to Chiat/ Day/Mojo in New York. Lord Einstein had the account since June. Michael Eskridge, the president of CNBC, a joint venture of NBC and the Cablevision Systems Corporation of Woodbury, L.I., said CNBC wanted to work with a bigger operation. Lord Einstein handled just the creative portion of the account; Chiat/Day/ Mojo will do that plus media planning and buying. An industry official said the account would bill $8 million to $10 million.

description: Col. Justin Dintino, in his first week as State Police Superintendent, has announced measures to curb reported abuses by troopers in stopping motorists on New Jersey highways.

The year-ago fourth quarter included a $3.5 million net gain on the sale of certain leased assets. Full year 1989 results included $8.8 million in charges at the Terra International Inc. agribusiness unit related to the contamination of a product it formulated, and to the cleanup of a fire at a contract manufacturer's facility. Full year 1988 results included a $26.7 million gain on the sale of U.S. copper assets.

These positions are set forth with clocklike regularity in ''Square One,'' a futuristic fable that has attracted such gifted theater people as the actors Richard Thomas and Dianne Wiest, the director Jerry Zaks and the designer Tony Walton to the Second Stage.

title: Ex-Metro-North Police Chief Is Acquitted in Computer Case

description: The nation's airlines have begun a new round of special frequent-flier offers. But restrictions on when the free tickets earned can be used are much tighter than they were during the last major offers.

title: Book Fair
description: Rare, vintage and just plain old books by the thousands will be for sale this weekend at Public School 3 in Greenwich Village during the 11th annual Antiquarian Book Fair. Novels, science fiction, mysteries, biographies, art books and nonfiction of every description, as well as prints, postcards, comic books, baseball cards, autographs and almost anything else that has found its way onto a printed page, will be sold at the school by more than 70 dealers. Hours are 6 to 10 tonight, noon to 7 P.M. tomorrow, and noon to 5 P.M. on Sunday. Admission is $12 tonight and for the whole weekend; $5 tomorrow, and $3 on Sunday. P.S. 3 is at 490 Hudson Street, near Christopher Street. Information: 673-9535.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the postponement of a space shuttle launching, partly because of the commander's illness, included an erroneous comment from NASA about the rarity of such an occurrence. It was at least the second time - not the first - that a manned space flight had been postponed because of a health problem. Later developments are reported today on page A9.

Most of the layoffs will occur in the test and measurement group, the electronics company said. The group manufactures various products, including Tektronix's original product line, oscilloscopes. It typically accounts for more than half Tektronix's sales, but its volume has recently declined at a faster rate than the company's other lines of business.

Deliveries of the Jetstream 41 are scheduled to begin in February 1993 and will be completed by the end of that year. Deliveries of the Super 31 will begin this month and will be completed by the end of this year.

That leaves the league well short of where it needs to be, but at least the direction is progressive.

title: Piniella Eager to Put Pinstripes Behind
description: He is trying to make the best of it, but the days have seemed to pass like months for Lou Piniella. Some days, he visits relatives. Others, he spends the afternoon fishing. Mostly, he waits. It has been like this since the first week of February, when Piniella and his family arrived at their beach home in Reddington Shores, Fla., and waited for baseball to begin. But there has been only stillness.

title: A Lutanist And a Tenor Collaborate Sporadically
description: Before a concert in Maryland the other day, the British tenor Nigel Rogers and the American lutanist Paul O'Dette took a moment to guess at the number of works they had performed since they began touring together in 1980. ''It must be at least 500,'' Mr. Rogers estimated. Mr. O'Dette added that because circumstances dictated that they offer a different program at virtually every concert, they have prepared 120 works for their current tour.

title: Review/Recital;   Barenboim's Interpretation Of the 'Goldberg' Variations
description: Lots of pianists still play Bach's ''Goldberg'' Variations in this age of the Baroque harpsichord. So one had to wonder, Wednesday night at Avery Fisher Hall, about the degree of pontification with which Daniel Barenboim had freighted his interpretation of the score. But art can justify life's foibles, and Mr. Barenboim's ruminations about himself and Bach had their points of interest. The real news, however, was that he delivered a deeply personal statement of this masterpiece, one that owed interesting debts to the evolving performance tradition but that spoke eloquently with its own pianistic voice.

description: ''You can help us most of all,'' Vaclav Havel told Congress Wednesday, ''if you help the Soviet Union on its irreversible but immensely complicated road to democracy.'' The Czech President, who embodies his country's emergence from Soviet domination, called this remark paradoxical. Maybe, but it also expresses a profound truth and suggests a wise course of action for the West.

title: Carnation Shifts Shops, Plans Interpublic Moves

Carnation, a subsidiary of Nestle S.A., has moved that portion of the account to M.E.D. Communications, a health-care ad agency based in Woodbridge, N.J. (M.E.D. is part of a new holding company, the Woodbridge Group, which also owns CHC Advertising and Aspen Communications.)
