description: After a regularly scheduled board meeting, CS First Boston Inc. issued a statement to employees yesterday offering a reassuring picture of the investment bank's financial well-being.

title: Aydin Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. Defends Proposed Pact With Exxon Over Oil Spill
description: Stung by objections to a proposed settlement of criminal charges against the Exxon Corporation in the Alaska oil spill, the Justice Department today defended itself against charges by state officials that the deal would let the company avoid paying the full cleanup costs.

title: DOUBTS ON SUPPLY SPUR PREDICTIONS OF HIGH OIL PRICES
description: New doubts about the world's ability to pump enough oil to keep pace with growing demand have convinced many analysts that oil prices will rise much more rapidly than previously expected, by about 50 percent within five years.

title: Ortega Says He Won't Arm Rebels In El Salvador if He Is Re-elected
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra said today that if he was re-elected, his Government would not provide leftist guerrillas in El Salvador with arms to fight a Salvadoran Government that he called ''legitimate.''

title: Britain's 5th-Warmest Winter
description: Daffodils are blooming and fruit trees are budding as Britain enjoys the warmest February since the American Revolution and the fifth-warmest winter since records began in 1659. Today's high of 65 degrees Fahrenheit tied a record for the date, and the coldest temperature all winter was 37 degrees on New Year's Day. The average temperature in central England this month has been 45 degrees, 7 degrees warmer than normal and the warmest February since 1779, when the average was 46 degrees.

title: McEnroe Loses Appeal
description: An appeal by John McEnroe of his disqualification in the fourth round of the Australian Open with accompanying fines of $6,500 last month was rejected yesterday by the International Tennis Federation in London.

title: Transcapital Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a pre-tax charge on securities of $6 million in the quarter and year primarily caused by valuation adjustments on high-yield corporate bonds; a pre-tax writeoff of $14.3 million in the year relating to TransOhio's termination of its proposed acquisition of Amerifirst Bank of Miami, Fla., and $14.1 million in net losses in the year related to the company's mortgage banking subsidiary, Ameristar Financial Corp. c-Net income Transcapital Financial Corp. is a majority owned subsidiary of American Capital Corp.

title: Health Chief Asks Athletes to Shun Tobacco Company 'Blood Money'
description: The Secretary of Health and Human Services today urged athletes and sports organizations to turn aside the ''blood money'' of tobacco company sponsorships.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping;   With Faulty Merchandise
description: The delivery men arrive at the end of the business day, and an hour or two later, after they have hauled the heavy boxes into the house and begun installing your new washing machine or bolting together your new wall unit, a defect becomes obvious: a dent, a broken piece of trim, a missing shelf, or something else that is not right with a major purchase.

title: Harsco Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included after-tax charges of $19.7 million in the latest quarter and $53.8 million for the year to cover expected losses resulting from current cost-to- complete estimates on contracts for the defense group. c-Included after-tax charges of $24.4 million in the quarter and $29.4 million in the year to cover future losses resulting from current cost-to-complete estimates on contracts for the defense group, and after-tax charges of $2.2 million in the quarter and $3.8 million in the year to cover environmental considerations.

title: Japanese Buy Farm Team
description: The Suntory International Corporation, an American subsidiary of Suntory Ltd., has bought the minor league Birmingham Barons baseball team, a spokesman for the Japanese brewery said today.

title: Sales Drop In Vehicles Is Reported
description: Sales of domestically produced cars fell 11.5 percent in mid-February, as a strengthening of the automotive market early in the month seemed to fade.

title: Mortgage Rates Mixed
description: Fixed-rate home mortgages are averaging 10.31 percent, up from 10.10 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.44 percent this week, down from 8.48 percent the week before.

title: Perrier Rival Talks of 'Serendipity'
description: At Evian Waters of France Inc., some executives are uncomfortable with the word ''opportunity.'' It sounds, well, opportunistic when discussing the troubles at Perrier, the rival French water company that earlier this month recalled millions of its bottles of sparkling water after a few were found to contain traces of the chemical benzene.

title: Yankee Energy System reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Yankee Energy was created July 1, 1989, as a spinoff from Northeast Utilities. Prior to July 1989, operating results are as a division of Connecticut Light and Power Co., a Northeast Utilities subsidiary.

title: Simmons Forms Slate For Lockheed's Board
description: Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas financier, moved forward today with his planned proxy fight for control of the board of the Lockheed Corporation by naming his slate of proposed directors. The slate includes John G. Tower, the former United States Senator from Texas, and Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr., the retired admiral who is also a director of Mr. Simmons's chemical company, NL Industries.

title: Long Island Lighting reports earnings for 12mo Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $1,345,110,000 from an adjustment in accounting. Results reflected previously reported charges associated with a settlement with New York State concerning the Shoreham nuclear power station and a class settlement in the Rico litigation. The loss also resulted from the decision to discontinue the accrual of the non-cash allowance for funds used during Shoreham's construction. The effect of the three items is about $382 million, or $3.43 a share. Accounting adjustment loss reflected non-cash writedown of certain costs disallowed by the State Public Service Commission.

title: 'Sweeney Todd' to Close
description: ''Sweeney Todd,'' the York Theater production of Stephen Sondheim's 1979 musical with book by Hugh Wheeler, will close after the matinee on Sunday at the Circle in the Square Theater, 254 West 50th Street. The musical, directed by Susan H. Schulman and co-starring Bob Gunton and Beth Fowler, will have run for 189 regular performances and 46 previews.

title: Indoor Track Ends a Sluggish Season Strongly
description: The North American indoor track and field season, which lumbered along at an innocuous pace for two months, ended tonight with a flurry of outstanding performances in the final event of the Grand Prix circuit, the U.S.A./Mobil championships.

title: Explosive Fabricators Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Intelligent Systems Masters L.P.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said year-ago fourth quarter figures included a loss of $1,944,000 from discontinued operations and a gain of $23,456,000, oe $2.46 a share, from sale of discontinued operations. The year-ago full-year figures included net from discontinued operations of $975,000, or 10 cents a share, and the $23,456,000 gain from sale of discontinued operations. The company also said net income figures reflect net income allocable to limited partners. Latest quarter results included additional inventory reserves of about $2 million following sales of product lines. Latest full year figures included the $2 million in additional inventory reserves and a gain of $4,939,000 from the sales of product lines. Year-ago fourth quarter and year results also included a charge of $1,005,000 from writedown of assets not sold with discontinued operations.

title: Angeion Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Behind That Big Door
description: It is a heavy, polished, brown-stained wooden door with a shiny chrome handle. I've seen better looking doors, some with brass knockers or small rose-colored windows or carvings of gargoyles, but for an office door, this would have to go under the heading of handsome, or at least serviceable.

title: Baseball Bargainers Will Continue Talking
description: Baseball's labor negotiators met for about three hours yesterday and made minute progress. The talks proceeded well enough to prompt the sides to meet today, the first Saturday session in the three months of negotiations. But neither their words nor their schedule signaled that a settlement was in sight.

title: Modern Controls Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Aide to Cuomo Begins Talks With Brooklyn's New Bishop
description: The Roman Catholic Bishop-designate of Brooklyn and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo communicated through aides today in what both sides hope will be a rapprochement.

title: D.&B. Accord Set on Lawsuits
description: A Federal judge in Cincinnati yesterday approved an $18 million settlement of lawsuits against the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation by customers who said they had been overcharged for credit reports.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost;   Reading Cognac Labels
description: Cognac, the brandy made in the Charentes region in western France, is often sold with confusing names and initials on the label; the French Government regulates some but not all of them. Almost all bottled Cognacs are blended from barrels of Cognac made in different years, and the letters on a label indicate the age of the youngest Cognac allowed in the blend. Some of the very best Cognacs, which are considerably older than that minimum, often do not bear these symbols. Bottles labeled Grande Champagne or Fine Champagne have nothing to do with bubbly Champagne but mean that at least 50 percent of the grapes were grown in the Grande Champagne zone of the Cognac district. Here are the markings the French Government regulates. $ Grade Minimum Age In Blend Usual Age Range V.S. (formerly three-star) 2 1/2 years 3 to 7 years V.S.O.P. 4 1/2 years 7 to 12 years Napoleon, X.O. 6 1/2 years 15 to 50 years

title: Giant Group Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Uslico Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
David Greenstone, 52, U. of Chicago Professor
description: J. David Greenstone, a professor of political science at the University of Chicago and an author, died of cancer on Wednesday at Bernard Mitchell Hosiptal in Chicago. He was 52 years old and lived in Chicago.

title: Investment Banker Proposed as Actuary
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins and the chairman of the Municipal Labor Committee, Stanley Hill, yesterday recommended Robert C. North Jr. to become chief actuary of the New York City pension systems, one of the largest pools of retirement funds in the country.

title: Chempower Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $935,000, or 17 cents a share, attributable to an accounting adjustment relating to a multi-year contract in progress.

title: KEY RATES
Tentative Approval for Church-Run AIDS Homes
description: The New York State Public Health Council tentatively approved plans yesterday for two new publicly financed AIDS nursing homes run by the Roman Catholic church, on the condition that the patients receive counseling on all types of AIDS prevention.

title: Colleges Could Boost School Science Programs;   Books Before Computers
description: To the Editor:

title: Mesa Medical Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Board of Elections Seeks Fines in Races For School Boards
description: Acting unusually aggressively, the New York City Board of Elections began civil action yesterday against 109 community school board candidates and 19 candidate committees for failing to file financial reports after school board elections last May.

title: Canron Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $5,831,000 and an extraordinary charge mainly from the sale of discontinued operations of $9,436,000. c-Net income and included a loss from discontinued operations of $2,790,000 and an extraordinary credit of $5,309,000, or 58 cents a share, mainly from the sale of land. The company said increased sales are due to the inclusion of the results of the Great West Steel division of GWIL Industries for the full year. The division was acquired in May 1988. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Inside
description: U.S. Defends Exxon Talks

title: Flames' MacInnis Found Not Guilty
description: Al MacInnis, the Calgary Flames defenseman who was voted the most valuable player of the Stanley Cup playoffs last spring, was found not guilty of assault today. He had been tried on charges stemming from a brawl outside a Calgary bar last summer.

title: Knicks Baffled By Heat
description: In the minutes that followed the game, Stu Jackson almost seemed to be battling himself. He stood in the hallway outside the Knicks' dressing room, uncertain whether to dismiss the night as an occupational hazard or to allow his anger to show.

title: Moore Products Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Patents;   A New Surgical Glove To Block Infection
description: A heart surgeon at Pennsylvania State University's College of Medicine has invented a surgical glove that he said reduces the chance of being exposed to blood contaminated by the viruses that cause AIDS and hepatitis.

title: U.S. Issues End Volatile Day Unchanged
description: Treasury securities prices were essentially unchanged yesterday, but the closing quotes masked volatile price moves here and overseas. One Treasury securities dealer likened the day's action to ''a football being kicked between players in Japan and West Germany with us as spectators.''

title: A Deodorant Aimed at the Fitness Set
description: Has deodorant succumbed to a high-tech breakthrough? The makers of a new antiperspirant-deodorant aimed at the physically fit want to outpace the pack with a time-release formula that is activated by perspiration.

title: Grand Met in Talks On Breweries' Sale
description: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the British food, liquor and retailing giant, confirmed it was negotiating to sell its brewing operations to Elders IXL Ltd. of Australia. A Grand Met spokesman, Bill Bullard, said Grand Met was also negotiating with another potential buyer, whom he refused to identify.

title: Interspec Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $182,000, or 3 cents a share for the quarter and $559,000, or 9 cents a share for the year. c-Net income d-Included an extraordinary charge of $237,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $294,000, or 5 cents a share for the year.

title: Former Justice Minister Acquitted in Geneva
description: A former Swiss Justice Minister was acquitted today of charges of divulging official secrets in a case involving the suspected laundering of profits from the drug trade.

title: Tarkanian Dispute With N.C.A.A.
description: Jerry Tarkanian, the Nevada-Las Vegas basketball coach, has approved an agreement that would end a 13-year attempt by the National Collegiate Athletic Association to suspend him from coaching, Tarkanian's son said yesterday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BEN H. BAGDIKIAN - an exemplar to a generation of journalists, a leading news-media critic and a professor of journalism at the University of California at Berkeley - is retiring from teaching this spring.

title: Mikolaj W. Balicki, Hospital Founder, 97
description: Mikolaj W. Balicki, a former judge in Poland and a founder of a childrens' hospital in Cracow, died of heart failure on Wednesday at his daughter's home in Montclair, N.J. He was 97 years old.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Colgate-Palmolive Co., the consumer products company, said 6.3 million shares, or 96 percent of the outstanding shares of common stock, had been tendered in its $14-a-share offer for Vipont Pharmaceutical Inc., Fort Collins, Colo., a health care company.

title: No Headline
description: In an increasingly bitter race for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination in Texas, State Treasurer Ann Richards today accused one of her opponents of planting a newspaper story that asserts she used an ethnic slur in a speech 14 years ago.

title: Democrats' Idea on Tax
description: Democratic leaders said today that Congress might consider trying to cut income taxes on ''upper-middle-class'' families but raising taxes on the richest Americans.

title: Interpoint Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income and after a gain of $169,700 from a cumulative effect on prior period of an accounting change for income taxes. Year-ago results are restated to reflect the acquisition of Micra Corp. in July 1989, on a pooling-of-interest basis.

title: Johnnie Ray in a Coma
description: Johnnie Ray, the 1950's singer known for such hits as ''Somebody Stole My Gal'' and ''Just Walkin' in the Rain,'' was in a coma today as a result of liver failure. Mr. Ray, 63 years old, is not expected to survive, according to a statement issued by Alan Eichler Associates, a public relations firm. Mr. Ray has spent the last week at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, where today his condition was described as grave.

title: A Necessary Cold War?
description: Unraveling the cold war is causing enormous concern and unease. The big headaches confronting Europe would have been settled long ago if World War II hopes had been fulfilled for maintaining at least friendly East-West relations, if not an actual alliance.

title: War or Peace in Cambodia?
description: The New York Times's Steven Erlanger reports that several thousand Vietnamese troops appear to have secretly re-entered Cambodia last fall to help stiffen military resistance to the Khmer Rouge. That news is sure to complicate the task of the Southeast Asian peace conference opening Monday in Jakarta, Indonesia. Yet the threat of widened war could also concentrate the diplomats' minds, not only at Jakarta but also in parallel talks among the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council.

title: Varco International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dinkins Aides Win Delay on Homeless Bill
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins, long a strong advocate for the homeless and a critic of New York City's efforts to house them, has found his new administration forced to adopt an approach to the issue that markedly tempers his past remarks as Manhattan Borough President and a mayoral candidate.

title: Laws Banning Sale of Car Rental Insurance Are Questioned
description: Now that laws to prevent car rental companies from selling separate collision insurance coverage are in place in New York and Illinois, other states are considering similar bans. But questions are being raised about how well the laws serve the consumer.

title: National Quick Lube Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: NCF Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest quarter's results were due to a high level of non-earnings assets and losses related to certain real estate investments.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''An athlete or sports figure should not allow his or her good name, hard-earned image or integrity to be exploited by the tobacco industry to push a product that when used as intended causes death. This blood money should not be used to foster a misleading impression that smoking is compatible with good health.'' - Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, Secretary of Health and Human Services. [12:1.]

title: To Ortega: Throw the Election
description: It isn't going to happen. But the smartest thing President Daniel Ortega of Nicaragua could do for his country in the short run (and for himself in the long run) would be to do the unthinkable: throw tomorrow's presidential election to his principal opponent, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro.

title: Interface reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Spy Planes Begin Flight From Legend to Museum
description: After more than 25 years of stratospheric snooping, the world's fastest and highest-flying planes have begun making their final flights this week -to museums across the country.

title: Still Invisible, and Dying, in Harlem
description: LEAD: In his acclaimed novel ''The Invisible Man,'' Ralph Ellison depicted a category of human beings whose suffering was so thoroughly ignored that they, and it, might as well not have existed. Thirty-eight years later, these people remain very much with us - and still very much unseen.

title: Chairman Quits At Ferranti
description: Ferranti International P.L.C., the troubled British military contractor, said today that Sir Derek Alun-Jones had resigned as chairman.

title: Upheaval in the East: Hungary;   Budapest Broaching a Role in NATO
description: The Hungarian Foreign Minister said today that a move by his country to join NATO's political councils would be a logical step toward a ''united democratic Europe.''

title: Child Safety Seats: Debate on Recalls
description: Even as airline officials call for the mandatory use of child safety seats on planes, Federal regulators are being criticized for not doing enough to let passengers know about seats that may cause problems.

title: General Delivery: Mail Call for the Homeless
description: ''General delivery'' in Manhattan once meant mail call for sailors, city newcomers, and far-flung tourists. Now it is more often the address of last resort - a lifeline not to the homesick but to the homeless.

title: Occupational-Urgent Care Health Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bush Must Stop Dithering on Global Warming
description: To the Editor:

title: Area Near Javits Center Is Rezoned
description: The New York City Board of Estimate yesterday approved new zoning and new buildings intended to revitalize the area surrounding the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center on the West Side.

title: CDI Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Corrections Corrections Corrections
description: A listing with the Personal Health column on Thursday, about sources of help for eating disorders, misstated addresses or telephone numbers for three organizations. The American Anorexia/Bulimia Association is at 418 East 76th Street, New York, N.Y. 10021; (212) 734-1114. The National Anorexic Aid Society's number is (614) 436-1112. The number for the National Association of Anorexia Nervosa and Associated Disorders is (708) 831-3438.

title: D.&H. Extension To March 23 Set
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission extended an order allowing three regional railroads to continue operating until March 23 on the Delaware & Hudson Railway tracks. The order, which was initially scheduled to expire today, allows the New York, Susquehanna & Western Railway, the Lackawanna Valley Railroad and the North Shore Railroad to use the tracks. The D.& H. line runs from Montreal to Washington and from Albany to Buffalo.

title: Adele Rosenfeld Meyer, Businesswoman, 92
description: Adele Rosenfeld Meyer, who was active in New York civic affairs and helped run a Manhattan poultry business, died Thursday at a nursing home in Portland, Ore. She was 92 years old and had lived in Portland since 1977.

title: Corrections Corrections Corrections
description: A subheading yesterday on an article about counseling of AIDS patients in New York referred incorrectly to the state's position on care in hospitals and nursing homes run by the Roman Catholic Church. While the church opposes counseling AIDS patients on a number of matters, like sex safety practices, the state has not proposed forcing church-run institutions to counsel patients to ignore church doctrine. Later developments are reported today on page 29.

title: Frank Moore Jr., Surgeon, 75
description: Dr. Frank Moore Jr., a retired surgeon, died of lung cancer on Wednesday at Huntington (L.I.) Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Huntington.

title: Fidelity Medical Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Election Means Little in Contra Camp
description: While this country prepares for elections, rebels in the steamy forests here are getting ready for war.

title: Strife Erupts in Kenya After Rite for Official
description: Anti-Government riots erupted in two Kenyan cities today after the funeral of a popular Cabinet minister who demonstrators say was slain.

title: Your Money;   States Increase Tax Vigilance
description: Many taxpayers will find state tax collectors newly vigilant this year. States are hungry for revenues, and with ever-improving computer and investigatory skills they are making aggressive efforts to step up tax collections.

title: Homestake Mining Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $18,505,000, or 19 cents a share for the quarter and $35,780,000, or 37 cents a share for the year. c-Included income of $448,000 for the quarter and a loss of $1,807,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations, and the year also included an extraordinary credit from cumulative effect of change in accounting of $3,125,000, or 3 cents a share.

title: BUSH PICKS A CHIEF TO LEND NEW LIFE TO RIGHTS PANEL
description: President Bush selected Arthur A. Fletcher today as chairman of the troubled Civil Rights Commission, a move that civil rights leaders lauded as a signal that the Bush Administration was taking the commission more seriously than the Reagan Administration did.

title: Review/Music;   Incomplete Works Left By Mahler and Schubert
description: Nature is a particularly brutal editor of man's aspirations. When creative artists think long, higher forces can rise up and cut them short.

title: Farah Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The year-ago quarter included the operations of the company's former subsidiary, Generra Sportswear Co., which was sold in the third quarter of 1989.

title: Ronald B. Monroe, Administrator, 50
description: Ronald B. Monroe, an administrator with the Conservation Company, a public-policy consulting concern, and Seedco, a community development and human services organization, died of AIDS on Wednesday at University Hospital. He was 50 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Microamerica Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Wyman-Gordon reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and the year included an extraordinary credit of $8,530,000, or 48 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The company said the most significant item offsetting its positive 1989 sales performance was a $16.9 million LIFO inventory charge. The charge reflected higher levels of inventory and higher raw material prices.

title: Las Vegas Discount Golf reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Japan Talks Fail to Gain
description: Talks between the United States and Japan on reducing the $49 billion trade imbalance between the two countries ended today with few signs of progress and ample evidence of mutual frustration.

title: Donatell Hired by Jets
description: The Jets continued their tilt toward young coaches with no pro experience yesterday when they signed Ed Donatell, a 33-year-old defensive backs coach from California State-Fullerton.

title: Nordson Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
Review/Music;   Opera Chief In Brooklyn Leaves Post
description: Matthew Epstein, the nationally known opera consultant and artistic director of the Brooklyn Academy of Music's opera activities since 1987, has resigned his Brooklyn post.

title: Girl in Custody Case Emerges in New Zealand
description: Hilary Foretich, the 7-year-old girl at the center of the nation's most highly publicized child custody suit, surfaced in New Zealand today after spending 30 months in hiding with her grandparents.

title: Sides Confer in Prego Case Amid Signs of a Settlement
description: The case of Dr. Veronica Prego, who contends she contracted AIDS from a contaminated syringe needle in a Brooklyn hospital, was interrupted yesterday afternoon as the opposing sides conferred in the judge's chambers for two hours amid signs that a settlement would soon be announced.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY, 24, 1990
description: The Economy

title: Drexel Asserts Bonuses Came to $260 Million
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. said yesterday that it paid its executives $260 million in cash and stock bonuses in the two months before the firm's parent filed for bankruptcy protection.

title: Donald Hutter, 57; Editor, Writer and Publishing Official
description: Donald S. Hutter, a book editor and publisher for more than 30 years who had his own imprint at Henry Holt, died of cancer at Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital on Thursday. He was 57 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

title: Rooney May Return in Two Weeks
description: CBS News, faced with increasing criticism from journalists, viewers and its own staff, may shorten the three-month suspension of Andy Rooney, a commentator on ''60 Minutes.'' A spokesman for the division yesterday confirmed reports in several newspapers that Mr. Rooney had met Wednesday with David W. Burke, the president of CBS News.

title: D. Veola Lederer, 81, Ex-Boutique Manager
description: D. Veola Lederer, a former executive of a Manhattan leather boutique and a former museum vice president, died of a heart attack on Wednesday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., while spending the winter in Pompano Beach. She was 81 years old and lived in Stockbridge. Mass. Mrs. Lederer was the widow of Ludwig G. Lederer. In World War II, while her husband taught celestial navigation to pilots in Mississippi, she managed his Fifth Avenue leather goods store, Lederer de Paris. The store was later sold. Mr. Lederer died in 1960.

title: Dr. Edgar H. Bates, 84, Ex-Professor of Surgery
description: Dr. Edgar H. Bates, a retired professor of surgery at the New York University Medical School, died of a stroke on Feb. 14 at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 84 years old and lived in Douglaston, Queens.

title: 69 Hurt as Protesters Clash With Police at Ball in Vienna
description: Hundreds of demonstrators clashed with the police outside the Vienna State Opera on Thursday night as socialites waltzed inside, and the authorities said today that at least 69 people were wounded.

title: Panel to Examine Ariane Rocket Failure
description: The president of a European space consortium said today that a panel of experts would be named to determine why an Ariane rocket exploded shortly after takeoff and to reassure customers.

title: Piedmont Natural Gas reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
U.S. Will Appeal Ruling on Flag Burning
description: As expected, the Justice Department said today that it would ask the Supreme Court to review a Federal district judge's finding on Wednesday that a law to ban the burning of the American flag is unconstitutional.

title: Sheriff to Keep Using Guard Armory as Jail
description: After a weeklong standoff with the state, the county sheriff here won permission today to maintain a makeshift jail at a National Guard armory for at least two more weeks.

title: Anger in Congress Over Aquino's Snub
description: President Corazon C. Aquino's refusal to meet with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney during his visit to the Philippines this week has stirred anger among Democrats and Republicans in Congress and accelerated proposals for moving American forces from that country to other locations in the Pacific region.

title: Aleppo Journal;   A Small Hotel, Its Memories Fading
description: There is a hotel here called Baron's, where emperors and adventurers, warriors and spies once tarried in the Orient's embrace.

title: Willcox & Gibbs Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest periods' results included those for Clark Consolidated Industries, an electrical distributor, acquired in January 1989, and also the results of Data Net and Dataspan, acquired in November 1988. The sales included in 1989 for these acquisitions were $95 million.

title: Colleges Could Boost School Science Programs
description: To the Editor:

title: United Merchants & Manufacurers Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary gains on extinguishment of debt of $95,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $167,000, or 2 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-After extraordinary gains on extinguishment of debt of $1,974,000, or 21 cents a share, for the quarter and $2,193,000, or 24 cents a share, for the 6 months. d-Net income The latest quarter's loss was after non-recurring losses from the termination or restructuring of certain operations and the sale of divisions of $57,828,000, of which $41,325,000 is the result of the writeoff of goodwill and other non-cash charges. Latest 6 months' loss included non- recurring losses of $59,570,000, including the writeoff of goodwill and other non-cash charges of $43,067,000, from the termination or restructuring of certain operations and the sale of divisions. The year-ago quarter's loss included loss on sale of divisions of $674,000 and the 6 months' net income included gain on sale of divisions of $40,756,000.

title: News Summary
description: International 3-8

title: Ex-Trustee Buys College At Bankruptcy Auction
description: In what is thought to mark the first time that an entire educational campus was put on the auction block because of bankruptcy, Bishop College, once the largest black college in the Western United States, was sold this morning after years of scandal and financial distress.

title: Upheaval in the East;   LITHUANIANS SEEK TO REMOVE K.G.B.
description: Lithuanian Communist Party officials have quietly begun talks with the K.G.B. intended to phase out the activities of Moscow's security police in this Baltic republic, officials here say.

title: Riedel Environmental Tech reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-After income of $188,000, or 6 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Huffy Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
400,000 Kashmiri Protesters Urge Independence
description: Hundreds of thousands of demonstrators marched through the streets of Srinagar today to press demands for independence for the predominantly Muslim border region. It was the largest such demonstration in decades.

title: Heck's Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 25
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $31,133,000 for the quarter and $41,500,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $12,176,000 and $32,377,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Gigante's Kin Give Up Action On Mental State
description: Relatives of Vincent (the Chin) Gigante, the reputed Mafia leader, have dropped a yearlong legal effort to have him declared mentally incompetent by a New York State judge.

title: G.E. Is Seeking Deal With Aeroflot
description: The General Electric Company entertained a delegation of Soviet aviation officials in hopes of getting multimillion-dollar contracts to supply jet engines to the Soviet airline Aeroflot.

title: Review/Pop;   A Little Hate Music, Please
description: When Andrew Dice Clay called himself ''the most vulgar, vicious comic ever to walk the face of the earth,'' as he did on stage Thursday night at Madison Square Garden, he left out two other adjectives: juvenile and calculating. Mr. Clay has devised a public persona - call it Everylout - that carries male high-school humor, bawdy and bullying, to the world outside the locker room. In the process, and probably not inadvertently, it exploits the tensions that are arising as white heterosexual males find that the days of unquestioned dominance are over.

title: ERC Environmental reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said share earnings in 1988 are pro forma, reflecting adjustments for the sale of 1.6 million common shares under the company's initial public offering of Dec. 15, 1988, the use of $10 million of the net proceeds of that offering to repay indebtedness to ERC International, as well as the dilutive effect of the assumed conversion of the $5 million principal amount of long-term convertible subordinated notes issued in a private placement.

title: Corrections Corrections Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about William W. Bartley 3d, a research fellow and former professor, misidentified a survivor, Elvina Bartley. She is his mother, not his wife.

title: Westchester Official Will Keep His Job
description: County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke said yesterday that Anthony M. Mosca would keep his job as Westchester County Police Commissioner although Mr. Mosca had improperly intervened in a drug case because he knew the defendant's family.

description: About half a million people die of heart attacks every year in the United States. But about 40 percent of them survive the initial attack only to die from subsequent complications that cannot be treated quickly enough.

description: The relationship between cause and effect can be a strange one. What if two Spanish dancers named Mariano and Dolores had not performed in Copenhagen in 1840? The world would have been bereft of a sparkling, lighthearted production presented by the Cleveland Ballet that grew out of that visit.

title: 'Rumors' to Close Today
description: ''Rumors,'' a comedy by Neil Simon, will close after this evening's performance at the Barrymore Theater, 243 West 47th Street. The play, directed by Gene Saks, will have run for 531 regular performances and 12 previews.

title: Rangers Alone at Top of Division
description: The Rangers, a team with its own nasty habit, tonight ran into and eventually over a team with a worse one. The Rangers can't hold an early lead, but the Capitals can't hold a late one, and when you can't do that, it's almost a sure thing that you can't win.

title: Review/Music;   Lutoslawski Is Presented By Mutter
description: On paper, there is a vague Central European coherence to Zubin Mehta's New York Philharmonic subscription program this week at Avery Fisher Hall. In practice, that breaks down, and the program becomes a showcase for the West German violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter.

title: Viva Costa Rica's Accessible Democracy!
description: During this stay there occurred a most important patriotic holiday, which was honored by an immense parade in a historic town near the capital, San Jose. President Oscar Arias Sanchez led the celebrants through unbelievably crowded streets, where I too was a spectator. As President Arias and the other dignitaries passed, I crossed the barrier and joined the parade as a photographer.

title: Hostage's Sister Again Tours Mideast
description: As her brother approaches the fifth anniversary of his kidnapping in Beirut, Peggy Say has embarked on her fourth tour of this troubled region to keep people from forgetting about him and the other foreigners still held in Lebanon.

title: C. Rodgers Burgin, Retired Banker, 90
description: C. Rodgers Burgin, a retired banker, died of pneumonia Thursday at Milton Hospital in Massachusetts. He was 90 years old and lived in Milton.

title: OMI Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $5,502,000 from an adjustment in accounting. The latest periods included gains from vessel sales of $11,241,000 for the quarter and $19,447,000 for the year. Year-ago fourth quarter and year figures included a gain of $12,812,000 from the sale of a 51 percent interest in a foreign subsidiary. Year-ago full year figures also included income of $2,859,000 from receipt of pension reversion funds and a gain of $7,467,000 from insurance proceeds.

title: Once an Epic and Still One - Almost
description: Some classic films have appeared on video in the past year, ranging from an unlikely, large-scale prospect such as LAWRENCE OF ARABIA (RCA/Columbia, $29.95) to THE WIZARD OF OZ (MGM/UA, $24.95), already so familiar from television that a video version scarcely seems to make a difference. But the classic least likely to survive the transition is GONE WITH THE WIND (MGM/UA, $89.95; two cassettes). When it was shown at Radio City Music Hall last year, it offered dramatic evidence of the difference between watching a version chopped up for television (the only way many people have seen this epic), and the quaint experience of viewing it on a vast screen, along with an audience that laughs, cries and all but recites ''I'll never be hungry again!'' on cue.

title: Grocers' Spray Poses No Major Risk, Study Says
description: After tracing a major outbreak of Legionnaires' disease to a supermarket's vegetable-spraying machine, the Federal Centers for Disease Control have concluded that ''misting machines'' and home humidifiers do not appear to pose widespread risks to public health.

title: To Drink or Not? Temperance on View
description: The temperance movement and the creative expression of its detractors and advocates is the subject of an exhibition on view through April 28 at the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center, 111 Amsterdam Avenue, at 65th Street.

title: Captain, Cleared of Spying, Leaves Air Force Honorably
description: A United States Air Force captain who was the subject of a spy investigation was honorably discharged on Friday and the investigation was closed, the Air Force said.

title: Give Shoppers the Right Voting Product and They'll Buy It
description: To the Editor:

title: Jersey Places Ban on Bass
description: A spokesman for the Fish and Wildlife Service said that the agency would impose a ban on the harvesting of striped bass in New Jersey's coastal waters beginning Thursday.

title: Question Of the Week;   Does Tyson Deserve An Immediate Rematch?
description: In boxing history, an upset victory in a world title fight has traditionally brought an automatic rematch. This fight will be demanded by the public, command the biggest payday for the new champion, and create the news media hype.

title:
GARDENING;

Improving the Odds for Shade Trees
description: LEAD: MANY maples are being attacked by verticillium wilt. Pin oaks in some areas are being disfigured by severe infestations of a mite-induced twig gall. London planes are succumbing to anthracnose, a disease to which they were once considered resistant. Add these problems to the loss of the American chestnut and the

title: A STORY OF LOVE OR A TALE OF DECEIT?
description: The outcome of the trial, for or against, George Gardner is not the issue of my distaste for the story by David Margolick. It is the invasion, even in death, of the privacy of a very private person.

title: Four Northern Towns Seek More Help From State Police
description: THE growth in population has brought many new challenges to northern Westchester in recent years, among them concern about maintaining adequate police protection in some towns.

title: Spain Extends Guarantees to Jews and Protestants
description: The Government has signed an accord that officially places the Jewish and Protestant faiths on par with Roman Catholicism.

title: 1990 Vote Will Test Power Of G.O.P. in the Sun Belt
description: The 1990 election campaign, which has so far generated little excitement despite a number of races with considerable significance, is approaching its first major event, the March 13 primaries in Texas.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Brunch;   Views and Victoriana, Not to Mention Food
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in the Connecticut, Long Island, New Jersey and Westchester Sunday regional sections of The New York Times. Ratings at the end of each item - satisfactory, good, very good, excellent and extraordinary - are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current.

title: Strickland Quick
description: In his first game as a San Antonio Spur, the former Knick Rod Strickland was a bit out of sync with his new teammates Friday night, but not so much that the Minnesota Timberwolves could notice.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Campus Life: Washington U.;   Professors to Vote On Plan to Close A Department
description: Nearly a year after Washington University announced that it would close its sociology department, debate over the the move still divides faculty members, who are to vote on Friday on a resolution in support of the department.

title: Malcolm Forbes, Publisher, Dies at 70
description: Malcolm Forbes, chairman and editor in chief of Forbes magazine and one of the country's most flamboyant multimillionaires whose enthusiastic pursuits included yachting, motorcycling and ballooning, died yesterday of a heart attack in his sleep at his home in Far Hills, N.J. He was 70 years old.

title: Question Of the Week;   Does Tyson Deserve An Immediate Rematch?
description: Your question regarding a Tyson rematch was a bit ambiguous. Are you referring to a rematch with Robin Givens, Mitch Green, Barbara Walters, Don King or Buster Douglas?

description: Plymouth, Conn. $260,000

description: ILLUSION, NOT MIME

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS/BIOGRAPHY
description: NIJINSKY

title: Pat LaFontaine, All-American Boy in Mostly Canadian Sport
description: ''HEY bud, that will be $5,'' said the bouncer at the Whispers Nightclub in the Smithtown Sheraton, grabbing the arm of a dark-haired boyish-looking man who had just walked past him.

title: ARROGANCE IN THE NAME OF LIFTOFF?
description: Television is not as simple as it looks. Not by a long shot. There are, for instance, two very different ways of approaching ''Challenger,'' the three-hour made-for-TV movie on ABC this evening at 8. From one perspec tive, it can be seen - thanks largely to a solid cast and Glenn Jordan's carefully measured direction - as a shrewdly constructed film that manages to draw inspiration, prime time's equivalent of mother's milk, from tragedy: the horrifying explosion of the space shuttle Challenger on Jan. 28, 1986, and the deaths of its seven crew members.

title: ROBINSON'S LEGACY REACHES A FRONT OFFICE
description: One day soon, a player's agent is going to stare across the negotiating table at the new assistant general manager of the Red Sox and suggest with a nuance or a smirk: ''Huh, a woman. What do you know about baseball?''

title: As Co-ops Spread, Discrimination Concerns Grow
description: AS more and more rental buildings in Brooklyn and Queens are converted into cooperatives, New York City's Commission on Human Rights is gearing up to tackle one of the stickiest of housing discrimination issues - the broad powers of co-op boards to reject would-be buyers without explanation.

title: Katherine L. Meyer Is Married on L.I.
description: Katherine Lord Meyer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles G. Meyer Jr. of Centre Island, L.I., was married yesterday at her parents' home to Christopher James Merritt, a son of Mrs. Walter H. Merritt of Hudson, N.Y., and the late Mr. Merritt. The Rev. Guy P. Hawtin, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Tex-Mex Lights Up Great Neck
description: BLAZING pink neon signs herald Cesar's Cafe in Great Neck. Also stopping traffic are the giant cacti seemingly flourishing in the ice of winter outside this Tex Mex-Southwestern restaurant. (Only after two or three touch tests does it become apparent that they are not real.) Cesar's interior is a match for its outside flash and dash. Southwestern art and earthy pottery share the stage with big city neon and sparkle. This smashing decor is highlighted by an eye-popping extravaganza of light, clear Lucite and water bubbles, with Cesar's Cafe logo emblazoned in pink neon.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

Warm Memories of Colder Days
description: LEAD: ON the golf course next to our house I can see the children sledding. Right after the first good snow the fairways, sandtraps and the many mounds are dotted with gaily colored jackets and pompom hats. The squeals, shrieks and laughter drift on the wind down to the house. All my sledding was done on a concrete driveway.

title: Science Education Shines for Melville
description: LEAD: A HALF-DOZEN students at Ward Melville High School in Setauket hover around a contraption of wood chutes, cardboard, batteries and wires. With breathless concentration, they set off a mousetrap to catapult a golf ball, but the projectile misses its mark. ''False start,'' the teacher calls out. She tries to cross the room to another team vying to represent the school in the national Rube Goldberg Contest.

title: A Music School Finds Fertile Ground
description: LEAD: THIS city has proved fertile musical territory for the Hoff-Barthelson Music School in Scarsdale. Enrollment has soared at the Mount Vernon Music Academy, a year-old joint venture of Hoff-Barthelson and the First Presbyterian Church of Mount Vernon, where a new semester of classes has just begun.

title: UNITING LOW POWER AND EFFICIENCY
description: Paul MacCready is best known as the creator of the Gossamer Albatross, which flew across the English Channel under human power in 1979. It was followed by other flights of low-power, high-efficiency aircraft. The inventor even developed a flying dinosaur replica, one of many exploits that have inspired admiration for Dr. MacCready's innovations over the years.

title: History in Porcelain: How East Met West at the Dinner Table
description: LEAD: THE Chinese were shrewd merchandisers. Starting in 1557, when the Portuguese established a permanent settlement at Macao, the Chinese began creating export ware for shipment to the West. Their markets grew to include the British, Dutch, Danes, French and, after the Revolutionary War ended British trade restrictions, the Americans.

title: Barbara Dill Wed to Joseph Treaster

A 2,016-Unit Rental Project

title: Actress Teaches the Art of Commercials
description: LEAD: IN the 1960's, when most actors shunned television commercials, considering them a comedown from the legitimate stage, Joan See auditioned for an Oxydol detergent commercial and got the part.

title: BORN FREE, BUT EVERYWHERE IN ZOOS
description: LIGHTS OUT IN THE REPTILE HOUSE

title: 'King and I' Is Back Where It Began
description: ''THE KING AND I'' at the Shubert in New Haven is a celebratory occasion and offers a sober perspective on a familiar musical.

title: Conflicting Pressures Shape The Future of Brazil Indians
description: RETREATING from encroaching bulldozers and chainsaws, some 45 enclaves of Indians survive in the depths of Brazil's Amazon basin, shunning contact with the 20th century. ''We don't know what language they speak, what their culture is,'' said Sidnei Possuelo, an official of Funai, Brazil's Indian protection service. ''The Brazilian Amazon is one of the last places in the world where there are still uncontacted stone-age groups.''

title: The Nicaraguan Vote: Break With the Past?
description: As Nicaragua prepares for national elections that all sides hope will draw a clear line between the country's past and its future, Nicaraguans on all sides are counting on the elections to halt their country's long slide into civil strife and economic ruin. Article, page 14.

title: Amy Goldfarb and Donald Adler to Wed in June
description: Eleanor Shane of New York and Murray Goldfarb of Boca Raton, Fla., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Amy Joy Goldfarb and Donald Dana Adler, the son of Erna Adler of New Rochelle, N.Y., and the late Dr. David Adler.

title:
ART;

A Lifetime of Social Concern
description: LEAD: AT first the title ''Reuben Kadish: Works From 1930 to the Present'' seems a misnomer. The works look as if they come from way before 1930; indeed, the newest sculptures look as old as the hills. But a refreshing aspect of the 77-year-old Mr. Kadish's retrospective at the New Jersey State Museum here, through April 15, is that his most recent work, sculpture from the 1980's, is the most riveting.

title: Christine Rodeno to Wed in Summer
description: August wedding plans for Christine Isabelle Rodeno and Lloyd Michael Bloom, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Bloom of New York, have been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Albert Rodeno of Paris.

title: Review/Dance;   'In and Out of the Agora'
description: Wisps of choreographic ideas drifted through ''Dances in and Out of the Agora,'' the program Silvia Marinari, Christine Coppola and Almalyn Largey offered on Monday night at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center. Some of their kinetic apparitions were mistily attractive. Others were totally insubstantial.

title: Lockout Theory Goes Awry
description: Unions, in recent years, have initiated strikes that have been costly to them, but owners of baseball's 26 teams appear to be losing their own lockout.

title: Cindy Berenson Engaged to Wed
description: The engagement of Cindy Elizabeth Berenson to Mitchell David Bernstein, the son of Richard B. Bernstein of New City, N.Y., and the late Mrs. Bernstein, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Berenson of Kings Point, L.I. A September wedding is planned.

title: Bush and Japan's Leader to Meet Next Month
description: President Bush and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan announced today that they would meet early next month amid signs that critical trade discussions between Japan and the United States are at a serious impasse.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: DR. JAN DRUCKER;

Can Children Be Believed About Abuse?
description: LEAD: IN the aftermath of last month's acquittal of two people in the 1983 McMartin preschool child-molestation case, some cars in the Los Angeles area are carrying bumper stickers proclaiming ''We Believe the Children.''

title: Chamber Orchestras: An Intimate Balance
description: THE repertoire for chamber orchestra is particularly rich, as composers rise to the challenge of writing pieces that approach the sonorities of a full symphonic ensemble, yet maintain the intimate precision we associate with string quartets and brass or wind quintets.

title: China Acts to Restrict Study Abroad
description: In the most tangible sign so far that China is retreating from its decade-long commitment to sending students abroad, new restrictions will make it virtually impossible for most university graduates to study in other countries unless they work first for five years.

title: Review/Music;   New Schnittke Quartet
description: The Alban Berg Quartet brought Alfred Schnittke's newest string quartet (his fourth) to Alice Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon. It is a piece that lives for its slow movements, of which there are three.

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Czechoslovakia;   SOVIETS PREPARE CZECH DEPARTURE
description: ''Glory to the Soviet Union!'' proclaims a red banner slung across the gates to the Soviet command in Czechoslovakia, situated in this small town less than 20 miles northeast of Prague. But 21 years after the Soviet Army and other Warsaw Pact forces invaded Czechoslovakia to crush the reform movement of Alexander Dubcek, it is with an apology for that invasion and acceptance of defeat that the Soviet Army is scheduled to begin a slow withdrawal on Monday.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ''When my purpose tends to men, I always see burdened wretches, I have only the feeling of ridiculous objects. Never [so] in front of women, where I always find a way to isolate a few elements that satisfy the painter in me.'' So wrote Edouard Vuillard (1868-1940), a Parisian painter who never married, stayed home with maman and his sister and painted them repeatedly at their daily work as seamstresses. The painter's subjects never return his stare; they hazard peeks at one another in maybe one of 10 paintings. The space they occupy is choppy and irrational, pulled at from all sides by competing points of view. In the introduction to THE INTIMATE INTERIORS OF EDOUARD VUILLARD (Museum of Fine Arts, Houston/Smithsonian Institution, $45), Elizabeth Wynne Easton, an assistant curator at the Brooklyn Museum, promises to use Vuillard's diaries, recently made public, to ''eavesdrop on Vuillard's private conversation.'' But she doesn't, not really. Instead she advances a strictly formal thesis: that Vuillard transformed his Symbolist influences into a novel use of line and color. When she comes to Vuillard's odd and obsessive themes she treats them like afterthoughts, taking them up at random, then letting her commentary skate the surface of biography. The startling intrusion of a bearded man into one domestic interior, for example, is supposed to refer to ''the impending marriage of Vuillard's sister''; not until the last sentence of that paragraph, and only in passing, does Ms. Easton chance so provocative a notion as voyeurism.

title: A Radical New Style for Stodgy Old Gillette
description: Now that the Gillette Company has introduced Sensor, a lot more than a tough beard is riding on the razor's edge. Management's neck is, too.

title: Cambodia Will Talk Again, But Listeners Are Scarce
description: THE last time the warring factions in Cambodia sat down together at an international peace conference, in Paris last August, they seemed incapable even of holding a civil conversation. The world's diplomats concluded that the conference had been premature and that flexibility toward a solution, let alone its shape, would have to come after the warring sides had done some more fighting in the absence of Vietnamese troops. This process was rather callously but nearly universally termed ''the test on the battlefield.''

title: Erika S. Marshall Becomes a Bride
description: Erika Story Marshall, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Marshall of New York and Stony Brook, L.I., was married yesterday to David James Gladwell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George William Gladwell of London.

title: Evening Hours;   Smart Turnouts or an Art Show And for Bachelors
description: The Art Dealers Association of America moved into the giant Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue Wednesday, filling the space with small galleries to display art works that span five centuries. The gala cocktail previews - there were three of them Wednesday night - benefited the Henry Street Settlement, which provides social services on the Lower East Side. Stuart Silver designed the floor plan for the 64 exhibitors. About 2,000 guests attended the previews, where waiters served cocktails and hors d'oeuvres. The diversity of the art and the fashionable but understated crowd created an atmosphere that rivaled that of the opening parties for the Winter Antiques Show at the armory last month.

title: Ring of Support Awaits Strawberry
description: Darryl Strawberry is expected to complete his 28-day program of treatment for alcohol abuse Friday and to leave the Smithers Center in Manhattan with a new determination to rejoin the Mets and salvage his marriage and career.

title: THE LADY SOMETIMES VANISHES
description: LEAD: Suddenly, Teresa Stratas is back. She is still canceling performances, but the real news is that she is back. In fact, the diminutive, dark-eyed, 51-year-old dramatic soprano is in the middle of a highly charged period on stage and before the camera.

title: Seton Hall Easy Prey To UConn
description: Chris Smith scored 21 points and Nadav Henefeld sparked a 13-0 run to start the game as sixth-ranked Connecticut cruised to a 79-57 victory over Seton Hall tonight in a Big East Conference game.

title: ECONOMIC PULSE: The New York Region - A Special Report    NEW YORK REGION FACES SLOWDOWN OF THE ECONOMY
description: After their greatest boom since World War II, New York, New Jersey and Connecticut face the prospect of years of slower economic growth.

title: Bulgarian Communists Agree to Delay Voting
description: The Communist Party has agreed to remove its representatives from the work place and to postpone elections by a month, until June, the state press agency said.

title: Long Shapes, Vaguely Suggestive
description: To the Editor:

title: POSTINGS: Condos and a Chapel;   Site Sharing
description: Nearing completion on the same site in Morningside Heights is a 200-seat chapel for the Seventh Church of Christ, Scientist, and a 71-unit condominium called Lionsgate. The plot, at 520 West 112th Street, near Amsterdam Avenue, is approximately 100 feet square and had, until three years ago, been the site of a brownstone owned by the church, as well as of the church building itself, which had fallen into disrepair.

title: Reagan Testifies, For Better or Worse
description: RONALD REAGAN was on television again, unfazed but unable to remember. He had meant the Iran-contra operation to be covert but not illegal, he said in the videotaped deposition that John M. Poindexter, the next defendant to stand trial in the scandal, had sought for so long. Mr. Reagan could not recall conversations from his Presidency or even identify the Chairman of his Joint Chiefs of Staff. And after eight hours of answers, it was not clear whether Mr. Poindexter, Mr. Reagan's national security adviser, would be better off with or without this witness.

title: Exploring a New Berlin
description: BERLIN, it now seems likely, is to become once more the capital of the Germans. In principle, that should make the city whole again, a megalopolis of three million people free to reclaim its place among the great centers of European culture and industry. But it is hard to imagine how the return of the capital will do more than add one more Berlin to the bewildering set already shaped by a tortuous history. Schizophrenia seems the natural condition of this city, where for so long the Berlin Wall served not only to divide but to shape disparate cultures and lives.

title:
FRANKLIN LAKES JOURNAL;

Borough Acquires a Liquor License and Will Offer It for Bids
description: LEAD: UNTIL now, restaurant patrons who considered drinks a perfect accompaniment to dinner may have been well advised to avoid making dinner reservations here.

description: Gershon Mamlak, a slight intense man, talks about his past and present in impassioned bursts. He stabs the air with a finger to press a point and pulls letters out of manila folders to document others.

description: Mr. and Mrs. Philip Horn of Teaneck, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Gila to Dr. Joel Gellman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Gellman of Johannesburg. A September wedding is planned.

description: Recalling a May Day crafts festival 14 years ago when she first saw glassblowers working in the dark, Ann Morhauser says she was ''hypnotized'' and knew she had to work in glass. Today her Annieglass Studio ships about 80,000 pieces of handmade glass tableware a year.

title: Soviet Jews Find New Friends Waiting
description: LEAD: WHEN Bella Galinovsky emigrated from Moscow and arrived in Philadelphia in 1974, she was brought with her husband and young son to a hotel, given some money and told to try to find an apartment and a job. Her son, Aron, became ill the first night. She knew no one to call for help.

title: Series of Anti-Semitic Incidents Continues in Middlesex County, N.J.
description: Anti-Semitic incidents continue to plague Middlesex County, N.J.

title: Some in U.S. Congress Kept From Nicaragua
description: A group of conservative Republican members of Congress said today that the Nicaraguan Government had rejected their request to observe the national elections on Sunday.

description: When ''Driving Miss Daisy'' led the list of Academy Award nominations, executives at Warner Brothers got a double dose of pleasure. The movie's nine nominations mean money and ego satisfaction.

title: Schools Act Cautiously On Adding Languages
description: LEAD: FEW Americans would be as adept at ordering a meal from a menu written in Chinese as the nine students in the new Chinese II class at Mamaroneck High School. Nor would many in this country be as familiar with the Chinese culture as these teen-agers, most of whom are studying Chinese as their second or third foreign language.

title: 'WORDS WALKING WITHOUT MASTERS'
description: CHANGING OUR OWN WORDS

title: Exit Interview: Gunn Stands Clear Of the Closing Door
description: SIX years ago, David L. Gunn took charge of New York City's crumbling public transportation system, embarking on what he called a ''suicide mission'' to turn it around. On Wednesday, Mr. Gunn will step down as president of the Transit Authority, turning the job over to Alan F. Kiepper, a former general manager of Houston's transit system. In an interview last week with Suzanne Daley, a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The New York Times, Mr. Gunn talked of what has - and has not - been accomplished. Here are excerpts from the interview.

Warner released the film, which is rated R, on Feb. 8 at the price of $24.98, meaning that the studio thinks it should sell better than it rents. Now comes the suspense.

description: The biggest non-Olympic crowd ever to see a United States national soccer team play witnessed a vivid example today of how much ground the American squad must make up in the international race.

title: Goblins Obscure Views of Youth
description: BUCKING the tide, swimming upstream, is as much a part of the mission of social agencies today as is serving people in great need. To do only the latter quietly or in isolation, is to miss the opportunity of unveiling to the community the great triumphs of the human struggle that occur each day, in every community.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;

Mourning Altman's: A Death in the Family
description: LEAD: AMONG those who lament that B. Altman and Company has closed forever, few families will continue to note more poignantly its demise than mine. No one will mourn its loss as deeply as would have my late father, whose intimate relationship with the store flourished for more than 50 years. His association with Altman's permeated his existence and later, by extension, my mother's; my sister and

title: More Than Counting Heads
description: IT still asks homeowners if they have indoor plumbing, and there are 232 communities in Mississippi that currently do not. It asks if the kitchen has a sink, range and refrigerator, and there are thousands of illegal apartments, including hundreds in Westchester, that do not.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE TARRYTOWN GARMENT COMPANY;

Campeau's Troubles Trickle Down to a Swimsuit Factory
description: LEAD: THE sewing machines are constantly in motion at the Tarrytown Garment Company here, making a steady hum that is really more of a roar. At each machine sits a member of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, stitching intently. Pieces of fabric become whole bathing suits in seemingly no time at all.

description: THE HOT JAZZ TRIO

description: Peace is bringing deficits, not dividends, to Brazil's arms-exporting industry, until recently the third world's largest.

title: The India of the Nawabs
description: THERE is a feeling of substance about Lucknow, a city important to the history of both Indian nationalism and British imperialism. Jawaharlal Nehru, India's first Prime Minister, called the Lucknow area ''that heart of Hindustan as it has so long been considered, the seat and center of both ancient and medieval civilizations, the melting pot of so many races and cultures.''

title: Catherine Kuehn Weds Malcolm Price
description: Catherine Elizabeth Kuehn and Malcolm Keith Price were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York by the Rev. John Hartnett. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Bernd P. Kuehn of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Westerly, R.I., and Mr. and Mrs. Bruce E. Price of Ballarat, Victoria, Australia.

description: In the five and a half years since Tom Clancy's nuclear-submarine thriller ''The Hunt for Red October'' became a best seller, the cold war, as every schoolchild knows, has lost much of its icy terror.

description: Q. I have some iodine spots on my bathroom sink that I cannot seem to remove. I've tried various cleansers, but nothing seems to help. What should I use?
