title: Kabobs and Breads of Lucknow
description: KABOBI-SHARABI is an old Urdu (the language of Moguls in India) expression. Literally it means one who loves grilled meat (kabob) with wine (sharab). In a broader sense it is ascribed to anyone who appreciates good living and delights in gastronomic pleasures. Ask any kabobi-sharabi for the best in the world for kabobs and he will invariably point to Lucknow, the capital of Northern Province and the home of the great Nawabi culture.

title: YEARNING FOR AN IRON HAND
description: An addendum to your article: I've been told that Russian emigres to Israel are reporting that, to gain admittance to Pamyat, prospective members must provide the organization with the names, addresses and phone numbers of several Jews. Those Jews are then harassed over the phone with death threats and orders to leave the country.

title: Dressing on a 'Dime': Choose Your Mood
description: LEAD: If a woman wants clothes to suit her every mood, she might think she needs an extravagant budget. But stylish dressers can communicate a variety of whims and attitudes, drawing less on their bank accounts than on the more important resources of imagination, wit and charm. Striped clothes, for instance, can be mixed to create an Op-Art mood that is either sophisticated or funky.

title: Kelly A. Murray To Marry in 1991
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Murray of Skillman, N.J., and Westhampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kelly Ann Murray to Michael Upjohn Kole, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Larry Kole of Clifton, Va. A June 1991 wedding is planned.

title: Lisa Marie Sacuto to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John M. Sacuto of Charlottesville, Va., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Lisa Marie Sacuto and Jonathan Hodson-Walker, a son of John Hodson-Walker of Truro, West Cornwall, England, and the late June Elizabeth Hodson-Walker. Miss Sacuto, 25 years old, is a financial analyst with the Ford Motor Company in Louisville, Ky. Mr. Hodson-Walker, 25, is an associate with Drexel Burnham Lambert in New York.

title: Campus Life: Penn State;   Students Dance Weekend Away To Aid Ill Children
description: More than 500 Penn State University students spent 48 hours in a campus gym last weekend dancing for charity, and walked away with sore feet on Sunday night after raising $671,572 for children with cancer. Of the 536 students who began the 1990 Penn State Dance marathon, 511 finished it.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Washington;

2 Towers Near Completion
description: LEAD: CHEVY CHASE PAVILION, a $130 million project in which two towers, one a hotel and the other an office building, are rising from a three-level shopping arcade, is nearing completion on a strategic corner in Friendship Heights at the Maryland line.

title: Julie Anne Tighe To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Tighe of Darien, Conn., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Julie Anne Tighe and Joseph D. Carrabino Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Carrabino of Encino, Calif.

title: Mexico's Dismal Debt Deal
description: The jury is now in on the 1989 debt restructuring agreement between Mexico and the international financial community. Unfortunately, the deal is a bad one for Mexico. The agreement, signed on Feb. 4, falls far short of the country's needs, has not and will not produce the desired effects, and leaves the nation in a woefully weak position for future negotiations.

title: Goya's 'Disasters of War': Grisly Indictment of Humanity
description: IT took 10 years to produce ''Disasters of War'' and another 43 to publish the series of etchings. Their visit to the Benton Museum at the University of Connecticut, however, is brief. On loan from the Sarah Campbell Blaffer Foundation in Houston, these 80 images leave Storrs on March 11.

title: A Judge of Plays Wins Play Contest
description: ALICE and Biff and Mimi and Randall are two married couples in ''I'm Sorry, I'm Sorry,'' a one-act play by Rosemary Foley of Pelham that just won first prize in an international competition.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD:

title: Hearts and Cholesterol
description: To the Editor:

title: County Now Turns to Albany For Tax Relief
description: COUNTY EXECUTIVE Andrew P. O'Rourke and the Board of Legislators, at odds for the last two months over a record-breaking 1990 county budget, have joined forces to seek Albany's approval for new legislation that they say would help relieve the burden on Westchester taxpayers.

title: Inside a State-of-the-Art Kaleidoscope
description: First there was Vicki Baum's best-selling novel of 1929, then her play, then M-G-M's version, the original all-star Hollywood movie -Garbo, the Barrymore boys, Joan Crawford, Wallace Beery and Lewis Stone. Now, some 60 years after it all began, comes ''Grand Hotel'' the musical. Of course: the dashing staircase rippling with prestigious entrances! the billowing drapes! the revolving stage to sweep us from suite to suite! Here the joyless ballerina, there the handsome baron! Now the sexy secretary, then the crooked businessman! Look, behind that pillar - it's the dying bookkeeper who wants to ''see life''! And there's the grand ballroom, ironically swirling with dancers drunk on the frivolous rapture of the waltz!

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;

Why Renting a House Is Gaining Favor
description: LEAD: SOME of the best housing deals available on Long Island today are not house purchases, but house rentals. The prices being charged for rentals are usually well below the cost of ownership, even when tax benefits are considered. And now that appreciation has flattened, at least for the short term, the investment value of houses has also plummeted, so that rentals have become a viable alternative even for those who can well afford to buy.

title: Renee Trambert Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leonard K. Trambert have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Renee Stephanie Trambert and Edward Tyler, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Tyler of Oceanside, L.I. Miss Trambert, 25 years old, is a nurse at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, where her fiance, 31, is a pharmacist. She graduated from the Columbia University School of Nursing and is studying for a master's degree in public health at St. John's University. Mr. Tyler, a graduate of St. John's, is studying there for an M.B.A.

title: BROTHER HOODS
description: LEAD:

title: Cantata on Dr. King in Premiere
description: LEAD: WHEN Kenneth R. Force set out to write a cantata based on the life of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., it began as a routine, if challenging, assignment.

title: 'Smart' Tires That Read the Road
description: One way to boost a car's mileage is to increase tire pressure, which reduces rolling resistance. But increased tire pressure means a harsher ride on uneven surfaces. Cornering ability suffers as well.

title: To Know Berliners, Know Their Cafes
description: IN West Berlin, where only 45 years ago Allied soldiers could execute a man for being on the street without his I.D. card, the conundrum of identity - of who you are when you're not at home - has never quite been solved. It's the riddle at the heart of this schizophrenic city, yanked at from every quarter by contradicting tugs, and one that Berliners express in their choice of cafes. Scratch a Berliner and you'll find a favorite cafe; visit it, and you'll probably learn more about that person's taste in fashion, music, newspapers and decor than in the course of a three-hour conversation.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Columbus Avenue;   'Mom-and-Pops' Are Yielding to a New Makeover
description: COLUMBUS AVENUE, which remakes itself every few years, is in the middle of another transformation, marked by a high number of vacancies, lower rents, frequent turnover and the loss of the very stores and restaurants that once epitomized the avenue.

title: Jocelyn Taylor Weds Henry McIntire
description: The marriage of Jocelyn Keith Taylor and Henry Dickson McIntire took place yesterday at the Congregational Church in Peru, Vt. The Rev. Alice O'Donovan performed the ceremony. The bride's daughter and son, Ashley C. Taylor and Ashton K. Taylor, attended the couple.

title: Pioneer 11 Is Reported to Leave Solar System
description: Seventeen years after it was launched and more than a decade after it became the first spacecraft to visit Saturn, Pioneer 11 flew beyond Neptune's orbit and out of the solar system Friday, the space agency and the company that built the probe reported.

title: Islanders Rally For Tie
description: The Islanders ended a four-game losing streak this afternoon by rallying from a 3-0 deficit and earning a 3-3 tie with the Detroit Red Wings at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Infiniti Is Going Out of Sight Fast
description: What do you get when you cross a Ford Taurus with a Mercedes 450 SEL?

title: Defendants in a Fraud Trial Say They Exorcised for Fees
description: A lawyer representing a mother and daughter accused of defrauding customers of almost $250,000 says the women cannot be convicted unless the state proves that evil spirits do not exist.

title: Tokyo Teeters, But New York Holds Firm
description: In October 1987 and again two years later, Wall Street started panics that spread around the world, only to be slowed and eventually halted in Tokyo. Each time, the Japanese stock market slipped a little but soon rallied, to the great relief of traders everywhere.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: BORROWED TIME: An AIDS Memoir, by Paul Monette. (Avon, $8.95.) A poet chronicles the final year and a half of his lover's life, as his body succumbed step by step to AIDS. ''Fired with the knowledge that his own immune system was compromised, Mr. Monette has etched a magnificent monument to his lover's bravery, their commitment to each other and the plague of hatred and ignorance they had to endure,'' William M. Hoffman said here in 1988. ''The memoir has the leanness and urgency of war reporting, sparing the reader none of the details of the illness or of the emotional state of the principals.''

title: Mixed Reviews
description: For Joseph F. Cullman 3d, the scenario had to be one of the oddest of his 77 years. In one court, his corporate accomplishments were drawing fire. In the other, his sports accomplishments were drawing praise. Like a tennis net, Cullman was straddling both courts.

title: Is the TV Screen of the Future To Be Shaped by the Movies?
description: In all the international wrangling about future forms of high-definition television (HDTV), there was at least one accord. Everyone agreed that the screen should be wider. Now even that idea has been questioned.

title: Borrowing Trouble II
description: The man who took television to new lows has reached one himself. Morton Downey Jr., whose syndicated Morton Downey Jr. Show was generally considered the prototype of ''shock television,'' filed a Chapter 11 bankruptcy petition in Federal Court in New Jersey last week. Mr. Downey listed assets of more than $6.8 million and liabilities of about $2.4 million, but he apparently is having cash-flow problems. He is seeking protection from about 75 creditors including banks and a limousine leasing company whose owner said that Mr. Downey turned his leased auto ''into a trash can.'' Mr. Downey, who claimed to have only $100 in ready cash and $320 in the bank, was unavailable for comment on his problems, which apparently were linked to the decline of his once-popular show. The show's ratings began to slide as Mr. Downey went beyond brow-beating his guests and was charged at least twice with assaulting them. The show finally sank into oblivion as stations in major markets stopped carrying it last year.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Outing;   Here, Doubtful Shoppers Are Advised to Pounce
description: On any given Friday, Saturday and Sunday, the U.S. No. 1 Flea Market and Antiques in New Brunswick, N.J., about 45 minutes down the turnpike from Manhattan, draws some 30,000 people. They push their way past sweatshirt vendors and bulletin boards announcing events like a Marvelettes concert at the local high school to get through the streaky glass doors.

title:
DANCE;

For Lubovitch, Dance Is a Verbal Art
description: LEAD: The opening image in Lar Lubovitch's choreography for a new duet, ''Fandango,'' is a sexy, topsy-turvy embrace. The dancer Mia Babalis is seen in a one-armed handstand, her torso supported at an awkward angle by her partner, Sylvain Lafortune. From that moment and for the next 15 minutes, the two performers pull, hang, lean, climb, hug and step on each other, their bodies constantly coupling to the lush intensity of Ravel's ''Bolero.

title: Business Graduates: Shying Away From Wall Street
description: In September 1987, as the bull market still raged and few guessed that a crash was but a month away, there was a huge waiting list for the investment banking course at Northwestern University's Kellogg School of Management.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey;   Recent Sales
description: Freehold $237,500

title: Baseball Deadlock Is Nearing
description: Baseball's labor dispute could be only one meeting away from disrupting the start of the regular season.

title: Sweet Rite of Passage for High School Star
description: As long as there are children and hoops in this part of southern Indiana, people will remember the night Damon Bailey cried and more than a few in the customary adoring crowd of more than 6,300 wiped away their own tears.

title: New Housing Proposal Is Just a Red Herring
description: As members of the Ossining Ministerial Association who have worked on the Affordable Housing Proposal for Ossining for more than two-and-a-half years, we appreciated the article ''Divergent Goals Collide at River Site Owned by State'' [Feb. 4] . While the need for affordable housing seems all too obvious to many of us, there are still some who question such initiatives, especially if it is in their neighborhood.

title: SPIES & THRILLERS
description: In THE GOOD SPY by John Griffiths (Carroll & Graf, $17.95), the setting looks back a few years to the Brezhnev period. A Russian sleeper in the United States is called into service. Coincidentally, the head of an American intelligence agency learns that there is a mole in his department. There is a good deal of maneuvering before things are straightened out, to the satisfaction of all concerned. Especially the sleeper.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Feb. 18 about Fort Lee, N.J., misstated the range of prices at the Westgate town-house complex. It is $159,990 to $214,990.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: BIOGRAPHY
description: RAGTIME TUMPIE

title: High Productivity: The Best Social Security
description: LEAD: The lively debate on Social Security started by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan will rank as a Great Debate if it yields the right choice on disposing of the Trust Fund surplus.

title: There's No Escaping Wittgenstein
description: To the Editor:

title: Can a Dictator Tell Us Something About Ourselves?
description: Back in 1977, when Miss Margarida, the redoubtable schoolteacher, first strode onto a New York stage, it did not take the audience long to figure out that they were in the hands of a rather unusual tyrant.

title: YEARNING FOR AN IRON HAND
description: There is no mention in the article of the embarrassing fact (embarrasing for Russian nationalists, no doubt) that Russia acquired the lion's share of its Jewish minority through brutal conquests at the expense of Poland in the late 18th century. If these Russian ''patriots'' really cared about Mother Russia, they would take a critical stand against their beloved czars, who provoked and fought one war after another to expand their frontiers far beyond any defensive purposes and who cruelly subjugated conquered peoples, whose descendants, not surprisingly, were flocking to the revolutionary parties by the beginning of the 20th century.

title: Laurie Abramowitz, a Lawyer, Is Wed
description: Laurie Abramowitz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mark Abramowitz of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married last evening to Robert F. Doherty, a son of Mary Doherty of Scarsdale, N.Y. Justice Edward K. Pincus of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn and Staten Island officiated at the Pierre in New York.

title:
IN SHORT;

NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Rookie Is Suspended
description: After failing a drug test and being suspended from the National Basketball Association for the rest of the season, Roy Marble, an Atlanta Hawk rookie from the University of Iowa, has entered an addiction treatment program in California. . . . Fred Lebow, the president of the New York Road Runners Club and the director of the New York City Marathon, will undergo a biopsy tomorrow to determine the extent of a tumor found on his brain during a series of tests at Mount Sinai Hospital last week.(AP)

title: St. John's Slips Past DePaul
description: Less than three minutes into last night's game between St. John's and DePaul, Robert Werdann, the St. John's center, was knocked to the floor at Madison Square Garden.

title: In Tide of Change, Worry About North Korea
description: The revolutionary changes in Eastern Europe are now tearing at North Korea's foreign policy, leading some diplomats to worry that the unpredictable North Korean leadership may react in dangerous ways.

title:
MUSIC;

Tokyo Quartet Playing Beethoven Cycle
description: LEAD: RESTORING a musical cycle that was once a tradition for Princeton concertgoers, the Tokyo String Quartet is presenting the complete Beethoven string quartets this season, in a series of six concerts. Until World War II, all the Beethoven string quartets were performed every few seasons by the Budapest String Quartet, but in recent years no quartet has played the complete cycle of 16 works.

title: Holocaust Books For Children
description: With all due respect and admiration for David A. Adler's work, I would like to make a correction to ''For Youth, Memories of the Holocaust'' (Jan. 28), where it states that ''We Remember the Holocaust'' by David Adler is believed to be the first publication about the Holocaust experience for children.

title: Photo: Karen Lawson-Johnston (Bachrach) Miss Gallagher Wed in Massachusetts
description: The marriage of Karen Ann Gallagher, a daughter of Mrs. Joseph L. Gallagher of Milton and Harwich Port, Mass., and Peter Lawson-Johnston Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawson-Johnston of Princeton, N.J., took place yesterday at St. Agatha Roman Catholic Church in Milton. The Rev. Francis X. Turke officiated.

title: Board Moving Swiftly On Westhelp Proposal
description: THE proposal for housing homeless families in Greenburgh, which prompted major changes on the Board of Legislators after the last election, is now facing a leadership that seems determined to move swiftly on the issue.

title: Let Business Be Responsible
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW MEXICO WORKS
description: CONVERSATIONS WITH MOCTEZUMA

title: Ban Leaves Only a Whisper of Canton's Evils
description: Three men loitered on a dark street near Haizhu Bridge late one evening, whispering discreetly to young passers-by: ''Do you want to buy a Hong Kong video? Uh, about sex? Only 100 yuan.'' When the steep price, about $21, or more than a third of a worker's income here, was rejected, the men darted silently back into the darkness.

title: 6 TORAHS STOLEN FROM SYNAGOGUES
description: Six Torahs have been stolen this month from synagogues in New Jersey and Pennsylvania, and the authorities say they suspect that there is a ring specializing in religious objects.

title: Amy J. Lapkin To Wed in May
description: Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin Lapkin of Larchmont, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Amy Jessica Lapkin to James Eric Frank, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard J. Frank of Englewood, N.J. A May wedding is planned.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: MARDI GRAS TIME

description: Q. I have some iodine spots on my bathroom sink that I cannot seem to remove. I've tried various cleansers, but nothing seems to help. What should I use?

title: Maureen A. Kennedy To Wed David Hays
description: April wedding plans for Maureen Ann Kennedy and David Mortimer Hays have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Martin C. Kennedy of Wilton, Conn.

title: Question Of the Week;   Does Tyson Deserve An Immediate Rematch?
description: You asked the wrong question.

title: Campaign Finance Law Needs Changes
description: LAWMAKERS and regulators in Trenton should alter New Jersey's system of public financing for gubernatorial candidates to reflect the realities of modern political life. The state's Election Law Enforcement Commission, which monitors all of New Jersey's campaign laws, held a day of hearings last week to consider such changes in the wake of the recent election.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Alpine
description: LEAD: HIDDEN among the rocks and trees of the Palisades cliffs just 12 miles from Manhattan sits the Borough of Alpine, where nearly every street ends in a cul de sac and landscaped lawns spread out from stately homes that carry no addresses.

title: Sara McMakin to Marry
description: A May wedding is planned by Sara McMakin and Paul Andrew Lynn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward John Lynn of Southport, Conn., the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. McMakin of Hamilton, Ohio, have announced. Miss McMakin, 25 years old, graduated from Villanova University, as did Mr. Lynn. She is the controller of the Elmwood Federal Savings Bank in Media, Pa. Mr. Lynn, 24, is a staff accountant in Philadelphia for the accounting firm of Deloitte & Touche.tr 111641,ibp RDAY BOOK 2 NUMBERS DUPE 111640 02-17 W0126

title:
DINING OUT;

Colonial and Country Club Atmospheres
description: LEAD: THE stately Federal-style brick building, circa 1813, beckoned with its handsomely lighted facade a stone's throw from Route 78 in rural Hunterdon County. Spruced up and reopened by new owners last August, the two-story inn is not far from Clinton, in tiny Perryville.

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Bulgaria;   'Old Survivor' Aspires To Power in Bulgaria
description: Moved and still incredulous about the occasion, Petar Dartliev clutched copies of the newspaper that his party had just published for the first time in 41 years.

title: No Longer Faces in a Crowd
description: They were but faces in the crowd two years ago, among hundreds of young athletes trying to make the United States Olympic track and field team. And like so many whose forays ended too soon, they disappeared again into the background, left to ponder the what-ifs and train for future glories.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Someday Just Turned to Never
description: LEAD: YESTERDAY, I walked to my closet and pulled out my Someday file, a battered accordion folder about a foot wide. I was about to slip a magazine article on custom windows into the bulging folder when the thought struck me: Why am I still doing this?

title: Ellen B. Epstein Engaged to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Howard N. Epstein of Washington Crossing, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Beth Epstein, to Dr. Mark Steven Gloger, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Gloger of Pikesville, Md. A September wedding is planned.

title: Nicklaus Grandson
description: If you're having trouble absorbing the fact that Jack Nicklaus has turned 50 and will soon be playing on the Senior Tour, consider this: he is now a grandfather. Barbara Nicklaus, the wife of Jack Nicklaus 2d, gave birth to a 7-pound 21-inch boy Friday at St. Mary's Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla. The baby's name: Jack William Nicklaus 3d.

title: Auditors Call For Slowdown In Funds for Stealth Bomber
description: In its first public evaluation of the radar-evading Stealth bomber, the General Accounting Office has recommended that Congress slow the financing and production of the aircraft while it is tested further.

title: Camp Safety: What to Ask
description: CHILDREN evolve into independent travelers in progressive steps, and one of the most significant is the first stay at sleep-away camp. Parents who have focused on keeping children in seat belts, getting them to wear bicycle helmets and enforcing other travel safety precautions suddenly envision a world of hazards over which they have no control.

title: No More 'War on Drugs'
description: Figures of speech are supposed to enhance understanding; sometimes they impede it. That's happening with the ''war on drugs.''

title: Style Makers;   Coreen Simpson, Cameo Designer
description: When Coreen Simpson, a photographer and jewelry designer, saw some cameos in a fashion magazine last year, she thought they were beautiful but said to herself, ''No black woman is going to wear this, especially someone who is really into her culture.''

title: His Ballets Speak A New Language
description: ''Every Ballet,'' says Eliot Feld, ''deserves its own language. That sense of propriety, of the materials that are called for, is the quality that makes something beautiful.''

title: Ellen Levine Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Levine of Monsey, N.Y., have announced October wedding plans for their daughter Ellen M. Levine and Robert I. Altman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Altman of Marlboro, N.J. Ms. Levine, 28 years old, graduated from Pace University. She is a senior tax analyst with Young & Rubicam in New York. Mr. Altman, 30, graduated from Emory University and is the president of Mortgage Funding in New York.

title: Kathleen Byers to Wed W. S. Smilow
description: Kathleen Kay Byers and William Scott Smilow plan to marry in April, the prospective bride's mother, Mary Cooper Byers of Oakbrook Terrace, Ill., has announced. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joel E. Smilow of Westport, Conn.

title: 'The Remembered Present'
description: To the Editor:

title: For Unions' Hierarchy, Good News Amid Grim
description: The American people are always down on someone, the pollster told the trade unionists here: big government, big business or big labor.

title: Fashion;   Handbag Renaissance, With Visual Appeal
description: Women sometimes go out in public clutching strange, sensuous objects. These can be little jeweled leather boxes, slinky lizard-skin envelopes, iridescent silk pouches or shiny sequinned metallic balls.

IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: A Spill a Day, and Hardly Anyone Has Been Checking
description: NEARLY 44 million gallons of petroleum products pass through the New York Harbor area every day in a network of tankers, barges, refineries and storage terminals, and hundreds of miles of surface and submerged pipeline.

title: Red Ransom's '90 Debut Delayed
description: The long-awaited return of Red Ransom will have to wait a little longer.

title: Asia's Needs and America's Grow Harder to Synchronize
description: IN the four and a half decades since World War II ended, aboard the battleship Missouri, an overwhelming American military presence in the Pacific has been an accepted fact of the postwar order. The United States, after all, was the country that rebuilt and protected a demilitarized Japan, contained Communism at the 38th parallel and offset Soviet power.

title: Kerith Sheehan To Wed in June
description: Mrs. Robert T. Sheehan of Brooklyn has made known the engagement of her daughter, Kerith Leah Sheehan, to Marvin Stanley Putnam Jr., a son of Janice Crawford Putnam of Bangor, Me., and Mr. Putnam of Portland, Me. A June wedding is planned.

description: THE JOURNALIST AND THE MURDERER

description: LEAP YEAR

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months.

title: POSTINGS: Owners' Seminar;   Conversions
description: With Queens caught up in a flood of condominium and cooperative conversions, residents there may want to attend a seminar on owning and operating such apartments. It will be Tuesday at 6:45 P.M. at the Queens Borough Hall in Kew Gardens.

title: Policemen in Seoul Break Up Protest Against a New Party
description: The South Korean police crushed a peaceful protest against a new governing party today, kicking and punching demonstrators and detaining more than 400 in one of the most violent actions this year, witnesses said.

title: Question Of the Week;   Does Tyson Deserve An Immediate Rematch?
description: Tyson is the best world champion boxing has had since Ali. He has been extremely generous in his willingness to defend his crown. He has fought as often as every other month to accommodate the long list of candidates. Mike clearly deserves an immediate rematch.

Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have some iodine spots on my bathroom sink that I cannot seem to remove. I've tried various cleansers, but nothing seems to help. What should I use?

title: Review/Theater;   Musical Fairy Tale Adaptation
description: ''A Spinning Tale,'' a new musical at Playhouse 91, announces itself in its press release as ''targeted for an adult audience but guaranteed to entertain children.'' In reality it is targeted for a children's audience and not guaranteed to entertain adults.

title: Style Makers;   Judith Selkowitz, Art Buyer
description: Judith Selkowitz started Art Advisory Services Inc. because ''there are a lot of people out there who want to buy art, don't know anything about it and ought to get some help.''

title: Child's 15,000-Mile Odyssey In a Troubling Custody Case
description: Hilary Foretich, the 7-year-old girl at the heart of the country's best-known custody battle, went on a 15,000-mile odyssey in 30 months in hiding with her grandparents, traveling from Washington to Plymouth in western England to Christchurch, New Zealand, where her father located her a few days ago.

title: Pastimes;   Chess
description: Maxim Dlugy uttered the all-too-frequent grandmasters' lament, ''Oh, the won games I let get away!'' musing on the Hoogoven International Tournament in Wijk-aan-Zee, the Netherlands, which ended Jan. 28. But the Englewood, N.J., grandmaster, who originally hailed from the Soviet Union, also got a small piece of good fortune.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Young Einstein

title: Looking Good Under Pressure
description: WHere are women in the world whose mascara never smudges. Their lipstick never blurs, their noses never shine, their hair never droops or sags. Or maybe it does, but we never see it. The point is this: They don't spend hours planted before the mirror, fussing, primping and retouching their makeup.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have some iodine spots on my bathroom sink that I cannot seem to remove. I've tried various cleansers, but nothing seems to help. What should I use?

title: Lorenzo Buys Some Time for Eastern, but the Price Is High
description: Ever since Frank Lorenzo began to build his vast airline empire, he has been careful to keep the parent company, the Texas Air Corporation, as separate as possible from its operating units.

title: POSTINGS: A Film Warning;   Perilous Play on Elevators
description: One fad that appears to be gaining momentum among the young in urban areas is climbing atop elevators and riding them up and down the shafts in high-rise buildings.

description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Lovers of Graffiti Rally To Save an Old Bridge
description: They come at dark or brazenly by day, with buckets and brushes, or cans of spray paint, and scrawl their messages on the old railroad bridge for everyone to see:

title: Just Say 'Caterpillar'
description: From the Cocaine Situation Room or some other place deep in the bowels of the Agriculture Department has come the Bush Administration's latest notion for the war on drugs. The Administration has proposed to quadruple the budget of the Agricultural Research Service - to $6.5 million - mainly to study eloria-noyesi, a coca-eating caterpillar, and the feasibility of dropping millions of the insects into the coca fields of Peru and Bolivia. The caterpillar, which grows up to be the malumbia moth, is voracious enough to destroy whole crops of the leaves from which cocaine comes, officials said. ''If we could put them down there in sufficient numbers, we could then defoliate the plants,'' an official told The Washington Post last week. But nobody is sure what the malumbia will crave once all the coca is eaten - coffee plants? house pets? - and officials in Bolivia and Peru were less than enthusiastic. So the Administration rushed to reassure them. Said Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, ''Neither troops nor caterpillars will go in without prior request and consultation.''

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Track and Field

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Hoard Today, Gone Tomorrow
description: LEAD: ON the continuum of savers and tossers, I'm somewhere between my pack rat friend, Pat, and my friend Sandy, who throws out something for each new item she acquires. And I'm more seasonal than consistent in my attitude toward hoarding.

title: Could Israel's Political Feud Open a Way to Peace Talks?
description: MORE than almost anyone else in Israel, Ariel Sharon opposes the Israeli plan for peace negotiations with Palestinians from the occupied territories.

title: Wedding in May For Amy Petersen
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Petersen of Haverford, Pa., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter, Amy de l'Orme Petersen, and Gardner Ritner Skene Walling, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Campion Walling of Gladwyne, Pa.

title: Mental Health Is Too Serious for Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: AIDS Patients' Silent Companion Is Often Suicide, or Thoughts of It
description: Whenever Jim Lee opens his refrigerator, his two carefully hoarded bottles of Seconal are there, reminding him that he is soon to die, and that like large numbers of people with AIDS, he is preparing when the time is right to take his own life.

title: Review/Dance;   Monson's Designed Improvisations
description: Jennifer Monson called her new group work ''Ursa's Door,'' but the hint of mythology in the title and the set was not fulfilled in the dance itself, which was presented on Thursday night by the Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church. Instead, six personable, daredevil performers tumbled, dashed and teetered through a funny, often dramatic hourlong carnival of wild physical games.

title: Managing;   Revising Pay Packages, Again
description: During the 1980's, when inflation came under control and companies could get away with giving mediocre raises, they started tinkering with compensation packages. Instead of double-digit raises, they offered valuable employees stock grants, deferred bonuses and other potentially lucrative incentives if they attained higher profits, stock-price growth or other goals.

title: Question Of the Week;   Does Tyson Deserve An Immediate Rematch?
description: I still can't believe Mike Tyson was knocked down by an unknown journeyman fighter from Columbus, Ohio. Was that Iron Mike there in the ring getting punched silly by this upstart?

title:
The Executive Life;

Why Wall Street Is Laughing - at Itself
description: LEAD: Each night on an obscure side street in New York's Greenwich Village, limousines glide up to the door of an unprepossessing little theater. The crowd gathering for ''Other People's Money'' is strikingly well heeled and serious for Off Broadway. Many of the men and women sport suits and briefcases.

title: Abstraction Returns to Haunt Photography
description: After a hiatus of more than 30 years, the specter of abstraction once again haunts the art of photography. But today's version of abstract photography has little in common with the Abstract Expressionist style and high seriousness of work from the 1950's by Aaron Siskind, Minor White and others. Instead, it seems suffused with a sense of belatedness and loss, as well as an acute awareness that abstraction functions as a sign of the realm of the spiritual.

title: Pastimes;   Coins
description: A nice collection can begin and end with just one type of coin. A great coin to collect is the Franklin half dollar. Many dealers concur and feel that now is the time for purchasing Franklin half-dollars. Their reasoning is that there are only 35 varieties from 1948 to 1963 so a complete collection is not going to be a huge endeavor.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a capsule listing of issues in medicine last Sunday, with a front-page article about doctors, misstated the percentage of black and Hispanic doctors for 1988. Black doctors made up 3.3 percent of the profession; Hispanic doctors made up 4.7 percent.

title: City Ballet's Season: Steady Hand, Even Keel
description: The New York City Ballet season was fairly unexciting, a phenomenon that would have once been gratefully regarded as stability -by those concerned about the company's survival in its early days and immediately after the death in 1983 of its co-founder, George Balanchine.

title: Walesa Asserts Soviet Union Needs New Federal Structure
description: Lech Walesa, the founder of Solidarity, was quoted today as saying that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev should break up the Soviet Union and remold the federation.

title: PARADISE FOUND, AT LEAST FOR A MOMENT
description: Samite, A traditionalist musician from Uganda, passed on a traditional proverb to a recent New York audience: ''If you don't dance to music, it is wasted.'' By that standard, hardly a note went unused at some of the best concerts I've seen lately. In ascending order of capacity, the Meters at Tramps, the B-52's at Radio City Music Hall and Erasure at Madison Square Garden all catalyzed the kind of musical experience that no recording can duplicate - the feeling that everyone in the room, offstage and on, has become one big, happy, rhythm-driven community.

title: PERSPECTIVES: Apartments as Investments;   Buyers Seek Bargains in Co-op Buildings
description: A GRADUAL realignment is under way in New York City in the ownership of renter-occupied apartments in co-op buildings.

title: All About/Computers Talking to Computers;   Fast Modems: All Dressed Up, With Only a Slow Way to Go
description: Ever since personal computers became common in the late 1970's, users have wanted their computers to communicate. Modems answered their needs by allowing computers to exchange data over the telephone. During the 1980's, modems opened up a world of information, including electronic mail, computer data bases and services ranging from airline reservations to stock trading.

title: NO ONE GOES CRAZY ALONE
description: INSTITUTIONALIZING MADNESS

title: Justice Samuel G. Fredman Is Wed To Mimi Coppersmith, an Executive
description: Marian Barash Coppersmith and Justice Samuel G. Fredman of State Supreme Court in White Plains were married last evening in State College, Pa. Rabbi Jeffrey Eisenstat officiated at Congregation Brit Shalom. The couple were attended by the bride's son and four daughters and the bridegroom's two sons.

title: TALKING: Oil Tanks;   Testing For Leaks Advisable
description: TO all the other environmental hazards connected with homeownership - radon, asbestos and foam insulation among them - must now be added underground oil tanks.

title: No Headline
description: It seemed like a nightmare. Willie O'Ree, unable to see with his jersey pulled over his head, could only throw punches at the voices screaming around him.

title: Armed and Ready: Suburban Families Fight the Fear
description: THE O'Leary family of Merrick jogs together. Now they are also learning to shoot together. Clara O'Leary was recently attacked, and she, her husband, Michael, and their daughter Michele MacKay are buying handguns.

title: A Bounty of Egyptian Imagery
description: WHERE revivals were concerned, the Classical and Gothic styles had no competition until late in the 18th century, when there developed an interest in Egypt. Ancient though the civilization was, few Europeans knew more of it than what could be gleaned from the classical writers and the Bible. But this was the Romantic era and its figurehead, Napoleon, put Egypt back on the map by invading it and beating the Turks at the Battle of the Pyramids, in 1798.

title: Review/Dance;   Elbow-Raising Debut By Feld and Scarlatti
description: ''Ah Scarlatti'' was the premiere by Eliot Feld Thursday night on his company's second program. The remaining three ballets were ''Theater,'' ''The Gods Amused'' and ''Danzon Cubano,'' all created by Mr. Feld in the 1970's and looking better than ever.

title: YEARNING FOR AN IRON HAND
description: Bill Keller's account of Russian nationalism brought to memory tales of the Russian past on which I was weaned (''Russian Nationalists: Yearning for an Iron Hand,'' Jan. 28). My Russian-born father would tell us about the events of the 1905 pogrom, when Cossacks broke into his home. My grandmother hid him in a wardrobe closet and covered him with blankets to save him from the drunken attackers, who beat her furiously, with cries of ''Kill the Yids and save Mother Russia.'' My grandmother suffered a paralytic stroke as a result of the attack. The pogrom was the childhood tale on which I was raised. Mr. Keller writes that ''Russian nationalism appeals to . . . a yearning for order. . . .'' and that ''Since olden days, the Russians have loved strong and cruel authority, and have loved its very cruelty. . . .'' These statements could have been made in the 1930's about the Germans.

title: WHEN BRITISH JUSTICE FAILED
description: Court No. 2 of the somber Old Bailey Courthouse in London was packed to capacity last Oct. 19. Ranks of wigged lawyers squeezed into the jury box. A hundred reporters crowded the back benches; the public gallery was overflowing - but the courtroom was deathly silent. As the Lord Chief Justice of England, Lord Lane, finished his summing up, his voice, quiet and restrained, carried to the back of the courtroom: ''These appeals are allowed and the convictions are quashed.''

title: Wall Street;   A Coming Money Manager Shakeout
description: While most people think of mutual funds and retirement accounts as something to invest in, the ''money management'' industry sees them as consumer products, like six-packs of beer or bottles of shampoo. And, heaven knows, money management has been a good business over the past 15 years, as household financial assets have grown sharply and the share of those assets under professional management has expanded as well.

title: The Mianus Gains Regional Support
description: A NEW volunteer organization called the Mianus River Watershed Council has been formed by Westchester and Connecticut residents who say that the only way to stem pollution of the river is through a regional effort.

title: Some Small Joys On New Disks Of Italian Operas
description: At hand are the five newest major-label recordings of mainstream Verdi and Rossini operas, and there is no use in delaying the report that all five are unsatisfying. A grand old maestro with offbeat casting, dedicated restudying of scores through critical editions, a defiant stand in favor of ''traditional'' interpretation, superstar casting - nothing seems to work. Is there any hope for Italian opera?

title: Hilary Lea and M. L. Bernard to Wed
description: Hilary Martin Lea and Matthew Lionel Bernard plan to marry in June, the prospective bride's parents, Avice S. Lea of Greenwich, Conn., and Charles L. Lea Jr. of New York, have announced. Mr. Bernard is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan H. Bernard of Greenwich.

title: Jane Silberman Wed To Jeffrey S. Tauber
description: At the Rittenhouse Hotel in Philadelphia, Jane Silberman and Jeffrey S. Tauber were married last evening by Rabbi Louis Kaplan. Mrs. Tauber, 27 years old, is the daughter of Mrs. Wesley G. Wood of West Chester, Pa., and the late Malcolm Silberman. Her husband, 28, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur S. Tauber of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Boca Raton, Fla.

title: On Language;   Unify or Reunify?
description: An agreed, managed process of German unification,'' wrote Henry Kissinger, ''would ease an otherwise festering crisis.''

title: Betsy Lucas to Wed Garret Vreeland
description: Mr. and Mrs. George Brainard Lucas Jr. of Watchung, N.J., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Elizabeth Ann Lucas and Garret Walker Vreeland, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Walker Vreeland of Summit, N.J.

title: D. P. Karnovsky to Wed Priscilla Cohn
description: Mr. and Mrs. Albert L. Cohn of West Orange, N.J., and Chilmark, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Priscilla Betsy Cohn to Daniel P. Karnovsky, the son of Prof. and Mrs. Manfred L. Karnovsky of Cambridge and Chilmark, Mass. An August wedding is planned.

title: Sampras Reaches Final
description: For 18-year-old Pete Sampras, a draw that became progressively unkind to superstars and inspirational to newcomers allowed him to use a big serve and cool nerves to reach his first career final at the Ebel Pro Indoor tournament. Already the youngest player entered in the event, today he became the youngest finalist since the tournament's inception 29 years ago.

title: Pastimes: Gardening;   A New Map and Book To Guide Plant Choices
description: The new hardiness zone map is out. It appears as end papers in the just-released book ''The National Arboretum Book of Outstanding Garden Plants'' by Jacqueline Heriteau with Dr. H. Marc Cathey, the arboretum's director. The 320-page book with 450 color photographs is available in bookstores ($39.95, Simon and Schuster).

title: Dawn Parker Marries Michael Heifetz
description: Dawn Leslie Parker and Michael Bruce Heifetz were married last evening at the Hilton in Short Hills, N.J. Rabbi Louis H. Frishman and Cantor Bruce Benson officiated. Michele Joan Parker, the bride's sister, was her maid of honor, and Scott Craig Heifetz, the bridegroom's brother, was the best man.

title: U.S. Hostages in Colombia Are Reported to Be Released
description: Leftist guerrillas today freed two Americans they abducted early last week to protest President Bush's visit to Colombia for a drug-fighting meeting, Colombian radio networks said.

title:
Your Own Account;

Linking Love and Money
description: LEAD: The predivorce wrangle between Donald Trump and his wife, Ivana, has focused attention on an increasingly common element in the contemporary marriage - the prenuptial agreement.

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: U.S. Investigates Copter Crashes in Panama
description: United States officials are investigating the crashes of two United States Army helicopters in Panama that killed all 11 servicemen aboard, the Southern Command said.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;

Something New Under the Sun! Babies!
description: LEAD: AS anyone who is about to become a grandparent can testify, this generation of prospective parents is the first ever to have children. (Which is perfectly consistent: it was the first ever to have relationships or to get married.) Today's young couples are having babies in an age of major obstetrical discoveries, all of which are based on one premise:

title: Campus Life: Pennsylvania;   Volunteers Take To the Street For Safety Patrol
description: As freezing winds blew across Spruce Street, a sophomore at the University of Pennsylvania, John Steele, was on patrol trying to protect fellow students from crime and his hands from the cold.

title: Marijuana Dealer Doomed
description: A Malaysian court today sentenced a man to hang for trafficking in marijuana but acquitted his wife, saying that she did not know about the 21 ounces of marijuana that the authorities found in their home. The condemned man, Abdullah Zawawi Yusoff, 41 years old, became the 248th person sentenced to death for drug trafficking since 1975.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Providence, R.I.;

2 Backers Quit Capital Center
description: LEAD: KEY components of Capital Center - this city's ambitious redevelopment on about 30 acres of former railroad yards between downtown and the Rhode Island State House - have suffered a setback as work progresses on several other elements.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS/BIOGRAPHY
description: JESSE JACKSON

title: The Trouble With Merrill
description: To the Editor:

title: For the Russians, Food and Shelter Are a Bigger Topic Than Germany
description: Yevgeny Alekseyev was born after World War II, and like most Soviet children, he had drummed into him in his youth the pain and devastation that his country endured at the hands of the German enemy.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: BOSTON;

Office Complex Gets Big Loan
description: LEAD: THE developer of the largest downtown office complex, the $700 million, 1.7 million-square-foot International Place, has received a $268 million construction loan from the Bank of Boston for its second and final phase.

title:
DINING OUT;

An Intimate Italian Spot in Port Chester
description: LEAD: CLUSTERED with several other intimate little Italian restuarants in the northeastern section of lower Westchester, Giorgio's has been one dining spot we have in the past enjoyed visiting. Recent visits revealed little change over the years in the tiny dining room and the menu, save for the prices.

title: Gifts to the Neediest Cases Honor the Dead by Helping Others
description: By a large margin, people who wish to memorialize those who have died make up the largest single category of donors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. In letters that accompany their gifts, they recall parents, spouses, siblings, children, friends and associates and seek to honor them by helping others.

title: Port Authority's Incinerator Role Questioned
description: A $300 MILLION solid-waste incinerator being built in Essex County with fund provided by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is drawing criticism on environmental and financial grounds as the massive waste-to-energy plant nears completion.

title: Students Deplore Plan to Shut Chicago Seminary
description: In recent weeks, the leafy campus of Quigley South Preparatory Seminary, the largest Roman Catholic high school seminary in the country, has been more the scene of protest and rebellion than of pastoral contemplation.

title: Two Teen-Agers Held in Slayings Of 2 in Bronx
description: A 14-year-old drug dealer and his 16-year-old companion were charged yesterday with shooting a couple dead in a car in the Bronx last week, the police said.

title: No Play, No Pay
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Fashion;   Romantic Adornments for the Modern Ponytail
description: This season, display cases of hair ornaments reflect a trend toward nostalgia and romance. At Block Pharmacy (1282 Third Avenue, near 74th Street), more than 500,000 headbands, bows, combs, barrettes and snoods are on display, priced from $2 to $400. Block is one of a number of stores that have expanded their inventory beyond packs of covered rubber bands. The profusion of styles and fabrics has greatly increased since 1988, when the craze began.

title: Further Thoughts On the Turnpike
description: I read with great interest and amusement the article (''Turnpike Seen as Metaphor for America,'' Jan. 14) on the book by Angus Kress Gillespie and Michael Aaron Rockland, ''Looking for America on the New Jersey Turnpike.'' Twenty years ago, I wrote a song called ''New Jersey the Beautiful,'' which contained:

title: Gerald G. Conway, News Director, 76
description: Gerald G. Conway, who was news director of WOR Radio when he retired in 1976 after 30 years with the station, died of leukemia on Thursday at St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains. He was 76 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

Dabbling Ducks And Diving Ducks
description: LEAD: TWENTY-TWO of us huddled at the edge of Cooper's Neck Pond in a cold northwest breeze. Ice had closed all but the middle of his small body of water on Meadow Lane. As a pair of American widgeon paddled by, we fumbled to focus our binoculars with gloved hands, a flock of bundled, Saturday morning birdwatchers.

title: U.S. Designers Find Bright Horizon in Japan
description: Sam Lopata, a daring and innovative designer, helped make the restaurant scene sizzle in New York in the 1980's. He worked on places that helped define the style of the time. Among them were Cafe Seiyoken, one of the first noisy, grand cafes; Pig Heaven, a whimsical Chinese restaurant filled with pink pigs, and Batons, an austere environment with concrete floors and black and white light fixtures.

title: 'WELL, COMRADES, HAVE WE FIXED THINGS UP?'
description: LEAD:

title: THIS BURROWED LIFE
description: NOTES ON THE UNDERGROUND

title: Tunnel Vision
description: Culturally speaking, it still has the ring of a contradiction in terms: a Los Angeles subway. Nonetheless, ground was broken for the city's Metro Rail system more than three years ago. And work on the first 4.4 miles - M.O.S. 1, or minimum operable segment - proceeds on schedule; Angelenos can anticipate underground travel beginning in the fall of 1993. Financed by Federal, state and local agencies, the cost of M.O.S. 1 is expected to surpass $1.25 billion.

title: Continuing the Fight Against Illiteracy
description: Every few years there is an article on the topic of adult illiteracy that ''is causing alarm among government and education officials and corporate managers.'' Perhaps one contributory reason for widespread illiteracy, among even United States-born people who have some degree of schooling, is that editors and writers are, in general, ill paid and not respected.

title: Jessica Newman Wed in Philadelphia
description: Jessica Joy Newman and Andrew M. Kronfeld were married last evening at the Hotel Atop the Bellevue in Philadelphia by Rabbi Seymour Rosenbloom. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Newman of Philadelphia. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey S. Kronfeld of Merion, Pa.

title: A Job Is Lost, a New Life Is Gained
description: GETTING fired is an awful experience, way up there with other big losses. Even in this era of massive layoffs, being shown the door is humiliating. When it happened to me in 1987, I took it very personally. Over and over, I asked myself: what could I have done differently?

title: Helping the Homeless to Help Themselves
description: LEAD: THERE is a new approach to helping the homeless: encouraging the homeless help themselves.

title: Galloping Gamay
description: Sonoma-Cutrer, a prominent California winery, uses one grape and makes only one wine from it: chardonnay. In this respect, Sonoma-Cutrer is unusual. Many wineries make only one wine, but they use a number of grapes to do it. For example, a Bordeaux chateau like Lafite-Rothschild makes only one wine, the world-famous red that bears its name, but it may use three, four or even five different grapes, in varying proportions.

title: Unrest in Ivory Coast's Capital Turns to Violence
description: A week of growing anti-Government protests turned violent today for the first time as fierce confrontations erupted between crowds of youths and heavily armed police officers and soldiers.

title: Reporter's Notebook;   In Queens, a Confessed Killer Pleads Not Guilty
description: You can't even confess to a murder these days without having things get out of hand.

title:
GARDENING;

Improving the Odds for Shade Trees
description: LEAD: MANY maples are being attacked by verticillium wilt. Pin oaks in some areas are being disfigured by severe infestations of a mite-induced twig gall. London planes are succumbing to anthracnose, a disease to which they were once considered resistant. Add these problems to the loss of the American chestnut and the

title: Mike Nichols Surveys the American Dream
description: The most revealing of Mike Nichols's films does not include any of the scenes he made famous: not Dustin Hoffman dragging Katharine Ross away from her own wedding in ''The Graduate,'' her bridal veil trailing in the breeze as they run to catch a bus; not the deglamorized Elizabeth Taylor in ''Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?,'' her wig shot with gray, her figure bulging out of tight pants, braying at Richard Burton, ''I don't braaay!''; and not Melanie Griffith in ''Working Girl,'' leaning off a bar stool and purring at Harrison Ford, ''I've got a brain for business and a bod for sin. Anything wrong with that?''

title: Q and A
description: Right to Sublet in a Co-op

title: Flight Smoking Ban at Hand
description: A Federal law that bans smoking on virtually all domestic airline flights takes effect Sunday. Under the law, smoking will be allowed only on flights of six hours or more - that is, on some trips between Hawaii or Alaska and the 48 contiguous states.

title: At 80, Fenwick Continues to Confront Challenges
description: TODAY is Millicent Fenwick's 80th birthday. The former diplomat and Republican Congresswoman from Bernardsville is battling her way into a new decade, fighting age and illness as tenaciously as she championed the political causes she espoused.

title: Further Views On the Turnpike
description: As a frequent driver on the New Jersey Turnpike and the parent of a Rutgers University student who has taken courses taught by Professors Gillespie and Rockland, I compliment them on their entertaining, informative book on the turnpike. But I must temper my compliments with criticism.

title: Harold Moore 3d to Wed Evelyn Milne
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry R. Milne of Ridge, L.I., have announced April wedding plans for their daughter, Evelyn Beth Milne, and Harold Gregory Moore 3d, a son of Lieut. Gen. Harold G. Moore, U.S.A. retired, and Mrs. Moore of Auburn, Ala.

title: World Markets
description: The Japanese stock market was in all but free fall last week, dropping 2,569.35 points, or 6.9 percent. One culprit was that old bugaboo - computerized program trading, one of the few unrestricted American imports into Japan. And most of the program trading is being done by American firms, Japanese analysts say.

title: 4 Shot Dead and 2 Wounded In Nightclub in Washington
description: Four people were killed early today in a shooting at a nightclub in a neighborhood that is a frequent scene of drug-related violence. At least two people were wounded.

title: AT THE TATE, A COMPELLING INSIDE JOB
description: Though for some years past a refugee from the chocolate sundae topped with fudge and pecan, this critic still cannot see a lump of sugar without thinking with gratitude of Henry Tate, who in late Victorian times was England's Mr. Sugar.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: KARIN L. BERGWALL;

Filling a Demand for Interim Managers
description: LEAD: SAY ''temporary employee,'' and most people would think clerical worker. But an increasing number of companies are hiring top-and mid-level executives and managers on a temporary basis. Karin L. Bergwall is the president of Princeton Entrepreneurial Resources, a concern that matches companies seeking high-level help with experienced executives for full-time or part-time assignments lasting one to 12 months.

title: Lifestyle;   A Country Club With Guns Instead of Golf Clubs
description: Imagine this. A date takes you to a posh private club in the Wall Street area. The atmosphere's cozy: forest green leather love seats, beige carpeting, white oak-paneled walls that discreetly hide private lockers, cable television, and soothing contemporary music piped in from a compact disc player. Seems ideal for two people wanting to get to know each other.

title: America Is Discovering One of Its Own
description: The voice may resonate glowingly, but the name doesn't exactly ring a bell. Having spent most of her career in European concert halls and opera houses, the American soprano Arleen Auger has established a footing in the United States only within the last decade. ''I'm a late bloomer,'' says the California native, who has been singing professionally for 25 years. ''I've been building my career here very slowly. I've said no to certain things and then waited for them to come again. Sometimes they come, sometimes they don't.''

title: Threading Fish Tape
description: THREADING electrical cable behind walls to extend existing circuits or to add new ones is seldom easy. But stiff, tempered-steel tape called fish tape is the tool designed for the job and professional electricians rely on it. Fish tape is also used to route cable through conduit.

title: U. S. Must Unload 30,000 Properties, And Please Don't Ask How's Business
description: THE Federal bailout of the savings and loan industry signed into law last summer was not just a simple matter of covering the depositors' losses. To recoup what it can, the Government is obliged to sell off billions of dollars in foreclosed property it inherited from hundreds of insolvent thrifts.

title: Fan's Wary View Of a Lockout
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Western Europe Is Edgy Over the U. S. and Much Else
description: AFTER 40 years in an alliance held together by the Soviet military threat, the United States and Western Europe have suddenly realized that things may never again be the same between them. When Cold War issues dominated, Western Europe never questioned Washington's leadership. Today, trans-Atlantic ties are being pulled in all directions.

title: Miss Taylor Wed To J. E. Dezell 3d
description: Jocelyn Clare Taylor, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James G. Taylor of Fairfield, Conn., was married there yesterday to James Elton Dezell 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dezell Jr. of Atlanta. The Rev. Ernest T. Esposito, assisted by Deacon David Sanford, an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at St. Pius X Roman Catholic Church.

title: Wolfpack Inquiry
description: As if he hasn't had enough problems lately, Jim Valvano, the North Carolina State basketball coach, has a new potential scandal on his hands. The News and Observer of Raleigh reported that North Carolina State officials were investigating a report that Charles Shackleford, a former Wolfpack star who now plays for the Nets, accepted an illicit payment of $65,000 during the 1987-88 college season.

title: After Police Death, Questions for Guido
description: LEAD: WHEN Suffolk County Police Commissioner Daniel P. Guido called the car-bomb death of a veteran undercover narcotics detective, Dennis Wustenhoff, an assassination that appeared to be job-related, his words resounded across Long Island and beyond like a sharp report from the front lines of the war on drugs.

title: Good Workers Respect Tools
description: While I read with interest the article on ''Things of Value: Worker or Tools?'' I found myself at odds with the writer's theme. My experience as both a lumber-truck driver and a public-works crew driver, while different than the machinist, had certain parallels.

title: BAD VIBRATIONS
description: WHALE MUSIC

title: 'Closer Than Ever' Is One From the Heart
description: ''Overeducated, understimulated, overoptimistic, underprepared, overcomplicating, noncooperating, hyperventilating, scared'' goes the opening line of Richard Maltby Jr.'s lyric for ''The March of Time,'' from the Off Broadway revue ''Closer Than Ever.''

title: One Woman's Blues
description: To the Editor:

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Boston;

Office Complex Gets Big Loan
description: LEAD: THE developer of the largest downtown office complex, the $700 million, 1.7 million-square-foot International Place, has received a $268 million construction loan from the Bank of Boston for its second and final phase.

title: W. G. Roll to Wed Jane H. Choremi
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alec M. Choremi of Glen Head, L.I., have announced April wedding plans for their daughter, Jane Helen Choremi, and Walter George Roll, the son of Linda L. Roll of Locust Valley, L.I., and Peter B. Roll of San Francisco.

title: Borrowing Trouble
description: Luella Wilson thought she could afford to lend her great-nephew money for a car in 1984, but it nearly cost her everything she owned. The great-nephew, Willard Stuart, driving without a license and with alcohol and drugs in his system, ran the car off a bridge in an accident that partially paralyzed a passenger, Mark Vince. Under the doctrine of negligent entrustment, Mr. Vince's lawyer sued Mrs. Wilson, charging that she was negligent for lending a relative money for the car. In 1987, a jury found her liable for $950,000 in damages, more than her life savings combined with the value of her small farm in Vermont. But then a state appeals court ordered a retrial, saying that the auto dealer who sold the car should have also been a defendant. The case was settled last week under terms that will allow Mrs. Wilson to keep her home. (Insurance companies for the dealer and Mrs. Wilson will pay.) ''It's all over and I'm tickled to death,'' she said. But the point, said Mr. Vince's lawyer, is that dealers ''know now that if they sell cars to people like Willard Stuart they will be held liable.''

title: Republic by Republic, Soviet Vote Points to a Murky Political Future
description: Like many of the thousands of candidates campaigning for local office across the maddening new landscape of Soviet politics, Vladimir M. Rylyakov is a practicing Communist who is wondering what happened to Communism.

title: Upheaval in the East:A Shadow Over the Kremlin;   Soviet Position at 'Open Skies' Talks Puzzles West
description: With the first round of the ''open skies'' talks between NATO and the Warsaw Pact in its final week in Ottawa, the Soviet Union's approach is puzzling Western diplomats, prompting speculation that Moscow might plan to break off negotiations for internal political reasons.

title: Correction
description: An article on Feb. 11 about an outcry by Ringwood residents over a proposal to develop a portion of Sterling Forest misstated Jerome Wyckoff's role on the borough's Environmental Commission. He is a past chairman and a longtime member of the commission, not its founder.

A new regimen for weight loss. 3 2 11 THE GREAT WALDO SEARCH, by Martin Handford (Little, Brown $10.95.) A book of illustrations in which the game is to find an ubiquitous chap named Waldo. 4 1 BEWARE THE NAKED MAN WHO OFFERS YOU HIS SHIRT, by Harvey Mackay. (Morrow, $19.95.) Advice on how to get ahead in business in the '90's. 5 1 A BETTER WAY TO LIVE, by Og Mandino. (Bantam, $14.95.) Inspiration and "rules to live by" to achieve worldly success.

title: Mutual Funds;   Will Rising Assets Lower Fees?
description: The mutual fund business recently rang in a record-breaking $1 trillion in assets, and that was good news for the industry. But it should also be good news for investors. Higher assets should translate into lower fees as costs are spread over a broader base.

title: Galactic Evenness Gives Astronomers Pause
description: Astronomers have discovered more than a dozen evenly distributed clumps of galaxies stretching across vast expanses of the heavens, suggesting a structure to the universe so regular and immense that it defies current theories of cosmic creation and evolution.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week;   Was the Strickland Trade a Good One?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Best in Injuries
description: The Seattle SuperSonics may have no better than a middling record in the National Basketball Association's Pacific Division, but the team has one consolation of sorts: its injured-reserve list may be the best in the league, and it's getting better.

title: Parents Must Demand Better Principals
description: MOST recent education reform has been a ''top down'' effort. The governors of several states and a handful of education commissioners have taken the lead in addressing problems in the schools. In Connecticut, both the Governor and the Commissioner of Education are acknowledged leaders in this area.

title: The Bonus Boys
description: Once upon a time, in an earlier life, wise men came to instruct me in the ways of something called Management Incentive Compensation, which was always pronounced reverentially, capital letters understood.

title: Lieut. Gen. James Gavin, 82, Dies; Champion and Critic of Military
description: Lieut. Gen. James M. Gavin, a World War II commander who went on to become a top Army administrator, a diplomat and a leading management consultant, died of complications from Parkinson's disease on Friday at the Keswick Nursing Home in Baltimore. He was 82 years old and had homes in Wianno, Mass., and Winter Park, Fla.

title: Pastimes;   Stamps
description: There is one mail fraud that seems to persist despite a year-long effort by the United States Postal Service to halt it.

title: PURGES, PUNCHES AND OTHER CRIMES
description: BETWEEN TWO FIRESEurope's Path in the 1930s.

title: Teen-Ager Honored As Top U.S. Driver Is Killed in Accident

title: FICTION
description: HUMAN MOURNING. By Jose Revueltas. Translated by Roberto Crespi. Introduction by Octavio Paz. (University of Minnesota, Cloth, $22.50; Paper, $9.95.) First published in Spanish in 1943 and the winner of Mexico's National Literary Prize, ''Human Mourning'' is Jose Revueltas's first novel to appear in English. Together with Mariano Azuela's ''Underdogs'' and Martin Luis Guzman's ''Shadow of the Leader,'' this novel of three families who refuse to leave their parched land after the failure of a bitter antigovernment strike is considered essential reading for those wishing to understand the effects of the Mexican revolution on the peasant masses. As the novel opens, heavy rains have begun, and those left behind seek refuge on a rooftop. With the flood waters rising, the campesinos question their personal and collective past. Neither a chronicle nor a traditional narrative, this difficult novel, ably translated by Roberto Crespi, introduces characters who are both real and symbolic but who somehow never manage to come sufficiently alive. At his best, Revueltas (who died in 1976) creates a desolate rural landscape that mirrors the desperate and contradictory souls of the characters. But Revueltas overwhelms the reader with rhetoric and polemics, with images and memories, often carelessly piled on, and much of the book's action is internalized. Still, Revueltas's writing can be both moving and dramatic, as when, toward the end of the novel, buzzards begin to circle, waiting for the survivors to die. Included with the text are Octavio Paz's original 1943 review, as well as a 1979 essay in which he retracts much of his earlier criticism and also clarifies for the reader Revueltas's religious and political concerns.

title: Currency;   No Bottom Yet for the Yen
description: Expect more skirmishes this week in the so-far losing battle to boost the swooning yen. There was some hope last week that the yen would strengthen, given the victory on Sunday of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party in Japan's national elections and the expectation that the Bank of Japan would soon raise its discount rate. But the yen sagged, closing the week in New York at 147 to the dollar, down from 144 the week before. On Friday, the Bank of Japan tried to provide support by selling dollars for yen in Japan while the Federal Reserve did the same thing in New York. The yen responded only temporarily. More intervention is likely this week and a further decline could prod the Bank of Japan to move faster to raise rates.

title: NONFICTION
description: ROOSEVELT AND MARSHALL: Partners in Politics and War. By Thomas Parrish. (Morrow, $25.) In 1943, as President Franklin D. Roosevelt was weighing the candidates for leading the invasion of Europe, he told General Dwight D. Eisenhower that he was giving most serious consideration to the Army's Chief of Staff, George Catlett Marshall, because otherwise ''fifty years from now practically nobody will know who George Marshall was.'' Thomas Parrish's excellent history underscores that while Eisenhower was F.D.R.'s final choice and earned his own place in history, Marshall's place is equally secure. In ''Roosevelt and Marshall,'' it is Marshall who emerges as the more interesting of the pair, perhaps only because F.D.R. is better known. In World War I in France, Marshall began building his professional reputation as a staff officer by planning the gigantic concentration of American troops for the Meuse-Argonne offensive. As Chief of Staff, his relations with both Congress and the White House were key to building a small peacetime army into a vast machine. Indeed, Speaker of the House Sam Rayburn once told F.D.R. that when Marshall testified, ''we forget whether we are Republicans or Democrats. We just remember that we are in the presence of a man who is telling the truth.'' The President replied that even when he disapproved a Marshall recommendation, he could be sure that the general would continue to ''give me the most loyal support as chief of staff that any President could wish.''

title: Men's Style;   A New Work Ethic
description: THey are honest, romantic, sincere. Theyhave integrity. And they are sexy. Terms usually invoked to decribe friends, lovers, and sometimes, politicians, are the ones that crop up most when the topic turns to work clothes. Mention any one of those familiar and functional items, ranging from T-shirts to overalls to fishermen's caps, and the conversation takes on a high tone with a sentimental edge. Trend watchers are quick to point out that a resurgent interest in mechanics' coveralls, sanitation workers' slickers, cooks' shirts and ever-so-humble blue jeans expresses a yearning to return to a simpler way of life. ''Our focus is shifting from competing in the city to minding the house in the country,'' says Harold Koda, curator of the costume collection at the Fashion Institute of Technology in New York. Gerald C. Celente, the director of the Socio-Economic Research Institute of America, a consumer trend-analysis service, maintains that people want more control over their lives. ''Since the October crash on Wall Street,'' Celente says, ''people have increasingly refused to give their lives to the company.'' Work clothes become equalizers. Yet, though they rarely express protest or defiance, as they did in the 1960's, their very plainness tends to assert the wearer's personality. Clothing worn by policemen, construction workers or short-order cooks also boasts the virtue of making men feel virile. This may be a matter of fit. In a ruminative essay on blue jeans, Umberto Eco noted that because they held the hips, jeans put a man more in touch with his body. Eco observed that wearing a particularly snug-fitting pair of denims made him think about ''the relationship between me and my pants . . . I had achieved heteroconsciousness,'' he said, ''that is to say an epidermic self-awareness.''

title: German Questions No One Wants to Ask

title: FICTION
description: HARDSCRUB. By Lionel G. Garcia. (Arte Publico, Paper, $9.) ''What makes you so sure that they're her children?'' asks a man on a bus as he scrutinizes the mother and sons who are the focus of ''Hardscrub.'' ''Why she hit 'em,'' is his wife's immediate response. That premise - the parent-child bond as defined by violence -is the focus of this bracing new novel by Lionel G. Garcia, who won the 1983 PEN Southwest Award for his novel ''Leaving Home.'' Jim, the protagonist and narrator, is a precocious adolescent growing up in the arid, small-town world of West Texas in the early 1950's. Jim's sister and mother are the objects of his father's scorn and ridicule, but it is his brother, Richard, who receives most of the blows, and worse. Jim admires the older boy for standing up to their father, for simply being his brother and - although Jim knows it's wrong - for being an elegant and accomplished thief. As the novel proceeds, the bedraggled family is by turns abused and abandoned by the man who never wanted any of them. If this sounds terribly depressing, it is. But ''Hardscrub'' is also enlivened by Mr. Garcia's sense of humor and irony. Early on, for example, Jim's mother tries to comfort him, saying that his father ''may not be first class, but I believe that deep down he loves us. He just doesn't know it.'' To which Jim sensibly responds, ''When's he supposed to find out how much he loves us?''
