title: Where Did This Name Come From?
description: A TRIP over New Jersey's highways and byways could become much more interesting if the automobile passengers - especially families with young children - engage in a hypothesizing exercise about how certain places got their names.

title: Outdoors;   Proposal for Salmon Fishery
description: A proposal to use surplus brood stock of Atlantic salmon to provide a put-and-take sport fishery for the species in a section of the Merrimack River in New Hampshire has distressed many of those who have for years been laboring to restore spawning runs of those highly prized food and game fish to the rivers of New England.

title: Vintage Popular Music Gets Classical Respect
description: THEY look like classical performers, and they do take their music seriously, but members of the New World Consort play jazz, ragtime and ''jumps,'' and they sometimes stomp their feet and shout ''Ha-ha-ha!'' during concerts.

title: The West Helped to Create the Nazi Monster
description: To the Editor:

title: A CHILD'S GARDEN OF SUBVERSION
description: There exists in our world an unusual, partly savage tribe, ancient and widely distributed, yet until recently little studied by anthropologists or historians. All of us were at one time members of this tribe: we knew its customs, manners and rituals, its folklore and sacred texts. I refer, of course, to childhood.

title: Bridge Repairs Can Leave Stores Stranded on a Road to Ruin
description: LEAD: SINCE business has dropped at Jeffrey S. Donaldson's delicatessen his order has been too small for his grocery distributor. So Mr. Donaldson has been stocking his store by shopping with coupons at supermarkets, he said.

title: Track Is Factor In Horse Ratings
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's quite wonderful and quite easy, isn't it? I rejoice in the fact that when the going gets rough, I don't have to put up with it. Spiritually I'm in a wonderful, calm place.''

title: Auto-Leasers Look to a New Market
description: AS the Federal income-tax law eliminates deductions for interest charges and sales tax, automobile leasers in the county are hoping to attract a new type of customer. They say they are optimistic that more drivers will decide to lease a car for personal use instead of financing an automobile purchase.

title: Getting Arafat to Sit For a TV Portrait
description: Putting Yasir Arafat in an hourlong documentary film is like pinning down a ball of mercury: a heroic effort requiring patience, perseverence and a great deal of money.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a caption with the Technology column on Feb. 4 about the neurotransmitter serotonin misstated the chemical's formula. It is C10H12N2O.

title: Boston Police Actions Investigated by F.B.I.
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has opened a preliminary inquiry into charges that the Boston police exerted pressure on witnesses to develop evidence against a black man in the killing of Carol Stuart.

title: Tribal Feuds Won't Let Up in South Africa's East
description: Thandabantu David Ntombela is the headman at Elandskop, a Zulu community 60 miles west of Durban. He says he is a good Methodist who deplores violence and trusts in the Lord. He also carries a .38-caliber revolver under his shirt.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Yeats Unabated

title:
IN SHORT;

NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: THE POSTHUMOUS ADVENTURES OF LOUIS KAHN
description: These are heady days for the memory of Louis I. Kahn. The architect died 16 years ago next month, perhaps the most respected presence in his profession. And the intervening years seem only to have enriched Kahn's reputation still more, to the point where it is now no exaggeration to call him the most venerated figure in 20th-century American architecture after Frank Lloyd Wright.

title: The Executive Computer;   Can the Old Processing Technology Beat Back a Challenge?
description: Some hot new processors still rely on Complex Instruction Set Computing. THE Series 6000 work stations introduced by the International Business Machines Corporation earlier this month clearly demonstrate the fundamental speed advantages of the technology called Reduced Instruction Set Computing. The RISC machines use a type of simplified processor chip that yields performance once found only among computers costing 10 to 100 times as much. It would be premature, however, to proclaim the triumph of RISC technology over the more familiar chips that use CISC, or Complex Instruction Set Computing. These chips are at the heart of almost all the personal computers used in businesses, including I.B.M. PC's and PS/2's and compatible machines, Apple's Macintosh and even some low-end work stations. Do the new RISC-based work stations make them obsolete? Hardly.

title: Clarify and Vivify
description: To the Editor:

title: Food;   Homecoming
description: When I was a small child in Chicago, my mother began what became a repeated chant: we must return one day to gu xiang, ''the village of our ancestors.'' She became more urgent with time as she began to fear she would be too old to make the journey. And when China opened to travelers in 1978, my mother's determination grew. I fancy myself as Westernized, but I know my filial duties. I was going to travel with her.

title: Elegant, Practical Finnish Decorative Arts
description: FINLAND is probably the only country in the world where the designers of mundane objects can achieve stardom. The Finnish custom of lionizing artists started in 1900 when a team of architects and designers headed by Eliel Saarinen astonished the world with their realization of the national pavilion at the Paris World's Fair, an elaborate, shingled building in the National Romantic style. A half century later, the designers of the Finnish exhibit at the 1951 Milan Triennial carried off more prizes than any other country and were welcomed home like Olympic heroes. During the same period industry snapped up leading designers like Kaj Franck, Tapio Wirkkala and Timo Sarpaneva with the avidity of a younger George Steinbrenner going after free agents.

title: Boat People to Fight Hong Kong in Court
description: A fisherman from the south of Vietnam who said the Communist Government in Hanoi forced him to clear mine fields and gather grenades by hand gained permission today to challenge the way this British colony decides the fate of tens of thousands of boat people.

title: Yellow Jackets Prevail in Overtime
description: The freshman Kenny Anderson matched his season high with 32 points, including 5 in overtime, as Georgia Tech held off Notre Dame, 88-80, today.

title: Bridgeport is Fighting Its 'Dump City' Image
description: WALKING along the wintry shoreline of Seaside Park in Bridgeport, William Garrett paused to study the statue of the showman and entrepreneur P. T. Barnum, once the city's Mayor. The gaze of the imposing bronze likeness is fixed on the murky waters of Long Island Sound.

title: France on 1,500 Calories a Day
description: THERE must be a way to visit France and not gain weight; otherwise, there would be nothing but fat Frenchmen. Over the years my bulk increased with each vacation until I reached 233 pounds - a very uncomfortable weight, even for a man of 6 feet 2. Then, working with a colleague who specializes in clinical nutrition, I shed the detritus of a lifetime of abusive eating and emerged, one year later, a svelte and happy 182 pounds.

title: No Longer A Celebration
description: To the Editor:

title: WHEN THE NILE MET THE MISSISSIPPI
description: Egyptomania in American decorative arts lingered longer than most revival styles, lasting from the Civil War until World War II. Temple-shaped clocks and sphinx-embellished coffee urns proliferated in the nation's parlors and dining rooms while children learned their A B C's with obelisks of alphabet blocks.

title: U.S. Nuclear Strategy in Disarray
description: As the United States restructures its military forces and reduces military spending, it is imperative that it do so in a way that reduces the risk of nuclear war. But the first Bush defense budget moves us in the opposite direction - toward increased reliance on nuclear weapons and increased risk of a nuclear war that neither superpower wants.

title: Speaking for Himself
description: Nelson Mandela may be viewed by much of the world as a man to be admired, but Jon Westling, the acting president of Boston University, begs to differ. When the superintendent of the Chelsea public schools, Diana Lam, cited Mr. Mandela as a crusader for human rights in a speech, Mr. Westling dashed off a letter sternly apprising her of his disapproval. The Boston Globe reported last week that Mr. Westling, as head of the university that has been managing the Chelsea school system, wrote Ms. Lam that ''Nelson Mandela is not someone who should be held up as an heroic example of patient commitment to a good cause.'' Mr. Mandela, who was freed this month after 27 years in prison for his role as head of the African National Congress, has refused to call for an end of violent opposition to racial oppression in South Africa, where blacks are denied all manner of rights. Mr. Westling implied that in taking this stance, Mr. Mandela had somehow ''thrown in his lot with killers.'' Ms. Lam, the Globe said, was ''very upset'' by the letter.

title: Miss Filan, a Law Student, Is Married in Connecticut
description: Deirdre Mary Filan, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James K. Filan of Westport, Conn., was married there yesterday at St. Luke Roman Catholic Church to Francis Joseph Curtis 3d, the son of Nancy C. Duane of Manhasset, L.I., and the late Mr. Curtis Jr. The Rev. Thomas J. Driscoll officiated.

title: Hers;   Going Off The Deep End
description: I didn't take swimming lessons because of my 40th birthday. I'd like to blame it on that, but it isn't true. I took them because of my 7-year-old daughter, Teal. I could see it in her eyes. She already hated the water as much as I did.

title: Knicks Eager to Confront Pistons at the Garden
description: The Miami Heat, in its second season, is not expected to beat teams like the Detroit Pistons, the defending National Basketball Association champion. But after his team was held below 90 points and lost to the Pistons for a third straight time last week, Rony Seikaly blurted some words of wisdom.

title: Nicaragua Sees War of Screaming Headlines
description: The television commercial, set to ominous funeral music, showed Violeta Barrios de Chamorro smiling through a succession of bloody images - mutilated children, Nazi swastikas, raging fires and menacing rebels.

title: Teachers Say Yesterday's Texts Can't Keep Pace in Today's World
description: LAST September, when students returned to Granby High School, they were greeted with brand-new social studies textbooks. ''If only we had waited a year,'' said Jeanette W. Wiggin, the school system's director of curriculum and instruction. Within months, the textbooks, which cost $16,000, became outdated by the sweeping changes in the world, especially in Eastern Europe.

title: 'HE DIDN'T TOUCH ME ONCE'
description: BLUE TAXIS

title: San Francisco Becomes a 'Class Action' Suitor
description: For two weeks this winter, the San Francisco supervisors were ousted from their dome-ceilinged chamber in City Hall, courtesy of legislation they themselves had authorized.

title: Joelle Mast Weds Paul A. Loughran
description: At St. Catharine's Roman Catholic Church in Spring Lake, N.J., Dr. Joelle Mast, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Mast of Brielle, N.J., was married yesterday to Paul Andrew Loughran, a son of Mrs. George A. Loughran of Little Neck, Queens, and the late Mr. Loughran. Msgr. Henry Mansell, the chancellor of the Archdiocese of New York, performed the ceremony, assisted by Msgr. James Wilders.

title: It's Troika Time at the Philharmonic
description: It is not often that good luck comes disguised as a calamity. That, however, may be what is happening to the New York Philharmonic in its efforts to replace Zubin Mehta as music director. Having failed to induce Leonard Bernstein, its laureate conductor, to return to his old post with the orchestra and having lost out to the Berlin Philharmonic for the services of the next-best candidate, Claudio Abbado, Philharmonic officials have been flirting with a variety of more or less promising possibilities. To this point, the orchestra's luck has held up: none of the more frequently named suspects has been willing or able to accept the baton that Mr. Mehta is handing on.

title:
FOCUS: Washington;

Turning Pennsylvania Avenue Into a Neighborhood
description: LEAD: When models at the Pennsylvania apartment building open next month, they will be the first new residences on Pennsylvania Avenue in more than a century.

title: 'Whose Broker?'
description: To the Editor:

title: Of Church and State and Cuomo
description: FIRST, one Roman Catholic bishop warned Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York that he was in serious danger of going to hell, and the Archbishop of New York didn't disagree. Now, the new bishop of Brooklyn has said that Mr. Cuomo had better watch what he says in his home borough.

title: Black and White And Gray
description: Let's talk about race.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: February 25, 1990
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 1 STAR, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $5.95.) The crossed paths of a man and a woman, both destined for stardom, one in Washington, the other in Hollywood. 2 4 WEB OF DREAMS, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $5.50.) The origin of a curse that has haunted a family of orphans in five previous novels. 3 4 THE FORTUNE, by Michael Korda. (Warner, $5.95.) A young woman's ill-fated romance with the head of America's richest family. 4 5 MUTATION, by Robin Cook. (Berkley, $4.95.) A physician's attempt to create a superior child results in a prodigy that turns into a terror. 5 4 BILLY BATHGATE, by E. L. Doctorow (Harper Paperbacks, $5.95.) The life of a 1930's gangster. 6 3 BLACK SAND, by William J. Caunitz. (Bantam, $5.95.) A New York cop joins a Greek policeman in a deadly pursuit of a stolen ancient artifact. 7 4 FRENCH KISS, by Eric V. Lustbader. (Fawcett, $5.95.) (Signet/NAL, $5.95.) The family tragedy that came to light after the 1984 murder of a Toms River, N.J. woman. 3 11 NEW KIDS ON THE BLOCK, by Grace Catalano (Bantam, $3.50.) The lives and predilections of the five members of a teen-age singing group. 4 4 IN BROAD DAYLIGHT, by Harry N. MacLean. (Dell, $4.95.) title: Paris Said to Halt Arms Aid to Sihanouk's Forces
description: Senior guerrilla officials say France has halted its arms supplies to a guerrilla group fighting Cambodia's Communist Government after the covert program was publicized.

title: Vincent Teresa, 61; Mafia Aide Became Informer and Author
description: Vincent Teresa, a colorful, obese New England crime figure of the 1950's and 60's who became a Federal informer and later was a co-author of two books about his underworld experiences, died of kidney failure Wednesday in Seattle, The Associated Press reported. He was 61 years old.

title: Pastimes;   Around the Garden
description: For This Week: When there are mild days to work outside, fertilizer can be applied to evergreens, young trees, fruit trees, perennials; the nutrients will be soaked in by spring rains. Lime lawns with a calibrated spreader; if the earth is wet and soggy, stay off. Last call to mail orders for nursery plants and seeds.

title: MOSTLY MIRACULOUS
description: LEAD:

title: Tony Conigliaro; Ex-Outfielder, 45, Starred for Red Sox
description: Tony Conigliaro, the former Boston Red Sox outfielder who had struggled to overcome a beaning that interrupted his career, died of kidney failure Saturday afternoon. He was 45 years old.

title: 2 Groups Are to Open A Series at Town Hall
description: A performance by the Manhattan Marimba Quartet and the Women of the Calabash will open a New Riffs series at 8 P.M. on March 6 at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street.

title: Beau Genius Wins by 2 1/4 Lengths
description: Beau Genius, who provided Bill Shoemaker with his final career victory in a photo finish three weeks ago, had an even easier triumph under Craig Perret today as he rallied to win the $50,000 Deputy Minister Handicap at Gulfstream Park.

title: Woman Dies in a Fire Of Suspicious Origin
description: A 48-year-old Queens woman died in a fire of suspicious origin that caused extensive damage to her home in Springfield Gardens last night, the police said.

title: Jackson Rules Out Mayor's Race In Washington, Associates Say
description: Jesse Jackson has told supporters he will not run for mayor here, associates say.

title: Mandela Urges Blacks of Natal to End Deadly Rivalry
description: Nelson Mandela urged his followers today to bring an immediate halt to the factional warfare that has swept Natal's black townships and taken more than 2,500 lives in the last five years.

title: Bush Says Climate Will Warm if Fair Vote Is Seen
description: President Bush said today that if the Sandinistas win the Nicaraguan elections the United States will move to improve relations, provided that the elections are judged free and fair.

title: Bridge
description: When the 1977 world team championships were played in Manila, two United States teams clashed in the final. This was thought to detract from the international flavor of the event, and the World Bridge Federation set rules that would prevent this from happening again. American teams have had to meet in the semifinal, and the same has applied to European teams.

title: Review/Theater;   A Brechtian Salvo Against the Military Life
description: Galy Gay is an Irish-born waterfront porter in Kilkoa, India, who goes out one day to buy a fish for his dinner and ends up commanding a machine-gun unit in the Imperial Army on the Tibetan front.

title: NICARAGUA IS CALM IN HEAVY TURNOUT FOR CRITICAL VOTE
description: Under intense international scrutiny, this war-battered country voted today in the first free and broadly contested elections in its history. There were few reports of violence and strong signs of an overwhelming voter turnout.

title: Giant 'Eggs' Could Transport Oil Safely
description: To the Editor:

title: Vote 'Em Out, but Don't Limit Terms
description: The public has got the idea that Congress is self-perpetuating, and a companion idea that limiting members' terms of service would set things right. Both ideas are wrong, and so is a proposed constitutional amendment to limit terms to 12 years.

title: Judge Orders End to Race Barrier in Cemetery
description: A fence separating poorly tended graves of blacks from neatly kept graves of whites must come down, said a United States district judge in ordering a private cemetery to provide equal care to all its sections.

title: Bush and Kohl Struggle for Notes of Calm As the Headlong Rush to Unity Gives Pause
description: President Bush and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany spoke at length today about their ''similar views'' and ''common dreams,'' but on the difficult aspects of German reunification, they spoke with distinctly different voices while avoiding outright discord.

title: Even the '85 Pact Has Points at Issue
description: In the baseball club owners' most recent proposals in their labor dispute with the players, they have included a somewhat unusual element. ''Sign off on memorandum of understanding so as to permit immediate contract production,'' article IX of their Feb. 21 proposal says.

title: New York State Issue Comes to Market
description: Treasury financings this week are confined to today's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills. By late Friday, the outstanding three-month issue was bid at 7.68 percent, while the six-month issue was bid at 7.69 percent.

title: Nationalists Victorious In Lithuanian Election
description: The republic of Lithuania received a rousing push toward independence today as the Soviet Communist Party, put to the test in the Soviet Union's first free multiparty election in seven decades, was overwhelmingly rebuffed by voters.

title: East Germany's Social Democrats Back a Candidate and a Unification Plan
description: The East German Social Democrats, who are expected to get the most votes in the elections to Parliament on March 18, ended their first congress today by choosing a candidate for Prime Minister and presenting a timetable without a deadline for German reunification.

title: Further Rises in Rates Expected
description: Upward pressure on interest rates in Japan and West Germany is expected to continue to influence the domestic credit rate structure this week and in the near future.

title: Poland's Rush for Modern Banks
description: Marian Kanton, the president of Bank Polska Kasa Opieki S.A., readily admits that Poland's banking system is far behind the West's.

title: Reviews/Music;   Taking a Musical Trip by Cabaret Back to 1938
description: To cram almost 40 songs from a single year - 1938 - into a one-hour cabaret program and make it something more than a run-through of song titles is a challenge to a singer's ingenuity. But Spider Saloff and Ricky Ritzel, who opened at Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street, on Tuesday, are showing that it can be done with enough time to spare for period-setting headlines, radio commercials and even a brief Burns and Allen takeoff.

title: East Berlin Party Offers Unity Plan
description: The East German Social Democrats, favorites in the March 18 elections, presented a detailed plan for reunification as they ended their Congress.

title: P.L.O. Offers to Mediate for Lebanon's Christians
description: Two people died and five were wounded today in another day of artillery and rocket duels in East Beirut as the Palestine Liberation Organization offered to mediate in the conflict between rival Christian forces, its past enemies.

title: Korean Protesters Condemn U.S.
description: Protesters shouting anti-Government and anti-United States slogans tried to stone an American diplomat's residence today in Kwangju and clashed with the police in four other cities, according to Korean news reports and witnesses.

title: Outdoors: Angler Show Is Well Stocked
description: NOW in its 13th year, the World Fishing and Outdoor Exposition, at Rockland Community College in Suffern, N.Y., has become, for many winter-weary anglers, an eagerly awaited harbinger of spring nearly as salubrious to the spirit as the April 1 opening of the trout season.

title: Sampras, 18, Gets First Pro Victory
description: There had been no dates, no diploma, no proms and no pranks for 18-year-old Pete Sampras since he turned professional two years back. There had also been no entourage, no hair dye and, until today, no titles for Sampras, an Opie-lookalike who studied work ethic under the expert tutelage of Ivan Lendl and used it all week here to lay the groundwork for a 7-6, 7-5, 6-2 demotion of Andres Gomez in the Ebel Pro Indoor final.

title: Governor of North Carolina Says He's Quitting Politics
description: Gov. James G. Martin has decided against seeking any elective office after his term ends in 1992, saying he wanted to preclude criticism that he was positioning himself for future campaigns.

title: Manama Journal;   Atop High Horses, Neighbors Again Cross Swords
description: A soccer-tournament emblem depicting two horses that symbolize an old military setback for Saudi Arabia has caused a long-simmering feud between Saudis and Kuwaitis to explode.

title: Chronicle
description: An Eastern Air Lines ticket folder signed by MOTHER TERESA with the words ''God bless you'' added fetched $80 Saturday evening at an auction to benefit Miami-Dade Community College business students. The winning bid was from JUDITH MENDEL, whose husband is an autograph dealer. The folder was donated by EDWARD J. KROHN, head of the college's South Campus Business Administration Department. He ran into Mother Teresa, who has received the Nobel Peace Prize, in the San Francisco Airport. It was one of more than 1,100 items solicited by Mr. Krohn from celebrities the world over.

title: Excerpts From the News Conference Held by Bush and Kohl
description: Following are excerpts from a news conference today by President Bush and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany, provided by Federal News Service, a transcription company, and the White House. Questions and answers in German were translated by an interpreter.

title: Nicklaus Aims to Bridge Ages
description: Now that he has publicly challenged himself to become the first player ever to win a regular PGA Tour event and a Senior event in the same year, Jack Nicklaus has spent the last month preparing his game with an intensity he hasn't shown in several years.

title: Chronicle
description: Washington architecture aficionados were relieved when PRESIDENT BUSH reappointed J. CARTER BROWN to the Commission of Fine Arts, a panel that oversees preservation of the capital's plan and the historic district of Georgetown. Mr. Brown, director of the National Gallery of Art, will serve his fifth term on the panel. He has been its chairman for 18 years.

title: CHINA IS WATCHING WATCHERS CLOSELY
description: Despite the lifting of martial law in the capital last month, the Chinese authorities appear to have intensified their efforts to keep foreign journalists under surveillance and limit their unofficial contacts with Chinese, Beijing-based correspondents and some Chinese say.

title: Reviews/Music;   Mel Lewis Group Plays On Without Him
description: When big bands lose their leaders but continue to work, they are usually labeled ghost bands by musicians. It is an apt title; the bands often become ephemeral and fade away. Based on a set the Mel Lewis Orchestra played at the Village Vanguard on Tuesday night, it's obvious that the band - which will keep working every Monday night at the club (Seventh Avenue South at 11th Street) - is in no danger of fading away. Mr. Lewis, who died last month, was a funny, relaxed leader, and his presence still permeates the band.

title: Top Positions Are Filled At Wheelchair Maker
description: Barre L. Rorabaugh, who last worked for a health and fitness company, has been named president and chief executive of Everest & Jennings International Ltd., the nation's leading maker of wheelchairs.

title: Pepsi Is Open for Business in India
description: A company called Pepsi Foods made its debut in India last week, selling cumin-flavored potato chips and an Indian version of Cheetos seasoned with fenugreek.

title: Right Way to Read The Military Budget
description: To the Editor:

title: New Role For Bank In Germany
description: The rapid move toward the unification of the two Germanys is pushing the West German Government and the country's renowned central bank, the Bundesbank, to the center of the world's economic stage alongside the United States and Japan.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Trade Talks Seem to Be at Impasse;   Tokyo Says Requests Are 'Unreasonable'
description: When the political leaders of the United States and Japan agreed last summer to begin talks over how the most fundamental characteristics of their national economies might change, bureaucrats on both sides said the effort would create frustration and ill will.

title: Mexico Attacks a Habit of Tax Evasion and Starts to Increase Its Revenue
description: A well-known pop singer has been thrown into jail, accused of having evaded more than $400,000 in taxes. Government auditors have showed up in stores, auto-repair shops, dentists' offices and executive suites across the country, burrowing into financial records and comparing them with tax returns from recent years.

title: DEALS
description: HOCKEY HARTFORD (NHL) - Recalled Al Tuer, defenseman, from Binghamton of the American Hockey League. Sent Terry Yake, center, to Binghamton.

title: Caravan of Cars Enters Kennedy To Protest Crash
description: A caravan of about 1,000 cars, many bearing Colombian flags and cardboard placards, drove through Kennedy International Airport yesterday to protest the January crash of Avianca Flight 52. Many said the crash of the flight from Medellin was a result of discrimination against Colombians.

title: Preserve Some S.R.O.'s For Working People
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Calendar
description: Below are the major economic indicators to be released this week.

title: Chronicle
description: In the last year, GORDON PARKS has written a ballet, has won two awards, has had his 1969 film, ''The Learning Tree,'' selected for the National Film Registry of the Library of Congress and has a major retrospective of his photographs touring Europe. He is talking with the Soviets about making a movie there and is writing his 14th book.

title: Statehood For Puerto Ricans
description: Next year, the people of the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico may have a chance to vote themselves into the Union as America's 51st state. I am firmly convinced that statehood is not in the best interest of Puerto Rico or the United States. I believe that the present commonwealth relationship should be continued and enhanced.

title: Canada's Health Care Succeeds Where Ours Doesn't;   Quality Care for All
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-10

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Reviews/Music;   Sadness and Serenity in an Evening of a Cappella Songs
description: Chanticleer's evening of a cappella music at the 92d Street Y on Wednesday seemed more than anything an act of mourning. All the component parts were constant in this otherwise far-flung program - sorrow, fear, resignation, hope. These 12 male singers from San Francisco began with a Gregorian setting of the medieval hymn ''Ave Maris Stella,'' went on to Josquin's ''Missa Ave Maris Stella'' and then to a young Gyorgy Ligeti's versions of Central European folk songs.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American Healthcare Management Inc., Dallas, which operates hospitals, appointed Robert M. Dubbs vice president, general counsel and secretary.

title: Karen B. Muth Is Married to Michael E. Raskas
description: Karen B. Muth and Michael E. Raskas, students at Yeshiva University, were married yesterday by the bridegroom's grandfather Rabbi Murray Grauer of the Hebrew Institute of White Plains. The ceremony took place at Temple Beth El in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: Dispute Goes On
description: THE maker of the controversial Ping Eye2 iron has refused a proposal by the PGA Tour to allow a three-person panel of antitrust arbitrators to decide whether the tour can ban golf clubs with U-shaped grooves from its competitions. The refusal by Karsten Solheim, the president and founder of Karsten Manufacturing Corporation, emphasized the club maker's desire to take his lawsuit against the tour before a jury in Federal court. Such a process would likely delay a resolution in the case for at least a year and possibly much longer. In a Feb. 20 letter to Solheim, the PGA Tour commissioner, Deane Beman, urged the use of binding arbitration rather than the court system. Beman contended that a special panel could decide the issue by the middle of this year. But in a letter to Beman from the manufacturer's chief attorney, Leonard Decof, Solheim refused. ''We don't fear a jury trial,'' Decof said in a telephone interview on Saturday. ''We believe in our court system of justice. They apparently don't.'' ''I'm very disappointed,'' said Beman in a telephone interview. ''This issue has hung over the game long enough, and I don't understand his decision if he cares about the game.'' On Jan. 27, Solheim dropped a $100 million lawsuit against the United States Golf Association when the U.S.G.A. agreed to make legal forever all Ping Eye2 clubs that have already been manufactured. In exchange, Solheim agreed to stop manufacturing Ping Eye2 irons that do not conform to U.S.G.A. specifications by approximately March 31. Beman said that now that Solheim has settled his dispute with the U.S.G.A., he should try to do the same with the PGA Tour and ''restore tranquillity to the game.''

title: Admission by Shackleford
description: Charles Shackleford, now a forward with the Nets, was quoted today as admitting that he accepted payments while playing for North Carolina State.

title: IMMIGRATION LAWS LINKED TO JOB BIAS
description: Thousands of businesses in the New York metropolitan region, fearing employer sanctions established by the 1986 immigration law, are discriminating against people who are or who appear to be foreign-born, a New York State government study charges.

title: Albany Democrats Renew Effort to Wrest Control of the Senate
description: There is a lot of big talk in the sandstone halls of the State Capitol these days, and most of it is coming from the Democrats. Driven by the politics of reapportionment, they maintain that this will be the year they capture control of the State Senate for only the second time in the last half century.

title: Review/Television;   Prying Away a Daughter From an Ancient Profession
description: Beginning with its title, ABC's ''Daughter of the Streets,'' tonight at 9, has all the earmarks of standard prime-time exploitation, including plenty of sex, sudden eruptions of violence and a comforting finale. After 15 minutes, the vast majority of viewers could fill in the rest. This one, though, is better than most, primarily because it's loaded with estimable talent.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: Question Box
description: The Gashouse Gang

title: Europeans' Long-Held Myths of the New World
description: History is a curious creature, a cross between science and art that has a muse of its own. That muse, Clio, is rooted in Greek mythology, and it is the way in which myth becomes entangled with reality that is lately occupying the mind of C. Vann Woodward, perhaps the foremost historian of the American South.

title: Correction
description: An article on Wednesday about a draft law on the Soviet presidency misidentified Vladimir N. Kudryavtsev of the Soviet Institute of State and Law. He is a former director, not the current director.

title: Technicians Solve Problems That Halted Shuttle Launch
description: Technicians at the Kennedy Space Center resolved the computer and engine problems that earlier today halted the flight of the space shuttle Atlantis seconds before it was to be launched.

title: Vincent Teresa, 61; Mafia Aide Became Informer and Author
description: Vincent Teresa, a colorful, obese New England crime figure of the 1950's and 60's who became a Federal informer and later was a co-author of two books about his underworld experiences, died of kidney failure Wednesday in Seattle, The Associated Press reported. He was 61 years old.

title: Undermanned Nets Frustrated Again
description: With 6.6 seconds remaining in overtime today, the ball slipped out of Purvis Short's hands, and a chance for victory slipped away from the Nets.

title: Home-Repair Licensing Stressed
description: New York City's new Consumer Affairs Commissioner said yesterday that he was beginning a crackdown on unlicensed home-improvement contractors.

title: Books of The Times;   A Book With the Nerve To Use 'Essays' in Its Title
description: Essays in Disguise

title: F.D.A. IS FAULTED ON A HEART VALVE
description: The draft of a House subcommittee report criticizes the Food and Drug Administration and the maker of a mechanical heart valve for allowing the device to remain on the market after reports of malfunctions.

title: Europe Bloc's Prices Up
description: Big price increases in most member countries pushed the European Community's cost of living higher by five-tenths of a percent last month compared with December, the bloc's statistics office, Eurostat, said Friday. The 12-nation community's annual inflation rate held at a provisional 5.2 percent, however, unchanged from December. Eurostat originally put December inflation at 5.4 percent on an annual basis, but said it had revised the weights it gave to each country in its 1988 and 1989 calculations, slightly changing the results.

title: Matthew Einson Wed to Brenda Rich
description: Brenda L. Rich, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin D. Rich of New York and Fair Harbor, L.I., was married yesterday to Matthew D. Einson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Neal M. Einson of New York. Rabbi Lawrence M. Pinsker performed the ceremony at the Flat Rock Brook Nature Center in Englewood, N.J.

title: Should Orioles' New Park Honor a Yankee Hero?
description: BEFORE he was a Yankee, the Babe was an Oriole.

title: Jill Wender and Richard Spitz Are Wed
description: Jill Wender, the daughter of Mrs. Jerry Wender of Great Neck, L.I., and the late Mr. Wender, was married yesterday to Richard Spitz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Spitz of West Palm Beach, Fla. Rabbi Efraim Wolf officiated at the Water's Edge restaurant in Long Island City, Queens.

title: French Publishing House Is Torn by Classic Family Feud
description: If Editions Gallimard was offered a novel about a family firm caught up in bitter feuding over money, power and honor, France's most prestigious publisher would probably reject it as too lowbrow to merit publication.

title: Intrepid Moscow Theater Troupe Ventures Chekhov and Capitalism
description: Given the new freedom of Soviet artists to indulge the soul's delight, the latest theater company here has decided to risk all by combining the separate agonies of Chekhov and Soviet free enterprise.

title: Cuomo Seeks Big Donations Despite Panel
description: As this year's statewide election campaign in New York begins behind the scenes, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo is still soliciting contributions of up to $25,000 and is well on his way to having a $10 million campaign kitty despite criticism of such fund-raising practices by the Cuomo-created State Commission on Government Integrity.

title: Cyprus Talks at U.N. Today at Crucial Stage
description: The latest attempt to break the 26-year-old stalemate on Cyprus reaches a critical stage at talks opening here on Monday between the leaders of Greek- and Turkish-speaking Cypriots, diplomats and United Nations officials say.

title: In Ratings Of Bush, Omens for Democrats
description: There are many bad omens for the Democrats in President Bush's soaring approval ratings, but one of the most troublesome may be Mr. Bush's unusual popularity among blacks.

title: The Knicks Add a Touch of Velvet
description: A MOMENT came to mind of Maurice Cheeks on a basketball court nearly seven years ago. It wasn't in a game. It was after a practice session prior to the 1983 playoffs, the playoffs that his team then, the Philadelphia 76ers, would conclude as world champions.

title: Metro Matters;   A Caseworker Is Still Striving To Prove Herself
description: Sarah Smith's father was an alcoholic who abused her verbally and physically. Her first husband did, too. Somehow, she hoped her second husband would be different. He was. He was worse.

title: No Epidemic Is Expected From Drexel's Killer Flu
description: Aftershocks from the collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. swept through the markets last week, as traders openly questioned the financial health of several other Wall Street firms. But top financial officers of a number of large brokerage firms and leading credit analysts said the problems that suddenly engulfed Drexel are unlikely to be repeated.

title: Trade Talks Seem to Be at Impasse;   U.S. Stepping Up Pressure on Japan
description: The Bush Administration and an increasingly impatient Congress are intensifying pressure on Japan to slash import barriers and work down the nearly $400 billion of surpluses that Japan enjoyed in its trade with the United States over the last decade.

title: Image of New Bishop: Orthodox but Tolerant
description: On the first Sunday since his appointment as the new Roman Catholic Bishop of Brooklyn, Bishop Thomas V. Daily was swamped by well-wishers outside St. Lucie's Church here.

title: Islanders Tie Devils And Gain Optimism
description: After the Islanders' second consecutive tie of the weekend, their streak without a victory stood at six games, matching their longest of the season.

title: Reviews/Music;   Prague Chorus Ends Tour
description: Charles University in Prague was founded in 1348, but its chorus, which includes students and alumni, was established 600 years later. On Wednesday evening, the Charles University Chorus sang a concert of music from Czechoslovakia at St. Jean Baptiste Church.

title: Amid the Publishing Slump, Norton Thrives
description: At a time when many publishing houses are complaining about declining revenues and even losses, W. W. Norton & Company is not only profitable, but also independent.

title: Toll Workers Complain About Health Hazards
description: As environmental investigators pressed their search for the source of a mysterious illness afflicting toll officers on the Triborough Bridge, union officials complained yesterday about what they called management insensitivity to the health hazards of their jobs.

title: Governors and White House Plan Vast Schooling Reform
description: Declaring that ''sweeping, fundamental changes'' must be made in education, the nation's governors committed themselves today to work with the White House on a 10-year program of reforming primary and secondary schools.

title: Peace Dividend: $50,000 per Prisoner
description: What's the logical implication of the following four facts?

title: LITHUANIANS VOTE STRONGLY FOR INDEPENDENCE BACKERS; SOVIET CROWDS ASK CHANGE
description: The Communist establishment suffered a double blow today as protesters across the country thronged the streets in a defiant call for a share of power while one republic, Lithuania, voted to end Communist rule.

title: Comeback Trail
description: HE is there every day, almost lost among the young players who file in and out of the Yankees' minor league complex at Tampa, Fla. Like everyone else, he does his work, dreams a little dream of pitching in the big leagues, then goes home. But it is different for Brit Burns. He has been there before. Burns won 18 games for the Chicago White Sox in 1985, but his rising star fell the next spring - after he was acquired in a trade by the Yankees -when he limped off a mound in an exhibition game in Dunedin, Fla. A degenerative hip condition had become so bad that Burns was forced to return to his home in Alabama, his career apparently over. After two operations, his hip got better, but nothing else did. Four years of inactivity passed. Burns was involved in some bad real estate ventures and a difficult divorce. So he decided to try a comeback. Why? ''Not finding a niche in the real world,'' he admitted. ''It was a difficult transition. I'm not a salesman, and trying to fit into the business world made me realize how much I missed this. Once it gets in your blood, there is nothing outside of baseball that could ever replace it. When you try to, you only get frustrated.'' The Yankees aren't expecting much from the 30-year-old Burns, but he is expecting a lot from himself. He is an unsigned, non-roster player with no status, but when he is asked about pitching in the minors, he shrugs and says: ''I don't think that's going to be necessary. I expect to be handed the ball on the third or fourth day in New York.'' Burns, a left-hander, still has a distinct limp but said it does not affect his ability to pitch or to field ground balls. He is down to 220 pounds, 18 fewer than when he arrived and 45 fewer than he carried two years ago, when he battled periods of depression over the premature loss of his career. He smiles now, if only at the thought he is wearing a Yankee uniform once more. But neither that nor the notion that there is money to be made again has brought him back. ''Money is a byproduct, but it's not the issue,'' he said. ''If the financial picture weren't the way it is, guys would still be playing baseball. There's the atmosphere, the camaraderie of the clubhouse. It's gratifying.''

title: Guerrilla Warfare Over Nuclear Waste
description: State officials who want to inspect the site of a proposed nuclear-waste storage area here must first sneak by Margie Schlegel.

title: Advertising;   Raid on Saatchi Called Unlikely
description: The plummeting price of the Saatchi & Saatchi Company's stock does not make a takeover of the troubled conglomerate more likely, advertising analysts said Friday.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Feb. 25, 1990:

title: Bush and Kohl Try to Allay Fears Of a Reunified Germany's Powers
description: Ending two days of talks, President Bush and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany declared today that there was no reason for anyone to fear the economic, political or military power of a united Germany.

title: Reviews/Music;   Reggae Parables of Life in the Jamaican Ghettos of London
description: The Jamaican-English poet Linton Kwesi Johnson knows the reggae beat intimately, as both inspiration and accompaniment.

title: Hail to Unpredictability
description: Peace is losing; freedom is winning.

title: In Contra Stronghold, Fear Also Goes to Polls
description: In the blackest hours before dawn, long before a morning downpour let up, Maria left her small wooden shack on the slopes of the mountains that ring this hamlet and began walking here to vote for the first time in her life.

title: New Toll of Gang Shootings: Hospital to Shut Trauma Unit
description: A hospital here plans to close its doors to emergency cases, saying it was losing money treating poor victims of gang violence from Los Angeles.

title: Review/Theater;   'Burner's Frolic' Continues Fuller's Cycle
description: With ''Burner's Frolic,'' the fourth in Charles Fuller's continuing cycle of plays about black Americans in the second half of the 19th century, one has a clearer picture of the playwright's ambitious intention. Through a series of episodes, seemingly tangential in the sweep of American history, the playwright is scrutinizing the economic entrapment of people forced to weigh their pragmatic needs against their desire for complete emancipation and integration. From all four plays, it is also evident that neither Mr. Fuller nor his director, Douglas Turner Ward, has given them the necessary time and care to allow them to speak to their greatest advantage.

title: Sandro Pertini, Italian President With Common Touch, Dies at 93
description: Former President Sandro Pertini, whose open manner and common touch made him one of Italy's most beloved leaders, died in his sleep Saturday night at his apartment by the Trevi Fountain. Mr. Pertini, who was 93 years old, reportedly had not been well since he hit his head in a household accident this month.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Television;   NBC Losing Morning Race As Ratings of 'Today' Drop
description: One axiom of morning television, where viewing habits are especially ingrained, is that ratings tend to move at a glacial pace.

title: Lampoon Seeks to Repeat Its Best Bottom Lines
description: It was a classic magazine cover and a classic example of National Lampoon's humor. Accompanying a cover photo of a gun being held to a dog's head, the headline read: ''If you don't buy this magazine, we'll shoot this dog.''

title: Johnnie Ray, 63, 50's Singer Who Hit No. 1 With a Sob in His Voice
description: Johnnie Ray, a singer whose emotionally uninhibited hit recordings in the early 1950's anticipated the rock-and-roll era, died of liver failure on Saturday in Los Angeles. He was 63 years old.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I don't know if I'll fly anymore, except to Las Vegas. I'd be a little tense, drinking a lot more, doing crossword puzzles, eating candy. I've got to admit smoking's not good for you, but neither is living in L.A.''

title: 70 Held in Anti-Soviet Protest
description: Seventy people, including three rabbis, were arrested outside the Soviet Mission in Manhattan yesterday after they blocked traffic during a protest to urge direct flights to Israel from the Soviet Union.

title: Duke Outlasts Arizona by 78-76
description: Phil Henderson's second-half scoring binge and key defensive play helped third-ranked Duke overcome No. 21 Arizona's inside strength and led the Blue Devils to a 78-76 victory today.

title: Woman Is Named General Counsel for C.I.A.
description: A senior lawyer at the State Department has been appointed general counsel to the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: The Fall of Drexel's House of Risk
description: Behind the seemingly sudden collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. were months of missteps and pressures from outside forces that were fully understood by the firm's executives only as Drexel was drawing its last breaths.

title: Agents Fight for Share Of Foreign Book Rights
description: Lynn Nesbit, a literary agent, is selling Tom Wolfe's next book around the world. Publishers in Europe have paid well in excess of $1 million for it. Yet, Ms. Nesbit said: ''It's not a book yet. It's not even an outline. In fact it's hardly even an idea.''

title: A Small Sampling Of Exercise Videos
description: EXERCISE routines at home have come a long way since the early radio days when young listeners were urged to march around the breakfast table. Adults are marching now, but the voices they hear come from the well-toned bodies they see on television or videotapes.

title: Pistons Humble Knicks
description: The Detroit Pistons played like defending National Basketball Association champions yesterday at Madison Square Garden and the Knicks played like pretenders rather than contenders for the title. As a result, Detroit won by 98-87 in a game between two division leaders, who many have picked to meet in the Eastern Conference final.

title: 5 Killed in Florida House Fire
description: Fire swept through a house early today, killing five members of a family, the authorities said. The cause of the blaze in this northeastern Florida town of 1,000 was not immediately known, said Capt. Richard Schauland of the sheriff's department. Three adults and two children, 4 years old and 7, were killed, he said.

title: VOICE OF MILITANTS RISING IN KASHMIR
description: Young pro-independence militants are exercising increasing influence in the Vale of Kashmir, cutting the support for traditional pro-Indian groups and leaving mainstream politicians isolated and silent.

title: Chase Official to Head Global Securities Unit
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank, believing that institutional investors are taking a global approach, has combined its domestic pension trust and global custody business and put Marshall N. Carter in charge.

title: Celtics Defeat Nuggets
description: Michael Smith, who has averaged 3.6 points so far this season, scored 24 points and sparked a late rally as the Boston Celtics beat the Denver Nuggets, 115-107, today.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   A Nuclear Empire in Decay
description: He wrestles with a recalcitrant bureaucracy and a vast production system on the verge of collapse. Strapped for cash, he gambles that the promise of openness and restructuring will spark reform. But politicians in the outlying states of his empire are urging him to pull his people out and go home, and the half-patched new system seems to break down even more often than the old.

title: No U.S. Retaliation on Trade
description: The Bush Administration said Friday that it would not retaliate against the 12-nation European Community and South Korea over trade barriers imposed against United States telecommunications companies.

title: Son Takes Posts at Forbes
description: The Forbes family said yesterday that Malcolm S. Forbes Jr., 42 years old, would assume his father's position as chief executive and editor in chief of Forbes magazine.

title: Schools Don't Need Upgrading; Parents Do
description: To the Editor:

title: Oklahoma Defeats Missouri, 107-90
description: Missouri and Kansas have worn each other out playing tag with the No. 1 national ranking this season while their Big Eight rival Oklahoma, panned by some as a poor imitation of previous Sooner teams, has been the odd man out.

title: Census Maps Every Corner of U.S., But the Directions Can Be Impossible
description: The Federal Census Bureau this year is delivering on a promise it made seven years ago: to give America a computerized map of itself, a gargantuan file of geographic data knitting together every street, stream and political boundary.

title: David Goldfarb, Geneticist, 71; Won Battle to Leave Soviet Union
description: David Goldfarb, the Soviet Jewish geneticist who in 1986 won a seven-year battle to emigrate, died of heart failure Saturday at Georgetown University Medical Center in Washington. He was 71 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Malcolm Forbes, Publisher, Dies at 70
description: Malcolm Forbes, chairman and editor in chief of Forbes Magazine and a flamboyant multimillionaire whose enthusiastic pursuits included yachting, motorcycling and ballooning, died Saturday of a heart attack in his sleep at his home in Far Hills, N.J. He was 70 years old.

title: Canada's Health Care Succeeds Where Ours Doesn't;   Rationalized Services
description: To the Editor:

title: Balls Recalled
description: CALL it a safety-minded humanitarian gesture or a clever marketing ploy, but a leading manufacturer has stopped producing traditional baseballs for the youth market, issued a recall for those in circulation and called for other manufacturers to follow suit. The company, Worth Inc., says it will replace any of its balls bearing a youth league stamp with a model it claims will virtually eliminate serious impact injuries among often inept, accident-prone young players without sacrificing so much as a single extra-base hit or short hop of performance. The address is Box 88104, Tullahoma, Tenn. 37388-8104. The patented safety models, known as ''Reduced Injury Factor,'' or RIF balls, are the same size and weight as traditional balls and have real leather covers, real seams, and, Worth says, the same performance characteristics at Little League speeds. Unlike traditional balls, which are made of yarn wound around cork or rubber cores, RIF interiors are a single piece of polyurethane foam plastic, which Worth says absorbs 80 percent more impact because it compresses more, distributing the force over a larger area of bat - or skull. The result, according to independent tests, is that while a yarn-wound ball fired at 60 miles an hour has a 99 percent chance of causing a serious head injury, the rate for Worth's RIF ball is 2 percent. Worth introduced the RIF ball in 1985, a year after the United States Product Safety Commission reported that 35 of the 51 known baseball-related deaths of young players from 1973 to 1983 were caused by thrown or batted balls. The company cited those findings in calling for a total ban on production of yarn-wound balls for young players, a move that, not coincidentally, would leave Worth, already the largest softball manufacturer, as the lone supplier of the 6 million or so baseballs sold in the youth market each year. It's RIF is the only regulation ball that meets recently established safety standards. Because the claim that the slightly soft RIF ball's safety is achieved without affecting performance evokes almost automatic skepticism, Worth's president, Jess Heald, has taken to carrying around a golf ball and a spongy Super Ball for instant demonstrations that hardness does not determine bounce. Although the RIF has Little League approval, Worth says it has encountered sales resistance because the RIF has one resounding flaw: The sound it makes when struck by a bat is not the coveted ''ping,'' which has come to replace the satisfying ''crack'' of yore for the aluminum bat generation, but a deeper-toned ''pung.'' Worth, however, has reason to believe the ''pung'' will eventually become the sound of choice. It was Worth, after all, that made the ''ping'' king when it introduced the first aluminum bat.

title: Fed Up With Lies, Romanians Are Faced With Harsh Truths
description: At the street shrines where people died at Christmastime to overthrow the dictatorship of Nicolae Ceausescu, heaped with evergreen boughs symbolizing eternal life and pale yellow votive candles, there are impromptu gatherings each day to argue politics.

title: Plan Is Offered to Stabilize the World Birth Rate
description: In a country-by-country report made public today, the Population Crisis Committee estimates that the world population can be stabilized in the 21st century only if countries make birth control universally available by 2000 at a cost of about $10.5 billion a year.

title: Florida Candidate Apologizes for Capitalizing on Murder Case
description: A Democratic candidate for governor has apologized for trying to make a campaign issue out of a murder case in which the defendant is black.

title: Public Aid for Birth Control Found to Save Money
description: Taxpayers save $4.40 for every public dollar spent to provide birth control to women who might otherwise not have access to contraceptives, a new study has found.

title: Aloft Without Nicotine: Can Smokers Cope?
description: A mixed jeer and cheer went up from the smoking section of United Airlines Flight 133 from Boston to Los Angeles Saturday night when a flight attendant announced that a new law would ban smoking on all domestic flights under six hours starting today. ''So tonight's it, smokers,'' she said.

title: No More Tax Monkey
description: Political horse sense dictates an obvious strategy for the Democrats in an election year: fall in behind Senator Pat Moynihan's proposal for a rollback in the Social Security payroll tax of more than $60 billion over two years.

title: Tool Orders Declined 4.2% In January
description: Reflecting the continued downturn in the automotive industry, orders for American-made machine tools slipped 4.2 percent in January from December's level, according to a monthly report to be released today.

title: Colleges on the Run To Lure Star Players
description: SHORTLY after watching his basketball team lose to Louisiana State several weeks ago, Wade Houston, the first-year coach at Tennessee, expressed disappointment over losing at home to a conference rival. At the same time, Houston could barely hide his satisfaction over the excitement the game had generated.

title: Canada's Health Care Succeeds Where Ours Doesn't
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising;   Improving Marketing Of Movies
description: TO hear experts on movie marketing tell it, the basic challenge of creating advertising for a coming motion picture has remained unchanged for years.

title: The Bill of Rights Needs a Plug
description: LEAD: Expressions of outrage over Philip Morris's television advertisements celebrating the coming 200th anniversary of the Bill of Rights in 1991 represent the very height of naivete.

title: Nathan Magill, Manufacturer, 90
description: Nathan Magill, a retired textile manufacturer, died of kidney failure on Saturday at Hackensack Medical Center in New Jersey. He would have celebrated his 90th birthday yesterday.

title: Rangers Are at Top And Sitting Pretty
description: ''You win a game in the Patrick Division and you think about finishing first. You lose a game and you worry about finishing last.''

title:
Market Place;

Neutrogena Deals With Competition
description: LEAD: AS it feels the heat of aggressive new competition, the Neutrogena Corporation, a manufacturer and marketer of specialty beauty products, is experiencing growing pains. With annual sales that now exceed $200 million, the company is no longer ignored by industry giants like Johnson & Johnson and Revlon

title: Scenic Routes Join Vermont Snowmobilers and Skiers
description: SEVERAL times a week, I walk out the kitchen door, snap on my cross-country skis, and take off over an overgrown pasture to the edge of our property. A glorious system of trails awaits. These trails snake through the trees, cross frozen brooks and streams, climb steep hills and arc boldly through open fields. This is Mountain Tamer country. The Mountain Tamers are members of the local snowmobile club, the organization responsible for creating and maintaining trails in my town.

title: This Wool Cooperates
description: The widespread use of wool for winter clothing gave way in the last decade to new synthetic materials. But within the last year, a new generation of wool products has brought on a fresh look.

title: A Life of Strangers and Seedy Motels
description: For more than a year, Hilary Foretich, the focus of a bitter custody battle in Washington, D.C., lived with her mother's parents here in a few cramped motel rooms, revealing her identity only to the family doctor.

title: Advertising;   Y.&R. Says Executive And U.S. Reach Accord
description: The Government has decided not to try a senior vice president at Young & Rubicam charged with perjury in the Jamaica Tourist Board affair, the advertising agency said Friday. The case against Steven M. McKenna will be referred to the United States Pre-Trial Services Agency, Y.&R. said, and will be resolved under the Federal agency's pre-trial diversion program.

title: Killings Scandal Weighs on de Klerk
description: Efforts by President F. W. de Klerk have failed to still the controversy over allegations that death squads under military control have been killing opponents of apartheid. The continuing disclosures in South African newspapers appear to pose a growing embarrassment to Mr. de Klerk as he seeks a new political arrangement between whites and blacks.

title: Divers Recover the Last Body In a Lake Where Seven Died
description: Divers recovered the body today of the last of seven people who were killed when members of a youth group and four people trying to rescue them fell through thin ice into a lake.

title: Portrait of a Leading Family Enduring the Hurt of Drugs
description: At a grade school here during a celebration of Black History Month the other day, Mayor John C. Daniels warned the children ''to stay out of trouble and stay away from drugs.''

title: Review/Jazz;   Music to Commute By
description: Jazz repertory met mass transit when the MUNY - for Music Under New York - Big Band played Cal Massey's ''Liberation Suite'' on Friday afternoon in the main concourse of Grand Central Terminal. The 10-piece group was led by the tenor saxophonist Zane Massey, the late Cal Massey's son, 18 years and a day after the piece had its premiere in Brooklyn. The group also played another Cal Massey tune, ''Assunta.''

title: Review/Ballet;   Eliot Feld Choreographs To One of the Other Bachs
description: ''Contra Pose'' is a remarkable new ballet by Eliot Feld, a contradictory outpouring of emotion and mathematical precision; it is splendidly performed by 18 dancers with a suitable mix of stamina and exactitude. Despite its name, ''Contra Pose'' is not about Nicaragua.

title: MARKET IN TOKYO NORMALLY STABLE, SLIPS INTO TURMOIL
description: The usually stable Tokyo Stock Exchange plunged Monday in a day of wild gyrations that Japanese officials always thought only took place in other markets. The Nikkei index was off nearly 7 percent at one point, then rebounded near the close to finish down 4.5 percent for the day.

title: Lawsuits Filed Against Perrier
description: Several Federal lawsuits have been filed against Perrier Group of America Inc., contending that the company knowingly sold bottled spring water that was contaminated with benzene.

title: Review/Theater;   Spare Revival of a '70 Broadway Musical
description: There may be no surer test of the sturdiness of a vintage Broadway musical than to be subjected to the kind of spare revival that the American Jewish Theater has given to the 1970 Jerry Bock-Sheldon Harnick show, ''The Rothschilds.''

title: Business Scene;   Retailing Trouble Is Fundamental
description: AS everyone knows, retailers are in trouble.

title: INSIDE
description: Mandela Calls for End To Factional Warfare

title: Teen-Age Girl And 2 Men Die At Social Clubs
description: Three people, including a 15-year-old girl, were killed and two others were wounded in violent attacks at social clubs around New York City early yesterday, the police said.

title: Gerald G. Conway, News Director, 76
description: Gerald G. Conway, who was news director of WOR Radio when he retired in 1976 after 30 years with the station, died of leukemia on Thursday at St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains. He was 76 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Reviews/Music;   Japanese Compositions In the Western Manner
description: Aside from the flamboyant ritualism of Kodo at the City Center, Manhattan was awash with Japanese music last week. On Wednesday and Thursday nights, a chamber group called the Tokyo International Music Ensemble inaugurated an American tour with two programs at the Japan Society. And on Friday night at Carnegie Hall, the laudable Music From Japan series celebrated its 15th anniversary with a Brooklyn Philharmonic orchestral program.

title: Simmons to Fight Lockheed Rule
description: The Texas financier Harold C. Simmons, already waging a proxy fight for control of the board of the Lockheed Corporation, said he would also seek to eliminate the anti-takeover plan of the Calabasas, Calif., military contractor. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Simmons said he would solicit proxies to remove the plan.

title: Penobscot Journal;   Good Will Is Great, But Can It Fix a Road?
description: No one in this bayside town of 1,200 people charges that local government has squandered money or even that property taxes are too high. But on March 6, when townspeople gather for the annual town meeting, they will consider a petition to abolish property taxes.

title: Applied Bioscience InternaFtional Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Review/Theater;   A Show Keeps Coming Back, Getting Closer on Every Orbit
description: At the end of ''Merrily We Roll Along,'' three young people of 1957, all with dreams of theatrical or literary glory, stand on a roof in New York City to spot Sputnik, a symbol of their high hopes, as it streaks across a starry sky. Nine years after its failure on Broadway, ''Merrily'' continues to follow its own alluring, elusive trajectory through the musical theater.

title: Baseball Factions Leave the Table
description: As union officials left for Phoenix and a players' executive board meeting today, the chances for a settlement that would end the club owners' lockout and salvage the start of the baseball season seemed to hinge on the possibility of a last-minute proposal from the owners. No proposal, however, was forthcoming.

title: Pro Bono
description: * To attract younger volunteers, the American Red Cross introduced a television commercial yesterday in which the performers Carly Simon, Randy Travis, Branford Marsalis and Paul Shaffer do volunteer work to the music of the Rolling Stones' ''Gimme Shelter.'' The campaign was developed by the J. Walter Thompson Company in cooperation with the Ad Council.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We have shown the world an example of civic duty, demonstrating that we Nicaraguans want to live in democracy, want to live in peace and, above all, that we want to live in liberty.''

The agency was responsible for the creative work for the print advertising; it did not do the research for the advertising.

title: Edward Moor, Acting Teacher, 62
description: Edward Moor, an acting teacher and actor, died of cancer on Feb. 19 at his home in Manhattan. He was 62 years old.

The company said earnings increased due to improved results from insurance operations, continued favorable investment performance and elimination of losses from discontinued operations. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: CalFed Head In New Posts
description: CalFed Inc. said last week that Jerry A. St. Dennis, president and chief operating officer since July, had been named to the additional positions of chairman and chief executive.

title: Widespread Abuses Reported in Insurance for Nursing Home Care
description: Reka Hinderks, a widow hospitalized with osteoporosis at the age of 77 last year, was so concerned about her future care that she decided to buy a $2,400-a-year insurance policy to cover nursing home costs. The agent visited her in the hospital to collect the first premium.

title: Business and Health;   A.T.&T.'s Plan To Slow Costs
description: AT least a dozen major insurers and health-care chains are bidding to provide the American Telephone and Telegraph Company with an innovative insurance program that will be the nation's largest experiment in managed health care. Under the program, the telephone company and its unions will select networks of doctors and hospitals across the country to try to slow the telephone company's enormous medical spending.

title: Unigene Laboratories reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a picture yesterday with an article about a speech by Nelson Mandela carried an incorrect caption in some copies. The picture - at the right in a pair - showed Mr. Mandela, with security guards, speaking in Bloemfontein, South Africa.

title: Henry Fairlie, British-Born Writer On American Politics, Dies at 66
description: Henry Fairlie, an expatriate British author and journalist who wrote about the American political scene, died of heart failure Sunday at George Washington University Medical Center in Washington. He was 66 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Gibraltar Mines reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said the improved results reflect higher copper prices and sales volume, and lower unit costs. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Iphigene Ochs Sulzberger
description: By last winter, when she came to The Times for a brief visit, she had dwindled to a tiny sparrow. But her eyes still flashed with curiosity, and curiosity is a word that tells much about the long and happy life of Iphigene Ochs Sulzberger.

title: On Secession: Too Little and Too Soon
description: After irresponsibly encouraging Staten Island's ill-considered rush toward secession from New York City, Gov. Mario Cuomo is now trying to calm things down. He's pushing for a measure that would give the State Legislature final say over the borough's fate. That's an improvement over the faulty measure he signed in December, which lets Staten Island act unilaterally. But the Governor's proposal doesn't go far enough to remedy a potentially divisive process. Moreover, his timing couldn't be worse.

title: Cuomo and Florio Criticize Bush on Lack of Money for Education
description: The Democratic governors of New York and New Jersey, both of whom face major budget problems at home, criticized the Bush Administration today for failing to commit Federal dollars to the education goals established on Sunday by the White House and the nation's governors.

title: Books of The Times;   Marching, Disobediently, Into Mr. McGregor's Garden
description: Don't Tell the Grown-Ups

title: Noriega Co-Defendant Discussing Guilty Plea
description: A co-defendant of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega is negotiating a plea arrangement that could result in his testifyng against his former employer, a defense lawyer said today.

title: United Medical reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $35,000, or 1 cent a share, and $56,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively; the credit for the year represented an extinguishment of debt at a discount. The year also included income from discontinued operations of $8,834,000, or $3.03 a share, and a loss from an accounting adjustment of $390,000 from the cumulative effect of adopting FASB Statement No. 96, Accounting for Income Taxes. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $322,000, or 10 cents a share, and $831,000, or 26 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. The year also included an extraordinary credit of $322,000, or 10 cents a share, from the extinguishment of debt at a discount. Discontinued results in 1989 mainly reflect the gain on the sale of Renal Care Centers Corp. Income from continuing operations included currency translation gains relating to United Medical's Swiss note issue of $161,000 in 1989 and $908,000 in 1988. Results in the latest fourth quarter reflect a charge of $571,000 to reduce the carrying value of United Medical's investment in Maxicare Health Plans Inc.

title: Former Prime Minister Re-elected in Sweden
description: The Swedish Parliament confirmed Ingvar Carlsson as Prime Minister of a new Social Democratic Government today, 12 days after he resigned when his economic austerity policy was rejected.

title: Rensselaer Surges Into League Tournament
description: A surge by Rensselaer, a collapse by Harvard and the questionable availability of Colgate's goalie are the major factors as the ECAC Hockey playoffs open.

title: Turnover in Nicaragua;   Washington set to End Embargo And Aid Chamorro Government
description: Elated by the election results in Nicaragua, the Bush Administration said today that it expected to lift a trade embargo imposed in 1985, provide economic aid and send an ambassador to Managua if Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, the President-elect, takes office as scheduled on April 25.

title: Talks on Cambodia Under Way Amid Skepticism About Progress
description: A new round of talks on Cambodia opened here today, centering on an enhanced United Nations role to help administer the country and lead to new elections.

title: Review/Television;   Portrait of Arafat, a Man of the Shadows
description: No, you will not learn from ''The Faces of Arafat'' whether the durable leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization now truly abjures terrorism. The testiest exchange in tonight's edition of ''Frontline,'' on Channels 13 and 49 at 10, comes when the documentary's correspondent, Marie Colvin, presses Yasir Arafat on the part he may have played in the murder of Israeli athletes at the 1972 Olympics at Munich and of the American Ambassador to the Sudan in 1973. He stands on his dignity: ''You are speaking to the chairman of the P.L.O., the President of the state of Palestine. Be careful with your investigation.'' And he cuts short the interview.

title: INSIDE
description: Pretoria Curbs Covert Unit

title: Berry Is Dismissed By the Patriots
description: Raymond Berry, coach of the New England Patriots, who had been engaged in a power struggle over his staff with Pat Sullivan, the team's general manager, was dismissed yesterday.

title: Plantations Slip Into Texas History
description: John Holland Bannister enjoyed one last glance at the white clapboard house that his great-grandfather built with a crew of slaves in 1837 in the Texas wilderness.

title: As Guard Changes in Brazil, the Rain Forest Loses a Protector
description: A DC-10 was cruising 33,000 feet over the Amazon rain forest recently when a short, stocky man in blue jeans and a polo shirt barged into the cockpit. ''Hi, I'm Fernando Mesquita,'' the man announced, stretching out a hand to the startled pilots. ''See any fires down there?''

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

description: LEAD: The Detroit Edison Company said yesterday that John E. Lobbia will become chairman and chief executive in May when the current chairman, Walter J. McCarthy Jr., reaches mandatory retirement age, which is 65.

In addition, the company said it incurred $5 million in merger expenses which were charged to fourth quarter earnings.

The company aslo said that in connection with the sale of its Cup operations, it took charges of $120 million against earnings in 1989.

title: Question Arises as Execution Nears: Would California Death Be a Signal?
description: The scheduled death of Robert Alton Harris in the gas chamber here, the first state killing in California in nearly a quarter of a century, will not merely be No. 122 in a string of executions since the United States Supreme Court reinstated capital punishment in 1976.

description: A top commander of the American invasion of Panama said today that security breaches gave the Panamanians several hours' warning of the attack and resulted in increased American casualties.

description: An accountant who persuaded at least 40 people to join a rent strike in a luxury East Side apartment building stole more than $1.7 million of rent money he was supposed to have put in an escrow account, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

description: The International Monetary Fund extended a deadline today on talks for a new financing increase until June 30, but it said it hoped to fashion a deal in the next few weeks.

description: Among the ugly costs of Communist rule was the failure to keep pace with revulsion at the ancient disease of anti-Semitism, let alone create a new mentality, as boasted. So a side effect of advancing release from repression in the East is revival of slogans of hate.

description: Since the beach here disappeared about 50 years ago, all that has stopped the Atlantic from swallowing the rest of this skinny Jersey Shore borough is a stone seawall the length of Ocean Avenue.

description: Grove Weidenfeld, the book publishing company started in 1985 by Ann Getty and Lord Weidenfeld, will be offered for sale today, it was announced yesterday. The decision was reportedly made by Mrs. Getty, who is the financial backer of the money-losing company, and her advisers.

title: Our Towns;   Basketball Guard Wins for Being Just Like the Rest
description: Two days before Christmas in 1988, a car carrying Chris Samele and four other Torrington High School students skidded on an icy road, spun out of control and struck a guardrail. Two students walked away unscathed, but Chris and two others were thrown out the back window. Shawn Collins was killed. Dawn Storrs was injured. Chris's left leg was wrenched off just above the knee.

title: Koreans Weigh Iran Role
description: South Korea is encouraging its companies to help to complete a huge war-damaged Iranian petrochemical plant, a project abandoned by Japan, Energy Ministry officials said last week. They said the Minister of Energy and Resources, Lee Bong Suh, had held talks with Iranian officials on a possible role for South Korean companies in the project in a recent trip to Teheran.

title: Signs of Hope for Lebanon Hostages
description: Encouraged by promising signals from Iran, Syria plans a new effort to free 18 Western hostages believed held in Lebanon by Shiite Muslim militants with connections to Iran, a relative of an American hostage said today.

title: Israel Letting 16 Arab Colleges Reopen
description: The Israeli military authorities announced today that they were allowing 16 community colleges in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip to reopen. But the universities, shut down along with the colleges in the fall of 1987, will remain closed.

title: Shortchanged by the Census?
description: Why does the Census Bureau refuse to acknowledge that counting New York City is not like counting Salina, Kan.? Because it is apparently playing politics: someone in Washington doesn't want an accurate count in largely Democratic urban areas.
