description: A top Hempstead town official, accused of receiving $25,000 worth of free work on his home as a favor from two contractors who were awarded dozens of town construction contracts, has been indicted for income-tax evasion.

description: Marijuana production in Mexico is much higher than previously estimated, the Bush Administration said, but it played down reports of a tenfold increase.

title: IDEC Japan Link
description: The IDEC Pharmaceuticals Corporation, a privately held biotechnology company based in La Jolla, Calif., entered an agreement with the Institute of Immunology Company of Tokyo under which IDEC will receive up to $23 million for product rights and equity from the Japanese biotechnology company. Institute of Immunology, which is also privately held, will receive rights in Japan and certain Asian countries to develop IDEC therapeutic and diagnostic products and about 20 percent of IDEC's preferred stock.

description: Now that Charles Shackleford has admitted that he accepted money from two individuals while playing at North Carolina State, his agent said he hoped that Shackleford could continue his career without further controversy.

The charge reflected higher levels of inventory and higher raw material prices.

description: Creditors of the Drexel Burnham Lambert Group held a final conference yesterday about legal strategies as they prepared for the first volley of litigation stemming from its bankruptcy filing nearly two weeks ago.

CHRONICLE
description: The bronze sculpture of SYLVESTER STALLONE as Rocky was removed from outside the Philadelphia Museum of Art yesterday, after the completion of filming of ''Rocky V.'' It is being returned to the Spectrum sports arena, where it was moved once before when the museum decided it did not want to be graced by the sculpture.

title: Piper Plant Shut; 580 Are Laid Off
description: The financially troubled Piper Aircraft Corporation shut down its plant here for two weeks and laid off more than three-fourths of its workers, a company spokesman said. Joe Ponte, director of marketing, said that the layoffs were the result of a severe cash shortage and that the company did not plan to seek bankruptcy protection from creditors.

title: Review/Music;   Merkin Program of Works by Baltic Composers
description: In his programming for the New York University Chamber Music Society, Gregory Haimovsky, the group's artistic director, seems to be taking a stand on the separatist tensions that have lately been erupting in the Soviet republics. As a follow-up to last season's Year in Russian Music series, he is now leading his ensemble through the Year in Eastern European Music. The Thursday evening installment at Merkin Concert Hall was devoted to music by Estonian, Lithuanian and Latvian composers.

title: Cominco Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

description: Warren D. Manshel, an investment banker and publisher who was Ambassador to Denmark under President Carter, died of heart failure on Sunday at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., where he was being treated for cancer. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

description: The Business Scene column yesterday misstated the reason Saks Fifth Avenue was put up for sale. The action is part of a strategy by Saks's owner, B.A.T. Industries P.L.C., to defend itself from a takeover. It is not because of any bankruptcy filing.

title: Sandinistas Out: No Surprise
description: LEAD: The biggest surprise about the victory of Violeta Barrios de Chamorro in the Nicaraguan elections is that it was such a surprise.

title: Nets Have Bowie Plan
description: Harry Weltman, the Nets' general manager, said yesterday that he hoped to sign Sam Bowie to a long-term contract before the season ends. Bowie, the Nets' 7-1 center, will be a restricted free agent when his five-year contract expires. The 28-year-old Bowie has expressed dissatisfaction that the Nets have yet to begin serious negotiations. Bowie is the N.B.A.'s ninth-leading rebounder (10.1 per game); he leads the Nets in blocked shots (96), and he is averaging 13.4 points per game.

title: Southern California Water reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: A revenue refund reserve of $1,818,000 recorded in December 1988 reduced revenues for the year-ago quarter. In 1989 the addition to the reserve totaled $356,000. The company said the effects of a gain of $1,325,000 on the sale of its San Bernardino Valley Water systems and an offset of higher interest charges of $1,443,000 resulted in increased net income for 1989.

title: If New York Business Has the Will, City Has No Way to Recycle
description: To the Editor:

title: 30 Americans Hurt in Crash
description: Thirty passengers were injured when a tour bus carrying American youths to a recreation center plunged from the road down a 130-foot embankment, the police said today. The accident occurred Sunday night near the Rhine River city of Oberwesel, said Manfred Hilger of the Boppard regional police. Twenty youths were seriously hurt and 10 others suffered minor injuries, Mr. Hilger said. He said authorities had not determined whether the Americans were tourists or relatives of military or diplomatic personnel in West Germany.

title: KEY RATES

Digital to Offer Failure-Proof Unit
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation will announce that it is entering the market for fault-tolerant computing by introducing a specially configured model of its VAX line of machines. Fault-tolerant computers generally have several processors and special software that insures that data are not lost in the event of a failure. Such computers are used in banking and airline-reservation systems.

title: Review/Art;   The Cryptic Interiors of Vuillard, Close, Ominous and Enigmatic
description: Few artists in this century have been plagued by the question ''What if?'' more than Edouard Vuillard. Long before he died in 1940, the French painter had come to be regarded as someone who left unfulfilled the promise that was so much on view in the works he produced as a young man, during the last decade of the 19th century.

title: Market Place;   Xtra to Sell Itself And Avoid Proxy
description: RATHER than risk their removal in a bitter proxy vote, the top managers and directors of the Xtra Corporation said yesterday that they would put the company up for sale and would cancel the annual shareholders meeting originally scheduled for tomorrow. If the company is sold, the managers and board members are likely to reap a tidy profit themselves.

title: Midsouth Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PRETORIA MINISTER HALTS COVERT UNIT
description: Defense Minister Magnus A. Malan told Parliament today that he had ordered a covert unit reported to have assassinated opponents of apartheid to suspend ''all activities.'' At the same time he threw the assembly into an uproar by saying that one of the supposed victims of the killings had been an agent of South African military intelligence.

title: Tragedy's Victims Are Not Spoiled by News Media
description: To the Editor:

title: Study Shows Racial Imbalance in Penal System
description: Nearly one of every four young black males is behind bars or on probation or parole, a study released today said.

title: Review/Dance;   City Ballet Performs to Benefit Colleagues
description: The Annual Dancers' Emergency Fund Benefit at the New York City Ballet on Sunday night had the same packed house and intense atmosphere observed in recent seasons. Now in its sixth year, this special program has become a major, if curious, event, one of the most eagerly awaited in the entire dance season.

title: Critic's Notebook;   Hollywood Humorists Enlist Death and Brutality
description: When Kathleen Turner races out of a formal dinner party, jumps in her four-wheel-drive vehicle and runs over her husband's tiny vintage sportscar, with her husband still in it, ''The War of the Roses'' begins to turn nasty. As Barbara and Oliver Rose, the divorcing couple whose rancor far outmatches the passion they once felt, Ms. Turner and Michael Douglas have been satisfied with petty acts of vengeance to this point. He runs over her cat; she breaks a few of his ribs. When Barbara jams her fingers up her husband's nose to stop him from snoring, it is the least of the ordeals they inflict on each other in Danny DeVito's brutal but very funny black comedy.

title: Predators Influence Growth Of Snails
description: COMMON freshwater snails hunted by crayfish grow larger, reproduce later in life and live longer than snails not exposed to the predator, researchers have found.

title: BRE Properties Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Results for the latest 6-month period included a $10,434,000 net gain on sales of investments and the benefit of a $3,424,000 litigation settlement. The company said net income for the latest quarter was reduced as a result of a tenant's bankruptcy in September at the company's warehouse facility in Pomona, Calif. The loss of rental income, the tenant's continued use of a building through mid-January under the protection of the bankruptcy laws, and the charge-off of tenant-related expenses combined to lower second- quarter results by 4 cents a share.

title: Union Criticizes Volvo-Renault Tie
description: France's Communist-led trade union criticized a deal announced last week that links the Swedish car maker Volvo and its French rival Renault, saying it was bad for France. ''The Renault-Volvo deal is a confidence trick,'' said C.G.T., France's largest trade union, which includes most of Renault's 70,000 workers. ''It is bad for Renault and bad for France.''

title: New York Is Warned Again on Bond Rating
description: New York State received another warning about its finances today when Moody's Investors Service said the state was in danger of seeing its bond rating dropped.

title: Wang to Sell Unit
description: Wang Laboratories Inc. agreed in principle to sell its international lease-financing operations for about $250 million to GE Capital, a unit of the General Electric Company. Wang said about $215 million of the proceeds would be used to reduce its bank debt and $35 million would be used to increase its cash position. It said it was negotiating the sale of other nonstrategic assets to enable it to eliminate its bank debt. The price of Wang's class B shares rose 37.5 cents, or 6.4 percent, to $4.25 on the American Stock Exchange.

title: Police in the Ivory Coast Suppress Continuing Protests by Students
description: Riot policemen used tear gas and stun grenades today to stop student protesters from reaching the presidential office, where the government of President Felix Houphouet-Boigny discussed an economic crisis that is provoking increased dissent.

title: Prairie Oil Royalties reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Upheaval in the East;   How to Hammer Germany Back Together: The Nuts and Bolts
description: With the two Germanys seeming to move rapidly toward reunification, the debate is over how it should be done.

Harvey Gets Redmen (As Usual) Out of a Jam
description: Greg (Boo) Harvey, a last-minute hero for the second time in three games, hit a 12-foot jumper with three seconds left as St. John's rallied to beat Pittsburgh, 76-75, tonight in the Big East Conference game.

title: S.E.C. Allows Fund Holding
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission voted unanimously today to allow mutual funds to buy securities of foreign banks s d d surarae coc panies.

MCorp Backs Sale Of El Paso Bank

A management-led group will buy the bank's assets of $1.1 billion and deposits of $946 million for an undisclosed amount of cash. The transaction awaits additional regulatory approval and is expected to be completed by Sept. 30, the company said.

description: b-Net income and after a gain of $414,000, or 18 cents a share, from a cumulative effect on prior periods of an accounting change.

title: Rig Count Drops Again
description: The number of rigs exploring for oil and gas continued to decline last week, falling by 21, to 897, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. But the count so far this year remains 19 percent above last year's 757, said Ike Kerridge Jr., an economist with Baker Hughes. Mr. Kerridge said the rig count generally declines in the first quarter and is expected to bottom out in March or April.

description: Brightwater Towers, many of its tenants say, is a fine place to live, with many apartments looking out over the Coney Island Boardwalk to the steely Atlantic beyond. It is, in fact, so fine that the owner plans to pay each household as much as $38,000 to get the residents to leave.

description: ON Thursday, Dr. William L. Roper moves from the White House to head the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta, bringing an unusual combination of a trained physician's mind and political expertise to an agency that generally ranks low on the scale of political influence.

title: A Longer Day
description: The earth's rotation slowed minutely over a 10-day period recently, stretching the length of the day by two-thousandths of a second, timekeeping officials have reported.

description: The North American indoor track and field season had enough problems, with fewer meets this year, a paucity of records and declining attendance. Now, the Panasonic Company has decided not to renew its sponsorship of the Millrose Games, leaving the country's most prestigious indoor track and field meet without vital financial assistance.

The new printer, which offers improved printing quality, faster printing of charts and full compatibility with the earlier model, will have a list price of $2,399 when it reaches stores next month.

title: Pessimism in Air as Schools Try Affirmative Action
description: As the New York City school system embarks on the first affirmative-action plan in its history, there is little confidence among officials and scholars that it will significantly increase the numbers of minority teachers and little evidence that it will improve student performance.

Paul, Ralph and Albert Reichmann, and their giant property company, sued the Toronto Life Publishing Company and others in 1987 after a profile of the family was published in Toronto Life magazine. They are seeking damages of $102 million (Canadian), about $85 million in United States currency, for loss of reputation. In his ruling last week, Justice William Anderson said Olympia & York's financial statements might be necessary for the defendants to prepare their defense.

Jeffords Jr., former president, general manager and principal executive of the Brooklyn Borough Gas Company, died of a heart attack on Saturday while driving with his wife near their home in South Padre Island, Tex. He was 76 years old and also had residences in Christiana, Pa., Saratoga Springs, N.Y., and Lexington, Ky.

title: Ambitious Effort Aims to Find Gravity Waves
description: SCIENTISTS plan to embark on their most ambitious effort yet to find and exploit one of the most elusive of the predicted phenomena of nature: gravitational waves. As long ago as 1915, Albert Einstein predicted in his general theory of relativity that the violent birth and death of stars in the universe would give off gravitational waves, bathing the earth in a unique kind of radiation. But so far, after decades of searching with increasingly sensitive detectors, scientists have not found one.
