title: Osborn Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reflected an extraordinary gain of $129,105, or 2 cents a share, on extinguishment of debt, net of tax. c-Net income and reflected gain on extinguishment of debt, net of tax, of $999,577, or 20 cents a share, and after extraordinary credit of $1,246,135, or 24 cents a share, from utilization of loss carryforwards.

title: Helix Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Foster Wheeler reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-Included a gain of $8.2 million, or 23 cents a share, from the sale of an interest in Foster Wheeler Martinez, for both the quarter and year, and the year also included a gain of $3 million, or 9 cents a share, from curtailment and settlement of a foreign pension plan. c-Included a gain of $5.5 million, or 16 cents a share, from the sale of Conergics Corp.

title: Upheaval in the East: The Germanys;   West Berlin Mayor Critical Of Kohl on Boundary Issue
description: West Berlin's Mayor, Walter Momper, in Washington to meet with President Bush, criticized Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany today for failing to state clearly that he and his Government support the present boundary between Poland and Germany.

title: Turnover in Nicaragua;   Aristocratic Democrat; Violeta Barrios de Chamorro
description: Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, who was elected President on Sunday, lives by herself in a house by a park. But like her political career, the house is filled with the images and reminders of the absent figure who still dominates her life, public and private.

title: Lawson Products reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Edward Langenau, 75, A Research Chemist
description: Edward E. Langenau, a research chemist for 38 years, died on Friday at a nursing home in New London, N.H., after a long illness. He was 75 years old and lived in New London.

title: Dinkins to Give Up Mitchell-Lama Home
description: Settling a question that has nagged him for months, Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that he would give up his three-bedroom Mitchell-Lama apartment in upper Manhattan because no one in his family needs it anymore.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a computer editing error, the sports event listings on each highlights page of the Television section this week are those of a week ago. The events are shown correctly in each day's hourly program tables.

title: Homestead Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $1,529,000, or 14 cents a share, for the quarter and an extraordinary loss of $4,963,000 for the year; the year also included a loss of $21,287,000 from an adjustment in accounting. c-After an extraordinary loss of $479,000.

title: Gas Tanker Truck Crashes
description: A tanker truck carrying liquid nitrogen gas collided with a flatbed truck and burst into fire today, forcing the closure of westbound Interstate 84, the state police said. The accident occurred about 1:45 P.M., the police said. No information was immediately available on whether there were any injuries, the police said.

title: Turnover in Nicaragua;   Sleepless Night and Joyous Day for Anti-Sandinista Exiles in U.S.
description: Honking car horns, waving banners and generally cheering themselves hoarse, thousands of Nicaraguan exiles poured into the streets of downtown Miami today for an impromptu, Managua-style caravan to celebrate the opposition coalition's victory over the Sandinistas.

title: Handcuffed In History To Tony C.
description: In baseball, history handcuffs certain batters and pitchers. One is seldom mentioned without the other. Often they are linked in identifying a memorable home run: Bobby Thomson's pennant-winning homer off Ralph Branca, Henry Aaron's 715th homer off Al Downing, Roger Maris's 61st homer off Tracy Stallard. From those moments on, the batter celebrates while the pitcher suffers.

title: 'Fax Poll' Paying Off
description: At Business Month, they resist the term ''repositioning'' to describe the new look and tone of the magazine's March issue.

title: Review/Dance;   Movement On Mean Streets
description: Inside the Dia Art Foundation on Thursday night, it was just like being on some of the streets outside this Mercer Street theater. The space was littered with cans and lumpy bundles. At the start of ''No Place to Stay,'' some of those lumps came to life. They turned out to be members of Koo Dance, a multi-media company. But they symbolized the homeless people of New York City. ''No Place to Stay'' was a powerful 50-minute study of urban destitution making use of a large cast of dancers and musicians.

title: No Settlement in Trial of Doctor's Suit Over AIDS
description: Testimony resumed yesterday without a settlement in the trial of Dr. Veronica Prego's complaint that she contracted AIDS as a result of puncturing her finger on a contaminated needle in Kings County Hospital.

title: Precious Metals Off Sharply As Tokyo Shares Fall Again
description: Prices of precious metals plunged yesterday on extensive selling sparked by another sharp drop in share values in Japan. As share prices tumbled there, many private and institutional investors sold gold, platinum and silver to get cash to meet margin calls from their stockbrokers.

title: By Galanos, the Simplest of Splendors
description: With the dedication of a scientist, James Galanos has focused for most of his life on producing excellence in fashion. The result has usually been expertly crafted clothes in the best fabrics in the world. But he has hit the jackpot in his spring and summer collection. In addition to his marvelous construction, which bears comparison to the best custom-made clothes of Paris, there is a magical simplicity that takes styles as ordinary as a T-shirt and gives them a sense of wonder.

title: Blacks Move South for Positive Reasons
description: To the Editor:

title: One-Period Outburst by Rangers Pays Off
description: Embarrassed, Mike Milbury was nonetheless not inclined to be apologetic. Milbury, his Bruins having given up 40 shots in a 6-1 loss to the Rangers, figured he would at least attempt to get in the last, ultimately meaningless shot of the night.

title: Japan Now Ahead in Nuclear Power, Too
description: Japan is rapidly outpacing the United States in the field of nuclear power, American experts in Government, academia and the utility industry say.

title: Agency Says AIDS Should Not Bar Entry to U.S.
description: The Centers for Disease Control has recommended that AIDS and all other contagious diseases except tuberculosis be removed from a list of illnesses that is used to bar people from entering the country, Federal officials said.

title: International Broadcasting reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Transplant Patient Improves
description: Stormie Jones, the world's first and longest-surviving heart-liver transplant patient, remained in critical but stable condition today as she continued to recover from her second liver transplant, performed last Tuesday. The 12-year-old from White Settlement, Tex., was under intensive care at Children's Hospital here.

title: National Oil & Gas Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago share earnings were adjusted for 7 percent stock dividend paid in December 1989.

title: Envy Seen As Sensitive Barometer
description: A GRADUATE student, depressed that his adviser had taken on another student as well, tried to sign up for all the adviser's appointments so there would be no time left for his rival.

title: Turnover in Nicaragua;   Excerpts From the Speech by Ortega
description: Following are excerpts from a speech this morning by President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua, as recorded and translated by The New York Times:

title: Humphrey Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Latest year figures included a gain of $30,300 from tax-loss carryforwards; the 1988 year included a similar gain of $75,500.

title: Why World Shrugged Off Tokyo's Stock Tumble
description: For some time, market watchers around the world have expressed concern that if the high-flying Tokyo stock market ever plunged, other markets would be carried down with it. But the Japanese stock market's 11 percent dive over the last week, a fairly big move by most standards, has not touched off sharp slides elsewhere, and analysts are scurrying to explain why.

title: Family Retains Control of Times After Iphigene Sulzberger's Death
description: Despite the death of Iphigene Ochs Sulzberger, control of The New York Times and related properties remains with the Sulzberger family. It passes to her four children through the automatic termination of a trust established by her father, Adolph S. Ochs.

title: 1-in-a-Trillion Coincidence, You Say? Not Really, Experts Find
description: COINCIDENCES, those surprising and often eerie events that add spice to everyay life, may not be so unusual after all, researchers say.

title: Cryomedical Sciences reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Iphigene Ochs Sulzberger Is Dead; Central Figure in Times's History
description: Iphigene Ochs Sulzberger, who shaped the history of The New York Times throughout a long and active life, died of respiratory failure in her sleep yesterday morning at her home in Stamford, Conn. She was 97 years old.

title: Homecall reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Turnover in Nicaragua;   Recovering From Injury
description: In many photographs of Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, the Nicaraguan President-elect appears on crutches or a wheelchair, because of a fractured right kneecap that she suffered in a fall in her home at midday on Jan. 2.

title: Time Air Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $2,100,000, or 47 cents a share. c-Included extraordinary credits of $427,000, or 9 cents a share, and $470,000, or 9 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. Revenue figures for the fourth quarter periods were not immediately available.

title: Efforts Grow to Shield Girl in Custody Battle
description: People involved in the bitter custody battle over a 7-year-old American girl are taking steps to protect her from harmful experiences as the case works its way through court.

title: Honors for Offbeat Team That Shook Lacrosse
description: Teams that end up the object of political salutes more often than not are champions.

title: Pro-Med Capital Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Chess
description: ''That's what I was in it for,'' said John Fedorowicz of the Hoogoven Group B International Tournament in Beverwijk, the Netherlands. ''The main thing was that the winner of B would gain automatic entry in next year's A or top group tournament. My first prize does it for me. The money, $1,000 plus my $600 appearance fee, would not otherwise have been a sufficient inducement for me to play.''

title: Terreri Brilliant In Weekend Under Fire
description: The struggling Devils yielded 96 shots on goal in their last two games, but they earned 3 valuable points thanks to Chris Terreri's terrific play in goal.

title: Companies That Temper Ambition
description: Success in American business normally means scaling the ladder to the executive suite. But today more and more of the nation's leading corporations are encouraging employees to step off the fast track, and convincing even business school graduates that they can find rewards and happiness in lateral mobility.

title: Shearson To Get Cash From Parent
description: In a renewed effort to put more cash into Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., the American Express Company said yesterday that it would inject $750 million by buying new stock in the securities firm.

title: Variety of Consultants
description: Although the National Football League will not replace Dr. Forrest Tennant with a new drug adviser until late March, Tennant's successor will have several consultants for advice in key areas.

title: Southmark Is Sued by Unit
description: The San Jacinto Savings and Loan Association has filed a $1.4 billion claim against its parent, the Southmark Corporation, saying Southmark had forced it to make bad loans.

title: Library Bureau Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Latest quarter figures included a gain of about $221,000 from the sale of the company's interest in KSI Building Products, partially offset by a equity loss in KSI of $51,000. Year-ago figures included a loss in affiliate of about $48,000.

title: Turnover in Nicaragua;   Nicaraguan Decade: War, Ruin and Turnabout
description: 1978: Pedro Joaquin Chamorro, editor of the newspaper La Prensa, is shot to death on a Managua street by unidentified assassins, intensifying discontent that undermines the dictatorship of Anastasio Somoza Debayle.

title: Lawrence L. Hand, Lutheran Bishop, 59
description: Bishop Lawrence L. Hand, the spiritual leader of nearly 125,00 Lutherans in Philadelphia and its suburbs, died Saturday night, apparently of a heart attack, at a wedding reception in Norristown, Pa. He was 59 years old and lived in Norristown.

title: Slain Girl's Bloody Clothing Displayed by Expert at Trial
description: Testifying today in the murder trial of Robert Golub, a forensic expert from the Nassau County Medical Examiner's office held up clothing - a T-shirt, an oversize cardigan sweater and a pair of sneakers - and described how investigators found them covered with the blood of Kelly Ann Tinyes last March.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Newfoundland Capital reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $250,000, or 5 cents a share. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: American Precision Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-Included an after tax-gain of about $303,000 from the sale of unimproved land in 1989 for both the quarter and year.

title: Right Management ConsultFants reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits from an international subsidiary of $5,000 and $92,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Year Pact for Jefferies
description: Gregg Jefferies was among six young members of the Mets who signed one-year contracts yesterday, leaving the club with seven other players unsigned for 1990. He signed a contract for $200,000. His 1989 salary was $100,500. Last season, Jefferies had a .258 batting average, 12 home runs and 56 runs batted in.

title: At Least 30 Die as Gale Winds Hit Western Europe
description: Gale-force winds struck Western Europe today, tearing down roofs and power lines, disrupting land, sea and air transportation, and killing at least 30 people.

title: Claire's Stores Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
Shuttle Workers Load Fuel for New Liftoff Effort
description: After taking a 48-hour break in hopes of better weather and luck, mission controllers prepared today for another attempt to launch the space shuttle Atlantis.

title: Drug Agency Chief Is Retiring
description: The Administrator of the Drug Enforcement Administration announced today that he would retire March 23.

title: Tom Barwise, Food Executive, 80
description: Tom Barwise, co-founder of the Old El Paso brand of Mexican food products, died here Saturday. He was 80 years old and lived in El Paso.

title: Education;   Lessons
description: When the country's governors unanimously approved six goals for improving America's schools by the year 2000, President Bush congratulated them for ushering in ''a new era of education reform.''

title: In Manhattan Havel Couldn't Escape His Guards
description: LEAD: When Vaclav Havel, Czechoslovakia's new President, visited New York City the other day, a handful of young Secret Service agents took care of his security. There were likeable, intelligent, highly professional, well-mannered and tough but tactful. But something was odd: They didn't know Manhattan.

title: Restaurant Gunfire Kills 2
description: A man shot and killed one person and critically wounded another in a downtown restaurant early this morning and then was himself shot to death by the police. The Police Chief, Don Millhouse, said the gunman had begun firing after ''some kind of an argument started, we don't know what about.'' The Chief said the names of those shot would not be disclosed until relatives were notified.

title: Sports News Briefs;   DeBus's Hearing In Drug Case Set
description: After five postponements over is scheduled tomorrow in Los Angeles to consider testimony against Chuck DeBus, a track coach who has been accused by several athletes of advocating and managing their use of performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Boy, 5, in a Whisky Coma
description: Raymond Griffin, a 5-year-old boy who the police said was given 10 ounces of whisky at a party at his house and told to ''drink it like a man,'' was in a coma today and reported to have irreversible brain damage. Anthony Jimerson of Fort Worth, a 21-year-old guest at the party, was arrested on charges of injury to a child.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Feb. 20 about a new class of materials that respond to light by rearranging the electric charges in their microscopic structures misstated an affiliation of Dr. Jack Feinberg. He is at the University of Southern California.

title: The Kimbell Decides Its Building Is a Treasure to Be Cherished
description: The Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth, responding to an outpouring of criticism of the additions it planned to its celebrated building by the architect Louis I. Kahn, announced yesterday that it had postponed the new structures indefinitely.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Adage Inc., Billerica, Mass., a computer graphics company, said its holders had approved the acquisition of the company by General Business Investment Corp., West Chester, Pa.

title: Plans Pressed To Abandon Grand Juries
description: New York State's grand jury system, once seen as the protector of the rights of the accused, is coming under rising attack both from law-and-order advocates and civil libertarians, who say it has instead become an inefficient captive of often overzealous prosecutors.

title: N.F.L. Lengthens Its Season To Fit New TV Arrangement
description: To accommodate a huge new television deal, the National Football League will change its longstanding format of playing 16 consecutive weeks in the regular season.

title: Lenders Say Managua Has a Long Road Back
description: Despite a newly proclaimed eagerness by the Bush Administration and the World Bank to breathe new life into Nicaragua's economy, economists predict that the rebuilding will take years after more than a decade of war and a United States-sponsored trade embargo.

title: Chrysler Plans to Sell And Lease Back Center
description: In a move intended to raise cash for its automotive operations, the Chrysler Corporation today confirmed plans to sell and lease back the sprawling technology center it is building in a Detroit suburb.

title: Nicaraguan Envoys Resign Themselves To Sandinista Loss
description: Sadness and perplexity hung over the Nicaraguan Embassy today, as diplomats and staffers resigned themselves to their imminent departure from Washington as a result of the Sandinista election defeat.

title: Results Plus
description: TRACK AND FIELD

title: Some East Germans See Their Hopes Eclipsed by Bonn's Ascendancy
description: New Forum, the mass citizens' movement that played the leading role in the overthrow of Communist rule last autumn, has fallen from elation into dejection now that its victory appears complete.

title: Bridge
description: Each year three Charity Games are played throughout North America, and each generates close to $70,000 for the American Contract Bridge League's Charity Foundation. The same deals are played in every club, and the players receive an analysis sheet with an expert prediction of the likely course of bidding and play.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: THE term chopped beefsteak may sound like menu jargon for hamburger, but the recipe here is really much more than just run-of-the-mill burgers with melted cheese. For one, it begins with about one-and-a-half pounds of beef cut from the round. This is slightly more expensive than regular hamburger from chuck, but far superior. Beef round has better flavor, is leaner and has less gristle than chuck.

title: The Sauce Is Tangy, The Joking Tasteless
description: Christopher Carroll has heard all the jokes already, thank you. About how this is a spicy story. A hot controversy. A messy situation that drips with drama.

title: KEY RATES
Reviews/Music;   How It Feels to Be in Jail
description: ''The Empty Chair'' - played Saturday evening at the Kitchen - is a mixed-media piece by G. E. Lewis that through television, computer-generated music and live performers instructs the audience on the experience of being in jail. Its center is a long and intermittent soliloquy by Bernard Mixon. Mr. Mixon, in a resonant bass narrative style, describes the protagonist's youth in Southern black America, his college education in Northern schools, his idealism gone askew and his current status as penitentiary prisoner.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a computer editing error, the sports event listings on each highlights page of the Television section this week are those of a week ago. The events are shown correctly in each day's hourly program tables.

title: Hofstra Names Gardi
description: From 1976 to 1984, Joe Gardi served as an assistant coach and defensive coordinator under three Jet coaches. Yesterday, Gardi returned to the Jets' training site, Hofstra University, and this time he did so as Hofstra's new head coach.

title: New Pantheon Head Named Amid Resignation Protest
description: Amid a growing portest from authors, Random House Inc. appointed Fred Jordan as vice president and publisher of Pantheon Books yesterday, effective March 15.

title: Real Estate;   Bridge-Vault Development Is Stalled
description: THE concept seems efficient and appealing for crowded Manhattan: Use the gigantic empty vaults beneath the Brooklyn and Queensboro bridges as commercial, retail and even residential space to help ease the demand for development sites.

title: This Month: Dr. Jessica B. Harris, Brooklyn;   Tracking Cuisines With African Past
description: ''AT the moment my decorating motif is cat hairs and plaster dust,'' said Dr. Jessica B. Harris with characteristic acerbity. She is showing a visitor around the odd and interesting house she is remodeling in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, and her apologetic tone does not quite disguise the obvious pride she feels in the place.

title: Service for Drew Middleton
description: A memorial service for Drew Middleton, former foreign correspondent and military correspondent of The New York Times, will be held on Tuesday at 11 A.M. at the Century Club, at 7 West 43d Street. Speakers will include Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, Clifton Daniel and John Chancellor. Mr. Middleton died at his Manhattan apartment on Jan. 10 at the age of 76.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Profit Up at Omnicom
description: The Omnicom Group, the communications conglomerate that includes the advertising agencies BBDO Worldwide and DDB Needham Worldwide, reported yesterday that net income for its fourth quarter was $17.13 million, or 66 cents a share, compared with net income of $15.65 million, or 63 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1988. Revenue was $296.43 million, compared with $251.41 million in the 1988 quarter. For all of 1989, net income was $46.79 million, or $1.81 a share, compared with $39.19 million, or $1.58 a share, in 1988. Revenues were $1.02 billion, compared with $889.23 million in 1988.

title: Benjamin F. Schwartz, Navy Prosecutor, 80
description: Benjamin F. Schwartz, a prosecutor with the Navy, died of heart failure on Sunday. He was 80 years old.

title: National Trustco reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $1,425,000 from the sale of securities. c-After an extraordinary credit of $622,000, or 2 cents a share, from the sale of securities. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: A Postal Showdown in Westchester
description: Working conditions in the cramped regional mail center here are bad, postal officials concede. The roof leaks, sorting is done on several levels and employees have only a third of the space they require. In summer tents are put up.

title: W. E. Buckler, 65, Literature Professor And a Former Dean
description: William Earl Buckler, a specialist in Victorian literature and a former dean of New York University's Washington Square College of Arts and Sciences, died of cancer on Sunday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Reviews/Dance;   Cool Passion From Robbins And City Ballet
description: ''Other Dances,'' presented by the New York City Ballet on Saturday afternoon at the New York State Theater, is Jerome Robbins at his most sophisticated. An extended pas de deux set to Chopin piano pieces, the ballet has the music's teasing folk accents but is essentially a dance of stylized abandon and cool passion, founded in the classical ballet technique, for two playful and dreaming lovers.

title: Review/Music;   A Russian Opera And a Work By Weill
description: How much of Dmitri Shostakovich resides in ''Rothschild's Violin'' is something we shall never really know or perhaps need to. The one-act opera after Chekhov's story was left incomplete by Shostakovich's pupil Benjamin Fleischmann before he marched off to die in defense of Leningrad during 1941. The Juilliard Opera Center made ''Rothschild's Violin'' part of its double bill at the school on Friday night, joining it with Kurt Weill's hybrid stage work of 1933, ''The Seven Deadly Sins.''

title: Benches Removed From Subway Stations
description: Unable to enforce rules that prohibit people from sleeping on subway benches, the New York City Transit Authority is trying a new tack: removing the benches altogether.

title: Trade Deficit Shrank in '89
description: The United States trade deficit increased slightly in the fourth quarter of 1989 but narrowed to $113.2 billion for all of last year, its lowest level since 1984, the Government reported today.

title: Chronicle
description: For their "courageous and selfless actions during the Armenian earthquake relief effort," the Soviet Ambassador, YURIY V. DUBININ, gave his nation's Personal Courage award yesterday to some of the Americans who helped during the Armenian earthquake in 1988

title: The Easily Handled Phyllo Pastry Challenges Its Puffy Rival
description: A ONCE-IN-A-GENERATION change has been taking place in restaurant kitchens across the country with little notice. Phyllo, the flaky, thin pastry of the Middle East, has slowly but most certainly been replacing the finicky puff pastry that classical chefs both adore and curse.

title: Island Still Suffers Hurricane Scars
description: It has been five months since Hurricane Hugo tore into this hilly enclave of 8,000 people off Puerto Rico's northeast coast, but the physical and psychic scars of the ordeal are still painfully apparent.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Healthful Dining

title: Parcel Bomb Wounds Leading Spanish Judge
description: A parcel bomb severely wounded the president of Madrid's High Court today, the police said.

title: Washington Council Backs Vote on Congress Delegation
description: With the issue of statehood for the District of Columbia stirring once again, the City Council today authorized an election this fall in which voters will choose a ''shadow'' Congressional delegation to lobby the cause on Capitol Hill.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Autodesk Inc., Sausalito, Calif., a design software company, named Carolyn Aver chief financial officer. She replaces Donald W. Lohin, who is leaving the company.

title: Metro Airlines Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $1,150,000. c-Net income and after income of $7,965,000, or $1.37 a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Pungent Wisdom From A Kitchen Olympian
description: MIDWINTER rain fell in a contemplative pitter-patter on the stucco hacienda tucked in the hills. A calico cat sat rigid as a sphinx on the back stoop of the ranch, glaring at the heavy wooden door. But a guest standing inside saw only miles of vineyards, parched from a dry season, turning their pruned tips toward the sky.

title: Dow Climbs by 14.64; Tokyo Market Gains
description: Stock prices advanced for the second straight session yesterday on slightly stepped-up volume.

title: Poland Resumes Full Diplomatic Ties With Israel
description: Israel and Poland resumed full diplomatic relations today after a 23-year break. Poland was the third Warsaw Pact country to renew relations with Israel in the last six months.

title: Tokyo Stock Market: Island No Longer
description: The turbulence in the Tokyo financial markets in the last week has shown that the influence of one nation's market on another's, a process that has been dubbed globalization, is in some ways more powerful but works in more subtle ways than had been thought. It has also provided a vivid lesson of how much Japan's financial markets, now the world's largest, have changed in the last two years because of the easing of financial regulations and the rise of Japan as a global financial power.

title: Education;   Bush Criticized on Schools
description: House Speaker Thomas S. Foley said today that President Bush was failing to back up his oratory about educational excellence with Federal money and the Administration's proposed 2 percent spending increase for schools was ''meager'' and ''tepid.''

title: Arbor Drugs reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
For Mrs. Chamorro, The Honeymoon's Over
description: The Nicaraguan election, far from having clarified a murky situation, has plunged that country into a series of ever murkier questions.

title: Baseball Players Say They Won't Concede
description: Locked out of their spring training camps in Arizona and in Florida, a band of 100 major league baseball players met here today and refused to budge on the union's position in the stalemated labor negotiations.

title: Review/Music;   Love and Fidelity in Mozart's Harem
description: Mozart's ''Entfuhrung aus dem Serail,'' which returned to the Metropolitan Opera's repertory on Monday evening, is typical of his later works in that seriousness and comedy are so intertwined that it is pointless to wonder where the one leaves off and the other begins. Even in this lighthearted singspiel about the attempted abduction of an English woman from a Turkish harem there are sober undercurrents. As in ''Le Nozze di Figaro,'' ''Don Giovanni'' and ''Cosi Fan Tutte,'' Mozart manages to deal both broadly and subtly with the tangled questions of love and fidelity.

title: A Florida Hotel Where a Rabbi Opens The Restaurant and Kosher Prevails
description: ALONG with requests for water or more rolls, patrons at the lobby restaurant in the Hyatt Orlando hotel here often ask for something more: a rabbi.

title: Prince's Studio Makes A Star of Hometown
description: The entertainment realm of the pop-music superstar Prince is radically altering the reputation of a city whose main contribution to the movie industry used to be industrial training films.

title: House of Fabrics reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Now Batting in Birmingham
description: Major league baseball's stodgy owners are advised to note what's happening in minor-league Birmingham, Ala. The Japanese are coming. Suntory International, the American subsidiary of the largest privately owned company in Japan, is buying the Birmingham Barons, the hottest team in the Southern League.

title: Nucor Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After income of $38,558,822, or $1.82 a share, from discontinued operations. The company said pre-operating costs and start-up costs of new facilities reduced 1989 earnings by $1.85 a share, and 1988 earnings by $1.10 a share.

title: Among The Gators
description: We are somewhere in Florida.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: EXXON IS INDICTED BY U.S. GRAND JURY IN SPILL AT VALDEZ
description: A Federal grand jury in Anchorage today indicted the Exxon Corporation and its shipping subsidiary on five criminal counts stemming from the Alaskan oil spill, after negotiations between the Justice Department and the company on a settlement of the case broke down. .

title: The High Cost of Keeping the Northeast Warm
description: To the Editor:

title: Occidental Accord
description: A group of shareholders of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation has settled a dispute over the use of $86 million in Occidental funds to build an art museum for Armand Hammer, the company's chairman and chief executive. Another group, however, said it would oppose the proposed settlement when the class action lawsuit comes up for approval in Delaware Chancery Court on April 4.

title: Pretoria Foes Press Death-Squad Attack
description: A renewed outcry among opponents of the Government suggested today that Defense Minister Minister Magnus A. Malan had failed in his latest attempt to deflect pressures for a full and prompt disclosure of the activities of a secret military unit accused of killing opponents of apartheid.

title: Reviews/Music;   Arleen Auger Song Recital Stays an All-German Affair
description: Arleen Auger's recital of German lieder at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday evening showed intelligence even in its choice of encores. Evidently counting on the fact that few in the audience would leave (few did), Miss Auger parceled out a set of songs by Richard Strauss one at a time with spoken introductions and translations, nicely rounding out a program comprising Schubert, Wolf and Strauss in the first half and Schoenberg and Wolf in the second.

title: Nova Scotia Prices 9 1/4% Debentures
description: The Province of Nova Scotia yesterday priced $300 million in 9 1/4 percent debentures due in 2020 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Reviews/Dance;   An Old Man Who Isn't and Love That Kills
description: Folklore and music and the classical ballet might seem to be odd artistic partners. But the Hartford Ballet took on the challenge in an ingenious bit of programming on Friday night at the Bushnell Auditorium here. The program, called ''Folksteps,'' consisted of works set to scores drawn from folk music. Michael Uthoff's ''Tom Dula,'' was based on a folk legend. ''Coming of Age in the Milky Way,'' a new piece by Robby Barnett, Michael Tracy and Jonathan Wolken of Pilobolus, created its own mythologies.

title: U.P.I. Action On Reuters
description: United Press International asked a Federal court on Monday for an injunction to prevent Reuters from backing out of a photo exchange agreement between the two news agencies.

title: Panel Questions Credibility Of Nuclear Health Checks
description: A special panel has concluded that the program for monitoring the health of workers in the nuclear weapons industry should be moved from the Department of Energy to another Federal agency because the program's credibility has been damaged.

title: Omnicom Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the impact of acquisitions net of divestitures favorably affected fourth quarter commission and fee income by 11 percent, compared to a year ago, and favorably affected 12-month commission and fee income by about 7 percent, compared to the prior year.

title: Article 642490 -- No Title
description: The United States Postal Service announced a reward of up to $50,000 on Monday for information leading to a conviction in a mail bombing that injured Lisa Osteen, the 31-year-old daughter of John Osteen, a non-denominational church's pastor, at his church on Jan. 30.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   McCall's to Revamp Over Next 6 Months
description: Beginning with the April issue, readers of McCall's will be able to watch the magazine reshape itself during the next six months. The redesign will feature a cover that the publisher says is less cluttered. There will also be more emphasis on home fashion and furnishings. The redesign is an attempt to separate the women's service magazine from its six primary competitors.

title: Open Positions on Short Sales Increase by 9.2% on Nasdaq
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers yesterday reported a rise of almost 9.2 percent in the short interest in actively traded over-the-counter securities in its national market system for the four weeks that ended in mid-February.

title: Myers Signed by Nets
description: Looking to improve their bench, the Nets yesterday claimed Pete Myers on waivers only five days after the 6-foot-6-inch swingman was waived by the Knicks when they acquired Stuart Gray in a trade. To make room for Myers on the roster, New Jersey waived Jaren Jackson, a rookie guard from Georgetown.

title: Guy Caesar Bauman, Met Art Historian, 38
description: Guy Caesar Bauman, an art historian and assistant curator in the European paintings department at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, died of AIDS at his home on Sunday. He was 38 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Education;   School Turns Losers Into Winners
description: Young Aaron Cann, a teen-age dropout from high school, was a tall, husky neighborhood bully who had lots of money. With plenty of crack to sell and many customers, he had a lucrative business.

title: Bank of New England To Announce Chief
description: Lawrence Fish, formerly an executive vice president at the Bank of Boston Corporation, is expected to be named chairman and chief executive today at the Bank of New England Corporation, sources close to the bank said.

title: U.S. Schools Need an Integrated World History
description: To the Editor:

title: Northeast Utilities reports earnings for 12mo Jan 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $2,647,000, or 3 cents a share, for the latest year and $7,552,000, or 7 cents a share, for prior year. Revenue figures are from continuing operations.

title: Turnpike Sidesteps Confrontation And Votes to Keep Present Tolls
description: The New Jersey Turnpike Authority voted yesterday not to raise tolls this year, sidestepping a threatened showdown with Gov. Jim Florio.

title: After 10 Years, Queen Gives Up Hotel Scepter
description: Leona Helmsley loved her image as the queen of the hotel chain she runs. And she fiercely guarded it. When one advertising executive proposed an ad that featured the arm of a model reaching for a towel in a Helmsley hotel, she scrapped the idea. ''The only arm in these ads is going to be mine,'' she told the executive. But now the queen has abdicated. For the first time in 10 years, Leona Helmsley's likeness will not be seen in the hotels' advertisements when a new print advertising campaign for them begins in April.

title: How Bases Came to Be In Democratic Districts
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place;   Investors Return to Stock Funds
description: Despite a choppy stock market in February, investors resumed their purchases of stock mutual funds at a rapid rate, fund managers said yesterday. Investors had moved out of such funds in January for the first time in seven months.

title: Report Urges Low-Fat Diet for Everyone
description: Federal health officials recommended yesterday for the first time that all Americans, not just those with high cholesterol levels, reduce the fat content of their diets to lower their risk of heart disease.

title: Kremlin Says It Found Secret Soviet-Nazi Pact
description: The Soviet Foreign Ministry has acknowledged that it has found copies of a secret Soviet-Nazi agreement that allotted parts of Eastern Europe to the Soviet Union.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Economic Scene;   So Long, Marlboro Man
description: THE latest figures on death and destruction from tobacco, released last week by the Department of Health and Human Services, hold few surprises. The $52 billion financial toll estimated for 1985 looks downright conservative next to the $65 billion calculation made five years ago by the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment.

title: Eating Well
description: FOOD manufacturers seem to have a penchant for taking nutritious foods and processing them to the point where they are no longer wholesome. Potatoes are a good example. In its purest form, a medium 5-ounce potato provides only 155 calories and is virtually free of fat and sodium. Potatoes are also good sources of complex carbohydrates, fiber and vitamin B6, and excellent sources of vitamin C and potassium.

title: Book Notes
description: Paperback Rushdie

title: Joint Venture Expected For Display Screens
description: Several electronics companies are discussing the formation of a venture to develop and produce display screens for use in laptop computers, military gear and television sets, an official involved in the venture said today.

title: United Brands
description: The United Brands Company announced it would change its name to Chiquita Brands International Inc., effective March 20. The change is intended to increase the Cincinnati-based company's recognition, but will not alter its business strategy, said Keith E. Lindner, president and chief operating officer. The company is a leading marketer of fresh fruit and vegetables, including Chiquita bananas, along with prepared foods. The American Financial Corporation, a Cincinnati-based holding company that holds 82 percent of United Brands' common stock, has approved the name change and no further shareholder action is required. The Cincinnati financier Carl H. Lindner controls American Financial.

title: Notebook King Is Clever as a Legal Infighter
description: Is Don King's firm grip on the heavyweight division loosening?

title: Mitchell Set to Move a Clean Air Bill to Senate Floor
description: As bargaining on clean air legislation continued out of the public eye, the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, insisted today that he would bring legislation back to the floor Thursday, with or without an agreement with the Bush Administration.

title: Centaur Settles Part of Legal Fight
description: Centaur Partners said it and National Intergroup had settled half of a legal fight between the two parties in Delaware State Court. Under the agreement, disclosed in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, National Intergroup has allowed Centaur to solicit consents from the company's shareholders to force the election of a majority of the board at the company's next annual meeting, without starting the company's anti-takeover plan.

title: Honda Export Plan
description: The Honda Motor Company plans to export a United States-made Accord station wagon to Europe, Honda's chief executive, Tadashi Kume, said. Honda will begin making the Accord wagon at its assembly plant in Marysville, Ohio, later this year for the 1991 model year. Honda's Marysville plant now makes the Civic and Accord models. By 1992, Honda will more than double its production at its East Liberty, Ohio, plant to 150,000 cars a year, while production of about 360,000 cars a year will continue at Marysville, a Honda spokesman, Aki Kato, said. Of those, about 50,000 cars will be shipped to Japan from the United States. Other cars, including the Accord wagon, will be shipped to Europe, Mr. Kato said.

title: DIVISIONS HARDEN IN LEBANESE FIGHT
description: After a month of bitter fighting between rival factions, Lebanon's 300-square-mile Christian enclave has been partitioned into war zones, further splintering this divided country.

title: Arab Students in West Bank Protest Israel's School Ban
description: Palestinian students protesting Israel's two-year shutdown of their universities held sit-ins today in the occupied West Bank and one rally ended in clashes with troops.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: AFTER FEBRUARY

title: Chronicle
description: He began as a bad guy, but RICHARD WIDMARK was a Hollywood hero when he received the D. W. Griffith Career Achievement Award for his 40 years in films.

title: U.S. to Aid Negotiations On Contra Repatriation
description: Bush Administration officials said today that they would try to arrange negotiations between the Nicaraguan guerrillas and the new President-elect of Nicaragua so that the contras could disband and return home as soon as possible.

title: Sports News Briefs;   300 Attend Rites For Conigliaro
description: Tony Conigliaro, who died of pneumonia and kidney failure Saturday eight years after suffering a near-fatal heart attack that had left him an invalid, was remembered here today as a local boy who played the outfield and was a home run hitter for the Boston Red Sox.

title: Celtic Pact for Shaw
description: The Boston Celtics announced yesterday they had reached agreement on a multiyear contract with the guard Brian Shaw beginning next season.

title: Another Hurley Stars As St. Anthony Rolls
description: Danny Hurley's burden lines two walls of the Jersey City National Guard Armory.

title: Diasonics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits which represents the after-tax gain on the sale of discontinued operations, net of discontinued operating losses of $60,493,000, or 79 cents a share for the quarter and $54,109,000, or 72 cents a share for the year. c-After extraordinary charges of $402,000 for the quarter and $1,827,000 for the year.

title: Philippine Support for Aquino Continues
description: To the Editor:

title: Samuel R. Mozes Is Dead at 66; A Former New York City Planner
description: Samuel R. Mozes, a city planner for more than a quarter-century and a figure in international Jewish affairs, died of a heart attack last Wednesday at his home in East Hampton, L.I. He was 66 years old.

title: Integrated Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $28,344,000 for the quarter and $637,739,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income and after income from discontinued operations of $8,601,000, or $1.15 a share, for the quarter and $25,160,000, or $3.34 a share, for the 9 months. Share earnings reflected after preferred stock dividends. The operating results of the life insurance segment were restated to conform with requirements of Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 97 and the discontinuance of the life insurance segment, securities clearing operations and non-financial services operations.

title: Bank of Montreal reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The provision for credit losses in the latest quarter of $49 million represented a forecast provision for the 1990 fiscal year of about $196 million. The company said it does not expect to make provisions this year on its LDC portfolio. Results are in Canadian dollars. The bank is listed on the Montreal Stock Exchange.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We can talk openly about sex, violence, war, condoms and deviant behavior on television, in the newspaper and on the floor of the Congress. Yet we cannot seem to talk honestly and openly about whether we need more or less taxes, more or less spending, or what, if anything, we should do about the rising cost of entitlements.''

title: Text of Statement By Father Ritter
description: Following is the text of a statement released last night by the Rev. Bruce Ritter:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17

title: U.S. Urges U.N. Probe Of Cuban Rights Cases
description: The United States urged the United Nations today to investigate Cuba's human rights record.

title: Senate Again Blocks Armenian Resolution
description: The Senate voted today for the second time to block a resolution commemorating the mass death of Armenian civilians during World War I at the hands of the Ottoman Turks.

title: Budapest's Hard-Liners Seeking to Try It Again
description: One of the most thankless jobs in salesmanship has to be trying to persuade Hungarians to vote Communist in 1990.

title: Medflies and Malathion
description: The city fathers of Pasadena, Calif., sent up their police helicopter last Thursday night. Its task was to ticket some helicopters engaged by the state to spray the dreaded Mediterranean fruit fly. The bust was observed, of course, by a fleet of television helicopters. It's hard not to wonder if the fight between the fly and its foes hasn't lost touch with the ground.

title: Raiders Sign Montoya
description: The free-agent offensive lineman Max Montoya, a veteran of 11 seasons with the Cincinnati Bengals and a Pro Bowl player the past two years, has signed with the Los Angeles Raiders.

title: Knicks Regain Their Form and Stop a Losing Streak
description: The Knicks have long talked about the need to fit all the parts of their game together. But it was mostly talk, until last night.

title: Cornell Gunter, 53, Member of Coasters
description: Cornell Gunter, the lead singer of the Coasters, the doo-wop group whose hit recordings in the late 1950's included ''Yakety Yak'' and ''Charlie Brown,'' was shot dead here in his car on Monday, the police said today. He was 53 years old.

title: Nets' Road Slump at 16 After Loss to Pacers
description: Reggie Miller and Chuck Person each scored 25 points tonight as the Indiana Pacers handed the Nets their 16th straight road loss, 118-113.

title: About New York;   Old 'Contenders' Look for Help On Final Count
description: Here is the heavyweight Doug Jones who fought Muhammad Ali, then Cassius Clay, in a 10-rounder at Madison Square Garden on March 10, 1963, and believes that judges robbed him of an earned victory.

title: Fed Chairman Criticizes Social Security Tax Cut
description: As lawmakers continued to grapple for a response to Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's proposal to cut Social Security taxes, Alan Greenspan, who as chairman of the Federal Reserve is the Government's most influential economic policy maker, said today that Mr. Moynihan had properly diagnosed a crippling national problem but had prescribed the wrong medicine.

title: Rocky Flats Plant Has Gained a Year To Find Waste Site
description: The Bush Administration has gained more than a year to find a new storage site for plutonium waste generated by the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant near Denver.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   People
description: Sue Parento has joined Young & Rubicam as senior vice president and associate creative director.

title: Review/Television;   Halting Time's Ravages So Art May Endure
description: The ravages inflicted by time, nature and man on some of the world's most treasured monuments and works of art have received belated and somewhat panicky attention in recent years. If you've wondered what is going on behind the scaffoldings and tarpulins that keep tourists from seeing what they came to see, tune into ''The Future of the Past.'' This surprisingly upbeat episode of ''The Infinite Voyage,'' at 8 P.M. on Channels 13 and 49, tells of the efforts to save such prized expressions of Western civilization as the Parthenon, the stained-glass windows of Cologne Cathedral, the frescoes of Florence and New York's own Statue of Liberty.

title: U.S. Schools Need an Integrated World History;   Diversity and Tradition
description: To the Editor:

title: Producer Talks of Rooney's Return Soon
description: The executive producer of ''60 Minutes'' yesterday attributed a recent drop in the program's ratings in large part to the suspension of Andy Rooney and, in a memo posted at the CBS Broadcast Center, told staff members that the commentator ''will soon be coming back.''

title: A Darwinian Creation of Software
description: A fledgling science that creates software whose behavior mimics that of living creatures is beginning to provide scientists with a new class of software tools with significant commercial potential.

title: 25 Are Hurt as Storm Floods Welsh Village
description: Raging seas, whipped up by a storm that has killed 51 people in Europe, surged through a shattered sea wall and swamped homes in this coastal village today.

title: At Prague Colleges, Marxism Withers Away
description: Sitting in his half-emptied office, Prof. Zdenek Safar mulls over his future. For most of the last two decades, the 42-year-old instructor has taught Marxist-Leninist philosophy.

title: Mets Tickets Going on Sale
description: Tickets to Met home games will go on sale at 9 A.M. tomorrow at Shea Stadium and at all Ticketron outlets as well as through the Ticketron phone charge service.

title: The Spare-No-Cost Wedding Regains Popularity in China
description: After lavishing cigarettes and wine upon his wedding guests, Quan Xinguo hugged his new wife and chortled with delight over the sumptuousness of the nuptial celebrations. After all, they had cost nearly $6,000, or more than six years' wages.

title: A $194.04 Million Offering Is Made by New York State
description: New York State yesterday priced a $194.04 million issue of general obligation bonds and awarded the financing to a group of underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Market.

title: Retired Executive in Ohio Accused of Insider Trades
description: The Federal Government yesterday accused a recently retired senior executive of Philips Industries of Dayton, Ohio, of violating Federal insider trading laws for selling blocks of the company's stock shortly before it announced unfavorable news.

title: Antar Absent at Court Date
description: The founder of the Crazy Eddie Inc. electronics chain failed to appear today before a Federal judge to answer demands that he return $52 million to the United States.

title: INSIDE
description: Mandela Goes Abroad

title: 47 KILLED IN INDIA AS 8 STATES VOTE
description: At least 47 people were killed and 200 wounded by bombs, factional battles or the police today in voting for legislatures in eight Indian states, news agencies reported.

title: Reprimand for Coach
description: The Indiana State coach, Tates Locke, has been publicly reprimanded by Commissioner Doug Elgin of the Missouri Valley Conference for criticizing the officiating Saturday following the Sycamores' 67-60 home loss to Wichita State. Following the game, Locke said, ''The officiating in our league is awful but that was the worst out there.'' He also criticized Referee Willie Sanchez with an ethnic slur, for which Locke apologized yesterday. (AP)

title: Why Teen-Agers Dress the Way They Do
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 29 about the efforts of Lewis du Pont Smith, an heir to the du Pont fortune, to regain control of his inheritance misidentified the publisher of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders. It is the American Psychiatric Association, not the American Medical Association.

title: Wal-Mart Net Jumps By 31.8%
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the earnings of Wal-Mart Stores Inc. misstated the 1989 net income for Sears, Roebuck & Company's merchandising group. It was $646.9 million.

title: Cox Broadcasting Post
description: Nicholas D. Trigony has been named president of the broadcasting division of Cox Enterprises Inc. of Atlanta. The 49-year-old Mr. Trigony will succeed Stanley G. Mouse, who is 68, when he retires on Wednesday, Cox Enterprises said. Mr. Trigony is executive vice president for the division, which is responsible for Cox's seven television stations, five AM radio stations and seven FM outlets as well as Telerep, a national television sales representation concern. Cox Enterprises also owns newspapers, including The Atlanta Journal and Constitution, and cable television stations.

title: GTI Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Chamorro and Sandinista Rulers Begin Delicate Transition Talks
description: President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro has begun preliminary talks with the Sandinista Government on the first democratic transfer of power in Nicaraguan history.

title: Critic's Notebook;   Rock Music of Eastern Europe: So Western, So Familiar, So Old
description: My visitor was a Hungarian rock musician, in Manhattan for a short time, who had dropped by to tell me about his band. Soft-spoken, amiable and fairly fluent in English, he was Attila Grandpierre, the main ''howler'' of a group called Vagtazo Halottkemek, the Galloping Coroners.

title: Education;   Cold War Test Questions: Pretending Won't Do
description: State education officials hastily decided today to scrap outdated questions about Eastern Europe on a sixth-grade social studies test instead of asking pupils, as test administrators had planned, to pretend that the cold war was still being waged.

title: Germany's Duty to Ugly History
description: The question, of reverberating importance, was clear. The answer was not. Did the West German Chancellor consider the German border with Poland to be inviolate? All Helmut Kohl could bring himself to say was that the question would be settled definitely after German unification.

title: Note and Bond Prices Are Higher
description: An economic report that was much weaker than anticipated helped to push up prices of Treasury notes and bonds yesterday.

title: A Matter of Emphasis
description: To The Living Section:

title: Honduran President Asks Contras to Leave Soon
description: President Rafael Leonardo Callejas of Honduras insisted yesterday that the victory of the opposition in Nicaragua's election Sunday means that Nicaraguan rebels based in his country must leave as soon as possible.

title: A New Name: Greyhound Dial
description: Tired of being confused with the bus company it sold off in 1987, the Greyhound Corporation changed its name yesterday to the Greyhound Dial Corporation.

title: Northrop Guilty Plea Submitted
description: The Northrop Corporation pleaded guilty today to failing to conduct tests and to pay a $17 million fine, one of the largest penalties ever imposed on a military contractor.

title: Catholic Group Urges Sweeping Change in Church
description: A group of Roman Catholics from Chicago is seeking 100,000 signatures on an appeal for major changes in the Catholic Church. They would include the ordination of women and married people to the priesthood, widespread consultation with believers in developing church teaching about sexuality and the participation of priests and lay people in the selection of bishops.

title: Books of The Times;   For International Thrillers, Drug Trade Is a New Focus
description: The Running Target

title: Taba Journal;   A Sandy Corner of Egypt Sadly Misses Its Israelis
description: As the Israeli tour boat glides down the Red Sea and past Taba beach, the tour guide's amplified voice drifts to shore.

title: Sandinista Leaders, Facing Defeat, Didn't Argue, Carter Says
description: When Sandinista leaders discovered on Sunday evening that they were losing their country's first free and broadly contested national elections, they made no attempt to keep power or dispute the results, former President Jimmy Carter said today.

title: 50-Footers Are Returning To Revitalize Race Series
description: The Audi Southern Ocean Racing Conference, the annual yacht-racing series in Florida, stands to be revitalized this winter by the return of the prestigious 50-Foot Class.

title: U.S. and Cape Town Team Up to Train Managers
description: In an unprecedented move, an American university and a South African university are starting a joint program aimed at training black, Indian and mixed-race South Africans for business management posts in the racially divided nation.

title: C.D. Yields Remain Steady
description: Most yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were basically unchanged for the week that ended yesterday.

title: Ritter and Macchiarola Quitting Covenant House
description: The Rev. Bruce Ritter, who has been battling allegations of financial and sexual misconduct for three months, resigned last night as the head of Covenant House, which he built from two apartments in lower Manhattan into apartments in lower Manhattan into a network of 17 centers serving 25,000 youths.

title: WINE TALK
description: ITALIAN wine prices have been going up, just like French, Spanish and American wine prices. Even so, I would venture to say that there are more good Italian wines for under $20 than there are from any other country. Moreover, more than a few of the lower-priced Italian wines are better than wines priced three times as high.

title: Court Backs Right of Boards to Deny Takeover Offers
description: In a decision that will help many of the nation's biggest companies fend off hostile takeovers, a three-judge panel of the Delaware Supreme Court ruled yesterday that corporations have a right to decide their own future rather than sell to the highest bidder.

title: In Scary City, Some Insist: Say Please
description: In a city with a worldwide reputation for shoebox apartments, kamikaze bicycle messengers and menacing thugger-muggers, a band of high-powered executives says it has figured out New York's real problem: bad manners.

title: Eastern Requests Cash From Escrow
description: Eastern Airlines said that with the support of its unsecured creditors, the carrier had asked the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan on Monday to release $60 million from an escrow account. The account holds $557 million from sales of aircraft, routes and airport gates by the carrier since it filed for protection from its creditors on March 9 under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. The filing was prompted by a strike of Eastern's machinists, which still continues.

title: Drive to Help The Neediest Closes Today
description: The 78th New York Times Neediest Cases Fund drive closes today with record-breaking proceeds -$4,231,923.50, with the final accounting to be announced. The money is used to help relieve homelessness, poverty, sickness and suffering.

title: Hoare Govett Plan
description: The securities house Hoare Govett Ltd. plans to offer its employees a 51 percent stake in the company when its owner, the Security Pacific Bancorporation, cuts its holding to 49 percent starting in mid-1990, a Hoare Govett spokeswoman said.

title: New Jersey Weighs Jury Trials for Drunken Driving
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court examined today the range of penalties in the state's drunken-driving statutes to determine if they are serious enough to entitle defendants to jury trials.

title: 11th Circuit Won't Hear Bomb-Related Case
description: The judges of the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit removed themselves today from all aspects of a civil case growing out of the mail-bombing death in December of one of their colleagues, Judge Robert S. Vance.

title: New York to Add Lawyers For Surge in Youth Crimes
description: New York City plans to double its staff of lawyers assigned to prosecute juveniles because of an enormous surge in Family Court cases as well as crimes, city lawyers told a City Council hearing yesterday.

title: Tolls Gov. Florio Can Support
description: Former Gov. Thomas Kean of New Jersey did commuters no favor in December by blocking a proposed $1 toll increase on bridges and tunnels run by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. They are vital to the region's economic health and badly need maintenance, and the region's airports can no longer subsidize them.

title: Noodles for Soviets
description: The Samyang Food Company of South Korea hopes to export its ramen fast-food noodles to the Soviet Union by April, the company said today. The company plans to test the market with a shipment of $20,000 worth of noodle packages. South Korea has no formal diplomatic relations with Moscow but has been trying to improve ties recently.

title: For Skin: Skip the Vodka but Spread the Caviar
description: LEAD: FORGET toast points. Skip the minced onions. Ignore the vexing marriage issue (which is it, iced vodka or champagne?). Caviar has a new partner. Eye lids. ''Caviar stimulates skin, particularly skin around the eye, which is most likely to show stress and age,'' said Reine Cohen, a beauty consultant for Elaine Gayle Cosmetics.

title: Rewriting History in the House
description: Following his recent rebuke by the House Ethics Committee for making sexual advances to a Peace Corps worker, Representative Gus Savage, an Illinois Democrat, took to the House floor to denounce his three colleagues who had pressed the ethics charges. He said that one, Barney Frank of Massachusetts, ''has admitted keeping and prostituting a homosexual.''

title: Changes in Japanese Cabinet Set Off a Debate
description: Toshiki Kaifu was formally re-elected Prime Minister on Tuesday and was immediately plunged into disputes over the composition of his Cabinet, including the ouster of the ruling party's most prominent woman.

title: Study Weighs Race as Death Penalty Factor
description: The death penalty is more likely to be the sentence when a white is killed than when a black is killed, a Congressional report said Monday.

title: Ford of Canada reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Bank of Nova Scotia reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Canadian Occidental Pete reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $900,000, or 1 cent a share for the quarter and $14,300,000, or 22 cents a share for the year. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Conrail Buyback
description: Conrail said it had bought back 22.32 million of its shares - about one-third of its outstanding common stock - at $49 a share, or a total of more than $1 billion. Under a previously announced ''Dutch auction,'' Conrail invited each shareholder to tender shares at a price between $43 and $53. Conrail earlier announced it would repurchase the shares delivered at or below $49. The Philadelphia-based freight railroad said the exact number of shares it was buying was 22.32 million. Conrail said it began paying for the shares Monday.

title: Court Upholds Forced Treatment Of Mentally Ill by Prison Officials
description: The Suficials can treat mentally ill prisoners with antipsychotic drugs against their will without first receiving a judge's permission after a formal hearing.

title: Durables Orders Fall 10.5%
description: New orders for durable factory goods, the backbone of the nation's manufacturing economy, tumbled a record 10.5 percent in January, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Debunking The Rumors On Riney
description: ''WE are certainly not shopping the agency around,'' said Hal Riney, the San Francisco ad man who has been hailed as the David Ogilvy and Bill Bernbach of the 1980's. ''We have never, ever thought about calling people and saying, 'Would you buy us?' ''The implication is that Riney's going to retire and give up the business,'' he continued. ''That simply isn't going to happen.''

title: Police Defend Actions in Case Of Witness Killed in Queens
description: New York City police officials said yesterday that the recent killing of a potential witness in a Queens murder case did not require them to reassess procedures for protecting endangered witnesses.

title: Leaked Ulster Document Suggests Divisions in 2 Protestant Parties
description: A long-secret document outlining concessions that the two main Protestant parties in Northern Ireland are willing to make to break a political impasse in the British province was disclosed today in an Irish newspaper.

title: New No-Fat Dessert Gets a Taste Test
description: THE ice cream of 19th-century America was so rich in butterfat that it was considered too sinful to eat on the Lord's day, especially if doused with sauce or syrup. According to the Ice Screamers, an association of ice cream historians in Philadelphia, an enterprising soda jerk coined the term ''sundae'' as a code word, to save would-be sinners the embarrassment of actually articulating their desire for the forbidden treat.

title: Harken Withdraws Offer for Tesoro
description: The Harken Energy Corporation withdrew its offer to acquire the Tesoro Petroleum Corporation for $11.75 a share, or about $190 million, in cash. Harken's chairman, Alan G. Quasha, said in a letter to Tesoro's chairman, Dr. Richard V. West Jr., that Harken had concluded the San Antonio-based oil refining and marketing company's board was not interested in maximizing shareholder value.

title: Orchestra of Nice Cancels
description: The Nice Philharmonic Orchestra has canceled its 1990 North American tour because a French Government subsidy needed to cover costs was eliminated. The tour was to have included a concert at Carnegie Hall on Sunday, March 25. The Carnegie Hall Subscription Office will mail refunds to subscribers. Information: 247-7800.

title: Rust Succeeds Berry As Coach of Patriots
description: Rod Rust, who spent 14 seasons as a National Football League assistant, became the second oldest head coach in the league yesterday, taking over the New England Patriots a day after the team dismissed Raymond Berry.

title: GORBACHEV FORCES BILL ON PRESIDENCY PAST LEGISLATURE
description: Under fierce prodding from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Supreme Soviet gave initial approval today to his proposal to secure greater executive powers through the institution of a popularly elected presidency.

title: BOEING WINS PLEA ON SEVERENCE PAY
description: Unanimously rejecting the Justice Department's interpretation of a Federal ethics law, the Supreme Court ruled today that Congress has not barred private employers from giving lump-sum severance payments to employees about to enter Government sevece.

title: The Pop Life
description: New-Style Cole Porter

title: Chronicle
description: ARLENE MARK and REUBEN MARK were presented with public service awards from Big Brothers/Big Sisters of New York City on Monday night at the Waldorf-Astoria. She is a school psychologist. He is the chairman and chief executive of Colgate-Palmolive.

title: Once Again, Oklahoma Trounces a Top-Ranked Team
description: It's not clear what Kansas did to make Oklahoma angry, or what the Jayhawks took that belonged to the Sooners, but Oklahoma pounded the top-ranked Jayhawks tonight as if they had stolen something in administering a lopsided defeat.

title: Monday Night;   Rangers' Onslaught Quiets Bruins
description: Embarrassed, Mike Milbury was nonetheless not inclined to be apologetic. Milbury, his Bruins having given up 40 shots in a 6-1 loss to the Rangers, figured he would at least attempt to get in the last, ultimately meaningless shot of the night.

title: E-L Financial reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $31,832,000, or $8.29 a share which included investment gains of $7,119,000, profit on the sale of securities of $5,121,000, non-recurring dividend income of $18,243,000 and tax credits of $1,349,000. c-Included an extraordinary credit of $25,762,000, or $6.71 a share which included investment gains of $7,299,000, profit on the sale of securities of $6,063,000 and tax credits of $12,400,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Manila Seizes Ex-Defense Chief, Citing Tie to Coup
description: Senator Juan Ponce Enrile, the former Defense Minister who helped install President Corazon C. Aquino in the 1986 election and revolt that toppled the Marcos dictatorship, was arrested today in connection with a coup attempt that nearly overthrew the Aquino Government in early December.

title: Mount Vernon Man Charged in Fatal Fire
description: A Mount Vernon man has been charged with murder and arson in the weekend fire that killed a man here and left 20 people homeless, the police said today. The arson, they said, apparently was prompted by an argument involving a woman, a former companion.

title: Kellwood Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a pre-tax gain of $6.4 million on sale of an industrial building for quarter and 9 months.

title: Will Mighty Casey Ever Bat?
description: The outlook isn't brilliant for the Mudville lads this day;

title: Warsaw Fights for Role In German Unity Talks
description: Increasingly worried that Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany has not renounced all claims to Polish territory, Poland is making a concerted diplomatic drive for a place at any international talks on German unification.

title: No Old-Timers Voted Into the Hall of Fame
description: For the second time in three years, the veterans committee has failed to add any old-timers to the Baseball Hall of Fame, shutting out for at least one more year such former players as Phil Rizzuto, Nellie Fox and Richie Ashburn.

title: Levi Strauss Associates Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
description: The company attributed the increased earnings to the sale of a minority interest in the company's Japanese subsidiary and a lower effective tax rate. It said the pre-tax gain on the sale of the Japanese subsidiary's stock amounted to $71.8 million. Levi Strauss is the privately held parent company of Levi Strauss & Co.

title: France Is to Pay 80% of Cost of Abortion Pill
description: The French Government announced today that it would subsidize the cost of using a pill that induces abortion, known as RU 486, after 34,000 abortions were carried out free of charge with the method in the last 21 months.

title: His Evasions on Poland's Border Are Seen As an Attempt to Avoid Alienating Voters
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's reluctance to give Poland solid assurances that a united Germany will respect its borders derives to some degree from the ambiguity of postwar agreements and to a far greater degree from the arithmetic of West German politics.

title: OLD ALLIES GREET MANDELA IN ZAMBIA
description: Nelson Mandela, on his first trip out of South Africa since his release two weeks ago from 27 years in prison, arrived here today to an arms-open-wide welcome from exuberant crowds who saluted him as a statesman, a hero and a much-loved brother who had been painfully missed.

title: New York Area Tour Shows Panel Havoc of AIDS
description: Members of a Federal AIDS commission who toured New York City and northern New Jersey said yesterday that they had found the severity of the epidemic worse than they had feared.

title: Japan Is Target Of Ford Chief
description: Donald E. Petersen, who is retiring this week as chairman of the Ford Motor Company, today had some uncharacteristically harsh words for Japan in a breakfast meeting with reporters.

title: A Coal Furnace Delivers Cleaner Heat
description: A clean, efficient and low-maintenance home heating system of the future may run on coal.

title: Drexel Offers Plan to Court
description: In his first public comments since the collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert, Frederick H. Joseph, the firm's chief executive, said yesterday that there was ''nothing that we could have done differently.''

title: Senators Complain to Bush Over Kohl's Border Policy
description: Several leading Democratic Senators complained to President Bush today that Chancellor Helmut Kohl's refusal to unequivocally foreswear any German claims to Polish territory was unacceptable.

title: Lufthansa Looks To East Germany
description: Lufthansa, the West German airline, said it was in talks to buy a small stake in Interflug, East Germany's state carrier. Deutsche Lufthansa A.G. also said it was holding talks about a cooperative effort to modernize the East German airline's fleet.

title: To Our Readers
description: Because of a malfunction in The Times's newsroom computers, a number of articles may be missing from this edition, or incomplete. Printing of some copies was also delayed.

title: About Education
description: Advocates of children's television are poised to open an offensive in Congress next month against the network deregulation put in place by President Reagan. They hope to reverse a trend - the shrinking time given to children's programs and the growing time given to commercials beamed at children. After a decade of defeat, they are optimistic about their chances of victory.

title: South Carolina Sets Debt Issue
description: South Carolina, one of only five states whose general obligation bonds still retain a triple-A rating by both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation, yesterday priced $125 million of general-obligation debt through competitive bidding.

title: G.M. College Donations
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it would donate about $35 million to colleges and universities in 1990. Eighty percent of G.M.'s donations support science and engineering activities, while the rest goes to various business education programs, the company said. G.M. has donated roughly the same amount to universities for each of the last five years, according to the company. In addition, G.M. will spend about $3 million this year for research and development projects at 35 colleges and universities, a G.M. spokeswoman said.

title: Disease Control Center Says AIDS Shouldn't Bar U.S. Entry
description: The Centers for Disease Control has recommended that AIDS and all other contagious diseases except tuberculosis be removed from a list of illnesses that is used to bar people from entering the United States, Federal officials said.

title: San Francisco Shows Better Way on Fares
description: To the Editor:

title: Grateful Havel Honors Soviet Foes of Invasion
description: In a display of care for the embattled tradition of dissent in the Soviet Union, President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia met today with the few Soviet citizens who criticized the Kremlin's invasion of Czechoslovakia 22 years ago and suffered beatings and exile as a result.

title: Victory Over TB Seen as Thwarted by Budget Unit
description: Tuberculosis can be eliminated from the United States relatively cheaply and quickly, but the White House budget office has failed to ask for the small sum necessary, Federal health officials say.

title: Looking to '92
description: At the National Governors' Association dinner here on Monday, the Rev. Jesse Jackson worked the crowd and chatted with other guests about his decision not to run for mayor of Washington. He talked about concentrating on winning statehood for the District of Columbia and improving the moral tenor of the scarred capital.
